column2: Revenues Beat Estimates in Q1;4/28/2017;"The Goodyear Tire & Rubber CompanyGTreported 2.8% increase in adjusted earnings per share to 74 cents in first-quarter 2017 from 72 cents recorded a year ago. Moreover

column4: the company reported net income of $166 million or 65 cents per share in first-quarter 2017. In the year-ago quarter
column5: it recorded net income of $184 million or 68 cents per share.Revenues in the reported quarter inched up 0.2% year over year to $3.7 billion. Sales narrowly passed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $3.69 billion. This is primarily due to the improvement in price and mix as well as higher pricing of third-party chemical sales partially offset by lower tire unit volume.Tire unit volumes were 40 million
column6: down 4% from 2016. Replacement tire shipments dropped 2% while original equipment unit volume declined by 8% year over year due to lower U.S. auto production.Segment operating income dropped to $385 million in the reported quarter from $419 million a year ago. The decrease in segment operating income was due to the impact of lower volume and unabsorbed overhead

column9: here are   three areas for investors to watch.Model 3 newsOne of the hottest topics going into Tesla's first-quarter   earnings release is undoubtedly anything management says about   Model 3. With the comapny planning to launch the vehicle in July
column10: investors should look to see if management provides updates on   what to expect from the vehicle itself
column11: as well as from Tesla's   production plans for the vehicle.The Model 3 is critical to Tesla's plans to grow its business.   Management expects the Model 3's lower price compared to its   current vehicles to help Tesla increase its annualized production   from a rate of about 100
column12: 000 units today to 500
column13: 000 units next   year. Further

column16: 000 vehicles per week at some point in   2018.""Capital expendituresOf course

column18: as well as any guidance management   provides for the rest of the year.Thanks to the capital-intensive nature of building vehicles
column19: management said in its fourth-quarter shareholder letter that it   expected capital expenditures to skyrocket during the first half   of 2017. Management forecasted capital expenditures of $2 billion   to $2.5 billion during this period
column20: a big jump from Tesla's $1.3   billion in capital expenditures during the entire year of   2016.DemandAnother interesting area to watch will be any commentary on   demand for Tesla's vehicles.While Model X deliveries are still rising sharply each   quarter

column22: while deliveries for Model X have   continued to grow each quarter

column1: Tesla's Grohmann Acquisition Has Been a Mess;4/27/2017;"Electric-car makerTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) announced in November that it was acquiring   Grohmann Engineering
column2: a German company that specializes in   developing automated manufacturing with a heavy emphasis on the   automotive sector (Tesla was previously a Grohmann customer).   That was only Tesla's third acquisition ever
column3: preceded by Riviera   Tool in 2015 and SolarCity
column4: which was announced in June 2016 and   closed just days after the Grohmann announcement.At the time
column5: Tesla saidGrohmann Engineering would become Tesla Grohmann Automation and   that founder and CEO Klaus Grohmann would remain at the helm. The   deal would ""bring Mr. Grohmann's leadership
column6: a world-class team   and unique expertise in-house."" The goal was to ""yield   exponential improvements in the speed and quality of production
column7: while substantially reducing the capital expenditures required   per vehicle.""No financial terms were disclosed at the time
column8: but Tesla's10-Kthat was filed in March revealed that Tesla paid $150 million in   cash for Grohmann.makeArticleAd();Tesla factory in Fremont. Image source: Tesla.Why Grohmann really leftEarlier this month
column9: local media outlets reported (viaElectrek) that Tesla was moving to end Grohmann's existing relationships   with other companies
column10: including Tesla's German automotive rivals
column11: in order to focus on the Model 3 production ramp. That created   tension within the local workforce
column12: who worried that the move   would threaten job security; having a diverse set of clients made   sure there was plenty of work to go around. Local workers are now   interested in organizing with IG Metall
column13: mirroring rising unrest   among workers stateside at the Fremont factory that want to   organize with the UAW.CEO Elon Musk has attempted to appease workers in Germany with   modest pay raises and equity compensation
column14: arguing that Tesla   could one day potentially becomea $500 billion company
column15: in which case that equity compensation could one day become   extremely valuable. Even if there are other ways beyond   unionization to address workers' concerns
column16: Tesla's response in   Fremont has been less than diplomatic -- at best
column17: dismissive
column18: and   at worst
column19: antagonistic.It had been previously reported that contrary to Tesla's   initial announcement
column20: CEO Klaus Grohmann had decided to retire.   We might now know why.Reutersis reporting that Grohmann was ""ousted last month"" after clashing   with Musk over the decision to ditch existing clients. Grohmann   told Reuters
column21: ""I definitely did not depart because I had lost   interest in working
column22: but couldn't say much else due to   confidentiality agreements. That doesn't quite fit the retirement   narrative that Tesla previously offered regarding Grohmann's   departure.It's been less than six months since the deal was announced
column23: and less than four since it closed
column24: but Tesla's Grohmann   acquisition is already turning out to be quite a mess.A potential risk factor?Integrating acquisitions is a difficult task in any M&A   deal
column25: but that process is more challenging when acquiring a   company halfway across the world
column26: since the acquirer must factor   in cultural differences along with other aspects of integration.   Musk's reputation of being a difficult leader also precedes him
column27: andBloombergrecently tallied up a handful of high-level departures. From an   employee morale perspective
column28: feeling insecure about your job   while seeing your former leader leave immediately after selling   the company can't be good.The most important aspect of the Grohmann situation is whether   or not it represents a risk factor for the Model 3 ramp.   Launching its mainstream electric car is by far the most   important thing for Tesla right now
column29: particularly with the stock   hitting all-time highs in part due to investor optimism around   the Model 3. Reuters' sources say the timeline is still on track
column30: and Tesla has previously said that it doesn't ""anticipate any   impact on the Model 3 timeline.""The Grohmann situation continues to evolve
column31: and Tesla is still   hoping to commence Model 3 production in July. It's crunch time
column32: and Tesla needs to make peace with its workers.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column33: it can pay to listen. After all
column34: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column35: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column36: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3

column28: and replacement technologies tend to gain market acceptance faster than new off-the-block tech.Digital cameras took about 15 years to almost completely replace film while DVDs condemned VHS to oblivion in less than a decade.TSLA Stock Is Ahead of the CurveWhichever way you slice it

column1: Why Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) Could Be Entering an Endless Pit;4/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsExxon Mobil Corporation's(NYSE:XOM)biggest assets are the billions of barrels of oil it has in the ground
column3: waiting to be extracted. That's what has had many XOM stock holders interested in the company for so many years. Of course
column4: not all oil reserves are equal; oil in Saudi Arabia costs very little to pump
column5: while extracting oil from shale and oil sands only makes sense when oil prices are relatively high.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockU.S. Securities and Exchange Commission rules state that Exxon can only put the oil and gas reserves
column6: which it canprofitablyrecover on its balance sheet.Whenever prices fall
column7: XOM will have to write off oil reserves that it can no longer extract at a profit
column8: even though it still owns the oil and could extract it if prices rose. The company must leave it in the ground
column9: and the oil becomes a ""stranded asset"".This isn't a new concern; the Secretary-General of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) highlighted the risk of stranded assets in the oil industry in2013
column10: and Mark Carney
column11: governor of the Bank of England
column12: did so in2015.And XOM stock suffered the consequences in February. Low oil prices made extraction of oil from Exxon's Canadian oil sands projects unprofitable. Under SEC pressure
column13: the companywrote down its reservesby 14% - it had spent$20 billiondeveloping these reserves
column14: money that may be down the drain now.Could this happen to Exxon stock again? And if so

column16: further downward pressure on global oil prices could lead to more write-offs. But even if oil prices do not fall much lower
column17: XOM's fossil fuel reserves face the threat of regulatory action against climate change
column18: making it more difficult for it to produce oil.Let's examine these two threats to Exxon stock.Two Threats to XOM StockIf renewable energy and electric cars replace fossil fuels
column19: oil may end up being left in the ground
column20: harming oil companies like Exxon.I discussedTesla Inc's(NASDAQ:TSLA)  three-pronged attack on the fossil fuel economy inFebruary.Tesla is doing several things that threaten XOM stock. It's developing electric cars that use rechargeable batteries instead of burning gasoline. With its ""gigafactories""
column21: Tesla is lowering the costs of batteries
column22: which could incentivize people to install more solar panels and wind turbines
column23: which need a place to store excess power. And Tesla plans to install ""solar roofs"" in the fourth quarter this year.Fitch Ratings sounded the alarms in October 2016
column24: warning of the threat electric cars posed to oil companies. Fitch warned of a ""death spiral"" as investors sell both debt and stocks from oil companies
column25: resulting in a higher cost of capital for the industry.Are electric cars a threat to oil companies and stocks like XOM stock? Cuneyt Kazokoglu
column26: the head of oil demand at FGE
column27: an energy consultancy
column28: doesn't think so.First
column29: electric cars depend heavily on government subsidies and incentives. When these are withdrawn
column30: demand for electric cars collapses. Second
column31: battery technology may be improving
column32: but it has a long way to go before it even comes close to oil in terms of energy density.Third
column33: while the production of electric vehicles is increasing
column34: they still make up a small share of new car sales. Fourth
column35: even if concern over ""peak oil demand"" or ""peak car"" in the West proves justified
column36: the demand for vehicles is projected to grow rapidly in Asia
column37: and many of these will probably run on oil.The second risk will materialize and threaten oil companies like Exxon
column38: even if energy prices start rising. If concern over climate change continues
column39: governments might take further action to limit carbon dioxide emissions. This would mean that only a fraction of oil reserves could be pumped.Researchersestimateda carbon budget at 565 gigatons of carbon dioxide to 2050
column40: while known fossil fuel reserves make up 2
column41: 795 gigatons
column42: making 80% of these ""unburnable"".Oil companies like XOM could get around this by storing the carbon dioxide (a process known as carbon capture and sequestration)
column43: but progress remains slow .Institutional investors are concerned about oil companies. Last month
column44: Blackrock
column45: an asset manager with trillions of dollars under management
column46: threatened to vote directors who ignored these risks off the boards of companies that BlackRock owns shares in.Some doubt that governments will take action to limit global carbon dioxide emissions
column47: since developing countries like China and India need cheap sources of energy
column48: and renewable energy still has a long way to go before it can meet these needs. And now President Trump isrolling back emissionscuts.But Trump's position on climate change may be unique among world leaders
column49: as theSierra Club
column50: an environmental group
column51: claimed. And Trump is very unpredictable; talk of acarbon taxrecently surfaced
column52: although the White House later denied it.BP plc (ADR)(NYSE:BP) warned in January that if oil companies think fossil fuels will be phased out
column53: either because of new sources of energy or because of government regulations
column54: they will pump as much as they can
column55: causing a collapse in oil prices.Starbucks Corporation (SBUX) Should Dip After Earnings
column56: And That's OKThis could trigger a ""race to the bottom"" in oil prices
column57: they'd have the incentive toget out as muchas they could profitably extract. This is bad news for oil companies heavily invested in expensive oil projects that require a high price of oil to break even
column58: such asoil sands and Arctic oil. Most of the oil wells where oil can be extracted at a very low cost are in theMiddle East.Bottom Line on XOM StockWhat does this all mean for oil companies like Exxon? How serious are these concerns?Some dismiss concerns of a ""carbon bubble""

column1: This Auto Stock Doubled While You Were Watching Tesla;4/27/2017;"Shares of Silicon Valley car and energy innovatorTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) have been on quite a run. Thanks to excitement   around the company's upcoming Model 3 sedan
column2: Tesla's shares have   risen about 75% over the past year.Tesla gets a lot of attention from investors
column3: and rightly so.   But somewhat under the radar
column4: there's another auto stock that's   also been on a tear over the past year or so
column5: and it isn't   exactly a futuristic green company:Ferrari N.V.(NYSE: RACE) .Strong sales of Ferraris V12 models
column6: including the     GTC4Lusso
column7: helped power better-than-expected profit growth last     year. Image source: Ferrari N.V.makeArticleAd();It took investors a while to catch on to Ferrari -- and vice   versaIt's no surprise that many investors have overlooked Ferrari
column8: given that its history as a public company is quite short.Fiat Chrysler Automobiles(NYSE: FCAU) owned 90% of Ferrari and controlled the supercar   maker for decades -- but that changed in October 2015
column9: when FCA   began selling its stake through an initial public offering.Ferrari went public at $52 a share amid excitement around its   exceptionally strong brand. But that excitement faded quickly
column10: as   investors became concerned that the company hadno easy path to growth. Conservative 2016 guidance led to a sell-off that drove prices   down to a low of $32.00 on Feb. 11
column11: 2016. But since then
column12: Ferrari's shares have been on quite a run
column13: outpacing even Tesla's   over that period:RACEand TSLA data byYCharts. The chart shows the percentage growth of each stock from Feb.   11
column15: through April 25
column16: 2017.What changed? More than anything else
column17: what changed was the   story: Investors have caught on to how Ferrari plans to generate   bottom-line growth over the next few years -- and Ferrari has   caught on to how to tell its story to investors.Ferrari needed to show investors how its profits would   growWhat discouraged early Ferrari investors was a simple reality:   Ferrari has long limited its annual sales to preserve the   exclusivity of its brand. Investors began thatFerrari sell-off in February of last year
column18: after the company's2016 forecastanticipated a tiny 3.3% year-over-year increase in shipments
column19: to   just 7
column20: 900 vehicles. With little growth in the forecast
column21: investors lost interest. (That's why investors love Tesla
column22: with   its seemingly limitless growth potential.)Ferrari was still new to this public-company thing
column23: but   management quickly caught on. CEO Sergio Marchionne pointed out   that limited runs of super-high-priced Ferrari models (think   seven figures) could boost profits without boosting overall sales   numbers to the point of damaging the brand. And
column24: he hinted
column25: Ferrari could probably gradually boost its annual sales limit by   a few thousand cars a year without doing damage to the brand.As the year went on
column26: investors saw those themes begin to play   out. In the third quarter of 2016
column27: Ferrari'snet income rose 20%on a tiny 1.5% increase in shipments
column28: thanks in large part to the   limited-run (just 200) $2.1 million LaFerrari Aperta model.The seven-figure LaFerrari hypercar sold in tiny numbers but     generated huge profits. Ferrari plans similar limited-edition     models in the future. Image source: Ferrari N.V.Ferrari's full-year 2016 results drove the stock higher still.   Ferrari's net income doubled in the fourth quarter
column29: driving a 38%   increase to 290 million euros for the full year
column30: on just a 5%   increase in vehicles sold. Itsguidance for 2017called for more profit growth: Ferrari expects adjusted EBITDA of   more than 950 million euros in 2017
column31: up from 748 million euros in   2016
column32: on sales of about 8
column33: 400 Ferraris.Marchionne thinks Ferrari can nudge that annual sales number   up to about 10
column34: 000 over the next few years
column35: without significant   impact on its pricing -- or
column36: put another way
column37: while keeping   supply below the level of demand.Isn't Ferrari's stock expensive now?We've seen that Ferrari has a plan to generate significant   profit growth over the next several years
column38: as long as demand from   the world's wealthy sports-car fans remains strong. But does that   make its stock a buy now?At first glance
column39: Ferrari's stock is far from cheap unless   you're comparing it with Tesla. It's trading at a little over 33   times its 2016 earnings. That's ahugevaluation for an automaker. But that's not the whole story.Remember that Ferrari's forecast calls for substantial profit   growth this year. Looked at through that lens
column40: Ferrari's shares   are trading at 27 times its expected 2017 earnings. That's still   very high for an automaker -- but Marchionne has argued that   traditional big automakers are the wrong comparison for   Ferrari.Ferrari isn't just an automaker. Its Formula One racing     team
column41: Scuderia Ferrari
column42: is a sports brand with a huge global     following. Three races into this year's season
column43: Ferrari driver     Sebastian Vettel has won twice
column44: to the delight of Ferrari's     legions of fans. Image source: Ferrari N.V.Remember also that Ferrari isn'tjustan automaker; it's also a luxury brand. On top of that
column45: its   Formula One racing team is one of the world's most widely   followed sports teams. Taken together
column46: there's an argument that   Ferrari deserves a valuation more in line with established luxury   brands -- despite the high fixed costs of its core automaking   business.What would that look like? Well
column47: French luxury giantLVMH Moet Hennessycurrently trades at around 28 times its 2016 earnings
column48: whileTiffany & Companytrades at just over 26 times last year's result.Long story short: If we accept the argument that it should be   valued as a luxury brand
column49: Ferrari's current valuation is in the   right range.So is Ferrari stock a buy?I think Ferrari might be a buy for an investor looking for an   intriguing growth story that isn't an all-or-nothing bet. (I   don't own it myself
column50: but I might soon.) Ferrari will never have   the upside of a moonshot stock like Tesla. But on the other hand
column51: as a solidly profitable company with a top-drawer brand
column52: it   doesn't have nearly the risk of Tesla: Even if its growth falls   short of our expectations
column53: Ferrari will still be a very valuable   company.What about auto cycles? With the big automakers
column54: we worry   about slipping consumer demand now that the new-car cycle is   likely to be past its peak. But in Ferrari's stratospheric market   segment
column55: that's less of a concern. Unless there's a severe global   recession
column56: Ferrari is likely to be able to meet its sales goals   with strong pricing -- meaning that the profit growth we   anticipate is likely to materialize. And that profit growth   should outpace the growth of the overall market.Ferrari's valuation suggests that the expected growth for 2017   is largely priced in. An investor who buys Ferrari today might   need to be a bit patient. But Ferrari's profit-growth plan could   make for a fun and profitable ride over the next few years.10 stocks we like better than FerrariWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column57: it can pay to listen. After all
column58: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column59: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column60: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Ferrari wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3
column61: 2017John Rosevearhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Tesla. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: A Fund That Bought Tesla for Less Than $30 a Share;4/25/2017;"Primecap Management Company is an under-the-radar adviser that doesn't talk to the media. But it did something no other tracked fund did: it bought Tesla for less than $30 a share in 2011 and hung on to it through the stock's explosion this year. That's an estimated gain of 469%.Primecap advises the Odyssey Funds
column2: which consist of a stock fund
column3: growth fund and aggressive growth fund. Its investment profile reads like that of most typical value advisers
column4: looking to uncover undervalued stocks whose fundamentals will develop beyond Wall Street's expectations. With a long-term approach
column5: the managers identify changes in a company that could increase value in three-to-five years
column6: such as new products or management
column7: and then wait.Jack Bogle
column8: founder of $2.3 trillion firm Vanguard Asset Management

column10: 000 initial capital. Little information about Primecap's portfolio managers exists

column12: a Primecap founder

column30: 000 shares originally to 2

column1: Why Does Everyone Keep Calling Tesla a "Car Company"?;4/25/2017;"In this segment fromMarket Foolery

column3: Million Dollar Portfolio's Matt Argersinger
column4: andSupernovaandRule Breakers' Aaron Bush dip into the Fool mailbag and find a listener     confused about whyTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) is so often reduced in people's minds to merely     an automaker
column5: given its solar-power and battery-making bona     fides. And he's curious how the Fools would define it.A full transcript follows the video.makeArticleAd();10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip

column7: the newsletter they       have run for over a decade
column8: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column9: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of       them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even       better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3
column10: 2017This video was recorded on April 19
column11: 2017.Mac Greer:From Brian Bosak
column12: who writes: ""I keep seeing     headlines like this one: 'Tesla Just Passed GM to Become     America's Most Valuable Carmaker.'"" Brian goes on to write
column13: ""What I don't fully understand is why intelligent     people keep calling Tesla a carmaker when they do so much more     than that. They could be a battery producer
column14: technology     company
column15: energy company. Yet they keep getting     compared
column16: unfairly
column17: in my opinion
column18: toFordand [General Motors] when it comes to market cap. It feels a bit like callingApplea phone company and comparing them toMotorolainstead ofMicrosoftor Google. If you had to call Tesla a 'blank' company
column19: what     would you call them
column20: and to whom would you compare them?""Aaron Bush:I would say Tesla is a vertically integrating     energy-conscious car company. It's a car company
column21: OK? [laughs]Matt Argersinger:With several big adjectives in front of it.Bush:It's a car company. Yeah
column22: I think
column23: at the end of the     day
column24: it really is a car company. We were talking before
column25: Apple     is a phone company. I do think you have to look at what it     is that they're selling
column26: and it is cars. That said
column27: I do     think there's a danger in comparing here. I personally     don't want to compare Tesla to anyone
column28: literally anyone. My     thinking here stems around the fact that there are two types of     evolution. There's gradualism and there's punctuated     equilibrium. Those are fancy terms
column29: but the latter category
column30: which
column31: you could say
column32: in business-speak
column33: those are     the companies that create a new industry
column34: or radically change     an existing industry. They should not be compared to     the incumbents
column35: because the market is     forward-thinking and because they are changing the rules     of the game and will look different at some point in the     future. And investors who try comparing what's new with what's     old
column36: which is a classic innovator's dilemma
column37: are going to miss     out on the underlying story there.Greer:Punctuated equilibrium.Bush:There you go
column38: science lesson for the day.Greer:It sounds like a medical condition.Argersinger:I think Aaron nailed it on the head. I just think
column39: for     now
column40: if Tesla is going to be generating 90% of its     revenue
column41: roughly
column42: from cars
column43: and SolarCity is     getting integrated this year
column44: it's still going to be 90%     revenue from cars. Apple
column45: some 70% revenue from phones. That's     the prime product. Now
column46: that can change over time. Amazon
column47: I don't think it's fair to call Amazon a retail company     anymore. You could have called them an online retail     company five years ago
column48: but now
column49: because of the diversity of     the business
column50: you can call Amazon something different. But for     now
column51: where is the revenue coming from? Where is the beef     made?Greer:OK. Sorry
column52: Brian
column53: it sounds like
column54: for now
column55: still a car     company.Bush:Tesla is Tesla.Suzanne Frey

column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsChina is a tough nut to crack for U.S. technology companies. Due to strict content restrictions
column4: companies likeFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB)

column1: General Electric Company (GE) Stock Has Lost Investors Trust;4/25/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsInvestors inGeneral Electric Company(NYSE:GE) were surprised - and unhappy - that GE stock didn't gain after the company's first quarter earnings report last Friday.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)After all
column3: earnings came in well ahead of consensus
column4: and organic revenue grew 7%. GE reaffirmed full-year targets for cash flow and earnings
column5: meaning guidance was solid. And yet General Electric stock sold off
column6: declining 2.3% and nearing a post-election low.The problem
column7: asBarron'spointed out
column8: is that General Electric
column9: and GE stock
column10: both have acredibility problem. Cash flow numbers came in well below expectations
column11: leading to a sense that General Electric's earnings are being managed somewhat. And with the company's shares back near levels seen in 1998 - and still some 40% off early 2000's highs - investors just don't have much patience left.There's good reason for that sentiment. GE continues to zig when it should zag. It ramped up finance exposure ahead of the 2008 financial crisis. It entered oil and gas ahead of the bust there; it's still waiting for approval of its merger withBaker Hughes Incorporated(NYSE:BHI). Investors simply don't trust General Electric.That needs to change - but it will take some time
column12: if it happens at all.Cash Flow
column13: Not EarningsThe headline concern coming out of General Electric earnings was the company's operating cash flow figure. GE burned $1.6 billion in the quarter - a full billion more than it had projected. CFO Jeffrey Bornstein said on the Q1 conference call that $400 million of the gap came from receivables
column14: including a few large accounts in aviation and some past-due collections in the Middle East.7 Blue-Chip Stocks Every Investor Should OwnBut it's a sign of trust (or lack thereof) in General Electric that investor concerns weren't assuaged by his answer. JPMorgan analystStephen Tusa
column15: as quoted byBarron's
column16: pointed out that cash flow and earnings have diverged for some time
column17: driven by beneficial contract adjustments.That's a long-term problem for General Electric stock
column18: since much of its attractiveness is coming from shareholder returns.GE pays a 3.2% dividend
column19: for instance
column20: and the company has aggressively repurchased shares. Those buybacks are driving much of the company's EPS growth
column21: both at the moment and going forward. But if cash flow continues to lag earnings
column22: those repurchases will either slow down or be financed with increasing debt.Either outcome hurts GE's potential earnings growth and the company itself doesn't appear strong enough to drive that growth on its own.Net Income
column23: Not EPSFirst-quarter earnings growth looked strong
column24: with non-GAAP EPS increasing 12%. But those stock repurchases meant the company's outstanding share count declined 6%. In other words
column25: over half of that seemingly impressive EPS growth came simply from having fewer shares.In 2016
column26: industrial operating and verticals EPS (another non-GAAP figure which excludes fluctuations from GE Capital) rose 14%; net income on the same basis grew just 4%
column27: and adjusted operating margin in the key industrial segment actually compressed.Expectations aside
column28: General Electric simply isn't showing enough profit growth. There's a reason why GE stock and sharesHoneywell International Inc.(NYSE:HON) have diverged so far in 2017 - and why HON stock has outperformed General Electric for some time now. The earnings performance simply isn't strong enough.And when cash flow concerns are laid on top of those relatively weak profit improvements
column29: it's tough to turn bullish on GE shares.Bottom Line for GE StockThere's a sense that General Electric is running out of time
column30: and investor patience. CEO Jeff Immelt clearly is in the hot seat. Indeed
column31: our own Dana Blankenhorncalled for Immelt's removaljust two weeks ago. The big moves have been made
column32: with much of GE Capital sold off
column33: the purchase of Alstom's power division done and the Baker Hughes integration on the way.The Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Hype Cycle Will End in TearsSo there's a ""what's next?"" problem for GE.There's potential cost-cutting en route
column34: but $2 billion (after taxes) isn't a huge number against GE's $260 billion market cap. Immelt has publicly set a target of $2 in EPS by 2018
column35: butonly one of 18 analyststhinks General Electric can get to the number.Investors have good reason not to trust the long-term strategy here. While GE stock has performed well out of the recession
column36: it has underperformed against Honeywell and many other major industrials. Management has re-shaped the company but it still has exposure to problematic verticals like oil and gas. It's not growing earnings that strongly and revenue growth has been choppy
column37: at best.The reaction to the Q1 report shows that General Electric needs to change the narrative toward its shares. But it's not clear the company has the ability to do so.As of this writing
column38: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best Stocks to Buy for the Next Decade7 Healthcare Stocks With A-Rated Prospects10 Dividend Stocks That Will Deliver Double-Digit Returns Every YearThe postGeneral Electric Company (GE) Stock Has Lost Investors' Trustappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column16: which not only reaffirmed its previous outperform sentiment but also set a $45 target price.FTNT FundamentalsWhen delving into the fundamentals of Fortinet
column17: a very positive image begins to emerge for value investors. From its Silicon Valley headquarters in Sunnyvale
column18: Fortinet is dedicated to providing information security products and services
column19: particularly for large enterprises and major corporations.The company has been in business since the year 2000; since then
column20: it has developed a hardware network firewall powered by a proprietary operating system and its very own system-on-a-chip processor. Fortinet has shipped more than 3 million of these firewall units and has secured more than 350 patents. In the final quarter of 2016
column21: the company reported $1.3 billion in cash.When Robert Baird analysts explained their ratings and target price on FTNT stock
column22: they noted that the company should be considered to be a major player in the information security industry along with market leaders such asPalo Alto Networks Inc(NYSE:PANW) and evenCisco Systems
column23: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO).It is easy to see why Fortinet is in a great environment for growth. Spectacular data breaches now make frequent headlines that often cause embarrassment for their victims.Case in point: the Shadow Brokers release of CIA exploits and hacks
column24: which were foreshadowed by similar Wikileaks releases. As tech giants such asMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) rushed to fix and patch their operating systems and hackers
column25: the information security community worried about the impact of the releases
column26: which are surely giving malicious hackers ideas as to how they may be able to breach networks in the future.Why Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Can Make It Back to the TopInstitutional investors such asBank of the Ozarks Inc(NASDAQ:OZRK) andPNC Financial Services Group Inc(NYSE:PNC) have been increasing their positions in FTNT stock lately
column27: and they are doing so with good reason: after all
column28: this is a profitable company that is expected to increase its growth by 22% in 2017.Tech investors who follow the information security sector should also take note that Fortinet is augmenting its sales efforts to target providers of cloud services and major data centers.With the ongoing expansion of the cloud computing paradigm and the fact that FortiGate firewalls are more affordable than the Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance
column29: FTNT seems to have a great future ahead.As of this writing

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is More Than iPhone 8;4/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAfterInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) reported a drop in profits in its quarterly results
column3: Apple stock investors may think twice aboutApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL).makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockStrong sales of iPhones are hardly assured. Even though valuations between the two companies are similar on a forward price-earnings basis (12 for IBM and 13.8 for Apple)
column4: Apple will probably please the market when it reports results next month.Investors should also ignore rumors about the iPhone 8. Sales for the existing models are only starting to ramp up now.iPhone 8 Versus Samsung Galaxy S8Apple's impending release of an iPhone 8 would mark the tenth-anniversary for the device. Yet the company just released the iPhone 7 in September 2016. Refreshing the model just after a year may not make much sense. Apple stock isn't under significant pressure by competition fromSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) or any other Android device maker.7 Blue-Chip Stocks Every Investor Should OwnStill
column5: consumers may overlook the expensive initial price ofnearly $800 for the Galaxy S8. Samsung is releasing the latest phone on April 21. Fans may like the Galaxy S8's biometric scanners
column6: which include iris and fingerprint scanning. Those are some of the ways the phone may get unlocked.Samsung will introduce an assistant named Bixby
column7: but this feature could underwhelm its users. Chances are high that the AI software will be buggy and will need fixing. That is typical for any technology product that is in its first generation.By comparison
column8: Apple introduced Siri on the iPhone 4S
column9: way back in October 2011. Bixby is competing against six years of iterations on Siri.Expectations for Second QuarterAnalysts expect Apple will report revenue inthe range of $51.7 billion to $54.6 billion. That translates to earnings of between $1.91 to $2.14 per share. If Apple meets those expectations
column10: that would imply revenue growing in the single digits
column11: at around 5%. The company will likely report that its cash balance grew again. Apple stock ended its last quarter with $230 billion in offshore cash.The massive cash balance will only fuel rumors of the company making a big acquisition. Apple stock is strategically better positioned if it waits for the government to allow for repatriating the cash at a lower tax rate. The company may invest the proceeds in the business or make smaller
column12: local acquisitions. Historically
column13: Apple does not buy companies in the $100 billion range. Its biggest acquisition to date was Beats Electronics for $3 billion in August 2014.Diversifying Business Through Autonomous DrivingApple's management may give more details on its ambitions in building self-driving car technology. On April 14
column14: the company received a permit thatallows it to test auto-driving carsin California.Tesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) need not worry about Apple as a competitor. Apple is working only on the software part of ADAS (Advanced Driver Assistance Systems).Tesla develops both the all-electric hardware and the software. Still
column15: staying away from the hardware aspect of automotive development should keep profit margins high for Apple. Car manufacturing is inherently a low-profit business. Similar toMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) selling Windows software and not low-commodity PCs
column16: Apple will sell the software that self-driving cars will use.Apple is very deliberate on the products it produces. The company is in no rush to release the next iPhone 8
column17: but it is keen on diversifying its business outside of smartphones. Apple's progress in developing autonomous driving software ultimately makes the company a solid investment for long-time shareholders.As of this writing
column18: Chris Lau did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Home Improvement Stocks to Buy for Unstoppable Gains3 South Korean Stocks That Are Feeling the Heat3 Downtrodden Stocks That You Need to Short NowThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is More Than iPhone 8appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Rite Aid Corporation (RAD) Stock Investors Are Begging For ANY Good News;4/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt has been a tough couple of months forRite Aid Corporation(NYSE:RAD) stock. Rite Aid stock traded near $9 as recently as mid-January. Investors then were betting that a Donald Trump Administration Federal Trade Commission would approve the company's acquisition byWalgreens Boots Alliance Inc(NASDAQ:WBA). With WBA offering an even $9 per share for RAD stock
column3: RAD's $8.75 highs implied overwhelmingly positive odds of an approval.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrA little over three months later
column4: the situation looks very different. Walgreens cut its offer to $6.50-$7 per share of Rite Aid stock from the original $9. Since then
column5: RAD stock has declined 57%
column6: and trades below $4.Clearly
column7: investors are far less confident in the merger's approval. That
column8: in turn
column9: has increased the focus on Rite Aid earnings and sales - a problem itself after a tough few quarters for the company.Same-store sales declined 1.8% through the first three quarters of RAD's fiscal 2017 (ending February)
column10: including a 3.4% drop in Q3. Adjusted EBITDA fell over 23% during the same period. Given Rite Aid's $7.3 billion in debt
column11: fiscal year 2017 weakness raises serious concerns about the company's prospects if the merger fails.The result has been a triple whammy for RAD stock - the buyout price has been cut
column12: the odds of that buyout are down and the value of Rite Aid stock on its own has weakened due to poor operating performance. Indeed
column13: Deutsche Bank valued a standalone RAD stockat just $2.25last month.8 Retail Stocks That Can Win Despite AmazonThat leaves shareholders desperate for some kind of good news -anygood news - in the Rite Aid earnings report on Tuesday. But investors should be skeptical that such good news will arrive quite yet.The Walgreens-Rite Aid MergerObviously
column14: the focus coming out of Rite Aid earnings will be on the conference call. Investors will be trying to ""read the tea leaves"" in management commentary relative to expectations as to whether the WBA takeover will be approved. After all
column15: even the low end of Walgreens' updated range suggests 70%-plus upside for RAD stock - should the merger go through.The problem in the short term is that the Rite Aid earnings call seems unlikely to offer much clarity. It's not as if Rite Aid management has inside information on the FTC's thought process. Meanwhile
column16: the five-person FTC board hasthree vacancies already
column17: which not only complicates approval but makes forecasting the odds of approval rather difficult. The FTC also has other pressing matters to contend with - including a possible antitrust suit againstQualcomm
column18: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM).Investors expecting game-changing news out of Rite Aid earnings seem likely to be disappointed.Bear in mind that Walgreens management repeatedly said on its Q2 call earlier this month that it expected the merger to go through. Rite Aid stock stabilized for a few sessions
column19: but then resumed its decline. No matter what Rite Aid executives say at this point
column20: it's unlikely the market will believe them.RAD Stock EarningsIf there isn't major news relative to the Walgreens-Rite Aid merger
column21: as seems likely
column22: then the catalyst will have to come from Rite Aid earnings and sales. That seems unlikely as well.Rite Aid's business simply isn't performing all that well. As noted
column23: same-store sales are down almost 2% year-to-date. In contrast
column24: Walgreens grew comparable store sales 1.8% in the first six months of its fiscal 2017.CVS Health Corp(NYSE:CVS) comps rose 1.9% in 2016. Meanwhile
column25: Fred's
column26: Inc.(NASDAQ:FRED) - who will purchase hundreds of Rite Aid stores if the WBA-RAD merger goes through - saw a 2%-plusdeclinein its fiscal 2016 (ending January of this year).It looks as if Walgreens and CVS are outperforming their smaller competitors. And with Rite Aid having a huge debt load - $7 billion
column27: against a likely ~$1 billion in Adjusted EBITDA this year - that's a huge problem if the merger doesn't go through.Bear in mind that Rite Aid stock was pretty much left for dead not all that long ago
column28: trading around $1 through the end of 2012. If the company can't get sales and earnings positive
column29: RAD stock could return to those levels.Buy Rite Aid Stock?To be honest
column30: I do think RAD stock looks somewhat tempting at current levels. Obviously
column31: RAD is a high-risk play. But assuming Rite Aid stock is worth something in the event the merger falls through
column32: the current price implies a less than 50% chance of FTC approval.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Has Nothing to Worry AboutThat does seem a bit too low. The divestitures to Fred's would create a legitimate third competitor to Walgreens and CVS. As an analyst pointed out relative to the potential merger betweenSprint Corp(NYSE:S) andT-Mobile US Inc(NASDAQ:TMUS)
column33: the rule of thumb is thatRepublicans want three competitorsin an industry
column34: and Democrats four. That in turn implies that the merger should go through under the Trump Administration  at some point.The near-term problem is that I don't believe the Rite Aid earnings report will do much for Rite Aid stock - except maybe push it down. Unless there's a surprise waiting
column35: I don't think the good news RAD stock needs so desperately is on the way. For aggressive traders

column37: however

column1: What Apple Inc. (AAPL) Self-Driving Car Technology Looks Like;4/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe rumors have been flying for several years thatApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is secretly working on autonomous driving technology. We even had the code name for the effort: Project Titan. However
column3: the cat was officially out of the bag two weeks ago when AAPL received a permit to test an autonomous car in California.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleNow
column4: thanks to official training documents obtained byBusiness Insider
column5: we know what Apple's self-driving car technology looks like.Why Apple Is Interested in Autonomous Car TechnologyThe closest Apple has ever come to releasing a product for automobiles is its CarPlay standard for integrating an iPhone into a car's entertainment system. So why the apparent fascination with futuristic auto technology like an autonomous car?The company has exploded in value and influence over the past decade because of the iPhone
column6: but it's looking for the next big hit. With the successTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) has had
column7: and the publicityAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google has reaped from it's self-driving car program
column8: Apple clearly saw an opportunity. Over88 million cars and light duty trucks were sold in 2016and the revenue for automotive suppliers alone surpassed $670 billion in 2015.Even carving out a small slice of this market would be huge for AAPL stock holders.Fitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Is Going to Burn Amid Flex 2 Explosion ReportWe started to hear about Apple's Project Titan in 2015. At first
column9: it was thought to be an electric car to compete with Tesla. Even Tesla'sElon Musk seemed convincedApple was preparing to directly take on his company. However
column10: last fall there was an apparentshake-up in Project Titan. It was believed that Apple was pivoting from developing its own electric Apple car to instead developing an autonomous car software platform it could sell to automakers.Two weeks ago
column11: Apple officially tipped its hand. The company received a permit to drive three Lexus vehicles equipped with autonomous car technology on California roads.Apple's Self-Driving Car Technology Outed by Training ManualBusiness Insidergot the scoop on what AAPL is up toby obtaining a copy of a training manual and official government documentation filed by the company.Called the Apple Automated System
column12: AAPL's self-driving car platform uses a combination of hardware and software. Apple says its system is ""capable of sending electronic commands for steering
column13: accelerating
column14: and decelerating and may carry out portions of the dynamic driving task.""The documentation describes the testing Apple drivers must undergo on a private course before being allowed to take the Lexus autonomous car onto public roads. It also includes photographs of the cockpit of the cars and even details the modifications made to the vehicles.AAPL has equipped its test cars with a steering wheel and pedals made byLogitech(NASDAQ:LOGI) -the manufacturer of video game peripherals. The human ""driver"" can instantly take over control of the self-driving car by touching the brakes or grabbing the steering wheel.Where Does the Apple Automated System Go From Here?The end game for the Apple Automated System is clearly not to power an Apple car. At least not yet. Instead
column15: AAPL will take aim at the traditional auto makers
column16: hoping to convince them to license its system in their vehicles instead of spending the time and money to develop their own in-house technology.7 Tech Stocks That Are a Sneeze Away From CollapsingEven though it's now public knowledge
column17: expect AAPL to remain tight-lipped on its autonomous car project. The Apple Lexus test vehicles will be spotted on California roads
column18: but with so much at stake -Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) recently dropped $15 billion onMobileyetodevelop its own autonomous vehicle platform- Apple is likely to keep its cards close until it's ready for the big reveal.As of this writing
column19: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceBeware of Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock in 2017Friday Apple Rumors: Apple is Selling More Refurbished MacBook ProsApple Inc. (AAPL) Won't Buy Walt Disney Co (DIS) - But It Will Do ThisThe postWhat Apple Inc. (AAPL) Self-Driving Car Technology Looks Likeappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 Driverless Car Stocks You Won't Have to Babysit;4/24/2017;"Driverless cars are still in their infancy

column3: some analysts foresee the market for partially   and fully autonomous vehicles hitting $77 billion a year.We're still years away from fully autonomous vehicles
column4: but a   handful of companies are making bigger strides toward them than   their rivals. Among those areAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google
column5: NVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) andTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) . Each is taking a different approach the   driverless car market

column9: called Waymo.Through Waymo

column11: as well trucking
column12: logistics
column13: and consumer vehicles -- which   represents
column14: essentially
column15: nearly every facet of the automotive   market.Considering its just a small subsidiary

column17: and the fact that it was spun out   shows that management is confident that the unit could bring in   revenues of its own.With more than eight years of autonomous vehicle experience   under its belt already
column18: and the $86 billion in cash Alphabet has   on hand to exploit whatever opportunities it finds
column19: this   driverless car play is the epitome of a set-it-and-forget-it   stock.TeslaTesla has made some bold claims about its driverless-car plans   in the past. CEO Elon Musk said last year that by 2018
column20: the   company's cars would be able to be summoned remotely by their   owners -- as in not driven by anyone -- from across the   country.It's looking highly unlikely that Tesla will havethatfeature live by next year
column21: but the electric automaker's vehicles   are still far ahead of its competition. New Teslas already come   equipped with fully autonomous driving hardware
column22: and ongoing   updates to the vehicles' software are slowly making more and more   self-driving features available to their owners.Investors should note that Tesla's valuation issky high right now
column23: with a price-to-sales ratio of 7.1
column24: compared to 0.29 for   competitors likeFord
column25: and a forward P/E that sits above 150.There's likely to be some volatility ahead forTesla stockfor that reason
column26: but that doesn't mean thatcurrentTesla shareholders will have to babysit their investment.   Tesla is ahead of other automakers in the semi-autonomous space
column27: and will likely continue to keep its lead for the foreseeable   future. But investors considering opening up a position in the   company should know that Tesla will likely have a hard time   growing at the rate it needs to justify its current   valuations.NVIDIAAnother solid bet on the driverless car market is graphics   processing unit (GPU) maker NVIDIA. The company has developed an   automotive AI computing platform called Drive PX 2
column28: that can   rapidly process data from cameras and give semi-autonomous   vehicles situational awareness -- allowing them to ""understand""   and properly react to what they see around them.Already about 80 automakers and Tier 1 suppliers are using or   testing Drive PX
column29: and Tesla is the latest company to partner with   NVIDIA for semi-autonomous driving systems. NVIDIA earned about   7% of its total revenue in its fiscal 2017 (which ended Jan. 29)   from its automotive segment
column30: and sales from the business grew by   37% year over year in fiscal Q4 2017.Aside from that growth and its early lead in selling   semi-autonomous vehicle supercomputers to automakers
column31: NVIDIA is   the leader in the GPU space
column32: and earns most of its money (59% in   fiscal 2017) from sales in the gaming market. This will continue   to provide NVIDIA a lot of stability -- and resources -- as it   builds out its driverless car technologies. And it's a key reason   why investors won't have to keep a close eye on the company.To be clear
column33: any investment comes with its own level of risk
column34: and investors shouldn't assume that Alphabet
column35: Tesla
column36: or NVIDIA   are now
column37: or will remain
column38: sure bets. But each company is poised to   dominate the driverless car market in their own way

column1: Should You Buy Into the Hype for These Stocks?;4/24/2017;"It's no secret that Wall Street is forward-looking. The big   question we have to ask ourselves as investors from time to time   is when is the markettooforward-looking. In other words
column2: when do the valuations of stocks   far exceed their hype?With this in mind
column3: we asked three of our Foolish contributors   to weigh in on three highly hyped stocks to decipher whether they   have what it takes to meet that hype. Find out what they had to   say aboutTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column4: Autodesk(NASDAQ: ADSK)
column5: andNorthern Dynasty Minerals(NYSEMKT: NAK) .Tesla could soon turn profitable -- and that could be a     problemRich Smith(Tesla): Has there ever been a more hyped stock than Tesla?makeArticleAd();Elon Musk's electric car start-up (hey
column6: did you hear they make   solar roofs
column7: too?) makes battery buggies that can zoom from 0 to   60 in two seconds. More relevant to investors
column8: Teslastockhas zoomed from$15 million in revenues in 2008
column9: when it first   introduced the Roadster
column10: to $7billionlast year. That's more than 47
column11: 000% growth in just eight   years.Tesla Model 3 unveil. Image source: Tesla.And yet
column12: during all this time
column13: Tesla has failed to earn a   full-year profit even once. To the contrary
column14: annual losses have   ballooned from $83 million lost in 2008 to $675 million in 2016   -- an eight-fold increase.That's one reason thatElon Musk's promiseto build and sell 500
column15: 000 Tesla electric cars annually by 2018   doesn't excite me as much as it may excite other investors.   Historically
column16: you see
column17: the more cars Tesla sells
column18: the more money   it loses ...Sure
column19: according to some analysts
column20: Tesla might soon turn profitable -- perhaps not in 2018
column21: but by   2019 for sure
column22: says Piper Jaffray. But even then
column23: and even if   Piper is right
column24: I have to wonder: Maybe Teslawillearn a profit in 2019. But what kind of profit will it earn? Will   it earn the 3% operating profit margin thatFord Motorpulls down
column25: for example? Or perhaps even the 6% margin   that's more common atGeneral Motors? Because based on those kinds of profit margins
column26: investors value   Ford stock at only 10 times earnings
column27: and GM at a lowly 6 times   earnings.Right now
column28: with no profits to value Tesla on
column29: investors   happily pay several times annual sales for shares ofTesla stock. Once the company has profits to hang a valuation on
column30: though
column31: might they not decide to value Tesla stock on those profits?   Because if that happens
column32: then the $0.20 per share Tesla   might earn in 2019 would only be worth about $2 a share at Ford's   valuation
column33: or a buck-twenty at GM's.Those are two far cries from the $308 a share Tesla stock   currently fetches -- and one very big reason why I don't buy the   hype surrounding Tesla stock.Draw me a pictureDemitri Kalogeropoulos(Autodesk):Surging optimism around Autodesk's business has pushed the stock   up nearly 50% in the past year. What's most surprising about that   rally is that it happened while the computer-aided drawing   specialist endured a sharpdeclinein earnings.Net loss ballooned to $582 million in fiscal 2017 compared to   a loss of $330 million the year before. In contrast
column34: the company   had been generating consistent annual profits of over $200   million as recently as 2014.ADSKdata byYChartsYet investors are salivating at the financial prospects that   Autodesk's shift to a subscription-based selling model might soon   deliver. After selling perpetual licenses for years
column35: the company   has transitioned to term based memberships through the cloud.The shift is making Autodesk appear less profitable
column36: since it   now books revenue and earnings over time rather than in a lump   sum. That makes subscription figures the key metric for investors   to watch right now -- and the good news is that they have shown   robust growth. Subscriptions jumped 21% last year to over 3   million
column37: which represents a strong base of recurring revenue.Management believes it can boost subscriptions at a 20% pace   in fiscal 2018
column38: Autodesk's first full year under the new business   model. If it can keep that momentum going
column39: while also upgrading   many of the company's maintenance customers into bigger
column40: product-based subscriptions
column41: Autodesk should make solid progress   toward returning to profitability this year and earning its   premium valuation.A mountain of promise that can't be metSean Williams(Northern Dynasty Minerals): Northern Dynasty Minerals has
column42: for lack of a better pun
column43: been   a hot commodity among short-term traders in recent months.The company
column44: which is an exploratory-stage precious-metals   miner
column45: has the rights to the Pebble Project in Alaska. This   project could
column46: in theory
column47: be mined out for well over 100 years.   The election of Donald Trump
column48: who is expected to relax a number   of environmental protections (and thus ease the permitting of   Pebble in Alaska)
column49: as well as rising physicalgold priceson a per-ounce basis
column50: have investors excited about the company's   prospects.As for me
column51: I'm not buying into this hype.Image source: Getty Images.The biggest issue I have with a company claiming to be sitting   on a literal gold mine is that its own management team isn't   certain if the assets can be recovered profitably. The following   excerpt is taken directly from Northern Dynasty Minerals'   fourth-quarter report:The Group is in the process of exploring and developing the     Pebble Project and has not yet determined whether the Pebble     Project contains mineral reserves that are economically     recoverable.In other words
column52: there are no guarantees that
column53: even if the   minerals that are in the ground are proved resources
column54: the company   has a way to recover those minerals for a profit.Even if the company did
column55: it's going to need a heck of a lot   more capital than it has now. It ended the fourth quarter with   $7.2 million in cash and cash equivalents
column56: but burned through $24   million in 2016. It did complete a secondary share offering in   January for $32 million
column57: but with the way it burns through its   cash on hand
column58: this only buys it about a year.Plus
column59: developing the Pebble Project would cost billions upon   billions of dollars
column60: and we'd likely be two years
column61: if not more
column62: out from commercial production commencing. What bank in its right   mind is going to lend that much to Northern Dynasty without any   assurances that recovery can be done profitably for an extended   period of time?Pebble has changed hands a few times prior to Northern Dynasty   scooping it up
column63: and there may be a good reason its prior owners   ditched the asset. Put plainly
column64: investors putting their hopes   into Northern Dynasty could be sorely disappointed.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column66: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Could Tesla Really Become a $500 Billion Company?;4/22/2017;"Never one to shy away from bold predictions
column2: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has yet another one
column3: and it's not   about his new Neuralink venture that was detailed on Wait But Why   last night.The electric-car maker has been facing some workforce   challenges at its Tesla Grohmann unit
column4: the German automation   company that it acquired in November. Local workers are feeling   uneasy about job security after Tesla killed all contracts with   other automotive customers
column5: and they are threatening to strike   and want to unionize with IG Metall (the dominant German   metalworkers' union).In an effort to appease the local workforce
column6: Musk has offered   a modest salary increase alongside generous equity compensation
column7: a similar approach that the company is taking at its Fremont   factory
column8: where there is growing unrest among workers that also   want to organize with the UAW. In an email to the local workforce   obtained byElectrek
column9: Musk underscores the potential for capital appreciation   (translated from German):makeArticleAd();These shares can be easily sold for money
column10: but they also     open up the possibility of earning much more through stock     appreciation. The tenfold increase in our share price over the     past five years has made shareholding exceptionally profitable     for our Tesla employees. I firmly believe that we have the     potential for a further tenfold increase over the next five to     10 years.Tesla's market cap is currently hovering right around $50   billion
column11: so a ""tenfold increase over the next 5 to ten years""   would translate into a market cap of $500 billion.The whole value chain. Image source: Tesla.That's actually conservative relative to his prior   predictionMusk made headlines last summer when Tesla initially proposed   its acquisition of sister company SolarCity. On the conference   call to discuss the deal
column12: thiscommentattracted plenty of jeers (emphasis added):I think as a combined automotive and power storage and power     generation company
column13: the potential is there for Tesla to be a$1 trillion company
column14: market cap company. So if we play a major role in transitioning the world to a     new form of energy generation and storage and transport it's     what kind of happens. So that's [why] I think one isn't     going to be worried about whether it's a few hundred million     dollars one way or the other here down the road. It's not going     to make a difference.No company has ever breached that 13-digit threshold
column15: not eventhe most profitable company in the world. Getting to $1 trillion is clearly an outlandish prediction   that's extremely unlikely. But what about $500 billion?Still outlandishTesla is probably the hardest stock in the market to value
column16: given the lack of comparable peers and the breadth of its goals.   If you compare Tesla to automakers
column17: which fetch extremely low   multiples since they consumecopious amounts of capitaland often post single-digit net margins
column18: getting to $500 billion   seems impossible. If you compare Tesla to large tech companies
column19: which fetch much higher multiples since most tech companies enjoy   incredible scale and operating leverage
column20: getting to $500 billion   appears at least remotely possible. If you compare Tesla to   energy companies
column21: which are among the largest and most profitable   in the world since they provide an indispensable commodity
column22: $500   billion doesn't seem unreasonable.The challenge is that none of the above comparisons are apt.   Manufacturing cars dominates Tesla's operations and cost   structure
column23: and as such can't scale like other tech companies
column24: even if it approaches product development
column25: design
column26: iteration
column27: and   integration like a tech company. The aforementioned energy giants   are all oil companies
column28: while solar companies have long struggled   due to the tough economics of the solar industry. There are no   meaningful pure-play battery companies to compare against either
column29: as most of the companies that dominate the battery space today   are Asian conglomerates like Tesla partnerPanasonic
column30: LG Chem
column31: orSamsung SDI.Musk's futureYou also have to acknowledge that there is a Musk premium   inherently priced in
column32: since he's often considered the greatest   visionary since Steve Jobs. In fact
column33: you could even argue thatMusk is more important to society than Jobsever was
column34: given the seemingly endless scope of Musk's   aspirations -- electric cars
column35: reusable rockets
column36: colonizing Mars
column37: supersonic VTOL electric jets
column38: interfacing human brains with AI
column39: the Hyperloop
column40: weaning the world off fossil fuels with solar   energy
column41: digging holes in parking lots-- that have the very real potential to transform humanity. We're   not just talking about consumer electronics here.Of all of Musk's ventures
column42: Tesla is the only one that's   publicly investable
column43: and people simply want to invest in Musk's   future. All of that interest gets consolidated into Tesla
column44: contributing to its premium valuation.Don't get me wrong: I would love Tesla to reach $500 billion   in the years ahead
column45: which would make it a1
column46: 000-baggerfor me personally. But realistically
column47: while it's theoretically   possible
column48: it's not probable
column49: even if Tesla and Musk have a way of   defying reality
column50: especially when it comes to valuation.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column51: it can pay to listen. After all
column52: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Elon Musk Startup Neuralink Aims to Merge Our Brains With Computers by 2021;4/21/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsElon Musk is hoping to have his startupNeuralinkready to help people by 2021.makeArticleAd();Neuralink is theTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO's plans to create a company that allows human brains to operate alongside machines. Elon Musk says that he expects to have some of the tech ready in the next four years.During a piece withWait But Why
column3: Elon Musk says that this first line of technology from Neuralink will help those that have suffered from certain injuries. This means that those hurt by stroke
column4: cancer lesion
column5: congenital may be able to get help with the company's new devices.One of the major problems that Neuralink will face is limited bandwidth. The technology to quickly interact with the human brain isn't available yet. However
column6: growing advancements in these fields mean that the industry may be ready by 2034
column7: if it can advance at the same rate that computers do.The next major problem that Neuralink will face is implantation of the device. Open-skull surgery isn't widely available and can be expensive. It also isn't something that many would likely want to go through. To get around this
column8: the Elon Musk startup is looking for a non-invasive way to have its tech communicate with human brains.The lofty goals of Neuralink means that someday humans may be able to directly communicate with each other and computers with just a thought. However
column9: this is likely still a long ways off due to current limits in technology.10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Will Bleed for the Rest of 2017Elon Musk announced his plans to start Neuralinklate last month. There has been some concern that the Tesla Inc andSpaceXCEO may be stretching himself to thin with all these different efforts.More From InvestorPlace7 High-Yield Stocks That Could Wreck Your Retirement7 Energy Stocks That Will Turn 2017 on Its Head10 Hopeless Stocks to Wash From Your Portfolio ForeverThe postElon Musk Startup Neuralink Aims to Merge Our Brains With Computers by 2021appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Tesla Proves
column2: Once Again
column3: That It Is A Must-Own Stock;4/21/2017;"Tesla (Shutterstock photo)Some stocks
column4: it seems
column5: are just bulletproof. In the normal course of events
column6: stocks react in a fairly predictable way to news. Positive things like better than expected sales or orders cause the stock to rise
column7: while negatives such as problems with a product or the potential loss of key personnel cause it to fall. That is fairly obvious and usually true ... unless that stock is Tesla (TSLA).Yesterday
column8: Tesla announced that they were initiating a recall of 53
column9: 000 vehicles due to a parking brake issue. Now there are two ways to look at that number. When compared to the 12.8 million vehicles that GM (GM) recalled in total in 2014 due to faulty ignition switches it is a mere drop in the ocean
column10: and a muted response in the stock seems appropriate.makeArticleAd();Or
column11: from a different point of view
column12: the 53
column13: 000 cars recalled represent around 70% of Teslas 2016 deliveries. From that perspective
column14: and when consideration is given to the fact that Tesla is still growing and presumably doesnt have huge reserves of cash for such contingencies
column15: a much larger negative reaction would be perfectly logical.In addition
column16: Tesla CEO Elon Muskannouncedovernight that he has been working on Neuralink
column17: a company that is designing an interface between human brains and computers. The implications of that news are huge. Musk claims that they are about four years away from a commercial product that would allow our brains to control computers and therefore
column18: by extension
column19: almost any machine.Imagine
column20: for example
column21: getting into your Tesla
column22: thinking I need to pick up some milk and the car takes you to the nearest milk purveyor
column23: without any pushing of buttons
column24: or even speech.To some that is incredibly scary and to others it is the brave new world
column25: but whatever your reaction
column26: it is a remarkable and revolutionary idea and the potential of Neuralink looks enormous. From the perspective of Tesla stockholders though
column27: the scary part of the news is that Musk stated that he envisaged running the Neuralink project himself and remaining as the companys CEO.One would expect tech investors
column28: on hearing that
column29: to think immediately of Twitter (TWTR)
column30: where CEO and founder Jack Dorseys dual role as boss there and at Square (SQ) is often blamed for Twitters relatively lackluster performance.With Tesla though
column31: what one would logically expect and what actually happens are often two very different things.The five minute
column32: five day chart above shows that when the recall was announced yesterday TSLA did indeed react; the stock dropped around one and a half percent immediately following the news. From the first perspective
column33: as compared to GMs 2014 recall that seems about right
column34: but seen as a recall of around 70% of last years deliveries the reaction is muted to say the least. The chart also shows pre-market trades this morning
column35: after the Neuralink news broke and
column36: as you can see
column37: there has been no reaction to that in Tesla stock.This ably demonstrates the characteristic of TSLA that infuriates the bears
column38: but in many ways makes it such a great stock: resilience. Investing in a company with as daring a vision as Teslas would be in most cases an incredibly risky proposition. The grand plan and rapid growth business model offers the potential for enormous rewards but would normally come with the risk that even minor setbacks could result in huge selloffs.Tesla
column39: however
column40: is different.I will freely admit that at various times in the past I have looked at TSLA and seen it as overvalued
column41: even while recognizing the massive potential. What I did on those occasions was to judge it by conventional metrics and to expect the market to do the same. The reaction to the news over the last 24 hours has shown that that was then
column42: and will continue to be
column43: a mistake. The belief in the company is such and the potential so massive that bad news that would derail most stocks gets shrugged off. It is that resilience that makes TSLA a must-own."""

column1: Residential Solar Giants May Not Be Low Cost After All;4/21/2017;"National solar installersTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column2: Vivint Solar(NYSE: VSLR)
column3: andSunrun(NASDAQ: RUN) have long promoted themselves to investors as the   low-price options for going solar. And the company with the   lowest prices would have a significant competitive advantage in   the growing rooftop solar segment.But anew studyfrom the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) shows that   large installers may not offer buyers a cost advantage at all. In   fact
column4: large installers charge significantly higher prices than   smaller competitors for solar power systems
column5: which may explain   why they have been losing market share over the past year.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Higher prices from national installersThe full study byNREL can be seen here
column6: but the big takeaway is that systems from large   installers costs significantly more than those installed by   their smaller competitors. This chart shows the distribution of   quotes NREL studied
column7: mainly from EnergySage and its customers.   Large installers are defined as companies that installed 1
column8: 000   solar power systems or more in any year from 2013-2015. I'll note   that these quotes are for system sales
column9: not leases.Source: NREL reportUsing Residential Solar PV Quote Data to Analyze     the Relationship between Installer Pricing and Firm Size.This second chart is probably more meaningful because it   compares direct quotes from large and small competitors. These   are systems on the same house and have been adjusted for factors   like panel quality
column10: efficiency
column11: and other factors. You can see   that a large installer is
column12: on average
column13: $0.33 per share higher   than smaller competitors.Source: NREL reportUsing Residential Solar PV Quote Data to Analyze     the Relationship between Installer Pricing and Firm Size.The price differential could be driven by higher   administrative and sales costs for large installers
column14: or even   higher margins. Small installers often work on referrals
column15: spending very little on sales and marketing
column16: in contrast to their   larger rivals.What this means for solar companiesNREL wouldn't release the names of the companies in its large   installer group
column17: but we can easily figure that Tesla (formerly   SolarCity)
column18: Vivint Solar
column19: and Sunrun are in it. And given their   struggles growing in the past year
column20: this data makes sense. But   there's really no getting around their higher cost structure   without entirely changing their business model.SunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR) has put itself in an interesting position given   this data. It's a large presence in residential solar
column21: but   doesn't have a national installation network of its own. Instead
column22: it works with lots of smaller
column23: regional companies that install   its solar panels
column24: and use its technology for quoting and other   back-office services.As rooftop solar gets more competitive and customers buy more   systems
column25: it's possible that Tesla
column26: Vivint
column27: and Sunrun will   collectively lose even more market share
column28: and SunPower will grow   its share simply based on the difference between their   installation models. There's just no way around the fact that   large installers are at a cost disadvantage -- and that's not   usually an attractive proposition for investors.10 stocks we like better than Vivint SolarWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column29: it can pay to listen. After all
column30: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column31: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column32: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Vivint Solar wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3
