column1: Does Toyota's Hydrogen Truck Torpedo Tesla's Truck Tweet?;4/20/2017;"Toyota Motor Corporation(NYSE: TM) revealed a surprise on Wednesday: The automaker has   created a hydrogen fuel cell system to power zero-emission   electric heavy trucks. Toyota engineers have installed a   prototype of the system in a heavily modified Kenworth 18-wheeler   that will soon begin operating in a test in California.This big rig is powered by electricity generated by Toyota     fuel cells. Image source: Toyota.makeArticleAd();A wrench in Tesla's truck plan?Toyota's surprise announcement came less than a week afterTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) CEO Elon Musk announced thatTesla has an electric truck on the way:Tesla Semi truck unveil set for September. Team has done an   amazing job. Seriously next level.- Elon Musk (@elonmusk)April 13
column2: 2017Musk's tweet led at least one analyst todowngrade sharesof heavy-truck makerPACCAR(NASDAQ: PCAR) and diesel-engine giantCummins(NYSE: CMI)  on concerns that Tesla could emerge as a   dominant player in the market for zero-emission heavy trucks.   (That seems awfully premature
column3: given that Tesla hasn't even shown   its truck
column4: much less explained how
column5: when
column6: or in what factory   the truck will be built.)Toyota's announcement is a big warning for Tesla: The Silicon   Valley upstart isn't going to be the only player in that   game. And unlike Tesla
column7: Toyota actually has a working   electric truck to show off right now.Why Toyota's truck is important -- and differentTesla's electric truck will almost certainly be powered by a   battery pack
column8: similar to those used in its cars. But unless Tesla   has come up with a dramatic breakthrough
column9: its battery-powered   heavy truck is likely to have a couple of drawbacks:The number of battery cells required to move an     80
column10: 000-pound vehicle several hundred miles is very large
column11: meaning that the battery pack in Tesla's truck is nearly     certain to be bulky
column12: heavy
column13: and expensive;That big battery pack will take a long time to recharge
column14: taking the truck out of service for several hours a day.In theory at least
column15: fuel cells get around those disadvantages.   A fuel cell is a device that chemically converts the energy in   hydrogen gas to electricity. The only ""exhaust"" is water vapor
column16: and that can be collected and reused (it's just clean water). A   fuel cell system scaled for a tractor-trailer isn't huge or heavy   -- and it can be ""recharged"" in minutes
column17: as long as there's a   hydrogen refueling station nearby.Toyota's electric fuel cell truck will be tested in daily     service in southern California starting this summer. Image     source: Toyota.Of course
column18: unless you're in southern California
column19: there aren't   likely to be hydrogen stations nearby. But while that's an   obstacle for fuel cell passenger cars
column20: it seems like less of an   obstacle for long-haul tractor-trailers owned by a fleet operator   that can build its own strategically located stations along its   routes.That's the bet Toyota is making.About Toyota's hydrogen fuel cell truckToyota's system was developed over the last several months by   a secret ""skunk works"" team in Michigan. Working under the code   name ""Project Portal
column21: the team drew on the fuel cell technology   developed for Toyota's Mirai sedan to create a system capable of   powering a 80
column22: 000-pound ""Class 8"" 18-wheeler in a manner   comparable to industry-standard diesel engines.The resulting system uses two of the fuel cell ""stacks""   developed for the Mirai
column23: along with a 12 kilowatt-hour battery   pack. The system powers a single heavy-duty electric motor that   produces more than 670 horsepower and 1
column24: 327 pound-feet of torque.   That's right in the same neighborhood as Cummins' latest diesel   engines for tractor-trailer applications.Toyota's electric truck uses the fuel cell technology     developed for its Mirai sedan. Image source: Toyota.But unlike those diesels
column25: Toyota's fuel cells don't pollute   the air. That makes air-quality regulators in California happy --   and it's no coincidence that Toyota's prototype will be tested in   southern California. The Project Portal truck will begin   operating at the Port of Los Angeles in a feasibility study this   summer
column26: as part of the Port's ongoing Clean Air Action Plan.Is Toyota planning to build these fuel cell heavy   trucks?That's not clear yet. Toyota doesn't currently build Class 8   heavy trucks
column27: though it does build light and medium commercial   trucks under its Hino Trucks brand. It could tool up to build   fuel cell heavy trucks on its own
column28: or it could choose to partner   with an established truck builder. (It might be worth noting that   Toyota's prototype is installed in a Kenworth truck. Kenworth is   a PACCAR brand.)How well will Toyota's hydrogen truck compete?While it seems (very) likely that electric heavy trucks will   be coming to America's highways in the not-too-distant future
column29: most efforts to develop them are still in the early stages. It's   impossible to say right now how the competition will take shape.   But it's likely that Toyota's size
column30: scale
column31: and reputation for   quality will make it an instant major contender in this emerging   market --ifit chooses to enter.I think we'll know a lot more in a year or so
column32: after Toyota   has had a chance to thoroughly evaluate its fuel cell truck in   daily operation -- and after we get a look at what Tesla and   others might be planning.10 stocks we like better than Toyota MotorWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column33: it can pay to listen. After all
column34: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column35: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column36: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Toyota Motor wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3
column37: 2017John Rosevearhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Cummins
column38: Paccar
column39: and Tesla. The Motley     Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Is Primed for Long-Term Strength;4/20/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCutting prices is generally a signal that a company is bowing to competition or
column3: at best
column4: sacrificing current cash flow in order to grab market share down the road. And then there'sTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA)
column5: where Elon Musk's inherent reality distortion field flips the normal logic and turns what would otherwise be ominous margin pressure into confirmation that everything is right as rain.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockTSLA stock currently lives and dies on its luxury car sales
column6: so discounting the lower-end of the Model S series by $2
column8: 000 can cut into next quarter's top line by as much as $125 million.With the waiting list still running months behind deliveries
column9: I don't see this as a brute attempt to sell a few more electric sedans to potential customers who were on the fence - Tesla has all the orders it can handle
column10: and if you balk at a $74
column11: 000 car you'll probably keep balking at $69
column12: 000.Good News for TSLA Stock?What's really going on is an exponential increase in TSLA's production capacity. As the Nevada ""giga factory"" ramps up
column13: capacity is on track to triple this year and double in 2018
column14: so now is the time to start translating its market capitalization into real wheels on the road.After all
column15: the moment is coming fast when Musk is going to have more cars than ever rolling off the line. He needs to shift the sales profile down toward the mass market
column16: and this is part of that evolution. The really high end of the Tesla universe is actually getting more expensive because those cars are status symbols - someone who is paying $90
column18: 000 isn't really going to get sticker shock if it means an even more luxurious experience.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for the Next DecadeIn the end
column19: I expect the math will even out. And when it comes to the bottom line
column20: Tesla stock may not be sacrificing much on the margins in order to move those additional cars. The lithium battery was always the big cost center behind all the space-age bells and whistles. With the giga-factory starting to achieve efficiencies of scale
column21: Musk may be paying less than $10
column22: 000 for his ""low-end"" battery backs in a few months.If anything
column23: he may be passing just about all of the savings on as an incentive for people to buy the cheapest Tesla models
column24: but when you get up to the 90D and beyond
column25: his margins are actually expanding. Those ""discounted"" models earn shareholders a little more on every single sale. As volume increases
column26: so does profitability.And every month that giga-factory keeps scaling
column27: unit costs drop toward the point where TSLA stock can compete head-to-head with over a century of industrial combustion and reach the mass market without losing money. Tinkering with the pricing shows that the company is still on course - the breakthrough moment may move back a few days or weeks

column34: earnings induced rally.Overall

column1: Buy Starbucks Corporation (SBUX) Stock  Once It Cools Off;4/20/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLet's not mince words.Starbucks Corporation(NASDAQ:SBUX) is a great American success story
column3: and so is SBUX stock. However
column4: Starbucks is entering a new era.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIt's worth examining what has happened thus far with the company to understand why SBUX stock is likely about to cool off in the near-term
column5: but still looks great for the long-term.After all
column6: it's the long-term that ultimately matters
column7: and that's what my forthcoming stock advisory newsletter
column8: The Liberty Portfolio
column9: focuses on.The Starbucks StoryThe reason Starbucks found success was not because it served coffee. It's because it created a location between work and home where people could meet. There wasn't any obvious location for such a thing until SBUX came around.Think about it. When you need to meet with someone
column10: what's the easiest thing that comes to mind? If you are in any urban area
column11: Starbucks as a meeting location is probably one of the top three things to hit you.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for the Next DecadeOf course
column12: Starbucks also sold an addictive product
column13: which didn't hurt.It could have stopped there
column14: but it didn't. It moved its coffee into grocery stores. It made ice cream. In its own stores
column15: it added ice blended drinks
column16: flavored coffees
column17: teas and juices (via acquisition)
column18: snack food boxes and eventually pastries. Then it moved into breakfast offerings to compete with the fast-food chains.And SBUX stock did very well amidst all this expansion.However
column19: operationally speaking
column20: things have started to slow down a bit. The recent run in shares is belying this fact.SBUX is hardly in trouble - it's just starting to plateau as it reaches a zillion stores around the globe. It's not that the concept or the stores are getting tired and old
column21: likeMcDonald's Corporation(NYSE:MCD). It's not that there's no growth - it's just that growth isn't what it was. The numbers just suggest that it's time for a reboot.CEO Howard Schultz kicked himself upstairs to Executive Chairman
column22: where he will be developing the Starbucks Reserve Roasteries
column23: expand the Reserve retails stores
column24: and more ominously for this investor
column25: ""social impact initiatives.""What does this mean?The COO might need a little time to get adjusted. The Chief Operating Officer knows how to operate the business
column26: not innovate. He's there to keep tight watch on the company and make sure it continues to execute
column27: make money
column28: generate cash flow and not flail.There's probably some growth to be squeezed here and there
column29: but for the most part
column30: the COO moving to CEO smells like SBUX is going to cool off from its current burst.Still
column31: there's the long-term to think about.Bottom Line on SBUX StockWhile Starbucks is currently trying to make a run on its 2015 highs around $63
column32: I think shares are about to stall out. I doubt it will go much higher in the near-term so even selling some covered calls several months out may squeeze more upside out of your long position than just holding it.But don't sell Starbucks stock if you own it.Starbucks 3.0 is going to do very
column33: very well. See
column34: Schultz isn't an operator so much as an innovator. He has done very well when it comes to innovation. When he emerges with his concepts and they start rolling it out
column35: that's when Starbucks may re-enter its growth phase.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Longs: Don't Rock the Boardroom Too Much!Right now
column36: though
column37: SBUX stock trades at nearly 30 times net income. While analysts see 15% annualized growth over the next five years
column38: and Starbucks deserves a premium for its cash flow and brand name
column39: I think 30x is too expensive given the phase it's about to enter. So I wouldn't buy the stock here.But I think the stock market as a whole is overvalued
column40: and believe a true correction is coming. If it does
column41: SBUX will take a haircut. Ideally
column42: something around 20% to 30% would make things a whole lot more interesting for true value buyers.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital
column43: a specialty lender focusing on consumer finance. He has 20 years' experience in the stock market
column44: and has written more than 1
column45: 600 articles on investing. He also is the Manager of the forthcoming Liberty Portfolio. Lawrence Meyers can be reached atTheLibertyPortfolio@gmail.com. As of this writing

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Longs: Dont Rock the Boardroom Too Much!;4/20/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhether investors want to admit it or not
column3: one of the most fascinating parts of theTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) story is CEO Elon Musk. He's brilliant and brash
column4: intelligent yet immature
column5: and frank while frightening. He's not unlike shock-jock DJ Howard Stern. And both TSLA stock owners - and non-owners - love to follow the saga just because they have no idea what Musk might say or do next.makeArticleAd();Source:Chris Brown Via FlickrThere are times
column6: however
column7: where the best thing to say is absolutely nothing at all.Last week was one of those times.It will blow over; it always does. But Musk probably should have thought it out beforetweeting""This investor group should buy Ford stock. Their governance is amazing"" to a group of Tesla stock holders concerned that the company's board of directors isn't quite independent enough.While Tesla's (and Musk's) usual fans quickly came to his support
column8: the comparison toFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) not only showed a lack of discretion - it opened the door to closer scrutiny of governance at Tesla.A Brilliant Comparison to MakeMusk's tweet was in response to a letter he received on Monday from an ad hoc group of Tesla stock owners - presumably institutional investors - pointing out the conflicts of interest built into the board. Thegroup's specific concern:""We expect that as companies make the transition to publicly-traded status
column9: the governance structures and practices in place at the time of the IPO will evolve to align with the company's changing strategy. However
column10: Tesla's seven-member board is largely unchanged from its pre-IPO days.""His reference to Ford's governance may not have been coincidental
column11: taking a shot at the uncanny amount of influence the Ford family has over the company.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for the Next DecadeEach ""family"" share of Ford isgranted 16 voteson all matters that require shareholder involvement (like selecting directors)
column12: as opposed to just one vote per share of ordinary Ford stock. This effectively means the family controls about 40% of the company's voting power
column13: even without owning anywhere near 40% of outstanding shares.Non-family shareholders have attempted to change Ford's lopsided control structure
column14: but not surprisingly
column15: have failed to get enough votes to do so.From that angle
column16: Musk may have a valid point about being left alone; it could be worse. Nevertheless
column17: such a comment only draws even more attention to the matter
column18: giving the Tesla stock owner base a reason to look more closely at the company's ownership allocation  and the board.More investors may not like what they find.Keeping It in the FamilyAs of the latest look
column19: Musk - who is the chairman of the board as well as the Tesla's CEO - owns roughly 22% of outstanding TSLA stock by himself. Otherboard membersinclude Elon's brother and formerSolarCity(which Tesla acquired last year) CFO Kimbal Musk
column20: Steve Jurvetson
column21: Robyn Denholm
column22: Gracias Ehrenpreis
column23: and Ira Ehrenpreis. Both Ehrenpreis's are investors in another of Elon Musk's venture
column24: SpaceX(Gracias runs it
column25: in fact)
column26: while Jurvetson is also a director of SpaceX.Director Brad Buss doesn't seemingly have any familial ties or inappropriate business links to Tesla or Musk. But a closer look at his dossier reveals he was previously CFO of SolarCity
column27: and like Musk
column28: benefited greatly from the acquisition. (Elon was also a 22% owner of SolarCity.)So
column29: from that perspective
column30: the group of concerned investors may have a valid point. A bunch of people on the board are in one way or another beholden to Musk. Never mind the fact that he's the chairman as well as the chief
column31: and is only
column32: ultimately
column33: held accountable by himself.Bottom Line for Tesla StockTo his credit
column34: following Wednesday's tweet Musk added that the company waslooking to add two more directors to the board. Although he denies the pressure from the group of investors has anything to do with it - and it probably doesn't - this isn't likely the first time he's heard the concern. He knows it's only a matter of time before more owners jump on the bandwagon and apply even more pressure.Amazon.com
column35: Inc. (AMZN)
column36: Costco Wholesale Corporation (COST) Are Solid Long-Term BuysAll the same
column37: it remains to be seen how ""independent"" those two directors will be. Odds are
column38: Musk will somehow maintain a high degree of control in the boardroom.Does it inherently make Tesla stock a sell? No
column39: it doesn't. Whether appropriate or not
column40: the structure works in this particular case because it caters to Musk's amazing vision. Either you're okay with it
column41: or you're not. The near 800% gain TSLA shares have mustered since the end of 2012
column42: however
column43: says maybe investors might be just as well off leaving things alone.At least for the time being.As of this writing
column44: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 11 Best Dividend Stocks to BuyUnder Armour Inc (UAA) Stock Stumbles by Going the Apple Way5 Tech Stocks to Buy for Growth AND DividendsThe postTesla Inc (TSLA) Longs: Don't Rock the Boardroom Too Much!appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ) Stock Drops After Earnings (As It Should);4/20/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsDespite a valiant effort to stop the shrinking of its top and bottom line
column3: Verizon Communications Inc.(NYSE:VZ) just can't seem find a groove. Concerned shareholders sent VZ stock 2.1% lower following what can only be categorized as a disappointing first-quarter report from the company.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart Via FlickrAll told

column5: versus analyst expectations of a profit of 97 cents per share. Analysts were also calling for sales of $30.57 billion for the quarter ending in March
column6: but the telecom giant only produced $29.8. billion worth of revenue. Verizon reported $32.17 billion in revenue and $1.06 per share of profits in the year-ago quarter.CEO Lowell McAdam said of the Verizon earnings numbers:""Our first-quarter results again demonstrated that customers value a high-quality network experience. To build on our loyal customer base and the third-party recognition we have received for network leadership
column7: we extended our wireless and fiber network capabilities
column8: began offering an unlimited pricing option and expanded our opportunities in new markets""The wireless (and wireline) service provider launched the unlimited data plan in February
column9: which arguably helped the company attract and keep customers. Before the new package was made available
column10: Verizon had lost  398
column11: 000 postpaid customers. After the plan was introduced
column12: it added 109
column13: 000 connections. All told
column14: the company lost 307
column15: 000 postpaid customers in its first quarter. Postpaid churn was 1.15%.The 11 Best Dividend Stocks to BuyWhatever the case
column16: the adverse fiscal impact of Verizon Unlimited is clear.The new pricing plan isn't solely to blame for the quarter's fiscal weakness. Verizon missed itsprior quarter's earnings estimate as well- the first miss since the last quarter of 2014. This second shortcoming implies analysts didn't fully appreciate the competitive headwind that VZ ran into near the end of last year.Verizon Is Shifting StrategiesThe telecom icon is still a powerhouse
column17: not only boasting the most U.S. wireless market share
column18: but remaining a cash cow. Growth has been a struggle though
column19: ever sinceSprint Corp(NYSE:S) introduced its ""cut your bill in half"" promotion over a year ago
column20: andT-Mobile US Inc(NASDAQ:TMUS) began offering nearly free smartphones. RivalAT&T Inc.(NYSE:T) put just as much pressure on Verizon around that time as well
column21: however
column22: axing its two-year contract requirement.The end result was a price war that took a toll on all the industry's players; last quarter's lull was nothing VZ stock holders haven't seen before.The proposed solution thus far for some of the industry's leaders has been melding wireless service providers with media names
column23: blurring the lines between the two in an effort to sell (and cross-sell) new packages.AT&T is credited as the first to think outside the box
column24: acquiring satellite television giantDirecTVback in 2015. It's currently working toward a union with studioTime Warner Inc(NYSE:TWX)
column25: which would allow it to be the message and the messenger.Verizon is no stranger to lateral acquisitions
column26: though. Itbought internet venueAOLand all of its web properties back in 2015. VZ reportedly has done well with it
column27: although AOL's revenue was off 4% last quarter on a year-over-year basis.Now Verizon is looking to replicate that success with AOL via the purchase ofYahoo! Inc.(NASDAQ:YHOO).In fact
column28: Yahoo's last quarterly report as its own publicly traded entity was posted earlier this week  an ironic improvement in revenue
column29: and a respectable increase in income. The company had been losing ground for years
column30: leading some to believe Verizon was still overpaying for the web business despitethe discount offered at the 11th hour. With a much-needed rebound on the books
column31: though
column32: perhaps Verizon doesn't have as much work cut out for it as some suspected.That being said
column33: McAdam noted earlier in the week he was open to more M&A in the future
column34: and wasparticularly interested in deals that beef up Verizon's media delivery and 5G networking capabilities. McAdam even made a point of referencingComcast Corporation(NASDAQ:CMCSA) andWalt Disney Co(NYSE:DIS) as possible partners
column35: though he certainly didn't limit his options to those players. Both of those companies
column36: however
column37: would give Verizon a weapon to wield against a Time-Warner/AT&T (and DirecTV) combo.Nevertheless
column38: Verizon still operates a telecom business
column39: and must remain competitive on that front particularly with the advent of 5G connectivity representing a new battleground.Apple Inc. Wants to Make Recycled iPhonesThe company didn't win any new spectrum in the most recent FCC auction
column40: but it did ink a deal withCorning Incorporated(NYSE:GLW) this week
column41: agreeing to purchase at least $1.0 billion worth of fiberoptic cable from the company over the course of the coming three years. This suggests Verizon is aiming to keep a big portion of its customer connectivity running through physical lines rather than radio waves
column42: but also ramp-up its Fios business - which can support television
column43: phone
column44: and internet services. Its Fios revenue was up 4.7% last quarter.Looking Ahead for VZ StockVerizon didn't offer specific profit or revenue guidance for the quarter currently underway
column45: or for the full year. It only noted it expected this year's top and bottom line to essentially look like 2016's tallies. The company added it was looking for a rebound in wireless and equipment revenue later this year to offset the slow start.Analysts have been more specific
column46: calling for earnings of 99 cents per share on revenue of $30.35 billion.For the whole year
column47: analysts were modeling a bottom line of $3.81 per share of VZ stock on sales of $124.53 billion. Both would be down from last year's levels

column1: Why Investors Should Have Known Tesla's SolarCity Acquisition Was a Bad Business Decision;4/20/2017;"WhenTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) bought SolarCity in late 2016
column2: it was supposed to   create a vertically integrated renewable energy company. People   thought Elon Musk could marry EV sales with solar and combine   SolarCity's installation arm with Tesla's Powerwall to create a   path for customers to eventually go off-grid -- or at least   charge their car with solar energy. When the solar roof was shown   off last fall
column3: the expectations got even higher.But if we're looking objectively at Tesla's solar business   today
column4: it's largely a bust. Tesla is shrinking SolarCity
column5: has   already shut down its solar technology in favor of white label   panels fromPanasonic
column6: and hasn't shown any progress integrating solar into Tesla   showrooms. And withcompetitorsinresidential solar going bankrupt
column7: you have to wonder if Musk bailed out his solar company to save   himself hundreds of millions of dollars and keep from tarnishing   his impeccable reputation on the stock market.Image source: Tesla. Tesla's solar roof may be a big     distraction from Tesla slowing SolarCity's operations.makeArticleAd();Tesla is winding down solarDespite Elon Musk talking positively about solar
column8: make no   mistake: Tesla is slowing down SolarCity's solar business. In the   fourth quarter of 2016
column9: solar installations were 201 MW
column10: down from 272 MW a year earlier. Full-year 2016 installations   were 803 MW
column11: down from 870 MW a year earlier.As late as third-quarter 2016 earnings results
column12: SolarCity's   management expected the company to keep growing. They guided for   900 MW in full-year installations
column13: implying around 300 MW of   installs for the fourth quarter. Once Tesla took control
column14: the   number of installations dropped -- and the future for the   business doesn't look much better.Tesla's solar business is now less competitiveA recent study by the National Renewable Energy Lab (NREL)showed that quotes from large
column15: national installers   were priced $0.33
column16: or about 10%
column17: higher than smaller local or regional installers.   And as customers move toward more loan and cash sales versus   leases and loans
column18: the advantage national installers had with   scale is dissipating.Tesla's newly acquired solar unit may actually have higher   costs than competitors
column19: and it doesn't have a differentiated   product
column20: either.New solar panels aren't really new at allWhen Tesla bought SolarCity
column21: it was buying a company that had   a solar manufacturing plant under construction in Buffalo
column22: New   York. The plant was supposed to make high-efficiency solar panels   based on technology acquired from Silevo.But even before the deal closed
column23: Tesla signed a deal that   wouldbring Panasonic in as a partner and cut Silevo   technology out. Now
column24: it appears the solar panels Tesla has introduced are just   rebranded Panasonic panels. And with Panasonic running the   Buffalo plant -- dubbed ""Gigafactory 2"" -- Tesla doesn't have a   new or differentiated product at all. It's just installing   Panasonic panels.The solar roof could be a new product
column25: but we know very little   about it. And until we do
column26: investors shouldn't put much stock in   the new product.Tesla hasn't proven it can sell solar at allWe have yet to see solar end up in Tesla's stores
column27: and I'm   skeptical it will ever be a big business. Tesla's focus in 2017   and 2018 has to be on selling the Model 3
column28: and solar would be a   huge distraction from that.Even if Tesla does start selling solar in stores
column29: there's no   guarantee it will be a success. And with the traditional solar   sales business struggling
column30: the showroom is key to Tesla's solar   future.How Musk & Family cashed in on the SolarCity     dealWhat's becoming increasingly clear about Tesla's buyout of   SolarCity is that it was a huge benefit to Musk and his cousins   Lyndon and Peter Rive. Thethree had $100 million of solar bonds issued by   SolarCity
column31: bonds that were recently bought back by Tesla. The three will   have bonds transfered to Tesla under the same terms
column32: unlike   outside investors
column33: but would you rather have a struggling   SolarCity owe you $100 million
column34: or market darling Tesla
column35: who has   easy access to equity markets?The debt is on top of the 22.2 million SolarCity shares that   Musk turned into Tesla shares and the 2.3 million shares the   Rives converted. Had SolarCity gone bankrupt
column36: as some major   residential solar rivals have done
column37: rather than being bought by   Tesla
column38: they would have lost hundreds of millions combined.A bailout of their SolarCity stake to save Musk and the Rives   hundreds of millions is worth considering when you see   SolarCity's operations being shut down and manufacturing being   turned over to Panasonic. At this point
column39: it doesn't look like the   SolarCity acquisition was a good deal at all. Musk could prove   that wrong eventually
column40: but so far
column41: there's little indication he   has much interest in growing solar under Tesla's umbrella.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column43: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Apple Won't Be First to Augmented Reality
column2: but Can It Be the Best?;4/19/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) is very rarely a first mover
column3: and CEO Tim Cook   often points out that the company's goal is never to be the first   at something -- it just wants to be the best. The iPod wasn't the   first music player
column4: the iPhone wasn't the first smartphone
column5: and   the iPad wasn't the first tablet. There are more examples.WithFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) making abig official pushinto augmented reality (AR) yesterday
column6: complementing its virtual   reality (VR) efforts
column7: will the same scenario play out once again   for the Mac maker?Mark Zuckerberg at F8 2017 unveiling Facebook's AR platform.     Image source: Facebook.makeArticleAd();Hardware is hardCook has madeno secretof how much potential he sees in AR
column8: believing that the nascent   technology could be truly transformative since unlike VR
column9: AR   doesn't isolate you from the real world. In characteristic   fashion
column10: don't expect Apple to unveil whatever it's up to until   the company feels like it's ready for mainstream adoption. In   contrast
column11: Facebook is taking the more traditional Silicon Valley   approach of incremental iteration.The social network's new Camera Effects Platform currently   just focuses on photo and video filters as a form of expression.   Apple's new Clips app offers similar functionalities
column12: which may   very well be the foundations of its AR strategy
column13: but Apple isn't   calling anything a ""platform"" quite yet like Facebook is. Apple   is also expected to include some AR functionalities in upcoming   iPhones
column14: potentially as early as this year. Longer term
column15: both   companies appear to be working onAR glassesas the delivery mechanism for an AR platform.The hardware will be a critically important aspect
column16: and   fashion preferences have a lot of bearing on wearable technology.Alphabet's Google Glass was too early for its time
column17: and the super   futuristic aesthetic was alienating
column18: which may have contributed   to that device's failure. Facebook is relatively new to the   hardware game
column19: but has been beefing up its hardware talent. The   company poached Rich Heley last year fromTeslato join its Building 8 hardware team
column20: where he currently serves   as head of manufacturing; Heley was previously a hardware   director at Apple.Meanwhile
column21: hardware is one of Apple's greatest strengths
column22: so   expectations around Apple AR glasses will be (and should be)   quite high. Apple also has much more experience constructing and   operating computing platforms (as opposed to a social platform)   on a massive scale. Additionally
column23: Apple can leverage its broader   product ecosystem to deliver more integrated AR experiences that   leverage other Apple products a customer might have.The odds are stacked in the Mac maker's favor.AR platforms may not be mutually exclusiveIt's worth pointing out that AR platforms may not be mutually   exclusive. While the primary platform may very well be tied to   what hardware a customer buys
column24: it's quite conceivable that in   addition to making AR glasses
column25: Facebook could build its platformon topof other platforms
column26: too
column27: much like its current social platform is   primarily built on third-party mobile platforms like iOS and   Android.If Apple's underlying AR platform proves to be more   successful
column28: with greater mainstream adoption
column29: there wouldn't be   anything stopping Facebook from creating an AR app for Apple's   platform to deliver the AR experiences that Zuckerberg envisions.   On the flip side
column30: it's unlikely that Apple would pursue such a   strategy
column31: as it always sticks to its own walled garden.It's still early days in AR
column32: and the coming years will see   major AR investments and competition from all the major tech   giants. That's good news for consumers.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Qualcomm
column2: Inc. (QCOM) Beats on Q2 Earnings
column3: But Its Still a Trap;4/19/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFor a moment
column5: it looked like a bit of good news forQualcomm
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM). QCOM stock jumped in after-hours trading after the company's fiscal second-quarter report included beats on both the top and bottom lines.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockQualcomm stock was up as much as 3% after initially declining
column7: but it has since given back some of its post-earnings gains. All eyes are on the post-earnings conference call
column8: however
column9: as investors look to get more information onthe company's legal battlewithApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL).But on the numbers alone? Well
column10: Qualcomm earnings weren't bad  but they weren't nearly strong enough to get investor attention shifted elsewhere.Qualcomm Earnings: The Good NewsQualcomm admittedly reported strong Q2 numbers.Adjusted earnings of $1.34 per share beat estimates by 14 cents. Meanwhile
column11: non-GAAP revenue of $6 billion
column12: up 8% year-over-year
column13: was a point and a half ahead of the Street's growth projections.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for the Next DecadeQualcomm recorded strength in its QCT (chip) business - the one area in which QCOM has some degree of control. Licensing revenues and profits largely are based on shipments by Qualcomm customers - it's not as if Qualcomm has much influence over how many smartphones are shipped within a given quarter.The QCT numbers were good
column14: to be sure. Revenue increased 10% and EBT (earnings before taxes) rose a whopping 179% year-over-year. EBT margins moved from a narrow 5% to a much more healthy 13%. Guidance for Q3 suggests that margin improvement will hold
column15: at least in the near term.That's a notable step forward in Qualcomm reducing its reliance on the licensing business - because that is the business that worries investors at the moment.Qualcomm Earnings: The Bad NewsThe problem is that even a stronger QCT barely moves the needle for Qualcomm
column16: and QCOM stock
column17: as a whole. The licensing business (QTL) EBT was still more thanquadruplethat of QCT in Q2.That QTL business did have a solid quarter
column18: with revenue rising 5% and margins holding flat
column19: as 3G and 4G smartphone shipments rose 20%. But the Apple concerns still weigh.In its Q2 presentation
column20: Qualcomm said that Q3 guidance was wider than usual - EPS is projected between 90 cents and $1.15 per share - because of uncertainty as to whether AAPL suppliers would withhold royalties due. That's also somewhat disappointing compared to the consensus of $1.09.And even that wide range doesn't include a scenario whereallof Apple's suppliers withhold royalties.The potential impact of the Apple dispute still isn't known - and could still rear its head at some point over the next few quarters. That's not going to do enough for investor confidence to get QCOM stock out of its current rut.Adding to the worries about the near future
column21: smartphone shipments are expected to be much more moderate over the rest of calendar 2017. Qualcomm is projecting 3%-9% growth year-over-year - which against a 20% figure implies a flat or even contracting market over the next three quarters. In that context
column22: the Q2 beat looks far less impressive. It simply looks as if Qualcomm had some profits move into the quarter and out of fiscal Q3.How Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Can Generate 370% ReturnsAnd it looks as if the Apple issue still remains potentially damaging for Qualcomm stock.Stay Away From QCOM StockAll told
column23: Qualcomm's fiscal Q2 just wasn't enough. I've considered the companya value trapfor some time
column24: and the Q2 numbers don't change that opinion.The post-earnings conference call will give more detail
column25: but until investors understand the potential impact of lower royalties
column26: QCOM stock remains an avoid at best.As of this writing
column27: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceRite Aid Corporation (RAD) Stock Must DieCommit to Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock With Zero Money Down5 Oil Stocks Collapsing Under the Crude SelloffThe postQualcomm

column1: Dougherty Drops Tesla Price Target From $500 to $375;4/19/2017;"AmidTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)  shares' rally to record highs
column2: analysts and   investors continue pontificating on where they'll go from here.   Optimism around the forthcoming Model 3 launch is invigorating   bulls
column3: while the incredibly lofty valuation levels are feeding   the bears.Dougherty analysts Charles Anderson and Jessica McHugh are now   dropping the firm's price target on Tesla from $500 to $375
column4: according toBarron's. That's a pretty big cut
column5: but the underlying reason may not be   what you think.Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();Changing methodologyThe prior $500 price target was set by analyst Andrea James
column6: who left Dougherty in May of last year to start an executive   coaching practice. A few months later in September 2016
column7: Tesla   head of investor relations Jeff Evanson recruited her as an   investor relations associate/consultant; Evanson and James had   both worked together at Dougherty before Tesla hired Evanson in   2011 to lead its IR function.Anderson inherited Tesla's coverage from James
column8: including both   her rating and price target
column9: which he reiterated last year.   However
column10: the methodology that James used to derive her price   target was a bit odd: Her model estimated 2025 earnings and then   discounted those profits back to arrive at a $500 price target.   On one hand
column11: a long-term focus makes sense for a company like   Tesla
column12: since so much of the valuation is predicated on future   performance
column13: but price targets are often 12-month targets.   Anderson is changing the methodology to ""gain consistency with   the 12-month Price Target view of the rest of our coverage   universe.""The new $375 price target is derived from 30 times estimated   2020 earnings of $12.49. To get there
column14: the analyst is modeling   for a 35% compound annual growth rate from 2017 through 2020
column15: which Anderson believes justifies that earnings multiple.   Dougherty is still bullish overall
column16: and believes that Tesla still   enjoys a ""substantial lead in battery technology"" and much   greater brand strength
column17: citing the 350
column18: 000-plus Model 3   reservations that the company has gathered with no   advertising.Using 2020 estimates is more reasonable
column19: as longer-term   estimates are generally less reliable since so much can happen   between now and 2025
column20: especially for a company like Tesla.   There's also more visibility into Tesla's ambitions
column21: as the   company said a year ago that it hopes to produce 500
column22: 000 vehicles   in 2018 and ramp to 1 million vehicles by 2020. Whether or not   Tesla can actually pull off those ambitious goals is another   topic altogether.While the prior $500 price target was the Street highby far
column23: the new $375 price target is still the Street high
column24: just not by   as wide a margin. That target still represents over 20% upside   from current levels. Even Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jones
column25: one   of the most prominent Street bulls
column26: only has a price target of   $305
column27: which is roughly where shares are currently trading.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: How to Trade Netflix Stock While Its on the Ropes (NFLX);4/19/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsQuarterly earnings are just starting to accelerate this week with several big-name stocks announcing. So far
column3: there have been a few surprises
column4: with a couple of familiar names moving lower after reporting
column5: includingGoldman Sachs Group Inc(NYSE:GS) andInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM)The one familiar stock I want to focus on today however isNetflix
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX)for the reasons I will discuss below.makeArticleAd();Just recently
column7: Luke Langowrote about how investors need to look past certain numbers when it comes to NFLX and focus on what is important. He thinks the company's changes - including cutting some original content
column8: which has led to more profitability - could impress investors over the long haul.Lucky for us
column9: this trade idea on NFLX stock is not meant for the long haul.But before we go any further
column10: let's talk a little bit about an option strategy that I frequently consider. It is a vertical call credit spread. Essentially
column11: it is a bearish trade but it does have some special nuances to it. Depending on how it is implemented
column12: the strategy can profit if the stock moves lower
column13: stays the same or even moves higher. The ability to profit in this caliber is what gives options an advantage over other trading vehicles in my opinion.Let's take a look below.An Option Strategy for NFLX StockThe rationale:This trade idea is built upon the idea that Netflix won't move decisively higher. What better than to have multiple potential areas of resistance in its way
column14: then?Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock Will Correct
column15: But Don't WorryTaking a look at the chart just below the stock is currently trading below its 50-day simple moving average. Moving averages are often considered form of support
column16: and in this case potential resistance. In addition
column17: the stock has twice tested the $148 area - which was close to its all-time high ($148.29) - and failed. This might be an additional potential resistance area for NFLX stock in case it does try to move higher before the options expire.Click to EnlargeWhat could help this trade idea profit even quicker is a move lower. Netflix stock has now traded down to a potential support area at $140. This area has kept the stock from moving much lower after gapping above the area in the middle of January.But just because support has a better chance of holding Netflix stock up for the time being
column18: doesn't mean that it will bounce and move much higher again.The Trade:Sell the May $150 call and buy the May $155 call for a credit of 50 cents or more.The Strategy:The maximum potential profit for this trade is 50 cents if NFLX stock is trading at or below $150 at May expiration. Both call options would expire worthless. The maximum loss is $4.50 ($5 - $0.50) if NFLX is trading at or above $155 at May expiration. Breakeven is $150.50 at expiration based on a credit of 50 cents.Why would an options trader risk nine times what they are willing to make?How Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Can Generate 370% ReturnsThe odds. With the current delta of the short call at the time of this writing at around 0.18
column19: many option traders will say the option has an 18% chance of expiring in-the-money (ITM). That means based on the ""option trader's definition"" of delta
column20: there is an 82% chance of the option expiring out-of-the-money (OTM) and worthless leading to max profit.Like I mentioned above
column21: the stock can move lower
column22: sideways and higher as long as it does not close above the breakeven point at option's expiration. And you can consider exiting this position ahead of expirationGood luck!John Kmiecik is the head options instructor for Market Taker Mentoring

column1: Ford Motor Company (F) Stock Has a Secret Weapon;4/19/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSome in the media have suggested that Elon Musk was right when he stated sarcastically that institutional investors upset withTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) and its corporate governance should buyFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) instead.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockRecently
column3: I wonderedif Ford stock could ever hit $20
column4: a share price not seen since June 2001. I argued that dividends were not the answer; share repurchases
column5: smart R&D investments and increased debt repayments were.What I hadn't thought about were the special dividends.In early January
column6: Forddeclared a special dividend of 5 cents to go along with the usual quarterly payout of 15 cents. That's on top of the special dividend of 25 cents paid to investors a year earlier.Over the past 16 months
column7: Ford stock generated $1.20 in regular and special dividends for an annualized yield of 8.1%. That's awfully hard to resist in the low-yield era.Ford Stock Special DividendIn 2016
column8: Ford had $12.8 billion in free cash flow
column9: its highest level in the past decade. Of that
column10: $1 billion was used for special dividends (25 cents multiplied by an average of 4 billion shares outstanding) and $2.4 billion for regular dividends
column11: leaving lots of cash for debt repayment.10 Stocks That Won't Exist in a DecadeOver the past five years
column12: Ford issued and repaid$207.8 billionand $158.3 billion in debt
column13: respectively. In 2012
column14: it added just $3.2 billion in net debt (Debt issued minus debt repaid)
column15: its best job of trimming the debt load
column16: followed by 2016 when it added $7.2 billion in net debt.So the question for owners of F stock going forward is: Which is more preferable - Higher special dividends or increased debt repayment? Income investors would likely answer the former
column17: but that's short-sighted in my opinion considering higher interest rates are just around the corner.Ford shareholders would benefit greatly from a leaner balance sheet. That's especially true considering that profits in 2017 are expected to be lower than this past year
column18: with a nice rebound in 2018 off of new product introductions. That includes the Ford Bronco and higher margins due to $3 billion in cost reductions.In 2016
column19: Ford distributed $3.5 billionto investors. In 2017
column20: it expects that number to fall to $2.8 billion as a result of a special dividend one-fifth of the size as last year. If Ford's profits in 2017 are equivalent to those in 2014
column21: its free cash flow should be around $7 billion dollars. That only leaves a little more than $4 billion for debt repayment
column22: share repurchases
column23: etc.I'm a proponent of share repurchases in this instance because F stock is so beaten up
column24: but I believe debt repayment should take precedence. If Ford stock moves up to $15 by the fall
column25: however
column26: Ford management would be wise to slow its debt repayment and begin buying its stock in earnest as we move into the final quarter of the year.In 2018
column27: it's very likely that Ford's free cash flow will be higher than $12.5 billion
column28: leaving plenty of funds to make another 25 cent special dividend along with several billion in debt repayments and at least $1 billion in share repurchases.I'm a big fan of special dividends because you can turn the tap on and off as circumstances present themselves whereas regular dividends become something investors get accustomed to - they don't take kindly to any cuts or outright elimination of these payments.If you're an income investor
column29: I think it's fairly safe that Ford's regular dividend of 15 cents per quarter will continue well into the future. At a yield of 5.4%
column30: Ford stock is attractive indeed and that's without the special dividend added to the mix.The Sears Holdings Corp (SHLD) Stock Rally Is Pure FantasyThat said
column31: I find it hard to believe that over the next five years
column32: F stock will outperform Tesla stock - with or without the special dividend.Elon Musk might be outspoken
column33: the brightest generally are (think Steve Jobs
column34: Jeff Bezos
column35: etc.)
column36: but he's leading the automotive industry kicking and screaming into the future and that's always worth a big-time multiple.As of this writing

column1: Bank of America Corp (BAC) Stock Can Still Pay You Richly;4/19/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBank of America Corp(NYSE:BAC) reported earnings on Tuesday morning that beat on both the top and bottom lines. Revenues of $22.2 billion were better than expectations for $21.6 billion
column3: while earnings of 41 cents per share also exceeded the consensus mark of 36 cents. But BAC stock behaved  well
column4: weirdly.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrWhile BofA initially rallied on the earnings news

column7: and I expect the stock to languish over the coming weeks.And that's OK.On the surface
column8: earnings were impressive
column9: with a nice pop to net interest margins thanks to the Federal Reserve interest-rate hike. A closer looks highlights some concerns
column10: however. One is the drop in loan loss reserves
column11: which effectively is a huge piggy bank for the banks. By lowering their loss reserves
column12: they can effectively goose up earnings.InvestorPlaceMarket StrategistAnthony Mirhaydaridelves neatly into this in his BAC article.The 11 Best Dividend Stocks to BuyAnother worry is that most of the earnings beat (outside of lower loan loss reserves) was attributable to trading revenues

column14: trading revenues can be fickle. Core businesses
column15: such as mortgage origination and lending
column16: were less than stellar.Click to EnlargeFrom a technical perspective
column17: BAC stock did hold the critical support level at $22.30. It also bounced nicely off the 14-day Relative Strength Index oversold reading for the second time
column18: meaning Bank of America is still slightly positive (up 2.76%) year to date.Much of the initial euphoria that catapulted Bank of America 50% higher following Donald Trump's election victory has noticeably waned. Hopes for Dodd-Frank reform and a friendlier regulatory environment have diminished greatly
column19: especially following the Obamacare repeal defeat. While the Federal Reserve has raised rates once this year (a positive for NIM)
column20: the likelihood for three more rate increases in 2017 is just jawboning
column21: especially in light of slower economic growth. TheAtlanta Fedis now looking for just 0.5% expansion in Q1 GDP.So with many of the tailwinds for BAC stock now diminished
column22: I expect BofA to chop around the $22.30 support area for the next few months.To position for a period of consolidation
column23: a combination put sale and call spread sale makes sense.Our Trade on BAC StockSell the BAC July $22 puts at 90 cents and sell the BAC July $24/$26 call spread for 45 cents.The total credit received is $135 per combo. Ideally

column26: with a effective cost of $20.65.As of this writing

column1: Why Apple Could (but Won't) Buy Disney;4/19/2017;"As one of the largest companies in the world
column2: and with sales   of its iconic iPhone slowing
column3: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ: AAPL)  is facing speculation about how it can   continue to grow. CEO Tim Cook revealed during the January   earnings conference call that the company has made 15 to 20   acquisitions annually the past four years and that he believes   strategic value to be more important than size. He also noted   that the company had its best quarter ever for services and that   Apple's goal was to double that business over the next four   years.This outlook has led many to speculate that Apple is in the   market to make a big media acquisition to achieve that ambitious   goal. Add to that the company's record war chest of $246 billion
column4: and analysts can dream big.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani suggested last week   that Apple should consider buyingThe Walt Disney Company(NYSE: DIS)
column5: noting a number of potential synergies in the   matchup. Apple would immediately gain a foothold in the content   market
column6: based on Disney's treasure trove of intellectual   property
column7: and could immediately become a player in video   streaming. It would also help Apple achieve its goal of doubling   services revenue
column8: while acquiring a brand as iconic as its   own.makeArticleAd();Should Apple buy Disney? Image source: Pixabay.A stiff priceA deal like this would be predicated on a tax-repatriation   holiday. At the moment
column9: over 90% of Apple's cash is overseas
column10: and   the only way that will change is if there is a tax holiday
column11: that   allows management to bring it to the U.S. without writing a huge   check to Uncle Sam. Rumors of such a deal have been coming out of   the nation's capital for some time but have yet to   materialize.Consider also that Disney has a market cap of nearly $180   billion
column12: and any acquisition would come at a significant premium   over the company's current value. Factoring in a modest 32%   premium would result in a deal valued at $237 billion
column13: which   would nearly deplete Apple's coffers.Daryanani isn't the first to propose an Apple/Disney marriage.   Margate Capital's Samantha Greenberg pointed out in January that   Disney is the ""last remaining publicly traded non-controlled   content/IP company."" She noted that Apple would benefit from   exclusive content and make the company more immune to product   release cycles.Other potential matchupsSeveral other high-profile potential acquisitions have been   suggested over the years. Streaming giantNetflix
column14: Inc.(NASDAQ: NFLX) has been proposed as a way for Apple to jump-start   its ambitions for growth in its services business. In 2016
column15: Netflix generated $8.3 billion in global streaming revenue
column16: and   that number is only expected to grow as the company nears 100   million subscribers and continues its quest to penetrate its   nascent international markets.Electric-car makerTesla
column17: Inc.(NASDAQ: TSLA) has been a frequent recommendation among those   suggesting a massive Apple acquisition
column18: with some even suggestingElon Musk as a replacement for Apple's Tim Cook. Rumors   concerning Apple and a potential iCar have surfaced from time to   time. Musk has confirmed that he has had conversations with   Apple
column19: though he has declined to confirm the content of those   conversations. When Bloomberg asked if Tesla was for sale
column20: he   replied
column21: ""I think that's very unlikely
column22: because we need to stay   super focused on achieving
column23: creating a compelling mass-market   electric car.""Apple's biggest acquisition to date? Beats Music at $3     billion. Image source: Pixabay.It's a good story
column24: but...While analysts on Wall Street like to dream big
column25: the   likelihood that Apple will acquire Disney is small. Apple's head   of content
column26: Eddy Cue
column27: downplayed the idea of a megamerger at   Recode's Code Media conference in February. When asked about the   possibility of such an acquisition
column28: he said:[T]o the extent if we wanted to do what everybody else is     doing
column29: then you're right
column30: we might be better off buying     somebody or doing that. But that's not what we're trying to do.     We are trying to do something that's unique
column31: takes advantage of     our platforms
column32: and that really brings culture to it.While Apple makes numerous acquisitions every year
column33: its   largest to date has been Beats Music for $3 billion. That's a far   cry from the $237 billion a potential marriage with Disney might   entail. There are also many more ways for Apple to acquire   content or beef up its service revenue without emptying its war   chest. While it's true that anything is possible
column34: that doesn't   mean every idea makes sense.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column36: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column1: This is Audi's Tesla-Model-S Fighter. Will it Sell?;4/18/2017;"We've known for a while thatAudi AG(NASDAQOTH: AUDVF) is planning to release along-range battery-electric SUV early next   year
column2: the first component of its plan to directly challenge Silicon   Valley upstartTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) .Today
column3: Audi revealed a preview of the second component of that   plan. It's the sporty SUV-like vehicle you see here
column4: and Audi   said that it plans to bring something very much like it to market   in 2019.The Audi e-tron Sportback concept is a preview of a     battery-electric Audi that will arrive at dealers in 2019.     Image source: Audi AG.makeArticleAd();What we know about Audi's latest Tesla-fighterOfficially
column5: the Audi e-tron Sportback concept is a show car
column6: set to go on display at the Auto Shanghai show next week. But   Audi wasn't coy: CEO Rupert Stadler said that a production   version of the coupe-like SUV will go on sale in 2019.Audi also wasn't coy about sharing technical details. The   e-tron Sportback has a 95-kilowatt-hour battery pack powering   three electric motors
column7: one in front and two in the rear. It's   all-wheel-drive
column8: of course
column9: and while it's not   Tesla-Ludicrous-mode fast
column10: it's pretty quick for a big SUV-like   vehicle: Audi claims a zero-to-100-kilometers-per-hour   (62-miles-per-hour) time of 4.5 seconds.Another view of the Audi e-tron Sportback concept. Image     source: Audi AG.The electric Audi's construction is broadly similar to Tesla's   approach. The liquid-cooled lithium-ion battery pack is   positioned between the vehicle's axles
column11: below the passenger   compartment
column12: giving the e-tron Sportback a low center of gravity   and near-equal (52:48) weight distribution.Image source: Audi AG.Audi said the 95-kWh battery pack gives the e-tron Sportback   range ""in excess of 500 kilometers"" on the European test cycle.   That probably translates to ""in excess of 260 or so miles"" on the   stricter U.S. test (but it could be well ""in excess""). Audi   didn't give details on recharging times
column13: except to say that the   production version will be compatible with both AC and DC   chargers that use the Combined Charging System format.The unusual design might prove popularStylistically
column14: the e-tron Sportback combines the sportiness of   a coupe with a four-door cabin and a crossover SUV's ride height   -- an intriguing set of choices that could make it a compelling   alternative to a Tesla Model S when it arrives in 2019. (Tesla   has done a great job of updating the Model S's technology over   time
column15: but the car's basic shape and architecture may seem dated   in a couple of years
column16: next to the Audi.)The Audi e-tron Sportback concept's interior looks nearly     ready for production. Image source: Audi AG.Inside
column17: it's definitely a step or two ahead of current Teslas   (no surprise
column18: this is an Audi.) We only have photos to go on   right now
column19: but the e-tron Sportback's interior and dash look   close to production-intent -- I see nothing that's obviously a   show-car flight of fancy.In terms of production
column20: Audi's electric-vehicle effort is   supported by corporate parentVolkswagen's(NASDAQOTH: VLKAY) aggressive
column21: big-budget move toward electric   vehicles. Nearly all of VW's brands are known to have long-range   electric vehicles under development. Audi's economies of scale   (via VW) could well eclipse Tesla's by early next decade.So will it sell?The production version of the Audi e-tron Sportback will   certainly draw interest when it comes to market -- if nothing   else
column22: it's an attractive design. Whether it'll sell in large   numbers will depend on whether Audi can produce it in large   numbers
column23: on whether it's offered at a competitive price -- and   possibly on how well Audi's first long-range electric
column24: due next   year
column25: is received.Audi's e-tron quattro concept
column26: first shown in 2015
column27: previews     the electric Audi SUV that will arrive early next year. The     production version of the e-tron Sportback will follow a year     or so later. Image source: Audi AG.It'll also depend on how well the electric Audi's technology   matches up to Tesla's: Audi's numbers are in the right ballpark
column28: but the details will matter. On the other hand
column29: in Audi's favor
column30: it's a safe bet that its production electrics will match or beat   Tesla's Model S and Model X on interior quality and overall fit   and finish. Those may be compelling points for mainstream   luxury-vehicle buyers who like the idea of an electric
column31: but who   may have had qualms about Teslas.We'll know more as we get closer to production. But right now
column32: Audi's electric-vehicle effort looks very promising.10 stocks we like better than AUDI AG VORMALS     AUDIWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column34: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Tesla Torpedoes Shares of PACCAR and Cummins;4/18/2017;"Every day
column2: Wall Street analysts upgrade some stocks
column3: downgrade others
column4: and ""initiate coverage"" on a few more. But do     these analysts even know what they're talking about? Today
column5: we're taking one high-profile Wall Street pick and putting it     under the microscope...I'm afraid it's bad news for investors inPACCAR(NASDAQ: PCAR) stock today -- and owners ofCummins(NYSE: CMI) stock
column6: too. Elon Musk is building an electric truck
column7: and at least one analyst thinks that could spell doomsday for   Cummins and PACCAR.The news first broke last week
column8: whenTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) CEOElon Musk tweetedthat he has a ""Tesla Semi truck unveil set for September."" That   may have been a lot sooner than investors were expecting
column9: given   that Tesla doesn't even have its Model 3 sedan on the market yet.   It certainly seems to have spooked investment banker Piper   Jaffray
column10: which responded by downgrading shares of both PACCAR and   Cummins this morning.makeArticleAd();Here are three things you need to know about why it did   that.Image source: Cummins.1. Why PACCAR and Cummins should fear the coming   E-pocalypsePACCAR builds semis -- the enormous tractors that pull the   trailers that make up the 18-wheelers on our highways
column11: carrying   goods to and fro. Cummins builds internal combustion engines to   power those semis. As such
column12: Musk's intention to build an electric   truck capable of doing the same work that PACCAR's trucks do
column13: and   with a power source that could be more efficient than Cummins'   and that will certainly look ""greener"" to environmentalists
column14: poses a direct threat to the business models of both PACCAR and   Cummins.2. Tesla threatens PACCARPiper Jaffray makes no bones about this. In a downgrade   reported this morning onStreetInsider.com
column15: the analyst warns that Tesla's new ""Class 8"" electric truck   will have a ""potential disruptive impact"" on PACCAR.That makes sense. Even if Musk only unveils a model truck in   September
column16: and does not actually begin offering one for sale
column17: PACCAR could see an impact on its own sales and profits
column18: as truck   companies hedge their bets and potentially put off purchases of   old-tech trucks in order to be able to spend that money on   battery-powered Tesla semis later.This could be the reason Piper is cutting $0.02 from its   earnings projection for PACCAR this year
column19: and $0.07 more next   year
column20: ratcheting back estimates to $3.74 in 2017
column21: and $4.43 in   2018. It's also downgrading PACCAR stock to neutral and cutting   its price target by 8%
column22: to $66.3. Why Cummins should worry
column23: tooThe news is no better for Cummins. AsTheFly.comwrites
column24: Piper is worried that ""companies like Tesla are aiming to   supplant [Cummins'] products."" And while intention isn't   accomplishment
column25: Piper believes the risk is real enough to begin   taking chips off the table.After all
column26: Cummins shares are up 25% over the past 52 weeks
column27: versus only a 15% gain for PACCAR stock. Piper Jaffray believes   that ""Cummins' multiple has expanded to a fair level
column28: and   there's little left to be gained by buying the stock -- and   perhaps a lot to be lost if Tesla succeeds in supplanting   Cummins' internal combustion engines as the standard for powering   semis.Curiously
column29: at the same time as Piper is downgrading Cummins   stock to neutral
column30: and cutting its price target by 10% (to $144   per share)
column31: the analyst is raising its estimates for the   company's earnings both this year (to $8.14) and next ($9.59).   These are strange moves in a downgrade
column32: but perhaps Piper sees   the risk from Tesla as farther out
column33: and not so immediate as the   risk posed to PACCAR.Bonus thing: Keep your eye on the profits ballThe one thing Piper doesn't spend a lot of time on in making   either of these downgrades is pointing out that while Tesla may   pose a threat to PACCAR and Cummins
column34: that doesn't necessarily   makeTesla stocka better investment thaneitherof them.Remember: Even if Piper is cutting profits estimates for   PACCAR and Cummins this year
column35: it still expects both companies to   be firmly profitable this year
column36: and next year as well. In   contrast
column37: Tesla --which Piper Jaffray likes-- is not expected to earn any kind of profit either this year or   next
column38: and may only earn as little as $0.20 per share in 2019.So even if I agree in general with Piper's assessment that   Cummins stock costs too much at 18 times earnings
column39: and that   PACCAR costsmuchtoo much at 44 times trailing earnings (and I do agree)
column40: that   doesn't necessarily make Tesla a buy at infinity-times-negative   earnings. Small consolation to Cummins and PACCAR investors
column41: I   know -- but the numbers don't lie.Even if Cummins and PACCAR stocks are not buys
column42: I don't   believe that Tesla stock is
column43: either.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column45: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Here's How Apple Can Reach a $1 Trillion Valuation;4/18/2017;"""I sold my stock in Apple back in 1995. If I would have held it longer
column2: I would have been a millionaire!
column3: exclaims that one guy that we all totally know.While that guy tends to talk about ""what could have been"" a little too frequently to be taken seriously
column4: he does have a point here. After decades of consistent growth
column5: interrupted by just a few down periods
column6: AppleAAPLis the world's most-valuable publicly-traded company with a market capitalization of nearly $750 million.Perhaps no company has burned its imagery into the minds of the public better than this technology behemoth. The Cupertino
column7: California-based firm is more than just a brand-it's an influencer of culture. As Apple goes
column8: so do the masses. Its logo is iconic; its products are timeless.And investors still want more.So how can Apple
column9: with its well-established product lines and billions of existing customers
column10: break into uncharted territory? How does the one on top climb higher? How does the biggest get even bigger?The short answer: by trying something new.Old Dog
column11: New TricksOut of the many new options that Apple has to test out
column12: it seems like the company is taking self-driving cars the most seriously. Last Friday
column13: the iPhone maker received a permit to begin testing self-driving cars in California
column14: and it looks like Apple's formerly top-secret autonomous vehicle project is finally ready to take the next step (also read:Apple Gets Self-Driving Car Permit: What's at Stake for the Industry?).However
column15: we are still-at the very least-several years away from an ""iCar
column16: and Apple is likely to meet stiff competition from its industry competitors in this field.On top of the big-name automakers like TeslaTSLA
column17: General MotorsGM
column18: FordF
column19: and many others working on self-driving cars
column20: tech companies like Alphabet Inc.GOOGLand IntelINTCare also working on their own autonomous vehicle projects (also read:Intel Buys Mobileye: Are More Driverless Car Deals in the Future?).The self-driving car space is sure to be crowded
column21: but a brand like Apple won't have to worry about name recognition
column22: and if the company's previous products are any evidence
column23: Apple's car project will likely result in a sleek
column24: user-friendly
column25: and high-performing vehicle.Becoming a major player in what could be a world-changing industry
column26: especially one that is still at its infancy like this one
column27: would certainly help Apple gain even more value. Of course
column28: that's far from the only thing the Tim Cook-led company can do to bring its market cap over $1 trillion.If the internet-and its vast array of unfounded rumors-were left to decide how Apple can grow
column29: it would want the tech giant to enter the world of media production by buying DisneyDIS.Yes
column30: the age-old ""Apple should buy Disney"" conjecture is alive and well
column31: despite no real evidence pointing towards any merger talks between the two companies.And while it may be pure fiction
column32: an Apple-Disney merger does speak to something that is currently missing from Apple's portfolio of products and projects. For all of the snazzy devices that the company makes
column33: it owns very little of what its customers access on those devices.Sure
column34: Apple Music has growninsanely fast
column35: but Apple has notably not yet entered the world of video streaming or original programming. The Apple TV device is a strong candidate for any cord-cutter
column36: and an Apple-owned over-the-top streaming service has been rumored for years
column37: but buying a media company would immediately bolster Apple's arsenal if it does want to seriously contend in this space at some point.Bottom LineThe goal of a publicly-traded company is not to reach new market-cap milestones
column38: break records
column39: or make headlines. In fact
column40: it is quite a bit simpler than that. All public companies
column41: big or small
column42: need to provide value to their shareholders.This means that reaching a $1 trillion valuation is likely not an explicit goal for Apple right now. Instead
column43: Tim Cook and company are probably plotting on how to effectively deliver the next must-have product
column44: while also continuing to pump out the Apple products we all know and love.These goals are
column45: of course
column46: intended to help the company grow and provide that desired value for its shareholders.But an Apple that's worth $1 trillion is not that far away
column47: and the company has several obvious new routes it can take if it wants to add the nearly $250 million in market cap needed to reach the milestone.Only time will reveal how Apple intends on continuing its ridiculous growth
column48: but in the meantime
column49: we can continue to speculate. Will Apple become a self-driving car giant
column50: or will it purchase a media company and take the entertainment business by storm? I can't wait to find out.Sell These Stocks. Now.Just released: today's 220 Zacks Rank #5 Strong Sells demand urgent attention. If any are lurking in your portfolio or Watch List

column9: the tech stalwart became acquisitive. Thanks to its shopping spree

column11: investors can appreciate the intellect behind the acquisitions.The$8.5 billion dealfor Skype is a prime example. Over the past ten years

column20: and thereby

column23: but the idea that nobody job hunts in the old ""pick up the phone and hustle"" way. Just like Skype

column25: as is mentioned by all of Wall Street

column27: the company's venture into the cloud

column30: it's gaining increasing adoption among the top U.S. businesses. One only needs to reference the gargantuan revenue growth to see how important Azure is to MSFT stock.Don't Overlook the CoreAll of these are great bullish arguments. However
column31: I still love Microsoft stock for its core
column32: PC-based business.On the surface
column33: that seems like an oddball statement. Anyone that's anyone knows that the PC market is essentially dead on arrival. To survive in consumer retail

column42: the tablet platform is inherently a disaster. What would take minutes on a tablet can be squared away in seconds with a keyboard and mouse via the Surface.Should You Buy Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock or General Motors Company (GM)?And when you're talking about PCs
