column1: Should You Buy Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock or General Motors Company (GM)?;4/18/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEarlier this month
column3: Tesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) briefly surpassedGeneral Motors Company(NYSE:GM) as the largest U.S. automaker based on market capitalization
column4: causing many to question whether to add TSLA stock to their portfolios.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockSo far this year
column5: TSLA stock has gained a whopping 40% and its market cap rose as high as $51 billion. By comparison
column6: GM stock is down roughly 4% on the year with a market cap that's neck and neck with Tesla stock.The fact that investors are flocking to Elon Musk & Co. over a tried-and-true GM stock speaks volumes about the confidence Wall Street has in Tesla's future.Because Tesla has only been able to produce a profit twice since going public
column7: TSLA stock's current valuation reflects its future potential. Even TSLA CEO Elon Musk admitted the stock was""absurdly overvalued""based on past performance
column8: but said the price instead reflects the future cash flow Tesla shareholders can expect.So where does that leave GM? Has the car company been overtaken or is the Tesla rally irrational exuberance? My guess is that it's a little bit of both.TSLA Stock vs. GM StockSure
column9: Tesla stock overtook GM in terms of market cap earlier this month
column10: but GM is still head and shoulders in front of TSLA in terms of financial performance. Tesla sells just a fraction of the number of vehicles sold by General Motors each year
column11: and GM reported profits upward of $9 billion in 2016. Tesla? A $675 millionloss.Comparing the two companies in terms of investment potential is difficult. They are in two very different categories! While GM is an established value brand that plays by investors' rules
column12: Tesla is a cash-burning upstart that trades solely on future potential.As an investor
column13: the way a company makes and uses its money is an important metric to consider
column14: and GM clearly wins in this category.Despite worries that the U.S. auto market has reached its peak
column15: GM's management is projecting per-share earnings of more than $6 this year and the firm is undergoing several operational changes to further improve its profitability.GM isdropping it's less profitable European business
column16: which is expected to save the firm around $1 billion. Not only that
column17: but General Motors is shifting its production so that all of its vehicles can be produced using just four platforms. Such a move would cut down on costs dramatically and improve manufacturing time and efficiency.Tesla has been touted as arguably the most innovative automaker in the U.S. because of the firm's autonomous driving efforts and its success in making luxury electric vehicles.However
column18: just because TSLA was first in the electric car market doesn't mean it will remain at the top of the pack. Competitors like GM andFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) have their own fleet of electric cars that are continually being improved.Not only that
column19: but GM has been working on its own autonomous driving technology and the firm's substantially larger budget and experience in the auto industry makes it one of the best contenders in the industry.Astudy by Navigate Researchnamed GM as having the most potential in the self-driving space of all 18 companies evaluated. Tesla
column20: on the other hand
column21: came in toward the bottom half of the pack.Bottom Line on TSLA and GMThat's not to say that buying TSLA shares is a bad idea. The company boasts something that no other U.S. automobile maker has - youth. Tesla is just starting to iron out the details of its operations and has been ramping up production.TSLA is a growth stock
column22: something that GM can't ever claim because the company's established business doesn't have as much room for expansion as TSLA's does.Bank of America Corp (BAC) Stock Is a Screaming Buy After Q1 EarningsNot only that
column23: but even though TSLA's core business is electric vehicles
column24: the company is more than just an automaker - TSLA is also a tech firm and an energy company
column25: two spaces that are likely to see a great deal of growth in the years to come.GM stock offers investors security and consistency while TSLA is likely to bring volatility to your portfolio. For long-term investors with a stomach for risk
column26: TSLA stock is a good bet. For investors looking for solid companies with sound financials
column27: however
column28: GM is the better pick.As of this writing
column29: Laura Hoy did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Top Emerging Markets Stocks to Buy NowTrade Micron Technology

column1: Tesla Product Pricing Volatility Is a Headache for Consumers;4/17/2017;"Compared to larger automakers
column2: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) changes its product pricing relatively more   frequently. We're not just talking about international pricing
column3: where adjustments are often needed to compensate for foreign   exchange rate fluctuations; U.S. pricing is often a moving   target. That presents some unique challenges for customers that   don't know if or when a price change may be imminent
column4: or if   they're better off buying before or after such a change.That can potentially be a headache for consumers.Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();""Fair?""Over the weekend
column5: Tesla updated its design studio to reflect   the previously announced discontinuation of the Model S 60 and   60D
column6: which Tesla said would be available until April 16
column7: 2017.   The Model S lineup now starts with 75 kWh battery packs and up
column8: similar to Model X
column9: which saw its software-limited 60 kWh version   discontinued last year after just a few months of   availability.As mentioned last month

column11: the entry-level Model S base price would have jumped from   $68
column13: 500. That assumption very well may have led a   number of customers to order the 60 or 60D ahead of the   discontinuation
column14: believing that a meaningful price increase was   coming.@elonmusk@pkingdesignNew S60 owner for 2 months
column15: now S75 = S60 price + more features   (liftgate/roof)
column16: yet I have to pay $2000 for 60->75Kwh   upgrade? Fair?- Ramki (@Wertyu8088)April 17
column17: 2017Here's the thing: Tesla tweaked its Model S 75 and 75D pricing   and the new configurations offer even better value. A   single-motor 75 now starts at $69
column19: 500 more than a   single-motor 60 used to cost -- while adding the new all-glass   roof and power liftgate as standard features. The glass roof   option used to cost $1
column20: 500 and the power liftgate used to only be   included as part of the $3
column21: 500 premium upgrades package. Tesla   also reduced the price to upgrade any software-limited 60 kWh   packs to 75 kWh capacity to better reflect the new pricing.Last weekend's adjustment is just the latest in recent years.   In 2015
column22: Tesla dropped the 60 kWh ($70
column23: 000) Model S for the first   time and moved to 70 kWh ($75
column24: 000) versions. There was a $1
column25: 500   price hike in early 2016 associated with the Model S facelift
column26: before Tesla reintroduced the software-limited 60 kWh a few   months later at $66
column27: 000. That price was bumped up by $2
column28: 000 in   November with no explanation to start at $68
column29: 000.Tesla did not respond immediately to a request for comment
column30: but provided the following statement toElectrekregarding the recent price changes:Periodically we have adjusted pricing and available options     to best reflect the value of our products and our customers'     preferences. Today's updates include slight price decreases to     our 75
column31: 75D and 90D models to account for the discontinuation     of our 60 kWh models
column32: and next week we will be implementing     slight price increases to our higher end 100D and P100D models.     We expect our total average selling price to remain almost     exactly the same.Price increases for our 100D and P100D models will take     effect on April 24
column33: 2017 to best accommodate customers already     in the order process
column34: while price decreases for 75
column35: 75D and 90D     models will take effect today.It's still better than dealing with dealersThese changes may be frustrating for consumers to navigate

column38: according toAutomotive News. These programs indirectly but inevitably affect the price that   consumers have to pay.Automotive Newsalso previously reported on pricing volatility forGM's new Chevy Bolt as dealers test different price points to gauge   demand at the local level.In other words
column39: most car purchases lack price transparency and   suffer from volatility purely as a function of the dealer model

column1: Has Honda Already Fallen Behind General Motors on Electric-Car Technology?;4/17/2017;"Honda Motor Company(NYSE: HMC) finally offered investors some
column2: er
column3: clarityaround its green-car strategy. In a presentation in New York last   week
column4: Honda showed off all three variants of its Clarity sedan --   powered by plug-in hybrid
column5: fuel cell
column6: and battery electric   drivetrains.But the details left a lot of analysts wondering exactly what   Honda is thinking with these products -- and whether Honda is   already falling behind in the emerging race to bring electric   cars to the mass market.The 3 Honda Clarity models at Honda's New York event. From     the left: Clarity Electric
column7: Clarity Plug-in Hybrid
column8: and Clarity     Fuel Cell. Image source: Honda Motor Co.
column9: Ltd.makeArticleAd();What Honda said about its new Clarity green-car modelsAt a press event at the New York International Auto Show
column10: Honda officially unveiled the Clarity Plug-in Hybrid and Clarity   Electric sedans. The two Claritys join a third
column11: theHonda Clarity Fuel Cell
column12: which went on sale in parts of California late last year.All three Clarity variants share the same basic shape and   features. They're four-door sedans about the size (inside and   out) of Honda's popular and roomy Accord sedan. Like the Accord
column13: the Clarity triplets look good inside
column14: with crisp styling
column15: comfortable seats
column16: and sensibly laid-out controls.As with the other Clarity models
column17: the interior of the     Clarity Electric is typical of Honda. That's a good thing.     Image source: Honda Motor Co.
column18: Ltd.But unlike the handsome-if-generic Accord
column19: the Claritys'   exterior styling is best described as...quirky. Honda said the   Claritys' lines were optimized for low aerodynamic resistance
column20: but they also seem to have been calculated to make the 3 Clarity   models stand out from more mainstream vehicles.The Clarity Plug-in Hybrid combines a 1.5 liter gasoline   four-cylinder with a 181-horsepower electric motor and a 17   kilowatt-hour battery pack. Honda expects it to earn an EPA   miles-per-gallon-equivalent rating of 105
column21: with a respectable   electric-only driving range of 42 miles.The Clarity Electric has a 161-horsepower electric motor   powered by a 25.5 kilowatt-hour battery pack. Honda says it can   be fully recharged in just over three hours with a 240-volt   charger
column22: and it can get to 80% charge in 30 minutes with a DC   Fast charger.The Clarity Electric will launch in select U.S. markets later   this year
column23: while the Clarity Plug-in Hybrid will launch in 2018.   Honda is targeting sales of 75
column24: 000 Claritys (of all types) in the   U.S. over the next four years.What is Honda thinking with the Clarity Electric's tiny   range?The biggest question on everyone's minds had to do with the   Clarity Electric and its tiny 25.5 kilowatt-hour battery pack
column25: which is expected to earn an EPA range rating of just 80   miles. That's a very short range for a car with a price tag   that's expected to be around $35

The Bolt offers an EPA-rated range   of 238 miles -- for about the same price Honda is expected to ask   for its Clarity Electric.The Clarity Electric is expected to have a range of just 80     miles. Image source: Honda Motor Co.
column27: Ltd.Honda executives in New York argued that the Clarity Electric   should have a somewhat higher price because it's a larger   vehicle. The Bolt is a small crossover
column28: while the Clarity   Electric is a midsize sedan. But that's weak sauce: Plain and   simple
column29: Honda's electric car is coming out of the gate a couple   of big steps behind the competition. (Just wait untilTeslalaunches its Model 3.)Frankly
column30: the Clarity Electric's range is an embarrassment for   Honda. It suggests that the proud Japanese automaker has fallen   behind on this important emerging technology.Will the new Honda Clarity models sell?Honda's goal of 75

column33: the Accord   Hybrid.I certainly don't see the Clarity Electric or Clarity Fuel   Cell generating more than a handful of sales over the next four   years -- at least

column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe first-quarter earnings report fromNetflix

column5: and we got it. But it wasn't at all what investors might expect.makeArticleAd();Source:Vivian D Nguyen via Flickr (Modified)First-quarter profits beat the consensus
column6: with earnings of 40 cents per share topping estimates by 3 cents. However
column7: subscriber growth disappointed relative to even Netflix's seemingly cautious guidance. Q2 guidance came in above expectations
column8: though
column9: which fits the narrative coming from Netflix itself.Guidance given in January after Netflix's Q4 results set the table for a slightly different view. The company projected lower subscriber growth in Q1
column10: due to a tough comparison (including Netflix's global launch the year before) and a back-loaded content slate.But Netflix also guided for improved subscriber growth over the rest of the year
column11: thanks to a stronger content slate. And it forecast a sharp jump in operating margins to about 9% for Q1
column12: and 7% for the full year as some of those content and marketing costs kicked in.In other words
column13: Netflix seemed to set up 2017 as the first step in Netflix stock moving away from being a pure growth play - one in which investor attention focused solely on subscriber numbers. Bears on NFLX stock often have derided the fact that Netflix earnings ""don't matter."" Yet the company itself seems intent on countering that narrative
column14: including an aim detailed in the Q4 shareholder letter to ""balance growth and profitability.""From that standpoint
column15: the Q1 Netflix earnings report seems likely to do little to settle the argument between the bears and the bulls.Netflix Earnings Were Good EnoughNetflix stock is down modestly in after-hours trading
column16: but I'd expect a reversal. There's enough in the Q1 report to keep NFLX stock elevated - at least for now.5 Tech Stocks to Buy for Growth AND DividendsIn its first-quarter shareholder letter
column17: Netflix doubled down on its 2017 narrative
column18: telling readers that ""starting this year
column19: we can be primarily measured by revenue growth and (global) operating margins as our primary metrics."" Perhaps not coincidentally
column20: Netflix earnings look strong on both fronts.Revenue increased 34.7% year-over-year in Q1
column21: pretty much matching Street estimates. Guidance for a 31% jump in Q2 appears ahead of expectations as well. Subscriber growth did narrowly miss guidance. But Netflix is projecting 3.2 million net additions in Q2 - nearly double the year-prior total. The argument heading into the quarter - that better content would drive more growth after Q1 - seems to hold.Meanwhile
column22: operating margin for Q1 came in at a handsome 9.7%. There
column23: too
column24: Netflix is sticking to its story
column25: with Q2 EBIT margin guided down to 4.4%
column26: with much of the difference coming from the shift of the new season ofHouse of Cardsinto Q2.Netflix stock neared an all-time high heading into the report
column27: and is down a bit under 2% in early after-hours trading. There could be some weakness in NFLX stock on Tuesday
column28: if only because of what a 3%+ gain on Monday priced in.That said
column29: Netflix bears expecting a post-earnings collapse should be disappointed.Netflix Stock Might Not Be Good EnoughAt the same time
column30: it's hard to argue that Q1 was a blowout quarter
column31: particularly in terms of growth. Cash flow remains a concern. Netflix earnings were positive
column32: but free cash flow wasnegative$423 million. The company guided post-Q1 for cash burn of roughly $2 billion in 2017.Competition is an issue too - one Netflix addressed directly in its shareholder letter. It said followingAmazon.com
column33: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) into live sports was not a ""strategy that we think is smart for us."" (Amazoninked a dealto air Thursday night football last week.) Netflix wrote that so-called VMVPDs like Sling TV
column34: HuluandAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) YouTube weren't a competitive threat
column35: as Netflix is a ""largely complementary"" service.In other words
column36: it'sComcast Corporation(NASDAQ:CMCSA) andCharter Communications
column37: Inc.(NASDAQ:CHTR) that should be worried
column38: not NFLX stock holders.Advanced Micro Devices
column39: Inc. (AMD) Stock Isn't What Goldman ThinksMany bears would disagree
column40: however
column41: and would point to the cash burn as what is required from Netflix simply to maintain slowly moderating subscriber growth. Although  Q1 fits Netflix's narrative
column42: it's not going to dissuade those bears.With Netflix stock just off an all-time high set last month
column43: and NFLX shares now valued at over $60 billion
column44: anything less than a blowout likely is priced in.Where NFLX Stock Goes From HereAll told

column46: not solve it.Bulls can point to growth and margin expansion; bears can highlight cash burn and valuation. Coming out of Q1

column1: Apple Gets Self-Driving Car Permit: What's at Stake for the Industry?;4/17/2017;"Last Friday

The fundamentals are backing up this sob story - margins are cratering due to a price war withNike Inc(NYSE:NKE) andAdidas AG (ADR)(OTCMKTS:ADDYY) that's clearly not winnable.Under Armour is in desperate need of reinforcements.Lululemon Athletica Inc.(NASDAQ:LULU) could do the trick.The Under Armour Growth Story Is BrokenIn March
column5: I discussed the growth story at Under Armourand how Jefferies analyst Randal Konik believes it's still intact. Personally
column6: I find that argument hard to swallow when you consider that Under Armour's 21.8% revenue increase in 2016 translated to just $9 million in additional operating profit.Nike
column7: a far more mature company
column8: did a much better job converting revenues to profits in the past year providing plenty of ammunition
column9: in my opinion
column10: that Under Armour's growth story is in fact broken.7 Top Emerging Markets Stocks to Buy NowA month earlier
column11: I suggested thatUnder Armour CEO and founder Kevin Plank remove himself as chief executivebefore he does irreparable harm to his company and UAA stock. Nothing that has happened since has changed my mind. It's too personal for Plank; he's not going to be able to do the things that need to be done to turn the ship in the right direction. At least
column12: not quickly.Phil Knight had the right idea when he and the board chose to bring in an outsider to run Nike; they just hired the wrong guy. It happens. But at least NKE tried to shake things up.Bringing in a new CFO is not the solution.Time to Circle the WagonsI thoughtVF Corp(NYSE:VFC) would bethe company to make a playfor Lululemon
column13: but it has had its owntroublesto deal with
column14: and that has kept the apparel conglomerate relatively quiet on the M&A front. That could change at any time
column15: so the fact Under Armour is in its weakest position since its founding in 1997 makes this an opportune time for LULU to consider a deal.Under Armour and Lululemon ought to come together to fight Nike and Adidas. Both firms currently face serious challenges as they cope with growth. Together
column16: they would make a formidable team.LULU founder Chip Wilson floated the idea back in February when he rented a Vancouver bus shelter outside the company's headquarters that stated:""Lululemon
column17: Buy Under Armour Now!""""Lululemon's way more profitable
column18: Wilson told CNBC while talking about the reasons for placing the bus shelter ad. ""It's super weak right now. (I) wouldn't want to be working at Under Armour right now.""The irony of that statement is that LULU stock took a tumble March 30
column19: falling more than 20% on weak Q1 2017 guidance.One week before announcing its fourth-quarter earnings
column20: InvestorPlace contributor Laura Hoy made a whole bunch of argumentswhy a Lululemon/Under Armour tie-up made no sense. While I respect her opinion
column21: I think she has it wrong for a couple of reasons. Her valuation concerns make sense
column22: but she's forgetting several attributes of both businesses that had Wilson broaching the subject in the first place.5 Reasons Why Lululemon and Under Armour Should CombineHere's a quick-hit list of reasons why a merger would make sense right now:Lululemon has higher gross margins than Under Armour; LULU's are getting stronger
column23: UAA's are getting weaker.LULU is generating free cash flow
column24: Under Armour is not.Lululemon is overweighted to a female customer while Under Armour has more men buying its clothing. A tie-up solves that dilemma.Lululemon doesn't sell shoes. Under Armour gives them that category on a platter.Lululemon is more about lifestyle wear while Under Armour was founded on performance wear. Together
column25: they could tackle both markets head on giving Nike and Adidas a run for their money.Bottom Line for UAA StockIn my opinion (Chip Wilson probably doesn't agree)
column26: Lululemon CEO Laurent Potdevin would make an ideal leader of the combined company because he has managed to re-ignite LULU profitability over the past three years while continuing to improve its sourcing and quality control.Chipotle Mexican Grill

column28: the team in place is a heck of a lot better than it was before his hiring. I see good things ahead for the company and its stock despite the naysayers.Under Armour
column29: on the other hand
column30: has a CEO who is too busy empire building (he's got aliquor brand) to realize that he's losing a war he can't possibly win.As my InvestorPlace colleague James Brumley so aptly said
column31: ""Under Armour stock needs a change

column1: Should You Buy Tesla
column2: Inc. Stock? 3 Pros
column3: 3 Cons (TSLA);4/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has an awfully active Twitter account. He used it earlier this month to gloat
column5: tweeting: ""Stormy weather in shortville "" He's not wrong. TSLA stock has charged up from $180 in late 2016 to a new all-time high of $313 in April 2017.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe bulls have declared victory
column6: suggestingTesla shares are headed for $400
column7: or even higher. Not surprisingly
column8: bears continue to argue that TSLA is overvalued and heading for a massive fall.While momentum clearly is on Tesla's side
column9: it'd be wise not to tune out the bear camp completely. There are still several good reasons why TSLA shares could suffer a serious decline from here.So should you by TSLA stock? We'll take a look at the pros and cons to decide.ConsBloated Market Cap:Over the past month
column10: Tesla stock hit a significant milestone. It passed
column11: at least briefly
column12: the market caps of bothFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) andGeneral Motors Company(NYSE:GM).Yes
column13: I know Musk is a visionary and Tesla is working on a revolutionary future for the auto industry. Still
column14: it's worth taking a moment to consider Tesla's long-term value. General Motors and Ford are both behemoth American companies that are top-tier world competitors. Tesla
column15: by contrast
column16: sells a minuscule number of vehicles and has never shown its business model to be capable of producing consistent profits or cash flow.7 'Best of the Best' Stocks to Buy for the Second QuarterPonzi Scheme?You often hear TSLA bears describing the company as some sort of accounting trick. However
column17: that negative sentiment went much more mainstream last week.Leading North American vehicle retailerAutoNation
column18: Inc.(NYSE:AN) CEO Mike Jackson used some pointed language recently. He stated that Tesla: ""is either one of the great Ponzi schemes of all time"" or that it might turn out alright for investors.From 2009 onward
column19: Tesla's free cash flow has grown increasingly negative. Apart from 2013
column20: the company's cash burn has worsened almost every year. Cash outflow has topped $1 billion each of the past three years. The bail-out of the cash-incineratingSolarCitywill make Tesla's cash generation situation even more perilous.Recent Delivery Momentum May Slow:Tesla recently announced 25
column21: 000 deliveries for the previous quarter. That's a record. It's worth considering how Tesla pulled that off.One TSLA stock analystnotedthat Tesla changed its terminology. It used to discuss deliveries to ""end-customers."" Now it simply says ""customers."" Tesla also appears to have sold almost as many vehicles in Asia as North America this quarter; the company typically performs much more strongly in North America.Put it all together
column22: and it suggests that Tesla may have sold a bunch of vehicles to distributors rather than end customers. It's fine if Tesla is setting up a distribution network; it could be a solid strategic move. But don't expect a repeat of this quarter's strong performance if that's the case.ProsProbably Not a Ponzi Scheme:It's not hard to find a mountain of articles suggesting Tesla is near insolvency.In my view
column23: the SolarCity acquisition was utterly indefensible and did much to fuel this bearish line of attack. However
column24: there isn't anything inherently wrong with operating consistently free cash flow negative during the growth stage of a business.For many years
column25: a bears ranted aboutAmazon.com
column26: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) and its flimsy balance sheet. The company made little to no cash from operations
column27: to say nothing of earnings per share. If credit markets had frozen over at an inopportune company
column28: Amazon could have been sunk. However
column29: Amazon's calculated risk paid off. It has reached the inflection point where its fiscal position is sound.If Musk can deliver anything close to what he's suggested
column30: Tesla
column31: Inc. will get to that point in a couple of years as well. If you believe in Musk
column32: you want him to lever up now. It will produce better results for TSLA stock in the long run.Tesla Isn't as Unprofitable as People Suggest: A cursory reading of popular sources suggests that Tesla loses money on every vehicle it sells. See headlines such as""Tesla burns cash
column33: loses more than $4
column34: 000 on every car sold.""But this idea is based on an incomplete understanding of accounting.Yes
column35: Tesla loses money overall. However
column36: this is due to a lack of scale. On each actual car that Tesla sells
column37: it makes a gross profit. This profit is generally in the 20%-30% range. That's plenty high if you are selling a large number of cars. As it is
column38: Tesla isn't selling enough vehicles to come all its other overhead costs. These costs
column39: such as R&D
column40: get spread across each unit sold. It isn't selling enough - yet. Once again
column41: if Musk can perform
column42: this bearish point will look petty soon enough.Should You Buy Advanced Micro Devices
column43: Inc. (AMD) Stock? 3 Pros
column44: 3 ConsBig Lead in Its Niche:Yes
column45: TSLA is trying different things
column46: such as a more mass-market vehicle and therecently announced truck. Who knows if those will pan out? But within its core competency
column47: its luxury electric self-driving vehicle
column48: Tesla has a huge first-mover edge.Other luxury car companies are making electric vehicles. And the other automakers are doing their best to come up with their own autonomous solutions. However
column49: no other automaker has managed to assemble all the parts together so nicely in one package. That's even before you get to the glitzy extras such as the Supercharger network.Bears risk underestimating Tesla's strengths when they smugly assume that competition will eventually bury Tesla.Verdict on TSLA StockTesla is extraordinarily expensive after its recent record-breaking run. There is no way to value it based on traditional metrics
column50: which is why Piper Jaffray's analyst was reduced tousing ""creative"" techniques to justify the company's value.Simply put
column51: if you own TSLA stock
column52: you're betting on Musk. If you think he can drive the company forward
column53: Tesla shares could deliver
column54: even from this starting price.Tesla's bears have griped about the company's overvalution for years now without any success. The market punishes overly smug investors. However
column55: the bears do have real concerns
column56: so if you're sitting on big profits
column57: be careful here. Sentiment can turn quickly
column58: and since Tesla consistently has to raise more money
column59: its stock is especially vulnerable to changing emotions.As of this writing

column6: and cloud computing. Semiconductor giantQualcomm

QCOM offers both chips and licenses to its technology that resulted in $23.6 billion in sales last year and $7.4 billion in operating cash flow.That 31.4% cash flow margin demonstrates that Qualcomm is fantastically profitable. Last year
column8: that totaled $3.81 in reported earnings. For the full current year
column9: analysts project a big jump in earnings to $4.66 per share on sales of $23.8 billion. Its CDMA (Code Division Multiple Access) technology is prevalent in nearly every cell phone the 3G and 4G wireless communication standards. Any cell phone manufacturer that makes these handsets has to pay a royalty to Qualcomm.The 11 Best Dividend Stocks to BuyThis has led to a slew of legal challenges to its patents. Just this week
column12: Blackberry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY)
column13: an erstwhile giant in the cell phone market
column14: was awardedan $815 million ""refund."" A court ruled that Qualcomm owed the refund to Blackberry
column15: suggesting that Blackberry had overpaid on its royalties to Qualcomm because of its flagging sales of Blackberry mobile devices. The decision looks to be binding
column16: and Qualcomm will make the payment out of its large cash reserves.iPhone juggernautApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)is also fightingwith Qualcomm. The dispute involves both of Qualcomm's businesses - it supplies chips to iPhones
column17: and Apple also pays it royalties. The current spat is said to total $1 billion
column18: or slightly more than the Blackberry settlement.A quick search of Qualcomm's other disputes includeSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) and Chinese firms includingMeizu. China went after Qualcomm recently
column19: accusing it of violating antitrust rules because of its chip and patent stronghold on mobile devices. Since then
column20: it has sought to settle and renegotiate patent agreements.Add it all up
column21: and investing in Qualcomm is not exactly straightforward.The Bull CaseQCOM stock currently yields close to 4%

column30: whose current market capitalization is only about $75 billion.The merger has been approved by NXP Semiconductors shareholders and is expected to close by the end of the year. It will put Qualcomm in more direct competition with other chip providers
column31: includingNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) (autonomous driving cars) andIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) (cell phones and data centers).Bottom Line on QCOM StockThe NXP Semiconductors purchase offers the best potential for Qualcomm to boost sales and profit growth. However

column1: Apple Inc. Doesnt Need an iPhone Supercycle to Survive;4/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAfter enjoying a sizzling start to the year and hitting an all-time high
column3: the rally inApple(NASDAQ:AAPL) appears to be cooling off. Shares of Apple stock have been slipping over the past week
column4: probably as investors begin to worry that they're fast approaching nosebleed territory.makeArticleAd();Source:Beni Krausz via UnsplashAfter all
column5: AAPL has already exceeded five-year highs on common valuation metrics including price-to-earnings and price-to-book.Those concerns have not been helped by recent Wall Street sentiment regarding the upcoming iPhone 8. Wall Street appears to be deeply divided regarding whether the iPhone 8
column6: to be launched later this year
column7: will spur a mega-buying cycle or simply a good-enough one.The latest analyst to express its reservations is Susquehanna
column8: which reckons that Apple will only ship 100 million iPhone units during H2 vs.110M-115M previously estimated. FBN's Shelby Sherafy has also sounded the alarm
column9: saying that Apple stock's one-way trip higher could come to an untimely end because iPhone 8 will only drive a ""good"" upgrade cycle and not a ""supercycle"" as is widely expected.iPhone 8 Supercycle or Bust?The iPhone 8 is expected to sport pretty cool features
column10: including an OLED screen
column11: 3-D sensors and wireless charging that will supposedly prove too alluring for the throngs of Apple fans.7 High-Yield Stocks That Could Wreck Your RetirementIndeed
column12: bullish analysts might be right on the money if arecent Piper Jaffray surveyon teenage consumer trends is any indication. The survey found that 81% of teens expect their next smartphone to be an iPhone - the highest level of AAPL love ever recorded.Bearish analysts though have countered by pointing out that Apple's track record when it comes to new product launches is nothing to write home about. Apple has already delayed the launch of numerous products in the past
column13: the most recent being iPad Pro 2 by months. Some analysts are a bit optimistic the new iPad could arrive in April
column14: while others are far less sanguine and expect an October launch.A September launch had initially been chalked in for iPhone 8 - now it appears eager buyers won't be getting their hands on the iconic smartphone till much later. There are reports that the new iPhone could bedelayed by weeks or even months. The delay appears to be in connection to the use of curved OLED screens that eliminate the bezels. Why that should be a major issue considering thatSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) has been using them on its smartphones for years is anyone's guess.All that hullabaloo about iPhone 8 delay is not hard to fathom. Buyers of tech hardware are notorious for delaying their purchases when a new iteration is due to hit the shelves. The longer AAPL delays the iPhone 8 launch
column15: the more H2 sales are bound to suffer  which in turn could see Apple stock take a big hit.Could Trump Come to the Rescue?In reality
column16: though
column17: it would take a really bad delay - maybe a month or more - for Apple's top line to get dinged. AAPL is set to enjoy easy comps thanks to last year's awful sales
column18: especially during the latter part of 2016.Apple endured double-digit sales contraction after posting revenue declines of 12.8% for Q1 FY16
column19: 14.5% for Q2 FY16 and 8.9% for Q4 FY16 before returning to growth during Q1 FY17
column20: when it posted modest growth of 3.3%. Apple sold a mere 45.5 milllion and 78.4 million iPhone units during the third and final quarters of 2016. I believe the company can easily top that figure even in the event that iPhone 8 is delayed for two to three weeks.In any case
column21: investors have already been warned about a possible delay
column22: so the bad news is probably already baked into Apple stock.It's more likely that developments in Washington will play a bigger role in determining the trajectory for AAPL.3 Stocks to Watch on Monday: Netflix
column23: Inc. (NFLX)
column24: Tesla
column25: Inc. (TSLA) and United Continental Holdings
column26: Inc. (UAL)Both President Donald Trump and House Speaker Paul Ryan have proposed broad tax cuts in a bid to entice American companies to bring back home at least part of the $2 trillion they have stashed in overseas accounts. Apple has more than $240 billion in cash and investments
column27: most of which is parked in offshore accounts. Bringing home at least part of that bounty could help the company hunt for growth companies and stop over-relying on the iPhone.Moreover
column28: CEO Cook has already indicated a willingness for the company to ditch its timid M&A policy.Tesla(NASDAQ:TSLA)
column29: anybody?Bottom Line on Apple StockSteve Mnuchin recently said that Trump's administration has a target to pass the new tax plan before Congress goes on recess in August. The last comprehensive tax reform of 1986 took more than a year to complete
column30: so it's going to be tough for the administration to pull off the feat in a matter of months. Investors will no doubt also be apprehensive after the Republican gridlock that stymied the proposed American Health Care Act.The good news though is that there's much more agreement on tax reform than there ever was on the healthcare bill.An iPhone 8 supercycle certainly would be great for Apple stock. But AAPL could still receive another adrenaline shot if the proposed tax reform sails through.As of this writing

column1: Think You've Seen Crazy Valuations? Wait Till You See These 3 Stocks;4/15/2017;"Sometimes
column2: the market goes a little overboard with certain   stocks. Whether that's bidding them up well beyond reasonable   levels or selling them off at insanely cheap prices
column3: some stocks   just end up with crazy valuations. Three that have us scratching   our heads right now areTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column4: Chipotle Mexican Grill(NYSE: CMG)
column5: andSunoco LP(NYSE: SUN) . Here's why.Someone apply the brakes
column6: pleaseSean Williams(Tesla):While it's seemingly no struggle to find expensive   valuations in today's market
column7: no stock stands out as perhaps more   egregiously overvalued than electric-vehicle and solar-panel   maker Tesla. I have a number of concerns with the company
column8: so   let's tackle them one at a time.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();To begin with
column9: I have a hard time supporting Tesla's monstrous   $49 billion valuation
column10: which is approaching that ofGeneral Motorsand is higher thanFord's
column11: yet the company still isn't profitable on a recurring basis.   GM reported record full-year earnings per share in 2016
column12: with   automotive-adjusted free cash flow of $6.9 billion
column13: while Ford   reported $4.6 billion in net income and $6.4 billion in   automotive operating cash flow last year. Tesla? It wound up   losing $675 million in net income and burned through $1.56   billion cash for the entire year. In fact
column14: its accumulated losses   since 2007 have approached nearly $3 billion. And yet
column15: it's now   worth $49 billion.Another issue is that Tesla has a habit of overpromising and   underdelivering on those promises. The Model S and Model X were   both delayed due to various production issues
column16: which leaves me   highly skeptical that the company will be able to meet its   production targets on the Model 3. And
column17: for matter
column18: keep in mind   that so far Tesla is only on track to produce 100
column19: 000 vehicles   this year.Tesla's acquisition of SolarCity may also come back to   bite it. In the fourth quarter
column20: SolarCity only installed 201 MW   of solar energy
column21: which was nearly 100 MW lower than what   SolarCity had originally forecast for the quarter
column22: just a few   months prior. While SolarCity offers intriguing long-term   potential
column23: it's another cut to Tesla's already   bleeding balance sheet.Finally
column24: Tesla's cash needs are enormous
column25: and investors might   continue to pay the price for its neediness. Recently
column26: the   company announced that it would sell $750 million in convertible   notes (which means possible dilution down the road) and $250   million in common stock. This correlates to the high expenses   tied to its Gigafactory and production increases for the Model 3.   With a cash outflow expected for years to come
column27: Tesla might   continue to dilute investors in order to raise capital.Without any recurring profits
column28: Tesla's $49 billion valuation   is simply ludicrous.An expensive turnaround storyJordan Wathen(Chipotle Mexican Grill):Chipotle Mexican Grill shares trade at a 40% discount to their   peak price
column29: but I think there's reason to believe that the stock   is still overvalued.Shares currently trade at about 45 times a ""stretch"" earnings   goal of $10 per share in 2017
column30: but bulls expect that earnings   will ramp even higher in coming years. The thesis is predicated   on the idea that customers who avoided the company's restaurants   following E. coli outbreaks last year will return over time.At best
column31: I think Chipotle has a very difficult road to   recovery. At worst
column32: I think the brand is permanently impaired
column33: as   customers who took a break from the burrito chain discovered   substitutes.With heavy promotions and discounts to drive traffic
column34: Chipotle   has trained its customers to expect discounts at the same time   that input costs are growing at mid-single-digit rates. On the   most recent conference call
column35: Chipotle indicated that labor costs   grew 5% in the last year
column36: and it expected continued 4% to 5%   inflation in labor costs going forward. On the same call
column37: management spoke to the difficulties of raising prices
column38: saying
column39: ""We've not had a price increase in three years... at some point   over time
column40: we'll need to pass on some of the higher costs... but   we believe we'll be able to do that.""For Chipotle to recover
column41: it needs to manage expenses by   controlling food costs (or raising prices)
column42: cut down   its marketing spend to a historical level of 2.1% of sales   from an outsize 5.1% of sales in 2016
column43: and do it without   sacrificing customer traffic. That's no easy task for any   restaurant chain.From crazy expensive to insanely cheapMatt DiLallo(Sunoco LP):At first glance
column44: fuel distribution company Sunoco LP looks   absurdly expensive
column45: trading at 112 times enterprise   value-to-EBITDA (a common valuation metric for master limited   partnerships). However
column46: upon closer inspection
column47: an entirely   different story emerges
column48: one that suggests that Sunoco LP is   actually incredibly cheap.One of the reasons Sunoco LP appears to trade at a nosebleed   valuation is that 2016 was a brutal year
column49: which caused   significant downward pressure on earnings. Overall
column50: EBITDA   plunged from $612 million in 2015 to a mere $71 million last   year. However
column51: some of that decline was due to one-time items   such as impairment charges
column52: which totaled $680 million last year.   Once we adjust for those and other items to normalize earnings
column53: Sunoco LP's adjusted EBITDA was $665 million
column54: which was only down   $50 million from the prior year's adjusted EBITDA. If we plug   that number into the equation
column55: Sunoco LP's EV-to-EBITDA is just   11.8 times
column56: which is well below the mid-teens ratio of most other   MLPs.That said
column57: there are good reasons that Sunoco LP has such a   cheap relative valuation . Not only does it have a worrisomely   high debt level
column58: but it also distributed more cash to investors   than it collected. However
column59: the company appears to have addressed   those concerns by recently sealing a deal to unload the bulk of   its retail stores for $3.3 billion in cash. It expects both its   leverage and coverage ratios to improve significantly once that   transaction closes later this year. As a result
column60: it can focus on   building out its stable fuel distribution business
column61: which could   position it to restart dividend growth in the future.While Sunoco LP is higher-risk than most other MLPs
column62: it's dirt   cheap despite recently securing a deal that firmed up its   financial footing. Because of that
column63: investors willing to take on   more risk could be getting a steal with Sunoco LP if its   repositioning plan works.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why Fiat Chrysler Automobiles Created the Insane 2018 Dodge Challenger SRT Demon;4/15/2017;"After weeks of hype and teases
column2: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles(NYSE: FCAU) let the 2018 Dodge Challenger SRT Demon out of its   cage in an appropriately over-the-top event in New York this past   week.Yes
column3: there was an actual cage -- and a whole lot of tire   smoke. But there was some solid business thinking behind the   madness.The 2018 Dodge Challenger SRT Demon was released from its     ""cage"" at a raucous event in New York on Tuesday. Image source:     Fiat Chrysler Automobiles.makeArticleAd();What is this thing?Let's put it this way: If the707-horsepower Hellcat versionof the Challenger wasn't enough for you
column4: the 840-horsepower Demon   might be what you want -- at least
column5: if what you want is to go   drag racing. (Or to brag about quarter-mile times.)Although many parts are new
column6: the Demon is best thought of as a   Hellcat that has been souped up even further in pursuit of   drag-strip bragging rights. Its engine is based on the Hellcat   V8
column7: a 6.2-liter supercharged beast
column8: with heavier-duty parts
column9: a   larger supercharger
column10: and some unique go-even-faster technologies   aimed at maximizing the car's acceleration and drag-strip   performance.It all works. When launched in the proper drag-racing manner
column11: the Demon accelerates so fiercely that its front wheels lift off   of the ground -- something that was demonstrated live on stage at   the car's reveal event. Dodge claims the Demon is the world's   fastest-accelerating production car
column12: with a   zero-to-60-miles-per-hour time of just 2.3 seconds
column13: and a   quarter-mile time of 9.65 seconds at 140 miles per hour.(Yes
column14: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) fans will quibble with that zero-to-60 time; Dodge   fans will quibble with the ""rolling start"" launch that generated   the very slightly faster time recorded by aModel S in Ludicrous mode; expect those and other arguments to be resolved on America's   drag strips over the next year
column15: with plenty of evidence uploaded   to YouTube.)Inside
column16: the Demon is still a Challenger
column17: with most of the same   features offered on the top-trim Hellcat -- only less so. In a   move that is probably as much about trash talk as it is about   weight savings
column18: the Demon comes standard with only one seat
column19: for   the driver. (The other seats can be added back in as an option
column20: priced at $1 each.)Yes
column21: the Demon comes standard with just one seat. The others     can be added back in
column22: for $1 each. Image source: Fiat Chrysler     Automobiles.Is there an actual business case for the Demon?It may seem like a lot of silly over-the-top fun
column23: but the   Demon has a real mission: to put an even brighter halo above the   Dodge brand's already-solid reputation for performance. Think of   it as a big
column24: bold brand-marketing exercise that will probably   turn a solid profit for FCA.That was also themission of the Hellcatwhen it was launched back in 2015
column25: of course. Think of the Demon   as a way to update and boost the (highly effective) kick that the   Hellcat gave to the Dodge brand's luster and desirability among   performance-minded car enthusiasts.The Demon might also turn out to be a nod to the brand's   longtime fans
column26: one that heralds the beginning of the end of an   era. An all-new Challenger based on the vehicle architecture   developed for Alfa Romeo is expected to make its debut in the   next year or two. If so
column27: this is a fitting last hurrah for a car   that has inspired a devoted following.The Dodge Challenger SRT Demon's fender flares accommodate     wide drag-strip-ready tires. Image source: Fiat Chrysler     Automobiles.What will the Dodge Demon cost?No price has yet been announced
column28: but the safest bet in Detroit   is that the Demon won't be cheap. Dodge brand chief Tim Kuniskis   said that only 3
column29: 300 Demons will be made: 3
column30: 000 for the U.S.
column31: and   another 300 for Canada. That's it. It's a one-time deal
column32: for one   year only.Given the scarcity
column33: and the care with which FCA has stoked the   market for the Demon
column34: it's a given that you'll have to pay up if   you want one. The Challenger SRT Hellcat
column35: the current   top-of-the-line model
column36: starts at a little over $64
column37: 000. Expect   the Demon's sticker price to be considerably higher -- and dealer   markups to be huge.Regardless of the sticker price
column38: I expect that quite a few   Demons will be sold at six-figure prices.When will the Demon be available?Production begins in late summer
column39: Kuniskis said
column40: and   deliveries to dealers will begin in the fall.If you want one
column41: I suggest talking to your favorite FCA dealer   sooner rather than later.10 stocks we like better than Fiat Chrysler     AutomobilesWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: This Week in Solar;4/15/2017;"We're only a couple of weeks away from the solar industry's   first-quarter earnings reports
column2: which will give us an idea of how   companies are doing in this dynamic year for the industry.   Companies are grappling with low prices for solar panels and an   unstable financing and demand environment across residential
column3: commercial
column4: and utility-scale solar.This week
column5: we got some interesting data on installation   prices
column6: as well as news that gave us clues about where suppliers   may be headed in the future. Here's what we learned.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Big solar installers are no longer price-competitiveI've been warning thatTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) SolarCity
column7: Sunrun(NASDAQ: RUN)
column8: andVivint Solar(NYSE: VSLR) are in a tough position competing against smaller
column9: regional installers
column10: and there's a new report backing that view   with data.A report by theNational Renewable Energy Laboratoryshows that large installers (Tesla
column11: Sunrun
column12: and Vivint) are   pricing systems about 10% higher than smaller installers.   Overall
column13: large installers average $3.99 per watt to install   solar
column14: while smaller installers charge $3.62 per watt. When   quotes for similar homes are matched
column15: the difference is   $0.33 per watt
column16: which would be $1
column17: 980 for a 6 kW   installation.The higher cost structure for larger installers is now   starting to show
column18: and smaller installers are gaining market share   and showing customers better pricing. This isn't good if you're   looking at investing in one of the big installers.Capacity is still being built in solarPV-Tech released a preliminary analysis of global   solar manufacturing capacity expansionsthis week
column19: and February was an unusually big month for capacity   announcements. In an industry that's already oversupplied and saw   module prices fall about one-third last year
column20: that may sound   strange
column21: but when you look at who's adding capacity and what   they're adding
column22: it makes a little more sense.SunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR) will see the biggest expansion
column23: with a 5 GW   agreement in China. The news is based on Chinese media reports   and the project hasn't been officially announced by SunPower yet
column24: but look for something to be said about this capacity on the   first-quarter 2017 earnings call. This would be related to   SunPower's P-Series product
column25: which uses commodity front-contact   cells from third parties to make solar panels with slightly   higher efficiency than competitors can make. The company has big   hopes for the product
column26: so watch any word on performance of the   P-Series closely.JinkoSolar(NYSE: JKS) also announced 500 MW of new cell and 1.5 GW of   new-module capacity
column27: according to PV-Tech. In March
column28: Hanwha Q Cells(NASDAQ: HQCL) announced 1.2 GW of high-efficiency multi-and   mono-PERC manufacturing
column29: the next generation of solar cells.One thing that stands out about these expansions is that   they're being made by the industry's biggest companies and   they're trending toward technology that emphasizes efficiency.   Slowly but surely
column30: we're seeing a consolidation of power in   solar
column31: so differentiation on efficiency will be key going   forward.News and notesHere are a few other notable items for the weekYingli Green Energyreported fourth-quarter 2016 earnings     resultsand there wasn't a lot of good news for hopeful investors.     Revenue was $294.0 million on 635.1 MW of module shipments and     gross margin was just 7%. Net loss for the quarter was $267.1     million
column32: or $14.70 per share. Bankruptcy or insolvency is     likely in Yingli's future; as I mentioned above
column33: there's a     consolidation of power
column34: and this will be one of the losers in     that power struggle.Spain announced a 3 GW renewable-energy tender this week
column35: which seems like great news for the solar industry
column36: which has     been a big winner of energy tenders around the world. But the     country set up a price floor and any tie will go to the energy     source that produces the most energy per day. In other words
column37: wind will win this tender over solar
column38: at least until Spain     enacts a more balanced tender process.Canadian Solar(NASDAQ: CSIQ) sold two solar power plants in China
column39: totaling     69.5 MW
column40: to Shenzhen Energy this week for $99.8 million. This     is a notable infusion of cash for the company
column41: and the $1.44     per watt price is slightly higher than the $1.34 management     assumed overall when stating that it has $1.6 billion of     operating power plants on its balance sheet.That's all for this week in solar

column1: What Investors Missed in the Market This Week;4/14/2017;"The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 both dropped   lower this week
column2: and both closed below their 50-day moving   averages for the first time since November on Wednesday. Markets   traded slowly into the holiday-shortened week
column3: as they closed in   observance of Good Friday. Still
column4: there were some companies   making big headlines or big moves. Here are some highlights.Be careful what you wish for!It's been a trendy topic to poke atTesla's (NASDAQ: TSLA) absurd valuations over the years
column5: or to poke at   its controversial acquisitions
column6: but the markets keep on devouring   what Musk is selling
column7: sendingTesla stockto new highs recently.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();However
column8: an influential group of investors is applying a bit   of pressure to Tesla in hopes of adding two board directors with   no ties to Elon Musk -- a hint that there are concerns regarding   the company's direction. Currently
column9: five of six board members   have personal or professional connections to Musk
column10: and a group of   investors is hoping to get yearly director elections
column11: rather than   vote every three years
column12: in addition to the two independent board   members.Seemingly irritated over the development and constant prodding   about anything from Tesla's valuation to the company's strategy
column13: Musk did his best to channel his inner Donald Trump and took to   Twitter. ""This investor group should buy Ford stock
column14: Musk posted   on Twitter
column15: Wednesday. ""Their governance is amazing.""While Tesla has the potential to turn an industry on its head   by skipping dealerships and selling directly to consumers
column16: as   well as creating an energy empire on top of its electric   vehicles
column17: Musk should be careful what he wishes for.Ford Motor Company(NYSE: F) is putting $4.5 billion into electrifying its vehicle   portfolio
column18: it's developing smart mobility projects to contend   with start-ups such as Uber
column19: and it's trading at a ridiculously   cheap valuation with a 5.3% dividend yield. Investors could do a   lot worse than purchasing shares of Ford at these prices.A shiny new stakeWhole Foods Market(NASDAQ: WFM) was a wild success story for its investors between   2009 and 2014
column20: but over the past couple of years
column21: the stock price   has gained little to no traction. Yet shares were up about 10% on   Monday as activist investor firm Jana Partners disclosed a new   8.8% stake in Whole Foods Market
column22: citing the following
column23: according   to the13D filingwith the SEC:JANA has substantial experience analyzing and investing in     the grocery sector and more broadly across the food and retail     sectors
column24: and the other Reporting Persons collectively possess     significant operational
column25: financial
column26: and nutritional expertise
column27: including
column28: for some of the other Reporting Persons
column29: experience     creating significant shareholder value in the food and grocery     sectors.At first glance
column30: this new stake by Jana doesn't materially   change the investment thesis for Whole Foods Market
column31: but aWall Street Journalreport hinted that Jana will push for operational improvements   and a potential sale of the company. Investors who have held on   over the past couple of years might as well ride this out. If   management and its new activist partner can help drive   operational improvements and increase its private-label   penetration to increase margins
column32: then a sale for a decent premium   to its current price -- perhaps to the mid-$40 range -- is a   possible and valuable outcome.When two became oneIn other news
column33: shares ofKnight Transportation(NYSE: KNX) and former rivalSwift Transportation(NYSE: SWFT) traded higher starting Monday after announcing the   companies would combine. The stocks then gave back some gains   over the course of this week.Looking at the details
column34: the companies announced an all-stock   transaction that will create the largest full truckload company.   When the dust settles
column35: Swift shareholders will control about 54%   of the stock
column36: despite Knight actually being named as the   ""accounting acquirer."" Swift Chairman Richard Dozer said in   a press release:This is a terrific opportunity for our stockholders
column37: who     stand to benefit from the significant upside potential of this     transaction. Indeed
column38: by coming together under common ownership
column39: the companies will be able to capitalize on economies of scale     to achieve substantial synergies.The combined company will generate about $5 billion in annual   revenue and expects to generate $15 million in cost savings this   year alone. The synergies are expected to save roughly $100   million in 2018 and $150 million in 2019. For two companies   operating as rivals in a low-margin industry

column1: Tesla Introduces Solar Panels Ahead of Gigafactory 2 Opening;4/14/2017;"Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) quietly released a new solar panel this week
column2: pushing the company closer to a differentiated product in the   residential solar industry. If you've seen any media coverage   about the announcement
column3: like that fromQuartz
column4: International Business Times
column5: orInc.com
column6: you might think this changes the solar industry forever. IB   Times proclaimed that Tesla will ""take the ugly out of solar""   overnight with one new product and Quartz said the panels were   ""barely visible.""But Tesla isn't releasing much in the way of information about   this new product
column7: except   a few pictures and limited technical data. What we've learned so far isn't as revolutionary as many of the   headlines make it seem.Tesla's solar panel design that will soon begin rolling out     to customers. Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();What we know about Tesla's solar panelsTesla says it's introducing solar panels that ""exceed industry   standards for durability and lifespan
column8: according to the   company's website
column9: and early reports from Electrek (in an   article that has subsequently been taken down) say that the   efficiency of those solar panels will be 21.76%. But there's no   official industry standard for durability or lifespan
column10: so that   could mean anything. As for the efficiency number
column11: it's   incomplete and vague
column12: at best
column13: which I'll explain below.What wasn't advertised on Tesla's website is that this isn't a   Tesla manufactured product at all. They are actuallyPanasonicsolar panels sold exclusively through Tesla and they're likely   coming from a Panasonic-owned plant
column14: not the Gigafactory 2 that's   due to start production this summer. These also aren't   panels made with Silevo technology
column15: which has been abandoned   since Tesla bought SolarCity. Instead
column16: Tesla is either buying   Panasonic solar panels and putting its name on them or
column17: if these   will come from the Gigafactory 2
column18: they're Panasonic panels made   in Tesla's facility.What's unique about the product is Tesla's racking design
column19: which is described as a ""sleek
column20: low-profile design
column21: including an   edge skirt
column22: an edging that reduces the sharp line at the edge of   the solar installation to blend into the roof. But it's not   entirely new to the world. The low-profile
column23: easy-to-install   design is similar toSunPower's(NASDAQ: SPWR) Equinox product that was introduced last year
column24: and there's no indication Tesla's product will be more efficient   than SunPower's.This isn't to say that the complete design solution isn't   important. Designing panels to integrate with racking helps move   work from the roof to the manufacturing floor
column25: which could be an   advantage for Tesla's cost structure. And aesthetics is becoming   more important to customers. But Tesla isn't really doing   anything that isn't already available on the market.SunPower's X-Series panels with a low-profile design     introduced in 2016. Image source: SunPower.Efficiency is important
column26: but Tesla/Panasonic is not the   industry leaderIt's not yet clear what the reported 21.76% efficiency number   for Panasonic/Tesla panels means
column27: if it's true. Does it refer to   cell efficiency or module efficiency? I emailed Tesla
column28: and   they wouldn't answer or provide data sheets
column29: only saying
column30: ""We're not releasing any additional information right now.""If the original Electrek report of a 21.76% efficient module   is true
column31: it would be among the industry's best
column32: but there are   indications that that efficiency number might actually be for a   cell
column33: not the module. Tesla says the new panel is a 325-watt   design
column34: comparable toPanasonic's 320-watt offeringthat has 21.6% efficient cells and a 19.1% efficient panel.   However
column35: Panasonic also makes a330-watt panel that's 19.7% efficient on a module   level. If the reported 21.76% efficiency is really a cell-level   efficiency number
column36: it would imply that the panels for Tesla are   similar to Panasonic's other modules and provide no   differentiation. And note that Panasonic shut down some of   its own solar manufacturing capacity because it was no longer   cost-competitive with other products in the market. If there's no   efficiency or cost improvement between Panasonic and Tesla
column37: this   won't be a differentiated product at all. But Tesla isn't   clarifying any details about efficiency yet.When Tesla releases data sheets specifying whether the   efficiency numbers are at a cell or panel level
column38: it will be clear   whether this is an industry-leading product or a fairly average   solar product. SunPower's X22 solar panel is22.2% efficient
column39: according to its data sheet
column40: and management said during its last quarterly conference   call that cells are now 25% efficient
column41: implying that actual   module efficiency is trending closer to 23%. That's the bar for   Tesla to surpass to be an industry leader.Tesla isn't a solar disruptor yetIf Tesla is going to make the SolarCity acquisition work and   justify Gigafactory 2
column42: it needs to make differentiated solar   panels itself
column43: and while this new solar module is a step in that   direction
column44: it's not clear how differentiated the company's   product will actually be. But with Panasonic essentially running   Tesla's solar manufacturing
column45: investors shouldn't get the idea   that this product is a game changer. Tesla could have bought   panels with similar efficiency to Panasonic's on the open   market without building a manufacturing plant or entering into a   long-term partnership with Panasonic.And if it really wanted to be an efficiency leader
column46: Tesla   should have bought SunPower
column47: as I wrote about last July. This recent announcement still doesn't prove that Tesla's   product is any better than SunPower's either aesthetically or   technically
column48: despite what many of the headlines might imply.   Until we hear more
column49: we don't even know if Tesla's panel is better   than what Panasonic was already making for sale in the open   market.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column2: Inc.'s Model 3: Final Unveiling in July;4/13/2017;"One of the key facets behind electric-car makerTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) soaring stock price in recent months is   increasing confidence from investors in the company's ability to   ramp-up vehicle production from an annualized run rate of about   100
column3: 000 units today to management's target for as many as 500
column4: 000   units next year. But Tesla will need to successfully launch its   higher-volume
column5: lower-cost Model 3 first before it can take its   production to the next level.On this note
column6: Tesla is back with some more news on its crucial   Model 3 launch. The final unveiling of the Model 3 will be in   July
column7: Tesla CEO Elon Musk said onTwitterThursday.Model 3. Image source: Tesla Motors.makeArticleAd();What to expect from the Model 3 unveilingBased on how Tesla went about the final unveiling of its Model   X SUV in late 2015
column8: a final unveiling of the Model 3 could   include the first deliveries of the vehicle to customers
column9: along   with details on the big unknown facts about the vehicle
column10: such as   battery capacity options
column11: official EPA-rated range on a single   charge
column12: and the vehicle's finalized design -- inside and out.Up until Thursday
column13: it wasn't clear when Tesla would be holding   an event for the final unveiling of its Model 3. While Tesla said   it would begin Model 3 production in July
column14: Musk suggested the   company might continue to keep details about the $35
column15: 000 vehicle   secret as long as possible
column16: particularly since the first   deliveries were slated to go to employees
column17: anyway.""I think it's important for us to have a good feedback ... on   the product that we're making and if there are any issues or   valuable things that need to be addressed that we can address   those before customers experience them
column18: Musk explained in   Tesla's fourth-quarter earnings call.Musk went on to say that the unveiling could be as soon as a   few months from its Feb. 22 earnings call or ""as far as July   itself."" Apparently
column19: Musk opted to keep as many secrets about   Model 3 as possible for as long as possible.As far as what exactly the final unveiling might reveal about   Model 3 is still a mystery. Musk stated in the company's   fourth-quarter earnings call that the final version will be   ""pretty close"" to the prototype unveiled last year
column20: ""but with   polish and refinement and a few more details that are added.""In addition
column21: Musk said: ""It will be better than what was   unveiled. And I guess in some ways
column22: it will be a lot better.""   Could Musk be any more vague?The main details investors know today is that it will have at   least 215 miles of range on a single charge
column23: be slightly smaller   than the Model S
column24: include Autopilot hardware as standard -- but   customers will have to pay to activate ""Enhance Autopilot"" -- and   have a starting price at about half of the Model S' starting   price.Model 3. Image source: Tesla Motors.But don't expect volume Model 3 deliveries yetDespite a target month for the final unveiling of Model 3
column25: investors should keep their expectations in check. After the   stock's 51% rise in the past six months
column26: investors are already   pricing in not only a successful Model 3 launch
column27: but a   well-executed production ramp to unit-volume levels that Tesla   has never achieved.In addition
column28: while production of Model 3 and a final unveiling   of the vehicle are coming in July

column1: Tesla Inc. to Unveil "Next Level" Semi This Year;4/13/2017;"In an update on its long-term plans last summer
column2: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) CEO Elon Musk said one of the company's main   priorities in the future will be to expand its vehicle offerings   ""to cover the major forms of terrestrial transport
column3: including   commercial vehicles like ""heavy-duty trucks and high   passenger-density urban transport.""When Tesla announced plans for these vehicles last year
column4: they   were in the early stages of development and were excepted to be   unveiled in 2017. While there's no new information on Tesla's   passenger vehicle
column5: Musk said onTwitterThursday that the heavy-duty truck
column6: or ""Tesla Semi
column7: is on track   for an unveiling in September.Image source: Author.makeArticleAd();Tesla commercial vehicles""Tesla Semi truck unveil set for September
column8: Musk tweeted.   ""Team has done an amazing job. Seriously next level.""Few things are known about Tesla's semi
column9: but Musk did say in   the company's ""Master Plan
column10: Part Deux"" blog post last year that   the Semi will ""deliver a substantial reduction in the cost of   cargo transport
column11: while increasing safety and making it really fun   to operate.""Tesla isn't the first company to show an interest in electric   semis. Indeed
column12: Mercedes-Benz has already started small-series   production of an all-electric heavy-duty truck
column13: which it calls   the Urban eTruck. Capable of about 125 miles of range
column14: the Urban   eTruck is focused on short-distance applications.The Tesla Semi would just be one facet of Tesla's plan to move   beyond its consumer vehicles
column15: which currently include its Model S   sedan
column16: Model X SUV
column17: and its upcoming higher-volume
column18: lower-cost   Model 3 sedan. The other main commercial vehicle Tesla wants to   bring to market is its high passenger-density urban transport   vehicle
column19: or what Tesla has also called the ""Tesla minibus.""The minibus
column20: which Tesla says isn't the official name of the   vehicle yet
column21: will be built on the company's Model X platform
column22: Musk noted in the company's second-quarter earnings call last   year. Musk explained the reasoning of an all-electric minibus in   more detail in the company's master plan last summer.With the advent of autonomy
column23: it will probably make sense to     shrink the size of buses and transition the role of bus driver     to that of fleet manager. Traffic congestion would improve due     to increased passenger areal density by eliminating the center     aisle and putting seats where there are currently entryways
column24: and matching acceleration and braking to other vehicles
column25: thus     avoiding the inertial impedance to smooth traffic flow of     traditional heavy buses. It would also take people all the way     to their destination. Fixed summon buttons at existing bus     stops would serve those who don't have a phone. Design     accommodates wheelchairs
column26: strollers and bikes.Tesla vehicle production. Image source: Author.Why it mattersTesla believes an aggressive production ramp-up of compelling   electric vehicles
column27: along with an expansion of its lineup to   address more of the major transportation markets
column28: will help it in   its mission ""to accelerate the world's transition to sustainable   energy."" By bringing compelling electric vehicles to market
column29: Tesla is betting it can catalyze manufacturers and consumers to   transition to electric vehicles more rapidly.Tesla Semi represents a key part of this plan. While a   Tesla-branded heavy-duty truck is still too far away for   investors to begin pricing in its potential impact on the   company's business

column8: it feels like Tesla stock can go only so far before it runs out of gas  no pun intended. But for all its momentum
column9: it's worth exploring the idea of $400 as a next stop
column10: as much as it is $200.Let's look at what would have to happen to hit either target
column11: and which seems likelier.Scenario #1: TSLA Stock Goes to $400Tesla has been rising in 2017 in anticipation of the Model 3 - a relatively inexpensive electric vehicle that will bring more car buyers to Tesla - hitting the car market.10 Under-the-Radar Stocks to Buy Now for Explosive UpsideAlthough the starting price for a Model 3 is $35
column13: San Diego data expert Ben Sullins suggests most of the 400
column14: 000-plus reservation holders will likely pay between$45
column16: 000for their vehicles once you add options most drivers want including an upgraded battery that gets a 300-mile range instead of the standard 215.Not only is the average price of the Model 3 expected to be higher than $42
column17: 000 - the number CEO Elon Musktweetedin April 2016 - but the average price of the Model S is likely to be as high as $90
column18: 000.If you own TSLA stock
column19: this is a good news/bad news kind of situation.The good news? Revenue will be higher than anticipated providing a greater possibility that the Model 3 will ultimately make money. The bad news  I'll cover in my discussion about Tesla stock and a $200 scenario below.For $400 to be a possibility
column20: its current stock price has to make sense
column21: because if it doesn't
column22: a drop to $200 becomes more likely than rising to $400. Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas recently discussedwhy he believes Tesla stock deserves a $300 share price:""The sooner investors view Tesla as a transportation/infrastructure company rather than as just a car company. A significant portion of our $305 price target can be accounted for by the value of Tesla Mobility
column23: an on-demand and highly automated transportation service we anticipate to be launched at low volume in 2018. Our DCF valuation of the core automotive business is $233.""Of the 16 analysts with 12-month price targets
column24: the high is $375
column25: the low is $155 and the median price target is $245. From this perspective
column26: it's clear that many analysts don't view Tesla in the way that Jonas does.I've always been a fan of Tesla and CEO Elon Musk and do think it's a stock most investors 45 and youngershould consider for their retirement portfolio. But I could see why some analysts see a darker future.Scenario #2: TSLA Stock Drops to $200Question:How many vehicles has Tesla delivered in the past five years?Answer:183
column27: 000.Question:How much money has Tesla made the past five years?Answer:Zero. It has lost$2.8 billion
column28: hence the need for additional debt and equity raises.Can you see where I'm going with this?Tesla makes no money
column29: is on the hook to deliver 400
column30: 000 Model 3s in the next couple of years
column31: yet has managed to deliver an average of just 1
column32: 088 vehicles per week over the past five years.Elon Musk says Tesla will produce 10
column33: 000 Model 3s by 2018. How does it expect to get to this number when it's never produced more than one-tenth of that in an average week?That right there is the million-dollar question
column34: and a big reason why some analysts are very wary about its current share price.Don't Buy Amazon.com
column35: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Because of the NFL
column36: But ...""Tesla's overall customer experience - which we believe is not strong today - and could be further pressured as the company migrates to selling to a more mass-market consumer
column37: a Bernstein analyst recentlywrotein a note to investors. ""A poor ramp and customer experience on Model 3 could not only impact Tesla's near-term financials
column38: but undermine the franchise longer-term.""The analyst is saying
column39: ""Ford sold 235
column40: 000 vehicles in the U.S. in March; Tesla produced less than that over five years. Ford's made $30.8 billion over the past five years; Tesla's lost billions and it could get worse.""Ford stock is valued at 0.3 times sales while Tesla's P/S ratio is 20 times that. When you look it from this perspective
column41: it's hard to get excited about a $400 share price.It's especially true when you consider how much pressure the company's facing with the launch of the Model 3. If the Model 3 doesn't get the same kind of reviews from consumer product testing groups as the Model S gets
column42: Tesla shareholders will look back on $300 as the price at which they should have sold.Bottom Line on TeslaAs I said in March
column43: I think TSLA stock could hit$500by this time in 2018 on its way to $1
column45: but only if the Model 3 is a success. I think it will be.As such
column46: I think bulls can get excited. A $400 price target is much likelier than $200.As of this writing
