column1: 3 Crucial Milestones Tesla
column2: Inc. Must Hit This Year;4/11/2017;"WithTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) stock rising nearly 60% in the past six months
column3: its valuation is pricing in significant growth in the coming   years. But investors won't have to wait years for Tesla's ability   to execute on ambitious growth targets to be tested. In 2017
column4: Tesla has three milestones on the horizon it will need to achieve   to keep investors betting optimistically on the company's   longer-term growth potential.Look for Tesla to live up to these three important landmark   targets for 2017.makeArticleAd();TSLAdata byYCharts1. Model 3 productionIt's difficult to overstate just how important the Model 3 is   to Tesla's stock price. With a starting price of $35
column6: or   about half the starting price of its pricier Model S sedan
column7: the   upcoming vehicle represents the culmination of Tesla's efforts to   date. Ever since Tesla CEO Elon Musk laid out his ""secret master   plan"" in 2006
column8: Tesla's mission was crystal clear: Tesla's pricier   vehicles were only a medium for the company to build a business   that could eventually support production of a higher volume
column9: more   affordable vehicle -- the Model 3.But it's 2017 now
column10: and it's time for Tesla to deliver on its   promise. As of Tesla's most recent shareholder letter
column11: the   company said it plans to begin Model 3 production in July.Can Tesla pull it off?2. Volume production of Model 3Of course
column12: Tesla is going to need to do more than begin   production of Model 3 in 2017. It needs to ramp up production to   a significant volume. With a market capitalization of $51 billion   yet having only delivered 86
column13: 500 vehicles in the trailing 12   months
column14: investors are betting that Tesla will not only begin   Model 3 production
column15: but eventually scale it to annual production   in the hundreds of thousands.Tesla vehicle production. Image source: authorTesla has said it expects to achieve ""volume production"" in   September.What could the production ramp-up of Model 3 look like? Tesla   gave a preview of what management expects in the company's   fourth-quarter shareholder letter:""Our Model 3 program is on track to start limited vehicle   production in July and to steadily ramp production to exceed   5
column16: 000 vehicles per week at some point in the fourth quarter and   10
column17: 000 vehicles per week at some point in 2018.""For the entire year of 2018
column18: Tesla expects the combined   production of Model S
column19: X
column20: and 3 to add up to about 500
column21: 000   units.3. Production ramp-up of solar glass tilesAnother key area investors should keep their eyes on is   Tesla's ability to put its late 2016-acquisition of SolarCity to   work. One of the first targets on the horizon for Tesla's solar   business is bringing its new glass solar tiles to market and   ramping up their production.Home with Tesla solar tiles. Image source: Tesla.In Tesla's fourth-quarter earnings call
column22: Tesla's chief   technology officer
column23: J.B. Straubel
column24: said Tesla will ""ramp and   start scaling"" production of its solar tiles by the end of the   year.For Tesla to live up to high investor expectations
column25: it's going   to have to deliver on these three near-term milestones first.   Otherwise
column26: investors will have little confidence in Tesla's   longer-term targets
column27: namely its goal to produce 500
column28: 000 vehicles   annually by next year and 1 million annually in 2020.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock   tip

column1: Tesla (TSLA) Becomes U.S. Most Valuable Automaker
column2: Passing GM;4/11/2017;"Tesla (Shutterstock photo)Can anything stop Tesla (TSLA)? The California-based luxury electric vehicle company
column3: which calls itself the Quickest production car on earth

column10: which by contrast renders the slow-growing GM and Ford  despite dominating Tesla in total vehicle sales  to used car status. Reutersnotedthat Teslas market cap  which peaked Monday at $51.105 billion  is now the equivalent to $102

column15: which has already soared 46% year to date

column17: continues to defy gravity. ""As a car company alone
column18: Tesla is crazy high valuation

column21: who oversees more than $105 billion in assets.Gundlach
column22: who sees more reasonable value in the battery component of Teslas business

column1: General Motors' Answer to Tesla's Autopilot Is a Step Forward;4/10/2017;"Self-driving technology -- at least
column2: the stuff you'll soon be   able to buy -- takes another step forward:General Motors(NYSE: GM) said its hands-free
column3: highway-driving system
column4: Super   Cruise
column5: will come to market later this year as an option on the   Cadillac CT6 luxury sedan.At first glance
column6: Super Cruise seems similar toTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) Autopilot
column7: the best-known ""hands-free
column8: driver-assist system. But it's a bit different: Super Cruise adds   some new pieces to existing driver-assist systems to create a   genuine Level 3 partial self-driving system -- and that raises   some interesting questions.GM's Super Cruise highway-assist system will debut later     this year as an option on the big Cadillac CT6 sedan. Image     source: General Motors.makeArticleAd();What GM said about Super CruiseIn what might be a subtle dig at Tesla
column9: GM said Super Cruise   is ""the industry's first true hands-free driving technology for   the highway:""Unlike other driver assistance systems
column10: Super Cruise     utilizes two advanced technology systems - a driver attention     system and precision LiDAR map data - to ensure safe and     confident vehicle operation.These systems are added to the network of cameras and radar     sensors in the CT6
column11: providing a more data-rich approach to     driver assistance that is unique in the industry.One of those two new systems is clearly a good thing. We know   that the first full self-driving systems will require highly   detailed maps of the areas in which they operate
column12: to supplement   the information from the car's sensors. GM has created such a map   for Super Cruise: Its ""precision LiDAR map data"" includes finely   detailed maps of all highways in the U.S. and Canada
column13: which the   system can use to double-check (or back up) its sensor readings.   That's a welcome addition.It's the ""driver attention system"" that will raise eyebrows
column14: at least among self-driving experts. Here's why.Almost self-driving -- but not quiteFirst
column15: let's define some terms. Under the classification   system for vehicle-automation systems developed by the Society of   Automotive Engineers and adopted around the world
column16: GM's Super   Cruise appears to be a Level 3 system. That's the highest levelbelowfully self-driving systems
column17: in which no human intervention is   necessary.A Level 3 system is defined as one that can drive itself under   certain conditions. But -- and this is a big ""but"" -- the human   driver has to be alert and ready to take over on short notice
column18: if   something comes up that the system isn't equipped to handle.   That
column19: in turn
column20: means the system has to keep tabs on its drivers   to ensure they are paying attention and ready to take over   if needed.That's where GM's ""driver attention system"" comes in. The   system uses a small camera and infrared sensors to track the   driver's head position whenever Super Cruise is operating. If it   determines that the driver has looked away from the road ahead   for too long
column21: it prompts the driver to return his or her   attention to the road.Lights built into the steering wheel's rim alert drivers to     the status of the Super Cruise system -- and help keep the     driver's eyes from wandering off of the road. Image source:     General Motors.If the driver doesn't respond immediately
column22: the system keeps   driving the car while it works through a series of escalating   alerts to get the driver's attention. The alerts include lights
column23: sounds
column24: and ""tactile alerts"" transmitted by the car's seats --   each one (hopefully) harder for the driver to miss. (If the   driver is still unresponsive
column25: the system brings the car to a safe   stop and uses GM's OnStar system to call for help.)Some automakers aren't even trying Level 3Partial self-driving systems came under scrutiny after afatal accidentinvolving a Tesla last year. In that incident
column26: a Tesla Model S on   Autopilot ran full-speed into a tractor-trailer truck crossing   the road. The Tesla's driver
column27: whose attention may have been   turned away from the road
column28: did not survive the collision.That accident made it clear that automakers offering partial   self-driving systems needed to find ways to ensure that drivers   were paying attention -- at least enough attention to grab the   controls quicklyif something (like a white truck crossing the highway on a bright   sunny day
column29: as in the Tesla incident) came up that the system   couldn't handle.And that has proven to be a challenge that at least some other   automakers
column30: including a big GM rival with good technology
column31: are   choosing not to try to tackle.Ford(NYSE: F) said last year that it haddecided not to develop a Level 3 systemat all
column32: because its research had shown that drivers found   the required attention-checking systems to be -- yes -- too   annoying.Has GM solved the driver-attention problem?Will drivers find Super Cruise's attention monitoring and   reminders to be too much? Given that GM has enough   confidence in Super Cruise to launch it on a high-end Cadillac
column33: I   expect GM believes it has found a way to effectively nudge   drivers without causing too much irritation.We'll know soon: Your humble Fool will get a close-up look at   GM's new Super Cruise system later this week. I'll let you know   exactly what I think after I check it out.10 stocks we like better than General MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column34: it can pay to listen. After all
column35: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column36: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column37: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and General Motors wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3
column38: 2017John Rosevearowns shares of Ford and General Motors. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Ford and Tesla. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Why Tesla
column2: Inc. Shares Jumped Today;4/10/2017;"Shares ofTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) jumped today
column3: setting a fresh all-time record high   of nearly $314 and also briefly overtaking GM as the most   valuable U.S. automaker by market cap. The companies remained   neck-and-neck in terms of market valuation as shares fluctuated   during normal trading.A lot of the bullishness on Tesla's part today comes from an   analyst upgrade. Piper Jaffray analyst Alexander Potter has   upgraded Tesla shares from neutral to overweight
column4: while   meaningfully ratcheting up the firm's price target from $223 to   $368. That's a pretty big change
column5: especially considering the fact   that the prior price target was well below current prices
column6: and   the new price target represents nearly 20% upside.A Tesla store. Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();""Tesla isn't just another company""Potter and his team purchased a Tesla vehicle for research   purposes
column7: and have been driving it regularly for the past seven   months. The analyst writes that Tesla vehicles have a   ""captivating impact"" on both customers and investors
column8: which peers   have a hard time replicating. ""Tesla isn't just another company""   to customers
column9: employees
column10: and investors
column11: according to Potter. He   doesn't even think a botched Model 3 launch could hurt investor   optimism
column12: believing that shareholders would simply ""withhold   judgment.""Piper notes that Tesla faces plenty of risks going forward
column13: but these risks don't faze the stock at all. ""Even with all the   risks
column14: we think growth investors can't afford to ignore this   stock
column15: the analyst writes. In terms of unit estimates
column16: Potter   expects Tesla to miss its 2018 target of 500
column17: 000 deliveries
column18: but   thinks the company can make up for this in 2019 by delivering   over 750
column19: 000 units. Gross margin is expected in the low- to   mid-20s range on the automotive side (in line with Tesla's   current profitability levels)
column20: and Potter does not expect Tesla   to need additional capital raises going forward.It's hard to value Tesla using conventional metricsThe analyst concedes that trying to assign a price target for   Tesla requires a ""creative"" approach to valuation. This is likely   due to the fact that Tesla has no directly comparable peers
column21: given its ambitions for the energy sector as well as its   different approaches to the auto industry
column22: as seen in direct   sales.It's no secret that Tesla shares are almost impossible to   value
column23: which is also why bearish theses that are predicated   entirely on valuation alone using conventional metrics may be   doomed. That's not to say that Tesla doesn't make mistakes in   terms of operations and execution
column24: another common theme among   bears
column25: but misaligned body panels aren't bringing down the   company anytime soon. Tesla is
column26: and will remain for the   foreseeable future

column1: Beyond Tesla: 2 Lithium Stocks to Buy Now;4/10/2017;"While the market for Lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries has a ton of untapped potential
column2: Tesla Inc.'sTSLAdecision to build a$5 billion Gigafactoryto meet its requirement of lithium-ion battery packs brought glaring focus on the shortage of supply of this emerging energy storage technology.Li-ion batteries are a type of rechargeable battery in which lithium ions move from the anode to cathode during discharge
column3: and from cathode to anode when charging. They are a popular choice by electric car manufacturers
column4: and are used byGeneral Motors Co.GM
column5: Navistar International Corp.NAV
column6: BMW AGBAMXF
column7: Daimler AGDDAIF
column8: andFord Motor Co.F
column9: among many others. Li-ion batteries are also used in cellphones
column10: laptops
column11: and other electronic devices as well as in the aerospace and defense sector.Back in January
column12: it was reported thatPanasonic Corp.PCRFYagreed to invest up to $1.6 billionin Tesla's Gigafactory. Kazuhiro Tsuga
column13: President of Panasonic
column14: said that ""We are sort of waiting on the demand from Tesla. If Tesla succeeds and the electric vehicle becomes mainstream
column15: the world will be changed and we will have lots of opportunity to grow.""By 2020
column16: Tesla expects the annual Li-ion battery production of the Gigafactory to exceed the global production in 2013. The factory will produce enough battery packs to allow Tesla to build around 500
column17: 000 electric cars annually by 2020.Production at the Gigafactory is slated to begin by the end of this year
column18: but until then
column19: the focus will be on other lithium-related companies. Thus
column20: it would be a good idea to invest in some companies that manufacture these batteries
column21: as well as those who directly handle lithium.Let's take a look at two stocks that are looking good at the moment:Arotech Corp.ARTXhas two business divisions: Training and Simulation
column22: and Battery and Power Systems. The Battery and Power Systems division manufactures and sells Lithium and Zinc-Air batteries and smart chargers for the military and to the private defense industry in the Middle East
column23: Europe
column24: and Asia.ARTX stock has gained more than 17% over the past 12 months
column25: and has an average earnings surprise of 106.25%. It's a relatively smaller company
column26: with a market cap of currently $84.51 million. Arotech
column27: however
column28: is in a fast-growing industry;Electronics-Militaryis in the top 2% of all industries ranked on the Zacks Industry Rank.Arotech has a price-to-book (P/B) ratio of 1.22
column29: lower than the industry average of 1.92. It has seen historic cash flow growth of 51.58% and historic EPS growth of 700%
column30: both well above the industry averages of 6.32% and 14.24%
column31: respectively. While 2017 looks to be a mixed year for Arotech
column32: the company expects year-over-year earnings growth of 200% for its next quarter
column33: and sales growth of just about 5% in the same period.Albemarle Corp.ALBis a major producer of fine and performance chemicals including bromine
column34: catalysts
column35: and lithium
column36: and the company became the world's largest supplier of lithium when it acquired Rockwood Holdings back in January 2015. Bloomberg estimates Albemarle's share of the world's lithium to be about 35%.ALB
column37: a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) stock
column38: reported an average earnings surprise from each of the trailing 4 quarters of 14.28%. The company sits in a fairly strong industry as well;Chemical-Diversifiedis in the top 18% of all industries ranked on the Zacks Industry Rank. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for the company's current year (ending December 2017) is $4.17 per share
column39: reflecting 16.74% year-over-year growth.Albemarle has a price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 25.42
column40: above the industry average of 16.54. Its price-to-sales (P/S) ratio is 4.11
column41: while its current PEG ratio sits at 1.84. ALB stock has seen historic EPS growth of 18.51% and historic cash flow growth of 3.41%.Bottom LineAs a whole

column44: the global market for Li-ion batteries doubled to $22.5 billion in 2016 from $11.7 billion in 2012. Consumer goods and automobile sectors
column45: in large part drove the demand.And

column1: Tesla Inc Hype Hits a Fever Pitch (TSLA);4/10/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) has now overtaken bothFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) andGeneral Motors Company(NYSE:GM) to become America's most valuable automaker - at least by market capitalization.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockDespite the fact the electric vehicle purveyor only sells a small fraction of the units of the established players
column3: investors look beyond Model 3 production ramp fears
column4: a large cash burn rate and a very extended valuation to push shares to fresh highs.In trading on Monday
column5: shares are up another 3.4% to push beyond the $310-a-share threshold. This is up nearly a third from the lows hit in late February. And it represents a whopping 72% rise from the early December low. Tesla's market capitalization hit $51.17 billion
column6: eclipsing GM's $51.1 billion and Ford's $45.1 billion valuations.The hype is real as the company continues to tick many of the right boxes for Wall Street: It's a play on autonomous vehicles
column7: a play on EVs going mainstream
column8: it's both a big-tech and socially-responsible investing play
column9: and it's poised to benefit should President Trump
column10: as hasrecently been reported
column11: embraces a carbon tax to gain Democratic support for hits tax reform plans.Yet one wonders when hopefulness turns to hard expectations and investors demand actual results. GM maintains a 17.3% market share and has beat Tesla to market with a mainstream EV with a 200-plus mile range; compare that to Tesla's 0.2% U.S. market share and its yet-to-be-launched Model 3. The company is targeting the production of 500
column12: 000 vehicles next year
column13: up from just 84
column14: 000 last year.The 11 Best Dividend Stocks to BuyMuch of the recent rise in TSLA was driven by the allaying of capital raising fears after China'sTencent Holdings Ltd(OTCMKTS:TCEHY)
column15: owner of Chinese social network WeChat
column16: acquired a 5% stake in the company.Possible overconfidence is appearing
column17: with TSLA CEO Elon Musk taking to Twitter recently to mock the bears. Headwinds noted by the skeptics
column18: including everything from a weak balance sheet
column19: tendency to dilute existing shareholders with secondary offerings and even questionable product decisions like avoiding LIDAR technology
column20: have simply not mattered.Even Wall Street analysts are throwing in the towel
column21: with Piper Jaffray analyst Alexander Potter upgrading the stock to overweight with a $368 price target - a 65% increase - admitting ""we sympathize with bears - but their (arguably rational) arguments probably won't matter.""The company will next report results on May 24 after the close. Analysts are looking for a loss of 69 cents per share on revenues of $2.59 billion.Anthony Mirhaydari is founder of theEdge(ETFs) andEdge Pro(Options) investment advisory newsletters. column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhether people want to admit it or not

The one sector that hasn't quite received the benefits of the ""Trump rally"" are energy stocks.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrIt's a reversal of fortune for companies likeBP Plc (ADR)(NYSE:BP). Once a poster child for oil stocks mired in a public relations crisis
column7: BP eventually clawed its way back.While I won't excuse thehorrific damagethat the company caused in the 2010 oil spill
column8: what's done is done. People and corporations can't wallow in their mistakes forever. BP took it on the chin
column9: and soldiered on
column10: ultimately gaining 31% in 2016.Right now
column11: however
column12: the enthusiasm does not appear to have carried over. BP stock is down 6.3% since its January opener
column13: and is struggling to break out of the doldrums. Since early February
column14: BP has largely gone nowhere.Naturally
column15: several investors are frustrated.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: Still the Best?The ""good news"" about the pedestrian trading is that energy stocks overall are heavily burdened
column16: particularly big oil stocks. Marquee rivals such asExxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM)
column17: Royal Dutch Shell Plc(ADR)(NYSE:RDS.A
column18: NYSE:RDS.B) andChevron Corporation(NYSE:CVX) haven't shown much to their shareholders
column19: either. Therefore
column20: BP stock is unlikely to lose much volume to its core competitors.However
column21: schadenfreude has limited value on Wall Street. Can BP stock rise above the fray in energy stocks on its own merits?BP Stock Has a Mountain to ClimbAt first glance
column22: that notion doesn't seem very plausible. AsInvestorPlacewriter Tom Taulli notes
column23: BP isnot blessedwith great financials. Against key metrics such as profitability margins
column24: return-on-equity
column25: and sales growth
column26: BP stock is consistently terrible. Worse
column27: the company ranks well below the average among big oil stocks.That's saying a lot considering the pain inflicted against energy stocks in general. Major clunkers exist within the sector
column28: dragging the entire average way down. Even with that mulligan
column29: BP stock fundamentally looks extremely ugly.Then
column30: as Taulli states
column31: you have to factor in oil price volatility. Frankly
column32: energy stocks are getting a bum deal so far this year because of their underlying indices. Apparently
column33: the international benchmark Brent Crude Oil is still deciding whether it wants to play ""good cop"" or ""bad cop."" Currently
column34: it's playing bad cop
column35: with the Brent index down 7% year to date.Finally
column36: some high-level headwinds are making their presence known. Acting as the biggest culprit is the U.S. Dollar Index. The greenback has lost significant ground this year
column37: down more than 2%. Still
column38: it is unusually elevated against historical averages. Furthermore
column39: the hawkish tone that the U.S. Federal Reserve is transmitting isn't doing BP and other oil stocks any favors.Don't Overlook the Positives for BP!On the flip side
column40: the bearishness towards BP stock sets up a great contrarian play for the speculator. For starters
column41: it was hit harder than other energy stocks in its class. Presently
column42: Exxon-Mobil is down about 14% from its 2014 closing high. For Chevron
column43: it's even tighter at around 10% down. BP stock
column44: though
column45: takes the cake with a disparity of over 22%.Even if shares don't do particularly well
column46: BP can still be a winner for shareholders. All it has to do is not crumble - a fairly reasonable task given what it has gone through already. Both Mr. Taulli and fellowInvestorPlacecontributor Will Ashworth point out the 7.1%dividend yield. Not only is the yield substantially better than the competition
column47: management is forced to abide by it
column48: in a way.Click to EnlargeBP stock has been a laggard for many
column49: many years. Cutting the yield will not only send the wrong message
column50: it would be a repeat of the PR mistake that gutted the oil firm during the oil spill crisis. I'd like to think that even an oil company is better than that.That might be wishful thinking. However
column51: what's not deniable is the technical stability that BP stock has found.Netflix

column53: 2017 has started off on the wrong foot. From the close of Feb. 11
column54: 2016 until December 2016 ended
column55: BP has lifted skyward by a more than 30% margin. That magnitude of enthusiasm has to be corrected before it can begin a next move higher.When factoring in an improving labor market
column56: and the potential of vacationershitting the road

column1: Buy Tesla Inc. Stock Before the Ball REALLY Gets Rolling (TSLA);4/10/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsJust a little less than two weeks ago
column3: I pointed out thatTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) was in a better position for a breakout than it had been in years. If Tesla stock was going to work its way out of an annoying sideways rut
column4: this was an opportunity its fans and followers couldn't afford to ignore.makeArticleAd();It looks like traders saw the same last week
column5: and believed it enough to buy into it. TSLA has not only cleared the ceiling at $287 - it has followed through quite nicely without yet looking back. It looks like that old range between $179 and $287 really is in the rear-view mirror.What I didn't say then -just because of time and room constraints- was now that the stock's no longer shackled
column6: it becomes infinitely easier for analysts to dish out new (or more) bullish opinions on Tesla stock. We saw what could become a string of upgrades on Monday morning  even if it a strangely-worded bullish thesis.The Ball Is RollingFirst things first.The chart of Tesla shares below largely speaks for itself. That is
column7: since early 2014
column8: TSLA has bounced around between $179 and $287. A minor floor at $195 also played an occasional role. Last week
column9: though
column10: with some help
column11: Tesla stock finally pushed its way above a ceiling that had quelled a rally three different times over the prior two years.The 5 Best Stocks to Buy for AprilThe looming advent of the Model 3 and enthusiasm surrounding the newModel Yget most of the credit for the bullish thrust.Click to EnlargeIt matters more than you might think.As much as they'd like for you to believe otherwise
column12: Wall Street's analysts watch charts as much as anybody else does
column13: if not more so. There's nothing more damaging to their careers than deeming a stock a ""buy"" that doesn't move higher
column14: or calling a particular stock a ""sell"" that doesn't move lower. If nothing else
column15: a stock's chart trajectory helps the pros determine what's in store for a particular name.With that as the backdrop
column16: last week's breakout move from TSLA stock just made it considerably easier for an already-bullish analyst community to raise their opinions on the electric vehicle and solar panel maker.Piper Jaffray was one of the first to pull the trigger
column17: even if apologetically so.An Un-Upgrade on TSLA
column18: But WhateverAt first glance
column19: Piper Jaffray's upgrade from ""Neutral"" to ""Buy"" and the raised price target for Tesla stock from $223 to $368 seems like a fairly typical shift in sentiment. It was analyst Alexander Potter's explanation that left the market wondering if they should heed his advice. He noted:""Admittedly
column20: before investors can follow our advice and buy TSLA shares
column21: they will need to employ a ""creative"" valuation methodology and prepare for a bumpy ride.""Creative valuation? It gets better.Potter went on to say:""We sympathize with bears - but their (arguably rational) arguments probably won't matter. In many ways
column22: TSLA seems to play by its own rules. The company burns through cash at a rate that better-established companies would likely be crucified for  Tesla's production timelines are unreasonably fast.  Yet
column23: because of its superior products
column24: loyal shareholders
column25: and inspiring mission
column26: TSLA remains unscathed.""To a new investor looking for a results-driven valuation
column27: it's a maddening lack of results-based opinion. But trading veterans have a pretty good idea of what he means.While most stocks are driven by the underlying company's balance sheet and income statement
column28: a handful of stocks - ""story"" stocks - are largely a bet on future sentiment regarding that company's basic premise.Amazon.com
column29: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) is one of those names.I've said it before
column30: but it merits repeating now: AMZN shares are supported almost entirely on the notion that it's so pervasive because it's woefully profitable. The average consumer/investor loves the idea of being able to buy anything and everything at the push of a button
column31: and have it in their hands within a couple of days (if not sooner). The premise is more than enough to obscure the poor net margins Amazon habitually produces.Ditto for TSLA stock. Tesla burns through money like nobody's business and has a habit of overpromising and underdelivering. But it just doesn't matter. Electric cars are the future
column32: and CEO Elon Musk makes them cool
column33: not just EVs that look like go-carts.Apple Inc. Stock Will Correct Ahead of Q2 Earnings (AAPL)For Potter - and soon
column34: I suspect
column35: others - the premise is enough now that the stock's unstuck.Bottom Line for TSLA StockIt is what it is. Tesla stock may not be a great fit for grandma's retirement portfolio
column36: but for investors that understand some stocks are more of a psychological chess match than an investment
column37: TSLA can play a respectable role.Potter even goes on to say so without really saying so
column38: commenting ""[the company's products] have a captivating impact on consumers and shareholders alike; this advantage will be difficult to replicate.""Don't overthink this one. Just go with the flow. More upgrades are apt to be on the way now that Piper Jaffrey stuck its neck out.As of this writing

column1: No Profits for Tesla This Year -- or Next Year Either
column2: Warns Analyst;4/10/2017;"Every day
column3: Wall Street analysts upgrade some stocks
column4: downgrade others
column5: and ""initiate coverage"" on a few more. But do     these analysts even know what they're talking about? Today
column6: we're taking one high-profile Wall Street pick and putting it     under the microscope...What do you do when one of the top analysts on the planet   slashes its earnings forecast for one of the most popular stocks   in America -- but then recommends buying the stock anyway
column7: and   raises its price target 65%? I don't know about you
column8: but I sit up   and pay attention.Because that's exactly what we're seeing this morning
column9: as   investment bankerPiper Jaffray-- ranked in the top 20% of investors we track on   Motley Fool CAPS -- announced a new upgrade for shares ofTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) stock.makeArticleAd();Car buyers reserved Tesla's Model 3
column10: some before even the     vehicle was unveiled. Investors may happily do the same withTesla stock. Image source: Getty Images.1. Upgrading TeslaHere's how the story goes. This morning
column11: Piper Jaffray   announced the results of a seven-month road test it's conducted   on a Tesla electric car
column12: and a parallel valuation test it's   conducted on Tesla stock. Its conclusion: Tesla stock deserves an   upgrade from neutral to overweight (aka buy).As detailed in twin reports onTheFly.comandStreetInsider.comthis morning
column13: Piper says it's impressed with the car
column14: and ""can't   ... ignore"" the stock any longer. In particular
column15: Piper says it's   met with Tesla management and come away convinced that Tesla will   meet its goal of beginning deliveries of a Model 3 electric sedan   this year -- and the car's going to be a hit.2. Tesla's ""captivating impact""Actually
column16: those aren't Piper's exact words. To be precise
column17: what the analyst said is that Tesla's electric cars have a   ""captivating impact on consumers and shareholders alike.""Which is good news for Tesla
column18: because the price on this stock   just went a lot higher.3. Tesla by the numbersFollowing astrong Q1 deliveries reportlast month
column19: Tesla stockgained 7% in a day
column20: and hasn't looked back since. Now
column21: you might think that the   initiation of Model 3 deliveries this year would add to that good   news
column22: and maybe even drop some profits to Tesla's bottom line   ahead of schedule. (According to most analysts cited onS&P Global Market Intelligence
column23: Tesla is expected to report its first full-year profit in 2019
column24: and its first pro forma profit in 2018.)Piper used to count itself among those optimistic analysts
column25: but after crunching the numbers carefully
column26: and meeting with   management
column27: Piper now warns investors to buckle up for a bumpy   ride. Piper predicts Tesla will run into production   inefficiencies in striving to fulfill its Model 3 promise
column28: with   the result being that profits at the company will take a hit.   Instead of beginning to earn profits as early as Q3 of 2017   (Piper doesn't specify whether it's referring to pro forma   profits or the real
column29: GAAP-calculated variety)
column30: the analyst now   believes Tesla will lose money in every single quarter of 2017
column31: and end this fiscal year with a $4.83-per-share loss -- versus   the $0.42-per-shareprofitit previously predicted.Furthermore
column32: Piper expects Tesla to lose money in Q1 2018   ($0.88 per share) and Q2 2018 as well ($0.81)
column33: only turning   profitable -- finally -- in Q3 2018
column34: one full year later than it   had previously hoped to see.And even then
column35: Piper says Tesla will lose money for 2018 as a   whole -- $0.11 per share worth.So...sell Tesla
column36: right?Put it all together
column37: and what Piper Jaffray is predicting is   two more long years of no profits whatsoever coming out of Tesla   stock
column38: and only a chance of the stock turning profitable in 2019.   For the record
column39: that's also the year most other analysts on Wall   Street believe Tesla will finally turn profitable
column40: and earn about   $0.20 per share in GAAP net profit.Despite all this
column41: and despite the prospect of delayed   gratification
column42: Piper insists Tesla stock is a buy. Employing what   by its own admission the analyst calls ""a 'creative' valuation   methodology
column43: Piper argues that Tesla stock today -- at least two   years before it earns its first profit -- is worth $368 per   share. That's 65% more money than Piper previously thought Tesla   stock was worth. It also values the stock
column44: today
column45: at a simply astounding 1
column46: 840 times the profits that most   analysts believe that Tesla stock will earn...two years from   now.Does this sound like a crazy valuation? Yes
column47: it does. Then   again
column48: Tesla had no problem attractingpre-orders for 400
column49: 000 carsfrom buyers willing to wait a year (or longer) before they could   ever hope to see their new cars. Maybe Tesla investors will prove   willing to wait as long (or longer) to see their company earn a   profit.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column50: it can pay to listen. After all
column51: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column52: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column53: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3
column54: 2017Rich Smithhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Tesla. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Is a Factory Part of Tesla's (TSLA) Expansion Plan in China?;4/10/2017;"Rumors ofTesla
column2: Inc.TSLAbuilding a factory in China have surfaced once again. Southern Metropolis Daily
column3: a local Guangdong province newspaper
column4: has claimed (citing sources) that the company plans to independently fund and construct a factory in the region.Per the report
column5: Tesla has already approved a site for the facility and is awaiting the green signal from the local government. The report also speculated that the project will be announced within a year if the plan proceeds smoothly.However
column6: the electric vehicle producer has denied the report
column7: as told to CNBC. Tesla reiterated its commitment to the Chinese market
column8: the second largest auto market globally
column9: but stated that the plans outlined per the report are untrue.Tesla in ChinaAs the report noted
column10: a manufacturing unit in China would help Tesla reduce its border tax. Recently
column11: Chinese tech giant Tencent Holdings Ltd.TCEHYpurchased a 5% stake or 8.17 million shares in the company for $1.8 billion
column12: making it the fifth largest shareholder and paving a way for Tesla's further expansion in China. Tencent
column13: also based in Guangdong
column14: stated that the companies currently do not have any cooperative plans but may work together in the future.Tesla's market in China is significantly growing. The company saw its annual revenues from the country increase more than three times to over $1.06 billion in 2016
column15: making it second only to revenues from the U.S. China imported 11
column16: 839 Tesla vehicles in 2016
column17: five times more than the previous year. It has 24 stores and 348 regular charging stations in the country.Regulatory RequirementsWhile rumors of Tesla building a factory in China appear repeatedly
column18: a number of problems may also hinder the company in making this a reality. China has a policy requiring foreign auto manufacturers to set up joint ventures with local companies to produce vehicles. Moreover
column19: the foreign manufacturers cannot own more than 50% in the venture. Therefore
column20: it isn't clear whether the government would approve a plant owned independently by a foreign automaker.Rumors of a factory being set up by Tesla in partnership with other local companies have surfaced in the past. All of them have been subsequently denied by Tesla.PerformanceTesla outperformed the Zacks categorizedAuto Manufacturers-Domesticindustry over the last three months. During the period
column21: Tesla gained 31.6% while the industry witnessed a 0.6% rise. The outperformance has been supported by expansion plans and higher deliveries in first-quarter 2017.Zacks Rank & Key PicksTesla currently carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).Better-ranked companies in the auto space include American Axle & Manufacturing Holdings
column22: Inc.AXLand Allison Transmission Holdings
column23: Inc.ALSN. Both companies sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). column1: Buy Advanced Micro Devices
column2: Inc. (AMD) Stock When It Returns to Reality;4/10/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLast week
column4: Goldman Sachs started new analytical coverage ofAdvanced Micro Devices
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD) at a ""sell
column6: suggesting the stock had rallied too far
column7: too fast. Judging from the 6% tumble AMD stock took that day
column8: the market didn't see it coming.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockSee
column9: as far as traders were concerned
column10: the 430% gain that Advanced Micro dished out over the prior 12 months implies that traders felt the development of theRyzencomputer processor and theVegagraphics processor were going to put the company back on a growth track. Goldman Sachs' thoughtscalled their whole logic into question.Does Goldman analyst Toshiya Hari have a point? He does. More than that
column11: though
column12: Hari serves up an important reminder that a stock and the underlying company aren't always necessarily one and the same.Yes
column13: AMD Stock Is OvervaluedHari specifically feels Advanced Micro Devices isovervalued to the tune of 236%based on a plausible projection of sales over the course of the coming five years. He finds the stock's valuation is ""difficult to justify"" simply because it's ""priced to perfection
column14: and then some.Once rivalsIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) andNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) turn it into a price war
column15: the ugly reality of this overvalued name could take a real toll.That's why Hari believes AMD stock worth just $11 per share. That's more than 18% less than last week's closing price. And
column16: with a forward-looking (2018) price-to-earnings ratio of 45.1
column17: his stance sounds less and less crazy.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: Still the Best?It all begs the question: How in the world did AMD shares get in this condition in the first place?The simplest answer is: human nature.But Advanced Micro DevicesIson TargetYes
column18: you own a stock not for where the company is
column19: but where the company is going to be six to 24 months down the road. It's not always easy to make a reasonable long-term guesstimate
column20: but most traders do it well enough most of the time.There are times
column21: however
column22: when common sense seems to get thrown out the window and investors decide today's a good day to buy simply because there's no bad news today. There's been no (relative) bad news from or about AMD stock for months now - because the company has been in regroup mode - and traders remained in buy mode without ever stopping to realize they've been in perpetual buy mode since April of last year. Hari only pointed that out.It's not the first time investors have needed to be reminded a stock can't rise forever on a company's ""promising future."" Sooner or later
column23: the future has to arrive and justify a frothy valuation. That future for Advanced Micro Devices is still a little too far off to keep the stock propped up at these levels.That being said
column24: the stock/company relationship is still a two-way street. A falling stock doesn't necessarily mean the underlying company is doomed. It's simply a matter of aligning a stock's price and a company's potential. Several observers still feel good about AMD (the company).Barron's Tiernan Ray is one of those optimists.Ray recently wrote:""My colleague Teresa Rivas has anice summary of the Goldman argument
column25: and Barron's positive view in contrast. The gist is that Hari is right about all the risks
column26: which have always been there. But the stock is not priced expensively
column27: as Hari implies
column28: if one believes the company can take significant market share back from Intel (INTC) and possibly Nvidia (NVDA).In hours of conversation with CEO Lisa Su
column29: CTO Mark Papermaster
column30: and other executives
column31: I did get a sense of a company with a more sober sense of purpose than in past days. I think the seriousness with which management recognizes both the opportunities and the risks is a meaningful factor. The company is aware that in past AMD fumbled leads it obtained. It is committed as an organization not to do so again.""All fair points.3 Stocks to Watch on Monday: Tesla Inc (TSLA)
column32: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) and Delta Air Lines
column33: Inc. (DAL)But
column34: even Ray's commentary has a big ""if"" in it: If Advanced Micro Devices can steal market share back from INTC and NVDA. The consensus is
column35: Nvidia and Intel are ready to go to war.Bottom LineI'll repeat something I said back on March 10:""Don't confuse any future weakness from AMD as evidence of what's in store
column36: results-wise
column37: from the company. Advanced Micro Devices is very well positioned for a great 2017. The trick is just being patient enough to wait for a truly palatable entry price. That could still be well below the recent low.In other words
column38: you don't want to step into AMD stock for the long haul until it's almost uncomfortable to do so. We aren't there yet.""We still aren't there yet. I'm not even sure a retreat to Hari's target of $11 would get us all the way there. It's still a compelling company though.As of this writing
column39: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceFitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Hurts

column4: Fitbit shares are down 24% in the markets. Obviously

column6: it wasn't supposed to be like this. FIT stock was a breath of fresh air for a whole number of reasons.You can start with the leadership. Fitbit CEO James Park doesn't fit the mold of your typical Wall Street boss
column7: and I think that's great! He seems to really care about his organization
column8: and how he can return value for FIT stock investors. Apparently
column9: he has yet to finish his degree at Harvard College
column10: so he's not an education snob
column11: either.That quirkiness and lively ""can-do"" personality is evident in FIT products. For example
column12: rather than naming their products with generic
column13: alphanumerical codes
column14: Fitbit dug a little deeper in thecreative department. Offerings such as ""Alta
column15: ""Charge"" and ""Surge"" are self-defined and help clarify what their mission purpose is. These attributes also contributed to memorable marketing campaigns - a big plus for Fitbit stock.Sales Decline Truly Hurt FIT StockOf course
column16: things almost always work better in your head. And while the fundamentals were supportive of FIT stock
column17: the markets had their own say.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: Still the Best?The biggestimpedimentto Fitbit stock is sales. Simply put
column18: FIT is no longer the toast of Wall Street. Back in 2012
column19: for instance
column20: the company registered $76 million in sales. A year later
column21: that figure jumped to $271 million
column22: or a near-257% gain. Most remarkable of all
column23: it only took two years from there to hit the billion-dollar benchmark. When it did so
column24: it was threatening$2 billion
column25: not $1 billion.But in fiscal 2016
column26: FIT stock could only muster less than $2.2 billion in revenue. Against the banner year of 2015
column27: that's only a 17% gain. But sales growth between 2013 and the end of 2015 averaged almost 200%. You can see the day-and-night dichotomy here. And if you can see it
column28: so too can the professional traders and hedge fund managers.The problem wasn't just limited to a one-off occurrence. Sometimes
column29: the markets are charitable
column30: or at least forgiving. The issue became what was at stake. Fitbit products began looking awfully commoditized
column31: which was the kiss of death forGoPro Inc(NASDAQ:GPRO).Not wanting to repeat that mistake
column32: investors quickly dumped out of Fitbit stock.I can understand their concerns
column33: but here's a thought: if Fitbit is commoditized
column34: aren't all consumer electronic companies likeApple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)
column35: Sony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE)
column36: andSamsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) also commoditized?The point is not whether commoditization is occurring - it is. Rather
column37: it's the potential for future business. And this is why I'm still bullish on FIT stock.Potential Demand for Fitbit Products Is Huge!In a previous article about Fitbit stock
column38: I mentioned that Americans love theirgym memberships.Good times or bad
column39: we head to fitness centers across the country. Logically
column40: we can deduce that people will also open their wallets for fitness-related accessories. That's a net positive for FIT stock
column41: no matter how you cut it.Still
column42: the gym membership factor only considers those who are currently involved in fitness regiments. Outside of that group lies an enormous pool of potential Fitbit customers. According to the President's Council on Fitness
column43: Sports & Nutrition
column44: ""Less than 5%of adults participate in 30 minutes of physical activity each day."" Furthermore
column45: ""only one in three adults receive the recommended amount of physical activity each week.""In other words
column46: FIT stock may be levered to a commoditized product
column47: but there is great demand for it. After all
column48: fitness is the cheapest and most effective way to promote healthy living and reduce overall healthcare costs. If more education about fitness concerns proliferate
column49: the debate about ""Obamacare"" may finally simmer down.How to Short Advanced Micro Devices
column50: Inc. (AMD) Stock for FreeFinally
column51: what makes Fitbit stock stand out at this juncture is the economy. It's not as great as President Donald Trump wants it to be
column52: but it's getting there. If people were already spending money on gym memberships when the economy was pedestrian
column53: imagine what they may do as it improves.You can't necessarily make the same argument about other consumer electronic devices. Nobody needs to have another camera
column54: or the latest smartphone. But humans absolutely need at least a modicum of physical activity. Fitbit devices helps people achieve their personal fitness goals
column55: and the current environment is quite conducive. Therefore
column56: I see good things ahead for FIT stock.As of this writing

column1: Edmunds Predicts an EV Crash. Should Tesla Be Scared?;4/9/2017;"Edmunds has some potentially terrible news for the nascent   market for electric vehicles. In anew report(link opens a PDF)
column2: industry analysts at the automotive   researcher predict that the upcoming expiration of federal tax   incentives could utterly destroy the EV market. In no uncertain   terms
column3: Edmunds predicts
column4: ""Without these credits
column5: this market is   likely to crash."" Ouch.The underlying rationale for that grim assessment is a case   studio of the EV market in Georgia
column6: which looks at how EV sales   fared before and after the state's EV tax credit ($5
column7: 000) expired   a couple of years ago. As a product category
column8: EVs saw their   market share decimated after the state tax credit expired.   Georgia's share of U.S. EVs fell from 17% to just 2% following   the expiration. Extrapolating the impacts
column9: Edmunds concludes that   we may see the same play out on the national level once the   federal credit expires. President Trump is a notorious climate   denier and champion of coal
column10: but the idea of eliminating the   credits prematurely is probably more trouble than it's worth.   What's more likely is that Donald Trump and a Republican Congress   simply won't renew them.Model S. Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();As the dominant domestic player in EVs
column11: shouldTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) be scared?The Leaf does not speak for everyoneNaturally
column12: Tesla is included in the Georgia market. Just as   expected is that Tesla's unit sales comprise a small minority
column13: given high price points and premium positioning. There's another   vehicle that effectively dominated the market though: theNissanLeaf. It's not an exaggeration to say that the Georgia EV market   more or less lived or died by the Leaf. Citing IHS Markit
column14: Edmunds points out that the Tesla Model S saw a more minor dip   following the credit's expiration
column15: and then rebounded ""within a   few months."" The Leaf did not recover.Image source: IHS Markit via Edmunds.Here's the thing: The underlying data of the report speaks   primarily of the Leaf. The Leaf has been declining in both   relevance and competitiveness as a product for a few years now.   Nissan was certainly a first mover in EVs
column16: but the company didn't   continue investing aggressively to improve things such as range   or battery degradation. The DC fast-charging standard that Nissan   championed
column17: CHAdeMO
column18: is also in decline. There's an entirely new   breed of EVs on the horizon
column19: including the Model 3
column20: that can   offer twice the range of the Leaf at almost the same price point.General Motors' Chevy Bolt is here; GM has already sold roughly 3
column21: 600 units in   the U.S. since launching last year
column22: and the geographical rollout   is ongoing.The Bolt and Model 3 are arguably the first mainstream
column23: affordable EVs that can offer 200 miles of range or more
column24: a key   psychological threshold for consumers to alleviate range anxiety.   Extrapolating the Leaf's declining performance
column25: some of which is   undoubtedly attributable to the credit expiration in Georgia
column26: to   other superior EVs nationwide is a tenuous argument.Deal breaker?Edmunds points to the historical underperformance of EVs too
column27: citing President Obama's famous prediction that there would be 1   million EVs in the U.S. by 2015. The market fell far short of   this target for a number of reasons
column28: but consider that Tesla   currently has about 400
column29: 000 Model 3 reservations in hand --   singlehandedly representing 40% of Obama's target from 2011.Some of these Model 3 buyers will receive the federal tax   credit; Tesla is expected to hit the 200
column30: 000 threshold that   triggers the phase-out in early 2018. But a meaningful percentage   of these customers should have no illusions of receiving the   credit; it's unclear how many are actually basing their   purchasing decision on the credit and whether the credit is a   deal breaker for them.@nickbaumI believe so- Elon Musk (@elonmusk)March 24
column31: 2017Even without the credit
column32: the average sales price of a car in   the U.S. is right around $35
column34: so it's not unreasonable to   price a compelling EV at that price point with no additional   incentives. Tesla's reservation tally for the Model 3 shows   beyond a doubt that there is meaningful demand for the right EV   at the right price and could very well pick up where the Leaf   left off in carrying the EV market. Demand is not the issue here;   the biggest challenge for the time being will be ramping up   manufacturing to satisfy that demand.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: General Motors vs. Tesla Stock: Why GM Will Win;4/9/2017;"Shares of electric-car pioneerTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) have rocketed higher by 65% since the beginning of   December
column2: after two and a half years of up-and-down performance.   This big jump reflectsgrowing anticipationfor Tesla's upcoming Model 3 sedan
column3: continued strong sales for   its pricey Model S and Model X vehicles
column4: and improving investor   confidence regarding Tesla's other green energy ventures.Tesla's huge rally has boosted its market cap to about $49   billion
column5: even though the company is still unprofitable. That   figure puts it ahead of No. 2 U.S. automakerFord Motor. Tesla is now closing in on industry leaderGeneral Motors'(NYSE: GM) $51 billion market cap.makeArticleAd();Tesla stockprice and market cap growth; data byYCharts.Barring a huge setback
column6: Tesla is almost certain to surpass   GM's market cap eventually
column7: and it will probably be soon.   Nevertheless
column8: General Motors is a better bet for investors --   even those with a long-term mindset.Tesla has been on a rollThere's no doubt that Tesla has been firing on all cylinders   in the past few months. In the company's most recent earnings   report
column9: Tesla revealed that orders for the Model S and Model X   combined were up 49% year over year in Q4. It also confirmed that   it is on track to begin limited production of the new Model 3 in   July.Tesla reported more good news last week
column10: announcing that it   built 25
column11: 418 vehicles during the first quarter and delivered just   over 25
column12: 000. That was important
column13: because while Tesla has never   had trouble selling cars
column14: production snafus have been a recurring   problem.If Tesla is finally ironing out its operations
column15: that's a very   good sign for shareholders. CEO Elon Musk envisions building 1   million vehicles annually within a few years
column16: way above the   record of 76
column17: 230 deliveries reached last year. Achieving that   goal (or even getting close) will require Tesla to master the   complexities of mass production.Tesla is gearing up to start production of the Model 3     sedan. Image source: Tesla.But cash flow matters -- a lotNotwithstanding Tesla's strong growth trajectory
column18: the company   is still losing money and burning cash at a rapid rate. Tesla has   had to raise capital repeatedly in the past few years by selling   more shares and raising debt (mainly convertible notes).By contrast
column19: General Motors has become extremely profitable.   In 2016
column20: it generated a record adjusted operating profit of $12.5   billion and adjusted automotive free cash flow of $6.9 billion.   While investors seem to be very worried that U.S. auto sales have   peaked
column21: GM's management has said the company will produce EPS of   $6.00-$6.50 this year
column22: in line with or slightly higher than   last year's record mark of $6.12.General Motors' strong earnings and cash flow have allowed the   company to start returning lots of cash to investors. GM stock   has a strong dividend yield above 4%. Furthermore
column23: the company   has spent more than $6 billion on share buybacks over the past   two years and plans to repurchase another $5 billion of stock in   2017.GM's cash flow trajectory may be bumpy going forward
column24: but it   is well positioned to increase its free cash flow over the next   five to 10 years. First
column25: the company's decision to jettison its   money-losing European operations will improve its annual free   cash flowby about $1 billion.GM's decision to sell its Opel/Vauxhall division will boost     its free cash flow. Image source: General Motors.Second
column26: General Motors is in the early stages of a long-term   plan to move all of its vehicles to as few as four major   platforms (or ""vehicle sets"") to reduce costs. If this effort   succeeds
column27: it could reduce GM's annual capex requirements further
column28: boosting free cash flow. That situation would allow it to return   even more cash to shareholders.Focus on total return
column29: not market capMany investors seemingly fail to appreciate the fact that GM   is returning more and more cash to shareholders
column30: while Tesla is   steadily issuing more shares to fund its growth.There's nothing wrong with either capital allocation strategy
column31: per se. General Motors is a mature company
column32: so it's appropriate   for it to focus on generating free cash flow and returning most   of that cash to shareholders. By contrast
column33: Tesla is still in the   early innings of its growth
column34: so it's quite sensible for the   company to be investing heavily to drive future growth.However
column35: this distinction means that investors shouldn't be   comparing changes in the two companies' market caps. Instead
column36: they should be focusing on GM and Tesla shares' total return
column37: including dividends.Thanks to its frequent share issuances
column38: Tesla's market cap has   nearly doubled in the past three years
column39: while GM's market cap has   declined. But on a total return basis
column40: Tesla's lead over GM is   much smaller -- and it was trailing by a significant margin just   a few months ago.Tesla vs. General Motors market cap and total return   performance; data byYCharts.General Motors stock currently trades at a depressed price   because investors are extremely pessimistic about its long-term   prospects. Conversely
column41: Tesla stock has a lofty valuation because   of investors' optimism about its growth trajectory.However
column42: in the very long run
column43: free cash flow drives share   price performance. Every year General Motors generates strong   free cash flow and returns it to shareholders
column44: existing GM   shareholders will get a bigger proportional stake in this cash   machine. Every year Tesla issues more shares
column45: investors see their   stake in the company's future profits decrease.This gives GM a huge advantage over Tesla in the long run from   an investing standpoint. If the company's initiatives to become   more efficient and increase its cash flow are even halfway   effective
column46: General Motors stock is likely to deliver bigger gains   for investors than Tesla stock over the next five to 10 years.10 stocks we like better than General MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column48: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column1: STMicroelectronics NV (ADR) (STM) Stock Is a Stealthy Giant;4/7/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSTMicroelectronics NV (ADR)(NYSE:STM) is finally getting its time in the sun. This maker of components and integrated circuits isn't a consumer brand as much as it is a mainstay in almost all facets of consumer and industrial tech products.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAnd what that boils down to is that this Swiss company is a major player in the massive Internet of Things transition
column3: as well as inventory and production monitoring technologies.On the consumer side
column4: you have companies likeNintendo Co.
column5: Ltd (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NTDOY) that areusing its motion sensors and touch screen integrated circuitsin its new Switch console/handheld hybrid. On the industry side
column6: you have cutting edge firms likeMicrovision
column7: Inc.(NASDAQ:MVIS) partnering with STM to develop laser beam scanning technology to enhance products for augmented and virtual reality
column8: as well as pico projectors (tiny digital projectors that can fit in your hand).These are just a couple typical deals that STM has been in engaged in for decades. But the compelling thing about STM now is
column9: the tech it has been building and perfecting
column10: it's time has come.3 Bank Stocks to Trade Without Spending a DimeWhat's the Big Deal?For many years
column11: people talked about how RFIDs (radio frequency identification) was going to be a massive game changer. But that revolution became more of an evolution once the global financial crisis hit. RFID circuits are used to track goods more efficiently than traditional methods.For example
column12: say there is a container ship arriving in port. If customs wants to see what's in the containers
column13: it has historically had to open some of the containers to see if it matches what's on the manifest. But that becomes a crapshoot. Most cargo ships hold around 20
column14: 000 containers that have to be unloaded and moved out of the harbor as quickly as possible.With RFIDs
column15: you can simply use a scanner that can read the contents of the containers without ever having to open them up. Much faster and efficient. You may also see them in mail order packages that show up at your house. The pharmaceutical industry has begun to use them with name brand drugs and opioids to track them as they make their way to pharmacies and hospitals. STM is one of the leading makers of RFIDs.As for the quickly developing megatrend the Internet of Things
column16: STM has been waiting for the market to catch up to it for years. And now it has. The stock is up more than 190% in the past 12 months. But this is simply pent-up growth from years of preparation for industry to catch up with STM technology.Put the Twitter Inc (TWTR) Stock Nightmare to BedThe other significant advantage STM has in this sector is its size. Now that companies are investing in this kind of transformative tech
column17: they need a proven supplier that can deliver large quantities of high quality products.And STM can deliver both.Louis Navellieris a renowned growth investor. He is the editor of five investing newsletters:Blue Chip Growth
column18: Emerging Growth

column1: Count on Procter & Gamble Co (PG) Stocks Consistency;4/7/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsProcter & Gamble Co(NYSE:PG) has been around for almost 180 years at this point.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Let that sink in. Almost 180 years. Over that course of time
column3: it has been through quite a lot. Texas had recently declared independence from Mexico
column4: Martin van Buren was President of the United States - and PG was selling soaps and other millinery.While its dividend doesn't go backthatfar
column5: it has grown its dividend every year since Dwight D Eisenhower was president. Its rival along the way has beenColgate-Palmolive Company(NYSE:CL)
column6: which has been around even longer. More recently the Anglo-Dutch conglomerateUnilever Plc (ADR)(NYSE:UL) has also joined the fray. However
column7: PG towers above its competitors in market cap.The interesting thing is
column8: Procter & Gamble has cut almost 100 brands since 2014 in effort to focus its energies on its top products. The strategy has paid off. Margins are strong
column9: debt is down and the stock continues to perform well.All that
column10: and it delivers a rock-solid 3% dividend yield.The 7 Best Retirement Stocks That No One Talks AboutGranted
column11: since the Donald Trump Rally has begun
column12: its dividend and slow-but-sure growth may not look very sexy but not everything in your portfolio should be rockets to the moon. And given the continued run up
column13: you can be sure that the good times aren't going to last forever. We're already seeing signs of growing volatility
column14: which is a sign that president and Congress' honeymoon is over on Wall Street and it's looking for results now
column15: not rhetoric.The Future of PG StockOnce significant economic decisions are made in Washington
column16: you can be sure Wall Street will vote with its feet. And that is why stocks like Procter & Gamble are so important to have as bedrocks to any portfolio. It has proven it can grow through the toughest market conditions. And if things get dicey
column17: even the seasoned professionals turn to consumer staples like PG.There are some challenges in some of its key strategic markets. For example
column18: UL's Dollar Shave Club is making inroads into Procter & Gamble's stranglehold on the men's shaving sector
column19: where PG now has a 65% market share. But in the big picture of things
column20: this isn't a major concern because it is very good at keeping its costs under control.For example
column21: in 2012 its costs of goods sold were around $42 billion. This year
column22: they're around $32 billion
column23: according to company numbers. All that was occurring while the global economy was going through slow to no growth. And it has continued that kind of hard-nosed look at its bottom line to this day.But it's not all about cutting products and costs
column24: either. PG is also focused on the next wave of growth. For example
column25: it recently just finished a deal to purchase a start-up laundry business for college students. The operation is already on 23 college campuses around the U.S. and now PG will roll out itsTide University Laundrybusiness to even more locations.Richard Band'sProfitable Investingadvisory service helps retirement savers outperform the market without losing a minute of sleep along the way. column1: Are Light Vehicle Sales on a Secular Decline?;4/6/2017;"The automotive industry came out with its monthly sales data this week and things don't look so good. While March does seem to be something of a low point
column2: the seasonally adjusted annualized rate (SAAR) was the lowest in two years. Data provider Autodata says that SAAR of sales for March 2017 was 16.62 million units compared with 16.67 million units a year ago.WardsAuto data was even more conservative at around 16.53 million units. Analysts polled by Reuters were expecting around 17.3 million units
column3: so auto stocks did a nose dive following the results.What Seems to Be the Problem?Used Car Prices Are on a Decline: With used car supplies on a rise as a large number of previously-leased cars reportedly hit the market
column4: there is a pressure on prices. This impacts new car sales because of cheaper used car alternatives. It also extends the replacement cycle since turning in an old car fetches a lower price. This affects new car sales.Longer Holding Period: People have been hanging on to their cars longer than they did earlier
column5: mainly because of the extended recessionary conditions that made consumers more conservative. So even after the markets got more conducive
column6: the decision to replace has become dependent on incentives (at least in part). Morgan Stanley expects government incentives like cash for clunkers to kick in some time this year
column7: as older cars without the latest safety equipment continue to get into more accidents.Lower Gas Prices
column8: Rising Consumer Confidence: This would be positive for car sales; just that consumers seem to be bypassing the light vehicle category and opting for SUVs and pickups instead. This is an overall positive for automakers although negative for their light models because SUVs and trucks are higher-priced and generate higher profits. IHS Markit analyst Stephanie Brinley says that new SUV models to hit the market this year will ensure strong sales and ""These vehicles will continue to drive the story of increasing popularity of utility vehicles and maintain pressure on car sales.""Rising Delinquencies on Auto Loans: The last few years have been favorable from an interest rate perspective
column9: helping sell cars
column10: especially to those who would not otherwise have bought one. But the situation is getting a bit out of control as the 60+ day delinquency rate for subprime auto loans is at the highest in at least seven years
column11: according to Fitch. But since car sales remain hard to make
column12: it could further increase competition between lenders
column13: adding to their risk (as Moody's predicts). This would mean a contraction in loan supply further down the line
column14: driving a vicious cycle.Automakers have now started increasing their discounts on cars in order to burn off rising inventories and there should be corresponding negative impact on profits. But sales levels indicate that even the heavy discounting is not fetching desired results
column15: so they may be required to cut production. This will of course lead to lower capacity utilization and thereby
column16: hit margins again.2017 Was Supposed to Be GoodMorgan Stanley was positive about car sales going into the year and estimated that sales would grow 2-4%. It was banking on higher replacement and government incentives.Germany's Center for Automotive Research (CAR) estimated a 2% increase
column17: on the back of Trump's economic stimulus programs and tax cuts.J.D. Power and LMC Automotive said that expected fiscal stimulus and deregulatory policies of President Donald Trump would boost sales.BMI Research was less enthusiastic
column18: saying that the market was reaching a natural plateau after several years or strong growth and that rising used car stocks and the debt situation would take a toll. It expects a 1-1.8% decline this year despite 1% growth in SUVs and trucks.March Gainers and LosersThetop gainersin March shipments were General MotorsGM1.5%
column19: Tesla MotorsTSLA45.9%
column20: Nissan 3.2%
column21: Volkswagen 2.6%
column22: Mitsubishi 6.2%
column23: Mazda 4.9%
column24: BMW 3.6%
column25: Daimler 2.0%
column26: Subaru 11.3%
column27: Porsche 3.6%.Thetop losersin March were FordF-7.2%
column28: Fiat Chrysler AutomobilesFCAU-4.6%
column29: Toyota Motor Sales (TM) -2.1%
column30: HondaHMC-0.7%
column31: Hyundai -8.0%
column32: Volvo Cars -21.9%
column33: Kia Motors -15.2%.Summing UpThis year could see automakers under pressure to sell accumulated inventory of light vehicles and they may also be driven to cut production. But there will be a boost in other areas
column34: so companies like Ford that have popular models in those categories will do well.Second
column35: there is expected to be a steady flow of new SUV models that will also be positive for automakers' revenue and profitability. Not all automakers have gotten in the electric car game
column36: but 2017 should also see some speeding up there
column37: particularly because it is incentivized by the government.So although light vehicle sales remain disappointing and the near to mid-term prospects in that category aren't too bright
column38: this may not be a disappointing year for automakers.Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today

column1: Tesla Inc: The Model S Is Better Than the Model 3;4/6/2017;"Electric-car makerTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) is getting aggressive about informing potential   customers that its upcoming Model 3 is not a third version of its   Tesla vehicles
column2: but rather a smaller
column3: more affordable version of   its pricier Model S sedan
column4: with fewer features and less   range.Tesla CEO Elon Musk first started pushing this anti-selling of   Model 3 late last month
column5: when he tweeted
column6: ""Am noticing that many   people think Model 3 is the 'next version' of a Tesla
column7: like   iPhone 2 vs 3. This is not true."" In a follow-up tweet
column8: Musk   admitted the Model 3 name could cause confusion: ""I was a dumb   idiot and didn't realize at the time that it would cause   confusion.""Model S. Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();But now Tesla is back again with a more formalized approach to   clarifying any confusion about how the Model S and Model 3   differ. In a new company blog post
column9: titled ""Model S or Model 3
column10: Tesla details the different value propositions for the two   vehicles. Here are some highlights from the blog post.Model S is more advanced than Model 3""Our higher priced premium models still include the most   advanced technology and the best driving experience we have to   offer
column11: reads the blog post. Tesla goes on to explain that Model   S is still a hit with customers. Citing a recentConsumer Reportssurvey
column12: Tesla said 94% of Model S owners would buy the vehicle   again.Key differentiating features for the Model S compared to the   Model 3 include:It has a 5-star safety rating and will continue to be our     flagship Model with more range
column13: more acceleration
column14: more     power
column15: more passenger and cargo room
column16: more displays (two) and     more customization choices. With Ludicrous+
column17: Model S has a     zero-to-60 time of 2.28 seconds as measured by Motor Trend
column18: making it the fastest accelerating production car in the world.     Model S will also continue to be the longest-range vehicle     we offer
column19: capable of a landmark 335 miles on a single charge
column20: meaning you can travel from Los Angeles to San Francisco     nonstop.So
column21: what does this leave for the Model 3? Ultimately
column22: the   biggest value proposition for the Model 3 is its more affordable   price tag. Model 3 will start at $35
column23: 000 while Model S starts at   $74
column24: 500 (Tesla isdiscontinuing its $68
column25: 000 60 kWh Model Son April 16). Apart from Model 3's lower price tag
column26: Model S has   Model 3 beat: The Model 3 is smaller
column27: simpler
column28: and will have   fewer options than Model S
column29: Tesla explained in Thursday's blog   post. In addition
column30: the Model 3's starting driving range of 215   miles is well below the 259-mile starting driving range of the   Model S.Model 3. Image source: Tesla.Safety is still a top priority for Model 3When it comes to safety
column31: however
column32: Tesla won't be compromising.   The self-driving hardware will come standard in Model 3
column33: just as   it does in Model S
column34: Tesla explained on Thursday. Tesla says   over-the-air updates will eventually enable all Tesla vehicles
column35: including Model 3
column36: with thisOctober-released hardwareto achieve a safety level that is ""substantially"" greater than   what a human driver is capable of.Tesla's anti-selling of Model 3 in favor of Model S comes as   Model S sales growth is slowing. In 2016
column37: Model S deliveries   increased only 1% compared to 2015. And in Tesla's first quarter   of 2017
column38: Model S deliveries were only 8% year over year
column39: while   deliveries of Tesla's newer Model X SUV nearly quadrupled.Tesla's need to clarify the differences between Model S and   Model 3 also comes as the company's planned Model 3 launch nears.   Tesla intends to begin Model 3 production in July.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
