column1: Its Time Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Bulls Act Humble;4/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe story atTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) is one of the most interesting in the entire stock market. Led by CEO Elon Musk
column3: Tesla is building an automaker essentially from scratch. (Notentirelyfrom scratch: the company did buy its Fremont
column4: California plant from a joint venture owned byGeneral Motors Company(NYSE:GM) andToyota Motor Corp(NYSE:TM).) It will take years
column5: if not decades
column6: for Tesla to achieve its ultimate goals. That timeline leads to a great deal of volatility and controversy in Tesla stock.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIndeed
column7: there are few stocks more divisive in the entire market. Tesla bulls call Musk a visionary and look to a future revolutionized by Tesla's electric vehicles and solar cells.The bears likely choose different words to describe Musk
column8: pointing to a nearly $50 billion market capitalization off negative free cash flow. After all
column9: Tesla shipped just 25
column10: 000 cars in the first quarter
column11: and yet shares of TSLA surpassed that ofFord Motor Company(NYSE:F)!There's truth to both arguments - something TSLA bulls and bears alike too often forget. Tesla has impressive potential - and a price to match. Considering that the story surrounding Tesla stock is going to take years to play out
column12: investors on both sides need to be nimble
column13: and need to be willing to change their views to match the facts on the ground.Most of all
column14: they need to be humble - because at some point
column15: many currently ardent Tesla investors will be proven wrong. Very wrong. The only question at this point is who.Tesla Stock Is Tough to Value@ForIn2020@waltmossberg@mims@defcon_5Exactly. Tesla is absurdly overvalued if based on the past
column16: but that's irrelevant. A stock price represents risk-adjusted future cash flows.- Elon Musk (@elonmusk)April 3
column17: 2017""A stock price represents risk-adjusted future cash flows."" Musk is precisely right.The argument about the valuation of TSLA stock is
column18: in essence
column19: an argument about what those future cash flows will be. And that's a legitimate argument to have. We don't know what Tesla's future auto shipments will look like. Government policies worldwide will influence the adoption of Tesla's solar roofs. Considering a February rollout
column20: it's not yet clear what consumers think of the product
column21: or how durable those roof tiles will be under real-world conditions.Where are steel prices going? What will U.S. wages look like in 2018? How about 2025? Each of these data points shapes an individual investor's model of what the current price of Tesla stock should be. Even that model impactsitself. The faster Tesla turns profitable
column22: the less Tesla needs to issue equity to fund the business
column23: and the more of the company current shareholders will own.There are myriad questions to be answered when estimating - emphasis on ""estimating"" - how much cash Tesla will generate in the future
column24: and thus how much a share of Tesla is worth. Intelligent
column25: rational investors can come up with very different end results.It's worth remembering that none - not a single one - of those investors will be right. Some will be closer than others
column26: but we're all just guessing. There are plenty of reasons why investors on both sides could be terribly
column27: terribly wrong.What TSLA Bulls Should RememberFirst
column28: $50 billion is a lot of money. It's too simplistic to argue that Tesla stock shouldn't be worth more than Ford stock simply because Ford makes many more automobiles
column29: and unlike Tesla
column30: is profitable. It's far from guaranteed that TSLA will be more valuable than Ford a year from now - or ten years from now. Tesla has an amazing amount of potential - but it has as much risk as almost any stock in the market.Second
column31: Tesla doesn't operate in a vacuum. Competition in electric vehicleswill be intense. GM has its Bolt.Nissan Motor Co Ltd (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NSANY) will replace the Leaf. On the higher end
column32: Tata Motors'(NYSE:TTM) Jaguar
column33: Audi(OTCMKTS:AUDVF)
column34: Porsche(OTCMKTS:POAHY) andMercedesall are targeting the space over the next two to three years.Right now
column35: Tesla can hold its own
column36: and it likely will be a fearsome competitor for some time. But the company also has benefited from largely having the middle- to upper-end of the EV market to itself. That will change.Third
column37: stuff happens.Amazon.com
column38: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) was a dot-com bust fifteen years ago.Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) almost went bankrupt. GMdidgo bankrupt
column39: and Ford almost followed. One single
column40: even minor
column41: recession changes the growth trajectory for Tesla stock. Consumers tend to focus less on the environment when they're worried about their own pocketbooks.And
column42: by the way
column43: Tesla's CEO is also launching rockets into outer space and trying tocreate cyborgs. He might get tired at some point. In all seriousness
column44: growth stories generally don't go in a straight line. TSLA stock likely won't be any different.What Tesla Stock Bears Should RememberAdmit it - even if you hate Tesla stock
column45: the cars are pretty cool. Reviews are generally positive
column46: and there is some value in the Tesla brand. The valuation may be too high
column47: but it's hard to see Tesla meeting the fate of the Delorean.Secondly
column48: comparing Tesla stock to Ford stock ignores the fact that Tesla isn't just a car company. Tesla even changed its name from ""Tesla Motors"" to reflect that fact. The acquisition of SolarCity and the larger ecosystem ambitions of the company matter to valuation
column49: too. Tesla wants to be a transformative company
column50: not just an automaker.Most importantly
column51: valuation alone is a dangerous reason to short a stock. TSLA bears may be proven right in the long run
column52: but the rest of the market has to realize it for Tesla stock to decline. What comes in the meantime - a borrow fee
column53: potential ""short squeezes"" - could be painful.What All Investors Should RememberInvesting is hard work
column54: but it should be fun at least sometimes. It's just money
column55: after all. Enjoy the ride! Don't take Tesla - or any other stock - so seriously.Amazon.com
column56: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Can Hit $1
column57: 000. But When?In the case of TSLA
column58: in particular
column59: don't be afraid to change your mind. Because with 100% of the value of Tesla Inc coming from future activity
column60: not current earnings
column61: all of us right now are simply guessing the best we can.As of this writing

column5: thereby negating my homework. The short-term reaction to earnings is mostly guesswork. For that reason

column1: Better Buy: NVIDIA vs. Qualcomm;4/5/2017;"NVIDIA's(NASDAQ: NVDA) success in PC graphics cards and its rapid   progress in nascent markets such asautonomous carshave translated into huge gains on the stock market in the past   year. In fact
column2: the graphics chipmaker has outperformed the   NASDAQ-100 Technology Sector Index by a wide margin
column3: but the same   cannot be said about industry peerQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) .NVDAdata byYCharts.makeArticleAd();Qualcomm has been plagued by competition from Taiwanese rivalMediaTekthat's eating into itsmarket share
column4: while a lawsuit fromApplehas brought morenegative publicity. Simply put
column5: the chipmaker is finding it difficult to grow even   as NVIDIA is showing no signs of stopping.NVDA Revenue (TTM)data byYCharts.But is Qualcomm's weakness an opportunity in disguise
column6: or is   NVIDIA a better bet despite its terrific rise in the past   year?The case for QualcommQualcomm needs to be given credit for pursuing several   fast-growing markets to elevate its growth
column7: including feature   phones and virtual reality hardware. Though the chipmaker's   smartphone application processor market share has taken a beating   in the last couple of years owing to MediaTek's rise
column8: it is now   taking the game to its rivals.Qualcomm's Asian rival has thrived by offering lower-cost   chips to smartphone manufacturers. In fact
column9: MediaTek's strategy   helped it increase its smartphone processor market share to 23%   in the first half of 2016 from just 14% at the end of 2014.Qualcomm is now taking a leaf out of MediaTek's playbook by   targeting low-to-mid-range smartphones. The good news is that   this strategy seems to be bearing fruit
column10: as it could begaining market sharein China
column11: which is not surprising as Qualcomm iswinning overcertain chip spots from MediaTek.Image source: Qualcomm.What's more
column12: Qualcomm is also gaining traction at key Chinese   smartphone manufacturers
column13: such as Vivo and Oppo
column14: that are   expected to dominate the industry. The American chipmaker signed   a patent licensing agreement with these companies in August last   year
column15: and it has already found a way inside Oppo's latest F3 Plus   smartphone with its Snapdragon 652 processor.Qualcomm's partnerships with Chinese manufacturers will be   important in boosting its smartphone processor market share. This   is because the country's top three OEMs -- Oppo
column16: Vivo
column17: and Huawei   -- could account for a third of global smartphone shipments this   year with 500 million units in sales.Additionally
column18: Qualcomm is also making a move into the   potentially fertile feature phone market with its latest 205   mobile platform. The chipmaker plans to bring LTE and digital   payments services to sub-$50 phones with its latest launch
column19: which   is a smart move as 400 million feature phones were sold last   year
column20: according to Counterpoint Research.However
column21: China could also pose a concern for Qualcomm as the   government is trying to promote a domestic chip-making industry   with a $100 billion investment. In fact
column22: Xiaomi has already taken   this route as it recently announced that its latest Mi 5C   smartphone will be powered by an in-house chip. This is a red   flag since Xiaomi is one of Qualcomm's customers
column23: and the   possibility of others following suit could land a body blow to   the chipmaker's Chinese business.To mitigate the risk from China
column24: Qualcomm is moving early into   virtual reality (VR) hardware by offering adeveloper kitto accelerate the development of head-mounted displays (HMDs)
column25: which could be a $29 billion industry in 2020. Not surprisingly
column26: the chipmaker wants to take the lead in this space by trying to   become the supplier of choice to HMD manufacturers.The case for NVIDIANVIDIA's terrific growth is not going to stop anytime soon as   it dominates the discrete graphics processing units (GPU) market   with a 70% market share. In fact
column27: gaming contributes more than   60% to the chipmaker's business
column28: which is good news for investors   as the segment will witness annual growth of 6% for the next two   years
column29: according to Jon Peddie Research.Not surprisingly
column30: NVIDIA is trying to maintain its lead in   this market by tapping high-end gaming systems -- which accounted   for 43% of hardware last year -- and launching its latest   flagship GPU before rivalAMDcould make its move. As it turns out
column31: NVIDIA has upped the ante   in the GPU war by bringing out a new high-performance product --   the GTX 1080 Ti -- which is around 20% to 45% faster than its   predecessor.More importantly
column32: NVIDIA's lead in gaming graphics should give   its top line a strong boost as GPU shipments could rise to 67   million units in 2020 from around 30 million units in 2015
column33: according to Research and Markets.What's more
column34: NVIDIA is putting its GPU expertise to good use   in the automotive market
column35: which presents a lucrative revenue   growth opportunity. In fact
column36: the company is already supplying its   autonomous car platform toTesla's electric car line-up
column37: while it has also started working withPACCARto develop fully autonomous self-driving trucks.In all
column38: NVIDIA believes it has a revenue opportunity of   $6 billion to $10 billion in the automotive space
column39: and it is   going all-out to target the same by partnering with big   manufacturers.The better buyNVIDIA is a high-growth play as its earnings are expected to   grow around 18% over the next year
column40: compared to Qualcomm's muted   growth projection of less than 3%. Not surprisingly
column41: NVIDIA   carries a premium over Qualcomm from a valuation perspective
column42: with the GPU maker trading at almost 42 times last year's   earnings as compared to the latter's trailing price-to-earnings   ratio of 17.Additionally
column43: Qualcomm's market share is under threat from   Asian rivals. NVIDIA
column44: meanwhile
column45: is dominating its core market   hands-down and is spreading its wings into other fast-growing   areas that could lead to stronger returns.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column46: it can pay to listen. After all
column47: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column48: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column49: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now and Qualcomm wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3
column50: 2017Harsh Chauhanhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Apple
column51: Nvidia
column52: Paccar
column53: Qualcomm
column54: and     Tesla. The Motley Fool has the following options: long January     2018 $90 calls on Apple and short January 2018 $95 calls on     Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Could Ford Motor Company (F) Buy Tesla Inc (TSLA)?;4/5/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFirstTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) passedFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) and now it's done the same toGeneral Motors Company(NYSE:GM).makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThat's right
column3: Tesla has a bigger market cap thanall three of America's automakers. If Tesla stock keeps climbing at the same rate as the first three months of the year - it's up 32% year-to-date through April 5 - by the end of 2017 it could have a bigger market cap than all three of them combined.That's unlikely to happen
column4: but it shows you just how much of a story this is.Right now
column5: Ford stock is stuck in neutral while Tesla stock is flying down the stock market highway at 90 miles per hour. Things are so good for Tesla at the moment we've got Elon Musktauntingthe shorts. Normally
column6: I'm not a fan of CEO outbursts
column7: but it's hard not to like a guy who's singlehandedly changed the car business - for the better.Recently
column8: Ireflectedon Ford's plans for self-driving vehicles including its $1 billion investment in Argo AI
column9: a company that specializes in artificial intelligence and autonomous vehicles and founded and still run by the people who were in charge of self-driving cars atAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column10: NASDAQ:GOOGL) andUber.I came to the conclusion thatSmart Mobility LLC
column11: the business segment responsible for Ford's work commercializing self-driving cars
column12: was the key to the long-term success of Ford stock.I still feel this way
column13: which is why in recent days I've pondered the question: Could Ford really ever buy Tesla? Well
column14: three things stand in the way.Would Ford Want to Buy Tesla?No one's disputing Ford has a proud history producing cars and trucks in this country; Henry Ford almost single-handedly put the Motor City on a global stage. However
column15: the fact that it continues to lose ground to other car companies including GM
column16: suggests its future is anything but secure.In March
column17: Ford's U.S. sales fell by7%compared to a 5% decline atFiat Chrysler Automobiles NV(NYSE:FCAU) and a 1.6% increase at GM. For Ford it was a good news
column18: bad news scenario this past month selling 10% more F-Series pickup trucks in March at an average transaction price increase of $2
column19: 500 over March 2016. Unfortunately
column20: the rest of its business was abysmal.7 Tech Stocks That Will Crush the Market for YearsThere is signs Ford's Lincoln business is getting stronger and its fleet sales are still pretty healthy despite a 17% decline in March against strong year-ago numbers.I'm not sure CEO Mark Fields sees the need to throw a Hail Mary pass at this point in the game. However
column21: we're closer to the second half than I think anyone realizes.Could Ford Afford Tesla Stock?Tesla's enterprise value is currently $54.3 billion with most of that market cap and some net debt thrown in for good measure. Any offer for Tesla stock would have to be well north of $300.Ford's free cash flow for the latest 12 months is $12.8 billion
column22: higher than it's been in the past decade and trending higher. Certainly
column23: the higher prices it's getting for the F-Series helps a whole lot.Ford finished 2016 with $13.2 billion in automotive debt and $27.5 billion in automotive cash with 89% held in the U.S. That puts its automotive net U.S. cash at $11.3 billion. Without selling any assets or issuing shares it's got enough net cash to put down a 20% down payment based on a $60 billion price tag.If debt's used to cover the remaining $48 billion
column24: Ford's debt load would grow four-fold
column25: something that's not nearly as attractive given Tesla's lack of profits. If Tesla were making money it wouldn't be nearly as daunting a task.And of course
column26: there are rising interest rates which could make any discussion of this kind of a moot point.Would Elon Musk Ever Sell?It's really doubtful that the Tesla CEO
column27: who is the company's largest shareholder with26.5%of Tesla stock
column28: would ever consider selling the company he first invested in way back in2004. Not to Ford
column29: not to anyone. There's been too much blood
column30: sweat and tears in the 13 years since then for Musk to give up making Tesla theworld's greatest solar-powered transportation fleet.The only way I could see Ford or any other car company getting a deal done for Tesla would be under two scenarios: The first being that Tesla needed a deal to keep going
column31: and second
column32: the potential acquirer was willing to sell 100% of their business that made combustion-powered vehicles.Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock Is on Sale -- Go Long for FreeClearly
column33: the first scenario is more likely than the second. That said
column34: like the Model T
column35: Ford buying Tesla under either of these scenarios would be historical in nature and likely successful for Ford shareholders.But I wouldn't hold my breath.As of this writing
column36: Will Ashworth did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Entertainment Stocks to Buy as Summer Approaches11 A-Plus Stocks That Are on Bernstein's 'Buy List'Don't Spend a Penny on Amazon.com

column1: Will Clean Energy ETFs Benefit from a Carbon Tax?;4/5/2017;"The Washington Post recently reported that the Trump administration is considering the imposition of two controversial taxes
column2: a value added tax and a carbon tax. Shortly after the story surfaced
column3: the White House declared that it was currently considering neither of the two.A White House spokesperson said that the team is hearing inputs from multiple sources on how to fund the tax reform
column4: as it prepares to get the bill passed in the Congress after the failure of the healthcare bill.This indicates that the tax bill is still in the early stages of development
column5: as Trump fights to keep his promise of individual and corporate tax cuts without harming the economy.The carbon tax is likely to be aimed at industry emission of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases by burning fossil fuels. Though many Democrats supported the idea in the past
column6: it has been opposed by the majority of Republicans
column7: saying that it would be devastating for the economy. What's interesting is that such a tax
column8: if implemented
column9: would negate President Trump's ideologies on climate change
column10: as it will penalize people who burn coal
column11: oil and gas.When you use fossil fuels to generate electricity
column12: or to power your car
column13: the energy or gasoline prices are reflected in the bill. What is not reflected is the price of negative externalities. An individual is not paying for the pollution caused by the car
column14: even though it is impacting others who breathe the same air. A carbon tax is perhaps one of the better ways to promote the use of clean energy
column15: as it will increase the price of electricity and gas
column16: and therefore lead consumers to shift to hybrid cars and solar energy.The impact of such a move on the economy in terms of unemployment and standard of living is still uncertain. However
column17: assuming rational consumer behavior
column18: if prices of regular commodities rise drastically and alternatives are developed and available at cheaper rates in the future
column19: consumers are unlikely to shy away from clean energy (read:Auto ETF

column1: 3 Reasons to Buy Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Right Now;4/5/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhen it comes to stocks
column3: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) is as blue chip as they come. The technology giant has been a portfolio staple for decades and has powered generations of investors with long-term gains.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIn fact
column4: had you bought MSFT stock when it went public back in 1986
column5: you would have made nearly 67
column6: 000% on your investment. No wonder why Bill Gates is the richest person on the planet.And MSFT stock continues to impress investors. Mr. Softy was up an impressive 16% last year alone. With such an extraordinary returns history
column7: the question is
column8: can shares of Microsoft continue to make some serious money for its investors going forward?With the following three catalysts in play
column9: the answer is a resounding yes. Microsoft is still one of the better long-term buys in tech.Everything to Love About MSFT StockThe Cloud: While Microsoft is still the dominating force in PC operating systems
column10: it's future is a bit more cloudy. The continued rise of cloud computing and running virtual machines is driving MSFT stock into the future.According to technology market research firm IDC
column11: worldwide spending on cloud computing services is expected to grow to $195 billion by 2020. That's great news for Microsoft
column12: which is the second-largest player in cloud computing - behindAmazon.com
column13: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN). But Azure
column14: Microsoft's main platform
column15: is quickly growing at a faster clip.11 A-Plus Stocks That Are on Bernstein's 'Buy List'Microsoft continues to snag larger enterprise customers. Amazon has done well with smaller firms and regarding infrastructure as a service (IaaS). But the win for MSFT is that Azure can span on-premises and cloud environments.According to tech analysts
column16: many large enterprise IT users still have plenty of hardware of their own and aren't ready to fully embrace the cloud. The full migration of these larger customers is still in the early innings
column17: and because of its capabilities
column18: Microsoft has been quite successful at snagging them.Revenues for Azure surged awhopping 93%last quarter versus the year-ago period
column19: while overall cloud applications and software increased by 8%. Even better is the future. According to asurvey of CIOs by Morgan Stanley
column20: Azure will overtake Amazon Web Services by 2019 in both IaaS and Platform as a Service (PaaS) applications. This continued growth will only continue to drive revenues and profits for MSFT and its cloud division.The Hardware:It's no secret that MSFT hasn't exactly been known for its consumer hardware. Zune anyone? But that has been changing in recent years. Its Surface tablet/laptop hybrid has been a runaway hit. As has its latest Xbox entertainment unit. But the real growth could be from Microsoft's new Surface Studio high-end PC. While computer sales have slipped thanks to smartphone and tablet usage
column21: high-end PCs continue to feature swift sales figures. After all
column22: there's plenty of applications you can't do on the phone.Long has the high-end computer market been ruled byApple Inc's(NASDAQ:AAPL) Mac and smaller firms like Alienware. However
column23: the Surface Studio is a monster of a machine and could significantly take market share from Apple and other high-end producers of PCs.While it won't generate the kind of revenue that its cloud operations will
column24: it does get MSFT's other big business - productivity software - in the hands of more users and could help turn the tide of overall lower licensing fees.The Dividend:Thanks to its sustainable growth in earnings and cash flows
column25: MSFT stock has quickly become dividend stalwart. Over the last ten years
column26: Microsoft has increased its dividend by 300%. It's latest increase was another 8.3%. But more jumps could be on the horizon.For starters
column27: MSFT has about a $121 billion in cash on its balance sheet. That in of itself could lead to more dividends - especially if President Trump plans to allow repatriation of that cash at tax-free rates.There Is No Turnaround for Twitter Inc (TWTR) StockMoreover
column28: gains in cloud computing and other business should help MSFT earn around $4.33 per share in three years. Keeping its average rate of dividend growth
column29: MSFT stock should pay out around $2.10 to $2.15 per share in dividends in three years. That should give it a comfortable payout ratio of around 49%. That's easily doable and will lend itself to more dividend increases as well.In the end
column30: the growth in cloud computing and other surprise businesses - like hardware and LinkedIn - will continue to propel MSFT stock forward. It's hefty
column31: and growing dividend is icing on the cake. For investors looking for one of the best tech stocks out there
column32: Mr. Softy has to be on your list.As of this writing
column33: Aaron Levitt did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Energy Stocks That Are Ready for a Turnaround7 Tech Stocks That Will Crush the Market for YearsShort Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Without Getting Run OverThe post3 Reasons to Buy Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Right Nowappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Are Options Traders Betting on a Big Move in Tesla (TSLA) Stock?;4/5/2017;"Investors inTesla Motors
column2: Inc.TSLAneed to pay close attention to the stock based on moves in the options market lately. That is because the July 4th
column3: 2017 $230 Call had some of the highest implied volatility of all equity options today.What is Implied Volatility?Implied volatility shows how much movement the market is expecting in the future. Options with high levels of implied volatility suggest that investors in the underlying stocks are expecting a big move in one direction or the other. It could also mean there is an event coming up soon that may cause a big rally or a huge sell off. However
column4: implied volatility is only one piece of the puzzle when putting together anoptions tradingstrategy.What do the Analysts Think?Clearly
column5: options traders are pricing in a big move for Tesla shares
column6: but what is the fundamental picture for the company? Currently
column7: Tesla is a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) in the Automotive - Domestic industry that ranks in the Bottom 11% of our Zacks Industry Rank. Over the last 30 days
column8: one analyst has increased earnings estimate for the current quarter
column9: while no analyst has revised the estimate downward. The net effect has taken our Zacks Consensus Estimate for the current quarter from a loss of 68 cents per share to a loss of 67 cents in that period.Given the way analysts feel about Tesla right now
column10: this huge implied volatility could mean there's a trade developing. Often times
column11: options traders look for options with high levels of implied volatility to sell premium. This is a strategy many seasoned traders use because it captures decay. At expiration
column12: the hope for these traders is that the underlying stock does not move as much as originally expected.Looking to Trade Options?Each week
column13: our very own Dave Bartosiak gives his top options trades. Check out his recent live analysis and options trade for the LULU earnings report completely free. column1: Bankruptcies Give Vivint Solar and Sunrun a New Opening in Residential Solar;4/5/2017;"The residential solar industry in the U.S. is up for grabs and   there could be a new opportunity forVivint Solar(NYSE: VSLR) andSunrun(NASDAQ: RUN) to grab market share.SungevityandVerengo Solarrecently went bankrupt andNRGHome is exiting the home solar business
column2: taking three big   competitors out of the game.This doesn't change the fact that local andregional installers are gaining market share
column3: but it leaves fewer large installers with a national presence.   And there's still an opportunity to use that position to   profitably grow their customer base.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();National installers face the musicAs national installers like Vivint Solar
column4: Tesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) SolarCity
column5: and Sunrun built out their business
column6: they bet that a national infrastructure with third-party   financing (leases) would give them a competitive advantage. Over   the past year
column7: that strategy has fallen apartas loans and local and regional installers have gained market   share. Everyone in the industry is now realizing that the trend   will continue
column8: so Sunrun
column9: Vivint
column10: and Tesla are pushing toward   loans to stem some of the lost market share.While national installers were fighting one another for a   smaller piece of the pie
column11: it left everyone in a weaker position.   But weaker players like Sungevity and Verango Solar didn't   survive
column12: leaving just a few of the larger installers. And they're   making a needed transition to focusing their efforts on   profitable customers
column13: rather than growth at all costs. And with   fewer competitors
column14: it may be easy to make that transition to   profitability.Taking a new strategy to marketFewer competitors and the focus on cash and loan sales could   also open up new markets. When Sunrun announced it was entering   the Wisconsin market last week
column15: it did so with cash and loan   options and notably left out the lease. This is an acknowledgment   both that new markets may see solar as an attractive option and   that the lease is no longer a financing option that's worth   bringing to market.I would expect other states like Minnesota
column16: Missouri (Kansas   City)
column17: Illinois
column18: Indiana
column19: and Ohio to attract more installers   with similar structures. Particularly in Tesla's case
column20: the   company could expand into new states just by leveraging its   retail format. But I would expect Vivint and Sunrun to continue   to explore their own expansions now that they're armed with loan   offerings as well.Bankruptcies could be a big opportunityOver the past few years
column21: there have just been too many   companies fighting for the same pie in residential solar. Now   that some of the weaker players are falling off
column22: it'll leave   Vivint Solar and Sunrun in a stronger position
column23: particularly ifSolarCity backs awayfrom solar under Tesla.The fact that local and regional installers are gaining market   share is a challenge
column24: but I think there will still be a place for   national companies that are disciplined in their approach. Look   at it like home construction or home improvement
column25: where there are   national as well as local companies with a place in the   market.At the very least
column26: having less competition will make it easier   for Vivint and Sunrun to operate profitably. And with immediate   cash coming in from more cash and loan sales
column27: these may soon be   cash-generating businesses rather than solar finance companies
column28: which would be a welcome change for investors.10 stocks we like better than SunrunWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column29: it can pay to listen. After all
column30: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column31: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column32: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Sunrun wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3

column1: Best Stocks for 2017: Zions Bancorp (ZION) Stock May Find Nirvana in 2017;4/5/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEditor's note: This column is part of ourBest Stocks for 2017contest. John Jagerson and Wade Hansen's pick for the contest isZions Bancorp(NASDAQ:ZION).makeArticleAd();The beginning of 2017 was a time of hope and optimism on Wall Street. The election of President Donald Trump had changed everything from policy expectations and growth expectations to inflation expectations and more
column3: and the ramifications of those changing expectations had just started to play themselves out in the U.S. stock market.With that in mind
column4: we choseZions Bancorp(NASDAQ:ZION) to be one of the top-performing stocks in 2017.We believed ZION was uniquely situated to take advantage of a growing number of the potential changes that were expected to play themselves out in the U.S. economy and stock market this year. We believed the Trump administration could bolster ZION by:Scaling back
column5: or fully repealing
column6: the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act;Boosting inflation expectations;Relaxing environmental regulations for drilling while OPEC caps oil production; andLowering corporate tax rates.While the Trump administration has been successful in a few of these areas
column7: it has thus far fallen woefully short in others. Let's take a look.Scaling Back
column8: or Repealing
column9: Dodd-FrankWe were looking forward to the scaling back
column10: or repeal
column11: of the Dodd-Frank Act and believed it would boost ZION's revenue-generating potential by enabling the bank to trade more freely and issue more loans by creating collateralized debt obligations (CDOs) containing trust preferred securities (TrPS). We also anticipated a reduction in expenses for the bank as compliance costs fell.The 5 Best Stocks to Buy for AprilUnfortunately
column12: not much has happened on this front. In fact
column13: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has even expressed some support for the Volcker Rule - the portion of the Dodd-Frank Act that prohibits financial institutions from engaging in proprietary trading.It's still early
column14: but with all of the other legislative priorities stacking up in front of financial regulatory reform
column15: we aren't as confident this issue is going to be addressed in the near term.Boosting Inflation ExpectationsWe
column16: along with most others
column17: expected President Trump's economic policies to boost inflation here in the United States. Analysts were anticipating increased economic growth
column18: coupled with the potential for trade battles and the implementation of tariffs
column19: would boost inflation. As a result
column20: bond yields would be pushed higher to compensate bond investors for the increased inflation risks they would be facing. This
column21: in turn
column22: would lead to a steeper yield curve
column23: which would be a boon for banks.Unfortunately
column24: the ""reflation"" trade that dominated the market through the end of February has faded
column25: and the yield curve is flattening once again. This is a negative for banks and their net interest margin levels.Relaxing Environmental Regulations while OPEC Caps ProductionPresident Trump made good on his promise to relax environmental regulations for energy producers
column26: including opening up previously unavailable areas for oil exploration
column27: when he signed his ""energy independence"" executive order on March 28. This should benefit oil producers here in the United States
column28: some of whom have taken out loans from ZION.This should help the company reverse the rising tide of having to increase its loan loss provisions to compensate for the number of charge-offs in the energy sector.Lowering Corporate TaxesWith the failure of the Congress to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA) with the American Health Care Act (AHCA)
column29: many are wondering if the Trump administration is going to be able to do what it takes to reform the U.S. tax code and lower corporate taxes.ZION stock has shown in the past that it is more than willing to send cash back to shareholders in the form of increased dividends and share buyback programs. But if tax reform fails to materialize
column30: the company won't have any savings to pass on to shareholders.Conclusion for ZION StockWeekly Chart of Zions Bancorp (ZION)Each of the four fundamental factors we've discussed above has to potential to lift Zions Bancorp to new multiyear highs on its own
column31: but our confidence in them all coming together to push ZION higher has dropped somewhat.The Best Way to Play Tesla Inc (TSLA) at All-Time HighsZION hasn't really moved anywhere since we first looked at this stock at the beginning of the year. It has been up and down
column32: but there has been no net change.It still has the potential to climb back up toward longer-term resistance at $55 during 2017
column33: but it can only happen if the Trump administration and Congress can come together on tax reform.InvestorPlace advisors John Jagerson and S. Wade Hansen
column34: both Chartered Market Technician (CMT) designees
column35: are co-founders of LearningMarkets.com
column36: as well as the co-editors ofSlingShot Trader
column37: a trading service designed to help you make options profits by trading the news. Get in on the next trade and get 1 free month todayby clicking here.More From InvestorPlaceThe 7 Best Stocks to Buy for an Income-Rich RetirementAmazon.com
column38: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Has Reached Absurd Levels: Fade the Rally7 'Best of the Best' Stocks to Buy for the Second QuarterThe postBest Stocks for 2017: Zions Bancorp (ZION) Stock May Find Nirvana in 2017appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: It's Official: Tesla Is My Second 10-Bagger;4/4/2017;"I boughtApplethe year before the iPhone debuted (July 2006 at a pre-split   price of $60.83) and I boughtTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) about 18 months before the Model S.It was November 2010
column2: less than five months after Tesla's   initial public offering priced at $17 per share
column3: raising   approximately $225 million to help fund development of the Model   S. While the $29.23 that I paid was a bit higher than that   offering price
column4: it's worked out quite well in the nearly seven   years since
column5: as I still maintain the position to this day. Just   yesterday
column6: Tesla tapped afresh all-time high
column7: surpassing the prior high of around $291 set in September 2014   and exceeding the $292.30 price that technically represents my   threshold for 10-bagger territory. Shares continued running   today.My original Tesla trade confirmation. Image source:     Author.makeArticleAd();Don't get me wrong. Like most investors
column8: my investing career   is littered with as many mistakes as successes
column9: if not more. But   in today's climate of active trading and years of debate around   the ""death"" of buy-and-hold investing
column10: a little celebration is in   order: Long-term investing can still pay off.I got luckyI won't purport to have had some insightful epiphany in 2010   regarding the future of electric cars; I was just a naive   stockbroker at the beginning of my career in finance. As   environmentalists
column11: my wife and I simply thought Tesla was worth   supporting. In other words
column12: we got lucky to some extent
column13: at least   initially. It's notably harder to have the discipline to maintain   such a position
column14: particularly consideringTesla stock's volatility and polarizing nature.Image source: Tesla.What's most important
column15: though
column16: is what comes next. There's an   endless debate about Tesla's valuation
column17: as the company's market   cap has just surpassedFord's and is now approachingGM's. Ford sold 6.7 million vehicles last year
column18: while GM sold 10   million; both are solidly profitable.Tesla delivered 76
column19: 000 vehicles in 2016
column20: losing $773 million   in the process. These facts often and justifiably confound   analysts
column21: investors
column22: and industry pundits alike. Hardly a day   goes by without someone arguing that Tesla is overvalued
column23: which   is hard to dispute using traditional valuation metrics. As CEO   Elon Musk pointed out today on social media
column24: valuation is more   about the future than it is the past.@ForIn2020@waltmossberg@mims@defcon_5Exactly. Tesla is absurdly overvalued if based on the past
column25: but   that's irrelevant. A stock price represents risk-adjusted future   cash flows.- Elon Musk (@elonmusk)April 3
column26: 2017The biggest pitfall of valuationSo much of valuing stocks is fundamentally predicated on   comparable analysis. Tesla makes cars
column27: so the tendency is to   compare it to automakers. However
column28: Tesla's similarities to the   auto industry end there. Tesla is as much an energy company as it   is an auto company. It has been working on battery technology for   years through its partnership withPanasonic
column29: and is stepping directly into the solar industry with 2016's   acquisition of sister company SolarCity. It is more vertically   integrated than traditional automakers
column30: particularly when it   comes to the integration of hardware and software. It uses a   direct model for both sales and support
column31: eschewing the antiquated   dealer model. It goes without saying that Tesla utilizes an   entirely different propulsion technology to power its vehicles.   These are but a few differences
column32: but they easily outnumber the   similarities.This says nothing as to whether or not these differences will   ultimately prove advantageous or not. Only time will answer those   questions. The point is that Tesla is an amalgam of auto
column33: tech
column34: and energy companies
column35: and there is a dearth of comparable peers.   The closest company that comes to mind is China'sBYD
column36: which stands for ""Build Your Dreams."" Warren Buffett famously   invested in BYD years ago. BYD is the only other notable company   that produces electric cars
column37: battery storage
column38: and solar   panels.But even then
column39: the comparison falls short. Beyond EVs
column40: BYD   also offers products like buses
column41: forklifts
column42: and commercial   trucks
column43: all of which are electric. Even in the passenger car   market
column44: BYD targets the more affordable midrange segment instead   of luxury vehicles. Additionally
column45: BYD operates in an entirely   different geopolitical environment halfway across the world.BYD is also much larger in terms of revenue ($14.5 billion in   2016) but also profitable ($733 million in 2016). For reference
column46: BYD trades at about 1.2 times sales
column47: significantly lower than   Tesla's 6.9 P/S multiple.To be clear
column48: I'm the first to admit that it's incredibly   difficult to justify new positions in Tesla at current levels
column49: because so much of the value is baked into the future. The   valuation magnifies the execution risks that Tesla faces in the   years ahead
column50: and there will be many. I just happen to be   fortunate enough to have such a low cost basis
column51: and I fell victim   to the ""house money effect"" long ago
column52: so I'm content to let it   ride
column53: despite the risks.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column54: it can pay to listen. After all
column55: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column56: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column57: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of April 3

column60: F
column61: and Tesla. The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on AAPL and     short January 2018 $95 calls on AAPL. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column5: 000 vehicles
column6: up 69% year over year
column7: indicating its likelihood of achieving the target of 50
column8: 000 vehicles in the first half of 2017.Meanwhile
column9: Ford reported U.S. sales of 236
column10: 250 units in March
column11: a 7.2% year over year decline. The company's U.S. sales
column12: as of Apr 3
column13: also declined 4.4% year over year.The BackgroundFord was established almost 114 years ago and has been making mass market vehicles for a large part of its history. The company sells millions of cars each year

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Promises New Mac Pro in 2018
column2: New Pro iMac in 2017;4/4/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has been taking heat from customers for ignoring its core
column4: professional Mac users. The Mac Pro was last updated in 2013
column5: and even then
column6: its design alienated some. Apple held a rare turntable event with tech journalists to talk about the Mac. The company promises it has heard the complaints and it's pledging an all new Mac Pro in 2018.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleTo tide those power users over in the meantime
column7: the company has goosed the specs of the existing model
column8: is cutting some prices and it will introduce a new iMac aimed at pro users later this year.Senior Apple Execs Talk Mac PlansApple brought a handful of tech journalists to its headquarters for a very rare
column9: roundtable meeting with three of its senior executives: Phil Schiller (Senior VP Worldwide Marketing)
column10: Craig Federighi (Senior VP Software Engineering) and John Ternus (VP Hardware Engineering).The reason? To talk about AAPL's desktop Mac roadmap.The companyupdated its MacBook Pro laptops late last year
column11: but desktop Macs have languished with outdated specs sometimes for years. The Mac Pro was last updated in 2013
column12: the iMac in 2015 and the Mac Mini in 2014. In the meantime
column13: Windows PCs have received multiple upgrades and are equipped with processors and graphics cards that leave AAPL's offering in the dust - despite the Mac premium price tag.The 10 Best Stocks of the S&P 500 in Q1AndMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) has emerged as a threat for the creative professional users who traditionally bought Macs
column14: with its newSurface Studio all-in-one PC.The situation was bad enough that AAPL staged this event to assure everyone that it hasn't abandoned the Mac or its professional users. It follows oncomments from CEO Tim Cookthat suggested APPL might be quietly working on a new Mac Pro.Apple Admits It Missed the Mark with Old Mac ProProfessionals who need a workstation-class desktop PC need a computer that can be upgraded. The Mac Pro AAPL introduced in 2013 looked cool
column15: but its compact cylinder form factor limited upgrade options.Quoted byMashable'sLance Ulanoff (who was at the routable)
column16: Apple's Federighihad this to say about the current Mac Pro:""The Mac Pro
column17: the current vintage that we introduced
column18: we wanted to do something bold and different. In retrospect
column19: it didn't well suit some of the people we wanted to reach  We designed ourselves into a bit of a thermal corner.""Phil Schiller then went on to say that AAPL engineers are designing an all new Mac Pro that supports upgradability and expansion. The Apple team admitted that this move came later than they would like
column20: but promised that a new Mac Pro in 2018 will win back its professional users. It is also going to release a new Pro display
column21: one made by Apple
column22: not theLGmonitor it has been steering customers towardsince discontinuing its Thunderbolt Display last year.In the Meantime
column23: Spec Bumps and a New iMac for Pro UsersA year is a long time to wait for a new computer - especially if you have already been waiting two or three years. But Apple has several solutions in the meantime. After noting that many professional users had been moving to high end iMacs
column24: the company is committing to releasing a new iMac in 2017 that's aimed at pro users.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Hits New Highs
column25: Threatens Massive BreakoutIt won't have touch capability - AAPL isn't trying to replicate that Surface Studio - but expect high end component options for this Pro iMac like more powerful CPUs and graphics cards. And for everyone else
column26: Apple is at leastgiving the existing Mac Pro lineup spec bumps and price cuts.Will the new Mac Pro arrive in time to save Apple's professional desktop PC market? While there have been some Windows switchers
column27: Mac users tend to be stubbornly dedicated to the platform. The effort by Apple to be transparent about its plans
column28: acknowledgment that it has allowed its desktop lineup to fall behind and a promise of a new Mac Pro in 2018 will hold many over.For those who can't wait
column29: price cuts and spec bumps take at least some of the sting out of buying a current Mac Pro. And the prospect of a new iMac aimed at the professional market is intriguing.The Mac business may not count for much in an Apple that is focused on iPhone revenue
column30: but the company is sending the message that it has no intention of abandoning the market.As of this writing

column1: Why General Motors Company (GM) Stock Is the Best of Its Breed;4/4/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTo say Monday's release of auto sales figures for March was a letdown would be a considerable understatement. They were downright alarming
column3: resulting in sizeable losses from stocks of industry stalwarts likeFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) andGeneral Motors Company(NYSE:GM)
column4: as well as setbacks for shares of foreign favorites likeHonda Motor Co Ltd (ADR)(NYSE:HMC) andToyota Motor Corp (ADR)(NYSE:TM).makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAnd why not? Auto sales have been suspiciously tepid of late
column5: and although the ""peak auto"" chatter has faded
column6: it has never really gone away.Of the six key names that make up the vast majority of the United States automobile landscape though
column7: one name continues to stand out as better than the rest. Keep GM stock on your watchlist
column8: even if you have to take all the others off your radar of potential investments.GM: Tough Month for Auto SalesLong story made short
column9: with the mostly meaningless exception ofNissan Motor Co Ltd (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NSANY)
column10: all the major car brands in the U.S.fell short of March's sales expectations.And it's not as if the bar was set very high for most of these names. The pros were calling for Ford's sales to plunge 5.9%
column11: and the company couldn't even do that - Ford sold 7.2% fewer automobiles than it did in March of 2016. Honda was expected to improve sales by nearly 5%
column12: but instead posted a 0.7% decline. All told
column13: five of the biggest eight names in the U.S. car business reported lower year-over-year sales.7 'Best of the Best' Stocks to Buy for the Second QuarterThe end result: The annualized pace of U.S. auto sales has fallen to 16.7 million
column14: versus an expected advance to a 17.2 million unit clip.The bullish case for the country's automakers - and the nation's preferred imports - is getting tougher and tougher to argue.With the dust settling from yesterday's lackluster March figures
column15: though
column16: General Motors has emerged as something of an exception to the norm. Indeed
column17: the old-school Detroit icon may well be strong enough to keep GM stock buy-worthy even as the industry itself hits a wall.General Motors Is Doing Something RightDon't read too much into the premise. Any of the problems other automakers are facing are sure to impact General Motors to some degree as well. The question is
column18: can GM stock shrug those issues off
column19: even if other names in the business can't? The answer seems to be a qualified but well-founded ""yes."" A handful of details from Monday's data dump should keep General Motos stock relatively propped up.Above all else
column20: while GM stock may have missed growth expectations by a country mile
column21: those expectations were unfairly high. Analysts were expecting a 7% increase in unit sales for the month. General Motors still mustered a 1.6% improvement in an environment that was quite tough for cars and trucks.The compelling footnote in GM's relative victory on Monday was that it didn't come from truck sales.A closer inspection of the recent red-hot automobile market reveals thatpickup trucks rather than passenger sedanshave been doing most of the driving since 2015.While trucks (and SUVs) are more profitable for automobile companies
column22: investors as well as the companies themselves were concerned about an over-reliance on light truck sales
column23: and perhaps an inability to sell passenger vehicles. GM's still got that magic touch with some sedan and crossover lines though.Sales of Chevy's Equinix
column24: Cruze and Camaro were all up
column25: as were sales of Buick's Regal
column26: LaCrosse and Encore.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Hits New Highs
column27: Threatens Massive BreakoutGeneral Motors also partially soothed another worry some GM stock holders may have been entertaining  it doesn't have to give buyers everything but the kitchen sink to get them to make a purchase. After being uncomfortably generous with car buyers in February
column28: offering incentives/discounts of 14.9% of a vehicles' purchase price
column29: General Motorsreeled that number in to only 13.5% last month. Yet
column30: the carmaker sold 256
column31: 224 in the United States last month
column32: up fromFebruary's tally of 237
column33: 388.Bottom Line for GM StockAgain
column34: being the top dog of the names at the bottom of the barrel doesn't inherently mean much
column35: as you're still at the bottom of the barrel. General Motors is clearly doing something right that its peers and competitors aren't though.To the extent the fear that upended GM stock and all the other automaker stocks yesterday wasn't fully deserved
column36: GM shares should be the first to recover
column37: and the best. In fact
column38: yesterday's selloff has already started to be undone today.Clearly it's not bulletproof
column39: but GM should at least be noted as the best of breed
column40: for when the time is right.As of this writing
column41: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best Stocks of the S&P 500 in Q1The 7 Best Stocks to Buy for an Income-Rich Retirement3 Entertainment Stocks to Buy as Summer ApproachesThe postWhy General Motors Company (GM) Stock Is the Best of Its Breedappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column8: who was also the chief engineer of theTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) Model S before leaving that company half a decade   ago. Lucid even took me for a spin in an alpha prototype.Lucid Motors is decidedly a California brand. Image source:     Lucid Motors.makeAd('4'
column10: 'mktsnews'
column11: 'vanguard'
column13: '');Here's what Rawlinson told me in an hour-long interview that   covered a wide range of topics. (Some quotes have been edited   lightly for clarity.)On patentsRawlinson was crucial in the development of the Model S and is   named as an inventor on many of Tesla's patents for its sedan.   Meanwhile
column14: Tesla famously open-sourced its patents in 2014
column15: vowing not to initiate any patent lawsuits against other   companies using its technology ""in good faith."" Given Rawlinson's   familiarity with the intellectual property and the apparent   ability to use it
column16: I wondered if Lucid was using any of Tesla's   patents.Lucid CTO Peter Rawlinson. Image source: Lucid Motors.Nope. Rawlinson says Lucid is using exactly zero of Tesla's   patents for a couple of reasons. First
column17: Lucid is looking to   develop even better EV technology on its own
column18: in which case it   simply doesn't need Tesla's IP. Second
column19: it's not clear what   constitutes ""good faith"" from Tesla's perspective
column20: and it would   be unwise and risky to build a product based on Tesla IP if there   is considerable uncertainty surrounding the usage and   implementation.Cells and chargingLucid has partnered withSamsung SDIto co-develop the battery cells that will ultimately make their   way into Lucid battery packs. All battery cells degrade over   time due to a variety of factors like depth of discharge or   environmental conditions
column21: to name a few
column22: so the universal goal is   to minimize potential degradation. Rawlinson says these new cells   are designed to withstand and minimize degradation: ""The   cell chemistry that we've co-developed with Samsung is   groundbreaking in that it is very tolerant to repeated
column23: cyclic   fast-charging.""Samsung SDI will be the primary production partner
column24: but Lucid   is also working with a couple other prominent suppliers. Lucid   will assemble the battery packs in-house
column25: which will feature an   advanced cooling system and industry-leading energy density.So much for fighting over who rides shotgun. Image source:     Lucid Motors.There are currently three prominent DC fast-charging standards   throughout the world (China is working on a fourth)
column26: including   Tesla's proprietary Superchargers that were born out of necessity   given how immature charging standards and networks were back   then. ""Tesla took a leading role
column27: it was the vanguard really
column28: in   creating a fast-charging network
column29: and is to be applauded for   that
column30: Rawlinson adds.Lucid hasn't picked a horse in this race quite yet. That's   because the company is still at least two years away from   production
column31: and the charging landscape will inevitably shift by   then. It looks like CCS is going to win out (CHAdeMO has been in   decline for years)
column32: and Rawlinson thinks that's the route Lucid   will take
column33: but it has plenty of time to figure out which   standard(s) to support (with adaptors if need be). ""I think that   we will see a maturity and proliferation of [the CCS] charging   network by then
column34: says Rawlinson.We can all agree that the last thing the EV industry needs is   yet another charging standard for consumers to navigate.Direct sales and serviceRawlinson also gives Tesla credit for pushing forward with   direct sales and service. As such
column35: Lucid also plans on operating   its own network of retail stores and service centers
column36: according   to Rawlinson:We plan to create a network of stores and a service network.     Now
column37: that will have to grow organically as sales grow. Before     launch
column38: we're planning our first store
column39: probably in the Bay     Area. And we'll grow that network in a synchronous manner with     sales. And yes
column40: that will be challenging to start with
column41: of     course.Given how antiquated the traditional dealer model is
column42: having   more companies advocating for direct sales -- an unfortunately   litigious endeavor -- is good news for consumers.About that $700 million factoryThere have been plenty of headlines that Lucid is planning to   build a $700 million factory in Arizona
column43: which raises an   inevitable question: Where is all that money going to come   from?Lucid Air has four displays that serve different purposes.     Image source: Lucid Motors.It's worth clarifying that Lucid isnotplanning on spending $700 million upfront
column44: which would be   reckless. Instead
column45: the manufacturing facility will have three   phases
column46: the first of which is expected to cost $240 million. That   should allow the company to ramp up to producing about 8
column48: 000 vehicles per year
column49: with production commencing in 2019.   Only after all three stages are completed (expected around 2022   if all goes well) will the total investment reach $700 million.   At that point
column50: the factory should have annual production capacity   of 130
column51: 000 vehicles.Lucid is currently working to secure its Series D financing   round; once the funding is secured
column52: then Lucid will break ground   in the Grand Canyon state.How Lucid will approach autonomyIn terms of autonomous driving
column53: Lucid plans on using an   ""overlay of LIDAR
column54: radar
column55: and camera"" for the hardware sensor   suite. The company recently announced that it is partnering withMobileye
column56: whichIntelis looking to acquire in a blockbuster$15.3 billion dealannounced last month.Lucid will use both long- and short-range versions of all   sensors: wide-angle cameras
column57: telephoto cameras
column58: and long/short   range radar and LIDAR sensors for maximum redundancy. Instead of   using roof-mounted LIDAR systems
column59: Lucid plans on using peripheral   LIDAR sensors embedded into the sides of the vehicle; software   will stitch the data together. This has functional benefits as   well as aesthetic ones (no one will be calling the Lucid Air anugly potatoanytime soon). Rawlinson said:The three technical aspects of making autonomous driving     work
column60: in my view
column61: are: the platform in terms of hardware --     that's the car
column62: all the sensors
column63: the whole integration of that     suite. Are we going to do that? Yes. Software
column64: are we going to     do that? No
column65: we're going to partner. And the third thing is big     data. Are we going to do that? Yes. Because we will be able to     collect and accrue big data.Rawlinson reiterated that Lucid is quite cognizant of how   difficult it is to bring a car to market
column66: and it doesn't make   sense to invest in autonomous driving software at this stage. The   company needs to remain ""laser-focused"" on the car itself in   terms of hardware and getting to production
column67: which is mostly what   its roughly 300 engineers work on.Lucid isn't trying to ""kill"" TeslaThere's a tendency to frame Lucid as a ""Tesla killer
column68: but   such comparisons miss the point. Rawlinson clarifies
column69: ""This car   isn't a Model S competitor; it's the next step forward. I   certainly don't see it as a 'Tesla killer.'"" Of course
column70: Lucid   will compete with Tesla on some level
column71: but the main rivals will   be the German automakers that dominate the $100 billion luxury   segment of the market.""What we've tried to do is create the next generation of car
column72: Rawlinson said.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column74: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Best Stocks for 2017: Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock Is Still a Tech Leader;4/4/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEditor's note: This column is part of ourBest Stocks for 2017contest. Louis Navellier's pick for the contest isNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA).makeArticleAd();We're officially through the first quarter
column3: and shares ofNVIDIA Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) - my top stock for 2017 - finished the quarter with a modest 2% gain. That performance seems like nothing to write home about
column4: especially when compared with theS&P 500'snearly 6% gain. However
column5: when it comes to the computer graphics company
column6: I predict that a little patience will pay off big time. In fact
column7: now is an excellent time to pick up NVDA stock before it explodes higher.I'll explain exactly why in a moment
column8: but first
column9: let's review what weighed on the stock earlier in the quarter. Back in early February
column10: Nvidia released perfectly respectable fourth-quarter results
column11: including 55% sales growth
column12: 193% EPS growth and a healthy 19.3% earnings surprise.Nonetheless
column13: some shareholders took the earnings report as an excuse to lock in their gains - a shortsighted move
column14: in my opinion.NVDA shares meandered lower through early March. Then
column15: a series of exciting announcements and analyst upgrades renewed interest in the stock Catalysts for NVDA StockIn mid-March
column16: Nvidia revealed that it designed the custom applications processor for theNintendo's(OTCMKTS:NTDOY) Switch videogame console. Since its March 3 debut
column17: the Nintendo Switch has been selling so well that Nintendo has decided to double its planned production for the current fiscal year. This is expected to boost Nvidia's own sales and earnings.The 5 Best Stocks to Buy for AprilThat same week
column18: NVDA also announced that it's teaming up withPACCAR
column19: a leading global truck manufacturer
column20: to develop self-driving trucks. The two companies have already built a proof-of-concept self-driving truck that is powered by Nvidia's Drive PX 2 technology. There are currently 300 million trucks on the road around the world
column21: representing a massive untapped market.NVDA stock is clearly doubling down on self-driving cars; it already has partnerships with many leading automakers
column22: includingAudi
column23: Tesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA)
column24: Mercedes-Benz
column25: Volvo
column26: Honda Motor Co Ltd (ADR)(NYSE:HMC) andBMW. As self-driving cars become more widely adopted
column27: Nvidia's artificial intelligence car computing platform will be in hot demand.Then in late March
column28: TenCent(OTCMKTS:TCEHY)
column29: one of China's largest internet service providers
column30: announced that it will be using Nvidia's Tesla GPU accelerators with its cloud computing platform. In laymen's terms
column31: TenCent will be relying on NVDA's industry-leading hardware to supercharge its cloud services.As a pioneer of artificial computing technology
column32: Nvidia's products are already used by plenty of cloud service providers
column33: enterprises and research organizations. However
column34: having TenCent's buy-in is a big deal. With nearly $22 billion in annual revenue
column35: the company operates the world's largest gaming platform.These developments build upon Nvidia's already strong sales and earnings prospects. This quarter
column36: NVDA stock is expected to post 103% earnings growth and 46.3% sales growth.The Best Way to Play Tesla Inc (TSLA) at All-Time HighsThen again
column37: most analysts have been aggressively revising their estimates higher
column38: so it seems like the sky is the limit. And I'm not the only one who thinks so. At the time of writing this
column39: NVDA stock rebounded nearly 12% from its recent lows before taking a hit on Tuesday after a Pacific Crest downgrade.From self-driving cars to virtual reality to artificial intelligence
column40: Nvidia is at the forefront of several fast-growing technologies. In my opinion
column41: the stock's first-quarter performance isn't indicative of its true potential. I still consider NVDA one of my top technology plays for 2017.Louis Navellieris a renowned growth investor. He is the editor of five investing newsletters:Blue Chip Growth
column42: Emerging Growth
column43: Ultimate Growth
column44: Family TrustandPlatinum Growth. His most popular service
column45: Blue Chip Growth
column46: has a track record of beating the market 3:1 over the last 14 years. He uses a combination of quantitative and fundamental analysis to identify market-beating stocks. Mr. Navellier has made his proven formula accessible to investors via his free
column47: online stock rating tool
column48: PortfolioGrader.com. Louis Navellier may hold some of the aforementioned securities in one or more of his newsletters.More From InvestorPlaceThe 7 Best Stocks to Buy for an Income-Rich RetirementAmazon.com

column1: Why Lowes Companies
column2: Inc. (LOW) Stock Will Keep Running Higher;4/4/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere are a lot of reasons to likeLowe's Companies
column4: Inc.(NYSE:LOW) stock at the moment. And that hasn't always been the case. LOW stock traditionally has underperformed that of its key rival
column5: Home Depot Inc(NYSE:HD). Even excluding HD's higher dividend yield
column6: investors in HD stock have received about 30 percentage points more return over the last five years than their counterparts in Lowe's stock.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (modified)But LOW stock may be positioned to outperform HD stock - and the market overall - going forward.Lowe's stock has a number of catalysts in its favor at the moment. With a bit of cooperation from the housing markets
column7: LOW stock should be one of the better-performing large-caps over the next few years.Strong Quarter and Year for LOW StockLowe's stock jumped 9.5% after the company's first-quarter report in early March
column8: and with good reason. Results were strong across the board. Adjusted earnings-per-share of $0.86 crushed consensus expectations of $0.79
column9: and increased a sharp 46% year-over-year. Even considering some likely help from better weather in key markets
column10: that's a huge earnings increase for an established company. Full-year adjusted EPS rose 21%
column11: with same-store sales up 4.2%
column12: including a 5.1% jump in Q4.Admittedly
column13: Lowe's same-store sales in Q4 were a bit below those of HD
column14: but the gap is smaller than it has been of late. Meanwhile
column15: guidance for 3.5% comps looks possibly conservative
column16: and Lowe's expects to turn those revenues into a 16% increase in earnings per share - even with FY16 (ending January 2017) having an extra week
column17: and thus a tougher comparison. And it certainly appears that Lowe's stock has room to grow considerably beyond just next year.The 10 Best Stocks of the S&P 500 in Q1Can Lowe's Stock Outperform HD Stock?Looking forward
column18: there are a number of multi-year catalysts behind LOW stock. The gap between Home Depot and Lowe's in terms of revenue seems to be narrowing. Home Depot outperformed LOW stock by 200 bps for the full year
column19: but just 70 bps in Q4. The nature of incremental margins are such that if Lowe's can grab a few more dollars from its rival
column20: its earnings should expand nicely.Meanwhile
column21: the housing cycle seems to imply a tailwind for both LOW stock and HD. Housing starts numbers have been solid so far in 2017
column22: and renovation activity appears to be picking up as well. Both bode well for sales to not only do-it-yourself individual customers
column23: but the large-volume commercial clients that drive a good chunk of Lowe's revenue.And there's one more
column24: somewhat hidden
column25: catalyst: The continuing decline ofSears Holdings Corp(NASDAQ:SHLD). Sears competes with Lowe's in both hardware and appliances. And the revenue being shed by thatstruggling company- both through store closures and declining same-store sales - has to go somewhere. Sears (not including Kmart) saw revenue decline by $1.5 billion in its most recent fiscal year. Some of those lost sales will make their way to Lowe's.In fact
column26: one analyst has estimateda 50-plus basis point tailwindto comparable sales for both Lowe's and Home Depoteach yearfrom Sears' struggles. And with the decline at that retailer not likely to end any time soon
column27: if ever
column28: that benefit should persist for some time.Bottom Line on LOWAnd yet
column29: Lowe's stock is priced very reasonably. LOW trades at about 15x its FY17 guidance of $4.64. In comparison
column30: HD trades at over 18x its guidance and a two-turn premium on an EV/EBITDA basis
column31: as well.If Lowe's can narrow the growth gap - as it has done of late - the valuation gap between LOW stock and HD should narrow in turn. A 19x multiple plus the 1.7% dividend paid by Lowe's stock implies about a 9% return over the next year. Any outperformance
column32: or strength in the industry as a whole
column33: puts total return into the double-digits on a percentage basis.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Hits New Highs
column34: Threatens Massive BreakoutAnd I'd expect some outperformance this year - and perhaps a rising tide for both HD and LOW in terms of earnings and multiples. Consumer confidence is up. Home builders are optimistic. Few
column35: if any
column36: retailers have the same protection from e-commerce andAmazon.com
column37: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN).Lowe's stock is near an all-time high
column38: but hitting $100 by 2018 hardly seems an outrageous expectation. A 19-20x multiple - up modestly due to rising optimism - and $5+ in 2018 EPS gets the stock into the triple digits.That's a 20%+ return in as little as a year
column39: and that's worth paying attention to. And so is LOW stock.As of this writing
column40: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Stocks You'd Be Foolish to Buy Right Now7 'Best of the Best' Stocks to Buy for the Second Quarter3 Entertainment Stocks to Buy as Summer ApproachesThe postWhy Lowe's Companies
