column1: Tesla (TSLA) Stock Jumps After Tencent Buys 5% Stake;3/28/2017;"Chinese tech giant Tencent Holdings Ltd.TCEHYhas purchased a 5% stake in Tesla Inc.TSLAaccording to a recently released U.S. regulatory filing. The purchase makes Tencent one of Tesla's biggest investors at a time when Tesla desperately needs to raise money.Tencent
column2: one of China's most valuable companies
column3: paid roughly $1.8 billion for its 5% stake in Tesla. Tencent purchased 8.17 million shares through a recentTesla stockoffering and the open market. Tencent's 5% stake makes it Tesla'sfifth-largest shareholder
column4: according to Bloomberg. The Chinese company took a passive stake in Tesla
column5: which means it is unlikely to try to pressure the electric car maker to make any changes.In the wake of the news
column6: Tesla's stock rose 3.42% to $279.39 per share in early afternoon trading Tuesday. Tesla is a Zacks Rank #3 (HOLD).Tencent is hardly well-known outside China
column7: but it is theworld's largest video game publisher by revenue. The company now owns both ""League of Legends"" and ""Clash of Clans
column8: two massively popular video games. Tencent also owns two major Chinese social-media platforms WeChat and Weixin
column9: which boast 890 million monthly active users combined.In early January 2011
column10: Tencent's stock price was $4.51 per share. Today
column11: Tencent's stock is up 1.75% to $29.49 per share and is a Zacks Rank #3 (HOLD). With a market cap of $276.6 billion
column12: the Internet giant is now worth more than Chinese e-commerce powerhouse Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.BABA
column13: which has a market cap of $269.7 billion.The major Tencent investment comes as Tesla continues topush towards the launchof its first mass-market car
column14: the Model 3
column15: in late 2017. Tesla plans to begin manufacturing its new less-expensive electric car by summer 2017 in order to start fulfilling the 373
column16: 000 pre-orders of the $35
column17: 000 Model 3 sedan.Tesla needs to raise a massive amount of money in order to produce the new electric sedans. Tencent's major investment is a start.The electric car company has over $2 billion worth of debt due in 2018. Still
column18: Tesla's stock price has climbed 26% in 2017
column19: and the company has reached a market cap of $45.5 billion. Tesla is nowthe second most valuable U.S. autocompany behind only General MotorsGM.Tesla has grown its presence in China
column20: where it now has 24 stores and 348 regular charging stations. China imported 11
column21: 839 Tesla vehicles in 2016
column22: five times morethan the previous year.Is Musk Overselling The Massive Model 3 Roll   Out?Tesla's chairman and largest shareholder Elon Musk's plan to transform his company from a luxury electric car company into a sustainable energy powerhouse is in full swing. But the introduction of its new solar power and sustainable battery businesses
column23: as well as a new mass-market electric car has done little to help improve Tesla's debt-laden and unprofitable bottom line.Musk hopes to produce 500
column24: 000 electric vehicles a year by the end of 2018 and 1 million by 2020. In order to do so
column25: Tesla said earlier this month it would try to raise a total of nearly $1.4 billion through a stock and debt offering.On a call with investors last month
column26: Musk said the company is ready to place orders with suppliers for ""1
column27: 000 cars a week in July
column29: 000 a week in August
column30: and 4
column31: 000 a week in September."" Tesla hopes to push that number to 5
column32: 000 cars a week by the end of 2017 and to 10
column33: 000 a week by the end of 2018.But the massive roll out of that many electric cars ""would be absolutely unprecedented based on what we know about car markets today and how people spend their dollars
column34: Bloomberg electric car analyst Salim Morsy said. ""It could happen. I'm pretty sure it won't.""Other Tesla EndeavorsTesla announced it isready to enter the Middle East market
column35: opening a pop-up store and a service center by July to sell its luxury electric cars in the United Arab Emirates. Tesla has similar plans for Abu Dhabi by 2018.South Africa
column36: Musk's home country
column37: has been in talks with the Silicon Valley-based company to open a manufacturing plant there. Musk also recently announced his intentions tobring Tesla to India. Tesla's $2.1 billion acquisition of solar power giant SolarCity signaled its massive move into the sustainable energy sector.Musk's Space Exploration Technologies Corp (SpaceX) plans to make history this week when it hopes to launch a rocket into space usingengine boosters that have already been used. SpaceX's Thursday launch at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida is set to prove that the use of previously fired engines makes frequent and cheaper space travel possible. Musk and SpaceX want to begin tocolonize Mars by 2024.The South African entrepreneur just launched a new company called Neuralink Corp as he tries tofuse computers with human brainsin order to help mankind compete during the upcoming age of artificial intelligence and robotics.More Stock News: This Is Bigger than the iPhone!makeArticleAd();It could become the mother of all technological revolutions. column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) andTencent Holdings Ltd(OTCMKTS:TCEHY) might be strange bedfellows. The former makes electric cars and solar roofs. The latter is the primary name behind online messaging appWeChat(though it sells and supports a variety of apps).makeArticleAd();Nevertheless

column5: making the Chinese technology outfit the fifth largest Tesla stock holder. That resulted in a 3% bump to TSLA stock by Tuesday afternoon.Faithful fans of Tesla and equally faithful owners of the stock are clearly stoked
column6: holding the sizable purchase up as a trophy of sorts. They might want to be a little careful about reading too much into the news  particularly as a hint that the young carmaker is on the cusp of being acquired.On the other hand

column11: distributes digital music
column12: maintains a microblogging platform
column13: and iswading deep into artificial intelligence waters
column14: among other things.9 Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9 a ShareTacking on a piece of Tesla doesn't make Tencent noticeably more jumbled than it already is.Nevertheless
column15: if nothing else
column16: the big chunk of TSLA stock that Tencent recently acquired is something of a moral victory for a company that has struggled to keep investors interested. The current price of $270 is roughly where Tesla shares were trading in the third quarter of 2014.Indeed
column17: the stock has yet to retest its September-2014 peak of $291
column18: even though it is arguably more investment-worthy now than it has ever been at any point in its history.The mid-priced electric car
column19: the Model 3

column21: and interest in its new solar shingles is reportedly significant - CEO Elon Musk thinks they'lleventually capture 5% of the nation's roofing market.Dilution Doesn't MatterThat said

column24: Tesla has garnered $6.5 billion in funds that was either dilutive
column25: or added liabilities to the balance sheet.Tesla raised another $1.15 billion this month
column26: mostly via new debt
column27: though it did sell another $250 million worth of common stock. Those funds were necessary to ramp up capacity for the large-scale production of the Model 3.But Tencent CEO Ma ""Pony Ma"" Huateng isn't deterred by the dilution
column28: debt obligations and Musk's penchant for overestimating deliveries
column29: commenting:""Elon Musk is the archetype for entrepreneurship
column30: combining vision
column31: ambition
column32: and execution. Tesla is a global pioneer at the forefront of new technologies including electric vehicles
column33: assisted driving
column34: shared vehicles
column35: digitizing real-world information
column36: sustainable energy generation and scalable energy storage.""Given Tencent's history under Huateng
column37: he knows what he's talking about when it comes to turning an idea into a revenue-bearing profit center. If he says electric cars
column38: energy storage and electric cars are worth pursuing and that Musk is doing it well
column39: then Musk is arguably barking up the right tree the right way.Bottom Line for TSLA StockA reason to take on a position in Tesla stock if you don't have one already? That kind of thinking might be a bit over the top; Huateng doesn't have access to any more information than anyone else does.Short the Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Super Story

column43: or understands just how much of an impactChina's support for electric vehiclescould have on Tesla's bottom line.In that light

column1: Buy GoPro Inc (GPRO) While the Chips Are Down;3/28/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNowadays
column3: GoPro Inc(NASDAQ:GPRO) doesn't seem able to catch a proper break. Good tidings for the beleaguered camera manufacturer have been few and far between ever since GPRO botched up the launch of Hero4.makeArticleAd();Source:ETC-USC via Flickr (Modified)That's why investors have been celebrating afterGPRO reaffirmed first-quarter revenue
column4: a move that helped GoPro stock break its freefall - at least for the time being. GPRO racked up 15% gains after it reaffirmed that first-quarter revenue will come in at the high-end of its $190 million-$210 million guidance.GoPro also said that it expects to boost the bottom line through program cost reduction and headcount cuts.Boosting the Bottom LineGPRO stock is beginning to show signs of cooling off
column5: and the rally could be on its last legs. Investors can be forgiven for feeling jittery about a stock that has gone through a series of false starts that are more often than not followed by a protracted selloff.After all
column6: it's not like GoPro just announced an exciting new product or anything like that. GPRO simply said that it plans to go ahead with the termination of roughly 270 positions and take a $10 million restructuring-associated charge in the process. In other words
column7: GoPro will take a short-term hit on its bottom line
column8: but could realize significant cost savings in the long-run.The 10 Best ETFs to Buy for the Rest of 2017That will mark the third round of job cuts by GoPro since 2016 as the action camera maker desperately tries to claw its way back to profitability. An announcement in January saw the company lay off 7% of its workers. The other round
column9: which came in November 2016
column10: was particularly severe - the company completely shuttered its entertainment division
column11: losing 15% of its workforce in the process
column12: and even lost company president and formerSkypehead Tony Bates.But all that seemed to do little good - GoPro still finished the year with a massive $373 million operating loss.Another False Start By GPRO?The investing universe seems to have lost faith in the ability of GoPro's management to get its act together. And that's saying a lot for a company that has yet to celebrate its third anniversary as a public entity. How did we get here?First off
column13: GoPro was forced to cut the price of its iconic Hero4 camera in half just a few months after its launch. GPRO then promised to lose its tag as a one-trick pony by launching the Karma drone. But here again the company just couldn't get its game going. After delaying Karma for months
column14: the company issued an embarrassing recall of the drone shortly after launch.According to CEO Nick Woodman:""We're a little bit embarrassed that it was something as basic as a battery retention issue.""Investors could not help but feel that GoPro's management was constantly being blindsided by events
column15: and that's never a good thing. That's the reason whyKarma's recent relaunchdid nothing for GPRO stock.GoPro said during the second launch that shipments would be limited at first
column16: which defies logic for a product that has been so long in development. Karma returned to the shelves on Feb 1
column17: 2017 but eight days later GoPro stock had tanked 23%.But maybe this could finally be the right time to pick up the shares when the chips are still down. For all its woes
column18: GoPro is still selling cameras
column19: with many of its products regarded as the best in class. GoPro's new Hero5 and Hero5 Session have proven to be something of a hit - the company sold 2 million cameras during the fourth quarter
column20: the second-highest figure in any quarter. Those impressive sales helped GoPro snap out of a revenue tailspin that stretched back four quarters.The midpoint of GoPro's first-quarter guidance points to revenue growth of 9%. That's not exactly earth-shattering
column21: but it will lay a foundation for further improvements down the road.Yes
column22: Tencent's Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stake Is a BIG Buy SignalGoPro has promised the next iteration of its action cameras
column23: Hero6
column24: will hit the markets sometime this year. The company has also said that Karma will be available in international markets later this spring. This makes GPRO stock a good turnaround bet.Bottom Line on GoPro StockIt's hard to tell whether GPRO has finally found a floor after losing a third of its value over the past six months. The stock is trading slightly above its all-time low
column25: and may remain range-bound for some time until another solid catalyst emerges. But I'm willing to wager that this is not another false start by GoPro stock.As of this writing

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk to Found New AI Company Called Neuralink;3/28/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsElon Musk
column3: the CEO ofTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA)
column4: is founding a new AI company that sounds like it comes straight from a sci-fi novel.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrThe new company that the Tesla Inc CEO is founding is called ""Neuralink"". While Musk hasn't said much about the company yet
column5: he did mention that it will focus on developing ""neural lace"". Neural lace is the term for a system that would allow thebrain to directly connect to a computer.Elon Musk says that neural lace is the only way that humans can remain relevant after AI starts to take off. He believes that it can give humans more control over machines and keep them from becoming useless. Musk also works with the OpenAI project to develop what is called ""safe"" AI.The Tesla Inc CEO is teaming up with Max Hodak to co-found Neuralink. Hodak is a former research assistant at Duke University Medical Center. He has worked on systems that allow monkeys to control machines with their minds. Musk is also planning to reveal more about Neuralink in aWait Buy Whypiece in about a week
column6: reportsCNBC.Reports claim that Neuralink won't start off by jumping straight into its neural lace work. Instead
column7: it will likely focus onbetter understanding the brainand providing solutions to medical issues. This approach is similar to how the Tesla Inc CEO got his other companies started.The 7 Best Dividend Stocks to Buy for the Second QuarterSpeaking of Musk's other companies
column8: he may be stretching himself too thin by adding another one. He admits in a Tweet that it will be difficult to dedicate the time to Neuralink
column9: but says that it is too important not to. Musk also has to worry about Tesla Inc
column10: Space Xand his other side project
column11: The Boring Company
column12: TechCrunchnotes.TSLA stock was up 2% as of Tuesday morning.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best ETFs to Buy for the Rest of 2017The 7 WORST Stocks to Buy Right Now7 Consumer Stocks That Will Lead Your PortfolioThe postTesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk to Found New AI Company Called Neuralinkappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Facebook Inc (FB) Slams Snap Inc (SNAP) With Facebook Stories;3/28/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) is keeping up its unrelenting game of copycat againstSnap Inc(NYSE:SNAP) by unfurling a fourth feature derived from the popular Snapchat app.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockFacebook will introduce ""Facebook Stories
column3: which will allow you to share photos and videos that will vanish after 24 hours. In response
column4: SNAP stock sold off by roughly 5% in Tuesday's morning trade.Again
column5: this marks the fourth time Facebook has ripped something straight from the pages of Snapchat
column6: though it's the first time the ""stolen"" feature has gone smack-dab on the primary Facebook app.Here
column7: we'll take a closer look at Facebook Stories
column8: and the other ways FB has copied rival SNAP.Facebook StoriesFacebook
column9: in its release
column10: ironically mentions the Instagram community as inspiration for this feature
column11: saying it has ""shown us that it can be fun to share things that disappear after a day.""But those familiar with Snapchat know that this is a long-time feature on that social app
column12: and even Facebook project manager Conor Hayes admits as much.The 7 WORST Stocks to Buy Right Now""This is something that Snapchat has really pioneered
column13: Hayes toldBloomberg. ""Stories has become a format for people to share and consume immersive video and photo across all social apps
column14: and it really differs for them based on the network they have or the way that they use a certain app.""Reports that FB was working on such a featurecame out back in January.Facebook Stories will also include a ""Direct"" feature
column15: which will let friends view videos or photos once - they can then either replay it or write a reply. ""Once the conversation on the photo or video ends
column16: the content is no longer visible in Direct
column17: Facebook says.The launch comes amid Facebook's announcement that it's rolling out a new camera replete with additional effects including masks
column18: frames and filters
column19: ""letting you turn your everyday selfie into a Picasso-style work of art.""Instagram StoriesThis isn't even the first time Facebook has copied the vanishing-photo feature
column20: of course. In 2016
column21: Facebook unleashed ""Stories"" on its Instagram app
column22: which quickly reached 150 million daily users.The move was heralded as Facebook's ""next step
column23: accenting the importance of video to Facebook's collection of apps. The feature works much the same way:""Stories let you share a series of videos or photos - and have them disappear after 24 hours. You'll see stories from the people you follow at the top of your feed
column24: and a ring around their profile picture tells you when their story has been updated.""Months after the launch
column25: several reports showed thatInstagram Stories appeared to be stealing Snapchat's users
column26: with decline counts ranging anywhere from 15% to 40%.WhatsApp StatusEarlier this year
column27: Facebook-owned WhatsApp launched a feature that might sound familiar:WhatsApp Status
column28: which allows users to share images
column29: GIFs and videos with their contacts for 24 hours before they disappear.The impetus behind the change was to spark a large number of users to interact with the app more
column30: as manysimply use default statuses and walk away.Facebook Messenger DayJust earlier this month
column31: Facebook launched ""Messenger Day
column32: which is pretty similar to Stories in that it allows people to post photos and videos on its Messenger app before they erase themselves  after a day. The photos can be adorned with drawings and other filters
column33: and can be shared with anyone on your Messenger list.Instagram GeostickersInstagram also was updated this year to include ""Geostickers
column34: which allow you to add various images and illustrations to Stories posts that are connected to wherever you are at the moment.Advanced Micro Devices
column35: Inc. (AMD) Stock Gears Up for WarThis is a mimic of theSnapchat ""Geofilters"" featurethat allows people to send city-specific ""stickers"" on top of images in their messages and snaps. That feature originally rolled out in big cities including New York City
column36: Los Angeles
column37: Sydney and Paris
column38: whereas Instagram's Geostickers started with a launch in just NYC and Jakarta.Facebook PokeBack in 2012
column39: Facebook launched a mobile app called ""Poke"" that also was meant to imitate Snapchat
column40: allowing users to send images and videos that would disappear within seconds.While the apps were very similar in nature
column41: and while Poke even had a few important differences including location service and longer messages
column42: Poke ended up being a massive flop.At the time
column43: Facebook was criticized for its blatant theft
column44: but still managed to get a quick amount of buzz on its launch. However
column45: it quickly dropped in popularity and fell down the rankings of the iTunes store.Clearly
column46: though
column47: that never served as a warning not to copy Snapchat again  and as the continuing success of Facebook's Snapchat clones indicates
column48: that might be for the best.As of this writing

column1: Tesla Taking Solar Roof Orders in April: What We Know and What We Don't;3/27/2017;"WhenTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) solar roof was announced in November
column2: Elon Musk   took the solar industry by surprise. The roof is elegant and   almost hidden on a home
column3: a design goal that's been elusive to   solar manufacturers. Tesla's shingle design is a concept that at   least a half dozen companies have tried before -- and failed at   -- and Musk said he could make it for the same price as a   ""regular roof.""After a short presentation showing off the product
column4: Musk   walked off stage
column5: and we haven't heard much in the way of details   about what the solar roof will be. Now
column6: Musk says orders will   start in April. Here's what we know
column7: what we don't know
column8: and what   investors should look for when details are announced.Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();Here's what we knowWe know that the solar roof is a glass shingle with a solar   cell in it. And the few glimpses we've seen indicate that the   solar roof is a great-looking product. We also know that Musk   says orders will start in April.And that concludes what we know about the product. Seriously   -- that's it.What we don't knowWhat we don't know about the solar roof is far more   consequential for Tesla's new product.Musk says the solar roof will be priced similarly to a     regular roof
column9: but what he means by ""regular roof"" hasn't been     defined. And unless he's referring to the most expensive roof     options
column10: like ceramic or concrete tiles
column11: it's hard to see how     his projected pricing could be possible. I did the calculations     a few months ago
column12: and cells alone arefar more expensive than asphalt shingles
column13: so it's hard to even pencil out how the roof could be     cost-effective. Cost is a big unknown.We know absolutely nothing about how the solar roof will be     installed and connected to an inverter. Based on what we've     seen so far
column14: each cell will need to be connected to its     neighboring cell and eventually to an inverter. How exactly     will that work?It's also not known who will install the solar roof. There     would presumably be very little volume early on
column15: so SolarCity's     installation infrastructure could be used
column16: but the product may     also be sold through a traditional roofing network
column17: where roof     replacements with a solar roof might make sense. Musk needs to     expand on the channel plan.When the solar roof was introduced
column18: it was obvious that the     roofs used to display the product had been completely rebuilt     for the solar roof. We don't know what kind of angle and space     limitations roofs will have
column19: so we don't even know how many     roofs could potentially take a solar roof.There's still uncertainty about when the solar roof will be     available. SolarCity's Buffalo
column20: New York
column21: manufacturing plant     is supposed to be where the cells and roof shingles will be     made
column22: but we haven't seen the facility produce a reliable     traditional solar cell
column23: much less a revolutionary solar     product.There's a reasonSunPowerCEO Tom Werner said he was ""skeptical"" about the solar roof. Musk   and Tesla are trying to create a solar product that many others   with more manufacturing experience have failed at. And there are   a lot of dots that need to be connected before customers will be   able to put the Tesla solar roof on their roofs.What investors should watch and expectAnyone expecting a solar roof to cost anything near a   traditional asphalt roof will be disappointed when details are   released. At best
column24: investors should expect that a solar roof   product will cost a customer over $15
column25: 000; an all-in price over   $30
column26: 000 wouldn't surprise me. The roof may also generate less   energy than traditional solar panels would
column27: given the design.Some challenges with installation could be answered with a   limited launch
column28: likely in solar-dense areas in California. And   Tesla will presumably design the product in a way that will allow   it to be installed on many kinds of roofs.Investors' highest expectations should be that Tesla could   make the solar roof a highly profitable niche product for the   high end of the roofing and solar market. Trying to make it a   mass-market product could end in disaster unless it's extremely   low-cost (which I've highlighted is unlikely). The solar roof   could be a good product for Tesla
column29: but the company shouldn't be   betting big on an untested product with untested manufacturing.   Until we know more
column30: I'll take a skeptical approach to the product   as well.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column31: it can pay to listen. After all
column32: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Why Cellect Biotechnology Ltd. (APOP) Stock Is Soaring Today;3/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCellect Biotechnology Ltd.(NASDAQ:APOP) is up 74% to start the week after the little-known biotech completed its first stem cell transplant in Phase I/II trial. Today's gains give APOP stock an astounding - though not uncommon for biotech - 260% year-to-date gain.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockCellect Biotechnology was founded just a handful of years ago
column4: with the intent of legitimizing the use of regenerative medicine. If Cellect succeeds in its mission
column5: it would position itself as the main provider of stem cell treatments and technologies for the Big Pharma industry. That's not exactly small potatoes.Essentially
column6: the now-risky process of stem cell treatments would become""a trivial
column7: safe and inexpensive process.""Investors caught a glimpse of that future today and bid APOP stock up accordingly.Cellect's Stem Cell SuccessThe transplant procedure was accomplished using Cellect's proprietary ApoGraft technology in a blood cancer patient.3 Biotech Stocks That Could Double OvernightUsually
column8: stem cell bone marrow transplants have a 50-50 risk of causing graft-versus-host-disease (GvHD)
column9: which is when a donor's immune cells attack the patient's healthy
column10: normal cells
column11: which can be life threatening.Cellect CEO Dr. Shai Yarkoni hadthis to say:""After 15 years of research
column12: this is the first time we have used our technology on a cancer patient suffering from life-threatening conditions. It is a first good step on a road that we hope will lead to stem cell based regenerative medicine becoming a safe commodity treatment at every hospital in the world.""The success of Cellect's stem cell transplant has led the independent Data and Safety Monitoring Board to approve two additional patient enrollments into the company's ApoGraft treatment program.Bottom Line on APOP StockUnlike many other once-hot biotechs
column13: Cellect shares have retained their gains throughout the life of APOP - up 125% since going public in July 2016. That's not to say it hasn't had its fair share of peaks and troughs
column14: however
column15: as APOP stock saw an intraday low of $2.30
column16: and is off of its high of $13.50. Today's trading volume of 7.3 million compares to an average of 165
column18: however
column19: suggesting the spotlight is now on Cellect Biotechnology.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Solar Roof Tiles to Go on Sale in AprilIndeed
column20: investors are applauding in droves Cellect's first successful stem cell transplant. That's because the global market for stem cells will growfrom $12 billion in 2016 to $26.6 billion by 2021
column21: with regenerative medicine as its major application. All eyes will be on Cellect's second stem cell trial
column22: as well as the success (or failure) of its competitors.As it is
column23: it's too early to tell whether APOP stock will continue to hold its gains
column24: or give it all back in one explosive misstep.As of this writing

column1: Tesla's Latest Challenge: An Oversupplied Battery Market;3/27/2017;"WhenTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) began construction on its $5 billion Gigafactory   in Nevada
column2: a lot of company observers saw it as a bold but wise   move. At worst
column3: if demand for electric vehicles and energy   storage didn't shape up as projected
column4: the company would be able   tosell batteries to cellphone manufacturers.As the Model 3 nears its launch date
column5: the Gigafactory is   ramping up production to meet demand for the 500
column6: 000 vehicles   Tesla plans on making next year. At the same time
column7: Tesla's   success in EVs and the growth of energy storage haven't gone   unnoticed by competitors. Companies around the world are building   out battery capacity to fill the needs of automakers and energy   storage developers alike. And rising capacity is driving   overcapacity
column8: leading to lower battery prices. If the trend   continues
column9: competitors will be able to ride the industry's   commodity prices while Tesla will have to contend with the   falling value of batteries coming out of the Gigafactory. Here's   why that's a challenge in the long term.Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();How the battery industry became oversuppliedWhen Tesla began building the Gigafactory
column10: it was expected to   nearly double the world's battery production when it opened. And   if Elon Musk was going to make 500
column11: 000 EVs per year
column12: he needed to   make a bet that big on batteries.But since then
column13: lots of competitors have begun expanding   battery capacity.BYD
column14: AESC (owned by Nissan and NEC)
column15: LG Chem
column16: Samsung
column17: and other Asian suppliers are building out their own capacity   in an effort to capture market share. And while capacity is   opaque
column18: there are indications that there will be more than enough   supply for everyone. Sources I've talked to say that finding   supply is the least of their worries
column19: and prices on the open   market are below $300 per kWh and falling. Costs are expected to   fall further as oversupply hits the market
column20: with manufacturers   likely to sell near their own cash costs just to gain market   share. One sign that batteries aren't a business that's very   attractive is that Nissan has decided to sell its stake in AESC
column21: having decided it's a better idea to buy batteries on the open   market. Through its partnership with Panasonic and the   Gigafactory buildout
column22: Tesla is moving in the opposite   direction.Tesla Powerpacks installed in California. Image source:     Author.On the demand side
column23: EVs haven't taken hold as fast as many had   predicted. In 2008
column24: President Obama said he wanted 1 million EVs   on the road by 2015. We might not hit that level in the U.S.   until 2020. Even Tesla
column25: for all its success
column26: has repeatedly   missed its own production and sales targets. That trend could   change
column27: but companies are investing in new battery capacity for   projected demand for EVs and energy storage. For now
column28: a   combination of slower-than-hoped-for growth in EV demand and a   boom in battery supply will leave the market oversupplied with   batteries for the foreseeable future.There's a parallel to solar energyThere's no question that the EV industry is growing
column29: and so is   energy storage
column30: so there is some good news. But how quickly   demand and capacity grow can tell us a lot about how companies   will perform financially. If the market is undersupplied
column31: you   want to have some captive supply of batteries to meet your   customers' needs. But if it's oversupplied
column32: you want to buy   product that manufacturers are dumping on the market at low   costs. And buying batteries on the open market can save billions   in capital costs to build capacity
column33: too.This same dynamic happened in the solar industry a decade ago   and in some ways continues today. Everyone gets excited about the   growth of the solar industry
column34: so suppliers build as much capacity   as they can. But demand doesn't grow as quickly as supply
column35: and   thus the market becomes oversupplied. Panel prices fall
column36: making   the product less valuable. Technology improves and the cost   structure of new manufacturing gets better
column37: and the cycle begins   again.Five to 10 years after solar plants were completed
column38: most of them were obsolete. You can see the financial devastation in former global capacity   leadersSuntech PowerandQ-Cellsgoing bankrupt and in the more recent collapse ofYingli Green Energy. The solar companies who have done well weren't panel   manufacturers
column39: they were companies buying solar panels from   commodity suppliers and riding the falling commodity prices in   the industry.The supply of batteries doesn't appear to be the     problemWhen Tesla decided to build the Gigafactory
column40: it did so because   it needed to ensure battery supplies for its massive EV and   energy storage growth plans. Today
column41: the market appears to be   flush with batteries
column42: and competitors can buy them on the open   market at costs similar to Tesla's manufacturing costs   without the headache of actually building a battery plant. Some   are even buying batteries directly from Tesla
column43: which is reporting   gross margins in energy in thelow single digits.Tesla is going to need to keep producing batteries at or below   the cost of competitors' or risk being at a competitive   disadvantage. Given the similarities between the battery market   today and the solar industry a decade ago
column44: and the fact that   building massive manufacturing capacity was the surest sign of   future financial trouble in solar
column45: investors need to watch   closely how Tesla executes its battery strategy. Building out   capacity can seem like a good idea
column46: but not if that leaves you   captive to older technology when competitors are buying better   technology for less.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column47: it can pay to listen. After all
column48: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column49: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column50: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column51: 2017Travis Hoiumhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Tesla. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column14: on average
column15: than they have been for four years.""JPMorgan also upped its earnings estimates on AAPL from to $11.74 per share in calendar year 2018.Also
column16: over the weekend
column17: a court overturned a 2016 ruling that said Apple violated patent designs of China's Shenzhen Baili - a now-defunct company that ""barely existed"" when it sued Apple over the design of its iPhone 6. While Apple faced an early injunction

column19: and thus the court victory
column20: while encouraging

column22: along with the rest of the market.United Continental Holdings Inc (UAL )United Continental is in hot PR water after refusing to lettwo passengers on a plane.Two girls traveling from Denver to Minneapolis were wearing leggings when they were refused entry onto a plane. The incident itself was fairly calm
column23: and a group behind the girls even offered clothes to help cover one of the girls to meet compliance.However
column24: social media went ballistic when someone who witnessed the event tweeted it out.United's initial response was that the company ""shall have the right to refuse passengers who are not properly clothed
column25: though later on

SNAP is trading at 16x EV/Sales on our '18 estimates vs. 8x for FB. We initiate coverage with an Outperform and $26 PT.""Credit Suisse also chimed in with an ""Outperform"" rating and a $30 price target.The dissenter from the group was Oppneheimer's Jason Helfstein
column36: which started Snap at ""Hold

column1: Apple Buys Powerful Automation App Workflow;3/26/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News

column3: andApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) knows it. That is why it has acquired the popular automation app Workflow
column4: according toTechCrunch.makeArticleAd();What Does Workflow Do?Source: ShutterstockLike the IFTTT service
column5: the Workflow app allows users to perform several complicated tasks with a single tap by enabling them to group together a large number of actions
column6: notes TechCrunch.Workflow came into existence in 2014. Since then
column7: it has made several tasks easy such as creating GIFs from a series of photos
column8: posting photos on several social platforms at once
column9: translations of texts and lot more. To use an automation task
column10: a user needs to go to the app's built-in gallery
column11: which offers them numerous options
column12: including custom automation.In 2015
column13: the app received AAPL's design award at its annual Worldwide Developers Conference. The iPhone maker told TechCrunch that it chose the app for the award because it used iOS accessibility features in a commendable manner.9 Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9 a ShareThe app did tremendous work when it comes to implementing VoiceOver with clearly labeled items
column14: thoughtful hints
column15: and drag/drop announcements. This made the app usable and easily accessible.How Could Workflow Help Apple?The Workflowacquisitionalso brings to Apple the team behind it
column16: which includes Ari Weinstein
column17: Nick Frey
column18: Conrad Kramer and Ayaka Nonaka. The app will become available for free on the App Store (it was a paid app earlier).Expressing his excitement about joining Apple

column20: ""We've worked closely with Apple from the very beginning
column21: from kickstarting our company as students attending WWDC to developing and launching Workflow and seeing its amazing success on the App Store. We can't wait to take our work to the next level at Apple and contribute to products that touch people across the world.""No more details about the deal are known for now. It is not known how Apple's offerings will be integrated with the app. It may be that its capabilities will be integrated into iOS in the future. According to TechCruch
column22: Siri could benefit immensely from Workflow's capabilities.How Much Will Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Fall If the iPhone 8 Flops?The Workflow acquisition could also help in one more way. AAPL automation guru Sal Saghoian recently quit. Since then

column25: it may continue them.The postApple Buys Powerful Automation App Workflowappeared first onValueWalk.More From InvestorPlaceCount Out Advanced Micro Devices

column1: Can Tesla and Uber Learn from Ford's Mistake?;3/25/2017;"Two of the most polarizing companies in recent years areTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) and Uber. The two
column2: in their own respective ways
column3: have flipped the automotive industry on its head
column4: and
column5: along with other technology companies
column6: have set the industry on a path to evolve wildly over the next two decades. Uber was a wake up call to major automakers
column7: such asFord Motor Company(NYSE: F)
column8: on ways to expand its top line without a traditional vehicle sale. And Tesla showed automakers electric vehicles are a viable business if you develop a strong product and brand.However
column9: what is becoming clear is that Tesla and Uber have something important they can learn from Ford: Corporate culture matters.makeArticleAd();Tesla's upcoming Model 3. Image source: Tesla Motors.What's going on?Uber's public relations team has put in some work lately with multiple stories regarding company executives and treatment of employees. Here's a snippet from Susan Fowler's blog post
column10: a former Uber employee
column11: about her time there and the culture she witnessed.I remember countless meetings with my managers and skip-levels where I would sit there
column12: not saying anything
column13: and the manager would be boasting about finding favor with their skip-level and that I should expect them to have their manager's job within a quarter or two. I also remember a very disturbing team meeting in which one of the directors boasted to our team that he had withheld business-critical information from one of the executives so that he could curry favor with one of the other executives (and
column14: he told us with a smile on his face
column15: it worked!).""Also within Susan's post are allegations ofsexual harassment and apathy from HRregarding the allegations. There's also a video of Uber CEO Travis Kalanickberating an Uber driver earlier this year. Just recently
column16: respected Uber President Jeff Jones quit his position after only six months at the company because the controversiesaren't what he signed up for.Meanwhile
column17: Tesla is having issues of its own. The promising electric vehicle automaker has witnessed a string of executive departures over the past year
column18: which is far from ideal as the company inches toward the launch of the company's incredibly important Model 3. Former Tesla CFO Jason Wheeler's recent departure is only the latest of defects and many others have cited long hours
column19: difficult production goals
column20: and a tense culture fostered by the company's brilliant
column21: but demanding
column22: CEO
column23: Elon Musk.""Any time you're going through a big change it's important to have consistent management
column24: Colin Langan
column25: a UBS analyst
column26: told Bloomberg. ""Jason Wheeler was a big hire and he's leaving
column27: and there have been many other departures. If you're putting out aggressive targets and the people aren't there to meet them
column28: it's a problem.""A trip down memory laneLet's rewind a second
column29: as many investors have forgotten how broken Ford's culture was in decades past. Ford was notorious for its toxic culture with executives putting their own advancement above their own departments and company as a whole. It created a culture of backstabbing
column30: undermining
column31: and anything but working together for the greater good.Left: Alan Mulally. Middle: Bill Ford. Right: Mark Fields. Image source: Ford Motor Company.The result was a cutthroat
column32: careerist culture that didn't produce results and culminated in a company that had failed product designs
column33: failed business strategies
column34: and little leadership. Its stock price was declining
column35: its debt was junk rated
column36: and it was about to get much worse as the looming Great Recession was just around the corner.In 2006
column37: Alan Mulally
column38: a former star executive at Boeing
column39: took over the struggling Detroit automaker and pulled off a miracle getting the automaker through the Great Recession without taxpayer money. Mulally and his team fostered a culture that encouraged teamwork
column40: consolidated and simplified the company's strategies
column41: and produced vehicles people actually wanted to buy. It was a wildly successful turnaround and the cornerstone of its success was driven by Mulally fixing the toxic culture -- and that might be the most important thing Tesla and Uber can learn from an automaker that's been in business since 1903. I'm not saying the CEO's need to go
column42: quite the opposite
column43: they need to take a page out of Mulally's book and fix the culture they started.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column44: it can pay to listen. After all
column45: the newsletter they have run for over a decade
column46: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column47: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: This Used Car Is Worth More Now Than When New;3/25/2017;"Demand forHarley-Davidson(NYSE: HOG) motorcycles used to be so great that a used bike   could be sold for as much or more than the price paid for it.   Waiting lists to buy new motorcycles ran months long until Harley   went into overdrive producing enough bikes to meet demand.You're usually not going to find a comparable situation in   production-model cars and trucks. Their ubiquity makes them
column2: if   not a dime a dozen
column3: certainly less valuable over time. That's   partially the reason a car's value drops so sharply once you   drive it off the dealer's lot. AFord(NYSE: F) F-150 pickup truck may be the best-selling vehicle on   the market today
column4: but Kelley Blue Book says a model year 2016   F-150 has already lost 11% of its value
column5: or some $2
column7: at   auction.Image source: Ford.makeArticleAd();Gas-guzzlers make a comebackRecently
column8: Kelley released its fourth-quarter 2016 survey on   retention values for manufacturer-suggested retail prices when a   car that's anywhere from one to three years old goes to auction.   It found thatfull-sized pickup truckslike Ford's have done surprisingly well at holding onto their   value
column9: with the F-150 coming in fifth among the competition
column10: but   theNissan(NASDAQOTH: NSANY) Titan is doing best overall
column11: losing just 2% of   its value.However
column12: the report took a closer look at model year 2015   vehicles to see those that retained values best
column13: and apparently
column14: lower gas prices were having a big effect on buyer choices: The   two worst-performing segments were subcompact cars that retained   just 51% of their value and electric cars
column15: which only managed to   hold onto 38%.The worst of the worst wereGeneral Motors'(NYSE: GM) hybrid electric Chevy Volt
column16: keeping just 40% of its   value; the subcompact Mitsubishi Mirage and smart fortwo
column17: at just   39% and 37%
column18: respectively; and the all-electric Nissan Leaf
column19: which
column20: at just 24%

column1: Affordable EVs for the Masses Are Already Here;3/25/2017;"Electric vehicles have been a big topic of conversation in the   auto industry over the last few years
column2: whether you're looking at   the disruptionTelsa(NASDAQ: TSLA) has created or the inroads the big automakers are   trying to make into the EV market. Still
column3: with most EVs costing   well over $30
column5: they aren't an option for most Americans.However
column6: millions of Americans might soon be riding the   streets in electric vehicles every day -- just not the way you   might expect based on the media hype. It's electricbusesthat could soon be taking millions of people to their   destinations.Proterra electric bus. Image source: Proterra.makeArticleAd();Why electric buses make senseElectric transportation doesn't make sense for all situations
column7: but in those cases where there's a known range requirement and   sufficient time for recharging at night or between uses
column8: there's   a big opportunity. That fits the bus market perfectly
column9: given the   local nature of most municipal bus programs.The challenges to making the switch have always been the cost   and availability of electric buses
column10: but those challenges are   receding. Proterra is leading the charge
column11: and it's making a   strong case to cities across the country. The company can   manufacture buses with single-charge ranges from 49 to 350 miles
column12: depending on the model. For short-range buses
column13: the charge time is   as little as 10 minutes
column14: while larger battery packs could take   three and a half to five hours to get powered up for 251 to 350   miles of driving. Those range options will fit the needs of most   municipal bus routes.The bodies of Proterra's buses are made from a   carbon-fiber-reinforced composite material
column15: so they're   lightweight
column16: and the company says they can save their owners a   small fortune. According to Proterra
column17: they'll cost $237
column18: 000 less   over their lifetimes on maintenance because what's under the hood   is so much simpler than in an ordinary bus -- essentially
column19: just   an electric motor and a two-speed transmission. Better yet
column20: at   $0.19 per mile
column21: an electric bus beats $0.63 per mile for a hybrid   fuel vehicle and $0.84 per mile for diesel.Image source: Proterra.Purchase prices are plunging for electric     busesThe cost of an electric bus is still about $750
column23: which is   well over the $450
column24: 000 or so that it costs to buy a diesel bus.   But when you look at the savings described above
column25: the overall   cost case can already be made for switching to electric. And more   progress on that front is coming.Batteries account for a huge percentage of the cost of   electric buses
column26: so the industry will be able to ride the cost   curve down along with automakers. Battery costs are held close to   the vest
column27: but McKinsey & Company has said battery costs for   EVs fell from $1
column28: 000/kWh in 2010 to $227/kWh in 2016. At that   price
column29: a 660 kWh battery pack would cost $149
column30: 820. But some   analysts project that costs will fall below $100 per kWh by 2030
column31: and many industry experts expect them to drop even faster. At   that point
column32: that 660 kWh battery pack would cost $66
column33: 000 --   still a sizable chunk of money
column34: but creating conditions under   which the overall cost of an EV bus could be lower than a   fossil-fuel model.The transition in this segment is progressing quickly. On theEnergy Gang Podcast
column35: Proterra CEO Ryan Popple predicted that by 2020
column36: one-third of   new buses in the U.S. will be EVs
column37: and by 2030
column38: 100% will be   electric. And a lot of the capability needed to make that change   is being built in-house
column39: given the fact that Proterra designs and   manufactures its own battery packs
column40: just like Tesla does. The sea   change in industry trajectory and the supply chain has   ramifications for everyone from battery makers to competitors in   the bus market.This isn't a transition that's just the dream of one bus   manufacturer
column41: it's already taking place in cities across the   country. Philadelphia has 25 electric buses in its fleet
column42: there   are 10 corporate shuttle buses run by JLL in Chicago
column43: Park City   Transit in Utah runs 6 electric buses
column44: and there aredozens of others operating electric buses across   the country
column45: with more on the way. The transition really is taking hold in   the bus market.Who could be in troubleI've focused on the upside for electric buses and companies   like Proterra
column46: which countsExelon(NYSE: EXC)
column47: General Motors(NYSE: GM)
column48: andEdison International(NYSE: EIX) among its investors. But the real story here could be   the loss of business for other bus manufacturers and   suppliers.Cummins(NYSE: CMI) is a manufacturer of large engines and a major   supplier to the bus market. It's already seen revenue stagnate   and net income shrink over the past five years
column49: so the loss of a   major market could push its business into an overall decline.New Flyer Industries
column50: Daimler
column51: Hyundai
column52: andMitsubishiare also big bus manufacturers that could take a hit in demand if   electric buses start grabbing big market share. New Flyer is the   biggest of these players
column53: and it's trying to move into electric   buses. But its development in that arena has been slower than   Proterra's
column54: and it's still developing hydrogen-fueled options
column55: which could be a distraction in the long term.This could be an industry more ready for disruption than the   consumer vehicle market. There's financial justification for   going electric
column56: and municipalities looking to cut costs will see   the savings potential as attractive. It may turn out that the way   millions of Americans take their first rides in EVs will be when   they climb on board a city bus -- which wouldn't be a bad thing   for the EV industry as a whole.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Supercharger Costs Are Still Relatively Small for Tesla Inc.;3/24/2017;"Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) was undoubtedly a pioneer when it came to building   out a charging network for electric vehicles that truly enables   long-distance travel across the country. And the network remains   atop priorityfor Tesla today
column2: particularly ahead of its Model 3 launch later   this year. The electric-car maker wants to be sure the network is   prepared to handle higher demand from a larger fleet of fully   electric vehicles.Some investors might wonder just how costly it is for Tesla to   build new Superchargers and to maintain them. Fortunately
column3: Tesla   provided some insights into the costs of Superchargers in its   most recent annual report. As it turns out
column4: the costs involved   with building out the world's largest network of fast-charging   stations are not only reasonable
column5: but also sustainable.Tesla Supercharger. Image source: author.makeArticleAd();What Tesla said about Supercharger costsThere are essentially two main types of costs for Tesla's   Supercharger expansion: up-front capital outlay and operating   costs. Here's what Tesla said about each in its most recent   annual report.Capital outlay:Regarding up-front spending on Supercharger stations in 2016
column6: Tesla said it represented only a ""minimal portion of total   capital spending."" Assuming Tesla accounts for the book value of   its Supercharger locations on par with the amount it spends to   build them
column7: this amount was probably about $40.6 million
column8: since   the net book value of Tesla's Supercharger network increased from   $166.6 million in 2015 to $207.2 million in 2016.While $40.6 million might seem like a lot
column9: it's a tiny portion   of Tesla's total capital expenditures. Tesla spent about $1.3   billion on capital expenditures in 2016.Since Tesla's total Supercharger locations expanded from 584   to 790 during this period
column10: the company likely spent around   $197
column11: 000 per new Supercharger location during the year.Operating costs:Though there aren't any figures available on the operating costs   of maintaining Superchargers and footing their electric bills
column12: Tesla does give investors some context. The company says it   allocates Supercharger operating costs to automotive cost of   goods sold and selling
column13: general
column14: and administrative expenses
column15: which makes sense since the Supercharger experience is ultimately   one of the key selling points for a Tesla vehicle. These costs   ""were immaterial for all periods presented
column16: Tesla said in its   2016 annual report.Overall
column17: therefore
column18: Supercharger costs are relatively small   for Tesla -- at least as a portion of total capital expenditures
column19: cost of goods sold
column20: and operating expenses.Tesla's Supercharger expansionEven as Supercharger spending has remained nearly   unnoticeable
column21: Tesla's Supercharger network is growing rapidly.   Measured by total connections (instead of total locations)
column22: Tesla   said last March it planned to double connections globally
column23: from   3
column25: 200 by sometime in 2017. Tesla has already made   significant progress toward this target
column26: with total Supercharger   connections today at 5
column27: 295.Model 3. Image source: Tesla.However
column28: though Supercharger costs have been manageable amid   this rapid expansion
column29: Supercharger utilization per dollar of   revenue from vehicle sales is bound to increase as the company   begins selling its Model 3 later this year for half the price of   its Model S and Model X. Fortunately
column30: Tesla has a solution for   this. The company has been rolling out a number of key changes to   its Supercharger program
column31: including afee for idle vehicles at Superchargersandfees per kilowatt-hour of chargingafter about 1
column32: 000 miles of free charging for each customer each   year.With Tesla's Supercharger network expansion already looking   like a feasible expenditure for the company to maintain as it   continues to grow
column33: these new fees for Supercharging should easily   be enough for Tesla to keep the network from being a burden on   financials in the years to come.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip

column1: Will the Tesla Model 3 Beat the Competition in 2017?;3/23/2017;"The market for electric vehicles (EV) and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEV) has been growing at very strong double-digits
column2: of course off a very small base. As a result

But market watchers believe that 2016 was like the appetizer before the main course with 2017 and 2018 expected to see some momentum. This is not without reason because things do appear to be coming together for the market-Regulatory SupportMost important amongst these reasons is the fact that world leaders are coming together on environmental and climate change matters. There is a visible effort to promote clean energy in every aspect of life. Since auto emissions are one of the biggest reasons for air pollution and also contribute to global warming
column4: this is where a lot of research is going on.Within the U.S.
column5: there is the Zero Emission Vehicle (ZEV) mandate that has been adopted by 10 states led by California and including Connecticut
column6: Maine
column7: Maryland
column8: Massachusetts
column9: New Jersey
column10: New York
column11: Oregon
column12: Rhode Island and Vermont. The goal is to push automakers to research
column13: develop and sell zero emission cars (these would be EVs rather than PHEVs although both receive some benefit).The ZEV authority of the concerned state certifies ZEVs
column14: which then qualify for credits. An automaker has to sell a steadily rising number of EVs each year to meet the credit goal in a given year. For instance
column16: the percentage of zero-emission passenger cars and light-duty trucks produced by the manufacturer and delivered for sale is required to be 4.5%
column17: in 2019 that number will rise to 7.0%
column18: in 2020 it will be 9.5%
column22: 2024 19.5% and 2025 22.0%. So far so good.In February
column23: the Auto Alliance trade group approached President Trump to relax the requirements from 2022 to 2025 because they say that Obama rushed through the mid-term review without taking into consideration upcoming research that would show the targets to be too burdensome. But President Trump has his work cut out if he is to relax the requirements
column24: because he along with the Transportation Department would have to ask the Environmental Protection Authority to revise their rules and cancel a couple of waivers to the State of California that allow the state to frame its own stricter rules if the federal government relaxes.Moreover
column25: California's rules can be adopted by other states
column26: creating a messy compliance problem for automakers. So stopping California becomes important.So any alterations will take time and involve a complex process. Moreover
column27: even if they are done
column28: it will be a moderation of the rule rather than a directional change. Bottom line: the regulatory environment remains positive for EVs.Rapidly Falling Battery CostsBatteries are of course extremely important for electric cars because they determine how far they can go on a single charge. So the cost of the battery pack (the individual cells plus the supporting structure
column29: cell cooling mechanisms and battery management systems) also determines to an extent the price of the car itself.According to a recent McKinsey report
column30: battery costs have dropped from around $1
column31: 000 per kWh in 2010 to around $227 per kWh in 2016. McKinsey expects battery pack prices to drop to around $190/kWH by 2020 and $100/kWH by 2030
column32: at which time the business is expected to be profitable for automakers.But R&D appears to be moving faster than estimates because TeslaTSLAhas said that it's already using a battery pack below the $190 range and expects to lower cost by another 30% before the Model 3 gets to market. The company
column33: along with partner Panasonic has started mass production for its other storage products at the Gigafactory in Nevada.Production for the Model 3 will start in the second quarter and capacity can be expanded as needed (estimated to be 35 GWh/year in 2018
column34: or nearly as much as the rest of the rest of the world's battery production combined). Musk claims that Gigafactory makes the ""highest energy density cell in the world and also the cheapest"". So let's hope they will allow the Model 3 to enter the market at the targeted $35
column35: 000 price point for mass market adoption.Tesla isn't the only one making progress. General MotorsGMproduct chief Mark Reuss has reportedly said that the Chevy Bolt uses battery cells (not the entire pack) costing $145 per kWh and is working to lower that number.An ancillary factor that can also help adoption is convenient and possibly wireless battery charging options. We seem to be really far from this today
column36: not because the technology isn't there (it almost is)
column37: but because the number of battery charging stations are nowhere near the number of gasoline stations
column38: so there's some infrastructure catchup waiting to get done there.Increasing Product RangeThe most popular electric and hybrid cars in 2016 were the Tesla Model S
column39: Chevy Volt
column40: Tesla Model X
column41: FordFFusion Energi
column42: Nissan LEAF
column43: Ford C Max Energi and BMW i3. Of these
column44: the Tesla cars
column45: the Nissan LEAF and the BMW i3 were fully electric with the rest being hybrids.This year will see new fully electric models from players like GM
column46: which launched the Chevy Bolt last December. Initial testers sound enthusiastic about the car despite its somewhat boxy design. So they could be popular with customers and also government departments that may not be so hung up on the more sexy Teslas.Tesla itself will launch the more efficient and lower-priced Model 3 (with autopilot and possibly
column47: a solar roof option)
column48: but the launch date can have something to do with how many it manages to sell.Then there's also BMW
column49: which estimates that it will sell 100
column50: 000 i3s this year
column51: up from 40
column52: 000 last year. The company expects EVs and PHEVs to make up 15-25% of its sales by 2025 as it gradually electrifies all the BMW Group brands.Another car that picked up steam in the fourth quarter of 2016 is the hybrid ToyotaTMPrius Prime
column53: so 2017 could see an uptick.One limiting factor for EVs and hybrids is their availability. If customers can't test drive the vehicle
column54: they most likely won't place an order. Testing is largely available only in the ZEV mandate states.Growing Consumer InterestLow gas prices are an obvious deterrent to buying clean energy vehicles
column55: but lower costs and discounting in some cases make them attractive. Plus
column56: they also get a federal tax break. All this combined is leading to increased awareness of the concept
column57: which could result in a spike in sales.Possible Problems for TeslaIncreasing Competition: We now know quite a bit about Tesla's battery production and also know that it intends to sell 500
column58: 000 electric cars a year by 2018 (that's next year). This is an exciting number on its own
column59: but today there are a growing number of players in the space
column60: increasing choice for consumers.Tesla's edge is in its design and autopilot system
column61: and its battery technology that can allow it to give more at lower prices while making more profit. All these advantages may be put to the test more now than ever before.Cash strapped/competitors have deeper pockets: Tesla makes fully electric cars
column62: which has both its positive and negative sides. In the current environment
column63: since it produces only all-electric cars
column64: it generates a whole lot of credits it doesn't need in the ZEV states. So it can sell these for a profit to those who need it
column65: thus helping its profits and cash flow. This isn't of course enough to keep a leading edge company afloat because the thing that keeps it ahead of peers is R&D
column66: which is expensive.The company has raised cash through both equity and debt so the Model 3 launch will go smoothly. But it certainly doesn't have a whole lot of marketing dollars left over
column67: which will come in handy as the established automakers sink their teeth into EVs.Bottom LineTesla still appears to be well ahead of the pack. Not only is its battery tech more advanced
column68: but it also has a fully compliant glass roof
column69: which may be used to generate solar power to drive the car. Yes
column70: others have tried it with limited success (such as the Prius). And no
column71: that doesn't mean Tesla won't do a better job.The glass roof means that there probably won't be too much extra cost to add the PV cells
column72: so who knows? After battery cost reduction
column73: battery charging is the next big problem to solve in order to hasten electric car adoption and what can be better than a free-of-charge
column74: auto recharge system?More Stock News: This Is Bigger than the iPhone!It could become the mother of all technological revolutions. Apple sold a mere 1 billion iPhones in 10 years but a new breakthrough is expected to generate more than 27 billion devices in just 3 years

column1: Safety Could Be a Key Selling Feature of Tesla's Model 3;3/23/2017;"It's hard to understate the importance of safety in the auto   industry

column7: the vehicle's safety will be   paramount.Model S and Model X. Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();Safety firstMorgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas

This would be achieved through a   combination of hardware and software features that ""provide a   level of active safety that could significantly lead all other   cars on sale today."" The analyst believes that this could be an   ""aha!"" moment for customers later this year when the vehicle   launches.How Tesla vehicles with second-generation Autopilot hardware     sense the environment. While Tesla's new version of   Autopilot that uses the second-generation hardware suite is just   now rolling out and is off to arough start

column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI usually use options

column8: or positions you may add to.Remember

column11: or sell

column26: however

column28: and if Netflix is put to you

column33: and I don't know what those investors are smoking

column37: and pocket the $1
column38: 800 premium.3 Short Squeeze Stocks to Buy in a Bull MarketPersonally

column20: while pointing down. As much

column22: I like the idea of using a targeted long call butterfly as a moderately bullish position in the nearer-term to catch profits in TSLA stock.The butterfly is one of the lower cost spreads available. By targeting an out-of-the-money strike

column1: Should Tesla Inc. Investors Be Concerned about Trump's Emissions Agenda?;3/23/2017;"Love him or hate him
column2: nobody can argue that President Donald   Trump hasn't made a lot of noise since he took his seat in the   Oval Office. And while many of the policies his administration   will promote remain up in the air -- and will for some time --   some major automakers have already begun changing up their   strategies.One policy shift that could impactTesla Inc.(NASDAQ: TSLA) investors is if Trump and his appointees loosen   automotive emissions standards.After all
column3: oil is fairly cheap now
column4: and if gasoline-powered   vehicles need less of the expensive technology being developed by   automakers to meet the stricter pollution standards put in place   by the Obama administration
column5: traditional vehicles will likely   come with lower sticker prices. That would make it more difficult   for consumers to justify buying electric vehicles
column6: which could   slow their mainstream adoption.makeArticleAd();But is this really an issue for Tesla investors to be   concerned about? If recent news is any indication
column7: don't lose any   sleep just yet.What's Trump doing anyway?If you remember
column8: just before Barack Obama was set to depart   the White House
column9: the EPA tried to secure the stricter automotive   emissions standards that were put in place during his   administration. Those efforts may be to no avail: Last Wednesday   Trump announced that his administration would reopen and review   those emissions mandates. That's positive news for producers of   large SUVs and trucks
column10: such as Detroit automakers
column11: but not as   positive for automakers like Tesla that are pushing for a faster   adoption of electric vehicles.Image source: Tesla
column12: Inc.The consequences of keeping the current standards are dire
column13: if   you're inclined to believeFordCEO Mark Fields. Early in 2017
column14: when Fields met with Trump
column15: he   claimed that 1 million jobs would be at risk if regulations   weren't toned down.Independent analysts respondedthat the figure he cited was a worst-case scenario from a report   that has been scathingly criticized for basing its results on a   set of dubious assumptions.However
column16: there's no doubt that keeping strict emissions   standards
column17: and forcing automakers to accelerate research and   development spending on technology required to meet those   standards
column18: will be costly. The EPA estimated the cost to add   fuel-saving technologies could reach $1
column19: 565 per vehicle
column20: depending on the time frame. That's a significant chunk of change   to tack on to a new car purchase.The relaxation of regulations   could help most automakers save a few bucks and keep their   sticker prices a bit lower.The good news is...Here's the good news for Tesla investors: A bunch of U.S.   cities remain willing to spend billions on electric cars and   trucks.More specifically
column21: according to a recent Bloomberg article
column22: more than 30 cities
column23: including New York and Chicago
column24: have asked   for specific cost information and details on the feasibility of   producing and purchasing114
column25: 000 electric vehicles-- from police vehicles to street sweepers. That number would be   close to three-fourths of total U.S. plug-in sales during 2016.   In essence
column26: those municipalities are looking to prove there is   plenty of demand for electric vehicles -- starting with   themselves.That position was stated firmly by Daniel Zarrilli
column27: New York   City's senior director of climate policy and programs
column28: in an   interview with Bloomberg: ""Now more than ever there is a need for   cities' leadership on climate. We really want to send a message   that there is a growing market for electric vehicles --   regardless of what is happening in D.C.""It appears that cities and the automotive industry in general   understand that our vehicular future is electric
column29: and that a   near-term change in policy by Trump's administration won't derail   long-term plans -- and certainly won't derail Tesla. Truth be   told
column30: a move to roll back emissions standards could have hurt   Tesla if it the company were already the size it hopes to be in   five to 10 years
column31: but at this point
column32: the impact will be less of a   negative for Tesla and more of a positive for Detroit   automakers.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Buy Tesla Stock
column2: Just Not for the Cars;3/23/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) is well-known within the investment community. Bears argue that Tesla is a cash-strapped company rich in valuation
column4: while bulls says Tesla stock is a buy based on its future potential. Most investors base much of their thesis on the company's car production.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockSpecifically
column5: they focus on Tesla's current deliveries of the Model S and Model X. They also focus on whether Elon Musk & Co. will be able to mass produce the Model 3. If the upstart futurist can efficiently produce and sell enough of the Model 3
column6: bulls will view this as a success.The plan is for Tesla's affordable
column7: mass-consumer Model 3 - reportedly in the mid-$30
column8: 000 range - to engage both mid-tier and high-tier buyers. Should a hiccup in production arise or a spike in costs materialize
column9: however
column10: bears will sink their teeth into the notion that success may not be so imminent.Both the bull and bear theses overlook something crucial to the future of Tesla: Energy.Tesla Stock's True DriverTesla acquired SolarCity in late-2016
column11: giving the company a new business segment with solar. While solar may not be the most profitable venture
column12: its synergies could be the focus.TSLA has been quietly ramping up its energy business. Specifically
column13: Tesla produces both residential and commercial battery packs. On the commercial side
column14: these refrigerator-sized batteries serve as a backup power source to municipalities.10 Clobbered Stocks to Buy That Are About to Get Red-HotTeslarecently installed396 of these batteries for a city in California. It did so ahead of schedule as well. This may seem like an immaterial footnote
column15: but it shows that management's execution is on point. This could be a key selling point alongside the product when it comes to getting new cities on board.Even more recently
column16: TSLAunveiled a big projecton the Hawaiian island Kauai. Tesla installed almost 55
column17: 000 solar panels in combination with 272 commercial batteries. The project will generate energy by day and night thanks to the battery and solar panel combination. Additionally
column18: it will save about 1.6 million gallons of diesel per year.Tesla's Tipping PointThese are just two recent projects. Admittedly
column19: the trickle down to the bottom line will not be significant at first. Now that Tesla's Gigafactory has started to come online
column20: battery production won't be as constrained.If TSLA is able to garner more contracts for these types of projects
column21: it could create a tipping point in its business model.Tesla stock is currently tied to auto production
column22: likeFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) orGeneral Motors Company(NYSE:GM). As demand grows for Tesla's vehicles
column23: it will be more susceptible to the cyclical whims of the auto market. If Tesla can balance out the ups-and-downs of this market with a more consistent energy business
column24: though
column25: investors should cheer the move.Our energy grid is susceptible to issues
column26: but through backup storage via batteries and power generation via solar panels
column27: Tesla is distinguishing itself from the competition.Bottom Line on Tesla StockIt's not all roses and rainbows for Tesla stock. Bears can point to lithium supply constraints or rising costs as negative catalysts. Tesla israising capitaland there is Model 3 execution risk
column28: too. These are all true points. We even laid out why we're not buyers of TSLA stock at current levelsearlier this month.GOOGL Stock Is Falling Into a FunkWith all that said
column29: CEO Elon Musk is a visionary. He's building state-of-the-art cars and quietly building out an energy arm that investors will soon take note of. While all growth stocks are susceptible to heavy volatility
column30: Tesla's long-term outlook is attractive - even if it looks expensive as well.Luckily
column31: Tesla has passionate investors.As of this writing

column1: 3 Stocks I'm Never Selling;3/23/2017;"When we own portions of outstanding businesses with     outstanding managements

Here's   why.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Still an early growth storySuccessful long-term investing is all about buying companies   with durable business models and significant growth potential. column9: which is why I've long considered this company to be   a core holding.Mastercard's vast network helps merchants

column12: convenient
