column14: and   offers rewards
column15: consumers in developed markets have accepted them   with open arms. In exchange for its services
column16: Mastercard pockets   a small fee for each successful transaction. With more than 2.3   billion cards in circulation
column17: consumers swipe a card with a   Mastercard logo more than 56 billion times each year. That allows   those small fees to add up quickly
column18: which is how Mastercard   pulled in more than $10 billion in total revenue last year.While Mastercard's business model is a thing of beauty
column19: the   reason I believe this company is a ""hold forever"" stock is that   roughly 85% of transactions worldwide still occur with cash   or check. With the global middle class expected to rise in the   coming decades
column20: I think this figure will continuously shift in   favor of electronic payments. That hints that Mastercard's   growth story is still just getting warmed up
column21: which is why I plan   on hanging around for the long haul.Giving Wall Street an edgeEvery investor knows that you can't make smart decisions   without access to data. Banks
column22: hedge funds
column23: insurance providers
column24: mutual funds
column25: and others all feel the same way and are willing to   pay a premium to get their hands on high-quality information.   That fact keeps FactSet Research Systems' services in demand.FactSet is a data aggregator that collects information from   hundreds of sources and then sells access to this information on   a subscription basis. The company counts a wide range of   financial companies as customers
column26: and once they start using   FactSet's system
column27: they tend to become heavily reliant on the   data. In turn
column28: they willing sign long-term contracts with   FactSet that feature annual price increases.FactSet's results show that customers continue to highly value   the company's services. Last quarter
column29: FactSet's customer   retention ratewas 95%
column30: which speaks volumes about the company's product offering.What's wonderful about this business is that the company's   financial statements are highly predictable. In fact
column31: FactSet has   reported 36 consecutive years of revenue growth and 20 straight   years of profit growth. Those are remarkable figures.Looking ahead
column32: investors can bank on the company using   acquisitions
column33: price increases
column34: and international expansion   to drive its top line higher. When combined with expense control   and share buybacks
column35: FactSet should be able to leverage that   growth into even bigger gains on the bottom line. This rock-solid   business model is why I plan on counting myself as a shareholder   for decades to come.Driving a sustainable futureThere's no doubt that Tesla is the most   controversial name on this list. The upstart automaker has   yet to produce a full-year GAAP profit
column36: has a habit of missingits own guidance

column44: and energy storage sectors all once. The opportunity is so big   that there are literally trillions of dollars in sales up for   grabs.What could that opportunity mean for investors? column1: 2 Concerns Facing Tesla
column2: Inc. Investors;3/22/2017;"Few people will argue thatTesla
column3: Inc.(NASDAQ: TSLA) isn't an amazing start-up story in an auto   industry that isn't easy on newcomers. The electric-vehicle   automaker has lit a fire under major automakers and likely pushed   up the development of their EV programs by years. However
column4: partly   due to the hype surrounding Tesla's potential
column5: it trades at an   extremely high valuation despite burning through cash
column6: and its   market cap is a rich $42 billion. For comparison
column7: Fordwhich has recently posted years of record profits
column8: trades at a   $48 billion market cap.Due to those rich valuations
column9: jumping on board the Tesla   bandwagon seems risky for the following two main reasons.Culture concernsInvestors shouldn't overlook the fact that Tesla's culture has   been criticized for some time. It's difficult to gauge how much   of a direct impact this has on results
column10: but what's clear is that   top executive talent is consistently choosing to leave. Just   recently
column11: Chief Financial Officer Jason Wheeler announced his   impending departure after spending slightly over a year at the   automaker. Last May
column12: two key executives also hit the road
column13: including Greg Reichow
column14: Tesla's vice president of   manufacturing.makeArticleAd();In mid 2016
column15: one of Tesla's biggest hires to that point
column16: Rich   Heley
column17: who rapidly rose through the ranks to vice president of   product technology
column18: decided to joinFacebook. Other top executives to leave include Mateo Jaramillo
column19: vice   president at Tesla Energy
column20: Michael Zanoni
column21: vice president of   finance and worldwide controller
column22: James Chen
column23: vice president of   regulatory affairs and deputy general counsel
column24: and Ricardo Reyes
column25: vice president of global communications. According toBloomberg
column26: more than two dozen management departures over the past year   have been recorded.These departures don't mean the sky is falling
column27: and Tesla   likely has an unfathomable amount of resumes from talented   contenders being sent in on a daily basis. The problem is that on   the eve of launching the company's most important vehicle to   date
column28: the Model 3
column29: having a consistent and steady executive team   is important to meet objectives and deadlines -- and strong   management in general is one key factor investors should highly   consider when examining a company.When small flaws go mainstreamIf you have a chance
column30: read my colleague's story about   repairing his Tesla Model S andthe nightmare that ensued. Beyond repair woes and the time it takes to get your car back   in some cases
column31: there's no shortage of flaws. Mechanical problems   and software glitches affect many of the vehicles. Some of those   are minor issues such as doors not being properly aligned
column32: and   some are design flaws such as the Model X's wing doors   accidentally smashing into things the sensors didn't detect.Tesla's production floor. Image source: Tesla
column33: Inc.Up to this point
column34: it hasn't turned consumers away from owning   Teslas
column35: but there's a reason for that. Right now consumers are   paying a steep price
column36: often around $100
column38: to be an early   adopter in what could be the future of the automotive industry.   Flaws likely aren't going to make early adopters love their Tesla   any less. The issue goes deeper than the flaws themselves
column39: as Tesla is continuously working to fix these production issues.   The problem is that once the Model 3 goes mainstream
column40: with a   price tag starting in the mid $30
column42: these are issues that   mainstream consumers won't take as lightly.Furthermore
column43: Tesla recently had aprivate investor call
column44: and it's rumored that the company willskip its beta prototype stage on the Model 3-- typically it goes from alpha prototype to beta prototype to   release candidates -- and will instead go straight to release   candidates. Perhaps Tesla believes its prototype is indeed ready
column45: or perhaps it's rushing to get the vehicle out too early. That's   a risk
column46: no matter how you view it
column47: and a big one because Tesla   needs to get the Model 3 nearly perfect to foster mainstream   adoption.As a company trying to change the automotive industry for the   better
column48: Tesla is easy to root for. Owning shares of Tesla given   the culture and product concerns on the eve of the release of the   critical Model 3 isn't as easy to do
column49: especially as expensive as   shares currently appear. Keep these two concerns in mind --   investors also would be wise to look into Tesla's cash burn
column50: debt   load
column51: and acquisition of SolarCity -- as we navigate through what   could be a make-or-break year for the company.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why Vale SA (ADR) (VALE) Stock Is Still a HUGE Risk;3/22/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOver the last month
column3: several analysts have been telling all who would listen that they need to buy mining stocks. Not just any mining stock
column4: a Brazilian mining stock.Vale SA (ADR)(NYSE:VALE) isthe stock in question.VALE's business is mining coal
column5: iron ore and nickel - the makings of steel. The company produces other metals as byproducts
column6: and mine fertilizer.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockVALE stock closed Mar 21 at $9.44 per share
column7: with a market cap of about $50 billion.With the Brazilian Real trading at 3.15 to the dollar
column8: it produced about $500 million in net income on $8 billion in revenue for its last quarter. Some of the optimism on VALE is based on iron ore prices
column9: which have doubled since June. Some is based on shipping prices for the ore
column10: which have fallen. But there is more to the VALE investment case than that.VALE: Brazil Turning a CornerMore than half of VALE stock is held by agencies of the Brazilian government
column11: which has been convulsed in bribery scandals
column12: and the government is now separating itself from business. Creatinga single class of stockwill water down government influence
column13: although thatmay not be as big a deal as it appears.CEO Murilo Ferreira isgetting the boot in Mayand while new president Michel Temerwill name the replacement
column14: it's expected to be the last time the government calls the tune in this way. Temer's government is said to be more conservative
column15: more pro-business than that of predecessor Dilma Rousseff.10 Clobbered Stocks to Buy That Are About to Get Red-HotBut there's more.VALE produced a record amount of iron ore last year
column16: moving production from southern Brazil to the Amazon
column17: and it will soon re-start production at a mine co-owned withBHP Billiton Limited (ADR)(NYSE:BHP) that suffered a deadly dam burst in 2015.Bymothballing inefficient mines
column18: re-opening the Samarco mine with BHP and increasing production at more-efficient mines
column19: the hope is that VALE stock will get good margins and make fat profits in 2017. By removing government interference from the boardroom
column20: the hope is that Vale shareholders will reap the full benefits.However
column21: as InvestorPlace contributor Ian Bezektook a look at all this recently
column22: he concluded that
column23: while many signs are positive for VALE in the near-term
column24: it's still a Brazilian company.While 3G Capital is also a Brazilian company
column25: the government has no holding in it
column26: as it does in Vale
column27: and the local economy is still mismanaged. A 2016 turnaround for Brazil never materialized
column28: with an unexpected drop in GDP
column29: so trust is at a low ebb.Then there is VALE's debt - about $30 billion worth. That's less than 30% of the company's assets
column30: and it has been heading down in recent years
column31: but the boom-bust cycle for mining stocks makes that debt a significant overhang if something unexpected happens in the iron ore market. The government's continuing role in VALE is why Bezek can't recommend the stock.The Bottom Line on VALE StockVALE
column32: and companies like it
column33: are a big reason why U.S. investors do most of their international buying through mutual funds that take out a big piece of the action each year in the form of fees
column34: but earn those fees by supposedly staying on top of things
column35: and keeping a diversified portfolio.Don't Wait for Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock to Fall Back to EarthInvestors are quickly learning
column36: however
column37: that political risk exists everywhere
column38: and that such risk isn't a question of left or right
column39: but right and wrong. Brazil has been down so long anything looks up from here
column40: and folks like the 3G boys have always made money there regardless of the government
column41: taking advantage of instability and making it their friend.In other words
column42: if you like a little speculation
column43: and you're tired of playing the big techs

column45: which means you're betting here on Trump's ability to whip deflation now.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud

column1: Dont Wait for Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock to Fall Back to Earth;3/22/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsInvestors who have been patiently waiting forTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) stock to come down from its lofty perch to a more familiar support level in a bid to gain fresh entry points could be outta luck. After weeks of drifting lower
column3: TSLA stock has managed to reverse course and is now on a fresh up leg. Tesla stock has racked up gains of 8% over the last 10 days and it is trading just 4% below its 2017 high.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockTSLA stock is up 22.6% in the year-to-date.New Era for TSLA StockTrouble for TSLA stock begun in late February after the company delivered a disappointing earnings report. Following the report
column4: Tesla stock suffered a massive 7% one-day loss that effectively ended a powerful 11-week bull run that had culminated in a 60% gain.The post-earnings breakdown created an ominous top after the stock had retested major resistance near 2014
column5: 2015 and 2017 highs. Long-term Tesla bulls might concur with sentiments by fellow Investor Place contributor Dana Blankenhorn who observes thatTSLA stock has been range-boundover the past three years. Dana says to use $250 as a sell signal or to short the stock and $200 as a buy signal or to go long.But a deeper pullback now looks unlikely. TSLA stock has been showing solid support around the $237 to $241 zone
column6: which suggests that the rules of the game have now changed. Perhaps that should hardly come as a surprise considering that we are now seeing the first innings of Tesla as a mass manufacturer of EVs as opposed to a luxury car maker.7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You BackTSLA stock has mainly been range bound in the past due to the company's unreachable deadlines
column7: including a 3-year delay for Model S.But Tesla is a different company now. The company managed to kick off production of Li-ion batteries at its Gigafactory in January ahead of schedule and also successfully launched a new Autopilot system as promised. TSLA is still very much a startup
column8: but seems to have learned from its past missteps.With the excitement surrounding the launch of Model 3 later in the year
column9: investors should not wait for the stock to fall dramatically even if it misses delivery estimates in the coming quarters.Tesla Stock: Cash Burn Worries a Long Way OffTesla bears have long argued that it's only a matter of time before the company suffered a severe cash crunch that would decimate TSLA stock. Tesla is a serial big-time spender that has been burning cash for fun with little to show for it in the way of profits. The company announced that it plans to spend at least $2.5 billion during the first half of the year to bring its manufacturing facilities up to speed in readiness for Model 3.This in effect means that Tesla will have spent $10 billion on R&D since 2014. For some perspective

column1: Just What Exactly Is SolarCity's Future Under Tesla?;3/22/2017;"SolarCity's transition to a subsidiary ofTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) has been a little strange for the formerly   dominant solar installer. The company is losing market share
column2: shrinking installations
column3: and now has to change its entire sales   model to work with the existing Tesla sales infrastructure.Amid the changes
column4: investors should look at what they can   expect from SolarCity in the years ahead. Whether successful or   not
column5: here's what SolarCity's future looks like under Tesla.Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();A smaller
column6: more focused companyThere's no question that Tesla is changing the solar business   at SolarCity. Installations fell in the fourth quarter of 2016 to201 MW from 253 MW a year ago. Potentially more consequential is that cash sales were 28% of   deployments
column7: up from 4% a year ago.Tesla clearly wants SolarCity to be a company more focused on   profitable installations and cash or loan financing. This will   take a lot of emphasis away from the leasing model that SolarCity   was built on
column8: but it's also a very positive move given industry   trends. What we haven't yet seen is that focus turn into higher   margins.Can solar be an add-on to EVs?The other big strategy change Tesla is making at SolarCity is   the move of the sales process away from cost-intensive   door-to-door and telemarketing strategies to sales through Tesla   stores. In theory
column9: this way
column10: customers would be highly likely to   go solar before coming to SolarCity and solar panels could be an   add-on to an EV.What's unknown is whether that strategy will be successful. We   know that customers who own EVs are more likely to be interested   in and buy solar
column11: but will they do so in the same transaction? Or   will they want to have their EV and solar coming from the same   company? That's the theory
column12: but only time will tell.Will SolarCity ever make money?The challenge for Tesla in folding SolarCity into its business   is to generate enough money to justify the acquisition and   associated debt. In the third quarter of 2016
column13: the final quarter   SolarCity operated as an independent company
column14: SolarCity had   $257.7 million in operating costs
column15: including $204.2 million of   SG&A and R&D expenses. Extrapolated over an entire year
column16: Tesla took on $800 million in annual operating costs that would   need to be paid for somehow.As Tesla transitions to more solar system sales and a larger   energy storage business
column17: we should see revenue and gross margins   be able to cover the operating costs I highlighted. However
column18: make   no mistake
column19: this will not be easy. In the fourth quarter of 2016
column20: the company generated just $131.4 million in energy-related   revenue
column21: which netted a gross margin of just $3.6 million
column22: or   2.7% of revenues.Management said this margin will trend higher toward a 20%-25%   gross margin
column23: but it's hard to see how that happens until   evidence proves it's feasible. Solar panel manufacturers
column24: solar   installers
column25: and battery companies aren't inherently high-margin   businesses and they largely operate in a commodity-type   environment. Even if SolarCity is successful in its new strategy   under Tesla
column26: it may never be the huge financial success that Elon   Musk and investors want it to be. And
column27: at worst

column1: AMD's (AMD) Success Is Not The Death Of Intel (INTC);3/22/2017;"My article on Tuesday
column2: which highlighted (some might say boasted) the recent achievements of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD)
column3: was perceived by some readers as an attack on Intel (INTC). But that was the intent.While Im admittedly an unabashed cheerleader of Intel
column4: I can still appreciate the rags-to-riches story that AMD CEO Lisa Su has successfully executed since her appointment in January 2012. AMD stock traded at $5.40 at the time. The stock recently made a 52-week high of $15.55. Save for the people at AMD headquarters
column5: no one anticipated this remarkable turnaround. But whats good for AMD is also good for Intel since a excitement surrounding chip battles increases consumer interest.Notably
column6: this renewed battle comes even as the rate of PC revenue continues to decline. In other words
column7: both companies
column8: which struggled at the height of the mobile era
column9: have moved beyond being just PC shops. And while AMD continues to make impressive leaps
column10: Intel is still the leader. The extent to which AMD pushes Intel to innovate
column11: the better off Intel will be. And thats exactly what Intel CEO Brian Krzanich has begun to demonstrate.makeArticleAd();Looking to avoid the another mobile-type miss
column12: Intel is pushing heavily to be future-ready. Fresh off its second mega-deal in less than two years
column13: Krzanich  in his fifth year at the helm  seems intent on putting Intels cash to use. The companys$15.3 billion acquisitionof Israeli self-driving technology company Mobileye (MBLY) was the most recent example. This follows $16.7 billion deal for Altera back in 2015.These two deals suggest that Intel is not worried about what AMD is doing. It can be argued that it should. But Krzanich
column14: who has found ways to get Intels top line growing again
column15: has shown to have a good pulse on what the company needs. Not only does Intel
column16: thanks to Altera
column17: now have an inside track on the Internet of Things and data center market
column18: Mobileye now puts Intel in the driver's seat in the realm of autonomous cars
column19: allowing it to better compete with Tesla (TSLA) and Google (GOOGL).In both acquisitions
column20: however
column21: market pundits
column22: who were unable to immediately see the financial benefits
column23: criticize Intel for overpaying. But
column24: recall
column25: Google was laughed at for buying YouTube in 2006 for $1.65 billion. Today YouTube is worth anestimated $40 billiontoday. Likewise
column26: Facebook (FB) was criticized for taking out Instagram. But assuming Intel can realize the estimated $70 billion total addressable market of driverless cars by 2030
column27: Mobileye could prove to be a bargain.In short
column28: AMDs improvements dont spell the doom of Intel. The management of both companies are executing on their stated operating objectives. And both stocks should perform well in the next 12 to 18 months. As to which stock is right for you? That all depends on where your allegiance is."

column1: Should Facebook Inc Just Buy Snap Inc.?;3/21/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhenFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) first tried to buy Snapchat for $3 billion in 2013
column3: many pundits thoughtSnap Inc.(NYSE:SNAP) should have agreed to the offer. Of course
column4: failing to make the deal hasn't hurt FB stock
column5: and SNAP - which has a $23.2 billion market cap - probably doesn't mind either.makeArticleAd();If Facebook wanted to do the deal now
column6: though
column7: it would be an incredibly expensive acquisition - the biggest in Facebook's 13-year history
column8: even bigger thanWhatsAppin 2014.But it would move a major competitor from the field of battle.Do the positives of getting rid of an irritating competitor help Facebook stock and outweigh the fact that FB would be paying eight to 10 times what it offered SNAP back in 2013?The answer to that question isn't nearly as obvious as investors might think. It really depends on why Facebook wanted Snapchat back in 2013  and why it would want it today.Facebook and Snapchat: A Brief HistoryWhen Facebook first approached Snapchat co-founder Evan Spiegel in late 2012
column9: it was
column10: according to Spiegel
column11: to scare him and co-founder Bobby Ryan into selling. Spiegel toldForbesin a 2014 cover-story profile that Mark Zuckerberg warned them: Facebook was going to release its own photo app called Facebook Poke that would blow Snapchat out of the water.10 Clobbered Stocks to Buy That Are About to Get Red-HotThat didn't happen. In fact
column12: Facebook Poke was an unmitigated disaster.Zuckerberg wanted to buy Snapchat to strengthen its teenage audience
column13: which was slowly drifting away from Facebook. Something like 26% of American kids aged 18-29 was using Snapchat at the time - a remarkably high capture rate in this all-important demographic.Snapchat's co-founders could smell fear on the part of Zuckerberg
column14: but also an opportunity. It's not unlike Zuckerberg saying no to any number of offers over the years for Facebook
column15: several at more than $1 billion during a time when the social media giant didn't have much revenue.Flash forward to the present.Should Facebook Make a Move?Analysts believe that Facebook could still make an offer for Snap despite the fact its valuation is now much more expensive than in 2013. That's because little has changed when it comes to Facebook's glaring weakness: people under the age of 30.""One of the key points that the bears on SNAP may be missing is that we believe that FB would love to acquire the company
column16: and it could be willing to pay at least $20B+ ($14/share) for the asset."" wrote FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi March 9
column17: initiating coverage of the recent IPO. ""Remember that FB paid $21.8B for WhatsApp
column18: a company which
column19: although it had more users than SNAP
column20: was not generating any real revenue.""More importantly
column21: the analyst goes on to remind investors
column22: is that buying Snapchat at the current inflated valuation would eliminate a significant threat to its business. It's the old addition by subtraction argument.And why not?Facebook has $29.4 billion in cash and marketable securities and no debt. It has introduced four different Snapchat clones in the past two years;the latest being Messenger Day
column23: which is thought by social media experts to be a blatant ripoff of Snapchat Stories.The biggest problem for Facebook is finding new places to display ads other than on its flagship app
column24: which is close to capacity. Copycat or not
column25: monetizing its Messenger app would deliver much-needed revenue growth at a time when FB stock really needs to provide investors with some light at the end of the monetization tunnel.So
column26: the question Facebook has to ask itself is whether its internal efforts to copy Snapchat are enough to match or exceed Snap Inc.'s future revenues. If 100% certain that they are
column27: buying Snapchat at any price would be a waste of money.Apple Inc. Launches New Red iPhone 7
column28: New iPadHowever
column29: if the answer is no or Facebook doesn't have a definitive answer
column30: then it's a resounding yes.Bottom Line on FB StockEither way
column31: if you own FB stock
column32: I don't think you should be selling anytime soon regardless of what Facebook decides.My inclination would be to wait and see what happens at Snapchat. After all
column33: it currently doesn't make any money and should things not go as planned over the next 12-24 months
column34: Facebook would be able to buy it for much less at that time.Besides
column35: the guys at Snapchat already said no once. It would be really embarrassing if they said no a second time
column36: given the dollars Facebook would be throwing at them.As of this writing

column1: Cooper Tire & Rubber Co (CTB) Stock Is A Classic Mid-Cap Value;3/21/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFor the past three years
column3: I've driven an SUV and a pickup. I got an unbelievable deal on the pickup (I always buy used)
column4: but it needed new tires.makeArticleAd();When I took the truck to the friendly neighborhood tire guys to replace them with similar all-terrain tires
column5: I then understood why they were so friendly and why the truck was such a good deal. Ouch.I'm not alone. Currently
column6: light trucks and SUVs represent 63% of 2016's record year for U.S. vehicle sales
column7: which came in at 17.55 million. Three years ago
column8: the truck and SUV share of auto sales was right at 50%.As far as cars on the road in the United States
column9: the average age of a vehicle in the light truck/SUV category is around 6.1 years. Eventually
column10: tens of millions of tires will be replaced to the tune of $800 to $1
column11: 400 a set.That's why I'm looking atCooper Tire and Rubber Company(NYSE:CTB).Cooper is the number five tire manufacturer in North America and number twelve worldwide
column12: with 2016 sales of $2.92 billion. Why do I want to buy the middle of the pack? First
column13: the stock is a genuine value with attractive internal metrics that position it for price appreciation. Second
column14: the company makes an attractive takeover target.The valuation metrics make a compelling case on their own. Currently
column15: the stock trades with a forward P/E of 11.45
column16: a 37% discount to the S&P 500 on a forward P/E basis. When pundits complain that there's no real value in the current market
column17: they'll get no sympathy. You can ALWAYS find value versus the benchmark!The internal numbers are just as intriguing. Price-to-sales sits at an undervalued 0.8. Long-term debt-to-capitalization is at a comfortable 28.8% - not bad for an industrial manufacturer. The most impressive number
column18: however
column19: is the return on equity (ROE) of 24.17%. Historically
column20: analysts consider a consistent ROE of 15-20% attractive. Cooper Tire regularly beats that average by 20%.Going forward
column21: the company expects to grow sales at an average annual rate of 6.5% over the next two years. The best opportunity to do this lies with the company's international efforts. A full 85% of Cooper's annual sales are from North America. Clearly
column22: emerging markets in Asia and Latin America will be the key drivers.The attractive metrics are also what make Cooper an acquisition candidateAfter the company's failed merger with British tire maker Apollo Tyre in 2013
column23: the most likely suitor would be Germany'sContinental AG (ADR)(OTCMKTS:CTTAY). AReutersstory from October 2016 alluded to Continental's interest in acquiring market share in the replacement tire market.While Continental holds the number four spot globally for tire manufacturers
column24: Continental and Cooper both hold a 7% share of the North American market. Continental's $40.2 billion market makes a $2.2 billion acquisition of Cooper Tire an easy hurdle to clear and a relatively cheap path to doubling share in the all-important North American market.Risks To Consider:The largest risk Cooper faces is its thin share of its primary market. It's ability to grow share organically hampered by its mid-cap status in the face of its large cap peers. However
column25: management has faced this challenge through successful execution and keeping the balance sheet healthy.Action To Take:As a standalone investment
column26: CTB shares are classic mid-cap value. The company chugs along
column27: executes dependably
column28: and has paid a dividend for 180 consecutive quarters (that's 45 years in civilian talk). The company is equally attractive as a takeover target for a larger
column29: international manufacturer looking to grow North American market share.3 Ways Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Can Reach $500 and BeyondThe stock currently trades around $43 with a forward P/E of 11.45 and a dividend yield just shy of 1%. Based on management's consistent track record
column30: a 12-month price target of $50 is reasonable. A takeover target price is a bit more difficult to determine. However
column31: my conservative guess would be a premium of 20-25% over the current price. Either way
column32: investors are poised to benefit.Editor's Note:This isthe most boring chartyou'll see all year. It's not production or consumption. It's not imports or exports. It's not any economic statistic at all. It's simply how much money this program has been piling up since we launched it seven years ago.Go here to see if it's for you.StreetAuthority's mission is to help individual investors earn above-average profits by providing a source of independent
column33: unbiased - and most of all
column34: profitable - investing ideas. Unlike traditional publishers
column35: StreetAuthority doesn't simply regurgitate the latest stock market news. Instead
column36: we provide in-depth research
column37: plus specific investment ideas and immediate action to take based on the latest market events. Visit us atStreetAuthority.com.More From InvestorPlace7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Flush With CashThe 10 Best Stock Charts on Wall Street Right NowThe postCooper Tire & Rubber Co (CTB) Stock Is A Classic Mid-Cap Valueappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column7: Tesla said it expects to   deliver 47
column9: 000 Model S and Model X vehicles combined
column10: up 62% to 72% compared to same period in 2016.Investors also know that Tesla ended its fourth quarter with a   record 6
column11: 450 vehicles in transit to customers
column12: setting the   company up for a strong start to the quarter. Tesla also said   demand for its vehicles is looking up; orders for the Model S and   Model X combined were up 49% year over year and were 24% higher   than any other quarter
column13: management said.But even this information still leaves lots of room for   guesswork since quarterly deliveries can also be influenced by   the timing of shipments to different regions
column14: as well as by   production challenges. The best ballpark figure investors can   arrive at for estimating Model S and Model X deliveries in the   first quarter
column15: therefore
column16: is one that simply cuts Tesla's   forecast for the first half of the year in half. Assuming Tesla   delivers half of its 47
column18: 000 estimated units for the   first half of the year in Q1

column21: 000   deliveries during the quarter -- up from 22
column22: 252 deliveries in the   fourth quarter of 2016 and 14
column23: 820 units in the first quarter of   2016.Investors should look for Tesla's first-quarter deliveries to   be between about 23
column25: 000. But since this estimate is   extrapolated from guidance for a broader period
column26: investors   shouldn't be surprised if actual deliveries deviate from this   estimate. If deliveries do come in below or above this level
column27: investors may want to look into a reason for the variance.Look for an update on demandBeyond Tesla's reported deliveries in its upcoming update
column28: which is usually released within three calendar days of the   quarter's close (anywhere between April 1 and April 3)
column29: investors   may want to look for an update on demand for Model S and Model   X.Model 3. Image source: Tesla.In Tesla's quarterly update on deliveries
column30: the company has   recently been sharing data for orders of the two vehicles. In its   update on fourth-quarter deliveries
column31: for instance
column32: investors   learned that Model S and Model X deliveries were increasing   sharply year over year and were at an all-time high.A look at demand levels for Model S and Model X during the   first quarter would be timely since Tesla is preparing to bring   to market its $35

column34: there's good reason to be concerned about Model 3   cannibalizing sales of Tesla's two older

column1: 3 Stocks to Buy Because of Their Eccentric CEOs;3/20/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhen deciding which stocks to add to your portfolio
column3: it's important to assess things like a company's financials
column4: its growth plans and who its competitors are.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrHowever
column5: most investors also put a lot of stake into a company's upper management because they are
column6: after all
column7: the ones calling the shots. CEOs have a lot of sway over a company's future
column8: so many investors keep a close eye on who is at the helm and how they're impacting the firm's bottom line.The management style of a firm's CEO is an important factor in its success and while calm
column9: cool and collected tends to be the most desirable trait to investors
column10: there are a few eccentric CEOs that are just crazy enough to make things work.10 Clobbered Stocks to Buy That Are About to Get Red-HotElon Musk ofTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA)
column11: Jeff Bezos ofAmazon.com
column12: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) and Michael O'Leary ofRyanair Holdings plc (ADR)(NASDAQ:RYAAY) are three such CEOs whose out-of-the-box personalities have brought their respective firms a great deal of success.Eccentric CEOs: Elon Musk
column13: Tesla Inc (TSLA)As CEO and founder of electric car company Tesla
column14: Elon Musk
column15: is one of the first people that comes to mind when thinking about mega-successful eccentric CEOs.Musk is well known using colorful language and not shying away from speaking his mind
column16: especially when it comes to talking about competitors. However
column17: while Mr. Musk can sometimes becontroversial
column18: you've got to give it to him for thinking big and executing those plans. His decision to create a TSLA Gigafactory in Nevada appears to be paying off.According to Musk
column19: Tesla is on-track to build 500
column20: 000 new vehicles in 2018.Eccentric CEOs: Jeff Bezos
column21: Amazon.com
column22: Inc. (AMZN)Jeff Bezos is the CEO and founder of e-commerce giant Amazon and although he flies a bit further under the radar than Musk
column23: he still found himself at the center of controversy when the corporate culture at AMZN came under fire last year.Former employees claimed that intense pressure and competition made their working environment unbearable
column24: but Bezosshot backsaying that his firm's culture promotes risk-taking and sets high standards
column25: which is a key reason why Amazon has been so successful.7 Small-Cap Tech Stocks on the Cutting EdgeWhether you agree with the way AMZN treats its employees
column26: you've got to admit that whatever they're doing over there
column27: it's working. Amazon has created an undeniably exceptional service that has hooked millions of people. The company's continued expansion and innovation makes Amazon an attractive stock to buy and hold and Bezos' high expectations should give shareholders confidence in the company's future.Eccentric CEOs: Michael O'Leary
column28: Ryanair Holdings plc (ADR) (RYAAY)Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary is perhaps one of the most polarizing CEOs on the planet. You either loathe or love his outlandish remarks and no-holds-barred comments
column29: and I fall in the latter camp.O'Leary doesn't shy away from having an opinion and he has always been upfront about RYAAY's mission - safety and profits
column30: profits
column31: profits. While many have criticized his intensecost-cutting measures
column32: the airline has become synonymous with low-cost flights. O'Leary's willingness to speak unfiltered to the press has given the airline a lot of free publicity.RYAAY has done well because of that- the company was able to thrive despite a financial crisis in Europe and has grown to become one of the largest airlines in the world. The company's profits have been nothing short of impressive over the last few quarters
column33: and although the impact of the Brexit is likely to take its toll
column34: RYAAY is likely to weather this storm successfully.Love him or hate him
column35: O'Leary delivers for shareholders and his flamboyant remarks are constantly generating buzz for Ryanair.As of this writing
column36: Laura Hoy was long RYAAY and AMZN.The post3 Stocks to Buy Because of Their Eccentric CEOsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column3: that's the word according to Iou1000
column4: a message board participant at Seeking Alpha. ""Again the shorts need a bear [market] or something untoward happening to Elon Musk to make money - Otherwise Tesla will make a new high on the way to 500

column6: 2017.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Lau via Flickr (Modified)TSLA stock closed trading Mar. 17 at $261.50

column8: halfway to a G-note. Assuming the prediction is on the money - when does it get there
column9: and more importantly
column10: how?There are three answers to this question
column11: in my opinion
column12: the first being the best option for TSLA stock blowing past $500 on its way to $1
column13: 000.TSLA Needs to Be ProfitableIt's a simple concept but one that investors have grappled with since TSLA stock startedtradingon June 29
column14: 2010. Since then
column15: it has amassed $2.4 billion in operating losses and $17 billion in revenue. That's an average of $343 million in annual operating losses and $2.4 billion in annual revenue for a 14.2% negative operating margin.It has never made money on an annual basis

column1: Tesla Inc.'s Capital Expenditures Could Soar Nearly 200% This Year;3/18/2017;"On Thursday
column2: electric-car companyTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) followed through on CEO Elon Musk's recent   commentary regarding a likelycapital raise to reduce riskassociated with rapidly increasing spending for its ambitious   growth plans. column3: it's a good time to take a look at how much the   company's capital expenditures could go up this year.Tesla vehicle production. Image source: Author.makeArticleAd();Big plans

column7: 000 units today   to a whopping 500

column9: Tesla expects capital spending during the first half of the   year to rise sharply as it lays the groundwork for production.   Management guided for $2 billion to $2.5 billion in capital   expenditures in the first half of the year alone -- an amount   that easily trumps the $1.3 billion it spent during the entire   year of 2016 on capital expenditures.What about the second half of the year? While Tesla didn't   provide guidance for expected capital expenditures then

column1: Business Model Innovation Will Help Make Make Energy Storage Work;3/18/2017;"Energy storage is coming to closer to a reality for hundreds   of thousands of residential energy customers
column2: and we still don't   know how companies are going to sell it to them. A battery system   could be purchased or leased
column3: and a customer could make money off   it through a revenue-sharing program
column4: or some kind of service   model that maximized its value to customers. If you look back to   2010
column5: when the residential solar market was in a similar   position
column6: it was the business model that separated the winners   from the crowd. And it was companies offering leases to customers   on a large scale who were early winners.We do know that residential energy storage is expected to be a   multibillion-dollar business by the end of the decade
column7: we just   don't know what business model will work for energy storage   companies. And whoever can get the business model right will be   in a nice position for investors.Tesla's Powerwall on a home. Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();The national installer modelA number of companies are trying to leverage their residential   solar footprint to expand into energy storage.Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) is the largest of these after its acquisition of   SolarCity
column8: andSunrun(NASDAQ: RUN) is another player worth watching.Tesla's early Powerwall models were sold directly to customers   with the main justification being backup power. But as costs come   down and rate structures with demand charges or time-of-use rates   become more common
column9: we'll see more financial justification for   energy storage
column10: and new business models will open up.National installers will also likely try to fold energy   storage into a long-term energy contract for consumers. Sunrun is   doing this with its Brightbox lease
column11: which matches its focus on   solar leases. Marrying the two together could keep the lease   alive and give national installers new life.The dealer energy storage modelI should also note that national installers are losing market   share because the lease is quickly losing popularity. I think   that will lead to a service-oriented dealer model opening up.SunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR) is an example of a company who uses dealers
column12: providing equipment and services
column13: but leaning on the dealer to   complete sales and perform installations.In energy storage
column14: SunPower may provide a pre-engineered   solution that plugs directly into its solar systems as well as   financing and some sort of value-generation model. A customer may   buy the energy storage system and then share the revenue   generated with SunPower. It may lease and share value
column15: similar to   the national installer model I outlined above. Or it may just   sell the system and provide the algorithm that controls the   system for a fee.The third-party energy storage modelOne growing model is having energy storage as a stand-alone   service
column16: not tied to a solar system's financing. Sonnen is one of   the industry leaders in Germany
column17: where energy storage has been   viable for years now
column18: and is moving quickly to grow in the U.S.   as well. In total
column19: the company has installed over 10
column20: 000 energy   storage systems around the world.Sonnen's system is designed to work with a solar system in the   U.S.
column21: but it wouldn't necessarily have to be combined with solar.   Sonnen can even aggregate excess energy from a community energy   program
column22: effectively creating an energy sharing program.Buying solar and energy storage separately is what's normally   done in commercial solar
column23: with companies like Stem taking the   lead on energy storage and only having an adjacent involvement   with solar. This model could potentially make sense as a business   model in the residential market as well
column24: although it would be a   harder sell than marrying up with a solar system.What we know energy storage needsYou may notice that all of the models I outlined above have a   large company behind the scenes pulling the strings
column25: and that's   important. A small company doesn't have the scale to build the   algorithms needed to know when charging and discharging an energy   storage system would generate the most value. And in different   states and areas under different utilities with different rate   structures
column26: the decision-making process would be different.   Companies need scale and the ability to control thousands of   energy storage systems to aggregate the value.While big players may be power brokers behind the scenes
column27: it's   still not clear how the model will interact with customers. The   solar market is moving toward more cash and loan sales and away   from leases from national installers
column28: so that's worth keeping in   mind if energy storage is tied directly to solar. But the need   for a large company to generate value from energy storage may   pull large companies back into the mix
column29: whether that's   manufacturers
column30: or on the installation side.Whoever can get this formula right will have a huge market   ahead of them. And the energy storage market is coming quickly   and may open up a lot faster than investors think.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Go Long the Super Story In Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock;3/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI recently shared winning trades inTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA). The most recent was along TLSA upsidetrade

column4: so I now need to reset another.makeArticleAd();Source: Tesla MotorsThe financial fundamental story in TSLA almost doesn't matter. column10: TSLA stock is a bad short idea. Bears cannot disprove the upside story in Tesla's claims. They are concepts with long-term milestones. This usually creates a negative headline vacuum
column11: levitating the stock. Elon Musk also publicly recommitted to staying there for the long term
column12: so that risk is low too.Click to EnlargeNot all TSLA stock fans will buy it at the same level; hence the chop in its price action. I have been successful in selling risk behind lines where most Tesla bulls would buy. Today I look to repeat performance

I need Tesla stock to stay above my sold put - otherwise I am committed to buying shares at $145 even if it falls much lower.For a less aggressive stance

column2: Inc. Raises $1.2 Billion in Offerings;3/17/2017;"Electric-car makerTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) priced its concurrent stock and convertible note   offerings last night
column3: and the total capital raised came in at   $1.2 billion
column4: slightly higher than the $1.15 billion that Tesla   had previously expected even after a 15% underwriter option. That   $1.2 billion is the gross amount raised before factoring in   underwriting discounts and other costs associated with the   offering
column5: some of which are not insignificant.The total amount raised could climb to $1.4 billion if   underwriters exercise all options. We'll find out in a few days   if they do or not.Tesla factory in Fremont. Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();The equityIn terms of the common stock offering
column6: it was priced at $262   and Tesla ended up selling 1.33 million shares
column7: compared to the   969
column8: 000 it initially planned to sell. Underwriters still have   options to purchase another 200
column9: 000 shares on top of that if   investor demand is there. The net proceeds to Tesla after the   underwriting discount are about $348 million. That puts the   dilutive impact of the stock offering at 0.8% -- rather   minimal.The stock offering is pretty straightforward
column10: while the   convertible note offering is where things get a little bit more   interesting and complicated.The convertibles are pricing in more riskThe convertible notes due 2022 ended up pricing at a 2.375%   coupon rate
column11: with an aggregate principal amount of $850 million
column12: up from the prior expectation of $750 million. The net proceeds   to Tesla will be $840 million after the underwriting discount.   The notes will have a conversion price of $327.50
column13: which   represents a conversion premium of 25% compared to current   levels.Compare those figures to Tesla's last convertible note   offering from 2014 (underwriters exercised their options in full   on that offering).MaturityPrincipal AmountInterest RateConversion Premium2019$920 million0.25%42.5%2021$1.38 billion1.25%42.5%Data source: SEC filings.The higher interest rate and lower conversion premium   associated with the current offering show that the market is   pricing in more risk associated with these notes. It's possible   this is related to the recent acquisition of SolarCity
column14: since the   deal weakened Tesla's balance sheet
column15: as it assumed quite a bit of   its sister company's debt; Tesla had $2.7 billion in total   long-term debt and capital leases at the end of Q3
column16: which jumped   to $6.8 billion at the end of Q4 after closing on SolarCity (not   including solar bonds).Additionally
column17: Tesla is entering into hedge and warrant   transactions to offset and mitigate any potential dilution should   the notes be converted. But these transactions areexpensive. Tesla says it expects to spend $131.5 million of the note   proceeds to cover the costs of these hedges
column18: which will only be   partially offset from proceeds from the warrant transactions.   That's a high price to pay
column19: but the alternative is for   shareholders to face even greater potential dilution if shares   exceed the conversion price of $327.50.In other words
column20: Tesla is spending about 15% of the net   proceeds from these notes on the related hedges
column21: so it will only   collect about $708.5 million.Model 3 production is only four months awayIf we add up the net expected proceeds from both offerings
column22: after deducting the hedge expenses but before the possibility of   underwriters exercising their options
column23: Tesla will add $1.06   billion to its coffers to help reduce risk ahead of Model 3
column24: which covers a good chunk of the $2 billion to $2.5 billion in   capital expenditures that are planned for the new vehicle. With   Model 3 still on track for production to begin in July

column1: Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock: Your Time Is Running Out;3/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) was a niche player in its early days
column3: focusing on graphic processing units (GPUs)
column4: or graphics cards. That was way back when
column5: before several NVDA stock splits.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIn the early days
column6: there were big players likeIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC)
column7: Advanced Micro Devices
column8: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD) andTaiwan Semiconductor Mfg. Co. Ltd. (ADR)(NYSE:TSM) that all made chip sets for GPUs. And they still do.But Nvidia madereally high-endGPUs. Gamers loved them. Research labs and universities loved them. NVDA carved out a solid business but was never given much attention since it was a niche and no matter how many geeks bought its GPUs
column9: it wasn't going to be a major player by dominating that sector.Nvidia then did what successful
column10: out-of-the-box companies do. It looked out years in the future and decided to set a course to a new industry - visual computing.9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonIt bet that as computers got faster and broadband delivered more information faster
column11: that visual computing would become a major part of computing for decades to come. And NVDA was right.Now
column12: the market cap for NVDA stock is bigger than all but the biggest players in the market - INTC andTexas Instruments Incorporated(NASDAQ:TXN). Because its tech is so advanced
column13: it also has partnered with a number of companies to add their components into devices and machines built for others. It's like car companies that feature a premium sound system or designer interior.It now looks like NVDA'snewest GPU is now on track to steal AMD's GPU's lunch. Also
column14: its GPUs were selected to be in the newestNintendo Co.
column15: Ltd. (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NTDOY) gaming devices. And both of these come on the heels of a very bullish Q4 and full year earnings report for NVDA.Oddly enough
column16: the stock sold off on the release
column17: which is certainly a ""buy the rumor
column18: sell the news"" kind of thing
column19: because there was no reason for the selloff. And even after the selloff

column1: 3 Reasons to Love Abbott Laboratories (ABT) Stock;3/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAbbott Laboratories(NYSE:ABT) is up 17% up so far this year and is beginning to look more like its old self. From early 2011 to the middle of 2015
column3: ABT stock expanded from just $22 per share to over $50. Since that high
column4: Abbott has been going sideways. The current run leaves Abbott at its highest point since the mid-2015 peak.makeArticleAd();Source:Open Grid Scheduler Via FlickrWhile some analysts believe Abbott stock is going to cool-off because of its recent run
column5: I believe in its prospects going forward.Abbott has an impressively diverse portfolio
column6: solid growth on tap and an enviable dividend history.Here are three reasons why you should still pursue Abbott Laboratories as astock to buy
column7: even with the gains it's already booked this year.ABT Has Strong Sales GrowthAbbott has a wide-ranging healthcare portfolio full of names consumers and medical experts alike are quite familiar with. Heard of Pedialyte and Pediasure? That's Abbott. Need generic pharmaceuticals for hypothyroidism or  Mnire's disease? Abbott. Need a vaccine for the flu? Abbott. That strong portfolio is one driver of growth for the company.7 Dividend Stocks With Yields That Grow Like WeedsWhile earnings have shrunk by 15% annually over the last half-decade
column8: a double-digit annual expansion is expected for the five years looking forward. Sales growth is in part to thank - this year
column9: sales are expected to expand by 25%.Abbott Is Acquisition SavvyThat sales growth is in part thanks to Abbott's recent acquisition of St. Jude Medical
column10: a medical device company that further rounds out the healthcare giant's portfolio. According to the company's most recent earnings release
column11: Abbott now holds the first or second positions across several cardiovascular device areas.Abbott also recently announced that it willnotfollow through on its acquisition of Alere. I like the fact that Abbott is willing to pivot in the face of what it sees as eroding value
column12: and believe certainty around the acquisition (okay
column13: well
column14: the lack thereof) is good for investor morale.ABT Stock DividendIn addition to offering organic growth
column15: Abbott also rewards loyal investors with a dividend. The company has paid a dividend for 373 straight quarters - a streak that dates back almost a century! On top of that
column16: it's increased the payout for 45 straight years.As the company noted on its website
column17: that makes Abbott a member of theS&P 500 Dividend Aristocrats Index
column18: which tracks companies that have annually increased their dividend for 25 consecutive years.A Tesla Inc (TSLA) Cash Raise Gets ... A Hero's Welcome?That gives ABT stock a yield north of 2.3% even in the wake of its recent run. You can bet that yield will grow with more increases.Abbott stock's run so far this year is a solid base for further gains. While the 2015 peak may serve as resistance down the line
column19: I think it will be easy climb until that point.Hilary Kramer is the editor ofGameChangers

column1: Better Buy: Tesla vs. BMW;3/17/2017;"In the high-end performance segment of the auto industry
column2: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) andBMW(NASDAQOTH: BAMXF) are two of the best brands and most innovative   manufacturers in the world. BMW has long been an aspirational   brand focused on high performance with a level of luxury that   consumers demand when spending upward of $100
column3: 000 on a vehicle.   Tesla is breaking all of the rules of the auto industry and is   growing its fleet of electric vehicles.But investors have to balance growth with performance and   value in a stock. And with BMW and Tesla
column4: those factors collide   amid a passionate debate about the future of the auto   industry.The electric BMW i3. Image source: BMW.makeArticleAd();The known commodityBMW is the better-known company of these two
column5: having sold 2.37   million vehicles in 2016 and generated 6.9 billion euros in net   income for the year. Its EBIT (earnings before interest and   taxes) margin of 8.9% is among the industry's best
column6: and   management has guided for 8% to 10% EBIT margin through 2020.What BMW brings from a manufacturing and quality standpoint is   extremely valuable
column7: even though those are less tangible factors   than financial results. The company has decades of   manufacturing expertise and has been able to generate strong   margins while staying at the forefront of new technologies like   carbon fiber
column8: autonomous driving
column9: and electric vehicles (EVs).   It's even launched a ride-sharing product in Seattle
column10: with   Portland (Oregon) and Brooklyn expected to follow.The advantage investors have with BMW is knowing that it can   execute on its automotive manufacturing plans and having   confidence in its ability to follow industry trends where they're   headed. With EVs clearly growing as a percentage of auto sales   around the world
column11: BMW can learn and adapt to where the market is   going. But it'll be able to follow upstarts like Tesla as they   grow the market rather than being on the bleeding edge of a new   industry.Tesla's Model S with the first Powerwall. Image source:     Tesla.The upstart with a lot of unknowns aheadTesla has gotten the most attention of any EV company
column12: and for   good reason. It's pushing the envelope
column13: and its EV-only business   model seems to be the most effective way to build a viable EV   brand. And with energy storage and solar power under its wing
column14: the company has broad and diverse exposure to renewable   energy.All of that growth comes at a cost
column15: though
column16: with Tesla   spending $1.28 billion on capital expenditures in 2016. Goldman   Sachs recently predicted that 2017 capital expenditures would be   $3 billion to build out capacity to build the Model 3 and ramp up   to capacity for 500
column17: 000 vehicles in 2018. Plus
column18: the company needs   to fund raw materials for building out the Model 3.The allure of growth is intoxicating
column19: but it comes at high   risk as well. Analysts already expect Tesla will need to   raise capital in coming months to fund its growth plans. And the   company certainly needs to improve quality and its parts supply   chain just to match competitors (for evidence of this
column20: read   fellow Fool Evan Niu's saga abouttrying to get his Model S repaired). Improving manufacturing quality and building out an   international parts supply chain is no small task
column21: and it's   something Tesla has never done
column22: so it's an unknown for the   company and leaves a lot of uncertainty for investors.Tesla's products are well liked by early adopters
column23: but   still haven't been tested by the masses. While BMW sold over 2   million vehicles last year
column24: Tesla has only sold about one-tenth   that figure in its nearly 14-year history. Translating hype to   operational success could prove harder than Tesla can handle.Why it's hard to pay up for potential in the auto   industryGiven the unknowns facing Tesla
column25: it's hard to justify paying   10 times the price-to-sales ratio investors are getting with BMW.   And keep in mind that Tesla would have had to increase deliveries   by 31 times just to match BMW in 2016.BAMXF Market Capdata byYCharts.Maybe the more fundamental question is whether or not the auto   industry
column26: and big players like BMW
column27: will be able to adapt to   Tesla if the latter's success continues. And I'll point out that   progress in the auto industry is extremely slow. Tesla seems like   an upstart
column28: but it's nearly 14 years old and is still making   fewer than 100
column29: 000 vehicles per year. That's not much of a track   record
column30: no matter how good the company's brand is
column31: and I think   automakers will quickly be able to catch Tesla in the EV   market.The fact that investors have to pay a massive premium to own   Tesla's shares is the main reason I think BMW is the better stock   to own today. There's more stability

column1: Auto Stock Roundup: Trump Plans Raise Hope; Ford, Honda Reveal Expansion Strategies;3/16/2017;"Last week was quite a positive one for automakers
column2: with the performance of most stocks reflecting the same. President Donald Trump extended support to auto manufacturers and suggested measures to invigorate growth.While Honda MotorsHMCannounced investment plans
column3: Tesla
column4: Inc.TSLArevealed plans to raise $1.1 billion capital before beginning of the Model 3 production.Ford Motor CompanyFexpanded its vehicle electrification program and Harley-Davidson
column5: Inc.HOGlaunched a new motorcycle that could help the company to break out of its niche market.(Read the previous roundup here:Auto Stock Roundup for Mar 9
column6: 2017)Recap of the Week's Most Important Stories1. Trump announced his decision to reopen the mid-term review of the agreement signed regarding the U.S. vehicle fuel-efficiency standards
column7: after extensive lobbying by automakers. Moreover
column8: he also stated that his administration would focus on the elimination of regulations that negatively impact industry growth as well as lower taxes to promote job creation.Additionally
column9: he ensured to keep in place regulations that would protect the union workers' jobs and auto factories
column10: promising promotion of growth in the auto sector. Trump will also be reviewing trade deals
column11: particularly NAFTA
column12: that he believes has been adversely affecting the U.S. auto industry and its workers. (Read More:Are Automakers Poised to Grow Under Trump's Presidency?)2. Honda announced plans of investing $150 million in two of its U.S. facilities. The investment will be utilized for the production of 10-speed automatic transmissions. These transmissions will then be installed in front-wheel-drive vehicles. (Read More:Honda to Invest $150M in US Plants for 10-Speed Transmission)Honda carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 (Strong   Buy) Rank stocks here.3. Tesla announced plans to raise $1.1 billion through a series of offerings. The company will offer roughly $250 million worth common stocks along with senior convertible notes worth $750 million due in 2022. Tesla aims to raise this capital to strengthen its balance sheet as well as lower risks related to the swift scaling of its business with the upcoming launch of Model 3. The company aims to begin Model 3 deliveries by the end of 2017.Tesla carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).4. Ford announced plans to expand its Advanced Fuel Qualified Vehicle Modifier (QVM) program. The new program
column13: eQVM
column14: will include companies which will develop and install electrified as well as hydraulic hybrid powertrains for Ford trucks and vans. The program is set to begin will three new companies that will modify a range of the company's vehicles. Ford plans to invest $4.5 billion over the next five years in 13 new electrified vehicles. (Read More:Ford Expands Commercial Vehicles Electrification Program)Additionally
column15: Ford's subsidiary
column16: Lincoln Motor Co.

column18: into the world's largest auto market

column1: Why Are Chipmakers So Interested in Autonomous Cars?;3/16/2017;"It's the same reason that automakers are interested in the market. Although for them
column2: it's also a question of preventing tech companies from encroaching on their turf. There doesn't seem to be any likelihood of such encroachment however
column3: at least in the near future
column4: as there is too much to making a car that's just too far from what tech companies do best. So the first fully-autonomous cars that make it to the market will most likely be a collaborative effort between auto makers and tech companies.The primary selling point for self-driving cars is increased safety due to fewer accidents. There has been some research suggesting that when computers take over the roads
column5: they will remove the chances of accidents due to human error (for sleep
column6: distraction
column7: intoxication
column8: carelessness
column9: brake failure or other mechanical problems
column10: or when it's the other guy's fault
column11: or any other reason). And of course this is what is broadly propounded by the companies invested in the phenomenon. Kathy Winter
column12: the VP and general manager of the automated driving division at IntelINTCthinks that it will also help create logistics solutions for transportation and delivery of products.But don't expect a sudden jump from driven to driverless cars. It's more likely that cars will increasingly incorporate features that automate certain functions over time
column13: making them semi-automated to varying degrees. Regulatory and insurance considerations will also likely require the presence of a driver long after cars become fully-automated.The Institute of Transportation Studies at University of California
column14: recently conducted a survey of forty experts including policymakers
column15: researchers
column16: government representatives
column17: nonprofit organizations and tech companies
column18: presenting the results in a report titled ""3 Revolutions: Sharing
column19: Electrification
column20: and Automation."" The chief findings were as follows:70% of survey participants think fully driverless vehicles   will account for more than 20% of vehicles sold by 2040.88% think commercially offered shared rides will make up more   than 5% of all U.S. passenger miles by 2030
column21: and 78% think   commercially offered shared rides will account for more than 20%   of U.S. passenger miles traveled by 2040.70% also think that by 2050
column22: the majority of vehicles used   commercially for ride and car sharing in the nation will be zero   emissions vehicles
column23: including battery
column24: plug-in hybrid
column25: and   fuel-cell electric vehicles.According to IHS Automotive forecasts
column26: several thousand autonomous vehicles will be on U.S. roads in 2020
column27: with the number growing to nearly 4.5 million vehicles by 2035. By then
column28: there will be 21 million autonomous vehicles on the road globally
column29: growing at a 43% CAGR from 2025 to 2035.No wonder everyone is excited.What's In It For Chipmakers?Both Intel and NVIDIANVDAsay that the fully automated car will have as much electronic horsepower as a super computer.Whether a lidar or radar system is used to pick up images of the area surrounding the car
column30: the system is based on semiconductors. These images have to be processed and matched with relevant data to decide a course of action at the blink of an eye. So there's processing (analog
column31: logic)
column32: communications and machine learning involved. Each of these operations will be facilitated with semiconductors. Plus there's entertainment
column33: displays and syncing with other devices that will also require semiconductors.Key PlayersThe Intel Go computer and NVIDIA Drive PX 2 are designed to help cars detect pedestrians
column34: objects
column35: lanes
column36: respond to traffic signals
column37: etc. BMW is testing the Intel solution while TeslaTSLAis testing the NVIDIA solution. BaiduBIDUis developing an artificial intelligence platform that combines its cloud platform with NVIDIA self-driving technology to deliver things like HD maps
column38: vehicle control
column39: automated parking
column40: etc for the Chinese market.NVIDIA has a lead in the machine learning segment and its automotive chips are already in millions of cars from a number of suppliers
column41: which in combination
column42: gives it an edge in the automated car segment.Intel has been in collaboration with Mobileye for quite a while and has finally announced that it will buy the Israeli supplier of self-driving technology (camera and laser-based sensors) for $15 billion. Mobileye currently sells its technology to 27 automakers across the world
column43: so the combination will be highly advantageous for Intel.QualcommQCOM
column44: which beat Intel hands down in the mobile computing business
column45: is also set to rule in self-driving cars (although this time
column46: competition will be tough with both Intel and NVIDIA having gained some mileage). The company recently launched its Drive Data Platform
column47: which is its version of a self-driving system to process the sensor inputs generated by a vehicle. The system is based on the Snapdragon 820Am and makes use of the Snapdragon Neural Processing Engine (SNPE).But there's more. Qualcomm's soon-to-be-completed acquisition of NXP Semiconductors in an all-cash deal worth $47 billion brings on board NXP's RF SoC for in-vehicle infotainment (IVI) systems. While IVI may not sound that exciting in the context of self-driving cars
column48: the thing to bear in mind in this case is the SoC technology that will shrink the size of high power systems while lowering the cost.This will be quite a breakthrough for Qualcomm as a lower price will speed up adoption of its systems. Additionally
column49: NXP is the biggest supplier of automotive chips worldwide so it has the necessary relationships to jumpstart its business.AlphabetGOOGLhas developed self-driving technology of its own but its component suppliers aren't known. Back in 2015
column50: the company quietly acquired Lumedyne
column51: a maker of micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) sensors including an optical accelerometer
column52: a vibration energy harvester and a ""Time Domain Switched"" type of inertial sensor for $85 million. Lumedyne also had a number of patents pending approval at the time.Over the years
column53: Google has also been hiring a growing number of people with chip design skills. In 2015 itself
column54: Google's Pixel team advertised an opening for a ""multimedia chip architect"" who can ""lead a chip development effort"" and ""work with other engineers to take chip to product shipment"". Google was particularly looking for expertise in ""image processing
column55: video processing
column56: stabilization."" The Pixel still uses NVIDIA chips
column57: but Google does have internally developed self-driving technology and the greatest number of self-driving miles on record to train its self-driving system.Wrapping UpThe self-driving/autonomous car conversation is just getting started. There will no doubt be much innovation in the space over the next few years
column58: both by the biggest tech players and automakers and by smaller startups. In fact
column59: CB Insights estimates that financing in the auto tech startup sector was over $1 billion in 2016 and more money will surely follow. This is one of the best places to be in because the technology is just being built
column60: so it could be good business. Also
column61: early investors can sell out their interest at a nice premium.For chipmakers it's a rush to grab a share of the pie.More Stock News: 8 Companies Verge on Apple-Like   RunDid you miss Apple's 9X stock explosion after they launched their iPhone in 2007? Now 2017 looks to be a pivotal year to get in on another emerging technology expected to rock the market. Demand could soar from almost nothing to $42 billion by 2025. Reports suggest it could save 10 million lives per decade which could in turn save $200 billion in U.S. healthcare costs.A bonus Zacks Special Report names this breakthrough and the 8 best stocks to exploit it. Like Apple in 2007

column1: Why the Market Likes Tesla's Capital Raise;3/16/2017;"While most companies tend to see shares fall after announcing   secondary offerings
column2: it's not uncommon forTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) shares to rise after announcing fresh capital   raises. This was true for both Tesla's2015 secondary offeringand to lesser extent the 2016 offering. It's also happening today   after the electric-car maker announced last night that it is   having concurrent offerings for both common stock and convertible   notes. Shares are up about 3% as of this writing.This time around
column3: there's probably a more specific reason why   the market is reacting favorably to the offerings: The dilution   hit that existing shareholders are taking ismuchsmaller due to the mix.The proceeds will be used to reduce Model 3 launch risk.     Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();The equity sideFor context
column4: consider the past two secondary offerings
column5: which   consisted entirely of stock. Last year's offering
column6: which raised   $1.7 billion
column7: was particularly dilutive.YearShares Outstanding BeforeShares Outstanding AfterDilution2016133.9 million147.3 million10%2015127.1 million130.2 million2%Data source: Offering prospectuses.The $250 million stock offering announced last night is fairly   conservative in terms of dilution. Shareholders took a pretty   large dilution hit last year with the all-stock acquisition of   SolarCity
column8: as there are now 161.6 million shares outstanding.   Tesla is selling between roughly 969
column9: 000 and 1.1 million shares
column10: representing dilution of just 0.6% to 0.7%
column11: depending on if   underwriters exercise their options in full. Underwriters   exercised their options in full for the past two offerings
column12: so it   seems conceivable they will do so again
column13: depending on investor   demand.The debt sideThe bulk of the capital being raised will be coming from $750   million in convertible senior notes due 2022. Here's how the   company closed out 2016 in terms of outstanding principal amounts   for any remaining convertibles.DuePrincipal Amount2018 notes$205 million2019 notes$920 million2021 notes$1.4 billionTotal$2.5 billionData source: 10-K.This does not include the $909 million worth of convertible   notes that Tesla inherited from SolarCity
column14: which bear higher   interest rates (other than a zero-coupon tranche).This comes after Tesla received notices of $422 million worth   of conversions for its 2018 convertibles last summer
column15: which the   company had to repay in cash at the time. In a way
column16: you can think   of it like Tesla is in part refinancing the convertibles that   were redeemed last summer
column17: except the new notes will likely end   up having higher conversion prices.The new batch of convertibles has not priced quite yet
column18: but   Tesla does intend to enter into convertible note hedge   transactions and warrant transactions as a way to mitigate any   possible dilution. The company has done this every time it has   issued convertibles in the past (not including the inherited   SolarCity convertibles).On top of all this
column19: debt capital is generally less expensive   than equity capital
column20: so the cost of capital associated with these   offerings is lower than if it consisted of all stock. Combined   with the minimal dilution that shareholders are facing and the   reduced balance-sheet risk
column21: the market seems to like it.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column22: it can pay to listen. After all
column23: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column24: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column25: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
