column27: CFAowns shares of Tesla. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Tesla. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Holders Might Have a Painful Wait;3/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has taken a bit of a breather this month after a terrific run. Apple stock gained 30% just between November and early March
column3: and is up over 50% from late June levels.makeArticleAd();The latter run
column4: incredibly
column5: has added about $250 billion to the market value of AAPL stock.Part of the gains have come from the fact that AAPL was just too cheap
column6: particularly below $100 this summer. But optimism toward the iPhone 8 has boosted hopes that Apple stock can jump-start growth. (The issues at key competitorSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)
column7: including theGalaxy Note 7 debacle
column8: likely have helped as well.)So the question now for AAPL is when the iPhone 8 is coming - and how much upside might be left from a successful launch and product cycle.For now
column9: it looks like there's still some gains left for Apple stock  but investors might need to have some patience.Will the iPhone 8 Move Apple Stock?At the moment
column10: it appears the iPhone 8 will be launched this fall
column11: according to various reports. But Apple has said little about the launch
column12: leaving a guessing game for observers and investors. Even the name isn't clear: The next phone seems likely to be called the iPhone 8
column13: not the 7S
column14: but that's not assured at the moment.Most observers are expecting an iPhone 8
column15: rather than a 7S
column16: because the next-gen product will have major changes. The most notable was thought to be a curved OLED screen
column17: but those reports have been questioned of late. Iris recognition
column18: facial scanning
column19: and a larger screen (on a phone of similar dimensions) are all expected to be features of various versions of the phone.7 Dividend Stocks With Yields That Grow Like WeedsWhat might be most interesting for Apple stock is the price. On Monday morning
column20: Instinet analyst Jeffrey Kvaal said supplier prices supported a possible $1
column21: 000 price for the new iPhone. Other reports of a high-end""Edition""have speculated an ASP over $1
column22: 200. Higher prices for iPhones mean higher margins for Apple - and likely a higher multiple for AAPL stock.Will Investors Buy the Leaks and Sell the News?The biggest worry ahead of the launch is if there will be a ""buy the rumor
column23: sell the news"" reaction from investors.It is clear that some of the optimism over the past few months
column24: in particular
column25: has been driven by consumer reaction to the leaked specs for the new iPhone. Indeed
column26: Apple stock traditionally has been movedalmost solely by iPhone sentiment. Sales of other products have been pretty much flat the last four years.So if there is a large base of investors bidding up the Apple stock price ahead of the iPhone 8
column27: the question then becomes: What might happen in September when the product actually is released?The higher expectations get now
column28: the greater the chance of a disappointment later. Every aspect of the new product will be dissected - and any rumored specs (like
column29: say
column30: the $1
column31: 000 price tag) that aren't in the iPhone 8 will be considered a ""miss"" by Apple.What's Left for the iPhone 8?With Apple stock back near an all-time high
column32: that possibility would concern me over the next few months. For investors with a longer-term focus
column33: however
column34: there's still reason to see upside in AAPL off the iPhone 8 launch.Again
column35: AAPL stock generally has matched up well with iPhone product cycles
column36: and that should keep the stock moving upward if the launch and subsequent sales are a success.The Tesla Inc (TSLA) Small SUV Has Big ImplicationsMeanwhile
column37: a big hit with the new iPhone could once again separate Apple from Samsung. It would also differentiate iOs fromAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column38: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Android ecosystem more broadly. That in turn might allow AAPL stock to once again receive a growth multiple
column39: instead of the low-double-digit-plus cash earnings multiple at which it currently trades.In either direction
column40: the iPhone 8 will matter
column41: because the iPhone still is the major profit engine for Apple. Roughly 63% of fiscal 2016 sales came from the iPhone - and given margins
column42: possibly a higher portion of profits. Apple needs a winner in the iPhone 8 to drive Apple stock higher. And while early speculation looks like the iPhone 8 will be a hit
column43: the recent run in AAPL stock may have priced in at least some of that success.Investors hoping for more likely will need to wait for September - and hope Apple has once again delivered on its promise.The author has no position in any securities mentioned.More From InvestorPlaceHow GoPro Inc (GPRO) Stock Could Make a ComebackDoes the Snap Inc (SNAP) Debacle Signal Doom for These Unicorns?Interest Rates are Rising -- Is Advanced Micro Devices
column44: Inc. (AMD) Stock Far Behind?The postApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Holders Might Have a Painful Waitappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why is Tesla Raising a Billion Dollars in Fresh Capital?;3/16/2017;"Tesla Motors
column2: Inc.TSLAannounced plans to raise around $1.1 billion through a combination of share and senior notes offering

The company will utilize the funds to strengthen its balance sheet and reduce risks associated with the rapid expansion of business. The remaining proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes.makeArticleAd();The electric automaker will be offering shares worth roughly $250 million and convertible senior notes valued $750 million. The notes are due to mature in 2022. Tesla CEO
column4: Elon Musk
column5: intends to purchase 96
column6: 900 shares worth $25 million himself.Tesla unveiled the Model 3 sedan in Mar 2016. The vehicle will be the company's first affordable electric car for the mass market

column8: Model 3 is a four-door
column9: five-seat electric sedan with a range of 215 miles per charge and acceleration of 0-60 mph in less than 6 seconds. Vehicle production and deliveries are expected in the second half of 2017. The company aims to steadily increase production to exceed 5
column10: 000 units per week in the fourth quarter of 2017 and 10
column11: 000 vehicles per week in 2018.Prior to this offering
column12: Tesla had raised $1.7 billion via a public offering of shares in May 2016. The capital was used to finance the accelerated production plan for Model 3 as well as to ramp up annual production volume to 500
column13: 000 units by 2018 and 1 million units by 2020.Tesla had cash and cash equivalents of $3.39 billion as of Dec 31
column14: 2016. However
column15: the cash balance mostly represents cash generated from its May offering
column16: the SolarCity acquisition and drawings on its credit facilities. Meanwhile
column17: the company saw cash outflow in 2016. The company projected capital expenditures of around $2-$2.5 billion for the first half of 2017
column18: implying limited cash balance before the Model 3 production scheduled for the second half of the year. column21: '');Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column22: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column23: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column24: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column25: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column26: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs had   notable inflows "

Makes Up Its Mind: Time to Raise Capital;3/16/2017;"There had been quite a bit of uncertainty in recent quarters   over whether or notTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) was going to raise more capital ahead of the Model   3 launch. The company raised $1.7 billion in its May 2016   secondary offering after underwritersexercised all of their options. That put Tesla in a relatively more comfortable financial   position at the time.The following month
column3: it announced its ambitious and   controversial proposal to acquire sister company SolarCity in an   all-stock deal
column4: which many expected to be cash flow negative.   This raised the notion that Tesla may need to raise capital yet   again. Tesla was able to mostly address this concern by   aggressivelyshifting away from solar leases and toward   sales
column5: which pulls forward both revenue recognition and cash flow;   Tesla's solar operations generated $77 million of positive cash   flow last quarter.Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();Still
column6: it wasn't clear until yesterday what the company was   planning to do. Then Tesla announced concurrent stock and   convertible note offerings
column7: expecting to raise $1.15 billion.Mixed messagesIn theS-4related to the SolarCity acquisition
column8: filed in August

column10: including cash and cash equivalents

column14: including through potential equity or debt offerings
column15: subject     to market conditions and recognizing that Tesla cannot be     certain that additional funds would be available to it on     favorable terms or at all.In October
column16: CEO Elon Musk backtracked on that expectation with   aseries of tweets.Would also like to correct expectations that Tesla/SolarCity   will need to raise equity or corp debt in Q4. Won't be necessary   for either.- Elon Musk (@elonmusk)October 9
column17: 2016@roger_kapplerProbably not then either- Elon Musk (@elonmusk)October 9
column18: 2016On the third-quarter earnings call later that month
column19: Musk   said
column20: ""It seems like we probably won't want to do a capital raise   even in Q1. I'm not saying we won't
column21: but probably not."" Musk   hedged quite a bit
column22: advising to ""take this with a grain of salt""   and noting ""that's not a promise"" -- the statements just   represented Tesla's view at the time. He added that it might make   sense to ""have a larger buffer and to de-risk the business.""On the fourth-quarter earnings call just last month
column23: Musk had   clearly warmed up to the idea:So this is really a question of what is the risk tolerance     of the company. Or how close to the edge do we want to go?     According to our financial plan
column24: no capital needs to be raised     for the Model 3. But we get very close to the edge. So then     that is probably not the best thing for shareholders on a     risk-adjusted basis. So we are considering a number of options

column1: Goldman Sachs Redeems Itself Somewhat With Tesla Objectivity;3/16/2017;"It looked really bad.Last year
column2: Goldman Sachs(NYSE: GS)upgradedshares ofTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) to a buy rating
column3: merehoursbefore the electric-car maker announced its 2016 secondary   offering in May. Goldman was one of the lead book runners in the   deal
column4: and exercised all of its underwriter options tomax out the secondary offering.The timing looked awfully suspicious on Goldman's part.   Goldman's upgrade pushed shares higher
column5: benefiting the offering's   pricing and translating into Goldman collecting more; the   underwriting discount was $1.78 per share and all underwriters in   that deal collectively earned about $19 million thanks to the   full exercise of underwriter options
column6: according to the   prospectus.makeArticleAd();At the time
column7: Goldman toldMarketWatch
column8: ""Our research is independent. We followed all of our standard   policies and procedures with respect to our research publication   on Wednesday."" The timing of the two announcements was ultimately   probably a coincidence
column9: but the optics could not have been   worse.Tesla announced last night that would be doing a common stock   offering ($250 million) as well a convertible note offering ($750   million). Guess who's among the lead book runners.Image source: Tesla.Spoiler alertAmong a few other big banks
column10: Goldman will be acting as lead   joint book-running manager for the offering. This time around
column11: the news comes after Goldman issued a downgrade on Tesla shares   inlate February
column12: from hold to sell. The main concerns driving Goldman's rating   change were risks associated with the Model 3 launch
column13: the recent   acquisition of SolarCity
column14: and ongoing free cash flow burn.It's worth noting that we're talking about two different   analysts. Goldman analyst Patrick Archambault
column15: who issued the May   2016 buy rating
column16: left the investment bank last year and passed   the metaphorical baton to analyst David Tamberrino
column17: who   downgraded shares to neutral in October. Tamberrino then took an   even more bearish stance with the downgrade just last month.Chinese wall intact?Goldman issuing a downgrade a few weeks ahead of the offerings   does look a bit better in terms of its objectivity. Investment   banks are required to maintain a ""Chinese wall"" between their   research divisions and investment banking divisions in order to   mitigate any conflicts of interest.How intact these Chinese walls really are remains an open   debate
column18: but at least in this case Goldman can more justifiably   argue that its research is indeed independent. Incidentally
column19: shares are higher now than they were after the downgrade was   issued.Reducing balance sheet riskAs far as Tesla is concerned
column20: it's taking a slightly more   conservative approach with this offering. It's smaller
column21: with the   aggregate gross proceeds expected at $1.15 billion. The proceeds   will be used to invest in capital expenditures ahead of Model 3   production
column22: which Tesla recently guided to $2 billion to $2.5   billion.On the last earnings call
column23: CEO Elon Musk acknowledged that a   capital raise may make sense in order to reduce balance sheet   risk. However
column24: Tesla gave mixed messages in late 2016 regarding   the prospect of a capital raise
column25: so it wasn't clear if Tesla was   actually going to pull the trigger this time. It did.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Investing in EV Infrastructure: Where the Money Is Going;3/15/2017;"Last year
column3: 139 electric vehicles were sold in the U.S.
column4: according toInside EVs
column5: but that's just scratching the surface of the industry's   potential.Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) plans to build 500
column6: 000 EVs in 2018 andGeneralMotors(NYSE: GM) just launched its first big bet on EVs in the Chevy   Bolt
column7: which will test the size of the market. With new cars fromNissan
column8: Porsche
column9: VW
column10: Volvo
column11: and many others
column12: there looks to be an EV boom on the   horizon. But the size of that boom is currently unknown.The U.S. Energy Information Administration (which typically   underestimates new technologies) predicts that annual EV and   plug-in EV sales will be 1.3 million by 2025 and that 7.5 million   EVs will be on the road by then. Meanwhile
column13: GTM Research   estimates that a total of 11.4 million EVs will be on the road in   the U.S. by 2025 and Bloomberg New Energy Finance thinks 35%   of all new vehicles sold in 2040 will be electric.We know that the EV market will be big and that
column14: given the   scale of the numbers above and the speed of growth
column15: EV charging   infrastructure will become increasingly important across the   country. That presents an opportunity for the companies building   out these charging capabilities.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.The chargers themselves could be big businessAs EVs become more common
column16: someone has to provide millions of   chargers for personal and public use.Aerovironment(NASDAQ: AVAV) has taken a leading position in the charger market   with partnerships with Volvo
column17: Nissan
column18: Ford
column19: and others. The company has also releasedcharging plansand session prices for Level 2 (12-26 miles of charge per hour)   and fast charging (40 miles of charge in 10 minutes) on the West   Coast
column20: where it is building out a network. In its most   recent quarter
column21: electric charging product sales jumped 74% to   $11.3 million
column22: a small but growing base for a small company to   build on.General Electric(NYSE: GE) is also moving into the market
column23: selling home chargers   and public charging options. As it's a major electricity   component supplier
column24: this is an adjacent market it can enter with   little risk
column25: and I would expect to see GE's charger revenue   grow as the market grows.Of course
column26: there's Tesla's charging infrastructure as well.   Tesla sells most of its own charging components to customers
column27: and   as it's the biggest EV company
column28: it's a big business. But the   proprietary charging technology it has bet on may end up   eventually walling it off from competitors.How chargers get builtWhat's less known is who will build the charger infrastructure   and how it will be paid for. Tesla's Supercharger network has   been built out entirely by Tesla for the use of its own   customers. It's been free for years
column29: but now new Model S and   Model X customers will get 400 kWh of supercharging free and then   pay a fee for charging based on local electricity costs.   Competing auto manufacturers haven't shown much interest in   building out their own networks and will most likely let someone   else build chargers.Image source: Getty Images.Utilities have shown some interest in chargers being a growth   opportunity. In California
column30: San Diego Gas & Electricis building 3
column31: 500 utility-owned chargers for $45 million
column32: Southern California Edisonis building 1
column33: 500 host-owned chargers for $22 million
column34: andPacific Gas & Electricis building the infrastructure behind 7
column35: 500 chargers in a   utility-private investor partnership. The question here is   whether or not utilities should be able to build chargers under   their monopoly power and therefore rate-base the cost to all   consumers
column36: whether they own an electric vehicle or not. In   theory
column37: a utility's low cost of capital could help build out   charger networks more quickly
column38: although keeping utilities out of   the market may bring in more innovative business models from   private companies.The third option is third-party charging networks.NRG Energy(NYSE: NRG)  tried to get into this business but sold off   EVgo earlier this year to an investment firm that may be able to   grow the network more effectively. The national network now   countsBMW
column39: Ford
column40: and Nissan as partners
column41: and its early mover status may be   helpful long term. ChargePoint is the nation's largest charging   network
column42: aggregating local EV charging stations into a national   network. Blink is another company building a large network
column43: which   is currently about 4
column44: 000 stations.EV charging will be big but still faces risksWhat's unique here is that there are three distinct business   models colliding in EV charging
column45: and we don't know which one will   win long term. My money would be on third-party networks   eventually becoming victorious because of their national scope   and ability to provide different charging technologies. And if   they do
column46: these (mostly private) networks and the companies that   build the chargers will be the big winners for investors.What we do know is that with millions of EVs expected to hit   the road in the next decade
column47: this is a big opportunity for   companies that can get their business model right.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Buy Facebook Inc (FB) Stock as It Steals Snap Incs (SNAP) Thunder;3/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe cat is out of the bag.Facebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) is copyingSnap Inc(NYSE:SNAP)
column3: and it is doing it everywhere.makeArticleAd();First
column4: it was Instagram Stories. Then it was WhatsApp Status. Now it's Messenger Day. With each copycat iteration
column5: the chorus of bearish arguments against FB stock gets louder and louder. They are all pretty similar
column6: and they go something like: ""Facebook is playing catch-up"" or ""Facebook isn't innovating"" or ""Snap will steal Facebook's users.""The market doesn't seem to be giving those arguments much credence. Facebook stock is up 13% since Instagram Stories launched and is currently at all-time highs. SNAP stock
column7: meanwhile
column8: is 25% off its post-IPO high and continues to make new lows.I think the market has it right on this one. Here's why.Facebook Stole Snap's ThunderOne thingApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) taught the technology world is that you don't need to be first to market to succeed. The iPhone was far from the first smartphone to market. Apple let other companies introduce the concept and dabble in prototypes
column9: then Apple leaped on the opportunity when the time was right.6 Tech Stocks to Buy for the VR BoomIn other words
column10: you don't have to be first. You just have to be better and have the right timing.Facebook is bigger
column11: and in the social media world
column12: that is better. The timing is also right for Facebook to be playing copycat.Scale is what has driven profits and driven FB stock higher. The entire Facebook ecosystem has tremendous scale. The main Facebook app has scale. Messenger has scale. Instagram has scale. WhatsApp has scale. This pervasive scale offers two advantages:Firstly
column13: scale will convert Snap Story users into Facebook users. As thisMashablewriterpoints out
column14: there is a certain broadcasting element to Snap and Instagram Stories. When you blast a picture or video out on social media for 24 hours
column15: you do so with the intent of grabbing as many eyeballs as possible. Snap only has so many eyeballs. Instagram has more than two times as many eyeballs. Messenger has more than six times
column16: and WhatsApp more than seven times.Secondly
column17: scale will allow FB to grab users before they ever even migrate to Snap. Instagram Stories just rolled out internationally
column18: where Snap only has some 90 million daily active users. Messenger and WhatsApp also have large international reach. As Instagram Stories
column19: WhatsApp Status
column20: and Messenger Day launch globally
column21: it will be the first time many of their users have seen the ""Stories"" concept. To them
column22: there is no copying or mimicking at work. Just a cool new feature on a favorite platform.The timing of Facebook's ""imitation game"" has also been pretty close to perfect.The concept of ephemeral media messaging
column23: particularly the core concept of Stories
column24: really took off in 2016. Snap saw its daily active user base grow from 107 million at the end of 2015 to 143 million by the middle of 2016.But then Instagram Stories launched in August 2016
column25: and Snap's user growth slowed. Snap ended the year with only 158 million daily actives. That means the platform added 36 million users in the first half of 2016 but only 15 million in the second-half.Meanwhile
column26: in just 25 weeks
column27: Instagram Stories grew to150 million actives(the same size as Snap).What Will Apple Inc. (AAPL) Show Off in Its April Event?It looks like Instagram stole Snap's thunder in August
column28: and rolled with it into the end of the year while Snap more or less flat-lined.Bottom Line on FB StockFacebook is playing copycat
column29: and so far
column30: it's working. Moreover
column31: it likely will continue to work
column32: and FB will only grow its user base and unit revenue as Snap fades into social media memory.All in all
column33: FB stock has become a classic ""buy-the-dip"" situation with a secular growth story and a reasonable - but not great - valuation. At nearly 21 times next year's consensus earnings estimate
column34: Facebook really isn't all the expensive. Earnings are actually expected to grow 28% this year and 23% next year
column35: so the stock trades at a discount to its growth. That is rare for a hyper-growth tech company.Facebook also has more than $10 per share in cash on the balance sheet and generates consistently strong cash flows.For what it's worth
column36: I'm not running to buy FB stock here near all-time highs. But Iamlooking to add to my position on any dips.As of the writing of this article

column1: What Will Apple Inc. (AAPL) Show Off in Its April Event?;3/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere are three announcements we've been waiting forApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) to make in the near future:makeArticleAd();A March special event to launch an upgraded 12.9-inch iPad Pro and 9.7-inch iPad Air replacement.A third iPad -an all new 10.5-inch iPad Pro with design cues from the iPhone 8- seems ready to go in May or June.The move-in date for its new Apple Park ""spaceship"" campus.A new report suggests the company is juggling the timelines and plans to hold an April Apple Event combining all three.New iPads Are OverdueApple's iPad lineup may not be doing the same business it once was
column3: but it's still due for a refresh.The iPad Pro line aimed at prosumers is priced at a premium
column4: helping to boost revenue for the division
column5: but it competes against some tough adversaries
column6: includingMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Surface Pro. Apple is expected to release a next generation version of 2015's 12.9-inch iPad Pro to stay current.6 Tech Stocks to Buy for the VR BoomAnall-new iPad Prothat is also expected in the late spring. This one is a 10.5-inch form factor
column7: but it seems likely to borrow from the design of the upcoming iPhone 8
column8: with an edge-to-edge display and virtual Home button. Doing so gives AAPL a physically smaller iPad Pro
column9: with a display larger than the current 9.7-inch iPad Pro
column10: making it more useful for professionals.The company is expected to also ship a replacement for the iPad Air 2
column11: its full-sized consumer tablet that was released in 2014.The new iPad Air and 12.9-inch iPad Pro were expected to be unveiled in March
column12: but with the month half-over
column13: an April Apple event seems more likely.Such a move also jives with rumors back in January that AAPL might be experiencing somemanufacturing challenges that could result in a later release.New iPads Identified in the WildOn Monday
column14: 9to5 Macbroke the news that an analytics firm hasdetected the identifiers for new iPad models in app downloadsin the Cupertino area. The model numbers show up as iPad 7
column15: 1; iPad 7
column16: 2; iPad 7
column17: 3 and iPad 7
column18: 4 - current iPad models show up in logs as iPad 6
column19: x.9to5 Macnotes that four new identifiers don't necessarily mean four new models
column20: as an iPad equipped with LTE has different numbers than the same version in a Wi-Fi-only option.The new models first showed up last September
column21: but the frequency accelerated rapidly in January and February
column22: indicating the new iPads are getting close to being launch-ready.Apple Park Ready for Its Grand OpeningApple Park is AAPL's massive new headquarters
column23: nicknamed the ""spaceship campus"" because of its round
column24: futuristic design.Under construction since 2013
column25: the massive building is 2/3 the size of the pentagon
column26: packed with the latest green technology (including 17 megawatts of rooftop solar power generating capacity)
column27: features the world's largest curved glass panels and came with a $5 billion price tag.One of the features of Apple Park is the new Steve Jobs Theater - the site AAPL plans to use for new product launches.AAPL has already announced 12
column28: 000 employees will begin moving into Apple Park next month
column29: so an April Apple Event of some sort to celebrate the opening of the new headquarters was already a given.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock: How ""Model Y"" Report Changed the GameNew iPads and Apple Park to Converge for a Big April Apple Event?Putting all the pieces together will take some work on AAPL's part. That new 10.5-inch iPad Pro in particular could be problematic (it wasn't expected this early)
column30: but Applecouldshow it off and announce availability closer to summer. However
column31: the stars appear to be aligning for whatDigitimesis reporting will be an April Apple event.Citing sources from within Apple's supply chain
column32: DigitimessaysApple will show off its new iPads at a combined eventthat also inaugurates the new Apple HQ.2017 is shaping up to be a massive year for Apple - one that will culminate with the 10th anniversary iPhone 8 in September.It's fitting if the company kicks things off with the opening of its new headquarters
column33: and the first new product launch at the Steve Jobs Theater. Expect the April Apple event to happen
column34: and to be a big deal.As of this writing

column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) rallied close to 5% on Tuesday on the back of a report saying the electric vehicle maker is planning on yet another new cardubbed the ""Model Y.""While to my knowledge
column3: Tesla has yet to confirm or deny these rumors
column4: the positive reaction in TSLA stock must be respected.makeArticleAd();From a technical analysis standpoint
column5: Tesla stock bounced off important support that could offer traders and investors a good reference area around which to build their trades.It was only three weeks ago
column6: on Feb. 22
column7: when Tesla reported its latest batch of earnings. In response
column8: investors sold off TSLA stock with both hands.Case in point? When I last mused about shares of Tesla onFeb. 24(the day following the initial reaction to the company's earnings report)
column9: I said that while TSLA remains an attractive longer-term growth story
column10: technically speaking
column11: it had reached the upper end of a longer-standing trading range and looked poised for a breather. I also offered that a mean-reversion move lower toward the $240 area looked to be in the cards.Just a few days later (Feb. 27)
column12: Tesla stock had reached its 50-day moving average near $242 - close enough to the $240 area
column13: and enough to allow traders to take profits on any short positions.The 7 Best IPOs to Buy for the Rest of 2017Before looking closer into the technical meaning of Tuesday's bounce
column14: let's review the bigger picture.TSLA Stock ChartsLooking at the multiyear chart
column15: we can see that despite selling pressure following the February earnings report and yesterday's bounce
column16: Tesla shares remain largely in a well-defined yet wide trading range.Click to EnlargeMy contacts on Wall Street capital markets trading desks continue to point toward another possible round of capital raise by Tesla Inc as a next event to look for - then depending on how investors react
column17: potentially scale back into the stock at a better size.As a former investment banker
column18: I agree with my contacts that a capital raise would be a critical time to look at TSLA stock closely. Still
column19: I have to also respect Tuesday's bounce.On the daily chart
column20: we see that Tuesday's rally in TSLA stock took place at a technical juncture that I often refer to as a ""confluence area"" of support.Click to EnlargeNote the simple black diagonal resistance line
column21: which the stock pierced above in January. This line now coincides with the yellow 50-day simple moving average - a moving average that for the past 12 months had been a good reference area for the stock.Through this lens
column22: the pullback in TSLA shares over the past few weeks merely offered a retest of this former diagonal line of technical resistance. Now
column23: following Tuesday's rally

column1: Tesla's Model 3 Reservation Count Likely Hasn't Changed Much;3/14/2017;"It's now been nearly a year sinceTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) provided its one and only disclosure on how many   Model 3 reservations it has collected. When Tesla conducted its   secondary offering last year
column2: it confirmed that in the month and   a half following the Model 3 unveiling it had garnered 373
column3: 000   reservations as of May 15
column4: 2016. Since then
column5: numerous analysts   have asked for updates on this figure
column6: which management has   declined to answer for fear that any updates would be needlessly   overscrutinized.There are only clues
column7: but it looks like Tesla's total Model 3   reservation tally hasn't changed much over the past year.Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();Normal fluctuationsThe balance sheet line item to look at is customer deposits.   This figure naturally fluctuates as customers place deposits for   new vehicles
column8: which are subsequently released when the vehicle is   delivered. Throughout 2014 and 2015
column9: these fluctuations were   often in the $20 million to $30 million range.At $1
column10: 000 per reservation
column11: the aforementioned 373
column12: 000 figure   from last year represents $373 million worth of deposits. Due to   the timing of the unveiling last year
column13: which occurred on the very   last day of Q1 2016
column14: not all deposits taken on March 31 were   captured in the corresponding balance sheet data due to credit   card and bank processing times. In other words
column15: that $373 million   increase in deposits took place over two quarters in terms of   balance sheet dates.Data source: SEC filings. Chart by author.The difference between deposits on Dec. 31
column17: and June 30
column19: was $396.5 million
column20: or that same $373 million and then some   within range of standard fluctuations. But since then
column21: customer   deposits have not changed meaningfully beyond what would be   considered standard fluctuations. More specifically
column22: CFO Jason   Wheeler attributed last quarter's sequential decline of $27   million to a large number of Model X Signature Series that were   delivered
column23: which originally had higher deposits.This suggests that Tesla's total Model 3 reservation tally has   not changed much.That's not necessarily a bad thingTo be clear
column24: this is not necessarily a bad thing. Wheeler   notes that Tesla does not ""want to make the line longer at this   point
column25: and CEO Elon Musk said the company ""anti-sells"" the Model   3 for this reason. So the company is not actively trying to grow   the Model 3 line
column26: and the first year's worth of production is   already effectively allocated to current reservation holders;   Tesla's site says new reservations won't deliver until ""mid 2018   or later.""The initial spike in reservations was certainly driven by   pent-up demand from enthusiast consumers that have long wanted a   Tesla but have been waiting for a more affordable option. For   consumers that are considering a wider range of brands for their   next vehicle purchase
column27: there's little to no point in placing a   $1
column28: 000 deposit for a vehicle that won't be delivered for another   year or longer. It's easier to sit on the sidelines and see how   things play out
column29: and see if Tesla can execute better in areas   like quality control and customer support.A longer line is also meaningless to Tesla if it's already   backlogged by over a year
column30: and its main focus is ramping   production and addressing any early issues that arise (which is   why the first deliveries will go to employees in the Bay Area
column31: close to the Fremont factory). There would very likely be a   tendency among critics to spin a relatively unchanged reservation   count as a negative storyline
column32: which may be what management is   trying to avoid by not giving updates.What matters most for the time being is just getting the   $35

column1: Here's Why Tesla (TSLA) Stock Popped Today;3/14/2017;"Shares of TeslaTSLAgained more than 4.2% in afternoon trading Tuesday after a speculative report from a British car publication fueled rumors that the electric vehicle manufacturer is set to launch a new compact SUV.This new speculation was caused by a story published byAutocardetailing the Model Y
column2: a rumored compact crossover that is reportedly based on the same platform as Tesla's new affordable Model 3. According to the report
column3: the Model Y is ""expected to be slightly more expensive"" than the Model 3.Citing the popularity of crossovers throughout the U.S
column4: the story claims that ""the compact Model Y could turn out to be Tesla's best seller."" The website even generated their own mockup of what the new car would look like
column5: and its sleek design cannot be overstated.The only problem is that the report seems to be based on absolutely no new information. In his updated ""Master Plan"" published on Tesla's ownwebsitethis past summer
column6: Elon Musk detailed his goal to ""address most of the consumer market"" with the Model 3
column7: as well as ""a future compact SUV and a new kind of pickup truck.""So we've already known that a compact SUV is in Tesla's future. Throw in an obvious observation that the new car will probably cost more than the Model 3
column8: speculate that it will be a bestseller based on the popularity of similar vehicles
column9: and boom-you've got yourself a story that looks powerful enough to move this stock.In reality
column10: if the Model Y starts production in late 2018 as Autocar suggests
column11: it will be behind several other comparable compact electric SUVs.And that's not even mentioning the fact that Musk's brief mention of a compact SUV was sandwiched in between his plans to shake up the energy storage market and his aspirations to revolutionize trucking and public transportation.In the new Master Plan
column12: Musk said that
column13: outside of consumer vehicles
column14: ""there are two other types of electric vehicle needed: heavy-duty trucks and high passenger-density urban transport.""He also claimed that both are in the early stages of development and should be ready to be unveiled in 2017.So maybe that's what we should be looking forward to next?Zacks' 2017 IPO Watch ListBefore looking into the stocks mentioned above

column1: NVIDIA or Intel: Which Is Better for Driverless Car Investors?;3/14/2017;"Self-driving cars
column2: once the stuff of science fiction movies
column3: are set to become a reality soon. Already many driver-assist features
column4: such as lane changing
column5: traffic jam assistant and others
column6: are being offered by automakers. Such features are
column7: essentially
column8: stepping stones to autonomous driving technology.By definition
column9: an autonomous vehicle is a car that is able to take on the primary transportation capabilities of a driver-controlled car. It can sense its surrounding environment and navigate that space without the involvement of humans. Technology like radar
column10: lidar
column11: GPS and computer vision help the cars accomplish this feat.Nearly all automakers are now in various stages of developing self-driving cars. Some have even started testing them on public roads. Although bringing these cars to market will take years
column12: it is obvious that driverless cars have a place in the future of the technology industry. Thus
column13: long-term investors interested in the technology sector would be well-advised to invest in stocks that look set to gain from this trend. Since the market is dominated by a few large players
column14: it makes sense to weigh the pros and cons before investing.Huge Growth Potential of the IndustryAccording to data available from BI intelligence
column15: 10 million self-driving cars will be on the road by 2020. Per Statista
column16: the market for fully autonomous vehicles will grow to almost $6 billion while partially autonomous vehicles market will reach $36 billion by 2025. According to Boston Consulting Group estimates
column17: the autonomous car market will be worth $42 billion by 2025 and $77 billion by 2035.These estimates encourage us about NVIDIA Corp.NVDAand Intel Corp's.INTCgrowth prospects in the space. With its sustained focus on developing new and more advanced technologies for self-diving cars
column18: we believe that the two companies is well poised to capitalize on this opportunity. Both these companies have generated high returns for investors so far and have the potential to exceed expectations in the days ahead.NVIDIA Vs. IntelNVIDIA and Intel are two big players within the driverless car space.Intel recently struck a deal to acquire driver assistance technology company Mobileye N.V.MBLYfor roughly $15.3 billion. The deal marks the next step in the driverless car race.Intel plans on integrating its own automated driving group with Mobileye's renowned operations
column19: and the combined entity will be run by Mobileye Chairman Amnon Shashua. The deal will combine Intel's processors with Mobileye's renowned computer vision
column20: making it the biggest purchase of a company that's solely focused on the self-driving market.Intel's $15.3 billion acquisition is the biggest ever for an Israeli technology company. The move positions Intel as a ""leading technology provider in the fast-growing market for highly and fully autonomous vehicles
column21: according to a company statement Monday. ""Intel estimates the vehicle systems
column22: data and services market opportunity to be up to $70 billion by 2030.""The deal comes afterMobileye partneredwith self-driving technology company Delphi Automotive in Aug. 2016. The two companies planned to create an affordable self-driving car platform to sell to carmakers by 2019. In Nov. 2016
column23: Intel announcedthat Mobileye and Delphi would use its processors. Intel
column24: Mobileye and German automaker BMW AG partnered to test 40 self-driving cars
column25: which could possibly lead to production by 2021.Intel's purchase helps the technology giant begin to compete in therace towards autonomous car technology.In January
column26: Intel announced it would purchase a 15% stake in digital mapmaker Here International B.V.
column27: joining BMW AG and Volkswagen AG'sVLKAYAudi
column28: to further the development in the real-time technology needed to improve self-driving car technology.With these types of partnerships in mind
column29: Intel and Mobileye's biggest competitor going forward will be NVIDIA and its collaboration with Tesla Inc.TSLA. NVIDIA is best known for its gaming and smartphone graphics chips
column30: but like Intel
column31: the company has been developing computing hardware for cars.NVIDIA's foray into the autonomous vehicles and other automotive electronics space has also been driving the stock higher since mid-2015. It should be noted that during the last reported quarter (fourth quarter of fiscal 2017)
column32: the company witnessed a 38% year-over-year jump in automotive segment revenues
column33: mainly driven by premium infotainment and digital cockpit features in mainstream cars.Notably
column34: during the 2017 CES event
column35: the company announced two important collaborations - with HERE and ZENRIN - that will expand the Live Map capabilities of autonomous vehicles Apart from this
column36: the company announced an extension of its decade-long partnership with Audi. The two companies have now decided to put advanced AI cars on the road starting 2020.It should be noted that NVIDIA forayed into autonomous vehicle and other automotive electronics space in 2015 by launching a computer vision system at the CES. It hasn't looked back since then and has been continuously bringing new and more advanced technologies in the space.At the beginning of 2016
column37: NVIDIA launched DRIVE PX 2 - the world's most powerful engine for in-vehicle AI. In Sep 2016
column38: the graphic chip behemoth unveiled a new AI supercomputer chip designed for self-driving cars called Xavier at its GPU Technology Conference (GTC) in Amsterdam. With its sustained focus on developing new and more advanced AI technologies for self-diving cars
column39: we believe that the company is well poised to become a leading provider of technology for autonomous vehicles.Notably
column40: since 2015
column41: NVIDIA has been providing various autonomous technologies such as digital instrument clusters
column42: navigation
column43: advanced driver-assistance systems and infotainment under its partnerships with several automakers including HondaHMC
column44: Tesla Motors
column45: Audi
column46: Volvo
column47: Mercedes-Benz and BMW.Therefore
column48: we believe that the recent permit to test its driverless cars will encourage various other auto manufacturers to use NVIDIA's processing units in their autonomous driving systems.For years
column49: these two companies have battled each other for market share and brand recognition in every conceivable way.Which Stock to Choose?Share priceNVIDIA
column50: a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) stock
column51: remains one of the best performers in the semiconductor space. The stock has been clocking solid returns since the beginning of 2016 and has gained 216.9% in the last one year
column52: outperforming the Zacks categorizedSemiconductor-Generalindustry's return of just about 39.9%.We note that Intel
column53: a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) stock
column54: has underperformed the ZacksSemiconductor Generalindustry in the past one year. While the company's shares gained 10.9%
column55: the industry returned 38.9% in the same period. Moreover
column56: we don't expect the shares to rebound in the near term.Estimate RevisionsOver the past month
column57: NVIDIA's current quarter estimates have risen from 63 cents per share to 67 cents per share and current year estimates have risen from $2.69 per share to $2.79 per share.While Intel's current quarter estimates over the past one month have not shown any movement and is pegged at 65 cents. However
column58: current year estimates have risen from $2.79 per share to $2.89 per share
column59: over the same time frame.Style Score
column60: EPS Growth Rate
column61: Market CapNVIDIA has a Growth Style Score of ""A"" with a long-term expected growth rate of 10.3%. The company has a market cap of $58.38 billion.Intel has a Growth Style Score of ""B"" with a long-term expected growth rate of 8.42%. The company has a market cap of $169.78 billion.ConclusionThese two stocks have grabbed the spotlight with striking performances on the back of solid earnings results and strong growth projections
column62: with their share of pros and cons. But given the current scenario
column63: we would bet on NVIDIA because it is well-positioned to outpace the industry and is fundamentally strong enough to withstand risks. Also
column64: NVIDIA was one of the hottest stocks in the S&P 500 last year
column65: and there's a very good chance it could perform that way again in 2017.You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank stocks   here.Zacks' 2017 IPO Watch ListBefore looking into the stocks mentioned above

column1: Mobileye NV (MBLY) Didnt Come Cheap. Heres Why;3/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAsk ten shareholders what they think of the this week's decision fromIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) to acquireMobileye NV(NYSE:MBLY) and you'll get ten different answers. Most of those answers
column3: however
column4: won't be terribly favorable opinions regarding the deal.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockEither the iconic chipmaker overpaid for Mobileye shares
column5: or Intel has no business leaving its comfort zone (CPUs and chipsets)
column6: or both. Besides
column7: long-term INTC owners know the company doesn't have the best track record when it comes to making acquisitions.There's a certain ""crazy like a fox"" quality to this purchase
column8: though. Intel stock holders may want to take a step back and look at the same long-term picture CEO Brian Krzanich is seeing.Not OptimisticOn Monday
column9: tech-giant Intel announced it was acquiring Mobileye - the maker of the ""eyes"" used by self-driving and auto-braking automobiles -for $63.54 per share of MBLY
column10: or $15.3 billion in all.That's a 45% premium to Friday's closing trade! But perhaps more concerning is that at $15.3 billion
column11: Intel will be paying 42.7 times last year's salesand 141.7 times 2016's income from Mobileye. Both are on the order of ten times the norm.The 7 Best IPOs to Buy for the Rest of 2017Analysts were mixed on the matter
column12: although a few were particularly optimistic. Perhaps the most bullish view came from Rosenblatt Securities analyst Hans Mosesmann
column13: who explained:""Intel is seeking relevance in automotive with the Mobileye acquisition in a market that is moving at a faster-than-expected pace. The acquisition is in line with the Altera acquisition in that it is defensive in nature and meant to defend Intel's historical CPU (central processing unit) incumbency from various accelerator technologies.""At the more pessimistic end of the scale
column14: Global Equities Research analyst Trip Chowdhry opined:""Basically
column15: Intel has now inherited Mobileye's problems
column16: and we don't think Intel has the capacity to fix Mobileye's issues.""All those views may be too short-sighted
column17: however.What Intel Sees in MobileyeKrzanichjustified the decisionto INTC shareholders by saying:""It's important now
column18: because if you take a look at what you're doing - talking about car models in 2020
column19: 2021 - and so we need to get in there. We need to get this platform developed
column20: brought to them
column21: and have that confidence so that we can really influence the real start of autonomous driving in that time frame.""He's right
column22: in all ways.He's right in the sense that although self-driving cars aren't exactly new
column23: the market isn't gelled yet - there's room for new players to step up and shape what the future of autonomous driving looks like. Better for Intel to shape it on its terms then end up chasing the lead pace set by the likes ofTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) andNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA).He's also right in the sense that by 2020/2021
column24: the landscape of the self-driving car market is going to look radically different. Not only will the market leaders be well-entrenched by then
column25: there's going to massive growth in the number of autonomous cars on the road by that time.How massive? BCG recently crunched some numbers
column26: concluding thatby 2035 annual sales of fully autonomous vehicles will reach 12 million. Annual sales of partially-autonomous cars will rise to 18 million by that point.Investors won't have to wait that long to see big-time growth
column27: though. BCG thinks the market will be worth $42 billion by 2025
column28: and grow to $77 billion by 2035. At the end of the timeframe
column29: roughly a fourth of all new cars sold will offer autonomous driving features.In a separate study
column30: Lux Research concluded that
column32: the self-driving automobile market will be worth $87 billion. Lux added that software developers will be the biggest winners of the movement. Making the hardware work is the hard part.With Mobileye now under its wing
column33: Intel has access to a full-blown platform - complete with software - it didn't have before.Bottom Line for INTC StockIt's not a deal that's going to pay dividends (literally or figuratively) tomorrow
column34: or even next year. Give it two years
column35: though
column36: or even five years for the autonomous car market to mature. It's coming
column37: and it's going to be big. It's far easier and far more affordable for Intel to stake its claim now than it will be to try and break into the market later.Tesla: Trade TSLA With Less RiskIf nothing else
column38: Intel wanted to make sure it made Mobileye its own rather than risk letting a competitor get hold of the up-and-coming company. The value will be there eventually.As of this writing
column39: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Monthly Dividend Stocks to Buy to Pay the Bills7 Huge M&A Deals That Should Happen ImmediatelyThe postMobileye NV (MBLY) Didn't Come Cheap. Here's Whyappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Can Intel Catch Tesla

column3: Apple In Autonomous Car Race?;3/14/2017;"Thanks to its$15.3 billion acquisitionof Israeli self-driving technology company Mobileye (MBLY)
column4: Intel (INTC) is no longer on the outside looking in when it comes to the autonomous car market
column5: which has become the new battleground for high-tech companies looking new revenue streams.While Intels semiconductor prowess and breadth in R&D should accelerate the pace of Mobileyes technology innovation
column6: will the combined company have enough tread to catch the likes of Tesla (TSLA) and Google (GOOGL)?Intel seems to think so. The deal
column7: which sent MBLY stock soaring 28% in active trade Monday
column8: ""merges the intelligent eyes of the autonomous car with the intelligent brain that actually drives the car
column9: said Intel CEO Brian Krzanich in a statement. The saying 'what's under the hood' will increasingly refer to computing
column10: not horsepower.makeArticleAd();Investors werent immediately impressed
column11: sending Intel shares down 2.1% to close at a three-month low of $35.16. This isnt Intels first run at self-driving cars

column13: Calif.-based chip giant
column14: through its financing arm Intel Capital
column15: hasspent $250 millionin R&D looking for an edge. The Mobileye deal
column16: meanwhile
column17: has now made it known that autonomous driving capabilities was never a hobby for Intel. Its become a critical market for the company.Still
column18: Tesla and Google wont be run off the road. In December
column19: GooglelaunchedWaymo
column20: which stands for a new way forward in mobility. Waymos website features a two-seater prototype fitted with Googles hardware and software that is built to move with the touch of a button
column21: with neither a steering wheel nor a brake pedal. Meanwhile
column22: in Teslas most popular sedan
column23: the Model S
column24: the company has already rolled out self-driving capabilities that receive incremental updates on autopilot features.These updates
column25: which include exit ramp autonomy on highways
column26: automatic lane-changing
column27: and auto-steering
column28: are also available to Model X
column29: its SUV family. And to say nothing about Apples (AAPL) own autonomous car ambitions
column30: which theWall Street Journalrecently confirmed. With more money stashed than the U.S. Treasury
column31: Apples autonomous car position depends only on how hard it wants to mash the accelerator.But heres the thing: Mobileye was once a prominent partner to Tesla
column32: meaning it could have had first-hand knowledge of what Tesla has under its hood. And to the extent Intel can utilize that knowledge to accelerate its own technology
column33: Intel will narrow that gap relatively quickly.At the same time
column34: the fact that Intel wants to emerge as the go-to chip name when it comes to autonomous car processors
column35: powering functions such as displays and communication between two self-driving vehicles
column36: Intel doesnt necessarily have to be the car

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) to Debut Tesla Model Y in 2018;3/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News

column1: 1 Chart That Suggests Tesla Needs to Invest More in Support Infrastructure;3/14/2017;"Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) has an ambitious and compelling vision of vertically integrating sales and service. Hatred of the traditional car buying experience is universal
column2: and service departments at dealerships aremajor profit centers. But pulling off the execution of that vision is far easier said than done
column3: and requires significant investments in infrastructure as well as talent. No one should ever have to wait nearlyeight monthsto get their car repaired.Digging through Tesla's SEC filings
column4: there are data points that could suggest that Tesla needs to be investing more aggressively in customer support.makeArticleAd();Tesla technicians performing service on a Model S. Image source: Tesla.A numbers gameFair warning: This will be an imperfect analysis
column5: mostly due to imperfect public data. First
column6: I took a look at cumulative vehicle shipments over time
column7: excluding the original Roadster that only sold about 2
column8: 500 units. While cumulative unit sales are generally not a great proxy for installed base because some units are inevitably retired over time
column9: Tesla's cumulative unit sales may be closer than other examples since cars tend to have longer useful lives and the company only started shipping the Model S less than five years ago. This isn't a small consumer electronics device that you get rid of after two years. It's not perfect
column10: but it's the closest proxy we can get.Tesla also reports the total number of sales and service locations that it operates. It would be more useful to distinguish between sales and service
column11: but for reporting purposes the company aggregates all locations. Third-party authorized body shops are not included in these figures
column12: as Tesla does not report how large its network is. Here's a chart of both cumulative unit sales and Tesla stores and service centers over the past five years.Data source: SEC filings. Chart by author.However
column13: if you divide cumulative unit sales by Tesla-operated locations
column14: then it starts to make sense why Tesla's support infrastructure is somewhat strained right now. Cumulative units per location rose from 91.5 in 2012 to 693.2 in 2016.Data source: SEC filings and author's calculations. Chart by author.Again
column15: this analysis is less than ideal since investors only have Tesla's public disclosures to work with. It does not account for geographical differences or concentrations
column16: it cannot distinguish between sales and service locations
column17: and the installed base is certainly less than the roughly 184
column18: 000 Model S and Model X vehicles that Tesla has delivered through the end of 2016. It's also not as if locations should scale linearly with deliveries. But directionally on average
column19: it stands to reason that Tesla's support infrastructure growth has not kept pace with delivery growth
column20: which in turn leads to backlogs within the network.It's also worth noting that Tesla measures many other internal metrics to assess service quality -- metrics that public investors are not privy to. For example
column21: head of sales and service Jon McNeillrecently notedthat 20% of jobs at Tesla's Palo Alto center are completed before the customer can finish a cup of coffee
column22: and that Tesla's overall parts backlog has been reduced by over 80%. These are also important data points
column23: but they aren't the sort that investors get regular updates on.Model 3 will need even greater supportMeanwhile
column24: Tesla does not break out its capital spending in detail
column25: either
column26: so it's hard to gauge how much the company is investing in support infrastructure. It goes without saying that areas like Gigafactory and Model 3 tooling are the top priorities
column27: but beyond that it's less clear. Here's CFO Jason Wheeler
column28: who recently announced he was leaving Tesla to pursue opportunities in public policy
column29: responding to an analyst question on capital expenditure categories on the last earnings call:We don't break down
column30: we don't disclose the specifics here
column31: but obviously Gigafactory and Model 3 are going to be the biggest investments. We've also got CapEx investments soon
column32: equipment and tooling related to Model 3. But then also there's going to be a piece in CapEx on building out our service and our retail infrastructure as well. And the Supercharger network. So it is the usual suspects.Given the looming Model 3 production ramp that remains on track
column33: perhaps Tesla should be allocating more capital expenditures to expanding support infrastructure.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column34: it can pay to listen. After all
column35: the newsletter they have run for over a decade
column36: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column37: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Why Intel Needed To Own Mobileye - Even If It Overpaid;3/14/2017;"Painfully
column2: Intel (INTC) has little to no presence in mobile devices
column3: save for a few modem chips here and there. Most everything on mobile devices is ARM-based due to its lower power consumption and cheaper costs. Intel and its -x86 platform simply cannot compete on price or power performance.Having realized this
column4: Intel has decided to do what any company in its position should do -- try and buy its way into the future
column5: acquiring Mobileye (MBLY) for $15.3 billion.No Matter the CostmakeArticleAd();The acquisition
column6: which is being billed as helping Intel turn into a data company (whatever that means)
column7: isn't likely to move the financial needle for Intel anytime soon.Mobileye generated just $240.6 million in revenue in fiscal 2016. By comparison
column8: Intel's full year revenue was $59.4 BILLION and its Data Center Group (which Intel is saying Mobileye will fit into) had $17.2 billion in sales.The Israeli-based Mobileye generated $108.4 million in GAAP net income in 2016
column9: making the deal worth 141 times net income. That isn't exactly cheap
column10: even if Mobileye is growing revenues at 46% year over year.This deal is about the future of the car
column11: one that will generate more data (thus needing more computing power) than at any time in history. Intel said cars could generate as much as four terabytes of data per day
column12: so it's important cars have the computing power to understand and make sense of all that data.Mobileye is best known for its role in advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS)
column13: having worked with companies like Tesla (TSLA)
column14: GM (GM)
column15: BMW (in conjunction with Intel) and others to bring self-driving cars to the forefront. (In 2017
column16: another 6 OEMs will come online using Mobileye's chips
column17: according to Jefferies analyst David Kelley.)Limited ImpactThis deal isn't likely to hurt Nvidia (NVDA)
column18: which makes GPUs for self-driving cars or Qualcomm (QCOM) or NXP (NXPI)
column19: which also makes chipsets for cars. Chips for ADAS systems and the cameras that go into them is a much smaller market than being the brains of a self-driving car platform. However
column20: it's clear that Intel needed to do something to get into this space
column21: or risk losing out like it did with mobile devices.There is still the risk that car manufacturers will cut Mobileye's units out of its cars (as happened with Tesla)
column22: but with Intel's muscle behind it
column23: that seems less likely to happen. Mobileye has deals with a number of auto manufacturers
column24: including Volkswagen and BMW
column25: enough to get its EyeQ chips into 16 million cars by the end of 2016.Ultimately
column26: this is a deal Intel had to do. It missed out on buying Nvidia when it should have
column27: as it was too focused on the Altera acquisition. It can't buy AMD (AMD) because of the implications for the PC market and -x86 chips.The PC market has had little to no growth for quite some time now
column28: leading PC chip makers to wonder what's next. Intel's latest acquisition of automotive chip maker Mobileye shows that under Brian Krzanich
column29: Intel is focusing on the future -- no matter what it costs."

column1: About to Buy Driverless Car Stocks? Read This First;3/13/2017;"There's no shortage of technology companies and automotive   makers that are are betting that autonomous vehicles will   transform both of their industries. But how do you figure   out which companies are poised to benefit the most?To answer that
column2: investors first need to know what the market   potential is for driverless cars
column3: what might slow it down
column4: and   how long it will take for the segment to mature
column5: and then   determine which driverless car investment angle they want to   take. Here are a few steps to help you get started:Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();How much the driverless car market will be     worthBy 2025
column6: the driverless car market is expected to be worth $42   billion
column7: according to Boston Consulting Group. The market size   jumps up to $77 billion by 2035
column8: which is the same year thatIHSestimates that there will be 76 million autonomous vehicles   already on the road.And it doesn't end there. Driverless cars are expected to   transform ride sharing services
column9: allow car owners to rent out   their own vehicles -- asTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has suggested -- and even help   traditional carmakers create their own ride hailing services
column10: likeFord(NYSE: F) has proposed.This might slow driverless car stocks downIt's not going to be all sunshine and lollipops for driverless   car stocks though. There are still many hurdles facing these   companies
column11: including federal regulations
column12: safety concerns
column13: and   consumer adoption issues.The two biggest automotive markets
column14: however -- the U.S. and   China -- have thus far been very open to driverless cars. Back in   September
column15: the federal government released guidelines for states   to help ensure that companies are able to innovate and not be   hampered by differing rules across state lines. But the problem   is that we're still in the very early stages of driverless   car technology (i.e. neither you nor I can buy fully autonomous   vehicles)
column16: so while the government is open to it now
column17: that could   change when more tech starts being used by the general   population.And even if the government doesn't end up stifling autonomous   vehicles
column18: there's currently a growing movement toban driverless cars in New Yorkbecause people are afraid they'll eliminate jobs for taxi   drivers
column19: bus drivers and others in the transportation sector. Add   to that the fact that there are parts of the population thatfeel very uneasyabout driverless cars and it's clear that the autonomous vehicle   market still has a long way to go.There are plenty of ways to investCompanies like Tesla are among the obvious choices for betting   on driverless cars. CEO Elon Musk has said he wants to have a   fully autonomous car capable of driving itself across the country   by 2018
column20: and every new Tesla built right now already has the   hardware capabilities for full autonomy (though not all of the   software is activated).Tech behemothAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) is another clear choice. Google's   parent company recently spun out its driverless car segment into   its own company
column21: called Waymo
column22: and is working to bring fully autonomous minivans to the roads   this year for public testing
column23: along with a ride-sharing   service.And then there are chipmakers likeNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA)
column24: which is investing heavily in artificial   intelligence and its own supercomputers to power driverless cars.   The company'sDrive PX 2 supercomputeris already used by 80 automakers and automotive suppliers   (including Tesla) and is likely to expand its automotive revenues   substantially in the coming years.Of course
column25: you could go the traditional route too and bet on   automakers like Ford
column26: which is also focusing its attention on   self-driving technologies. The company recently invested $1   billion in a self-driving car start-up
column27: called Argo AI
column28: and says   that it will release its own fully autonomous vehicle (with no   steering wheel!) by 2021.Ford may be taking a slower approach than some other   self-driving tech makers
column29: but it has plans to have 90   self-driving test vehicles on the road this year and is working   with more than 40 start-ups on driverless car technology.And if you're looking for a driverless car stock outside of   the U.S.
column30: thenBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU)  isprobably your best bet. The company has been developing self-driving technology for   years and just launched a test program in some Chinese cities to   implement its tech. The company wants to release a fully   self-driving car by next year with the hopes of having a   ride-hailing service in the coming years. Aside from its   aggressive driverless car approach
column31: Baidu benefits from China's   openness to self-driving technologies and fewer regulations for   road tests than the U.S.Here's how long you might need to wait for this to play     outAlright
column32: so now we know how big this market will be
column33: some of   the potential hurdles
column34: and who the key players are. So how long   will investors have to wait for this opportunity to pan out? IHS   estimates that we'll reach worldwide driverless car ubiquity by   about 2050.That doesn't mean it'll take that long for driverless car   stocks to benefit of course
column35: but it does mean that we still have   a long way to go before the market will mature -- which makes now   the perfect time for investors to start considering driverless   car stocks.10 stocks we like better than NvidiaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Self-Driving Car Race: Intel Buys Mobileye for $15 Billion;3/13/2017;"Intel CorporationINTCon Monday announced it struck a deal to acquire driver assistance technology company Mobileye N.V.MBLYfor roughly $15.3 billion. The deal marks the next step in the driverless car race.Mobileye's stock is up 29.43% in early afternoon trading on Monday to $61.19 per share
column2: near its all-time high. Intel's stock dropped 2.31% to $35.08 per share.Mobileye specializes in chip-based camera systems called ""artificial vision sensors."" The technology alerts drivers in real-time to potential road hazards
column3: like pedestrians. The company claims that the sensor technology is 99% accurate and helps prevent accidents. It is working towards putting this technology into self-driving car technology in the future. Mobileye currently helps support over 15 million vehicles.Israel-based Mobileye was founded in 1999 and it went public in July 2014. The IPO came after Mobileye began to invest in driverless car technology. The company'scurrent market capis nearly $10.5 billion. In amemo to employees
column4: Mobileye executives said Intel's existing automated-driving efforts will be integrated into the company
column5: and existing Israel leaders will head up the efforts.Intel's $15.3 billion acquisition is the biggest ever for an Israeli technology company. The move positions Intel as a ""leading technology provider in the fast-growing market for highly and fully autonomous vehicles
column6: according to a company statement Monday. ""Intel estimates the vehicle systems
column7: data and services market opportunity to be up to $70 billion by 2030.""Mobileye previously worked with Tesla
column8: Inc.TSLAto help power the electric carmaker's Autopilot technology. Thetwo companies parted waysafter a Tesla driver died in a car crash on May 7
column10: while using its Autopilot feature.The deal comes afterMobileye partneredwith self-driving technology company Delphi Automotive in Aug. 2016. The two companies plannedto create an affordable self-driving car platform to sell to carmakers by 2019. In Nov. 2016
column11: Intel announcedthat Mobileye and Delphi would use its processors.Intel
column12: Mobileye and German automaker BMW AG partnered to test 40 self-driving cars
column13: which could possibly lead to production by 2021.Intel's purchase helps the technology giant begin to compete in therace towards autonomous car technology.Last year
column14: in the self-driving race
column15: General MotorsGMspent $1 billion to purchase Cruise Automation. Uber recently bought self-driving truck maker Otto for $680 million. QUALCOMM IncorporatedQCOM
column16: an Intel competitor
column17: recently bought NXP Semiconductors N.V.NXPI
column18: a leading semiconductor supplier to the automotive industry.In Nov. 2016
column19: Samsung Electronics Co. bought Harman International Industries Inc. for $8 billion to move into the automotive vehicle space.Waymo
column20: the self-driving car company that split off from Google's parent company Alphabet Inc.GOOG
column21: asked a federal courtrecently to stop Uber Technologies Inc.'s from developing autonomous vehicles. Waymo claims that Uber stole proprietary design secrets. The lawsuit states that a former manager of Google's self-driving car project took documents before quitting to start the self-driving truck company Otto
column22: which Uber acquired quickly.Intel bought security-software company McAfee Inc. for $7.7 billion in 2011. The company sold McAfee for a major loss in 2016.After missing out on the rise of the smartphone
column23: Intel has fought to try and stay ahead of the next big technology. Intel is betting big on driverless car technology. The company purchased Israel-based 3D video technology company Replay Technologies in March 2016.Intel announcedin April 2016 it would lay off 11% of its workforce to in order to cut costs and to free up capital to invest in new businesses. In January
column24: Intel announced it would purchase a 15% stake in digital mapmaker Here International B.V.
column25: joining BMW AG and Volkswagen AG'sVLKAYAudi
column26: to further the development in the real-time technology needed to improve self-driving car technology.Auto part suppliers are doing well today in the wake of the Intel and Mobileye deal. Lear Corporation'sLEAstock is 1.30% to $46.36+ per share Monday
