column1: 2 Things Tesla Is Doing to Improve Body Repair Times;3/13/2017;"Long body repair times are unfortunately all too common forTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) customers. Third-party body shops often attribute   delays to waiting on parts from Tesla
column2: while Tesla in some cases   says the body shops are responsible for the delays. My own body   repair experience was terrible
column3: lasting acouple days shy of eight months
column4: and Tesla's response provided toElectrekmostly attempted to pin blame on the body shop.Beyond my specific case
column5: the broader issue is that Tesla's   support infrastructure for body repairs is strained. But the good   news is that Tesla is planning on making some much-needed   improvements to how repairs are handled.Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();""applying brute force""In a thread on Tesla Motors Club regarding my article
column6: Tesla   President of Global Sales and Service Jon McNeillposted a responseand outlined a ""roadmap"" for improvement. McNeill noted two   important things that Tesla is planning on doing to improve the   situation (emphasis added):We know from complaints that the body shop experience needs     to get a lot better -- and fast.What the service team has done so far is a roadmap of how     we're going to fix the autobody experience. Wait times for     appointments measured in hours and a handful of days currently.     We're providing same-day service from the Bay Area to Oslo and     everywhere in between. In fact
column7: almost 20% of jobs in our     flagship center in Palo Alto are handled before the customer     can finish their cup of coffee (yes
column8: you read that correctly).Thankfully
column9: only a handful of our owners experience accidents     each year. Since customers schedule and interface with the body     shops on their own
column10: we're largely blind to the service pace.Most of the customer complaints about body shops mentioned     parts
column11: so we focused on this issue. To date
column12: we've reduced     backlog by over 80%.Even though we reduced part wait times
column13: we continued to dig     into the body shop complaints. What we found was astounding --     cars sat at body shops for weeks and sometimes months before     the body shops took action and
column14: more often than not
column15: the body     shops blaming Tesla for parts delays were the very shops that     hadn't even ordered parts or started the repair.We are applying brute force to this immediately.We will have individuals on our team personally manage     each car on behalf of our customers that are in 3rd party body     shops.We're also going to increase our approved shop count by     300 over the next few weeks as well as eliminating poor     performing shops.If you have an issue with a shop
column16: please PM me directly and our     team will advocate and manage your repair.Tesla owners will get the service they expect from us - period.Thanks to the entire service team for their commitment to     setting the highest standard for service in the industry
column17: JonPart of the issue is that since these are third-party body   shops
column18: Tesla has less visibility into the repair timelines. In   order to mitigate this
column19: Tesla will have employees manage the   repair to ensure that everything is proceeding promptly. Having   an advocate should relieve customers of having to try to navigate   the repair. Perhaps more importantly
column20: Tesla is preparing to add   300 authorized body shops to its network in coming weeks
column21: which   should help alleviate backlogs at body shops. It's not clear how   many third-party authorized body shops Tesla currently has
column22: but   adding more will certainly help.Strengthening the customer support infrastructure is extremely   important ahead of Model 3's launch later this year. Tesla has   learned its lessons from making Model S and Model X overly   complicated
column23: which is why it is taking a more holistic approach   to Model 3 by designing the car from the beginning for both   manufacturability and reparability.Tesla is planning on ordering enough parts from suppliers to   start producing 1
column24: 000 Model 3 vehicles per week in July
column25: and this   will quickly ramp to 2
column26: 000 per week in August and 4
column27: 000 per week   in September. By the end of the year
column28: Tesla hopes to be producing   5
column29: 000 per week
column30: which would translate into an annual run rate of   over a quarter million vehicles as it enters 2018. In contrast
column31: Tesla produced approximately 84
column32: 000 vehicles in 2016. That's a   lot more vehicles on the road to support
column33: so getting ahead of   service and repair times will be a key factor in whether or not   the mainstream model succeeds.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: The Simple Reason Why I Won't Buy Tesla;3/11/2017;"Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) is
column2: arguably
column3: the quintissential story stock. I   know
column4: I know... that's not exactly a revelation at this point.   Elon Musk set out to create a world powered by renewable energy   and filled with electric vehicles
column5: told us about how great it   would be
column6: made itsexy
column7: and now we can't get enough of the vision. But it has its   drawbacks -- such as having an impossible-to-justify   valuation.When confronted with Tesla's ridiculous valuation
column8: bullish   investors counter that there's no comparison to what Musk is   building with the brand. That's true
column9: but I find the argument to   be dangerous
column10: not because I don't appreciate what the company is   attempting to accomplish
column11: but because analysts and investors   aren't appreciating that the company could fail to accomplish   what it's attempting.A gaudy (and simply ridiculous) valuation is the simple reason   why I won't buy Tesla
column12: and I think other investors may feel the   same way.makeArticleAd();Image source: Tesla.Price is what you payThe just-released full-year 2016 earnings showed impressive   year-over-year growth and promised even more in the first-half of   2017. The Model 3 launch in July and subsequent production   ramp-up in the fourth quarter of this year have the potential to   really push growth to the next level.Throw in a simultaneous ramp-up of energy storage products   from Gigafactory 1
column13: and it's easy to see why investors are   excited. But is all of this worth$40 billion of excitement?Tesla is now worth nearly as much asFord Motor CompanyandGeneral Motors-- established automakers that sell more cars in less than one   month than the company did in all of 2016.TSLA Market Capdata byYCharts.Investors could argue that offering the first mass-market   electric vehicle earns Tesla its enormous valuation
column14: but it's not   a very good argument. Ford and General Motors -- and most major   automakers -- are readying electric vehicles for market launches   in the next several years. Many have plans to greatly expand   their offerings of electric vehicles in the next 10 to 15   years.For instance
column15: the Chevy Bolt
column16: which has a starting price of   $37
column17: 495 and offers a 238-mile range
column18: promises to give the Model 3   a run for its money. It became available in two states last   December and will increase its footprint this year.Meanwhile
column19: Ford has an""electrification"" strategythat will gradually transition the automaker to hybrid and fully   electric vehicles over the next decade. The Ford Fusion Energi   was the fourth best-selling electric vehicle in the United States   through the first 10 months of last year.In addition to direct competition
column20: electric vehicles sold by   companies other than Tesla will eat away at the company's revenue   stream provided by Zero Emission Vehicle (ZEV) credits
column21: which are   sold to comply with regulatory obligations in certain states. In   2016
column22: these accounted for $302 million in revenue. It may not   seem like much
column23: but given the revenue is essentially cost free
column24: ZEV credit sales accounted for 19% of the company's gross profit   last year.What about non-transportation growth?Investors could argue that
column25: aside from leading the way on   electric vehicles
column26: Tesla's hefty valuation is partially earned   from leading the way in solar power and energy storage. The   annual update letter certainly showed impressive growth last   year.What it didn't show is that the company appears to be   abandoning plans to manufacture Silveo modules
column27: and will instead   purchase ""custom made modules"" from Panasonic
column28: according to an   agreement signed in December 2016. That could result in a   significant writedown of the acquisition costs and technology   development.The update letter also doesn't mention that Tesla's   energy-storage ambitionsaren't realistic from a technical standpoint. In addition to thermodynamic obstacles from specific   lithium-ion chemistries
column29: researchers who have crunched all of the   detailed numbers don't think there will be much -- if any --   battery cost-reduction benefit from building larger battery   factories. That should make investors a little uncomfortable
column30: especially considering cost reductions were a crucial argument   defending billions of dollars in expenses for building   Gigafactory 1.Why Tesla isn't for meTesla's reliance on storytelling is offputting to me
column31: doubly   so when it results in a $40 billion market cap that is impossible   to really justify. Investors continue to overvalue the potential   of imaginative solar roofs and uneconomical residential energy   storage. However
column32: the real drivers for the company's renewable   energy strategy are more likely to be riding the continued growth   in traditional residential solar and selling energy storage   products into niche markets
column33: such as peak demand stop gaps for   utility companies. Even then
column34: the market opportunity is less --   and the competition more -- than investors properly gauge.Shareholders today may benefit from the Musk Halo Effect --   which attaches a premium valuation to
column35: or boosts
column36: public goodwill   of companies and projects he's involved with -- but that doesn't   mean investors should bank on it lasting indefinitely. It's the   simple reason why I won't be buying Tesla.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: How Tesla Can Fix Its Flawed Solar Business;3/11/2017;"Tesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) acquisition of SolarCity was touted as a way to   vertically integrate the EV company into a one-stop renewable   energy provider for customers. Walk in a Tesla retail store
column2: and   you can walk out with an electric car run on electricity from   your roof that was stored all day in your Powerwall.The reality of solar in 2017 is that SolarCity's business   model is dying. The lease/power purchase agreement (PPA) that   made SolarCity so popular in the first place is being replaced by   loan and cash sales
column3: which are better served by smaller   installers. Sales are becoming harder as the low-hanging fruit   has already been nabbed by a highly competitive industry. The old   SolarCity isn't what it used to be.What's interesting are the new solar products that SolarCity   started working on
column4: and Tesla is finishing. The solar   manufacturing plant that's supposed to build high-efficiency   solar panels in Buffalo
column5: New York
column6: and the new solar roof   product
column7: which will eventually pair with the Powerwall to create   a holistic energy solution are a path forward for Tesla. But the   installation and sales wings of the solar business have become a   weight Tesla should no longer be willing to hold.makeArticleAd();Tesla's solar roof is a big product coming in 2017. Image     source: Tesla.Tesla should cut thousands of jobsThis sounds dramatic
column8: but don't worry
column9: there's still lots of   work for people to do installing Tesla solar systems. However
column10: maybe it doesn't make sense for them to do that work under   Tesla's umbrella.When SolarCity built out its solar business
column11: it put most of   its work into building out a sales force that could sell solar   systems and an installation force that could put them up. The   large
column12: national solar model was working and did until the end of   2015. But
column13: according to GTM Research
column14: the top three solar installers in the country grew at just 10%   in 2016 while all other installers grew 53%. Tesla/SolarCity's   decline is even more pronounced with deployments falling from253 MW in Q4 2015to201 MW in Q4 2016.Image source:GTM Research.This isn't necessarily a problem because Tesla would like to   automate the sales process
column15: or move it into Tesla's stores. So
column16: it makes sense for fewer for Tesla workers to be selling   door-to-door the way SolarCity did.On the installation side
column17: Tesla could offload work to hundreds   of contracting partners the do the actual installation work   rather than having the team in-house. Owning the installation   side of the business means Tesla is taking on the operating costs   of hiring workers and buying installation equipment
column18: and it has   to constantly keep those workers busy. If this work was   contracted out
column19: it would lower risk and potentially lower costs   as contractors compete for business.This wouldn't be a novel approach. Most of the construction   business works on this contractor model
column20: whether it's building a   home or replacing a roof or a kitchen. And with small solar   installers taking market share from Tesla
column21: it would be wise for   it to lower its operating risk.The Powerwall could be the center of a new solar strategy at     Tesla. Image source: Tesla.Create a pre-engineered solution that can     scaleIf Tesla moved to a business model that contracted out work
column22: it would need to create an easy-to-install solution for   contractors. And that is already on the way with the   development of the Powerwall and the solar panels made in-house.   Soon
column23: Tesla will be more vertically integrated than any other   full service solar company (including energy storage) so the   company could offer a suite of solutions few companies could even   dream of matching.Gigafactory 2
column24: the Buffalo solar plant
column25: will soon be making   solar panels
column26: and Tesla now owns the racking company for solar   systems. These products could be pre-engineered into a solution   that would be sold to smaller contractors. Even the Powerwall   would fit into this model
column27: and Tesla could provide services to be   the brains behind making the Powerwall economically viable.The Solar Roof could be another extension of this model
column28: a   product that could be sold through contractors without having to   train in-house installers on the product.Creating a pre-engineered solution for contractors could   create a highly scalable business for Tesla
column29: which would   potentially lead to a bigger solar footprint overall
column30: which is   Musk's goal
column31: after all.Ditch the solar leaseIf Tesla is serious about turning the solar business into a   cash-flow business
column32: it should eliminate the lease
column33: or power   purchase agreement. This would be turning its back on the   financing model that made SolarCity popular
column34: but the lease is   losing market share rapidly
column35: and it's not a product Tesla wants   to have on its balance sheet anyway.Lease financing has become unattractive over time becauseSolarCity's borrowing costs were rising. Without low borrowing costs the lease has no advantage over a   loan and with loan rates on the decline there no reason to keep   the lease in the portfolio.If Tesla moved to a contractor model for installations
column36: it   could offload the financing of solar systems to third-party   banks
column37: who are already entering the market
column38: and count on cash up   front with each sale. This way
column39: management and investors could   judge the solar business on its margins and cash-flow generation   rather than a questionable metric like retained value.Tesla would be better with a more focused solar     businessIf Elon Musk wants to create a successful solar business long   term
column40: he should de-risk the business by getting out of   installation and high-intensity sales. Instead
column41: focusing the   company on making great products and providing the services   contractors need to sell them would be a move in the right   direction. Investors would likely cheer the move.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: The 5 Biggest Challenges to the Driverless Car Revolution;3/11/2017;"The year 2017 is gearing up to be a momentous year for the   driverless car race. But despite major initiatives by   megacorporationsAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column2: Tesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column3: and others
column4: there are major road blocks ahead   for the driverless car revolution. A recentMcKinseyreport highlights five of them.1. PricingNo matter how incredible an innovation might be
column5: it's useless   if it's not affordable. Although Alphabet's Waymo has clocked   more than 2 million road miles in its autonomous vehicles
column6: McKinsey estimates that self-driving cars are ""unlikely to be   available before 2020."" Alphabet and others are inching closer to   commercializing their products. A partnership withFiat Chrysler Automobiles NV(NYSE: FCAU) will
column7: for the first time
column8: take Alphabet's autonomous   driving technology out of its peculiar ""panda car"" and into 100   Pacifica Hybrid minivans in early 2017. But those minivans aren't   for sale
column9: and
column10: if they were
column11: would probably cost magnitudes more   than an average minivan.2. Consumer UnderstandingmakeArticleAd();Video source: Waymo viaYouTubeEven if driverless cars become affordable
column12: no one will buy   them if they don't understand them. That means that self-driving   car companies need to educate consumers on the advantages of   autonomous vehicles. Informational videos like the one above   produced by Alphabet's Waymo are an important start
column13: and others   like Tesla Motors are producing their ownvideo vignettesto make self-driving cars salient. Tesla Motors and others have a   clear business incentive to make self-driving seem mainstream
column14: and the more that their message is spread
column15: the brighter the   future for their sales and sustainability.3. Safety/Security issuesConsumer understanding goes hand in hand with a major concern   about autonomous technology -- safety and security. At no point   was this clearer than in May 2016
column16: when Tesla Motors reported the   first driver fatality while its Autopilot technology was engaged.   The tragic crash occurred when neither the driver nor Tesla   Motors' technology recognized a truck's white-colored trailer   crossing its path on a highway. There will certainly be more   tragedies in the future of autonomous vehicles
column17: and it will   remain a continuing challenge and the highest priority for   self-driving car companies to minimize safety and security   issues. However
column18: it's also important to remember that these   high-profile cases can cause over-reactions
column19: and sticking to   statistics can help investors
column20: companies
column21: and consumers alike   identify the best autonomous option for investing
column22: manufacturing
column23: and purchasing.4 & 5: Regulation and TechnologyAs with all new innovations
column24: regulation and technology can   make or break a revolution. The McKinsey report is quick to note   that regulation is a hurdle
column25: rather than a never-ending issue. It   makes sense
column26: then
column27: that Ford
column28: Alphabet
column29: Lyft
column30: Uber
column31: and Volvo   Cars have all joined together to create the ""Self-Driving Coalition for Safer Streets."" Rather than rally for ""wild west"" free market competition
column32: these companies want to see a sensible framework of standardized   regulation upon which they can confidently build their new   business units.Technology isn't a hurdle
column33: but there is a minimum threshold   below which driverless cars will never be the norm. Companies   like Alphabet's Waymo and Tesla Motors are aiming for full   autonomy
column34: while others are taking the more step-wise approach of   offering semi-autonomous additions like Audi's ""Traffic Jam   Assist."" The McKinsey report estimates that
column35: once regulation and   technology issues have been resolved
column36: ""up to 15 percent of new   cars sold in 2030 could be fully autonomous.""Hit the brakes?Image Source: Getty Images.2017 will not be the year self-driving cars take over our   roads. Pricing
column37: consumer understanding
column38: safety/security
column39: regulation
column40: and technology issues will continue to impede this   industry's revolution. But Alphabet
column41: Tesla Motors
column42: and others are   making steady gains on addressing these issues
column43: and the ultimate   widespread adoption of autonomous technology is almost   inarguable. Forward-looking investors with long-term horizons   should acknowledge these issues
column44: select their self-driving stocks   accordingly
column45: and sit back to enjoy this multi-year market road   trip.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: 3 Beaten-up Driverless Cars Stocks: Are They Bargains?;3/10/2017;"By now you probably know that the driverless car is poised for huge growth in the coming years
column2: hitting an estimated market size of $77 billion by 2035.Companies spanning the technology and automotive sectors are jumping on board to ensure that they don't fall behind dominant players likeNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) andTesla. Investors looking for driverless cars stocks that both have huge potentialandare bargains should considerBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU)
column3: Ford(NYSE: F)
column4: andDelphi Automotive(NYSE: DLPH) .makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.BaiduOver the past few years
column5: Baidu has been working on self-driving vehicle technology and positioning itself to be a leader in the autonomous car space in China. Late last year
column6: the company set up a real-world test of its driverless cars with 200 members of the public. It was one of the first of its kind in China
column7: and was one of the biggest self-driving car moves Baidu made since first testing its autonomous vehicles.The company plans to launch a self-driving shuttle service as early as next year
column8: with the goal of mass producing driverless cars by 2021.Image source:YCharts.Unfortunately for Baidu
column9: the company's stock has remained flat over the past 12 months
column10: with less than 1% gains.. In the company's most recent fourth-quarter 2016 earnings report
column11: revenues fell by 2.6%
column12: mainly due to increasing regulations by the Chinese government on how it conducts online searches.But despite the temporary hit to revenue and margins
column13: Baidu's long-term position as a search powerhouse in China and a leader in driverless car technology remains intact.Baidu has a small fleet of semi-autonomous vehicles and has plans to launch more later this year. The company is partnering with NVIDIA to pair its mapping data with NVIDIA's driverless technologies
column14: which should enhance Baidu's driverless capabilities. Add to that the company's relatively low forward P/E ratio of just 23 (compared to the tech industry average of 26) and Baidu looks like a bargain right now.FordFord is taking a slow-and-steady approach to the driverless car market. The company talks a lot about wanting to make sure its technology is safe for its customers before it releases it out into the wild.But that doesn't mean Ford is lagging behind the competition. The company says it'll have a fleet of about 90 autonomous vehicles -- up from 30 -- by the end of this year

column1: Breaking Down Tesla's Inventory Increase;3/9/2017;"Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) reported fourth-quarter earnings last month

column4: a sequential increase from $1.6 billion in the prior   quarter.The breakdown of inventory isn't disclosed until the   subsequent 10-Q or 10-K is filed after earnings
column5: and Tesla filed   its 10-K earlier this month. Investors can now see the moving   parts.Tesla is now sitting on $1 billion in finished goodsFor starters

column7: combining both companies'   balance sheets. SolarCity had about $172.7 million worth of total   inventory (consisting primarily of $141 million in raw materials   and $31.8 million in work in progress) at the end of the year
column8: which accounts for a portion of the sequential increase.Image source: Tesla.Since SolarCity does not have a finished goods category for   its inventory
column9: we can safely say that the notable increase of   about $225 million in finished goods is coming from the   automotive side. column12: and   energy storage products."" Tesla keeps minimal inventory on hand   relative to traditional car dealers

Image source: Tesla.Investors do know that Tesla has been growing its   international sales -- total revenue outside the United States   grew 34% to $2.8 billion in 2016 -- and those orders take longer   to get to their new homes abroad. Reflecting this

column23: which would   suggest that approximately $100 million of the increase can be   tied to the increase in in-transit vehicles.The rest of the increase can probably be explained by a modest   increase in stores and service locations (14 new locations opened   during the quarter) and associated inventory models and loaners

column1: Bullish on NVIDIA? You'll Love These Stocks;3/9/2017;"Investors kind of have crush onNVIDIA Corporation(NASDAQ: NVDA) . The company has posted quarter after quarter of   strong sales
column2: grown gaming GPU market share
column3: introduced new   driverless car technologies
column4: and expanded its artificial   intelligence (AI) opportunities -- all of which have led   investors to swoon to the stock

column7: and   driverless cars
column8: then perhaps you should giveAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column9: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column10: andSony(NYSE: SNE) a good look as well. These companies aren't making   the exact same moves as NVIDIA
column11: but each is poised to dominate   one of these segments in their own way.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();An alternative artificial intelligence playNVIDIA is alreadytaking big stepsto make AI a priority through its investments in deep learning   technologies like Drive PX 2 (for cars) and servers   (DGX-1). But it's not the only one who will benefit from the   tech sector's focus on AI. Just look at the size of the   artificial intelligence market over the next few years (hint:   there's plenty of room for lots of winners).Data source:TracticaandStatista.And this is where Amazon comes in. The company has a dedicated   AI team that's already up to the ""thousands
column12: according to   Amazon
column13: and an AI focus that hits both the consumer and   enterprise markets.Amazon's Echo may seem like just another consumer product
column14: but   powering the unit is the company's Alexa virtual assistant. Alexa   can answer basic questions
column15: set alarms
column16: check the weather
column17: play   music
column18: and order items from Amazon (of course!). However
column19: Alexa   has also been opened to developers so that other companies can   integrate the AI into their own devices and services
column20: and it has   even started a fund to supply capital to companies that are doing   so.Amazon won't get rich off of selling Alexa-powered devices
column21: but the assistant is giving the company a leg up in the home   automation space. Amazon is using its AI virtual assistant   to grow its own ecosystem
column22: and it's clear from new rumors ofupcoming Alexa-powered devicesand continual integration of Alexa into other products that the   company will continue to use this AI to tie consumers to its   business.The real AI play for Amazon will be through its web hosting   services
column23: AWS.  The company released several new AI services   to developers at its re:Invent conference a few months ago
column24: including an image-recognition platform and a text-to-speech   service. And
column25: most importantly
column26: the company released a program   that allows developers to create AI chatbots capable of   multilevel conversations
column27: similar to Alexa.These are all important because as Amazon releases these tools   into the wild
column28: it expects to be paid back through developers   using those AI systems by hosting them through AWS.Amazon brought in $3.53 billion with AWS in Q4 2016 -- an   increase of 47% year over year -- and with more complex AI   systems being built now and into the future
column29: the company will   benefit from all of those AI systems needing a robust cloud   hosting service.Don't expect Amazon's AI strategies to be an immediate payoff
column30: but the company is taking big steps now with Alexa and its AI   tools for developers to build a strong artificial intelligence   foundation for the future.An alternative driverless car playNVIDIA bulls know that driverless cars will likely play a big   role in the company's future
column31: and part of that opportunity stems   from the company's recent partnership with electric car maker   Tesla. The automaker's self-driving technologies are powered   by NVIDIA's Drive PX 2 supercomputer
column32: along with Tesla's own   ""neural net for vision
column33: sonar
column34: and radar processing.""Tesla's driverless car play is a bit more hands-on than   NVIDIA's
column35: but it's no less important. CEO Elon Musk has said   that his company will bring a fully autonomous vehicle to market   by 2018
column36: and he has also mentioned that Tesla owners will be able   torent out their autonomous vehiclesin the near future
column37: when they're not using them.That's more than just lip service
column38: of course. Tesla already   manufactures its latest models with fully autonomous hardware   built into every new vehicle
column39: and it's slowly releasing new   software updates as it gathers more driving data. All of this   hardware -- and the release of new software -- means Tesla is   already a few steps ahead of the driverless car competition.An alternative gaming and VR playOf course
column40: gaming is one of NVIDIA's biggest opportunities.   The company already brings in 62% of its total revenue from its   gaming segment
column41: and the growing virtual reality market could help   NVIDIA continue its gaming success. By 2020
column42: the VR market will   be worth an estimated $70 billion.Investors looking for an alternative VR play should consider   Sony's recent lead in the space. The company released its first   VR headset just four months ago
column43: and it recently reported that it   has already sold 915
column44: 000 units. For comparison's sake
column45: the   Oculus Rift has sold an estimated 243
column46: 000 units
column47: and the HTC   Vive has sold 420
column49: according to Superdata Research.That's notable because Sony's PlayStation VR headset sales are   one of the first huge hardware successes for VR
column50: and they are on   track to surpass the company's own estimate of selling 1 million   headset in the first six months.Still
column51: hardware VR sales will eventually be eclipsed by VR   software sales
column52: and that's why Sony truly has a great opportunity   in virtual reality. The company is already working with 230   developers and content creators to build VR games and content for   its gaming console
column53: and it already has more than 70 VR games.Sony has identified virtual reality as one of the keys tobuilding out its important Game and Network   Services division
column54: and the initial numbers from its VR headset sales are a good   indicator that the company is moving quickly in that   direction.Of course
column55: there's no guarantee the stocks listed above will   have the same success NVIDIA's had recently. Nor are Amazon

column59: and virtual   reality

column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe vernal equinox marks the first day of spring and it is almost upon us.makeArticleAd();One of the most important days of the calendar is the date in which we turn the leaf from the long
column3: cold haze that the winter season consists of
column4: to the warm embrace of green leaves and pretty flowers that the spring brings with it.The vernal equinox is considered to be the first day of spring
column5: according to the Roman calendar. It is also known as the March equinox
column6: or the autumnal equinox in the Southern hemisphere
column7: as it marks the beginning of fall in the lower half of the world.It is the date in which the Sun crosses the celestial equator
column8: which is an imaginary line in the sky above the Earth's equator. The view happens from south to north and it usually takes place between March 19 and the 21st.This year
column9: the vernal equinox will take place on Monday

column1: Residential Solar Revolution: Why National Installers Aren't Evolving Fast Enough;3/9/2017;"Just over two years ago
column2: nearly three-quarters of residential   solar companies used third-party financing in the form of leases   or power purchase agreements to finance their solar systems. Now
column3: according toGTM Research
column4: that number fell to just 47% last quarter and the decline shows   no sign of slowing down.This has caused an upheaval for installers built on the   leasing model
column5: whether they'll admit it or not. SolarCity was in   trouble untilTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) bought it out
column6: andVivint Solar(NYSE: VSLR) andSunrun(NASDAQ: RUN) haven't been able to turn their leasing businesses   into sustainably profitable businesses
column7: either. With the   financing trends changing
column8: these companies need to find a new   direction forward.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Changing gears in residential solarI don't think the transition from selling solar systems with   leases to selling them with loans can be done over time because   the companies I mentioned have too much financial incentive to   sell leases rather than loans. Tesla is trying to make the   transition
column9: but its installations are declining
column10: and it was still   only 28% sales and 72% leases last quarter.Instead
column11: national installers need to rip off the Band-Aid:   Ditch the lease and replace it with a loan product that will be   easy for customers to understand. This will bring in cash   immediately and reduce confusion for customers.Another step they can take to transition their businesses and   generate cash is selling the portfolio of leased assets they have   sitting on the balance sheet. There are a number of yieldcos that   would love to own those residential solar assets at the right   price. And even if the price isn't perfect
column12: installers should   want to sell their financing assets to focus on lowering   installation costs.The third transition all solar companies need to make is think   about differentiation. Financing was a differentiator a few years   ago
column13: but if cash or loan sales are the dominant financing model
column14: what separates Vivint from Sunrun
column15: or anyone else at this   point?Tesla is making the case that it's different with an upcoming   solar panel
column16: the Powerwall
column17: and the solar roof that's supposed to   launch this summer. If these products are successful
column18: they will   create a path to the future.Sunrun and Vivint Solar have tested some new products like   energy storage
column19: but they need to double down on the next   generation. Vivint may be well served integrating more fully with   its sister company's security solutions. Sunrun would be wise to   partner with a high-efficiency solar panel manufacturer and an   energy storage company to differentiate itself.Financial results are starting to dragWith the market moving away from the national installer model
column20: financials are starting to look worse for these installers. Tesla   said it installed just 803 MW of solar in 2016
column21: down from an   original guidance of 1.25 GW. Vivint Solar's third quarter (the   most recent reported) saw installations fall from 61 MW a year   ago to 59 MW as it focused on leases. And while Sunrun is growing   more than the other two and has added cash and loan products
column22: it   has the highest costs of the three
column23: which should lead to lower   margins overall. It also has a clear incentive to push customers   toward the more profitable lease.Industry data shows that the solar lease is dying
column24: and solar   installers need to adapt. I think that will require a paradigm   shift in how they think about their business
column25: or they'll get run   over by competitors who adapt more quickly.10 stocks we like better than SunrunWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column26: it can pay to listen. After all
column27: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column28: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column29: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Sunrun wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column30: 2017.Travis Hoiumhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Tesla. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column3: Inc.TSLAlaunched a solar project in Hawaii

column5: using its panels and giant battery packs at the farm.makeArticleAd();The solar farm comprises 54
column6: 978 solar panels
column7: which have 13 megawatts of solar generation capacity as well as 272 52-megawatt-hour Tesla Powerpack lithium-ion battery storage systems. Tesla has installed these batteries in order to store the solar energy which can be used during night.Under the terms of the collaboration

It will include a 28-megawatt solar farm and a 20-megawatt five-hour duration energy storage system. This will be the biggest battery system globally.The solar project in Hawaii demonstrates Tesla's effort to transform into a one-stop-shop for clean energy consumers. column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is a Jekyll-and-Hyde Trade Right Now;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsShares ofApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) are higher by a solid 20% year-to-date
column3: and AAPL stock is up 40% over the past 12 months. Making ""bets"" on a stock based on its recent percentage moves doesn't make much sense
column4: though
column5: in a raging risk-on environment such as we've seen since last November.makeArticleAd();Over my career
column6: I have found that applying a multi-time-frame approach to stock trading and investing not only allows for better perspective
column7: but as a result
column8: also results in superior risk management - and dare I say ""timing"" of trade entries and exits.I make it a point in this column to often remind ye faithful that stocks are a highly correlated asset class
column9: particularly compared to other asset classes such as commodities. While the price of pork bellies has little correlation with the price of gold
column10: within the stock market
column11: around 80% of stocks tend to rise and fall together at any given time. I point this out because while the year-to-date rally in AAPL stock is impressive and worth respecting until it reverses
column12: there also has been a broader stock market risk-on trade thus far in 2017.More than anything
column13: I highlight this for perspective.When I last discussed Apple stock onFeb. 2following the latest earnings report
column14: I said that shares were reaching a critical technical area of resistance through a multimonth lens. While AAPL has since marginally pushed above this technical area
column15: the tale of two time frames remains.7 Cheap Dividend Stocks to Buy NowToday
column16: I would like to reiterate and update this analysis.AAPL Stock ChartsOn the multiyear weekly chart
column17: we see that Apple over the years has greatly respected its 200-week simple moving average (red)
column18: which was a source of technical support in 2013 and again just last year.Click to EnlargeAt the same time
column19: we also see that each time AAPL stock gets overly extended above this moving average
column20: it tends to fall into a consolidation phase. Currently
column21: the stock trades roughly 30% above this moving average; at past extremes
column22: Apple traded as much as 50% above it.From this perspective
column23: AAPL stock could have further to run on the upside.On the other hand
column24: the MACD momentum oscillator at the bottom of the chart has now reached levels that in the past led to some downside pressure.Lastly - and I believe most importantly - the rate of change (i.e.
column25: the near-vertical rally over the past couple months) has pushed AAPL stock back above its 2015 highs. While this in and of itself is a positive development
column26: previous important highs rarely if ever are overcome on a sustainable basis until and unless some consolidation near those previous highs has taken place.Apple stock has yet to consolidate. Thus
column27: it likely will find the current upside momentum unsustainable over the next few weeks or even months.Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8: New Name
column28: Late Release?On the daily chart
column29: we see that AAPL gapped higher again following its Jan. 31 earnings report
column30: and despite already being overbought by plenty of measures
column31: kept pushing higher as the broader stock market animal spirits brought in fresh momentum.Click to EnlargeNote that except for a couple days in early January
column32: AAPL stock has now held above its 8-day simple moving average (blue) since early December 2016. That is alongstretch to be trading above such a near-term moving average. I feel it increasingly begs for some consolidation lower.At the same time
column33: until this moving average is broken on the downside
column34: one must continue to respect the uptrend.Through this near-term lens
column35: if AAPL can close above $140
column36: a next squeeze higher into $143 - $144 looks plausible. Alternatively
column37: a break and hold below $138.50 could set in motion a better consolidation move lower with first downside targets near $136 and $132.Like what you see? column1: Is Realty Income Corp (O) the Best REIT Right Now?;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsRealty Income Corp(NYSE:O) is a real estate investment trust
column3: or REIT. It is one of the leading REITs in the retail sector and is one of the most consistent total-return REITs in the business.makeArticleAd();The question is whether retail REITs are the best place to be right now. With the growth of online shopping and the challenges many big box retailers are experiencing
column4: buying a stock in a firm that owns the property and buildings in the sector where a massive long-term disruption is taking place may not be the best choice.But that isn't O.O specializes in stand-alone retail spaces. For example
column5: its biggest tenant isWalgreens Boots Alliance Inc(NYSE:WBA). Its second largest client isFedEx Corporation(NYSE:FDX). Other major tenants includeCVS Health Corp(NYSE:CVS)
column6: Home Depot Inc(NYSE:HD) andDollar General Inc(NYSE:DG)
column7: to name a few.O's biggest competitor isSimon Property Group Inc(NYSE:SPG)
column8: which is almost 4x the size of O by market cap.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Lows in 2017The biggest difference between the two is that SPG focuses on shopping malls
column9: where O focuses on stand-alone businesses.That means O is in much better shape with its tenants than SPG is. Realty Income Corp has tenants that are not as challenged by online competition. And
column10: since its tenants don't rely on other tenants on the property
column11: it's much clearer the kind of revenue stream they need to make it profitable.SPG is at the whim of consumers and tenants alike. For example
column12: it's not unusual for smaller malls to have both aSears Holding Corp(NASDAQ:SHLD) and aJ C Penney Company Inc(NYSE:JCP) anchoring the rest of the mall. If the Sears leaves
column13: you have a problem. If the JC Penney leaves as well
column14: you have a disaster.This is the biggest challenge today. The mall concept is losing steam. The stores that are locked into leases for space in these malls will either walk away
column15: close up shop or request a rent adjustment given the new circumstances.Whatever option you choose
column16: it is bad news for SPG.But O is freed from all that bother. Its tenants are growing
column17: not contracting. They operate their own businesses and their models have been proven from small towns to big cities.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Continues to Ignore the Elephant in the RoomThis is the significant difference between it and others in the retail space.Its dividend is a solid 4.3% and O stock is focused on maintaining it and raising it. The stock has been treading water for the past 12 months
column18: but its numbers continue to impress. Some analysts are concerned that its valuation is too high
column19: but given the fact that it operates one of the best REIT portfolios out there
column20: it should be higher than say
column21: SPG and others.Now is a great time to pick this REIT up at a good price.Richard Band'sProfitable Investingadvisory service helps retirement savers outperform the market without losing a minute of sleep along the way. His straightforward style and low-risk value approach has won seven Best Financial Advisory awards from the Newsletter and Electronic Publishers Foundation.More From InvestorPlace5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Buy in MarchThe 7 Best ETFs for Market-Beating ReturnsThe postIs Realty Income Corp (O) the Best REIT Right Now?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why It's So Important for Tesla to Shift to Solar Sales as Quickly as Possible;3/8/2017;"One of the most prominent criticisms of SolarCity prior to   being acquired byTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) was that the solar installer had a cash flow   problem.This situation was created by the fact that SolarCity rose to   become the No. 1 installer largely through its leasing model
column2: which offered customers solar power at little to no upfront cost.   But that required the company to invest its own money upfront   into systems that it would subsequently monetize through lease   payments and power purchase agreements (PPAs) over the course of   decades.By its own admission
column3: SolarCity focused too heavily on growing   its MW deployments

column1: How Tesla Created an Opportunity for Bentley Motors to go Electric;3/8/2017;"British hyper-luxury brand Bentley Motors brought a surprise   to the Geneva Motor Show this week: an electric car.For now
column2: the Bentley EXP 12 Speed 6e Concept
column3: as it's called
column4: is strictly for show. But it's a show car with a mission: To help   Bentley decide if it's time to grab an opportunity it sees for an   electric luxury car positioned above the products fromTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) .The Bentley EXP 12 Speed 6e Concept could point the way to     the British super-luxury brand's first battery-electric     vehicle. Image source: Bentley Motors.makeArticleAd();What it is: A Bentley
column5: only electricThe EXP 12 Speed 6e is a high-performance convertible with the   craftsmanship and interior details that are typical of Bentley   (that is to say
column6: exquisite). It has the usual high-tech touches
column7: but done Bentley's way: The interior is swathed in   fine leather
column8: wood
column9: and hand-cut glass.Leather
column10: wood
column11: glass
column12: and over-the-top details? The EXP 12     Speed 6e is definitely a Bentley. Image source: Bentley     Motors.Bentley said that a production version would have rapid   inductive charging and ""a range sufficient for grand touring   requirements."" But didn't give details of the car's powertrain or   specifics on its battery or range
column13: because this isn't intended to   be a production car.Instead
column14: as Bentley CEO Wolfgang Durheimer explained
column15: this   Bentley is intended to be a starting point for conversations with   potential customers:The EXP 12 Speed 6e is a concept to show that Bentley is     defining electric motoring in the luxury sector
column16: with the     appropriate technology
column17: high quality materials and refinement     levels you'd expect from a true Bentley. This concept enables     us to engage with luxury customers and gather feedback on our     approach.Bentley is committed to offering an electric model in its     future portfolio and we are interested to receive feedback on     this concept.In an interview at the Geneva Motor Show
column18: Durheimer toldBloombergthat part of the idea is to find out if it's time for Bentley to   develop an electric model -- or if its customers will continue to   be happy with combustion engines and hybrids for the time being.   (Bentley will roll out its first plug-in hybrid next year.) If   the electric concept is well-received
column19: Bentley could have an   electric model on the market by 2021
column20: he said.But whether it turns out to be the right time or not
column21: an   electric Bentley is coming
column22: thanks to an opportunity created by   Tesla.Why Tesla's success creates an opening for an electric   BentleyBentley
column23: like other super-luxury brands
column24: is eyeing the market   segment above vehicles like Tesla's Model S and Model X. Those   Teslas are broadly competitive with the upper-tier models from   luxury brands likeBMWand Mercedes-Benz in terms of performance and features (and   price). But there's space for something even more luxurious.Brands like Bentley
column25: and its British competitors Rolls-Royce   and Aston Martin
column26: have for many years found a small but   profitable market in luxury cars that are a step up from the   likes of BMW and Mercedes. Now
column27: they seean opportunity to build carsfor well-heeled
column28: electric-car enthusiasts who might be happy   Tesla owners today
column29: but might also be interested in an   opportunity to move up to something more deluxe
column30: more   personalized.Bentley's typical attention to hand-crafted detail is far     from ordinary
column31: even by Tesla or BMW standards. Image source:     Bentley Motors.To credibly appeal to Tesla owners
column32: Bentley will have to   incorporate high-quality technology into its eventual electric   car. That shouldn't be a problem: Bentley Motors is owned by   giantVolkswagen AG(NASDAQOTH: VLKAY)
column33: and will presumably take advantage of the   battery-electric technology being developed for its sibling   brands
column34: Audi and Porsche.That technology is thought to be quite advanced: Audi plans to   launch a battery-electric SUV aimed directly at Tesla's Model Xearly next year. An electric Porsche sports sedan is expected to followabout a year later.It may or may not exactly match Tesla's technology. But it   should be close enough to satisfy customers drawn to Bentley's   other attributes -- customers that will be interested in an   electric Bentley largely because of Tesla's success.Another view of the Bentley EXP 12 Speed 6e Concept. Image     source: Bentley Motors.So will Bentley go electric?I think it's likely that Bentley will go electric. The total   world market for such a Bentley might only be a few thousand   models a year
column35: at most -- at least at first. But this is a brand   that sold a grand total 11
column36: 023 cars worldwide last year. Given   that an electric Bentley would be using technology sourced from   its corporate parent
column37: it doesn't seem like it would have to sell   in huge numbers to turn a profit.With Europe and China moving more aggressively toward electric   vehicles
column38: and all of those Tesla customers in the United States
column39: it seems likely that a well-done Bentley with a competitive   battery-electric drivetrain would find enough customers to make   the effort worthwhile. We'll likely find out in another year or   so.10 stocks we like better than Volkswagen AGWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Urban Outfitters
column2: Inc. (URBN) Q4 Earnings Raise Some Red Flags;3/7/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsHeading into theUrban Outfitters
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:URBN) fourth-quarter earnings report
column5: there were two areas of focus for investors. Urban Outfitters already released Q4 sales figures in early February. Flat comparable-store sales for the period were below expectations
column6: but URBN stock still gained modestly on the news. As such
column7: trailing revenue wasn't likely to be a major point of emphasis in the Urban Outfitters earnings report.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Rather
column8: the focus was on margins
column9: and on fiscal 2018 (ending January) guidance. And on both fronts
column10: expectations were low. MKM Partners downgraded URBN stock on Feb. 27
column11: specifically citing margin pressure at Anthropologie. Wunderlich cut its price target for URBN to $26 on Monday
column12: projecting compressed margins from higher online sales. Goldman Sachs already had cut Urban Outfitters stock to ""Sell"" in early February
column13: on concerns of overall retail weakness going forward.Urban Outfitters earnings for Q4 appear to support those concerns - even though shares have risen modestly in after-hours trading.The same pressures dogging the entire retail sector appear to have made their way to Urban Outfitters. That's not pushing URBN stock lower in Tuesday after-market trading
column14: but it could in the weeks ahead.Urban Outfitters Earnings Show Margin PressureMany retailers have responded to the endless omnichannel threat driven byAmazon.com
column15: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) by building out e-commerce businesses of their own. But until recently
column16: investors hadn't quite understood the inherent problem with that strategy: It hurts profit margins.9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonAdding an e-commerce supply chain and other capabilities on top of an existing brick-and-mortar footprint simply adds more cost. And to compete with online-only rivals
column17: retailers must cut price as well.Urban Outfitters specifically cited that problem in its Q4 release. Gross profit margin for the fourth quarter was down 142 bps year-over-year. The issue
column18: per URBN
column19: was ""primarily"" delivery and supply chain costs. Those costs were elevated by increasing DTC (direct to consumer sales). For the quarter
column20: flat comparables were driven by a double-digit increase in DTC revenue - offset by declining sales in-store.The formula of ~flat revenue and increasing e-commerce share implies margin and profit pressure - and that's exactly what happened to Urban Outfitters earnings. Net income declined 12% year-over-year in Q4
column21: with EPS missing analyst estimates by a penny. And declining profits won't support URBN stock
column22: which still trades at nearly 14x EPS at after-hour prices. (To be fair
column23: the multiple is closer to 12x including the company's ~$3 per share in cash and securities.)Sales and Profit Growth Questions Remain For URBN StockThe problem coming out of the fourth-quarter release is that those margin pressures aren't likely to abate. In fact
column24: CEO Richard Hayne said in the Q4 release that Urban Outfitters wouldincreaseits focus on DTC sales. Store occupancy costs were flat as a percentage of sales in the fourth quarter. But further revenue weakness in store could add deleverage on that line as well - and further pressure Urban Outfitters earnings.From a sales standpoint
column25: there wasn't much new information in the release
column26: though the post-earnings conference should give more color. It does appear that the Urban Outfitters brand
column27: which accounted for 40% of FY17 sales
column28: is reasonably well-positioned. That brand did have higher markdowns in Q4 - but lower discounting on a full-year basis.The other 60% or so of the retail base
column29: however
column30: may have some concerns.Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock: Stay Away at All Costs!Anthropologie sales declined in Q4
column31: as mentioned
column32: even with higher markdowns. And Free People saw lower gross margin in FY17 - again
column33: due to higher markdowns.URBN Stock Isn't That CheapAll told
column34: there's enough in the Urban Outfitters earnings release to suggest some potential problems for URBN stock in 2017.It's not as if Urban Outfitters is all that cheap
column35: either. A 12x-plus cash multiple mightsoundinexpensive
column36: but it's in line with most of the retail space.Gap Inc(NYSE:GPS) trades at similar levels
column37: as doesAmerican Eagle Outfitters(NYSE:AEO). Both of those stocks are coming off decent years - in my opinion
column38: betteryears than Urban Outfitters. AEO
column39: in particular
column40: given its ownership of Aerie
column41: has a growth catalyst that URBN stock may not at the moment.Retail in general is an extremely tough space
column42: to the point that some observers have called the sector simply ""uninvestable."" I tend to agree with that characterization. Those investors looking to enter the space need to chose only the best companies
column43: with the least risk. Urban Outfitters is one of the better companies
column44: but I'm not sure it's quite top-tier.And coming out of Q4
column45: there are a lot of potential risks to both sales and margins in fiscal 2018.As of this writing
column46: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Closed-End Funds That Have Big-Time YieldsIs Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Really Going to Crash 26%?7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Lows in 2017The postUrban Outfitters

column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhat do the pizza and big-box retail industries have to do withNetflix
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) and the performance of NFLX stock going forward?makeArticleAd();Source: AppleSurprisingly
column5: a lot.Domino's Pizza
column6: Inc.(NYSE:DPZ) recently got a boost from better-than-expected quarterly results. Meanwhile

column8: while TGT is down 20%. As weird as it may seem
column9: the simple parallel between Domino's recent success and Target's recent failures underscores a secular shift in the consumer economy which strongly favors NFLX stock.CNBC's Jim Cramer is calling it the ""stay-at-home economy
column10: and it's showing up in everyone's earnings reports. Companies - such as Domino's and Netflix - that cater to this mentality are thriving; those that don't are struggling.Netflix stock hasn't been the only big winner from this shift. Delivery-centric quick service food stocks like DPZ andPapa John's Int'l
column11: Inc.(NASDAQ:PZZA) are up big since the start of 2016. More traditional quick-service food stocks that don't focus on delivery
column12: likeMcDonald's Coproration(NYSE:MCD)
column13: have struggled recently.Non-store retailers and online marketplaces such asAmazon.com
column14: Inc(NASDAQ:AMZN) andEtsy Inc.(NASDAQ:ETSY) have surged. Meanwhile
column15: traditional retailers likeWal-Mart Stores Inc(NYSE:WMT) andMacy's Inc(NYSE:M) are rapidly changing their business models to stay relevant.In a nutshell
column16: though
column17: that is the problem with staying long the stocks that have been early winners of the ""stay-at-home"" shift. Everyone is catching on
column18: and most are catching up.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The Experts' PicksIn the food industry
column19: services likePostmatesare gaining popularity
column20: and that is democratizing food delivery. In retail
column21: all mall retailers are focused on building out an omnichannel presence
column22: and free shipping is becoming more of a regular. Competition for services in the ""stay-at-home"" economy will only intensify.With one exception: Netflix.Why Netflix Is DifferentIn many ways
column23: Netflix pioneered the stay-at-home economy. In 2011
column24: the company split its DVD rental and streaming services. Consumers weren't pleased
column25: and about800
column26: 000 membersquit Netflix.The dissatisfaction was short-lived
column27: though

column1: Repairing My Tesla Model S Has Been an Utter Nightmare -- and It's Mostly Tesla's Fault;3/7/2017;"Seven months
column2: three weeks
column3: and three days.That's how long it's been since myTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) Model S was involved in an accident and Istilldon't have my car back. That's nearly eight months of rather   large monthly payments for a car that I'm unable to drive; nearly   eight months of incrementally higher costs associated with   insurance and registration for a car that's sitting in the shop;   nearly eight months of having to find and arrange alternative   transportation; nearly eight months of having to buy gas again
column4: while the gas savings had previously offset part of said large   monthly payments; nearly eight months of impatiently waiting to   get back a car that I absolutely love; nearly eight months of   regularly prodding Tesla for updates with little to no   success.My Model S
column5: shortly before the accident. Image source:     Author.makeArticleAd();You may assume that my car was involved in some sort of   catastrophic incident that required a protracted period of time   to repair. Nope. It was a run-of-the-mill accident (more details   later). Tesla is predominantly responsible for why it is taking   so long
column6: because out of those eight months
column7: over five of them   were spent doing nothing but waiting for parts.Let me back up a bit and start from the beginning.Jan. 27
column8: 2016: Delivery dayIn late 2015
column9: my wife and I decided to take the plunge and buy   a Model S. We had been longtime supporters and investors in the   company
column10: firstbuying shares in 2011. We finally pulled the trigger in December of that year. In   order to save quite a bit of money
column11: we opted for a certified   pre-owned (CPO) model
column12: which cost about a third less than a   comparably equipped new Model S would have cost at the time.At the time
column13: the Colorado state tax credit ($6
column14: 000) for   electric vehicles could be claimed on used vehicles provided that   the car has never been registered in the state. (The state credit   was recently amended to exclude used vehicles
column15: effective starting   2017.) So we found one that was located in New Jersey
column16: and even   after paying the maximum transportation fee ($1
column18: it still   easily worked out in our favor. It was less than 2 years old and   had less than 20
column19: 000 miles on it; not bad for what we saved by   going CPO. It was even the exact same shade of dark green as my   first car
column20: a color option that had since been discontinued --   bonus nostalgia points.Delivery day at the Tesla service center. Image source:     Author.It took about a month for the car to arrive
column21: but we   immediately fell in love with it. We started taking road trips   more often (within the bounds of the Supercharger network
column22: of   course)
column23: and frequently found excuses just to drive and enjoy the   instant torque.Like most Tesla customers
column24: we became involuntary but not   unwilling advocates for the company
column25: fielding a constant string   of questions from friends
column26: family
column27: and strangers regarding how   the car worked as well as about the necessary behavioral   adjustments associated with going all-electric. We also attracted   the typical confounded stares when we'd put something in the   frunk
column28: or put the kids in the rear-facing seats that we had Tesla   retrofit post-delivery.A couple months after taking delivery
column29: we placed a reservation   for a Model 3 on March 31
column30: the day that Tesla unveiled the   vehicle and started taking deposits.July 11
column31: 2016: Accident dayI was actually at the Tesla factory in Fremont
column32: California
column33: when the accident occurred (I worked for Tesla very briefly   during the summer of 2016). My wife called me frantically
column34: exasperated that she had been involved in an accident. Most   importantly
column35: she was largely unharmed; just some minor whiplash   that she quickly recovered from. She was more concerned that the   car had been injured. She had been driving home from work
column36: sitting stationary at a stop light
column37: when a young driver failed to   hit the brakes in time and rear-ended the vehicle at a relatively   low speed.Here's the picture I asked her to take of the car immediately   after the impact:Immediately after the accident. Image source: Author.It looks worse than it was
column38: in part because the Model S and   Model X contain more aluminum than most vehicles. Aluminum   crumples much easier than steel since it's a softer metal. This   is also an important safety feature since the crumple zones are   both larger and able to absorb more impact
column39: with the downside   being that aluminum is more expensive. A consequence is that   Tesla accidents look really bad because the vehicles get mangled
column40: but the functional benefit is minimal intrusion into the   passenger cabin.Less than six months after we had taken delivery
column41: our Model S   was off to the shop.Nearly eight months later...While Tesla performs most routine service itself
column42: it   outsources major body work to a network of third-party body shops   that are certified by Tesla. The certification process is   expensive and time-consuming
column43: but certified body shops will   garner most of the local business (there is only one certified   body shop in my immediate area).Shortly after receiving my damaged car
column44: the body shop started   tearing down the vehicle to assess the damage
column45: and ordering the   parts that would be necessary for the repair. The vast majority   of the repair time has been gobbled up here. I had heard and read   stories about Tesla parts taking longer to deliver relative to   the rest of the industry
column46: but that's somewhat expected for a   young car company with just one factory.Anecdotally
column47: stories of it taking two to three months for Tesla to deliver   parts are not uncommon. After three months had passed and the   body shop had still not received all the necessary parts
column48: we   began reaching out to Tesla directly through their customer   service channels
column49: which serves as a liaison to the internal parts   department.At the body shop. Image source: Author.Initially
column50: no customer service representative that we   interacted with was willing to take ownership of our issue. We   kept getting passed between representatives with little to no   useful information (a customer service manager eventually took   ownership of handling our issue after repeated escalations).   Parts had started to trickle in
column51: but there still weren't enough   to start the repair so our car continued to sit idly. Two of the   more pertinent parts were a rear lift gate and rear quarter   panel
column52: which were still outstanding. During one of the   escalations in November (four months after the accident)
column53: Tesla guaranteed us that all parts would arrive at the body   shop no later than the last week of November. They didn't.In mid-December
column54: the shopfinallyreceived enough (but not all) parts to start working on the car.   At that point
column55: the holidays were nearly upon us
column56: and every   industry slows down around that time of year. The body shop would   begin the repair in early January 2017 after the holidays. There   were still a few outstanding parts
column57: including bulb rivets. I   would think that something as basic as rivets would be among the   easier parts to deliver
column58: but evidently I'm wrong (and not alone). We again contacted customer service
column59: and Tesla again assured   us they had just shipped the remaining parts for overnight   delivery. Frankly
column60: we didn't have much faith at this point
column61: as we   had been told this before. But in the final week of January
column62: the   shop confirmed that they had indeed received all remaining parts   necessary to complete the repair. It looked like light at the end   of the tunnel
column63: six months in. At this point in the story
column64: the car   has spentmore time in the shop than in our possession.A couple weeks ago
column65: the body shop updated us that the car was   about to enter the paint shop
column66: at which point it should only be a   couple more weeks to reassemble the painted pieces and then   perform electronics calibrations and a few other outstanding   items. It turns out that the 12V battery is also now in need of   replacement
column67: as it will no longer hold a charge (perhaps related   to how long the car has been sitting idle?). The shop ordered the   battery a week and a half ago. Tesla uses exactly one specific   supplier for its 12V batteries
column68: which is struggling to keep up   with Tesla's demands. We're now looking at yet another delay for   the 12V battery
column69: which is a part that most people are able to   purchase for their vehicles locally within 15 minutes.As soon as Tesla delivers this battery
column70: the car will be ready   within a day or two. It's supposed to be ready this week
column71: but at   this point I have incredibly low expectations
column72: as we are again   waiting on Tesla to deliver.Look
column73: Ma: No car!Tesla is known for having a generous loaner policy when   vehicles are being serviced
column74: but sadly this policy does not apply   to body work.The driver that hit us was uninsured
column75: so we had to file our   claims through our collision coverage
column76: and we have coverage for a   rental. But our rental coverage maxes out at 45 days
column77: which is   typically sufficient time for most body repairs. Having already   known that our repair would probably take at least two months
column78: I   knew we would need to arrange alternative transportation. Even if   we opted to use our insurance company's negotiated rental rates
column80: 000 per month to rent a car.   That'sin additionto the monthly loan payments that we are still paying.Fortunately
column82: and as such have little   need for their cars. My mother graciously agreed to let me borrow   her car as long as needed
column83: which relieved us of having to bleed   out a small fortune ($7
column84: 000 by now) in rental fees for an   indefinite and still ongoing period of time.What this means for investorsTo say that this whole experience has been traumatizing would   be an understatement. As long-standing investors and   newfound customers
column85: it has profoundly shaken our faith in Tesla   as a company. Thus far
column86: Tesla has not given us a reason as towhyour parts were so severely delayed
column87: so we have no indication as   to whether or not this is a one-off exception or if there is some   systemic problem within Tesla's parts operations. While we've   been waiting
column88: Tesla has delivered tens of thousands of vehicles
column90: 000 Model S sedans.Some of Tesla's weakness here is certainly related to its own   ability to produce parts
column91: which continues to improve every month.   Theoretically
column92: parts production should improve as Tesla continues   to ramp its overall manufacturing capacity
column93: but it seems like   this can't be the only reason. I'm mildly confident that my case   is an outlier
column95: it's still disconcerting that   situations like this can slip through the cracks after repeated   escalations and assurances.It also calls into question Tesla's ability to support its   existing customer base
column96: which is of critical relevance to whether   or not Tesla can support amassivelylarger customer base. The company is still targeting 500
column97: 000   units in 2018. As many analysts and pundits point out
column98: the   mainstream is far less forgiving for this sort of thing compared   to enthusiastic early adopters.We are now questioning our Model 3 reservation. We haven't   finalized our decision
column99: nor will we have to for a few more   months. Owning two Teslas now seems like a significant risk   should one of them ever be involved in any type of accident
column100: small or large. In sharing our story with other Model 3   reservation holders
column101: we know that a few of them canceled as a   direct result
column102: since our run-of-the-mill repair has devolved into   an utter nightmare.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column103: it can pay to listen. After all
column104: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column106: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column108: CFAowns shares of Tesla. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Tesla. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Amazon (AMZN) CEO Jeff Bezos Wants to Dominate Outer Space;3/7/2017;"The Milky Way (Shutterstock Photo)Is there any place in the universe too big for Jeff Bezos to want to conquer?After crushing the world of retail
column2: technology

column4: and a host of current projects poised to disrupt or create new markets

column6: who currently ranks at the world's third-wealthiest person

column8: Blue Origin
column9: which is expected to reveal some customers and new initiatives this week.makeArticleAd();With what began as just an interesting idea
column10: Bezos
column11: a self-proclaimed ""space geek
column12: has already established tons of credibility for Blue Origin
column13: which offers a family of reusable rockets powerful enough to penetrate deep into the solar system for suborbital voyages. Bezos envisions one day humans establishing a permanent settlement on the moon. Its more than just a pipe dream. And given his Midas track record
column14: Bezos space exploration plans should be taken seriously.The capabilities of Blue Origin
column15: which has grown over the past year
column16: can now blast both manned and robotic missions not only to the moon

column18: which Blue Origin built in-house and reportedly can take paying passengers into outer space some time next year.Blue Origin rivals the powerful rockets currently being touted by Tesla (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk's SpaceX. While Musk appears to have a sizable lead on Bezos

column28: as Star Trek claims? That remains to be seen."

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Is the New Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN);3/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) sold off hard following a fourth-quarter earnings report that fell short of the market's lofty expectations. Despite reporting better-than-expected revenue of $2.28 billion on the quarter
column4: Tesla stock delivered an earnings loss much larger that the market anticipated.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAs Tesla stock was already up more than 26% year-to-date headed into earnings
column5: it's not surprising that the stock sold off.I've written many times about the dangers of investing in Tesla stock at its current market valuation.Tesla's 2017 run pushed the stock's market cap to around $45 billion
column6: roughly in line with that ofFord Motor Company(NYSE:F). It's difficult to fathom such a high valuation for a company that shipped just 76
column7: 000 vehicles last year and burned through another $448 million in cash in Q4.The market may have higher hopes for Tesla stock than any other stock on the market. But long-term TSLA bulls don't care about Q4
column8: or even 2017 for that matter. They aren't just investing in an auto company. They believe Tesla Inc. will change the world.The Tesla Stock Bull Case Is About QualityTesla stock bulls believe that it doesn't matter how many cars the company delivers in the short term. They feel the autonomous driving technology that CEO Elon Musk is developing will make Tesla vehicles the best in the world in the next decade.General Motors Company(NYSE:GM) has gotten a head-start on the long-range electric vehicle mass market. But TSLA appears to be on track to be the first to market with a fully-autonomous vehicle.8 of the Most Overrated Stocks on Wall Street Right NowLast year
column9: Elon Musk tweeted that Tesla had already driven222 million cumulative autopilot miles. Those miles are extremely important because the precious data they provide
column10: which allows for fine-tuning the technology. By comparison
column11: Alphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column12: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Waymo driverless car has logged only about2 million milesof data.If Tesla is the first to market with a driverless car
column13: its data advantage will quickly compound exponentially. That huge advantage could make it very difficult for competitors to catch up.TSLA Stock Valuation Not an IssueThe scariest part about Tesla stock for most investors is its valuation. The stock already seems to have priced in tremendous long-term success.Compared to auto rivals Ford and GM
