column73: and Twitter. It also     recommends General Motors. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: The Big Factor That Will Help Tesla's Model 3 Launch;2/27/2017;"Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) is gearing up for maybe its biggest moment yet:   the start of production of its first true mass-market model
column2: the   Model 3.It's a moment that is fraught with challenges. The Model 3 is   all-new and different from earlier Teslas
column3: and it's going to be   built on an all-new assembly line that incorporates much more   automation than anything Tesla has tried to date.A lot rides on Tesla's ability todeliver high-quality Model 3s
column4: and there are a lot of things that could go wrong. But as CEO   Elon Musk explained during Tesla's earnings call last week
column5: Tesla   has an important new factor working in its favor: its   suppliers.makeArticleAd();Tesla's upcoming Model 3 sedan
column6: shown in concept form last     year. Image source: Tesla.Tesla is reaping the benefits of its growth with   suppliersAll automakers
column7: big or small
column8: are heavily dependent on   suppliers. In particular
column9: suppliers that specialize in certain   types of parts -- whether circuit boards or seats -- can produce   parts to a higher level of quality much less expensively than an   automaker could do on its own.Musk said that in Tesla's early days
column10: it was hard to get the   attention of the established auto-industry suppliers. Those   suppliers are used to thinking in terms of production runs that   will go into six or seven figures of volume -- and few in the   auto industry thought Tesla's Model S would end up selling in the   tens of thousands every year.But now that Tesla has proven that it can (and will) build and   sell cars in volume
column11: the suppliers are much more interested in   winning its business. Musk explained:We're able to get usually the A team at the A supplier for     Model 3. It's rare that we're not able to get that. Whereas
column12: particularly for Model S and to some degree for Model X
column13: when     we were trying to get suppliers for Model S
column14: a lot of the     top-tier suppliers wouldn't even work with us. They didn't     believe in the car. They thought we'd go bankrupt.Having shown the results of the Model S and the Model X
column15: the     interest from suppliers went from basically getting like the     worst team on second-tier suppliers to getting the best team on     first-tier suppliers. It's really a big difference.It should make a huge difference in some of the details of the   finished product. Think of things like the fit and finish of   interior panels
column16: or the comfort of the seats
column17: or the quality of   the glass used in the windshield. These are all things that drew   some criticism in the earlier Teslas
column18: and they're all things that   can be improved by having the A-list suppliers giving their best   efforts.If the Model 3's launch is smooth
column19: suppliers will be a big   reasonThere's a lot -- awholelot -- that can go wrong with Tesla's ramp-up to full production   of the Model S. Some things will go wrong: A few suppliers will   be late
column20: a few early batches of parts won't fit properly
column21: a robot   or tool on Tesla's brand-new production line won't work as   designed.These things happen to all automakers. They're more likely to   happen to Tesla with the Model 3
column22: simply because this is the   company's first-ever attempt at a high-volume production car.Analysts have looked to the problem-plagued launch of Tesla's   Model X for clues as to how the Model 3 launch might unfold (and   have downgraded their near-term expectations accordingly). But   the fact that Tesla has been able to significantly upgrade its   relationships with suppliers since the X's launch might make that   a misleading comparison.Long story short: I think the Model 3 launch could go more   smoothly than many expect. If so
column23: suppliers will be a big reason   why.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column24: it can pay to listen. After all
column25: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column27: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them! column2: Inc. (AMD) Stock Is Going to Stumble Soon;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe rebound inAdvanced Micro Devices
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD) is one heck of a story. Just one year ago the stock was trading below $2 and appeared to be on the brink of extinction. Then
column5: suddenly
column6: it turned itself around. Now AMD stock has powered through $15 for the first time since 2007.makeArticleAd();Source:Matthew Rutledge via FlickrThis sort of parabolic momentum was commonplace for tech companies back in the late 1990s - AMD experienced similar spikes in 1999-2000 and 2003-05
column7: each followed by a crash in the years ahead - but this is a very rare occurrence in today's environment.AMD stock is up more than 600% in the last year
column8: with new products primarily driving the growth. However
column9: you also have to keep fundamentals in mind
column10: and I believe there is reason to be cautious here.While Advanced Micro Devices is set to once againreport positive earnings in 2017 and even more robust growth in the coming years
column11: there's no question that AMD stock is overvalued.Looking ahead to 2020
column12: the 20 analysts currently covering this stock anticipate earnings will grow to 60 cents per share. A 25X multiple on that expectation would put AMD at $15
column13: which isn't far from where it's trading today. And based on 2017 EPS expectations of 6 cents
column14: the shares currently boast a forward price-to-earnings ratio of 237.AMD Stock ChartsSpeaking from a pure technical standpoint
column15: AMD has been one of the best stocks in the market over the last year with its methodical series of higher highs and higher lows.8 of the Most Overrated Stocks on Wall Street Right NowHowever
column16: today the stock is overbought and due for a near-term pullback.If the trend were to continue
column17: AMD stock would pull back and successfully test support around $12.60. On the other hand
column18: a break below that level would compromise the uptrend.As a result
column19: I wouldn't be a buyer at current levels.But if we do see some near-term weakness and a bounce off $12.60
column20: AMD could be a buy around $13 for a purely technical swing trade.Matthew McCall is founder and president of Penn Financial Group
column21: an investment advisory firm. Matt also is Editor of FUTR Stocks and the ETF Bulletin. Earlier this year

column1: Why Does Honda's Electric Car Have Just 80 Miles of Range?;2/27/2017;"The upcoming battery-electric Clarity sedan fromHonda(NYSE: HMC) will come with a big surprise
column2: according to a new   report: a range of just 80 miles.That's the word from trade publicationAutomotive Newsin a report that was more or less confirmed by Honda   officials.That seems woefully inadequate by 2017 standards. What is   Honda thinking?makeArticleAd();The upcoming Honda Clarity Electric is expected to look very     similar to the 2017 Honda Clarity Fuel Cell sedan released late     last year. Image source: Honda Motor Co.
column3: Ltd.Why such a short range?At an expected starting price of around $35
column5: the Clarity   Electric will be in direct competition (in terms of price
column6: at   least) withGeneral Motors'(NYSE: GM) Chevrolet Bolt EV andTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) upcoming Model 3 sedan. But the Bolt has an   EPA-rated range of 238 miles
column7: and the Model 3's range is expected   to be in the same ballpark. Why didn't the Clarity's range at   least come close to its rivals?Honda executives told Automotive News that the Clarity   Electric's short range was a byproduct of the company's decision   to base it on the platform of the midsize Clarity Fuel Cell
column8: introduced last year. The Clarity Fuel Cell is a midsize sedan
column9: about the size of   Honda's Accord. It's considerably bigger than the Bolt.The size and design of the Clarity platform
column10: which will also   be shared with a plug-in hybrid version
column11: didn't leave room   (physically or financially) for a larger
column12: longer-range battery   pack without a hefty cost increase
column13: they said.Why Honda committed to a three-Clarity strategyHonda explained last year that the idea behind theClarity's three-drivetrain strategyis that it will give Honda flexibility to vary the production mix   as the market and infrastructure evolves. It also allows Honda's   customers to choose their preferred path to an ""ultra-low carbon   vehicle that meets their lifestyle needs
column14: in Honda's words.I think the business decision flow probably looked like   this:After years of building tiny numbers of fuel-cell vehicles     for test markets
column15: Hondawantedto do a fuel-cell car that could be marketed to a somewhat     wider audience.Under pressure from investors (and maybe its dealers)
column16: Honda felt itneededto offer a midsize battery-electric car -- if only to show that     it could be competitive in that realm.Honda thendecidedto add a plug-in hybrid version that was likely to sell in much     greater numbers than either of the other versions
column17: in order to     give the Clarity a better chance of turning a profit.The problem is
column18: when you design one car around three very   different drivetrains
column19: a lot of compromises have to be made. And   the Clarity Electric's rivals are much less compromised   designs.The cost of compromising on a battery-electric carTesla has shown the world what can be done when a car is   designed from the ground up around a battery-electric drivetrain.   A vehicle designed from the start around electric motors and a   big battery pack can have plenty of range
column20: good handling
column21: a roomy   interior
column22: and lots of cargo space.The Chevy Bolt doesn't look like a Tesla
column23: but like the Teslas
column24: it was designed from the start as a battery-electric vehicle. It   doesn't have the range or speed of the big Teslas
column25: but it has   something else enabled by its battery-electric packaging: A   surprisingly roomy interior enclosed in a small
column26: nimble vehicle   perfect for city driving.It's no coincidence that the Teslas and the Bolt are the   current gold standard of battery-electric vehicles. And it's sad   that Honda
column27: which has spent years building up its green-car   credibility
column28: has settled for a compromised design with the   Clarity Electric.But will it sell?Some folks say range doesn't matter all that much
column29: and the   Clarity Electric will find buyers attracted to its size and   Honda's reputation for quality and durability. I'm skeptical: I   think the plug-in hybrid version of the Clarity -- or an Accord   Hybrid -- is likely to win over most of the green-minded Honda   loyalists who might have taken a chance on a Clarity Electric   with greater range.It's likely Honda will share more details about the Clarity   Electric at the New York International Auto Show in April. Your   humble Fool will be there.10 stocks we like better than Honda MotorWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column30: it can pay to listen. After all
column31: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column33: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Honda Motor wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Get Paid to Trade International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stock;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI have not been a fan ofInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) for a long time. It is my opinion that management was slow to shift cash cows. They lost their way and have yet to recover. They have been trying to carve a niche in artificial intelligence
column3: but that story has been over a decade in the making. To use a poker term
column4: they are pot-committed to AI.makeArticleAd();Luckily
column5: artificial intelligence has seen a recent resurgence in popularity so the wait may actually pay off to IBM longs.Experts are in awe of what Watson can do. Unfortunately
column6: its profit stream is taking too long to develop. IBM is no longer the sure long-term bet it once was. To me
column7: it more resembles a startup with a cool product still finding its way.Click to EnlargeUsually
column8: I like to sell longer-dated risk in companies that I believe are long-term winners likeAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column9: NASDAQ:GOOGL) orApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). In this case
column10: I am putting my trust in the IBM price action more so than its fundamentals.The Bet:Sell the IBM Oct $130 put. This is a bullish trade for which I collect $1.40 per contract to open. This trade has a 90% theoretical chance of success. This sounds like a great idea now
column11: but it comes with risk. By selling the put naked
column12: I am committing to buying the stock at $130 per share if IBM falls below it. Anything below $128.60 per share would accrue losses for me.The 7 Best ETFs for Retirement InvestorsSelling naked puts is not suited for most investors
column13: so I can modify the trade to make it more attainable.The Alternate:Sell IBM $140/$135 credit put spread. This also is a bullish trade
column14: but one with a finite risk profile. I collect 40 cents per contract to open. The 22% price buffer is smaller than that of selling the $130 naked put but for the finite risk profile advantage.While 40 cents may sound too little
column15: it would represent an 8% yield on money risked and for the high chance of success it carries it should elate most investors.I chose longer-dated risk so I don't have to fret the short-term gyrations. I find that longer-dated options risk is easier to manage. Also
column16: I can close either of these trades at any time for partial gains or losses.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column17: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.More From InvestorPlace7 REITs That Should Be CondemnedExxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) Should Keep an Eye on Tesla Inc (TSLA)7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Flush With CashThe postGet Paid to Trade International Business Machines Corp. column1: Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) Should Keep an Eye on Tesla Inc (TSLA);2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsExxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM) stock is down 9.65% year to date; the company has had a rough start to 2017. First
column3: a $2 billion asset impairment charge on gas assets in the Rocky Mountains clouded XOM's fourth-quarter earnings call on Jan. 31.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Then
column4: on Feb. 22
column5: XOM announced that it had to write off 3.3 billion barrels of oil in reserves at the end of 2016. With oil prices in the mid $50s
column6: getting oil from some of XOM's Canadian oil sands is no longer profitable.This represents a massive destruction of value for holders of Exxon stock. A decade ago
column7: XOM invested approximately  $20 billion in these Canadian oil sands amid concern over peak oil. Unless oil prices rise
column8: those billions will have been wasted.There could be more such downside surprises in store for Exxon as well. Further developments in clean energy could wipe billions more off the balance sheets of oil companies like XOM.XOM's Rosy View of Oil's FutureUnlikeRoyal Dutch Shell plc (ADR)(NYSE:RDS.A)
column9: whose CFO said thatoil demand could peak as soon as 2020
column10: XOM expects oil to dominate past the year 2040 .The 10 Best Oil Stocks to Buy Now for Big-Time GainsMcKinsey & Co. expects oil demand topeak by 2030
column11: with electric vehicles representing 30% of new vehicles sold that year. XOM
column12: on the other hand
column13: doesn't see electric vehicles passing 10% of new vehicles sold in the U.S. until 2040 .Could XOM be underestimating the threat of electric cars and alternative energy? A new study by the Carbon Tracker Initiative and Imperial College London suggests that the answer could be yes. This study found that the adoption of electric vehicles could displace2 million barrels of oil per dayin demand by 2025.Oil companies like XOM may be doing straight line extrapolations when the adoption of new technologiesactually follows an S-curve. Initially
column14: progress is slow for many years
column15: as only a few adopt a new technology. Eventually
column16: however
column17: usage of the technology jumps and it goes mainstream before growth tapers off.Advancements in battery technology may be reducing use of gasoline
column18: another form of energy storage. Recently
column19: gasoline consumption in the U.S. plummeted and the country experienced theworst gasoline glut since 1990.Is this temporary
column20: or could this be a sign of oil demand peaking?Tesla's Threat to Oil Companies Like XOMWith its recent acquisition of SolarCity
column21: Tesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) is on its way to becoming an alternative energy powerhouse. Tesla brings solar
column22: electric vehicles and energy storage together under one roof (pun intended). TSLA wants to beginsolar roof installationslater this year.Renewable energy depends on energy storage technology in order to compete with fossil fuels. Fossil fuels can be burned day and night
column23: while the sun doesn't shine at night. Some of the energy captured during the day must be stored for nighttime use.For renewables to replace fossil fuels in transportation (28% of energy usein the U.S.)
column24: batteries must replace gasoline as the method of storing energy in a car.  With cheaper batteries
column25: we can expect greater investments in renewable energy.Further
column26: global energy storage is set to take off. Bloomberg New Energy Finance expects global energy storage capacity toincrease by a factor of 15by 2024. Developing countries can expect even larger increases; the World Bank Group predicted a40-fold growth in energy storage capacityby 2025.Catch Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock While It's Under PressureBattery costs have declined 40% since 2014
column27: and this will continue. In January
column28: Tesla opened its $5 billiongigafactory
column29: which will double the world's production capacity of lithium-ion batteries. Costs are sure to come down as TSLA scales up.And
column30: Tesla isn't finished
column31: yet; CEO Elon Musk wants to open up three more such gigafactories.Tesla's newPowerpack battery
column32: revealed in October
column33: packs twice the power capacity of the original
column34: and Musk thinks TSLA can meet its goal of selling  500
column35: 000 electric cars per year as early as 2018.Clean energy could be nearing an inflection point
column36: with dire implications for oil companies like XOM.Mitigating FactorsLow energy prices
column37: like we are seeing now
column38: could have a silver lining for oil companies - and for XOM stock. While low oil prices will reduce XOM's profitability
column39: they also will ensure steady demand growth and slow the adoption of new energy-saving technologies. Musk said last year that cheap oil would be bad for EV makers like Tesla.Also
column40: oil companies may now have a friend in the White House. President Donald Trump seems skeptical of climate change and more comfortable with smokestack industries than Barack Obama. And
column41: Trump picked Exxon CEO Rex Tillerson as his secretary of state
column42: which couldbenefit XOM stockas well.As of this writing

column1: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Will Try to Dominate India;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhile China's e-commerce market is still growing
column3: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd(NYSE:BABA) and its affiliate Ant Financial are already looking south to India. Last year
column4: Morgan Stanley predicted that theIndian e-commerce marketwould grow the fastest globally
column5: to $119 billion by 2020. And Alibaba stock is poised to benefit.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockWhat's driving e-commerce and fintech in India? India passed the U.S. as the world's No. 2 smartphone market last year
column6: with 220 million users . T he number of smartphone users in India is expected to balloon to 810 million by 2021 and India's 3G and 4G networks could cover 300 million subscribers by March 2018.India's young and growing population is increasingly tech-savvy
column7: especially millennials.India's government also supports a cashless economy
column8: seeing this as a way to reduce corruption and tax evasion. The Indian government alsoremoved the largest banknotes
column9: 500 rupee and 1000 rupee notes
column10: from the economy. This led to an explosion in the use ofmobile wallets in India
column11: adding as many as  1 million users added per day .Last year
column12: the National Payments Corporation of India announced theUnified Payment Interface
column13: making it convenient for Indians to access their bank accounts on their phones and pay.And all these moving parts flow into the bull case for Alibaba stock.Taking Ant's Strategy to IndiaAlibaba and Ant (formerly Alipay) invested inOne97Communications
column14: the parent company of Indian e-commerce player Paytm. They are expected to increase their stake to 50% from 42%. Paytm last year spun off its payments business to comply with regulations. One97 holds a 49% stake in Paytm Payments Bank and Paytm founder Vijay Shekhar Sharma owns 51%.Paytm boasted177 million usersat the end of the year and CFO Madhur Deora has set a medium-term target of 500 million users . That growth would be a boost for Alibaba stock and Ant Financial which seeks2 billion users worldwideover the next decade.7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightPaytm is clearly taking a page out of Alibaba and Ant Financial's playbook. Like BABA'sMyBank-  the bank ""for the little guy"" - Paytm's bank promises to be a vehicle for financial inclusion
column15: bringing services to India's unbanked.Like Ant
column16: Paytm also wants to offer loans andasset management servicesto those who can't access them now.Ant Fortune
column17: a wealth management app
column18: debuted in 2015. Its users can put money in Yuebao
column19: a money market fund
column20: and invest inZhao Cai Bao
column21: where they can loan money directly to businesses.Paytm's Threat to BanksBanks in both countries are threatened by this disruption. Ant's Yuebao offers depositors higher interest rates than banks andinstant withdrawals. Technology companies don't have to maintain as many employees at branches as banks do
column22: and can link borrowers and savers directly. Their asset-light model is simply more efficient than that of existing banks
column23: which have to use their own capital
column24: and are burdened by legacy systems and regulation.Banks earn a profit on the spread
column25: the difference between the rate at which they lend and the rates they offer depositors. Platforms that connect borrowers and lenders and cut out the middleman can exert pressure on this. And because Paytm and Ant Financial are branchless
column26: they have lower overhead costs
column27: and can offer lower fees than banks.Paytm will be both a friend and a potential enemy to banks. It will help them drum up business by cross-selling their services to its users. But Paytm will probably be the front-end in customer interactions and relegate the banks to the back end .Banks risk becoming ""dumb pipes."" As I mentioned inmy articlelast year
column28: the front-end generally gives banks a higher return on equity than the back. AMcKinsey & Companystudy found that banks earn a 22% return on equity from sales and origination
column29: but only 6% from the extension of credit.Protectionism RisksAll of this doesn't mean that the success of Alibaba

column31: protectionist sentiment is rising in India asAmazon.com
column32: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) andUberclobber their Indian rivals. Indian startups such as Flipkart
column33: Snapdeal (in which BABA is an investor)
column34: and Ola have had their valuations repeatedly marked down over the past year. Now some are asking for protection against supposedly unfair foreign competition. Indian venture capitalist Vani Kola of Kalaari Capital called for such measures
column35: followed bysimilar sentimentfrom the founders of e-commerce player Flipkart and Ola
column36: viewed as India's home-grown Uber) .Since Paytm is an Indian company
column37: why would this be a concern? While Paytm is Indian

column39: Alibaba and Ant. Would India want such a company controlling something as critical as its payments infrastructure? Experts have raised concerns overPaytm user dataending up in servers outside of India.Pointing to Paytm's Chinese ties
column40: the chief minister of West Bengal
column41: Mamata Banerjee accused the prime minister ofcompromising national security. The Sino-Indian relationship is contentious; the two countries went to war as recently as 1962 over a border dispute.Valeant Pharmaceuticals Intl Inc (VRX) Q4 Earnings: What to ExpectFor Paytm to work

column1: Under Armour Inc (UA) Stock Offers the Easiest Profits Ever;2/27/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLost in the collapse ofUnder Armour Inc(NYSE:UA) stock over the past year is an odd divergence between two classes of stock. Shares of UAA stock (Class A) have traded at a substantial premium to UA stock (Class C). The difference is about 10% at the moment
column3: in fact.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThat gap makes little sense. Class C UA stock has no voting rights. Class A UAA stock does have voting rights of one vote per share. But those rights don't have much value. CEO and founder Kevin Plank owns all of the non-trading Class B shares
column4: which have 10 votes each
column5: giving Plank 65% of the voting power as of December 2016.UAA shareholders are paying a premium for votes which are largely symbolic. And it's not as if other considerations justify that gap. The market is figuring out the divergence
column6: as the 10% premium has narrowed of late. But there's still time for easy profits in shorting UAA and going long UA.As for investors bullish on Under Armour
column7: there's basically no reason to pay up for the UAA stock.No
column8: UAA Stock Isn't Worth More Than UA StockAs seen in the chart below
column9: the gap between UA and UAA has narrowed of late
column10: after peaking in November.7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightAt one point in late November - less than a year after the Class C UA stock was issued - the gap was over 20%
column11: a huge number. In dollars
column12: the difference has dropped to near $2 per share from as high as $7 - but some of that compression has come from the fact that Under Armour stock has declined precipitously after two disappointing earnings reports.With the largely symbolic voting rights not likely to change anytime soon
column13: there's simply very little reason for UA to trade above UAA.According to theregistration statementfiled by Under Armour with the SEC
column14: Class C holders of Under Armour stock are entitled to the same dividends. The only way for Class A shareholders to gain some sort of majority voting power would be for Plank to be terminated for cause or to give up his shares.Neither outcome seems particularly likely given that the CEO is 42 years old
column15: intensely competitive
column16: and intent on turning around his beloved Under Armour himself.Liquidity doesn't justify the different prices for Under Armour stock
column17: either
column18: with one possible exception.There was a notable divergence in equity volume a few months ago. UA stock had an average volume under 1 million shares per day in October
column19: roughly 20% of UAA stock. But volume over the past month is almost equal: 6.5 million shares a day for UA and 6.9 million for UAA. The increase in UA volume probably has something to do with the narrowing premium and implies that the spread will continue to tighten.How To Play Under Armour StockThere is one notable difference between UA and UAA: options volume. For instance
column20: open interest in the UA Jan 2018 $20 puts is just over 400. In contrast
column21: there are more than 11
column22: 000 UAA Jan 2018 $20 calls open at the moment.That difference is not enough to justify a 10% premium
column23: however
column24: particularly for smaller investors. And it seems the market is figuring that out. But the gap remains wide enough that there's still room to make what should be close to risk-free profits by going long UA and short UAA.Nvidia Corporation (NVDA): Amazing Company
column25: Not-So-Good Stock ... For NowAny major event - like an acquisition
column26: as unlikely as that seems at the moment - will treat shareholders equally. Any dividend payments will be the same. The only difference between UA and UAA is the opportunity to vote even though those votes have no practical impact.So an arbitrage trade still looks like it has some upside. Voting rights between classes at other stocks usually are below 5%
column27: meaning a long UA/short UAA trade could make another $1 per share with very low risk.For investors who still think Under Armour stock is a better opportunity
column28: then Class C UA stock is the right choice. The premium for UAA stock simply doesn't make a lot of sense - and it's still wide enough to profit from.The author is long UA and short UAA.More From InvestorPlace3 Stocks to Watch on Monday: Tesla Inc (TSLA)

column1: How Tesla Is Ensuring the Model 3 Delivers on Quality;2/27/2017;"Tesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) Model S and Model X were the first two models   built entirely by the super-innovative Silicon Valley auto   start-up. Critics acclaimed both
column2: but they weren't without their   flaws in the months after they were launched.Both cars had glitches (the S's door handles; the X's   falcon-wing doors) and while both had terrific technology
column3: they   both fell down in some more mundane respects (seats
column4: road noise)   when compared with similarly priced models from established   luxury-car makers.That hasn't really hurt. Tesla's early-adopter owner base
column5: many of whom are well-heeled
column6: mostly hasn't minded. They've been   willing to trade some rough edges for the privilege of being on   what they see as the cutting edge of automotive technology.makeArticleAd();But now
column7: Tesla is aiming at a broader market with its upcoming   Model 3. To generate the sustainably high sales the company is   targeting
column8: the Model 3 has to be able to compare well on quality   and refinement with
column9: yes
column10: mass-market internal-combustion   alternatives. It also has to be much easier to manufacture
column11: because its pricing will leave less margin for error.Happily
column12: CEO Elon Musk and the Tesla management team know all   of that. They've taken some big steps to ensure that the Model 3   is ready to carry Tesla's brand to a much wider audience.Tesla expects to begin production of the Model 3 in July.     Image source: Tesla.The Model 3 incorporates big lessons learned from earlier   Teslas""The Model 3 is designed with - it's really designed for   manufacturing
column13: Musk said during Tesla's earnings call last week.   ""It's considerably a simpler car than the Model S or the Model   X.""Not only does it have fewer ""bells and whistles"" than Tesla's   upscale models
column14: he said
column15: but it also reflects lessons learned   from the complicated and problem-plagued launches of the Model S   and (especially) the Model X SUV.In designing the Model 3
column16: Tesla skipped whiz-bang features   like the self-presenting door handles and falcon-wing doors of   its earlier models in favor of mechanical simplicity that would   be easier to assemble at a high level of quality. It has less   wiring
column17: fewer computers
column18: and other simplifications intended to   make it easier to build at scale.CTO J.B. Straubel acknowledged that the experience of the   Model X ramp-up imparted some painful lessons:We really learned a lot of lessons
column19: especially from the     difficult Model X ramp. That's something that's in our recent     memory
column20: and we fought through it and succeeded. But I think in     the design of the Model 3 and the system and the [production]     lines that produce it
column21: many of those learnings have been     incorporated from the beginning.The amount of complexity in the operations to assemble the     car is dramatically reduced. The amount of operations that     involve some level of sort of assembly craft
column22: where there's     more judgment from the operator
column23: are dramatically reduced
column24: almost eliminated. And a lot of these things that we could     identify directly as the bottlenecks that hurt us on the X     ramp
column25: we've been able to target specifically and reduce or     eliminate. So that has -- though painful
column26: it was a very helpful     experience for us to get ready for Model 3.The hard lessons of the Model X led to three big hiresTesla had the benefit of some new and very experienced   perspectives as it engineered the Model 3 and prepared its   production line. The company made several promising moves to   address its production quality in the wake of the Model X's   launch
column27: and three key hires stand out.Last May
column28: Tesla hiredproduction expert Peter Hochholdinger
column29: a veteran ofVolkswagen AG's Audi subsidiary. He has apparently has had a major influence   onTesla's approach to designing and engineeringthe Model 3
column30: as well as on Musk's (and Tesla's) thinking about   the manufacturing of electric vehicles more generally.Tesla's upcoming Model 3 will incorporate the hard lessons     learned from early production of its Model X SUV. Image source:     Daniel Sparks/The Motley FoolHochholdinger was joined in August by David Erhart
column31: anAppleveteran who became Tesla's senior director of reliability   engineering. Erhart is also thought to havehad a significant impact on the Model 3's   engineering.Last but not least
column32: Tesla was able to hireinterior-engineering expert Anders Bellfrom Volvo Cars. Bell was Volvo's head of interior engineering
column33: and he led the teams that created the interiors of Volvo's XC90
column35: and V90 models.These were all strong hires
column36: and taken together they suggest   that Tesla put much more effort into some key fundamentals with   the Model 3.The upshot: The Model 3 should be a better-built TeslaMake no mistake: The Model S and Model X are extremely   impressive vehicles
column37: especially given Tesla's size and resources   at the times they were launched. But that said
column38: it has been clear   that manufacturing
column39: reliability
column40: and interior quality are all   areas where Tesla needed to make improvements before entering the   mass market with the Model 3.Clearly
column41: Tesla came to the same conclusions and took action.   We'll know in a few months how well those actions are working   out.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column42: it can pay to listen. After all
column43: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column45: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: These 2 Big-Brand Dividend Stocks Are Ridiculously Cheap;2/26/2017;"It's getting harder and harder to find value in the stock   market. But there are still a few sectors that Mr. Market seems   to have overlooked. One big one: auto stocks.Not all auto stocks have been overlooked
column2: of course. Silicon   Valley's electric-car darling
column3: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column4: gets alotof attention from investors. It's obvious why: Tesla's story is   arguably the future of autos
column5: unfolding here in the present.   Investors love that.The thing is
column6: Tesla isn't the only company moving the auto   industry from the gas-guzzling present to a connected
column7: electrified future. A few of the old automakers are right in the   cutting-edge mix
column8: making smart
column9: aggressive moves to thrive and   profit as the industry transforms.makeArticleAd();To some extent
column10: those stories are happening a bit below Wall   Street's radar. Investors haven't yet caught on
column11: in part because   Tesla's story has overshadowed the others.That's a prime recipe for value. Here are two big-name   automakers that are well-positioned for the future
column12: available   today at value prices -- both sporting dividend yields over   4%.Ford Motor Company: Using pickup profits to transformWhen you think ofFord Motor Company(NYSE: F)
column13: you might think about huge-selling pickup trucks
column14: or   Ford's dramatic turnaround a few years ago.You probably aren't thinking about electric cars
column15: self-driving
column16: or new concepts of personal mobility that don't   involve selling cars to individuals. But CEO Mark Fields and his   team
column17: all battle-tested veterans of that turnaround
column18: are doing a   lot of thinking about all of those things these days.Ford's super-profitable pickups are helping to fund electric     cars and new high-tech businesses as the Blue Oval transforms.     Image source: Ford Motor Company.In fact
column19: they're doing more than thinking. Last fall
column20: Ford   explained how it's transforming itself into an ""automotive and   mobility company."" In a nutshell
column21: Ford is making major moves to   optimize the profitability of its current business while   simultaneously making biginvestmentsinself-driving
column22: electric vehicles
column23: and newtechnology-enabled conceptsof ""mobility
column24: ortransportation as a service. (Click on each to learn more.)Ford is already solidly profitable. It postedoperating profit of $10.4 billion in 2016(its second-best ever) with a 6.7% operating profit margin in its   auto-related business. Ford's near-term goal is to get that   margin up to a sustainable 8% by investing in its strengths   (including all thoseextremely profitable pickup trucks) and boosting the profitability of its weaker lines of business
column25: likesmall carsand theresurgent Lincoln luxury brand.Ford plans to begin mass-producing self-driving cars for     fleet use in 2021. It may also sell its self-driving system to     other automakers. Image source: Ford Motor Company.That margin boost will in turn help fund Ford's new lines of   business. Those will be even more profitable: Ford is targetingoperating margin of 20% or betterin each.Long story short: Ford's bottom line is primed for significant   growth over the next few years
column26: much of it driven by technology.   But right now
column27: it's trading at just 7 times its adjusted 2016   earnings

GM is making big   moves to boost the profitability of its core business while   investing in new technology-enabled businesses that will help it   thrive and profit instead of being ""disrupted"" as the industry   transforms.But GM is arguably farther along. GM beat everyone
column33: even   Tesla
column34: to market with anaffordable 200-plus-mile electric car. It's gearing up for ahuge test of ""thousands"" of self-driving   vehicleswith ride-hailing start-up Lyft
column35: of which GMowns 9%. GM's car-sharing business
column36: Maven
column37: is afast-growing high-tech rival to Zipcar-- and as with GM's partnership with Lyft
column38: Maven is introducing   lots of young urban folks to GM's best new models.The electric Chevy Bolt is GM's platform for future tech --     and the first of a whole line of electric GM vehicles. Image     source: General Motors.Meanwhile
column39: GM's core business is already performing at a level   few could have imagined a decade ago. Itearned $12.5 billion in operating profitlast year
column40: with a margin of 7.5%
column41: on all-time record revenue of   $166.4 billion. CEO Mary Barra thinks GM can do better: Several   initiatives are under way to push that margin up into the 8% to   10% range over the next few years.GM'sdividend is deliberately conservative
column42: to ensure that it's sustainable through a downturn. But even   so
column43: and despite the run-up in GM's stock price over the last   year
column44: it's still yielding about 4.1%. Rather than raising the   dividend to levels it might not be able to sustain
column45: GM is   returning cash to its owners with share buybacks --$14 billion worthsince early 2015.Long story short
column46: here's what you get with GM today: profit   growth

column48: a strong and steady dividend

column1: Just Wait: Better Batteries Are Going to Turn the Energy Industry Upside Down;2/26/2017;"Sometimes it's hard to see innovation happening until one day
column2: you wake up and realize everything has changed. A decade ago
column3: smartphones were the stuff of science fiction
column4: cheap solar energy   was a pipe dream
column5: and Elon Musk was still struggling to keep his   electric car startup alive. Today
column6: all three are huge growth   stories.The underlying technologies that drove the innovative products   in smartphones
column7: solar
column8: and EVs were present in 2007
column9: but most   people just didn't see how they could be practically adapted to   revolutionize the world in such a short time.Today
column10: improvements in battery technology are on the cusp of   changing everything we know about energy in transportation and   electricity. The groundwork has already been laid
column11: and a decade   from now
column12: we'll look back and think about how obvious the   transformation should have been ahead of time.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Batteries are the new solar panelsBefore we dive into how batteries will change everything
column13: I   think it's important to frame what's going on today. The future   of growing battery use and falling cost has some precedent in the   energy industry. When I started writing for The Motley Fool in   2010
column14: the solar power industry was small
column15: andthe cost to manufacture a solar panel was about   $1.10 per watt
column16: meaning buying a panel on the open market would cost you around   $1.60 per watt. In 2017
column17: solar panel prices hit $0.40 per watt on   the spot market
column18: a quarter of their cost just seven years   earlier
column19: and a much faster cost reduction than anyone had   predicted. It's no coincidence that between 2010 and 2016 solar   installations globally nearly quintupled from 16 GW to74 GW.The same dynamic is happening in the battery market today
column20: with massive capacity additions
column21: cost reductions
column22: and technology   improvements happening at multiple companies simultaneously   around the world.Tesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) Gigafactory gets a lot of attention
column23: and Musk   has said a 35% reduction in battery costs could be coming. Worth   noting that he claimed his costs were below $190 per kWh early   last year.By 2020
column24: the forecasts have battery costs falling to below   $100 per kWh
column25: with manufacturersSamsung
column26: Panasonic
column27: andLG Chemleading the way. LG Chem is the supplier for the recently   launched Chevy Bolt
column28: which reportedly got battery cells for just   $145 per kWH.On top of these cost reductions
column29: industry sources say that   energy density has doubled
column30: allowing more energy to be packed   into a smaller space. And as space constraints fall and costs   come down
column31: the potential for batteries to disrupt the energy   sector increases.Changing everything we thought we knew about     transportationWhen electric vehicles started to emerge on the scene
column32: battery   cost alone was a deterrent to manufacturing or buying them. When   batteries were $400 per kWh a few years ago
column33: that meant that by   itself
column34: the 65 kWh battery that powered a Tesla cost $26
column35: 000. But   with $100 per kWh pricing on the horizon
column36: a 100 kWh battery would   cost just $10
column37: 000 and provide a car over 300 miles in range per   charge
column38: making EVs a much more palatable choice.It's no coincidence thatGeneral Motors(NYSE: GM)
column39: BMW
column40: Tesla
column41: and many others are accelerating their EV development   now. Batteries themselves are no longer a hurdle for the industry   to get over; soon
column42: they will be a cost advantage over   conventional vehicles.I'm also becoming more convinced that transportation can be   disrupted on a larger scale. Electric buses built by companies   likeProterraare now cost competitive with diesel powered models
column43: Mercedes-Benzis testing urban e-trucks
column44: and new companies likeNicola Oneare launching electric semi-tractors.The market growth of electric vehicles of all sizes is like a   ball rolling down a hill -- we just don't know how fast it's   rolling or where it's going to land. But with battery prices   dropping
column45: we can be assured that the disruption in the   transportation industry is just beginning.Electricity will never be the sameWhile batteries in vehicles will be a highly visible   application
column46: power storage may be just as important to the energy   industry overall. Batteries can store energy to make the grid   more reliable
column47: to offset the intermittence of renewable energy   sources like wind and solar
column48: and even justify delaying or   cancelling the construction of ""peaker plants"" that come online   only during periods of high demand.The incredible innovation better
column49: cheaper batteries allow is   the ability to think of electricity as more than a constant   supply-and-demand equation. Since the grid was built
column50: generators   had to match their production capacity with peak demand
column51: no   matter what that demand was. Now
column52: we can move excess supply from   one time of a day to another
column53: and begin to start using energy   more efficiently.Batteries can also be installed in homes
column54: at businesses
column55: or by   grid operators. When a customer can react to price signals at a   moment's notice or can cheaply and easily store the energy from   their rooftop solar panels for use at night
column56: it changes the   electricity business forever.Batteries are going to change everythingThe rapid cost reductions and improving technology in the   battery industry are going to change a lot of what we thought we   knew about energy. And as these products get more cost effective   they'll become more common and soon they'll be commonplace.A decade from now
column57: it won't be strange to drive an electric   car
column58: or take an electric bus
column59: home from work
column60: and flip on lights   that are powered by solar or wind-generated electricity stored in   your battery system. The revolution is clearly happening
column61: and   investors should make sure they're on the right side of the   disruption so they don't get run over.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column62: it can pay to listen. After all
column63: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column64: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column65: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column2: Fitbit and Square;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsToday
column4: I'd like to take a look at three stocks -Tesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA)
column5: Fitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT) andSquare Inc(NYSE:SQ) - that caused the biggest reactions this week.makeArticleAd();Source:FamZoo Staff via Flickr (Modified)It's fun to dig into quarterly numbers
column6: but it's equally fun watching investors react to those very numbers and sometimes exaggerate even the slightest deviation from the models.So much hope is already leveraged in every tick on these charts that a penny can create or destroy billions in market cap - and when many high-multiple names report simultaneously
column7: the fireworks get intense.7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Flush With CashThis week
column8: the fireworks were intense.High-Impact Tech Earnings: Tesla Inc (TSLA)Source: ShutterstockTesla probably has the biggest cult on Wall Street right now
column9: producing just 83
column10: 000 cars a year to justify a $45 billion valuation.The key
column11: as always
column12: is growth: According to Elon Musk's conference call last night
column13: the assembly line should accelerate 500% this year and then double again in 2018. News that sales last quarter ramped up 30% year-over-year supports the still-hypothetical timeline and it even brings it incrementally closer.Beyond that all-important ramp
column14: TSLA is still bleeding cash
column15: which is far from surprising. While the burn rate is narrowing
column16: Musk is still going to be burning capital for at least another year.Until then
column17: the market feels comfortable moving Tesla Inc shares around at roughly 4.4x trailing sales - and this quarter at least
column18: Musk gave us a reason to keep cheering in the long-term.High-Impact Tech Earnings: Fitbit Inc (FIT)Source:Via FitbitFitbit
column19: on the other hand
column20: may be bouncing now
column21: but the fallen star is still staring down the gun of declining sales and it has little concrete comfort to give investors wondering whether to hang around a few years for the product mix to turn around.That may never happen. FIT sales in the key holiday quarter came in a little below Wall Street's already heavily discounted forecasts. A few months ago
column22: the bulls were counting on this quarter to bring year-over-year growth back
column23: but it's clear that just didn't happen.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy and Hold ForeverNow that the final numbers are on the table
column24: sales actually declined nearly 20% from last year
column25: which pushes the recovery window back to 2019
column26: if not beyond. That's a long time to run at a loss
column27: and in the meantime
column28: Fitbit Inc's research and development investment lags entrenched would-be competitors who want the wearable computing market for themselves.High-Impact Tech Earnings: Square Inc (SQ)Source:Via SquareSquare showed us the biggest fireworks. The stock was geared for 20% top-line growth
column29: while Wall Street wanted confirmation that revenue would clear $2 billion across the current year in order to keep that growth ramp - and we got it.What has earned the company a standing ovation is management's success when it comes to reducing the quarterly cash burn. SQ should actually break even on an adjusted basis in its next earnings report and earn as much as $0.19 a share for all of 2017 once all the ""adjustments"" are made.If so
column30: we're a lot closer to GAAP profitability than many people thought. Inflection points like that do great things to stock valuations
column31: which is why people are piling in on Square Inc now while they can.Hilary Kramer is the editor ofGameChangers

column1: Why Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Plunged
column2: And Why You Should Buy;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWall Street is a fickle beast. All you need to confirm that isTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA). The company reported a fourth-quarter loss that narrowed to 69 cents per share from $2.02 a year ago
column4: and revenues that nearly doubled from to $2.28 billion from $1.21 billion. And yet
column5: TSLA stock plunged roughly 6.4% following the report.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThat even ignored Tesla's announcement that Model 3 production was on pace with expectations and that it would deliver between 47
column7: 000 vehicles in the first quarter compared to just 76
column8: 000 vehicles in all of 2016.What gives?Well
column9: there are several reasons that the financial media are floating for the drop in Tesla stock.Earnings missed expectationsfor a loss of only 43 cents per share (even though revenue bested Wall Street's forecast for $2.19 billion).There is also the narrative that margins and revenue are cloudy due to the SolarCity acquisition.Finally
column10: the prevailing story for the knee-jerk selloff in TSLA stock is thatCEO Elon Musk hintedthat the company could issue more shares to raise capital for Model 3 production.All of these are valid reasons for a selloff.The problem is that Wall Street and investors knew about all of these factors prior to Tesla's quarterly earnings report.  In fact
column11: afterOppenheimer said on Feb. 14that investors should expect Tesla to take advantage of its recent highs to issue new stock to raise funds for Model 3 production
column12: TSLA stock went on a two-day 4% rally to a new all-time high.The 10 Best Stock Charts on Wall Street Right NowWhich brings us to the real reason Tesla stock is down following earnings: profit taking.What's Going on With Tesla?Click to EnlargeShares are up an impressive 32% since the November elections
column13: with most of those gains coming since the start of 2017. As a result
column14: TSLA was considerably overbought
column15: and traders are taking this opportunity to use previously known issues to take profits off the table.If you're in holding TSLA stock for the long-term
column16: don't panic. According to Tesla's quarterly report
column17: the Model 3 is still on track for full production in July
column18: and deliveries are ramping up in fine style (remember 47
column20: 000 vehicles in the first quarter compared to just 76
column21: 000 vehicles in all of 2016?)  And that's not to mention the opportunities that Tesla is working on outside of is electric vehicle operations.In fact
column22: with Tesla trading at a discount near $255 on Friday
column23: TSLA stock is a buy.The problem isn't whether shares will bounce back
column24: it's a matter of how to pick them up amid the current market volatility.The answer is options.Looking out over the short-term
column25: March TSLA options implieds are pricing in a potential move of about 7% heading into expiration. As a result
column26: the upper bound lies at about $269
column27: while the lower bound rests near $234.With key support near $250
column28: I would be extremely surprised to see TSLA stock trade near $235
column29: and the upper bound of $269 rests well shy of the stock's recent all-time highs
column30: leaving plenty of room for a rebound run higher.2 Trades for TSLA StockMarried Put:On way to buy Tesla at current levels and ensure you have peace of mind in your portfolio is to enter what is called a ""married put."" In this strategy
column31: traders buy to open one front-month at-the-money or out-of-the-money TSLA put for every 100 shares purchased.The strike of the purchased put should reflect your risk tolerance. So
column32: a March $250 put offers nearly full protection at current levels
column33: with losses limited to about the cost of the put and brokerage fees. An out-of-the-money March $245 put would allow for TSLA to dip a bit further before the ""insurance"" kicked in.Buy Under Armour Inc (UAA) Stock While the World Hates ItAt last check
column34: the TSLA March $250 put was offered at $6.78
column35: or $678 per contract
column36: while the stock position would total $roughly $252 at pre-open levels. If TSLA closes below $250 when March options expire
column37: you would be able to exit the position and avoid any additional losses by exercising the put.Finally
column38: if Tesla holds above $200 through March expiration
column39: you can roll the $250 put forward into April if you feel you still need the protection.Put Sell:You'll usually see me recommend put sell positions as a way to capture premium on a stock
column40: but you can also use these options as a way to essentially name the price you want to pay for a stock. If you want to own TSLA stock
column41: but want to wait for it to dip below $250
column42: you could sell the March $250 put for $6.78
column43: or $678 per contract
column44: collect the premium
column45: and wait for the shares to pull back.If Tesla doesn't trade below $250
column46: you still keep the premium and can roll your target out to the next contract month and try again. The downside here is that if TSLA never hits your target
column47: you never own the shares at the price you want to pay.As of this writing

column1: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Is Making a Money Grab;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAt first blush
column3: the purchase byAlibaba Group Holding Ltd(NYSE:BABA) ofMoneygram International Inc(NASDAQ:MGI) doesn't seem like a huge deal for BABA stock. Alibaba affiliateAntFinancialis paying $880 million for MGI
column4: after all. Yet
column5: Alibaba stock is worth nearly $250 billion - almost 300 times the acquisition price.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockI wouldn't dismiss the deal as ""minor"" so quickly
column6: however. While the purchase price isn't high
column7: and the near-term impact on BABA stock is likely minimal
column8: Moneygram highlights the long-term strategy and potential for Alibaba.The bull case for Alibaba stock has two major pillars: First
column9: the company can move beyond China to being a worldwide player and a legitimate competitor toAmazon.com
column10: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN). Second
column11: like Amazon
column12: Alibaba can move from its e-commerce roots into all sort of profitable efforts.The Moneygram acquisition scores well on both counts. Alibaba continues its push into the West. And
column13: through the tie-up of Ant Financial and Moneygram
column14: it continues its entry into the potentially lucrative digital banking and payment services markets.7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowStrategically
column15: the deal lays the groundwork for further growth of BABA stock - and at a very reasonable price. Investors shouldn't dismiss the deal simply because the price doesn't seem high enough to matter.Alibaba Stock Needs International GrowthAt the moment
column16: Alibaba's business still relies on Chinese e-commerce. In the company's third quarter (ending Dec. 31)
column17: China commerce generated 80% of revenue
column18: with ~96% of that figure coming from retail. Other businesses
column19: including cloud computing and entertainment
column20: make up the other 20%. But
column21: those businesses remain unprofitable; Alibaba earnings remain dependent on Chinese commerce. That's a bit of risk on its own
column22: given concerns about the Chinese economy.Ant Financial isn't consolidated onto Alibaba's P&L
column23: and at the moment
column24: BABA has a profit-sharing agreement and could take up to one-third of Ant's equity in an IPO. But
column25: even that minority ownership means Alibaba can use Ant Financial as an entrance into international markets
column26: and that's where Moneygram fits nicely.To begin
column27: Ant can target Chinese expatriates in the U.S. and elsewhere. Ant already has joint ventures and partnerships worldwide
column28: and Moneygram further supports its payment infrastructure. Plus
column29: Alibaba's other offerings such as e-commerce
column30: entertainment and even cloud services
column31: can follow Ant's lead.At a valuation of nearly $250 billion
column32: Alibaba stock probably can't hold up on the Chinese market alone
column33: considering the sheer size of that market. There are too many concerns about the macro environment in that country. Internet and e-commerce penetration is increasing
column34: but still low relative to developed countries. Every step Alibaba takes toward becoming a legitimate international presence - and a real competitor to Amazon - supports the bull case for BABA stock.The Moneygram purchase is actually a big step in that direction.Alibaba Isn't Just a RetailerIt's hard to imagine what Amazon.com might look like had the company decided to be ""only"" an e-commerce retailer. It's almost certain that AMZN stock would trade well below its current levels of approximately $840 per share.Alibaba has certainly learned lessons from its American peer. It's moved into cloud as well
column35: where the companyhas built a viable businesswith worldwide aspirations. Now
column36: Alibaba is looking to Hollywood for growth.Further
column37: the company has the infrastructure for a worldwide payments business
column38: at a time when the future of that industry is in serious flux. That's a significant opportunity for BABA stock
column39: even for a company the size of Alibaba's
column40: and even with the company owning only a portion of Ant Financial.Paypal Holdings Inc(NASDAQ:PYPL) is worth more than $50 billion. Combined
column41: Visa Inc(NYSE:V)
column42: Mastercard Inc(NYSE:MA) andAmerican Express Company(NYSE:AXP) are valued around $400 billion.7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Flush With CashThat's not to suggest that Ant is the next Visa
column43: or even the next Paypal. But
column44: Ant's efforts in payment services can move the needle for Alibaba stock
column45: even given BABA's $250 billion valuation. Plus
column46: Visa and Mastercard don't have the added luxury of using a payment services platform to grow retail sales.All told
column47: I continue to believe that BABA stock is undervalued. I don't know that the Moneygram acquisition changes that dramatically in the near term
column48: but it highlights the potential of the long-term strategy here. Owning a Chinese e-commerce retailer might seem to have a lot risk at the moment

column1: Nordstrom
column2: Inc. (JWN) Stock Looks Great After Q4 Earnings;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNordstrom
column4: Inc.(NYSE:JWN) tumbled ahead of its fourth-quarter earnings report Thursday
column5: but JWN stock is headed in the right direction once more after a better-than-expected result.makeArticleAd();Source:Phillip Pessar via Flickr (Modified)The short story: Profits looked good
column6: revenues are still going
column7: margins are showing signs of stabilization and cash flows are about to get a nice boost. Yet the valuation of JWN shares remains depressed
column8: leading me to believe that Nordstrom stock is going to head higher.A lot higher.The Margin Story Is Getting BetterFirst
column9: the headline numbers: Nordstrom earnings for Q4 came to $1.37 per share
column10: easily beating estimates of $.122 per share. Revenues of $4.2 billion were up 2.4% year-over-year
column11: but did fall shy of estimates for $4.37 billion.On the margin side
column12: though
column13: the story keeps getting better.The 10 Best Stock Charts on Wall Street Right NowSimilar toMacy's Inc.(NYSE:M) andKohl's Corporation(NYSE:KSS)
column14: JWN saw gross margins expand healthily in the quarter. Nordstrom
column15: though
column16: is significantly outperforming its mall peers. Retail gross profit rate increased more than 100 basis points in the quarter
column17: versus 90 basis points at Macy's and 33 basis points and Kohl's. This is due to management's strong execution.Firstly
column18: JWN is getting a handle on inventories. Sales growth outpaced inventory growth at Nordstrom by 500 basis points in Q4. Secondly
column19: the company is putting an emphasis on private label brands. This provides a shield against mall-wide promotional activity. Going forward
column20: gross margins should begin to experience some level of stabilization and maybe even steadily expand.Operating expense growth also really came down this year. Because the transition to a multi-channel business model required significant investment
column21: JWN's operating expenses grew at 9% per year from 2010 to 2015. The investments paid off
column22: and Nordstrom's e-commerce business now represents a fourth of overall sales (versus 8% in 2010).More importantly
column23: though
column24: this early digital success has been followed by less aggressive spend. Operating expenses only grew 4% this year. JWN management implied opex would grow at a lower rate over the next several years.In other words
column25: the ""big"" spending era seems to be over. That means we might start to see some opex leverage over the next several years. Opex leverage plus buybacks would flow into earnings growth greatly in excess of 3 to 4% per year.Again
column26: that isn't bad considering that JWN stock is trading at less than 15 times earnings.The Nordstrom BrandThe Nordstrom brand continues to underperform while Nordstrom Rack continues to outperform. This underscores the price sensitivity of the average JWN customer. That isn't great against the backdrop of intense price competition from other retailers.There are
column27: though
column28: several near-term catalysts which could re-spark growth in the full-priced business.Nordstrom is rolling out a new ""reserve merchandise"" mobile feature in 2017 to help drive full-priced sales. The Seattle pilot had tremendous success at a select few JWN stores
column29: so there is upside for sales in 2017 behind greater mobile commerce engagement.Nordstrom's buy-online
column30: pick-up-in-store program had a great 2016 with sales volume growth of 45%.The Canada business is only at $300 million in sales out of a $1 billion opportunity.JWN experienced 55% year-over-year growth this year in its Rewards member base to 7.8 million customers.Overall
column31: JWN management is guiding for 3 to 4% revenue growth this year. That is an appropriate multiyear compounded growth rate. In other words
column32: Nordstrom should be able to grow revenues around 3% to 4% per year over the next several years.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Just Entered Dangerous TerritoryThat isn't bad for a ""going-out-business"" department store. Especially considering that JWN stock trades at less than 15 times trailing earnings.Bright Cash Flow FutureThe end of the ""big"" spending era is also a significant boost to JWN cash flows. Despite margin compression and slower revenue growth
column33: JWN posted exceptional cash flow metrics in 2016. Nordstrom's operating cash flow was $1.6 billion
column34: far above the trailing 5-year average of $1.2 billion. Meanwhile
column35: free cash flow was $550 million
column36: also significantly higher than the trailing 5-year average.There are a couple things at play here.To adjust to lower sales growth
column37: JWN management is keeping inventories down. This is significantly boosting operating cash flows. Moreover
column38: Nordstrom decreased capital expenditures by 20% year-over-year. Both of these cash flow tailwinds are here to stay. JWN management is committed to tight inventory control
column39: and capex will equal 4% of sales over the next several years versus 5% historically.All together
column40: the company is positioned to see a strong boost in cash flows over the next five years.Bottom Line on JWN StockNordstrom sports a 3.3% dividend yield and only trades at 14.5 times trailing earnings. Revenue growth is positive
column41: and will remain positive into the foreseeable future given robust e-commerce growth. Margins will stabilize in the near future
column42: and earnings have a promising growth trajectory. Most importantly
column43: the company is set to return more cash to shareholders than ever before.Drop Wal-Mart Stores Inc (WMT) Stock Before It Drops YouThe stock traded around $60 per share just 2 months ago. The story today is a lot stronger than it was two months ago. From an investor standpoint
column44: this is a good set-up for significant share price appreciation over the next several months.As of this writing

column1: United Continental Holdings Inc (UAL) Stock Is Just Dying to Take Flight;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSeveral airline stocks that look interesting based on their charts
column3: but there is one that particularly looks interesting to me as an options trader. That stock isUnited Continental Holdings Inc(NYSE:UAL).makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockMaybe I'm biased on UAL stock because I just booked a flight from Chicago to Miami on United. Or maybe it's just that airlines - includingAmerican Airlines Group Inc(NASDAQ:AAL) andDelta Air Lines
column4: Inc.(NYSE:DAL) - have made double-digit gains since the beginning of November. There are several possible reasons behind this
column5: including President Donald Trump promising to upgrade the air traffic control system and recent interest in the airlines from Warren Buffett.For those reasons and more
column6: I like United stock
column7: particularly via the trade idea below.The Trade SetupThe rationale: Taking a look at the chart below
column8: United shares moved higher throughout the month of November before settling in and trading between about $70 and $76 since the beginning of December.Click to EnlargeIn addition
column9: UAL stock has made several attempts to move through the $76 level
column10: including several times this week. So far it has not been able to do so.The 10 Best Stock Charts on Wall Street Right NowI will be keeping an eye out for it in case it does for a bullish directional trade.How to Trade UAL Stock HereThe trade:Sell the UAL Mar $68/$70 put credit spread (selling the Mar $70 put and buying the $68 put) for 30 cents or better.The strategy:The maximum potential profit for this trade is 30 cents if UAL stock is trading at or above $70 at Mar expiration. The maximum loss is $1.70 ($2 - $0.30) or whatever credit was received for the spread if UAL stock is trading at or below $70 at Mar expiration. Breakeven is $69.70 at expiration based on a 30-cent credit.With all out-of-the-money (OTM) credit spreads like this trade
column11: the risk is greater than the reward. The reason for this is because of the likelihood of profit. Essentially this trade has three out of four ways to profit. The stock can move higher
column12: trade sideways or just stay above the breakeven point at expiration.For this trade idea to be successful and finish at max profit
column13: the stock needs to stay above the $70 level by March monthly expiration. The low end of the channel needs to act as support like it has done since early December.Adding to the potential support for this trade
column14: the 50-day simple moving average has moved up to the $74 area
column15: and the stock is currently trading above that level.Apple Inc. Fesses Up to iPhone 6 Battery Issue
column16: Releases FixWhat also makes this trade idea intriguing from an options perspective is the current implied volatility of the options. The current IV is above the historical volatility (HV) levels which may indicate the current premiums may be a little inflated.This is perfect for a credit trade on UAL stock.John Kmiecik is the head options instructor for Market Taker Mentoring
column17: and co-author of the eBook 3 Secrets to Making Money in Any Market. Get your complimentary copy of his option tradingeBookhere. He can be reached atjohn@markettaker.com. As of this writing

column1: Apple Inc. Fesses Up to iPhone 6 Battery Issue
column2: Releases Fix;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIf it seems as thoughApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has been fighting with battery issues with the iPhone 6 and iPhone 6s for months
column4: that's because it has.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleThere was a limited recall of iPhone 6s batteries blamed on a manufacturing issue
column5: problems in China and recently reports of widespread iPhone 6 sudden shutdown issues that seemed battery related. The company always denied any widespread issue.Until now.AAPL has finally acknowledged a problem related to the iPhone 6 battery  and says it has released a fix.The iPhone 6 Battery Has Been  ProblematicIf there's one thing 2016 will be remembered for when it comes to consumer electronics
column6: it's the challenges of working with lithium-ion batteries.5 Income Tax Deductions You Can't Afford to MissThe poster child for just how wrong this technology can go isSamsung Electronic Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF). Samsung had a terrible 2016 after its flagship Galaxy Note 7's lithium-ion batteries were implicated in multiple fires
column7: This led to a complete recall of the device
column8: an estimated $10 billion hit
column9: a seriously damaged reputation and anextensive investigation to pinpoint the cause.In comparison
column10: AAPL's iPhone 6 battery woes have been less spectacular
column11: but the cloud over Apple's previous two generations of phones has lasted just as long - if not longer. And they proved much more frustrating in terms of nailing down a cause
column12: or a fix. That's because there appear to be multiple issues at play. And just as Apple admits there's a problem and announces a solution
column13: another iPhone 6 battery issue seems to pop up.In 2016
column14: Apple had to deal with aninvestigation in Chinaover reports that iPhone 6 and iPhone 6s batteries were not only failing
column15: but leaving the devices with expensive damage. Apple's findings pointed to cheap knock-off chargers as the culprit. Then there were reports of iPhone 6s phones unexpectedly shutting down. Apple eventually pinpointed the cause as being a manufacturing defect in a batch of batteries. Abattery exchange programwas launched
column16: but that got off to a rocky start when Apple Stores were flooded by iPhone owners hoping for a replacement battery
column17: and a backlog of repairs.Just as that mess was being sorted out
column18: complaints began to rise of iPhone 6 sudden shutdown issues. This was a new iPhone 6 battery issue and seemed to affect a growing number of users. It also affected the iPhone 6s
column19: but not the iPhone 7.The problem got so bad that at one point in January
column20: rumors started thatApple was planning to launch a full-scale iPhone 6 battery exchange program. However
column21: AAPL continued to deny there was a widespread problem with iPhone and 6s batteries.Now
column22: Apple has come clean.Apple Releases Fix for iPhone 6 Shutdown IssueThe company finally admitted that iPhone 6 and 6s phones have been suddenly and randomly shutting down
column23: forcing owners to plug them into a charger before they can be restarted. But
column24: AAPL says it released a fix and it's effective.In a statement released toTechCrunch
column25: Apple says iOS 10.2.1 finally addresses the issue:""We're seeing a more than 80% reduction in iPhone 6s and over 70% reduction on iPhone 6 of devices unexpectedly shutting down.""So what happened?AAPL says the iPhone 6 battery (and in some cases the iPhone 6s as well) suffers from a limitation of all-lithium-ion batteries. As these batteries get older
column26: they sometime deliver power unevenly. This could trigger the iPhone's power management system to force an emergency shutdown to protect the device.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Just Entered Dangerous TerritoryApple made changes to that system in iOS 10.2.1
column27: essentially making it less sensitive to minor fluctuations. It also added new functionality so that should an iPhone 6 sudden shutdown occur
column28: the user can restart their device without having to be connected to a charger. The company says it also will add a battery diagnostic screen to iOS that warns iPhone owners when their battery requires service.The fact this issue was directly related to aging lithium-ion batteries explains why it was the iPhone 6 battery being implicated more frequently than the 6s
column29: why the numbers seemed to keep growing and why the iPhone 7 hasn't yet been affected.Will this mark the end of AAPL's drawn out iPhone 6 battery saga? The company has been playing whack-a-mole trying to identify issues with its lithium-ion batteries. But this fix seems to be enough of an umbrella solution that it may finally be able to put this chapter behind it.And let Apple go back to the good old days when complaints were limited to wishing the iPhone lasted longer on a battery charge As of this writing

column1: Energy Select Sector SPDR (ETF) (XLE): My Favorite ETF to Trade;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOne of my core strategies is relative value trading. This is the essence of the original hedge fund philosophy created by A.W. Jones - to buy a stock that is comparatively cheap and hedge by selling a highly correlated security that is comparatively expensive. One of my favorite ways to employ this strategy is by usingEnergy Select Sector SPDR (ETF)(NYSEARCA:XLE) versus the price of oil.makeArticleAd();By having an underlying correlated commodity to use in my decision making

column4: the ability to express a directional viewpoint
column5: look from relative value situations
column6: or hedge off risk using options is paramount.XLE provides tight bid/ask spreads along with considerable volume that is the hallmark of an effective trading vehicle.The 7 Best ETFs for Retirement InvestorsRight now

column8: 000 ETFs are listed for trading. Many of these have little to no volume and no options available-the so called roach motels. Others
column9: such as heavyweights likeSPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust(NYSEARCA:SPY) or  SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average ETF(NYSEARCA:DIA)

I would look for that convergence to continue over the coming weeks.How to Handle the XLEOne way to position would be to short XLE and go long oil futures orUnited States Oil Fund LP (ETF)(NYSEARCA:USO).
