column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Just Entered Dangerous Territory;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsShares ofTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) dropped sharply on Thursday following the company's latest financial results. Tesla saw a narrower-than-expected loss in the fourth quarter and revenue rose almost 90% on a year-over-year basis. However
column3: TSLA stock holders seemed to focus on the company's still-increasing cash burn rate that now raises ""concern"" for a new capital raise.makeArticleAd();As a result of Thursday's 6.45% selloff
column4: the near- to possibly intermediate-term path of least resistance now appears to point lower.In the bigger picture
column5: Tesla stock remains constructively positioned. And I believe shares ultimately will provide further gains for long-term investors. But for now
column6: even bulls might have to wear their bear costumes.When I last discussed TSLA stock onDec. 16
column7: I offered that the stock increasingly looked ready to move higher off the lower end of its bigger-picture trading range with a near-term upside target around the $215 area. This upside price target was reached just a few days later as the stock rallied a quick 8%.As a quick reminder before looking at the charts (and because yesterday I received some questions around this): How much money TSLA loses each quarter at this stage does not matter nearly as much as the rate of change in its car production and sales.The 10 Best Stock Charts on Wall Street Right NowThat is the basic definition of a growth stock. And Tesla is a growth stock.TSLA Stock ChartsLooking at Tesla shares through the lens of their multiyear weekly chart
column8: we see that TSLA has spent the majority of the past couple years bouncing around in a wide trading range that for the most part spans from around $180 on the lower end to about $285 on the upper end.Click to EnlargeJust last week
column9: TSLA stock once again bumped into the upper end of this range
column10: where it thus far has been promptly rejected. Note also that the most recent ascent over the past couple of months has seen the stock rally from the lower end to the upper end of this range in a straight shot.This very fact makes a sustainable breakout above this range in the near-term most unlikely due to the stock's near- to intermediate-term overbought readings.Also
column11: a sideways consolidation or possibly a mean-reversion move to the middle of the aforementioned trading range at this juncture looks likely.On the daily chart
column12: we see that with Thursday's selling
column13: TSLA stock not only broke below its steady
column14: nearly three-month-long uptrend
column15: but also below its 21-day simple moving average (yellow).Click to EnlargeNote also that the up-gap on Feb. 9 (blue arrow) was negated by yesterday's down-gap
column16: thus also forming what we may refer to as an ""island top"" formation.Buy This Nvidia Corporation Dip for Free Right NowAll of these three developments are bearish for TSLA stock as it relates to the near to possibly intermediate-term. The path of least resistance now looks to point toward the $240 area as a next downside target.Traders and active investors could look to initiate short trading positions either through Tesla stock or its options.As always
column17: any strong daily bullish reversal would be a stop-loss signal.Like what you see? column1: Qualcomm
column2: Inc. (QCOM) Stock Has Big Prospects Despite Its Problems;2/24/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt's a bittersweet victory
column4: to be sure. Just whenQualcomm
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) starts to unveil a game-changing technology
column6: a legal hurricane starts to make landfall. If any current or would-be owners of QCOM stock are torn as to what the future likely holds
column7: there's good reason.makeArticleAd();Source:Karlis Dambrans via FlickrAnd yet
column8: as much jeopardy as the company's bottom line may be in at this time
column9: the fact that Qualcomm stock is still down more than 25% over the past three years suggests the market saw a litigation headwind coming sooner or later. The worst-case scenario may already be priced into QCOM stock
column10: which means the recent weakness makes for a compelling entry point.The BadThe legal wrangling is mostly withApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column11: superficially. But
column12: should Apple be successful with its effort
column13: it opens the door to other litigation
column14: not to mention emboldens a similar case being brought against Qualcomm by the Federal Trade Commission.The short version of the story: Apple (and the FTC and the Korea Fair Trade Commission
column15: for that matter) are all arguing the same thing - Qualcomm's business model of licensing its technologies to phonemakers isnot only exorbitant
column16: but unlawfully stifles competition. That's a legal no-no in most any country. The Korea Fair Trade Commission isseeking $873 million for essentially the same.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy and Hold ForeverFor the record
column17: QCOM has lost this argument before. In 2015
column18: thecompany forked over $975 million to Chinafor breaking that country's antitrust laws. Indeed
column19: Qualcomm wasallegedly charging all-encompassing licensing feesto phonemakers that may or may not have needed access to all of the technology in that IP package another dubious practice.Years of sharp dealing have finally caught up with Qualcomm.The GoodThe irony is
column20: while the company was over-milking its aging patent portfolio
column21: QCOM was also developing some new - and highly marketable - intellectual property.The idea of the Internet of Things (IoT) is an exciting one
column22: but the reality is
column23: the technology and bandwidth needed to meet the need just isn't ready
column24: yet. Or
column25: it wasn't anyway. This week
column26: Qualcommunveiled its 802.11ax technology
column27: which can carry four times the amount of data current Wi-Fi technology carries
column28: but without using any more bandwidth.Qualcomm Technologies VP Rahul Patel explained:It is taking Wi-Fi to a new level from a user-experience point of view. What it is trying to do is prepare the Wi-Fi network
column29: which in many cases is experiencing a lot of congestion
column30: largely because the network is becoming dense and is not able to deal with the amount of traffic.At the same time
column31: the company has created a whole new kind of RF ""front end
column32: or the radio connection between a mobile phone's modem and the transceiver. Not only is it a superior solution to current alternatives
column33: it's a simpler solution that works with a variety of connection protocols
column34: such as LTE and MIMO
column35: by the utilization of modem intelligence.They're not the kind of advances the average consumer cares about
column36: or even understands. With 5G connectivity about to become the norm
column37: however
column38: these little advances are actually big advances that phonemakers will desperately need.Bottom Line for QCOM StockIn simplest terms
column39: the future of QCOM stock lies somewhere between the two ends of this good/bad continuum. One way or another
column40: sooner or later
column41: Qualcomm's business model of leveraging an aging patent portfolio - and doing so in a questionable manner - is going to falter. If the company wants to continue being an IP player
column42: it's going to need some new IP.The question is
column43: will 802.11ax and new RF front-end platforms be enough? It matters
column44: simply becausethe company's licensing and royalty revenue is roughly twice its revenue from outright chip sales.3 Stocks That Could Soar on a Short SqueezeThe answer to this question is a qualified yes; the qualification is the speed with which lawsuits will result in a decision
column45: and the time that will be needed for IoT and 5G to reach critical mass. Odds are good the former will hurt before the latter helps
column46: meaning Qualcomm could be headed for a dry spell
column47: earnings-wise.Still
column48: for the true long-termer who can stomach the ""in the meantime"" volatility
column49: the market may start to appreciate the potential of the distant future nowafter a few years of strong bearish pressure.QCOM stock may not be appropriate for grandma's retirement portfolio
column50: but there's little doubt the company's new technologies will be crucial to the next generation of connectivity.As of this writing

column1: Tax Reform by August? The Market Abides;2/23/2017;"Thursday
column2: February 23
column3: 2017makeArticleAd();The Dow keeps on rolling

column1: Has Fitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Finally Hit the Bottom?;2/23/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIf there was ever a company that needs good news
column3: and good newsnow
column4: it would beFitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT). Immediately after its introduction to the retail market
column5: FIT made a pronounced impact on the health and wellness sector. More importantly
column6: it became a cultural phenomenon thanks to the company's quirky advertisements. But in the financial markets
column7: Fitbit stock has lacked.makeArticleAd();Source:Via FitbitSure
column8: Wall Street piled into Fitbit stock during its initial public offering honeymoon phase. Between June 18 until Aug. 5 of 2015
column9: FIT stock gained an extremely impressive 74%. Unfortunately
column10: that only covers 34 trading days. Since then
column11: Fitbit stock has become the antithesis of its consumer base: lethargic
column12: unmotivated and  well
column13: something that rhymes with ""FIT.""But with the once on-fire consumer tech firm releasing its fourth quarter of fiscal year 2016 results
column14: will fortune shine on Fitbit stock?Just by looking at the hard numbers
column15: I wouldn't hold my breath.Tough Earnings for Fitbit to SwallowFitbit reported aQ4 lossof $146.3 million. Although the fact that FIT went into the red wasn't a surprise
column16: the magnitude certainly was. On a per share basis
column17: Fitbit stock was expected by Wall Street analysts to mitigate negativity to 48 cents. Instead
column18: losses adjusted for one-time gains and costs resulted in 56 cents of red ink.7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowThe top line didn't impress
column19: either. For Q4
column20: forecasted revenue averaged $575.8 million. In actuality
column21: FIT stock managed $573.8 million
column22: or a negative surprise of a little more than 0.3%. The margin of the miss isn't so bad in and of itself. However
column23: with so many critics taking aim at Fitbit stock
column24: the company needed something spectacular on this front. Whatever this is
column25: it just isn't going to do the trick.Although it's not fair
column26: the Fitbit earnings miss is exaggerated due to the fact that it's the first one. According toCNBC's archives
column27: prior to yesterday's earnings report
column28: the device maker leveraged an averageearnings surpriseof 103%.One of the most prominent criticisms came from Jim Cramer. Appearing on CNBC's ""Squawk on the Street"" segment late last month
column29: Cramer suggested that FIT was acommoditized company. Once people buy the product
column30: there is no compelling reason to buy again. And when you consider the sharp erosion in sales growth
column31: it's hard not to see this point.To illustrate
column32: quarter-over-quarterrevenue growthin 2015 was 170%. In 2016
column33: it has dropped to an alarming 25%!Since they're not killing it on profitability margins
column34: FIT has drastic actions to take. At least to that end
column35: management is making the right moves.Easing the Minds of Fitbit Stock BuyersLast month
column36: FIT announced aseries of layoffs
column37: which will affect about 10% of the total workforce. The tech firm is hoping to save $200 million
column38: which is a huge deal for its size.We also have to reconsider this criticism of Fitbit stock as a ""commoditized"" investment. It's both a valid and an invalid argument. You can literally say the same thing aboutApple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)
column39: Samsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)
column40: andSony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE). That hasn't stopped them from making smart phones
column41: tablets and cameras. The latter is a particularly good example of a widely distributed product continuing to find solid demand.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Is Making a Giant Push in Its Supercharger NetworkIt shouldn't come as no surprise that we live in a disposable world. Many of us couldn't fathom driving the same car for more than three or four years. As long as FIT stock remains an innovation investment first
column42: I don't care about ancillary titles like commoditized.And the company has a strong user base. Build those numbers
column43: and Fitbit Inc can turn that frown upside down.Finally
column44: there is something to be said about hitting rock bottom. Fitbit is sitting at breakeven despite what otherwise was apretty lousy reportthat also included negative guidance.The bearishness seems completely priced in. I'm not guaranteeing a floor
column45: but there are enough positives for Fitbit stock to begin recovering from here.As of this writing

column1: Will Driverless Cars End Traditional Car Ownership?;2/23/2017;"I bought a used car recently
column2: and a few days after I brought   it home
column3: a friend asked me
column4: ""Do you think this is the last car   you'll ever buy?""We talk a lot about self-driving cars
column5: so I knew exactly where   he was going with his question. He was hinting at the   fact that both autonomous car technologies and ride-sharing   services are advancing so quickly that by the time I'd be in   the market for another vehicle
column6: I might not actually need to buy   one.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();By 2035
column7: the IHS estimates there will be 76 million cars on   the road worldwide with some level of autonomy.Even now
column8: semi-autonomous cars that can keep themselves in   their lanes
column9: automatically brake in emergency situations
column10: and   slow down to match the speed of the car in front of themcan be purchasedfor as little as $20
column11: 000.And as genuinely driverless cars get cheaper and become   ubiquitous
column12: you and I may opt out of monthly car payments and   opt-in to a monthly mileage subscription service instead.Automakers are investing in this futureTo understand how it's possible that we could soon live in a   world where most people don't own cars
column13: we need to look no   further than what the automakers themselves are doing.Elon Musk's recently updated version ofTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA)  master plan includes details on a new   service: When the company's vehicles become fully autonomous (by   2018 or 2019
column14: according to Musk)
column15: Tesla owners will be able to   allow their vehicles to drive themselves around and be rented out   by other people.As Musk wrote:You will also be able to add your car to the Tesla shared     fleet just by tapping a button on the Tesla phone app and have     it generate income for you while you're at work or on vacation
column16: significantly offsetting and at times potentially exceeding the     monthly loan or lease cost.Image source: Tesla.Musk also said that Tesla would deploy its own fleet of   driverless vehicles for rent in areas where there was more demand   for Tesla vehicles than privately owned cars could meet
column17: so that    ""you can always hail a ride from us no matter where you   are."" Remember
column18: this isn't the catchphrase of a taxi company
column19: nor   even a ride-hailing service -- but rather the direction where   Musk sees his automaker headed.And just in case think this mentality is unique to the   innovative Tesla
column20: consider whatGeneral Motors(NYSE: GM)  is doing. The giant automaker launched a   ride-sharing service last year called Maven
column21: which allows some GM   owners to rent out their vehicles when they're not in use. The   cars don't drive themselves yet
column22: but the company sees it as a   first step toward a future where people are less inclined to own   cars.In a press release at the time
column23: GM said that more than 25   million of its customers around the world will use some form of   shared mobility by 2020
column24: and describe Maven as ""a key element of   our strategy to changing ownership models in the automotive   industry."" Maven has spread to 17 cities across North America in   just 11 months
column25: has 22
column26: 000 members
column27: and has been used for 57   million miles of driving.Not to be outdone
column28: Ford(NYSE: F) has launched i ts own ride-sharing service
column29: and is   developing autonomous cars just like GM. Ford has made it clear   that it intends to launch a ""high-volume"" driverless car paired   with ride-hailing and ride-sharing services by 2021. The   company is already testing 30 self-driving Fusion Hybrids in   several states
column30: and plans to triple the number of test vehicles   this year.Other automakers are moving in this direction as well.Fiat Chrysler(NYSE: FCAU) is working withAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google to test a fleet of 100   self-driving minivans that will be the basis for aride-hailing serviceset to launch later this year. It's still unclear what the   service will look like
column31: or if Fiat Chrysler will play a critical   role in it
column32: but what is clear is that the automaker believes in   the viability of Waymo's cars-as-a-service goal.Will this really end car ownership?It's hard to answer this question conclusively
column33: of course.   After all
column34: most people haven't even seen a fully autonomous   vehicle on the road
column35: let alone ridden in one.But John Zimmer
column36: the co-founder and president of   ride-hailing company Lyft
column37: believes thatby 2025 ""private car ownership will all-but end in major U.S.   cities."" Lyft expects the majority of its vehicles to be   self-driving by 2021
column38: and rival Uber is testing similar   strategies as well.Others have set similar timelines for the demise of car   ownership. Georg Bauer
column39: who has held executive positions at   Daimler
column40: BMW
column41: and TeslatoldBusiness Insiderlast year that he thinks car ownership could be dead within   five to 10 years.Government regulations and our own apprehension about giving   up control over our vehicles may preserve the widespread car   ownership culture for longer than some expect. But what's crystal   clear is that tech companies and automakers alike are betting on   an automotive future that looks very different than today. Like   many things
column42: the transition from owning cars to renting   driverless ones on an as-needed basis will likely occur in stages   -- but let's be clear
column43: things are certainly moving in this   direction. And I
column44: for one
column45: would welcome a world without car   payments.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column46: it can pay to listen. After all
column47: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column48: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column49: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column52: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Chris Neigerhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Alphabet (A shares)

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Is Making a Giant Push in Its Supercharger Network;2/23/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) has already run into issues with congestion at Supercharger locations. There are also areas of the country where charge stations are few and far between. With the affordable Model 3 on track to go into mass production in September
column3: what is now an annoyance to customers could quickly become a real problem.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockTesla is getting ahead of the issue by accelerating the growth of its Supercharger network
column4: with plans to double the number of North American Supercharger locations in 2017.Tesla's Supercharger Network Is Critical to EVs' SuccessTransitioning from gasoline-fueled automobiles to electric cars isn't just a matter of convincing consumers to spend a little more on the initial purchase price. The technology
column5: green cred and especially the potential long-term fuel savings go a long way toward overcoming any initial sticker shock.The big problem is range anxiety.7 Marvelous Mid-Cap Stocks to Buy for the Best of All WorldsRegular drivers don't worry about running out of gas because there is a vast network of gas stations across the country. With an estimated150
column6: 000 gas stations in the U.S.(in 2015)
column7: you are seldom more than a few minutes away from being able to refuel. Once there
column8: it's typically five or 10 minutes to gas up
column9: pay and be back on the road.Electric cars like those made by TSLA have the advantage of being able to be charged at home
column10: but that takes a long time. According to Tesla's figures
column11: half an hour on a home charger gets about 27 miles of driving range. And that doesn't help when you're traveling.The company has been building up a Supercharger network that takes on the role of gas stations. A Supercharger is capable of adding 270 miles of driving range in 30 minutes
column12: and can fully charge a Tesla Model S with 90 kWh battery in roughly 75 minutes.Each Supercharger location isestimated to cost TSLA between $100k and $175kto build
column13: taking 12-20 weeks to complete.TSLA Will Double Its North American Locations in 2017Tesla's Supercharger network has two challenges.First
column14: it is much
column15: much thinner than the nation's network of gas stations. In all of the U.S. Canada and Mexico
column16: Tesla currently has just 373 Supercharger locations
column17: with 2
column18: 636 connections. Many of those Supercharger locations are concentrated on the east and west coasts.Then there is the charging time. While filling your car with enough gas to go 500 miles might take five or 10 minutes
column19: fully charging a base Model S takes 75 minutes.With Tesla ownership limited to early adopters with relatively deep pockets
column20: the sparse Supercharger network has mostly been an annoyance - something Tesla owners learn to work around. With the Model 3 slated to go into production in September and kick off a wave of mass market Tesla ownership
column21: those annoyances risk becoming a serious problem.Early adopters may be willing to work around challenges
column22: but average consumers quickly turn against a product that requires them to jump through hoops.In its full-year 2016 update letter to investors
column23: TSLA announced that is tackling the issue:""We plan to accelerate expansion of the Supercharger network this year
column24: starting with doubling our number of North American Supercharger locations in 2017.""Expansion and New Charging PoliciesDoubling the number of North American Supercharger locations helps to address range anxiety by filling in some of those areas on the map that are currently blank. Since each location has multiple Superchargers
column25: it also significantly expands the number of Tesla cars that can be charging at any given time.Tesla can't do much about the time needed to charge one of its cars - at least with current technology - but it has implemented several policies in the past few months to help deal with congestion at its Supercharger network.Weibo Corp (ADR) (WB) Stock Goes Cold Despite Hot Q4 EarningsIn December
column26: TSLA announced an idle fee(billed by the minute) would be charged to Tesla owners who parked their vehicles at Superchargers and left them connected. Then in January it announced theend of unlimited free Supercharger accessfor new Tesla buyers going forward.Withclose to 400
column27: 000 of the $35k Model 3s pre-ordered- and a goal of producing 500k electric vehicles a year by 2018 - the pressure is on TSLA to ensure its Supercharger network can meet the coming flood of demand. The policy changes will help
column28: but ultimately Tesla needs to expand its network of chargers to provide the coverage and availability drivers expect.Doubling the number of North American Supercharger locations this year will be costly
column29: but is a necessary move for Tesla to go mass market.As of this writing
column30: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 8 Camera Will Be RevolutionaryWWDC 2017: Here's What Apple Inc. column9: respectively.Notably
column10: Tesla's reported revenue benefited from the inclusion   of six weeks of SolarCity's operations

column21: Model S and Model X seem to remain in high demand ahead   of Model 3. Tesla said fourth-quarter Model S and X orders   reached a record high
column22: increasing 49% year over year.Tesla said its integration of SolarCity's operations is going   well
column23: stating that the company is ""on track to generate $500M in   cash (including growth of non-recourse project financing) by 2019   and achieve the cost synergies we committed to upon acquiring   SolarCity."" To meet that goal
column24: Tesla is taking the ax to   SolarCity's high advertising expenses and will be selling solar   products at Tesla stores. In addition
column25: Tesla will continue   shifting SolarCity's system sales away from leasing.Tesla provided more details on how it is already on track with   this target:As evidence that we are on plan

column1: Mobileye NV Q4 Earnings Are Good Enough for Now
column2: But ;2/22/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI've long thoughtMobileye NV(NYSE:MBLY) is too expensive. Mobileye has an interesting opportunity in driver assistance
column4: and eventually
column5: autonomous driving. But it also has intense competition from companies ranging fromNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) toAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) to Tier 1 suppliers likeDelphi Automotive PLC(NYSE:DLPH) andAutoliv Inc.(NYSE:ALV). But I haven't shorted MBLY stock - yet - and I hardly thought Mobileye's fourth-quarter earnings on Wednesday presented an opportunity.makeArticleAd();Source:U.S. Embassy Tel Aviv via FlickrAfter all
column6: MBLY is a story stock
column7: and the story looked strong heading into Mobileye earnings. A series of deals and partnerships announced in the past few weeks led MBLY stock up 35% from late December lows. Optimism around autonomous driving and increasing automotive technology continues to rise; there's a reasonTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) stock is near all-time highs. Betting against that in the short-term seemed foolish.That story appears to hold for a little while longer
column8: as Mobileye earnings out Wednesday morning came in ahead of consensus estimates and the company's own guidance. In response
column9: MBLY stock reversed from modest gains to modest losses back to 2%-plus gains again in premarket trading. That seems to imply that investors already are looking forward.But it's there the Mobileye story might have some holes.Mobileye Earnings Look SolidMobileye earnings for Q4 beat both Street consensus and its own guidance on the top and bottom line. Revenue of $104.6 million
column10: in particular
column11: looks impressive. MBLY had guided for roughly $96 million coming out of Q3 in moving expectations to the high end of a full-year $344 million-$350 million range. Heading into the earnings report
column12: analysts largely backed those projections.7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowThe beat
column13: then
column14: implies growth roughly 11 points higher than thought
column15: with revenue growing almost 46% year-over-year.The driver (no pun intended) appears to be aftermarket sales. Those sales - largely dash-mounted systems on existing cars
column16: rather than installed systems in new cars - increased 156% year-over-year. MBLY management had raised full-year projections for that division after Q2 to 20% of total sales. In fact
column17: Q4 Mobileye earnings show the aftermarket drove 23% of full-year revenue
column18: with sales increasing 113% for full-year 2016.Earnings per share beat consensus and implied guidance by 2 cents
column19: which implies that profit margins were roughly as expected. The reason likely is that aftermarket sales offer lower gross margins
column20: and thus aren't quite as profitable. MBLY has improved gross margins in the business
column21: but mix seems like the most significant reason why the company didn't better leverage sales growth.Long-Term Questions Remain for MBLY StockThe fact that the revenue beat came from aftermarket growth isn't quite the outcome that Mobileye stock bulls would have preferred for Q4.The exciting business here is in OEM
column22: from both the standpoint of market opportunity and profit margins. While 113% growth for aftermarket sales is nothing to sneeze at
column23: it's still off a rather small base. And $82 million in aftermarket sales for 2016
column24: on its own
column25: isn't near enough to support a stock with an enterprise value over $10 billion.That seems to mean investors are looking forward. 2017 guidance on the conference call is for EPS of $1.01-$1.05 and revenue of $490 million-$505 million. Earnings appear just shy of analyst estimates of $1.04
column26: while revenue of $490 million-$505 million suggests an outperformance to Street expectations of $491 million.That combination
column27: however
column28: means margins will be a bit lower than forecast by analysts. That
column29: in turn
column30: likely comes from a higher-than-expected proportion of aftermarket revenue - again
column31: not what the bulls necessarily wanted to hear.And that may be enough for some of the long-term concerns to enter the narrative in MBLY stock in post-earnings trading.Looking ForwardMorgan Stanley downgraded Mobileye stock at the beginning of the month based on margin concerns - a move that took MBLY stock down 3%. And the ability of Mobileye to maintain margins is a big concern of mine
column32: longer-term.I'm still skeptical that any semiconductor company can hold pricing (and thus margins) longer-term. One of the few exceptions
column33: of course

column35: now trading at ~45x 2017 EPS

column37: and part of Nvidia's huge gains over the past year have come from optimism over prospects for its Drive PX 2 platform.How to Trade Facebook Inc for 470% ReturnsThat platform is what Tesla turned to after its relationship ended with Mobileye (and somewhat acrimoniously). That decision alone illustrates the long-term challenges. Competition will be intense

column5: I am seeing and hearing more and more bears capitulate and join the buying spree. As a side note

column8: either buying breakouts
column9: or

column11: waiting until a first level of support is reached and confirmed by a bullish reversal.Either way

column1: Can Tesla
column2: Inc. Grow Model S Sales in 2017?;2/22/2017;"Tesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) growth in vehicle deliveries continued soaring   higher in 2016
column3: essentially extending the company's streak of   about 50% compound average annualized growth or higher to four   years. But it took Tesla's late-2015 launched Model X SUV for the   company to maintain this impressive growth rate. Model S sales in   2016 were up only a meager 1% last year.With Model S growth quickly decelerating from 59% year over   year growth in 2015
column4: to just 1% growth in 2016
column5: could Model S   sales growth come to a halt -- or even worse -- begin declining   in 2017?Model S. Image source: author.makeArticleAd();Demand is still looking upDespite reporting just 1% growth in Model S sales in 2016
column6: Tesla seems optimistic about demand for the 2012-launched sedan.   In the company's most recent shareholder letter
column7: Tesla pointed to   rapidly growing demand for the vehicle in the U.S. as evidence of   the vehicle's popularity with consumers.More than four years since its introduction
column8: Model S     continues to expand market share
column9: which is a testament to our     continuous vehicle innovation. In the U.S.
column10: which is Tesla's     most mature market
column11: Model S deliveries grew nearly 60% year     over year
column12: increasing its lead status with a 32% share of the     top 12 selling large luxury sedans
column13: as Model S unit growth     significantly outpaced U.S. large luxury sedan category sales     growth.And in the company's brief press release on its fourth-quarter   deliveries
column14: Tesla said fourth-quarter net orders for Model S and   X were at an all-time high.Further
column15: Tesla has some good reasons to be optimistic about   Model S going forward. While Model S was launched in 2012
column16: Tesla   has aggressively been rolling out major updates for the vehicle.   Indeed
column17: some of the most significant updates to Model S have   found their way to the sedan very recently.In August
column18: Tesla launched a flagship P100D Model S with a zero-to-sixty     time of 2.5 seconds when Ludicrous mode is enabled. And the     time dropped to 2.4 seconds earlier this year after a software     update.In October
column19: Tesla began including sensors for autonomous driving in every     vehicle (the autonomous driving itself is slated to come later     on via a software update). Along with this new hardware
column20: Tesla     began offering an enhanced version of its Autopilot.In January
column21: Tesla launched its highest-range Model S yet
column22: capable of     driving 335 miles on a single charge.Of course
column23: Tesla'srelentless updatesto Model S don't guarantee the model's sales will continue to   increase
column24: especially with the vehicle already outselling   comparably priced luxury sedans. But recent new features to Model   S
column25: particularly standard self-driving hardware
column26: are likely to   mitigate the possibility of sales declines in 2017.Could Model 3 orders cannibalize Model S     sales?But all of this overlooks one key concern about demand outlook   for Model S in 2017. Investors may be concerned Tesla's cheaper   Model 3
column27: which is slated to launch later this year
column28: could begin   cannibalizing Model S sales. After all
column29: Model 3's starting price   is nearly half of Model S'.Model 3. Image source: Tesla Motors.Fortunately
column30: there's already a precedent for how Model 3   announcements impact demand for Tesla's higher-cost models. Musk   explained how the Model 3's unveiling
column31: which generated about   400
column32: 000 deposit-backed reservations for the vehicle in the months   following the product event
column33: impacted Model S demand:An important point worth mentioning
column34: we were fairly worried     about what would happen with the Model 3 announcement. Would it     cause like some a big drop in
column35: say
column36: Model S sales? It seems to     have had the opposite effect. It seems as though S demand has     increased.Therefore
column37: it's possible that as hype grows ahead of the Model   3's launch
column38: more overall interest for Tesla's entire vehicle   lineup could mount. Obviously
column39: investors shouldn't count on this.   But at least Tesla's previous big Model 3 announcement's impact   on Model S demand bodes well for how any upcoming announcements   could affect Model S orders.Investors may be able to find out more about what Tesla   expects from its Model S this year when the company releases its   fourth-quarter earnings today

column1: Warren Buffett Might Make These 3 Driverless Car Investing Mistakes;2/22/2017;"Warren Buffett is well-known for having
column2: among the core tenets   of his investment strategy
column3: a preference for companies with   serious ""competitive moats"" -- attributes that give them the   ability to sustainably keep ahead of their competition. But based   on his rues
column4: Buffett would never invest in an emerging industry   like self-driving cars
column5: and his competitive moat ideas don't   necessarily hold water in this world. If you're a fan of the   Oracle of Omaha
column6: beware of following his investment philosophy   into these three mistakes.1. Focusing too much on sizeImage source: Alphabet (Waymo)makeArticleAd();Economies of scale are an important indicator for almost any   company. As the logic goes
column7: the bigger a company is
column8: the greater   its ability to cut per-unit costs.Ford's(NYSE: F) ability to keep its car costs lower thanTesla Motors'(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column9: for example
column10: isn't just based on the fact that   it produces more economically designed vehicles. It's also due to   the fact that Ford produced 1.5 million cars in the third quarter   of 2016
column11: compared to the 24
column12: 800 cars Tesla Motors delivered   during the same period.But scalability in the driverless car industry doesn't   necessarily have anything to do with car sales. The automaker   with the best technology may ultimately come out ahead.   Technology is scalable at almost no cost. When Tesla Motors   wirelessly uploads its latest software to its already-sold   vehicles around the world
column13: the company pays nearly nothing in   per-unit costs. The race to build the best driverless car at this   stage has much more to do with technology than with numbers of   vehicles sold
column14: and the quantity of cars a company has sold thus   far isn't a indicator for which company is best placed to scale   in the future.2. Exaggerating the value of network effectsWhat network?Network effects are often touted as one of the strongest   competitive moats around.Facebook
column15: an actual social network
column16: perfectly defines the allure of the   network effect. If everyone is using a specific product or   platform
column17: it can be extremely difficult for another company to   make inroads.At first glance
column18: driverless cars seem to be an excellent   opportunity to build network effects. If one company's cars all   ""talk"" to each other as they navigate the roads
column19: they'll get to   their destinations faster and more safely than competitors' --   right? Wrong. Driverless car technology must necessarily take   into account public safety
column20: and unique
column21: exclusionary networks fly   in the face of a universal platform for safe self-driving cars.   Automakers engaged in this space already know this; it's why   Ford
column22: Tesla
column23: and others are equipping their driverless cars with   the best real-world object detection technology available.When Ford announced earlier last week that it would invest $1   billion over five years in Argo AI
column24: it wasn't because   the startup has thousands of self-driving cars on the road   -- it was because the company's robotics expertise ""gives Ford a   distinct competitive advantage at the intersection of the   automotive and technology industries
column25: explained Ford Chief   Technology Officer Raj Nair in a press release. Likewise
column26: Alphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) spinoff Waymo isn't relying on   Google's treasure troves of data to guide its vehicles as they   drive around. Instead
column27: Waymo cars are equipped with sensors and   software designed to detect obstacles up to ""two football fields   away in all directions."" Ford
column28: Alphabet
column29: Tesla Motors
column30: and others   aren't interested in network effects in this arena. They're   interested in their cars having the most acute local-area   awareness they can contain.3. Expecting government regulation to limit competitionRegular regulationRegulation can provide some of the widest competitive moats   around. If only one company is able to meet all the regulatory   requirements of being in a business
column31: it's essentially illegal for   others to try to compete with it. The driverless car industry   recognizes this
column32: and is making moves to ensure a level playing   field for all involved.Alphabet
column33: Ford
column34: Lyft
column35: Uber
column36: and Volvo Cars joined together   last April to create the ""Self-Driving Coalition for Safer Streets
column37: "" a lobbying group whose stated mission is to ""work with   lawmakers
column38: regulators
column39: and the public to realize the safety and   societal benefits of self-driving vehicles."" These companies are   interested in standardizing national policy with simple and   low-cost barriers to entry for all interested automakers. So for   Buffett fans looking to back the company with the strongest   regulation-related advantages
column40: know that some of the biggest   names in the business are working proactively to push   policies that ensure no company can ever build a regulatory   moat.Picking the right self-driving car stockWarren Buffett is an incredible investor
column41: but he doesn't have   answers for every industry. There are many open questions around   self-driving cars
column42: and some companies are morepoised to profitthan others. Rather than sticking to one-size-fits-all investment   mantras
column43: equip yourself with the factsyou need to know
column44: make informed investments
column45: and set your   portfolio to auto-pilot for years to come.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column47: the newsletter     they have run for over a decade

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as ofDecember 12

If an investor was to sell-to-open that put contract

column5: but will also collect the premium

column1: Tesla Earnings: 3 Questions for CEO Elon Musk Today;2/22/2017;"After the market closes today
column2: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) will update investors on its fourth-quarter   results and will probably provide forecasts for first-quarter and   full-year expectations. Further
column3: the quarterly shareholder letter   may include an update on the company's important lower-cost Model   3
column4: which is slated to launch in the second half of 2017.But some of the most notable takeaways from Tesla's update   tomorrow may not come from the quarterly shareholder letter
column5: but   rather its earnings call following the letter's release. Known   for extra-long question-and-answer sessions
column6: CEO Elon Musk often   fields questions from analysts for about an hour during the live   call. In previous calls
column7: commentary has ranged from insights into   meaty details on the company's gross margin to updates on how   Tesla is anti-selling the Model 3 so demand doesn't get too far   ahead of the company's ability to ramp up supply.Tesla CEO Elon Musk. Image source: author.makeArticleAd();So
column8: what are some topics likely to surface during Tesla's   earnings call on Wednesday afternoon? Here are three questions
column9: along with some relevant background
column10: that analysts are likely to   ask Musk.1. Will Tesla need to raise capital in 2017?In Tesla's third-quarter earnings call (via a Reuterstranscript)
column11: Musk said the company's ambitious Model 3 program currently   didn't require any capital raises. But Musk was also careful to   emphasize that this didn't mean the company wouldn't want to   raise capital:Now that's different from saying whether we should raise     capital or not to account for uncertainty to have a larger     buffer and to derisk the business. ... It seems like we     probably won't want to do a capital raise even in Q1. I'm not     saying we won't
column12: but probably not. And it's overall looking     quite promising.Tesla's first quarter is more than halfway over
column13: and the   company hasn't announced any capital raises yet. ButTesla stockis also trading significantly higher than it was during the   company's last earnings call. Tesla stock is up 50% in three   months
column14: making an equity capital raise far more attractive than   it was toward the end of 2016.2. When will Tesla share more details on the Model     3?Tesla's Model 3 will obviously be the center of attention in   Tesla's fourth-quarter update. Investors will want to know if the   vehicle is on schedule and how many units management expects to   deliver in 2017.Model 3. Image source: Tesla Motors.But investors may be particularly antsy to get another update   on how the vehicle's development is faring
column15: given that Tesla'sfirst unveiling of its Model 3was a prototype more than a year before planned production. So   investors may want to know when the company is planning to share   more details on the vehicle. column16: a GARP stock has a PEG ratio of 1.0

column47: General Motors won accolades for   rolling out electric cars.While General Motors doesn't make the batterycellsthat go into powering these cars (South Korea's LG Chem does that   for the company)

column49: GM's involvement in battery technology may be   deeper than you know.InThe Powerhouse: Inside the Invention of a Battery to Save the   World
column50: formerWall Street Journalcorrespondent Steve Levine describes the history of America's   Argonne National Laboratory and its efforts to build a better   rechargeable battery -- specifically
column51: one capable of powering a   car for 200 miles of driving on a single charge. Central to the   book's story is General Motors' work with battery behemoths such   as LG Chem
column52: and also with ground-breaking start-ups such as   privately held Envia -- including through making equity   investments in the latter.Simply put
column53: GM is working -- both through its in-house battery   lab and through partnerships elsewhere in the battery industry --   to develop an entirely new ""superbattery"" that it calls NMC 2.0.   Unlike the banks of generic
column54: cheap
column55: but older-tech   nickel-cobalt-aluminum 18650s that power Tesla's sedans
column56: GM has   been developing a nickel-manganese-cobalt cell that it believes   will offer greater energy density
column57: giving Chevy's Bolts (and   future electric cars) a range advantage over Tesla.At last report
column58: General Motors still hadn't solved the mystery   of inventing NMC 2.0. But investing in GM stock for just 6.2   times earnings
column59: you wouldn't be paying much for the potential   that it eventually will.10 stocks we like better than General MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Go Long the Super Spike In Tesla Inc (TSLA) Earnings;2/21/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI recently wrote up severalTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) trades where profits came too fast. This is a good problem to have. So why am I booking profits instead of riding Tesla stock higher? Simple: I don't trust the fundamentals.makeArticleAd();Source:Windell Oskay via Flickr (Modified)Before you send in the hate mail
column3: I am not dissing Tesla or its prospects. I am merely acknowledging the hurdles it has to grow into its valuation. Having said that
column4: I reiterate that I am a fan of the price action in Tesla stock.Usually I like to sell risk against extreme opinions. So logic here would be to want to sell calls or call spreads against this mega spike. Not this time. Earnings are coming and these are binary events. For the short term
column5: trading earnings is more gambling than investing. I don't know how traders will react to earnings regardless of the quality of the numbers themselves.So today
column6: I want to invest some of my profits in going long TSLA stock for a breakout to new highs. I want to ride the so-called ""animal spirit"" that is the meme of 2017.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy and Hold ForeverClick to EnlargeTechnically
column7: TSLA stock already hit my target from the $258 per share breakout as noted on the chart. From here
column8: we would need a game changing event and earnings could serve that purpose. Wall Street has a crush on Elon Musk and his conference call could be a treasure trove of catalysts.The Bet:Buy the TSLA March $330 call. This is a bullish trade for which I pay $1.60 per contract to open. This is my maximum potential risk. If TSLA spikes to new highs this level should be within target.I could modify this trade for a more moderate bet by turning it into a spread. So I'd buy TSLA March 31 $315/$320 debit call spread for 60 cents per contract. If TSLA rallies past my spread I stand to gain more than $4 per contract. The spread makes the trade more reasonable as it is closer to current price. So I don't require as big a move as buying calls at $330.Often I like to lower my out of pocket expense and in this case I could sell some puts against TSLA stock levels I deem safe.The Bank (optional):Sell the TSLA Jan 2018 $200 put. For this I collect $14 per share. I need TSLA stock to stay above my strike sold or risk being put the stock. I only sell naked puts if I am willing and able to own Tesla stock at $200 per share. Anything below $186 per share would constitute losses on this leg alone.I am not required to hold my Tesla options trade open through their expiration. I can close any of these trades at any time for partial gains or losses.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column9: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.More From InvestorPlaceYes

column1: How a Major Utility Fell on Its Face in Renewable Energy;2/21/2017;"It was supposed to be an easy transition forNRG Energy(NYSE: NRG) from utility giant to renewable energy powerhouse.   The company had billions in cash flow coming in from fossil fuel   plants that could then be turned around and invested in wind
column2: solar
column3: electric charging stations
column4: and energy storage. Simple   enough
column5: right?The problem for NRG Energy and former CEO David Crane is that   utility investors and renewable energy investors are like oil and   water. They simply don't mix and neither one quite understands   the other. So
column6: less than two years after launching a brand-new   Home Solar business and putting a huge focus on clean energy
column7: the   company is shutting down parts of its solar business and looking   into strategic alternatives afterElliott ManagementandBluescape Energy Partnerswere given seats on the board of directors. Don't be fooled: NRG   Energy is heading for a breakup because dirty and clean energy   just can't live together.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();The death of NRG HomeAt one time
column8: NRG Home was supposed to give SolarCity a ""run   for their money."" Seriously
column9: NRG thought it could build a solar   installation arm that rivaled the biggest players in the country.   It acquired Roof Diagnostics to gain a decent market share and   added solar products company Goal Zero as another way to attract   customers.The theory was good on the surface. A big utility name puts   its financial muscle behind residential solar
column10: which will give   the product validation and the company's operations stability.   Only that's not what the industry needed.Instead of customers flocking to a utility trying to distrupt   itself
column11: they stuck with companies trying to disrupt the world.   SolarCity
column12: Vivint Solar
column13: Sunrun
column14: andSunPowerremained more attractive options for customers than NRG Home. And   in the past 18 months
column15: the market has been shifting away from   large national installers to local and regional installers that   have lower costs and can be more nimble in the market.We've seen something similar with NRG's EV charging network.   It's a good solution from the wrong player in the market. So
column16: instead of NRG's flexible charging network being a marvel of the   EV community
column17: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) is the charging network that's become the standard   everyone else has to live up to.The clash of the old world and the newIt isn't that NRG's management got their vision of the future   wrong. It's that NRG wasn't necessarily the company to execute on   that vision. Its customers were confused by the transition to   solar
column18: and in many states NRG Home was trying to enter
column19: they had   no prior knowledge of NRG. And investors in a utility like NRG   were looking for cash flow
column20: not billions of dollars of investment   in a business that may take years to show real signs of   progress.With the activist investors involved
column21: NRG Energy is likely to   split into a green business and a fossil fuel business. The green   business has already been separated and is either shutting down   or being sold. NRG Home is being wound down and a majority stake   in EVgo has been sold. It's possible theNRG Yield(NYSE: NYLD) stake will be sold as well in an effort to monetize   assets and return the cash to shareholders.Whether there's a spinoff or just a sale of assets
column22: it looks   like the old energy world is beating the new at NRG Energy.A transition gone wrongIt's harder than it seems for fossil fuel companies orutilities to make a transitionto new
column23: cleaner forms of energy. The investment structure and   incentives for the two are just too different to coexist. Fossil   fuels and utilities are all about cash flows and finding ways to   make money off the status quo.Renewable energy
column24: particularly energy production on rooftops
column25: is about breaking the energy status quo and replacing it with   more individual independence. And breaking the traditional energy   business doesn't always come with predictable cash flows or   installations each quarter.The two strategies are simply at odds with each other
column26: and NRG   Energy abandoning most of its renewable business is a casualty of   the realities of the energy industry today. Old and new forms of   energy just don't mix under one roof and NRG Energy found that   out the hard way.10 stocks we like better than NRG EnergyWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column28: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column5: Zacks Investment Ideas feature highlights Features:Tesla(NASDAQ:TSLA-Free Report)
column6: Volatility Index(NYSEARCA:VXX-Free Report)andGilead(NASDAQ:GILD-Free Report).5 Major Myths About Options TradingWhen it comes to investing
column7: pretty much everyone has an opinion. While those opinions are great
column8: sometimes investors will spread myths about subjects they don't have a firm understanding of. One of the most confusing subjects isoptions trading. Due to the many moving parts involved
column9: investors find themselves befuddled and not knowing where to start. Here I'm going to debunk five major myths of options trading.Myth #1: Options are Riskier than StocksThis is one of those broad-based
column10: blanket statements that does not tell the whole truth. People think options are riskier because you can lose 100% of your investment in an option. However
column11: you can use options to limit your risk on trades.Here's an example
column12: let's say you wanted to buy 100 shares ofTesla(NASDAQ:TSLA-Free Report)ahead of their earnings report next week because you think they are going to have a good report and the stock will go up. Today it would cost you around $270 per share or $27
column13: 000 to own 100 shares. If TSLA goes down 10% on its earnings report
column14: you are going to lose $2
column15: 700 dollars. If it goes up 10%
column16: you'll make $2
column17: 700.On the flipside
column18: you could buy the March 17th$270 Call option for $1
column19: 350. If TSLA goes down 10% and stays there through expiration
column20: you'll lose your $1
column21: 350. If it goes up 10%
column22: you're call option will be worth at least $2
column24: maybe more. If you wanted to define your risk as $2
column26: you could buy two of these contracts
column27: controlling 200 shares of Tesla rather than only 100. Same amount of nominal risk
column28: but now your upside potential is doubled.Myth #2: You Need to be a Sophisticated Trader for   OptionsThere certainly are options strategies that involve a great deal of complexity. With so many choices available to trade it can be very complicated. Each options expiration date has call options and put options of varying strikes available. At first glance the selection process can be daunting. Many stocks now have weekly options expiration
column29: making these even more overwhelming for investors.You don't need a PhD in Applied Mathematics to use simple options strategies to make money and create income. For example
column30: buying a call in the hopes that a stock goes up. If you know there is an event coming up that you think the stock will profit from
column31: you can buy a call near the money on the stock and if it goes up you can profit. If you want to make a trade that benefits when the stock goes down
column32: you can buy a put option in the hopes the stock goes down. Start with the basics and add more complex strategies as you become more comfortable.Myth #3: It Takes a Lot of Money to Trade   OptionsThis couldn't be further from the truth. It's a lot less capital intensive to trade options than it is to buy 100 shares of your favorite stock. Most brokerage firms allow you to sell options premium
column33: a more advanced strategy
column34: in accounts that contain as little as $2
column35: 000. Compare that to Pattern Day Trader accounts which require at least $25
column36: 000.Trading options allows smaller accounts to gain exposure to more stocks for less money. You can diversify your options trades across many industries and many stocks simultaneously. There are even options on ETFs like theVolatility Index(NYSEARCA:VXX-Free Report)so you can gain exposure to exotic financial instruments while managing your risk.Myth #4: Time is Always Working Against YouIf you are long or buy options then yes
column37: there is a time value element that's working against you. However
column38: there are simple ways to flip the script so this time works in your favor. One way is by using long call and long put spreads rather than buying a call or put outright. The other is to use credit spreads.A long call spread
column39: or a bull call spread
column40: is a two-legged options trade where a closer to the money option is purchased to open and a further out of the money call option is sold to open or shorted. This helps to drop the overall net debit or price of the call spread. It also limits the total profit potential of the trade.For example
column41: if I bought a March 17th$67.50 Call onGilead(NASDAQ:GILD-Free Report)today it would cost me about $2.95. My upside potential would be unlimited but my breakeven would be the strike price plus the net debit which in this case is $2.95
column42: making my breakeven $70.45.However
column43: if I believe Gilead's upside is limited to $72.50
column44: I could sell that $72.50 Call at the same expiration and take back some money
column45: dropping my overall cost on the spread
column46: therefore bringing down my breakeven. I could sell the $72.50 Call for 55c. Now my cost on the $67.50/72.50 Call spread is only $2.40
column47: my breakeven now $69.90
column48: and I'll make more money up to $72.50 than I would have with the long call by itself.Another example is the credit spread. Rather than buying the aforementioned spread
column49: if I'm bearish on GILD I can sell the spread. So instead of spending $2.40 for the spread I would pocket $2.40. My risk would be the $5 difference in the strike prices
column50: minus the $2.40 I took in premium. So I risk $2.60 to make $2.40. This credit spread would max out or give me the largest possible winning outcome of $2.40 if shares of GILD closed at or below $62.50 at expiration on March 17th.Myth #5: You Need a Special Account to Trade   OptionsWell
column51: sort of. While you do need to sign an options risk acknowledgement form and get your account approved specifically for options trading
column52: it's not exactly a ""special account."" Pretty much any non-qualified
column53: or non-retirement
column54: account is eligible for options trading. I specify non-qualified because accounts like IRAs are restricted as to the type of options trading you can do since you can't short stocks in retirement accounts.There are several levels of options approvals out there
column55: designed to save investors from themselves. Each level or tier is restricted
column56: only allowing certain types of trading. Each broker has their own guidelines for what these levels look like. All you really need for approval is experience trading and capital. It's not like you have to be a millionaire or anything.Bottom LineThose are the five biggest myths about options trading that scare off potential traders. If you take the time to learn more about trading options
column57: you'll find that they are a great way to manage your risk and gain exposure to the stock market.FollowBrian Bolanon Twitter@BBolan1Want more articles from this author? column1: Are General Motors and Lyft About to Crush All Self-Driving Rivals?;2/19/2017;"General Motors(NYSE: GM) is planning to build and deploy thousands of   self-driving electric cars in test fleets with Lyft next year
column2: according to a newReutersreport.If that's for real
column3: it will be by far the largest fleet of   autonomous test vehicles in operation. It's a very big deal that   has huge implications for GM
column4: Lyft
column5: and their   rivals.What the report saidAccording to the Reuters article
column6: GM will build thousands of   Chevy Bolts equipped with prototype versions of the self-driving   system GM has developed with its subsidiary
column7: Cruise Automation.   Most of these self-driving Bolts will go into ride-hailing   service with Lyft in several states starting sometime in   2018.makeArticleAd();GM has no plans right now to sell the self-driving Bolts to   the general public.CEO Mary Barra announced in December that GM would begin     producing self-driving Chevrolet Bolt test vehicles in early     2017. Image source: General Motors.What it would mean for GMGM has been working on self-driving technology for years. That   work seemed to take a big leap forward with the acquisition of   San Francisco-based start-up Cruise Automation early last year.   It appears that Cruise has since become the center of GM's   research efforts. Cruise's self-driving Chevy Bolt test cars have   become regular sights on San Francisco streets
column8: and recent videos   taken from inside self-driving Bolt test cars suggest thatthe GM/Cruise technology is at a fairly advanced   level. GM announced in December that it would soon begin   producing self-driving Bolt test vehicles
column9: but the hint was that   -- at least in the near term -- they'd be produced in   small quantities for GM's own testing.A mass deployment would demonstrate two things: First
column10: that   GM's technology really is at a high level
column11: and second
column12: that GM   and its supplier partners are ready and able to mass-produce   self-driving cars.Both of those things are significant. Taken together
column13: it would   be a strong argument that GM is leading the way to mass-produced   Level 4 self-driving vehicles. Companies likeAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) andTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) have attracted a lot of investor attention for   (among other things) their self-driving efforts
column14: but --   as of right now
column15: at least -- GM seems poised to leapfrog just   about everybody.What it would mean for LyftLyft
column16: like its larger rival Uber Technologies
column17: knows that   replacing its human drivers with self-driving vehicles is crucial   to its future. Autonomous ride-hailing vehicles will allow Lyft   to lower its prices while generating (hopefully) strong   profits.Uber has been working on its own self-driving technology for a   couple of years
column18: and has a fewprototype self-driving test cars in servicenow. Lyft isn't known to have done any work on a self-driving   system of its own
column19: but it doesn't need to: GMowns a 9% stakein Lyft
column20: and GM seems to have it handled.If Lyft beats Uber to a self-driving fleet at scale
column21: Uber will   have a big challenge on its hands.GM president Dan Ammann (center) with Lyft co-founders Logan     Green (left) and John Zimmer. GM owns 9% of the ride-hailing     company
column22: and Ammann is a member of its board of directors.     Image source: General Motors.Could this be for real?The Reuters report
column23: by veteran auto-business journalist Paul   Lienert
column24: cites two unnamed ""sources familiar with the automaker's   plans."" Generally
column25: investors (and everyone else) should take   reports based on information from unnamed sources with a grain or   two of salt. But a few things suggest to me that this is probably   for real.First
column26: Lienert is a veteran with good sources
column27: and Reuters   holds its reporting to high standards. Second
column28: the report fits   with the known facts: GM and Lyft have both said that atest of autonomous GM vehicles in Lyft service is   forthcoming. Third
column29: GM's Orion
column30: Michigan
column31: factory
column32: where the Bolt is built
column33: has plenty of capacity to do a special production run in the   thousands.Finally
column34: and most tellingly
column35: neither Lyft nor GM denied the   report. In fact
column36: GM's statement in response was almost a smiling   hint:We do not provide specific details on potential future     products or technology rollout plans. We have said that our AV     technology will appear in an on-demand ride sharing network     applicationsooner than you might think. [Emphasis added.]Translation: This is likely to happen
column37: and it might begin   sooner than 2018.How important is this for GM investors?If it happens
column38: it will be a big deal. While the idea of a   ""race"" to self-driving technologyisn't really useful to investors
column39: a big test like this next year (or sooner) will show that GM   isn't about to be disrupted by Silicon Valley when it comes to   self-driving. It will also give lots of people an   opportunity to experience self-driving technology firsthand
column40: which will almost certainly speed its adoption by increasing   consumer demand.If nothing else
column41: it seems very likely to attract investors'   attention and give GM shares a boost.10 stocks we like better than General MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Solar Energy Production Hit a Record High in 2016
column2: So What's Wrong With Solar Stocks?;2/18/2017;"2016 was an amazing year for the solar industry overall
column3: even   if it wasn't great for solar stocks. GTM Research recently   reported that its upcoming U.S. Solar Market Insight Report done   with the Solar Energy Industries Association will reveal a 95%   jump in installations last year to 14.6 GW.To put that number into perspective
column4: that's enough solar to   power 2.4 million homes in the U.S. On top of the huge   installation numbers
column5: solar accounted for 39% of all new   electricity installed in 2016
column6: a record for the industry. And   with costs coming down every year
column7: the future looks bright for   the industry.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();The solar industry's great yearThe chart below shows the solar industry's incredible growth   over the past six years. Every segment of the market has grown
column8: led by the utility-scale solar market.Data source: GTM Research / SEIAU.S. Solar Market Insight Report.This surge versus 2015 was driven by falling costs for solar   installations and contracts signed to be completed in 2016 before   the solar investment tax credit (ITC) was extended. It really   was the ITC that led to a massive boom in solar last year
column9: but it's also the reason solar stocks had a terrible 2016.What went wrong with solar stocksAcross the board
column10: solar stocks had a rough year in 2016
column11: despite the installation boom.SunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR)
column12: First Solar(NASDAQ: FSLR)
column13: Vivint Solar(NYSE: VSLR)
column14: andSunrun(NASDAQ: RUN) are all down significantly since the start of 2016.   And SolarCity would be in the same boat if it weren't for its   buyout byTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) .SPWRdata byYCharts.The reason stocks are down is because the ITC extension meant   there were very few new contracts signed in 2016. The activity   that led to last year's boom in installations was a result of   contracts signed in 2014 and 2015
column15: before the ITC extension was   signed. So
column16: what investors were concerned about was the lack of   new contracts in the market.Even the residential market went through something of a   slowdown. Final numbers aren't out yet
column17: but growth is likely in   the single or low double digits
column18: driven by the lack of urgency to   install solar. Residential projects have a much shorter lead time   than utility projects
column19: so the ITC extension hit the market as   early as the first quarter of 2016
column20: whereas the impact of the ITC   won't be a drag on utility installations until 2017.What solar investors can expect in the futureWe've known for a few quarters now that 2017 will be bad for   the solar industry. Utility-scale projects will be hard to come   by domestically and even projects signed this year won't likely   begin construction until 2018 or beyond. And the 14.6 GW of solar   installed in 2016 will likely be the industry's peak until at   least 2018.But the good news is that solar energy is cheaper than   ever and it's now competing with fossil fuels on a cost   basis. Long term
column21: that will lead to a tremendous amount of   growth
column22: and companies like First Solar
column23: SunPower
column24: Vivint
column25: Sunrun

column1: Why Wind and Solar May Have to Fill In for America's Crumbling Hydro Infrastructure;2/18/2017;"When politicians talk about ""crumbling infrastructure
column2: it's   often hard to ascertain exactly what they're talking about. Is itbridges falling down
column3: an excessive number of potholes
column4: or maybe aging airports? It   could mean any number of things depending on who's talking and   who's listening.This week
column5: an aging piece of infrastructure is acutely   impacting nearly 200
column6: 000 people in California as the Oroville   Dam's damaged spillways teeters close to collapse
column7: potentially   flooding a large swath of northern California. The dam itself   doesn't (yet) appear to be damaged
column8: but it's not functioning as   planned. And the problems aren't new given the fact that   environmental groups were pushing for additional spillway   construction 12 years ago at the now 49-year-old dam.   Incidentally
column9: dams are only designed with a 50-year life span
column10: so   it's worth keeping in mind that infrastructure isn't built to   last forever.Any kind of infrastructure goes through normal wear and tear   over time
column11: but the challenge today is the sheer age of dam   infrastructure in the U.S. According to a 2015 Department of   Energy report
column12: 75% of hydro capacity is at plants that are over   50 years old (although some have been upgraded since first   construction). The Oroville Dam's potential spillway collapse   could bring that age into focus
column13: which could impact other sources   of renewable energy as well.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Crumbling dam infrastructureThe chart below is from the Department of Energy's 2014   Hydropower Market Report
column14: which was released in April 2015. It   shows that a vast majority of U.S. hydro plants were built   between 1940 and 1970
column15: particularly large plants.Image source: Department of Energy 2014 Hydropower Market     Report.If these plants begin to be reviewed more closely or are   decommissioned
column16: it could take dozens of gigawatts of energy   production offline over the next decade. And given their age
column17: it   may be a good idea to do just that.The crumbling hydro infrastructure may also be a new   opportunity for wind and solar energy in the U.S.. When you   consider that hydro power generated 249 million MWh of   electricity in 2015
column18: the opportunity is enormous.Energy and the RPS standard conundrumHydro power is the biggest source of renewable energy in the   U.S.
column19: only recently surpassed by all other renewable energy   sources (excluding nuclear) combined. So
column20: it's a big piece of the   energy industry.Image source: U.S. EIA.But it's also the biggest single part of state-level renewable   portfolio standards (RPS). In states like California
column21: this is the   policy that has driven the growth in wind and solar over the past   decade. If you pull any hydro plant out of the mix
column22: another   energy source has to fill that gap. And it will have to be clean   energy
column23: so wind and solar fits the bill.A growth opportunity for solar energyLet's take the Oroville Dam as an example of the challenge and   opportunity for utilities
column24: grid operators
column25: and renewable energy.   If the 819 MW dam were to be taken offline
column26: it would take about   3.5 GW of solar (which only produces energy about a quarter of   the time) to fill the gap. That compares to 14.6 GW being   installed in all of 2016
column27: according to GTM Research
column28: so large   dams are incredibly important to the country's electricity   infrastructure overall.But it wouldn't be crazy to think that over the course of the   next decade or two some of these hydro plants will be   decommissioned as they age. And to replace all hydro
column29: about 114   GW of solar or wind would need to be installed to replace clean   energy with clean energy. RPSs would demand that wind and solar   would fill the gap
column30: not fossil fuels.That's an incredible potential opportunity for developers likeFirst Solar(NASDAQ: FSLR)
column31: SunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR)
column32: andTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column33: whether they're building solar plants or energy   storage to provide more predictable power output.The crumbling infrastructure opportunityWhat's going on at the Oroville Dam has an impact on years'   worth of energy planning
column34: especially if the spillway collapses.   In California's RPS structure
column35: a large hydroelectric dam couldn't   be taken offline without eventually being replaced by renewable   energy sources like wind and solar. And when you consider the   sheer age of the hydro infrastructure in the U.S.
column36: it could   create a huge hole other sources of renewable energy would need   to fill.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip
