column1: Tesla Model 3: How Many Will Be Delivered In 2017?;2/17/2017;"Going into electric-car makerTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) fourth-quarter earnings release
column2: here's the   biggest question: How many Model 3 vehicles will management say   it expects to deliver during the year? After all
column3: we already know   Tesla has about 400
column4: 000 deposit-backed reservations for the   $35
column5: 000 vehicles. But the big mystery is how Tesla's Model 3   production ramp-up will look -- and thus Model 3 deliveries.While investors may not get a very specific answer
column6: management's guidance range for total vehicle sales will likely   provide some useful insight into Tesla's outlook for the highly   anticipated
column7: lower-cost vehicle.Model 3. Image source: Tesla Motors.makeArticleAd();Looking to guidanceIf Tesla follows its usual practice
column8: it will provide an   outlook for expected full-year vehicle deliveries when it reports   itsfourth-quarter resultson Feb. 22
column9: but it won't break down this forecast by model.   Still
column10: investors can extrapolate from guidance for total   deliveries to get an idea of what management might expect from   Model 3.Tesla CEO Elon Musk has long predicted it expects its   late-2015 launched Model X to eventually rival Model S   deliveries
column11: bringing total Model S and Model X annual deliveries   to about 100
column12: 000 units. With this context
column13: any guidance beyond   100
column14: 000 units in 2017 could presumably represent expected Model 3   deliveries.So
column15: what sort of guidance range should investors expect from   Tesla management? While this may not be the answer investors are   hoping for
column16: management will likely guide for a wide range of   possible outcomes. There's simply significant uncertainty   associated with forecasting a huge step change in vehicle   manufacturing.Musk explained the difficulty of forecasting Model 3   deliveries in the company's fourth-quarter earnings call:Another thing I really want to emphasize is the production     ramp tends to look like -- is exponential. Ultimately it is an     S-curve. An exponential goes to linear then goes to log. And     it's very difficult to predict exactly where that beginning     part of the exponential and the S-curve fits in between     quarterly reporting.A shift of even a few weeks one way or the other can have     quite a dramatic effect on what it looks like in that quarter
column17: but that's not indicative of the future. So we're telling you     what we -- we're giving you the best assessment we have short     of having a crystal ball.But Musk did provide some vision -- albeit very vague -- into   Tesla's expectations for Model 3
column18: saying he thinks it will be an   ""exciting 2017."" Further
column19: he said that Model 3 production will be   very uncertain in Q3 but ""gets pretty clear in Q4.""Why Tesla's guidance mattersShould investors even take Tesla's guidance seriously? I think   so.It's worth noting that
column20: despite Tesla's well-documented   tendency to miss targets
column21: its recent misses are relatively small   in relation to its rapidly growing targets. Even more
column22: the   percentage gap between Tesla's initial annual guidance in recent   years and its actual deliveries isn't growing
column23: despite extreme   growth in its targets.YearInitial GuidanceActual Vehicle DeliveriesDifference201320
column34: 985(7.2%)Asterisk indicates figure is calculated using a midpoint of a   guidance range. Table by author.Sure
column35: there will likely be more uncertainty associated with   Tesla's guidance for 2017 deliveries than in previous years given   the guesswork even management will need to employ to predict   Model 3 deliveries. But Tesla's history of small misses on big   growth targets gives investors good reason to at least expect its   guidance to reflect a likelytrajectoryfor actual vehicle deliveries in 2017.Wait! What about those Model X delays?When forecasting Tesla's Model 3 production ramp-up in 2017   and beyond
column36: it's probably tempting for investors to look to   Tesla's Model X delays and production challenges as a forewarning   for Model 3 production troubles. But there are several issues   with this reasoning.First
column37: unlike the Model X
column38: the Model 3 was designed from the   ground up for high-volume production. Second
column39: the Model X is   an insanely complex vehicle
column40: featuring never-before-manufactured   features like falcon wing doors
column41: self-presenting front doors
column42: the   largest front windshield in any vehicle
column43: and monopost seats.Further
column44: the Model X is the first fully-electric SUV ever   built. Indeed
column45: it's arguably a borderline miracle that Tesla was   even able to achieve an annualized production run rate of 40
column46: 000   Model X units by the end of 2016.Model X. Image source: Author.In Tesla's third-quarter earnings call last year
column47: Musk   specifically warned investors not to look to Model X as an   example of how Model 3 production could turn out:It's always tempting for people to reason by analogy instead     of first principles. And that would be the mistake of assuming     that anything to do with the X production has bearing on the     Model 3.They are very different programs with completely different     approaches. column1: Five Major Myths about Options Trading;2/17/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();When it comes to investing
column2: pretty much everyone has an opinion. While those opinions are great
column3: sometimes investors will spread myths about subjects they don't have a firm understanding of. One of the most confusing subjects isoptions trading. Due to the many moving parts involved
column4: investors find themselves befuddled and not knowing where to start. Here I'm going to debunk five major myths of options trading.Myth #1: Options are Riskier than StocksThis is one of those broad-based
column5: blanket statements that does not tell the whole truth. People think options are riskier because you can lose 100% of your investment in an option. However
column6: you can use options to limit your risk on trades.Here's an example
column7: let's say you wanted to buy 100 shares ofTesla (TSLA)ahead of their earnings report next week because you think they are going to have a good report and the stock will go up. Today it would cost you around $270 per share or $27
column8: 000 to own 100 shares. If TSLA goes down 10% on its earnings report
column9: you are going to lose $2
column10: 700 dollars. If it goes up 10%
column11: you'll make $2
column12: 700.On the flipside
column13: you could buy the March 17th$270 Call option for $1
column14: 350. If TSLA goes down 10% and stays there through expiration
column15: you'll lose your $1
column16: 350. If it goes up 10%
column17: you're call option will be worth at least $2
column19: maybe more. If you wanted to define your risk as $2
column21: you could buy two of these contracts
column22: controlling 200 shares of Tesla rather than only 100. Same amount of nominal risk
column23: but now your upside potential is doubled.Myth #2: You Need to be a Sophisticated Trader for OptionsThere certainly are options strategies that involve a great deal of complexity. With so many choices available to trade it can be very complicated. Each options expiration date has call options and put options of varying strikes available. At first glance the selection process can be daunting. Many stocks now have weekly options expiration
column24: making these even more overwhelming for investors.You don't need a PhD in Applied Mathematics to use simple options strategies to make money and create income. For example
column25: buying a call in the hopes that a stock goes up. If you know there is an event coming up that you think the stock will profit from
column26: you can buy a call near the money on the stock and if it goes up you can profit. If you want to make a trade that benefits when the stock goes down
column27: you can buy a put option in the hopes the stock goes down. Start with the basics and add more complex strategies as you become more comfortable.Myth #3: It Takes a Lot of Money to Trade OptionsThis couldn't be further from the truth. It's a lot less capital intensive to trade options than it is to buy 100 shares of your favorite stock. Most brokerage firms allow you to sell options premium
column28: a more advanced strategy
column29: in accounts that contain as little as $2
column30: 000. Compare that to Pattern Day Trader accounts which require at least $25
column31: 000.Trading options allows smaller accounts to gain exposure to more stocks for less money. You can diversify your options trades across many industries and many stocks simultaneously. There are even options on ETFs like theVolatility Index (VXX)so you can gain exposure to exotic financial instruments while managing your risk.Myth #4: Time is Always Working Against YouIf you are long or buy options then yes
column32: there is a time value element that's working against you. However
column33: there are simple ways to flip the script so this time works in your favor. One way is by using long call and long put spreads rather than buying a call or put outright. The other is to use credit spreads.A long call spread
column34: or a bull call spread
column35: is a two-legged options trade where a closer to the money option is purchased to open and a further out of the money call option is sold to open or shorted. This helps to drop the overall net debit or price of the call spread. It also limits the total profit potential of the trade.For example
column36: if I bought a March 17th$67.50 Call onGilead (GILD)today it would cost me about $2.95. My upside potential would be unlimited but my breakeven would be the strike price plus the net debit which in this case is $2.95
column37: making my breakeven $70.45.However
column38: if I believe Gilead's upside is limited to $72.50
column39: I could sell that $72.50 Call at the same expiration and take back some money
column40: dropping my overall cost on the spread
column41: therefore bringing down my breakeven. I could sell the $72.50 Call for 55c. Now my cost on the $67.50/72.50 Call spread is only $2.40
column42: my breakeven now $69.90
column43: and I'll make more money up to $72.50 than I would have with the long call by itself.Another example is the credit spread. Rather than buying the aforementioned spread
column44: if I'm bearish on GILD I can sell the spread. So instead of spending $2.40 for the spread I would pocket $2.40. My risk would be the $5 difference in the strike prices
column45: minus the $2.40 I took in premium. So I risk $2.60 to make $2.40. This credit spread would max out or give me the largest possible winning outcome of $2.40 if shares of GILD closed at or below $62.50 at expiration on March 17th.Myth #5: You Need a Special Account to Trade OptionsWell
column46: sort of. While you do need to sign an options risk acknowledgement form and get your account approved specifically for options trading
column47: it's not exactly a ""special account."" Pretty much any non-qualified
column48: or non-retirement
column49: account is eligible for options trading. I specify non-qualified because accounts like IRAs are restricted as to the type of options trading you can do since you can't short stocks in retirement accounts.There are several levels of options approvals out there
column50: designed to save investors from themselves. Each level or tier is restricted
column51: only allowing certain types of trading. Each broker has their own guidelines for what these levels look like. All you really need for approval is experience trading and capital. It's not like you have to be a millionaire or anything.Bottom LineThose are the five biggest myths about options trading that scare off potential traders. If you take the time to learn more about trading options
column52: you'll find that they are a great way to manage your risk and gain exposure to the stock market.Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today
column53: you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.Click to get this free reportIPATH-SP5 VX ST (VXX): ETF Research ReportsTesla Motors

column1: 3 Vanguard Treasury Bond Funds to Consider;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIf you want to invest in government bonds with Vanguard funds
column3: there are a few primary ways to do it. You can invest in one of three Vanguard treasury bond funds
column4: invest in one of their agency bond funds or invest in a Vanguard index fund that covers all types of government bond funds.makeAd('4'
column6: 'mktsnews'
column7: 'vanguard'
column9: '');Today we'll focus on Vanguard funds that hold U.S. Treasury bonds. The three types of treasury bond funds that Vanguard offers are categorized by the primary bond durations
column10: which include short term
column11: intermediate term and long term.Investors who buy treasury bond funds are usually looking for exposure to a basket of bonds with high credit quality
column12: which means the objective that suits this need is one of conservative income.In translation
column13: investors looking for high yields aren't typically buyers of treasury bond funds.Vanguard Treasury Bond Mutual FundsVanguard Short-Term Treasury Fund(MUTF:VFISX): Vanguard's VFISX fund invests in U.S. Treasury bills
column14: which are short-term bonds with durations that average about two years. Short-term treasury bonds typically have higher yields than money market funds but lower interest-rate risk than intermediate- and long-term bonds. Although they're not without market risk
column15: short-term treasury bonds can be a good fixed-income choice for conservative investors. Expenses are 0.2% and the minimum initial investment is $3
column16: 000.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayVanguard Intermediate-Term Treasury Fund(MUTF:VFITX): Vanguard's VFITX holds government debt in the form of intermediate-term U.S. Treasuries
column17: which have an average duration of 5.3 years. Intermediate-term bond funds make good core holdings for the fixed-income portion of a portfolio because they generally kick off higher yields than short-term bond funds and carry less interest rate risk than long-term bond funds. The expenses for VFITX are 0.2% and the minimum initial investment is $3
column18: 000.Vanguard Long-Term Treasury Fund(MUTF:VUSTX): Vanguard's VUSTX invests in a basket of long-term Treasuries that average more than 15 years in duration. Over the long haul
column19: investors can expect VUSTX to produce higher yields and better annual returns than its short- and intermediate-term counterparts
column20: but they'll have to accept higher interest-rate risk along with them. For example
column21: when interest rates are rising
column22: prices for long-term bond funds tend to fall further than those with shorter average durations. VUSTX has an expense ratio of 0.2% and has a minimum initial investment of $3
column23: 000.As of this writing

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Is Charged and Ready to Go;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) andTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) may not be competitors
column3: but you can trade them as if they are. Let me explain.makeArticleAd();I am a fundamentally driven trader. Meaning I like to set my risk based on solid fundamentals. Tesla and Twitter are both perceived as risky bets. This is not a slight against either of them; I am merely saying that their fundamentals have yet to grow into their valuations. Tesla has a few obstacles ahead it. I get the potential but for now it's a speculative play in my book.A few days ago I suggestedclosing TSLA long profits and roll into TWTR longs. I did so because I didn't have room for both speculative trades in my portfolio. The move turned out to be an instant win as that day marked the high in TSLA and a coincided with a spike in TWTR.Click to EnlargeTesla Stock has a cult following. But on Thursday it caught a downgrade that caused a 3.9% drop.It won't be long before TSLA fans start touting great entry points. Personally
column4: I reiterate my skepticism in its fundamentals so I won't be buying the stock.3 Dow Jones Stocks That Are Weighing You DownOn the other hand
column5: I remain a fan of the TSLA stock price action. So
column6: I like selling risk in Tesla options.I am always looking for opportunities to cautiously catch the falling knife. The easiest way I can do it is by repeating what has worked in TSLA
column7: which is to sell risk against extreme opinions. I am not reckless so I always leave plenty of room for error since I never assume that I will pick the perfect time of entry. In this case
column8: I will nibble with a first tranche trade then add to it as price unfolds.The Trade:Sell TSLA Jan 2018 $185 put. This is a bullish trade for which I collected $11.50 to open. The 30% price buffer gives me an 80% theoretical chance of success. My breakeven point is $173.5 per share. Selling naked puts is dangerous and is not suitable for all investors especially on a speculative high-priced stock. So I can modify this trade to carry less overall dollars at risk.The Alternate:Sell TSLA Jan 2018 $185/$180 credit put spread. For this collect $1 to open. If successful
column9: this trade yields more than 25% on money risked. Selling a spread limits my maximum risk to the width of the spread less what I collect to open.Amazon.com
column10: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is Ready for a BreakoutI am not required to carry these trades through expiration. I can close them at any time for partial gains or losses. Selling naked puts is dangerous especially in markets hovering at all time highs. I only do it if I am willing and able to own the stock at the strike sold.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column11: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best Stocks to Buy and Hold Forever3 Cheap Lithium Stocks to Buy That Will Energize Your PortfolioThe postTesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Is Charged and Ready to Goappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column13: TTM

column15: TSLAThe auto sector saw mixed developments in the past week but most of the companies from this space witnessed positive stock price movement. Ford Motor Co. (NYSE:F-Free Report) announced new investments
column16: while Lear Corporation (NYSE:LEA-Free Report) increased its authorized share repurchase program and quarterly dividends.However
column17: Tata Motors Limited (NYSE:TTM-Free Report) reported significantly weak quarterly results. Toyota Motor Corporation (NYSE:TM-Free Report) began the sales of its improved plug-in hybrid vehicle in Japan but also recalled all Mirai cars sold by it.Tesla Motors
column18: Inc. (NASDAQ:TSLA-Free Report) expanded into the Middle East with operations commencing in Dubai. The company also announced further expansion plans.(Read the previous roundup here:Auto Stock Roundup for Feb 9
column19: 2017)Recap of the Week's Most Important Stories1. Ford has announced its decision to invest around $1 billion in Agro Al
column20: an artificial intelligence company
column21: over the next five years. The company is expected to develop a virtual driver system for Ford's autonomous vehicle
column22: which is due to launch in 2021. Agro Al and Ford's autonomous vehicle software developers will collaborate to promote the commercialization of driverless cars. (Read more:Ford to Invest $1 Billion in Argo AI Over Next 5 years).Ford has also announced its decision to invest $200 million in an innovative aerodynamic testing facility that will simulate driving conditions to improve fuel economy. Construction of the 13-acre complex in Michigan is expected to commence this year.Ford carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).2. Lear's current authorized share repurchase program has been increased to $1 billion and the repurchase period has been extended to Dec 31
column23: 2019. The company began the program in 2011 and has bought back roughly 40% of its outstanding shares since
column24: returning about $3.5 billion to shareholders.Lear had roughly $341 million left under the repurchase program at the end of 2016. Moreover
column25: the company has hiked its quarterly cash dividend on the common stock by 67%
column26: increasing it from 30 cents a share to 50 cents.Lear currently holds a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).3. Tata Motors recently reported results for the quarter ended Dec 31
column27: 2016. The company's consolidated profit after tax for the quarter plunged 96.2% year over year. The company's bottom line was adversely affected by negative currency translations and a weak performance in the Jaguar Land Rover (""JLR"") business segment. The JLR business witnessed weaker product mix and lower wholesale volumes in the quarter.The company's commercial vehicles segment also saw lower demand due to the demonetization of high-value currencies in India. Management expects the JLR segment margins to be better in the next quarter

column1: 4 Stocks to Buy Near 52-Week Lows;2/15/2017;"With U.S. stock markets trading near their all-time highs
column2: many companies' valuations have become a bit stretched. But there   arealwaysbargains to be found if you are willing to turn over enough   rocks. We asked a team of Fools to highlight a stock trading near   its 52-week low that they think is worth buying today. Read on to   see why they pickedAmerican Outdoor Brands(NASDAQ: AOBC)
column3: Gilead Sciences(NASDAQ: GILD)
column4: CVS Health(NYSE: CVS)
column5: andFord(NYSE: F) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();This stock is under fire
column6: but it's fighting backDan Caplinger(American Outdoor Brands): American Outdoor Brands isn't a familiar name to most   investors
column7: but the company formerly known as Smith & Wesson   is well known as a premier gun manufacturer. The company decided   to change its name to highlight that it makes a variety of other   products in addition to its extensive gun offerings
column8: such as   laser sighting systems
column9: knives
column10: tree saws
column11: and tactical lighting   products. Moreover
column12: American Outdoor Brands produces gun vaults   and accessories
column13: along with gunsmithing and reloading tools.American Outdoor Brands has seen its stock fall recently
column14: in   large part because of the results of the U.S. presidential   election in November. Many believed that the stock would climb if   the Democratic candidate had won
column15: with expectations of stricter   gun control restrictions leading many gun enthusiasts to make   purchases prior to any such regulations taking effect. However
column16: with the victory of President Trump
column17: the urgency among gun buyers   is gone
column18: and investors fear that American Outdoor Brands will see   sales suffer as a result.However
column19: American Outdoor Brands' strategy to emphasize its   broader product line should help it sustain growth in the long   run. Even if sales fall now
column20: American Outdoor Brands has the   quality and brand awareness to prosper for long-term   investors.The cash to cure what ails itMatt DiLallo(Gilead Sciences): Shares of biotech giant Gilead Sciences have   stumbled over the past year
column21: dropping more than 35%. The stock   recently hit another 52-week low after reporting disappointing   fourth-quarter earnings
column22: with no clear signs of a turnaround in   sight. The culprit is declining sales of its hepatitis C   franchise
column23: which isn't expected to turn around anytime soon.That said
column24: Gilead still managed to generate a whopping $16.7   billion of operating cash flow last year. It returned most of   that cash to shareholders
column25: buying back $11 billion in stock and   paying $2.5 billion in dividends. The company also recently   increased the dividend by 10% thanks to that copious cash flow.   Even with those increasing shareholder returns
column26: the company was   able to add to its cash position
column27: which stood at $32.4 billion at   the end of last year.That cash position might be just the medicine that cures the   company's ailing sales because it could use it to make a   meaningful acquisition
column28: such as acquiring a company with a   compelling late-stage drug pipeline or a fast-selling drug. If   Gilead can find the right deal
column29: it could halt the stock's slide   by giving investors a reason to be optimistic that sales   can grow once again.Political attention = opportunityBrian Feroldi(CVS Health): Changes are coming to the Affordable Care Act
column30: while   politicians have been accusing pharmacy benefit managers such as   CVS Health for driving up the cost of drugs. Mix in competitive   pressure that caused the company tocut its guidance
column31: and it is easy to understand why CVS's shares have been tossed   into the discount bin.While 2017 looks as if it'sgoing to be a wash
column32: I can't help feeling good about this company's prospects over   the long term. Baby boomers are retiring in droves
column33: which should   drive prescription volume growth for years to come. CVS Health's   in-store MinuteClinics are a hit with consumers
column34: and there's   plenty of room left for expansion. TheTargetand Omnicare integrations are going well
column35: and sales of specialty   drugs are growing nicely. That's a lot of good things happening   for a stock trading near its 52-week low.Meanwhile
column36: the company continues to crank out cash flow that   it generously passes back to shareholders in the form of a rising   dividend and share buybacks. Yet CVS Health's depressed share   price has pulled its valuation down to 13.5 times forward   earnings. With a strong competitive position and a market-beating   yield of 2.5%
column37: this is a terrific stock to buy at today's   dirt-cheap valuation.The forgotten automakerTravis Hoium(Ford): Automakers not namedTeslaare having a hard time getting any love in today's stock market.   Ford has made vast improvements in the quality and attractiveness   of its vehicles since the recession subsided
column38: and now it's   churning profits quarter after quarter. And no one seems to   care.F Revenue (TTM)data byYChartsWhat's impressive about Ford today is that it's profiting from   the market's trends (SUVs and trucks) while investing in future   technologies such as electric vehicles and autonomous driving.   Don't mistake the fact that Ford isn't showing off the latest   0-to-60 times as a sign that it's falling behind: Ford is working   on autonomous vehicles in a big way.The company recently showed off its second-generation   autonomous Ford Fusion

column40: and invested $1 billion in Argo AI to develop commercial   ride-sharing fleets by 2021. On top of that
column41: 90 autonomous Ford   Fusions will be on the road this year across the U.S. and   potentially Europe
column42: refining autonomous technology.Ford is a leading automaker of the future

column5: it is important to point out that 13F filings do not tell the whole story
column6: because these funds are only required to disclose theirlongpositions with the SEC
column7: but are not required to disclose theirshortpositions. A fund making a bearish bet against a stock by shorting calls
column8: for example
column9: might also be long some amount of stock as they trade around their overall bearish position. This long component could show up in a 13F filing and everyone might assume the fund is bullish
column10: but this tells only part of the storybecause the bearish/short side of the position is not seen.makeArticleAd();Having given that caveat

column1: The Chevy Bolt EV Gets Off to a Strong Sales Start;2/12/2017;"Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has talked about creating an   affordable electric car for more than a decade. That car -- the   Model 3 -- is finally taking shape. Test production could begin   within the next few weeks

column6: the Chevy Bolt. The 2017 Chevy Bolt went on sale in   December and is selling quite well so far. It may not match the   Model 3 in terms of total sales
column7: but the Bolt is on its way to   becoming a key part of GM's vehicle lineup.A bolt from the blueTesla has been talking up the Model 3 -- at least conceptually   -- for a very long time. A few years ago
column8: it set 2017 as a target   for beginning production.makeArticleAd();Tesla still hopes to start delivering the Model 3 sedan     later this year. Image source: Tesla Motors.Thus
column9: most industry observers were shocked when GM showcased   the Bolt concept car in early 2015 and then quickly confirmed   that it would go into production with an on-sale date of late   2016. This allowed the Chevy Bolt to make it to marketbefore the Model 3.The Chevy Bolt offers an impressive EPA-estimated 238 miles of   range. It has a starting price of $37
column10: 495 and is eligible for a   $7
column11: 500 federal tax credit. (Some states
column12: including California
column13: offer additional tax credits.) Furthermore
column14: most reviews of the   Bolt have been quite positive and have confirmed that the   advertised 238-mile range holds up in real-world driving   conditions.Strong sales out of the gateThe first Chevy Bolts arrived on dealer lots in December. GM   dealers delivered 579 Bolts to customers that month. In January
column15: availability improved modestly and sales doubled to 1
column16: 162   units.That may not seem like much compared to the nearly 200
column17: 000   vehicles GM dealers delivered in the U.S. during January.   However
column18: the Bolt is only available in two states so far:   California and Oregon. (To be fair
column19: electric vehicles are   particularly popular in those states.) Furthermore
column20: inventory   remains extremely low
column21: with Chevy Bolts spending just seven days   on dealers' lots on average.GM plans to gradually roll the Chevy Bolt out to more states   over the course of this year. It will be available in most West   Coast and Northeast markets by the spring
column22: with nationwide   availability scheduled for September.The Chevy Bolt will be available nationwide by September.     Image source: General Motors.Considering the strong initial demand for the Bolt
column23: sales   could far exceed anything the plug-in hybrid Chevy Volt has   managed over the last six years. In 2016
column24: GM delivered 24
column25: 739   Volts
column26: which was a new record for the model.A key piece of the puzzleThe Chevy Bolt is likely to remain a relatively low-volume   model for GM. However

column28: it could prove to be very important for the General.First
column29: even if it isn't as cool as Tesla's Model 3

column33: it will help   General Motors meet the EPA's aggressive fuel economy targets in   the coming years. Full-size trucks and SUVs generate the lion's   share of GM's profit and will continue to do so. However
column34: in   order to continue churning out those gas-guzzlers
column35: GM also has to   produce some fuel-efficient vehicles. With a 119 MPG-equivalent   rating
column36: the Bolt goes a long way in this regard.Third

column1: In Case You Missed It
column2: This Hasn't Happened in the Solar Industry in 16 Years;2/11/2017;"The solar industry has been on a growth streak for the past 16   years and is now a formidable force in energy. But this year may   finally see the growth streak come to an end.According toGTM Research
column3: 2017 is expected to see a 7% decline in installations from 74   GW to 69 GW. This would be a significant downturn after years of   growth
column4: but it's not all that surprising to industry observers.First Solar(NASDAQ: FSLR)
column5: SunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR)
column6: Canadian Solar(NASDAQ: CSIQ)
column7: and even shares ofTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) in SolarCity were all hammered by this decline   before the calendar turned to 2017.While this year may be bad for solar energy
column8: it may be the   calm before a wave of installations hits starting in 2018. And if   you look out on the horizon the solar future looks to be getting   brighter everyday.makeArticleAd();Solar installations like this one have become more and more     common around the world in the past decade. Image source: Getty     Images.A series of unfortunate eventsThe decline in installations in 2017 will be driven by a   number of negative events all hitting at once. There was an   urgency that drove a boom in installations in 2016 when the   investment tax credit (ITC) in the U.S. was set to expire
column9: but   the extension in late 2015 took away any urgency for utilities to   sign solar contracts for 2017. Long-term
column10: the extension will lead   to more solar installations
column11: but not until the 2018-2021   timeframe.China will also be a drag after installing a record 34.2 GW of   solar (enough to power 5.6 million U.S. homes) in 2016 according   to the Chinese National Energy Administration. No one quite knows   how much solar will be installed in China in 2017
column12: but the NEA   only plans to average 27.5 GW of installations over the next four   years so it's safe to say installations will be down.Japan is another country where the solar industry is in for a   rough year. According to GTM Research
column13: an estimated 10.2 GW of   solar was installed in Japan in 2016
column14: but that will drop to 8.8   GW in 2017 as feed-in tariff reductions hit. Japan is a high   potential solar market
column15: but public policy hasn't kept up with   potential and that will keep a cap on growth short-term.Why growth is on the horizonWhile these factors in the U.S.
column16: China
column17: and Japan will drive a   decline in solar installations in 2017
column18: that doesn't mean the   industry is heading into a dark chapter. Solar energy has never   been cheaper and bids for new power plants are coming in under 4   cents per kWh in some locations
column19: a price that would beat any new   fossil fuel or nuclear plant on a cost basis.Image source: SunPower.Emerging markets like Chile
column20: Mexico
column21: Argentina
column22: India
column23: and the   Middle East are starting to see the potential of solar as well.   Mexico's recent auction resulted in clean energy contracts with   an average price of 3.3 cents per kWh and given the low cost many   countries are following with their own reverse auctions in 2017.   Nearly four dozen countries could have energy auctions this year   and that would lead to a boom in demand in 2018 and beyond.Solar energy is cost effective today
column24: but energy projects have   this lag between when people decide to go solar and when projects   are in the ground. That's the lull the market is in today.   Leading developers like First Solar
column25: SunPower
column26: and Canadian Solar   could will their backlog in 2018 and 2019
column27: despite having a down   year in 2017.Solar energy is still the future of energyOver the past decade alone
column28: solar energy has grown from a 2 GW   industry that could install enough power generation to power   368
column29: 000 homes per year to an industry giant that installed 74 GW
column30: or enough to power 12.1 million homes
column31: in the last year alone.   And growth was driven by a whopping 90% drop in solar panel costs   as technology improves across the industry.2017 may be a down year for the solar industry for a variety   of reasons
column32: but it doesn't fundamentally change the fact that   solar energy is the most abundant energy source in the world and   the cost to generate solar power is now lower than fossil fuels   in most of the world.Like it or not
column33: the solar boom is really just beginning and   2017 will be a calm before what could be another 16 years of   consecutive growth for solar energy.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Denies Employees Suffer Poor Working Conditions;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk is denying claims that its employees suffer poor working conditions.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrThe claims against Tesla Inc come from Jose Moran
column3: an employee at its San Francisco Fremont plant. Moran claims that the employees have to put in mandatory overtime
column4: suffer preventable injuries don't get adequate pay.Jose Moran made all of these claims in a recent Medium post. He also says that management at the factory has taken steps to keep workers from coming together to form a union. This includes allegedly having them sign a new confidentiality policy.Tesla Inc CEO Elon Musk argues that this ins't the case. He claims that the allegations made by Moran are""morally outrageous"". Musk also went on to say that he believes that the employee was a plant from the United Auto Workers to try and rally other employees to push for unionization
column5: reportsCNBC.The United Auto Workers have disputed Elon Musk's accusations about Jose Moran being a plant. It also claims that other employees of Tesla Inc have come to it speaking about wanting to unionize. It says it will welcome these employees ""with open arms.""According toUSA Today
column6: the Tesla Inc plant is the only one owned by an auto company in the United States that isn't unionized. However
column7: there isn't a single plant in the country that is operated by a foreign automaker that does have a union. United Auto Workers has had its eye on unionizing the TSLA plant since at least May 2016.More From InvestorPlaceThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets Profits10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America Great7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018The postTesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Denies Employees Suffer Poor Working Conditionsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Nvidia Shows Artificial Intelligence Revolution Is Biggest Trend Of Our Time;2/10/2017;"Nvidia (Shutterstock photo)It's no secret that Nvidia (NVDA) was the best performing stock in the S&P 500 in 2016
column2: gaining more than 370%. But while the company's graphics processor unit (GPU) chips are being used in everything from gaming PCs to autonomous cars to virtual reality to data centers
column3: the reinvigoration of Nvidia is built by one thing: artificial intelligence.AI is increasingly being used in everything and everywhere
column4: most notably data centers for machine learning
column5: where Nvidia's GPUs have a tremendous lead over the competition
column6: including anything from AMD (AMD) and Intel (INTC). Data center revenue was up 67% year-over-year in the quarter at $296 million and more impressive
column7: up 23% from the impressive fiscal third-quarter 2017 results that helped send the stock soaring more than 30% in November 2016.makeArticleAd();The technology is touching everything and anyone
column8: be it on your smartphone or when you shop on Amazon (AMZN) or using software. In fact
column9: Nvidia CEO Jen-Hsun Huang toldBarron'sthat AI is just the future of software.If you read Nvidia's conference call transcript and itsearnings press release
column10: AI is mentioned everywhere and with good reason: deep learning is only made possible by the advancements in AI being made by university researchers and big companies such as Google (GOOG)
column11: Apple (AAPL)
column12: Facebook (FB)
column13: Amazon and others.In reacting to the blow-out earnings results
column14: Jefferies analyst Mark Lipacis called Nvidia essentially the only publicly traded company solely focused on AI. ""[Nvidia] posted its 7th consecutive beat
column15: and while YoY rev growth of 55% likely marks 2nd derivative peak
column16: the 200% growth in its Datacenter business and improving GM reinforce our thesis that NVDA is emerging as the de facto standard in AI - one of the most exciting growth drivers in tech
column17: Lipacis wrote
column18: while raising his price target to $140 from $125.Of the aforementioned areas
column19: perhaps the one that is most tangible to show consumers the AI revolution is autonomous driving.Tesla (TSLA) and CEO Elon Musk have pioneered autonomous driving in the Model S (though to which extent is up for debate)
column20: but Tesla has chosen to use Nvidia's chipsets to not only help it with its infotainment unit
column21: but more importantly
column22: the software that helps withautonomy
column23: using the NVIDIA DRIVE PX 2 AI computing platform.Society is a little bit away from true autonomy in a car (Level 5)
column24: in which a human does not need to do anything
column25: but Tesla is working on getting towards Level 4/5 faster than anyone else
column26: thanks to Nvidia. (For a good primer on what each level means
column27: clickhere.)Nvidia has several other automotive partnerships
column28: including recently announced ones with Bosch andAudi.All of this highlights that self-driving cars is not just a science fiction fantasy
column29: it's real and it's coming. And it's being powered by AI. The societal impact AI will have is up for debate
column30: whether it will be a net positive or a net negative
column31: but there is no stopping it.AI is continuing to become more prevalent in everything we do
column32: but we are nowhere near general AI
column33: in which computers can make decisions just as a human can. What we're experiencing right now is soft (weak) AI
column34: in which humans tell a computer to do a task and it does it better than any human can. But thanks to deep/machine learning
column35: we're getting closer to general AI
column36: even if it's still decades away. That means the AI revolution is only just getting started and it has years and years on which to run.All thanks to Nvidia."

column1: 2 Brilliant Ways NVIDIA Corporation Is Investing in the Future;2/9/2017;"Investors followingNVIDIA Corporation(NASDAQ: NVDA) already know that the company is a clear leader in   the graphics processing unit (GPU) space as it holds more than   70% of the discrete desktop GPU market share right now.NVIDIA earns about 62% of its total revenue from sales of GPUs   in its gaming segment
column2: but the company isn't satisfied with just   kicking up its feet and reaping the benefits of that. Instead
column3: NVIDIA is using its GPU knowledge to begin dominating two future   markets: self-driving technology and data centers.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Hitting the gas on self-driving technologyIt's hard to write about NVIDIA's future without talking about   semi-autonmous driving. That's because autos are a clear area of   focus for the company and because NVIDIA has already taken an   early lead.NVIDIA uses its GPUs to process images from on-board cameras   mounted on semi-autonomous cars so that the vehicles know what   they're looking at (i.e.
column4: a moving car vs. a dumpster). NVIDIA's   supercomputer
column5: called Drive PX 2
column6: is on its second iteration   already and is used by more than 80 automakers and Tier 1   automotive suppliers to deliver high levels of semi-autonomous   features.Teslais the latest carmaker to begin using NVIDIA's technologies for   self-driving capabilities
column7: and there are plenty of reasons   investors should be optimistic that NVIDIA's current automotive   investments are just getting started.The company earned $127 million from its automotive segment in   fiscal Q3 2017
column8: which was a 60% increase year over year. While   that figure isn't a lot of money for the company -- it represents   just over 6% of NVIDIA's top line in the quarter -- it's worth   mentioning that the overall driverless car market is expected to   be worth $77 billion by 2035.Tesla's commitment to its ongoing release of new   semi-autonomous driving tech
column9: Google'snewly created Waymoself-driving car company
column10: andBaidu's aggressive self-driving technology tests in China all point to   a coming future of semi-autonomous and fully autonomous vehicles.IHSAutomotive predicts that the world could reach driverless car   ubiquity about 30 years from now -- and NVIDIA is creating some   of the technology right now to make that a reality.Data centers risingAside from automotive tech
column11: the other area NVIDIA is investing   its future in is data centers. This segment has been part of the   company's business for a while
column12: but recently
column13: NVIDIA has doubled   its efforts to expand into new data center markets -- and it's   paying off enormously.In fiscal Q3 2017
column14: the company earned $240 million from its   data center segment
column15: a staggering increase of 192% year over   year. When asked about the company's data center growth
column16: CEO   Jen-Hsun Huang said NVIDIA has been creating new   opportunities in the space like virtualization
column17: deep   learning
column18: and computational science.Data center revenue accounted for about 12% of the company's   top line in the third quarter
column19: but investors should keep in mind   that this segment is the company's fastest-growing business
column20: and   it has some of the highest margins as well. NVIDIA believes its   data center addressable market is worth $5 billion
column21: making it a   massive revenue opportunity for the company's future.Just the beginningNVIDIA had a tremendous 2016
column22: with the company's stock price   skyrocketing 229%
column23: and that's left investors understandably   wondering if there's more where that came from. We'll know a bit   more when the company releases its fourth-quarter 2017 results   later this week
column24: but no matter what happens
column25: investors should   look to NVIDIA's long-term pursuits outside of its core gaming   segment. NVIDIA's focus on automotive technologies and data   centers could be two huge growth areas in the coming years -- and   they're future opportunities investors shouldn't overlook.10 stocks we like better than NvidiaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column26: it can pay to listen. After all
column27: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column28: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column29: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Nvidia wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column30: 2017.Chris Neigerhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Baidu

column32: and Tesla. The Motley     Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Why You Should (and Shouldn't) Buy NVIDIA;2/9/2017;"NVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA)
column2: the graphics-chip maker and leader in the   burgeoning virtual-reality and driverless-car markets
column3: has been   on an absolute tear over the past 12 months
column4: with shares up over   340%. At this point
column5: it's natural for investors to wonder if it's   too late to buy a few shares -- this run could just be the   start of NVIDIA's path to world domination
column6: or it could be the   very top of a bubble-like valuation.While the truth probably lies somewhere in the middle
column7: there   are certain types of investors who should
column8: and shouldn't
column9: invest   in NVIDIA no matter what the reality is. So with this fundamental   truth in mind
column10: we asked two of The Motley Fool's best and   brightest just who should (and shouldn't) invest in NVIDIA.   Here's what they had to say.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.You firmly believe in the growth storyChris Neiger: NVIDIA has caught the eye of many tech investors with its stock   price run-up in 2016. The investor optimism is more than just   speculation
column11: though. NVIDIA is already a dominant force in the   GPU market
column12: with more than 70% of the discrete desktop GPU market   share
column13: and it shows no signs of ceding its lead to rivalAMD. That's important
column14: because the company brings in about 62% of   its total revenue from its gaming GPU segment.If that were the only thing going for NVIDIA
column15: it would   probably be enough. But one of the reasons this company is so   exciting is that it's taking what it knows about GPUs and   applying it to all-new growth markets -- namely
column16: semi-autonomous   driving and high-powered
column17: artificially intelligent   supercomputers. The company's DGX-1 computer uses deep learning   and artificial-intelligence analytics to generate as much   processing power as 250 conventional servers. Data-center revenue   is NVIDIA's second-largest business segment
column18: and the company is   proving it can innovate like no other in the space.In the semi-autonomous-driving market
column19: NVIDIA's Drive PX 2   supercomputer is being used as the onboard computer for many   self-driving vehicles. The computer uses NVIDIA's GPUs to   processes visual information in real time and give cars a type of   situational awareness. Eighty automakers and Tier 1 automotive   suppliers are already using NVIDIA's Drive PX system
column20: andTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) just became one of NVIDA's most recent customers.   Some investors may be scared away by the company's pricey P/E   ratio of 74
column21: but NVIDIA should continue to be a long-term growth   story as long as the company continues growing gaming revenue at   a healthy clip and its investments in AI and semi-autonomous   driving continue to pay off.Because everyone else isSean O'Reilly: NVIDIA remains the undisputed king of advanced graphics chips.   What's more
column22: thanks to its NVIDIA Drive PX 2 computing   platform
column23: it has a respectable stake in the future of   driverless carsandartificial intelligence. Given these catalysts
column24: it's shouldn't   have been surprising that NVIDIA was one of the best performing   stocks of 2017. Yet that awe-inspiring performance is precisely   where the danger in investing in the company now lies.To invest in any company
column25: not just NVIDIA
column26: you need to believe   in that company and perform your due diligence. You need to read   conference calls
column27: have faith in management's vision for the   future
column28: and find the current valuation compelling
column29: because at   some point
column30: your faith in the company will be tested. It's not   unheard of for a stock that's rewarded shareholders with huge   gains in a short period to fall
column33: or even 30%
column34: only to   then rocket ever higher -- leaving those who sold in the pullback   out in the cold.NVIDIA has a fantastic suite of offerings
column35: led by its GeForce
column36: PureVideo
column37: nForce
column38: GoForce
column39: and Quadro chips
column40: and a foothold   in a number of potentially huge markets. NVIDIA is exceptional at   what it does -- but they are not unassailable (yet) and it's   worth repeating that those big catalysts arepotentiallyhuge markets. Right now
column41: the company is a non-monopolistic   business
column42: playing in nascent tech segments
column43: and it's priced at 40   times forward FY 2017 earnings. Even further out
column44: the company   currently trades at 23 times FY 2020 estimates earnings
column45: as   estimated byS&P Global Market Intelligence. If NVIDIA stumbles with quarterly results or offers up guidance   that implies the business will slow down
column46: the stock price will   more than likely take a hit as expectations of future profits   normalize.Bottom line: Don't just buy into NVIDIA because it's the   current hot stock. Investors interested in the business need to   have the stomach for growth investing. You will be tested

column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsPolitical pundits were generally aghast when President Donald J. Trump appointed then-CEO ofExxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM)
column3: Rex Tillerson
column4: to the post of Secretary of State. The prevailing wisdom that somehow this position had to be filled by someone from government

column10: and I believe it is very good news for XOM shareholders over the long term.Few people had likely heard of the joint venture between XOM and Russia's state-owned oil exploration and production operation
column11: Rosneft(OTCMKTS:RNFTF). Exxon created astrategic agreementto ""establish the framework for joint oil exploration and production in Russia
column12: the United States
column13: and other countries
column14: according to Exxon. Ten joint ventures for projects in the Russian Arctic
column15: Black Sea and Siberia have since been set up.Of course
column16: pushing this forward became difficult because the U.S. placed sanctions on Russia.My expectation had been that Trump would lift sanctions on Russia in exchange for some kind of agreement to partner on attacking Isis
column17: or some cosmetic withdrawal from Crimea or Ukraine. Then
column18: Exxon could get back to work with Rosneft. Who better to negotiate this deal with Putin that the most recent CEO of Exxon Mobil?In a shocking coincidence (yes
column19: that's sarcasm)
column20: Putin suddenlyannouncedthat it had sold 19.5% stake in Rosneft to a mysterious Singapore investment group
column21: allegedly a 50-50 JV between Swiss and Qatari oil firms. Yet
column22: nobody seems to know who funded about 25% of the purchase
column23: and why some portion of the ownership is a Cayman Islands company belonging to an unidentified owner.My working theory is that Trump is all about deals. Say what you will about Putin
column24: but at the end of the day
column25: politics is about deals. Putin will make deals. Not only is Tillerson a deal-maker
column26: but he knows politics. He's been all over the world
column27: traversing all kinds of political landscapes to make deals for his global oil company! Duh!12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenAll of these moving parts are
column28: I believe

column31: BP plc (ADR)(NYSE:BP) also ownsa 20% stakein Rosneft. About 5% is publicly traded. If Russian state ownership falls under 50%
column32: and we see Rosneft's projects start up
column33: we'll have our answer.I'm also willing to bet that the mysterious buyers of this recent sale are ultimately tied directly to the Russian state or Putin himself. It just looks like it isn't.Now
column34: what does this mean for Exxon Mobil stock? It's all good. The Russian Arctic is expected to hold tons of oil
column35: not to mention the other areas of the joint venture. One has to assume that XOM stock is going to benefit because Exxon has already deployed assets and human capital over there. It may not exactly be a matter of flipping a switch
column36: but the projects are much farther along than trying to hunt and contract for new areas to explore.Nor does XOM have to get involved with the bad PR that would result from wanting to drill in protected areas here in the U.S.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Socks the Shorts With the Model 3Thus

column16: and it essentially means that Nvidiamustgrow rapidly. Otherwise

column18: Nvidia operates in some of the most exciting growth areas for semiconductors. The company is best-known for graphic chips
column19: and in particular its graphic processing units
column20: or GPUs. The company boasts it is the ""world leader"" in visual computing. This looks accurate - a recentBarron'sarticlepegged its GPU market share at 68%. This is one of the most compelling spaces in the semiconductor industry.Nvidia's chips are an integral component in the ecosystems that are pioneering growth in virtual reality
column21: cloud computing
column22: machine learning
column23: and self-driving cars. These are some hugely disruptive industries that could end up revolutionizing many facets of the gaming
column24: computing
column25: and automotive industries.The company's gaming business is the largest operating unit and growing 30% per year on average since 2013. Its data center business (to support cloud computing) is expanding at a more rapid clip - 40% annually. And automotive is skyrocketing 75% annually
column26: though from a very small initial base.In some respects
column27: and provided you are comfortable with the lofty valuation

column29: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)

column31: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD)

column33: machine learning
column34: and servers used for cloud computing.Intel is somewhat hamstrung from its dominant market share in personal computing. Its 80% market share to power personal computers and related devices has literally resulted in hundreds of billions of dollars in cash flow over the past several decades. This gives it unmatched rivalry to invest in new technology and keep a leadership position over chip competitors. But computing is mature and barely expanding.Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Socks the Shorts With the Model 3AMD had been thought to have lost its way. Years of mismanagement allowed Intel to expand on its dominance and nearly put AMD out of business. But new management appears to have reinvigorated AMD
column35: and investors are starting to believe it can also benefit from the same markets Nvidia is pursuing.Bottom Line on NVDA StockIn arecent interview

column38: consumer electronics
column39: and gaming."" Chips that power data warehouses to serve the rise in cloud computing represent yet another market for these firms.NVDA stock is an investor's best bet to gain exposure to these markets. The rub

column42: though with its current low levels of profitability

column44: and there is a modest dividend yield of 2.86% that should grow over time.I suggest taking a wait-and-see approach to Nvidia earnings. The fourth quarter is likely to impress

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Socks the Shorts With the Model 3;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNot that there was any risk of it happening
column3: but never let it be saidTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) isn't a perpetual source of news. Indeed
column4: TSLA stock holders have something new to process nearly every single day
column5: and the occasional weekend day to boot.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThis week was no exception
column6: and three of this week's developments are doing most of the driving right now:Tesla is taking a big step toward Model 3 production starting as planned.Tesla wants to enter India later this year.Short sellers are increasingly betting against Tesla stock as a rather amazing rally has unfurled since the end of November.Here's a little more perspective on all three matters owners of TSLA stock may want to digest
column7: for better or worse.Model 3 Production Beginning SoonThe details on the matter are scant to far
column8: but on Thursday morning
column9: Tesla announced it wouldshut down its California plant this monthto get ready to produce Model 3s
column10: and might begin building the prototype Model 3 as early as Feb. 20. The company anticipates full-scale production beginning later this year  in July
column11: as initially suggested by Musk.The market knew it was only a matter of time
column12: but to see it happening can elate current and would-be owners of Tesla stock. Somehow
column13: the goal of producing 500
column14: 000 vehicles per yer by next year doesn't seem out of reach.7 High-Risk
column15: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowThe company is believed to havereceived nearly 700
column16: 000 reservations- complete with deposits - for the Model 3
column17: which is expected to sport a sticker price of around $35
column18: 000.IndiaThe news came as a tweet on Tuesday - a response to a question to CEO Elon Musk via Twitter
column19: actually. In less than 140 characters
column20: Musk said hehopes to enter the Indian market by this summer.The knee-jerk response is optimism; entering new markets means more revenue potential. It's the second thought that raises questions
column21: though. India is a poor country
column22: per capita. The average annual income in India is $5
column23: 630. Worse
column24: median income is $616. It's not likely many of those consumers are even thinking about buying a TSLA vehicle.There's a curious nuance with the way India's income is distributed
column25: though.In India
column26: the richest 1% of the country controls 58% of the nation's wealth. That's one of the world's most extreme levels of wealth disparity. And when you're talking abouta country with a population of 1.33 billion
column27: it doesn't take a large proportion of the population to create a decent-sized pool of potential buyers.And for what it's worth
column28: the more manufacturing Musk can do in that country rather than import vehicles into India
column29: the better
column30: in terms of marketability. At the same time
column31: though its consumers still aren't as flush as they are in other parts of the world
column32: that's changing.Manhattan Venture Partners' Santosh Rao recently opined
column33: ""The market opportunity is too compelling to ignore. India has a growing middle class with rising disposable income. The manufacturing cost will also be relatively lower.""Short SellersTheWall Street Journal'sBen Eisen was right about one thing this week:Tesla's short-sellers are a persistent bunch.Thing is
column34: they may be a little too persistent for their own good.The 44% gain that TSLA stock has dished out since the first day of December
column35: amazingly enough
column36: wasn't a short-covering one. As of mid-January
column37: 35.04 million shares of TSLA stock were held as a short position
column38: up from the total as of the end of December
column39: and well above the mid-November tally of 31.5 million shares. That's essentially a $9.2 billion collective bet against Tesla
column40: according to calculations from S3 analyst Ihor Dusaniwsk.The bears aren't backing down
column41: betting against Tesla stock as it ticks higher. The mid-January reading is almost a record-high short interest.Big mistake.This is a stock that the market still loves to love
column42: and though it has been a love-hate relationship at times
column43: there's been more love than hate. That hasn't changed recently. Indeed
column44: if anything
column45: as production of electric vehicles scales up
column46: margins should improve. Don't forget that Teslaswung to a profit last quarter
column47: and may well surprise again later this month. It shouldn't take much more upside in TSLA stock to flush these bears out of their short trades
column48: augmenting any rally - the only way to close out a short trade is by buying the stock.The Smart Money: Sears Holdings Corp (SHLD) Is Already InsolventBy the way
column49: Dusaniwsk estimates that the collective short positions entered of late are have translated into unrealized losses of $2.27 billion. Those traders are apt to be getting very antsy.Bottom Line for Tesla StockTesla still has plenty of hurdles ahead. Namely
column50: it's still spending heavily on well
column51: pretty much everything
column52: and it remains to be seen if the integration with SolarCity will bear fruit.But
column53: the potential of India is a positive for Tesla stock
column54: as is what is ultimately an ill-advised wave of short-selling of TSLA shares. The prospect of the Model 3's production beginning soon. of course
column55: is a show-stopper.Although a technical dip in the near-term may be in the cards
column56: this week's news can be scored as a pair of wins in the ledger.As of this writing

column1: Earnings Preview: Guidance Is Key for Pandora Media Inc (P) Stock;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt seems unlikely that from a fundamental standpoint
column3: there will be a lot of news in thePandora Media Inc(NYSE:P) earnings report on Thursday.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockPandora already announced last month that fourth-quarter results would come in ahead of guidance for both revenue and adjusted Ebitda. That disclosure sent P stock up 6%
column4: and would seem to limit the possibility that the numbers in the Pandora earnings report will boost the stock further.That doesn't mean there will be no news coming out of Pandora earnings. The company has set itself up for a busy 2017. The replacement of Pandora One with Pandora Plus appears to have had some success in the fourth quarter. Commentary on that initiative will be closely watched on the Q4 conference call.Meanwhile
column5: in December
column6: Pandora announced a new ""Premium"" service to compete with offerings fromSpotify
column7: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) and others.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenThat product should roll out shortly
column8: potentially boosting growth in 2017. And Pandora has said it is aiming to return to Ebitda profitability in 2017. The Q4 report should give some color as to whether investors in P stock should believe the company.A Busy 2017 for Pandora StockPandora stock actually is up about 65% over the past year
column9: after coming close to all-time lows in early 2016. Those gains have come despite mixed performance in the business. Revenue is up 14% through the first nine months
column10: and likely rose a similar figure in Q4. But about half the year-to-date growth came from the acquisition of TicketFly last October. Advertising revenue also increased 14% through the first three quarters - but came solely from higher pricing. Active users were actually down year-over-year at the end of Q3
column11: and subscription revenue declined in the quarter as well.The user and subscription figures are a major problem for Pandora stock. The market simply doesn't trust that Pandora can create consistent profits based on advertising revenue alone. That's particularly true given thehigher royalty ratesthat took effect at the beginning of last year. So the move by Pandora to upgrade One to Plus - adding features like song replays - and to develop Premium are a clear step toward a subscription-based model.The plan from Pandora
column12: as detailed after the third quarter
column13: is for that type of model to provide a more stable revenue base. Moving customers to subscription-based services both helps margins and improves retention. If Pandora is successful
column14: Pandora stock likely will rise. But that remains a relatively big ""if.""What to Watch for in Pandora EarningsIn the Pandora earnings report
column15: then
column16: the most important numbers likely will come from the company's guidance. That guidance will give some color as to how successful management thinks Plus has been so far - and what kind of opportunity Premium has to boost Pandora earnings this year.But the Pandora earnings conference call also seems like it might move P stock. Management will have another opportunity to detail its strategy for 2017 and beyond. The company laid out its ""three-legged stool"" strategy - Plus
column17: Premium and Ticketfly - after the third quarter
column18: but investors weren't terribly impressed. Pandora stock fell about 14% over the next seven sessionsThe issue with P stock is that there's a real fear that Pandora's model simply doesn't quite work. The product itself is attractive
column19: as evidenced by the nearly 80 million active users. But it's not clear that Pandora can pay higher royalty rates through ad revenue alone. The company did announce layoffs ofabout 7%of its employees in a bid to improve 2017 profits. That simply raised additional concerns about Pandora stock. The most notable is: Can Pandora really compete with Apple
column20: Spotify andAmazon.com
column21: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)?After all
column22: those companies have much larger businesses - and much more cash - than Pandora. P stock still is worth almost $3 billion
column23: yet the company has burned about $127 million in cash just in the first three quarters of 2016. Full-year Ebitda loss is likely to be huge as well
column24: and that's not counting depreciation or the additional $139 million in Pandora stock awards.Make Free Profits From Tesla Inc (TSLA) StockFor Pandora stock to appreciate in the near term
column25: the company needs to get at least close to breakeven in 2017. So full-year guidance given in the Pandora earnings report will be key. But that aside
column26: investors also will be looking for more information on the plan going forward here.Can Pandora find a niche in the music industry? Is Pandora Premium ""too little
column27: too late"" against the offerings from Spotify
column28: Amazon and Apple? And is there really a profitable business model here
column29: or are royalty rates simply too difficult to manage?Those questions can't be answered quite yet
column30: but investors will be looking at the Pandora earnings report closely to better assess the company's prospects. And it's likely the commentary on the future - not the past - that will determine how Pandora stock reacts to Q4 earnings.As of this writing
column31: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. The author does receive royalties from Pandora.More From InvestorPlace4 Energy Stocks That Are Ticking Time Bombs3 Stocks to Buy for Their Coming ReboundThe postEarnings Preview: Guidance Is Key for Pandora Media Inc (P) Stockappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: GM's Race To Win Self-Driving Car War Provides Long-Term Opportunity;2/7/2017;"Like Tesla (TSLA)
column2: Google (GOOG
column3: GOOGL) spinoff Waymo
column4: Ford (F) and a host of others
column5: General Motors (GM) is going full-force in the race to be the leader in autonomous cars.A new study shows that it's further along than previously thought
column6: which is a good sign for investors
column7: even if they're not happy with the company's fourth-quarter results.The California Department of Motor Vehicles released a number ofreportsearlier this month from various automakers and tech companies on what they're doing as it relates to self-driving cars and GM
column8: long thought to be ceding the race
column9: has vaulted its position
column10: thanks to acquisitions and heavy spending.makeArticleAd();Cruise Automation
column11: which GMboughtfor more than $1 billion in March 2016
column12: is using a bunch of Chevrolet Bolt EVs to test its software and its cars out in the field. Cruise now has more than 20 vehicles licensed in California
column13: up from just two in early 2016
column14: when it was using a couple of Nissan Leafs.This is a bright sign for the Mary Barra-led company
column15: as it looks to own the entire ecosystem of the next version of the automobile
column16: instead of ceding the race to others.It's likely to keep dealing further into in this area
column17: whether it'spartnering with Lyftor adding engineers to its self-driving car fleet in order to keep testing and building cars inDetroit.Projects like this are likely to help shareholders in the long-run
column18: even if it impacts spending in the interim.In the fourth-quarter
column19: GM earned $1.28 a share on $43.91 billion
column20: ahead of estimates $1.17 a share on $41.53 billion in sales. Despite the earnings beat
column21: investors sent shares lower on concerns of a slowdown in auto sales for 2017
column22: as well as the potential for elevated inventory levels.It's unclear what impact
column23: if any
column24: self-driving cars are likely to have to vehicle volumes in the future. There may be a need for less cars
column25: since they could be working more efficiently. Or there may be a need for a massive resurgence in sales
column26: as costs come down and regulators incentivize manufacturers to make transportation safer.It's just a huge unknown at this point.GM has been building and manufacturing cars for over 100 years
column27: giving it a leg up
column28: at least in terms of the manufacturing process
column29: over any of its Silicon Valley competitors. This is something that Barra has consistently cited as an advantage.We have 100 years of really understanding vehicles
column30: putting them on the road
column31: making sure we have a safe
column32: high-quality vehicle
column33: Barra told reporters at a December press conference. When you take autonomous
column34: electrification
column35: connectivity
column36: I think we are going to have a very special offering to the consumer.The world is still a ways away fromLevel 5 autonomy(true autonomy
column37: in which a car can drive by itself in any condition anywhere without any help from a human)
column38: so the self-driving car race is far from over.But it looks like GM
column39: which has notoriously been secretive about its operations
column40: is a lot further along than anyone thought. And that's something shareholders can rest easy about."

column1: Why Tesla
column2: Inc. Stock Soared 18% in January;2/7/2017;"What happenedIn January
column3: shares of electric-car makerTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) extended their march higher
column4: gaining 17.9%
column5: according to data provided byS&P Global Market Intelligence. This comes on top of a 17.5% gain in December.So whatTesla stock's rise during January is likely due to a combination of Tesla   CEO Elon Musk's growing access to President Trump
column6: the National   Highway Traffic Safety Administration's decision to exonerate   Tesla's Autopilot after an investigation of the technology
column7: and   the company's ongoing preparation ahead of its important Model 3   launch later this year.Image source: author.makeArticleAd();In late January
column8: Musk was not only seen meeting with the   president
column9: but he joinedyet anotherforum of executives purposed to give the president advice on   matters. This particular council was formanufacturing policy.Further
column10: after a thorough analysis
column11: the National Highway   Traffic Safety Administration decided tocloseits investigation of Autopilot's performance in an fatal crash   that occurred while the technology was activated. The auto safety   organization not only concluded there were no defects
column12: it also   said the technology is reducing crashes by about 40% -- a figure   Musk said in January he believes Tesla's recently released   second-generation Autopilot sensors can get to 90%.Finally
column13: in January
column14: Tesla continued to make key investments   ahead of its planned Model 3 launch later this year. In   particular
column15: the company revealed that its Gigafactory hasdoubled in sizesince July and is on track to begin volume production of battery   cells for Model 3 in the second quarter.Now whatGoing forward
column16: investors should keep an eye on Tesla's   timeline for its Model 3. Given the significant ramp in   production the company anticipates it will achieve with the   vehicle
column17: the lower-cost
column18: higher-volume electric vehicle is key to   Tesla's growth story. Tesla will likely provide some key insight   into the progress it's making on its Model 3 in the company's   upcomingFeb. 22 fourth-quarter earnings release.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column20: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column28: delivered Jan. 10

column1: 3 Earnings Reports Every Investor Should Watch;2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhile a whole lot of market headlines have been largely focused on trying to game the new mood in Washington
column3: the real signal behind the noise has been coming from a lot closer to Wall Street.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockEarnings season is approaching a climax and so far a lot of trading lights are flashing green for the first time in years. With over 35% of theS&P 500companies already on the books showingaround 4.6% growthback on the table for the market as a whole
column4: we know the broad strokes.This is great to see
column5: especially when you consider where we were a year ago. And while I expect the rest of earnings season to be relatively calm
column6: that doesn't mean there aren't new things the upcoming reports can tell us.In fact
column7: three companies reporting earnings over the next few weeks should give us some good insight into economies and sectors that have struggled in the past. This is why I'm so excited for whatYum China Holdings Inc(NYSE:YUMC)
column8: Mylan N.V.(NASDAQ:MYL) andTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) have to say about China
column9: biotechs and the energy sector.Yum China (YUMC) EarningsYum China's results on Tuesday will shed light on what Beijing won't tell us and what the markets around the world need to know: the health of the mainland Chinese consumer
column10: as measured by the most accurate indicator ever invented.Yum China runsmore than 7
column11: 300Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut restaurants in China - the top chains in the country - and if the number holds up sequentially
column12: it's a pretty good sign that over 1.3 billion hungry people are still snacking as much as ever.3 Big Buyout Deals That Could Crush InvestorsI'm looking for $2 billion in sales and management's take on conditions on the ground. Unless you're really in the stock as anything other than a proxy on the Chinese consumer
column13: that's the key number to watch.Mylan (MYL) EarningsMylan's earnings release on Feb. 15 is also more color than numbers. This particular company is at the center of controversy around drug pricing and healthcare regulation -remember the EpiPen?I'm looking for management to answer questions on the mood in Washington in terms of price controls and even repatriation of foreign profit. Of course if the business is booming

column15: on Feb. 22
