column1: 2 Ways to Play Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Q4 Earnings;1/26/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) investors appear to have finally put theSolarCity Corpdeal behind them. TSLA stock has rocketed more than 40% higher since early December
column3: and the shares have even broken through former resistance at $350.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockBut how long can Tesla shares keep this momentum going?The company has a major roadblock just ahead: fourth quarter earnings. Tesla has missed the consensus estimate in each of the past five reporting periods
column4: save the last quarter when the company blew past the Street's projections.For the fourth quarter
column5: Wall Street expects Tesla to post a loss of 28 cents per share
column6: up from a loss of 84 cents in the same period last year. Revenue is seen rising 27% to $2.22 billion.As with every Tesla earnings announcement
column7: TSLA stock's reaction may depend more on guidance
column8: delivery projections and news on pending and current projects than the actual figures. Traders should keep a close eye out for news on the new gigafactory and any delivery/production updates on the all-important Model 3.Turning to TSLA's sentiment backdrop
column9: we find little in the way of optimism. For instance
column10: Thomson/First Call reports that only seven of the 21 analysts following Tesla stock rate the shares a ""buy"" or better. Furthermore
column11: the 12-month consensus price-target of $240.94 represents a discount to the stock's current trading range north of $250.5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in FebruaryElsewhere
column12: short sellers are loaded for bear heading into next month's report. As of the most recent reporting period
column13: roughly 35 million shares of Tesla stock were sold short
column14: accounting for nearly 30% of the stock's total float
column15: or shares available for public trading.And if these short sellers are nervous about a potential post-earnings rally
column16: they aren't buying calls to hedge their positions. At last check

column18: with puts and calls in balance.What's more
column19: this ratio rises to 1.49 for the 10 Feb series (i.e.
column20: those options most affected by Tesla's quarterly report).Implieds are pricing in the usual post-earnings move for TSLA stock of about 6.5%-7%
column21: placing the upper bound near $269 and the lower bound at $236. The $269 region is home to Tesla's 2016 highs
column22: and a breakout here could force analysts and short sellers to capitulate. Meanwhile
column23: the lower bound lies near 10-day and 20-day trendline support.So

column25: I'm expecting a sell-on-the-news event following next month's earnings. Unless the results are stellar and/or the Model 3 is ahead of schedule
column26: expect Tesla traders to take some profits off the table
column27: resulting a pull back in the ensuing week.To take advantage of this retreat

column31: while a maximum profit of $3.54
column32: or $354 per pair of contracts

column1: Consider This All-In-One Biotech Fund With a 10% Yield (CHI);1/26/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhile the investing world continues to shovel money toward exchange-traded funds (ETFs) (full disclosure: I find myself using them more and more)
column3: it's almost as if the grandfather of the ETF
column4: the closed-end fund (CEF)
column5: has been reduced to a memory like dial phones or the Nehru jacket. But when I'm at a loss for finding value in an individual stock
column6: I often find myself looking through CEF names like a millennial at a record shop.makeAd('4'
column8: 'mktsnews'
column9: 'vanguard'
column11: '');CEFs can trace their origins back to the 1860s in Great Britain
column12: when they were primarily used to raise money to build U.S. railroads. The first American CEFs appeared in 1893
column13: 30 years prior to the first U.S. open-end mutual fund. Prior to the Crash of 1929
column14: American CEFs claimed over $4 billion in assets
column15: which was big money for the time.CEFs have evolved over the decades since
column16: but their organization and basic features have remained relatively consistent. CEFs are and always have been professionally and actively managed
column17: exchange-traded
column18: internally leveraged
column19: and income oriented.Recently
column20: while screening a handful of CEFs
column21: one piqued my interest:Calamos Convertible & Hi Income Fund(CHI).As the name suggests
column22: most of the fund's heavy lifting is done through the use of convertible bonds
column23: which are what is known as a hybrid security. Each bond is convertible to a pre-determined number of shares of the issuer's common stock. This gives an investor two things: an income stream and participation in the movement of the company's stock. Often
column24: convertible bonds are issued by high-growth companies whose common stock does not pay a dividend.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The Experts' PicksThe fact that the fund is managed by Calamos Investments was the attention grabber. Founded in 1977 by John Calamos
column25: Sr.
column26: the firm became one of the investing world's premier convertible bond managers. I had the pleasure of meeting Mr. Calamos at a conference a few years back.Knowing the fund was managed by a true authority
column27: I looked under the hood. 37.9% of the fund
column28: naturally
column29: is made up of convertible bonds while 16.4% is convertible preferred stocks.But what really excited me was the sector allocation.Over 35% of the fund is weighted across information technology and healthcare
column30: represented by disrupters such asTesla Motors Inc(TSLA) andPriceline Group Inc(PCLN).Indeed 19.2% covers the consumer discretionary sector with another 20.3% allocated to financials
column31: energy
column32: industrials and utilities. The fund is noticeably underweight in telecom
column33: materials
column34: real estate
column35: and consumer staples.Debuting in June of 2002 as the bear market of the same year approached its bottom
column36: CHI sports assets of over $1 billion with total internal expenses of 1.25% which is high if you're comparing to a Vanguard index fund. But keep in mind
column37: Vanguard index funds don't have dividend yields approaching 11%.Risks To Consider:Like many CEFs
column38: CHY uses leverage to juice up yields and returns. Currently
column39: the fund's leverage percentage is at 28.57% which isn't too terribly out of whack. However
column40: portfolio leverage is like being lent an umbrella when it's not raining. When the raindrops fall
column41: the lender typically wants it back. Therefore
column42: rising rates are probably the biggest external risk facing the fund. This would create volatility in both the fund's lower coupon holdings and leverage position. But with the link between convertible bonds and equity markets
column43: rising stocks should help offset this risk.7 Cheap Stocks to Buy That Could Double in 2017Action To Take:The unique complexion of CHI offers conservative
column44: income-oriented investors a unique opportunity to gain exposure to the growthiest of growth stocks in a risk-managed package with above-average income. Currently CHI shares trade at around $10.50
column45: which is a 3.5% discount to their net asset value (NAV)
column46: with a 10.85% dividend yield that is paid monthly.Editor's Note:Since 1926
column47: one collection of stockshas accounted for HALF of the S&P's return - through every market environment imaginable. If you don't have this group in your own portfolio
column48: you could be missing out on the single best place to put your money this year and next.Learn which stocks canStreetAuthority's mission is to help individual investors earn above-average profits by providing a source of independent
column49: unbiased - and most of all
column50: profitable - investing ideas. Unlike traditional publishers
column51: StreetAuthority doesn't simply regurgitate the latest stock market news. Instead
column52: we provide in-depth research
column53: plus specific investment ideas and immediate action to take based on the latest market events. Visit us atStreetAuthority.com.More From InvestorPlace10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You BackThe 7 Best High-Yield Investments for RetirementThe postConsider This All-In-One Biotech Fund With a 10% Yield (CHI)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 Reasons Trump Should Worry IoT Investors;1/26/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.President Trump had his fair share ofverbal scuffles with technology companiesduring his election campaign. But now that's he's the president
column2: his stance on federal funding for new technologies
column3: tax credits
column4: and his push for more American manufacturing could have   ramifications for many companies
column5: including publicly traded ones   betting on the Internet of Things (IoT).A few months ago
column6: BI Intelligencepublished some forecastson how Trump's presidency was likely to affect the growth of   the Internet of Things and the companies behind it; now that   the inauguration is over
column7: it's worth giving this information a   good look over.makeArticleAd();Here's what could change:Funding for smart city projects could dry upIn fiscal 2015
column8: the federal government spent $8.8 billion on   IoT projects
column9: and from fiscal 2011 through 2015
column10: it spent a total   of $35 billion for IoT infrastructure
column11: software
column12: and   cybersecurity. One project involved an investment in smart cities   that allowedAT&T(NYSE: T)  bring IoT connectivity to 10 cities across the   U.S. for lighting
column13: transportation
column14: parking
column15: and safety   features.But the BI Intelligence report noted that smart city   projects will likely ""stall or be abandoned due to a lack of   federal support from a Trump administration."" That's because   Trump plans for taxes would reduce federal revenues by $9.5   trillion over 10 years
column16: leading to a major spike in the national   debt and leaving funding scarce for such high-tech infrastructure   investments. They further note that given Republicans' refusal to   acknowledge climate change
column17: programs that subsidize   energy-efficient or green technology projects -- many of which   have IoT aspects -- are likely to have their funding cut or   canceled outright.That's important not just for AT&T and its smart city   projects
column18: but also for broader American IoT innovations. I've   written before thatChina is leading the way in the IoTbecause its government has committed to spending lots of   money to help companies develop new technologies. If the Trump   administration backs away from IoT investments
column19: expect China's   lead on the U.S. to widen even further.Self-driving car innovations could slowIf you're thinking that Trump couldn't possibly have influence   over the autonomous car revolution
column20: consider that   electric-vehicle makerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) has released some of themost advanced semi-autonomous hardwareand software to date.Many of Tesla's vehicles are purchased with the help of   federal tax credits
column21: but under Trump -- who does not have a   particularly fond view of environmental policies -- green energy   tax incentives could be reduced or eliminated.Tax credits of this type have pushed down the cost of current   plug-in electric cars like the Model S
column22: and could help reduce the   cost of the cheaper
column23: upcoming Model 3. New versions of the Model   S and the upcoming Model 3 will have a full suite of self-driving   hardware built into them
column24: but if that green tax credit   disappears
column25: as an analyst from AutoPacificbelieves it could
column26: then the higher prices could significantly slow the sales   growth of Teslas specifically
column27: and impede the spread of   driverless car technology in general.Automation might be less desirableA big part of the IoT involves companies using an internet   connection and sensors to automate systems and analyze data. In   the manufacturing sector
column28: General Electric(NYSE: GE)  uses internet-connected machinery and software   to increase plant efficiency
column29: both in its own factories and in   those of other companies.In huge plants
column30: keeping track of all the physical parts used   to manufacture a product can be tricky. So instead of keeping the   chaotic and cost-prohibitive old systems (where people would run   around a plant trying to track down parts) GE created its Work in   Process Manager -- powered by its Predix software -- that   automatically tracks manufacturing. The company says that the   system allows supervisors to ""immediately know where any parts or   components are in the plant.""Trump wants to increase the number of manufacturing jobs in   the U.S. which isn't a bad thing. But that could lead to him   attempting to put pressure on manufacturing companies to keep   people employed in jobs that could instead be automated with IoT   tech like GE has developed. If companies fear that using IoT   systems to become more efficient will put them in conflict with   the administration
column31: expect to see some businesses submit
column32: even if   it means their expenses are higher than they would have been by   adopting the newest technology.Of course
column33: there's no guarantee that Trump will cut green tax   credits
column34: reduce federal funding for new smart city projects
column35: or   put any federal pressure on companies that will impair   manufacturing innovations. But he has certainly indicated that   he's willing to push hard against companies when he doesn't agree   with what they're doing -- and that means IoT investments could   certainly be at risk.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column36: it can pay to listen. After all
column37: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column38: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column39: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla Motors wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Why BMW and Nissan are Building Electric-Car Recharging Stations in the U.S.;1/25/2017;"BMW AG(NASDAQOTH: BAMXF) andNissan Motors(NASDAQOTH: NSANY) announced that through their joint efforts
column2: a   slew of new electric-vehicle fast-charging stations have recently   been installed across 33 U.S. states -- and there are more to   come.What BMW and Nissan said about the new charging stationsThe two automakers have beenworking together since late 2015to build recharging stations in the U.S. In this latest push
column3: the   two worked with EVgo
column4: the largest U.S. public network of ""DC   Fast"" recharging stations
column5: to add 174 new locations in 33 states.   The stations give EVgo a total of 668 fast-charging stations   right now -- with 50 more
column6: supported by the BMW-Nissan   partnership
column7: set to be added during 2017.makeArticleAd();A BMW i3 and a Nissan Leaf at a DC Fast charging station.   Image source: BMW AG.The stations are 50-kilowatt dual-port DC Fast chargers with   connectors to support both the CHAdeMO (used by Nissan) and SAE   Combo (or ""CCS
column8: used by BMW) charging standards
column9: Between the two   standards
column10: any electric vehicle equipped with quick-charge ports   can recharge at these stations.They're fairly fast
column11: too: The stations can charge a Nissan   Leaf or BMW i3 up to about 80 percent in roughly 25 to 30   minutes. That's significantly faster than the Level 2 (240-volt)   chargers that are most commonly available at U.S. public charging   stations.Both companies say they're committed to building a strong   network of public charging stations in the U.S. as part of a   larger effort to encourage Americans to choose electric   vehicles.""BMW's continuing collaborations with Nissan and EVgo
column12: further   demonstrate the company's commitment to building a robust public   charging infrastructure across the country. We recognized early   on that meaningful partnerships like this would be essential in   order to support the expansion of convenient and accessible   electric vehicle charging options
column13: said Robert Healey
column14: head of   EV Infrastructure for BMW of North America. ""The expansion of the   plug-in vehicle charging infrastructure will give more U.S.   drivers the confidence to choose an electric vehicle
column15: such as the   BMW i3
column16: as longer distance EV travel becomes increasingly   commonplace.""""Nissan continues as a leader in building accessible   infrastructure to benefit Nissan LEAF drivers as well as all EV   owners. Infrastructure for all is a key strategic priority for us   as we continue expanding the network of dual-port quick chargers   across the country
column17: said JeSean Hopkins
column18: Senior Manager
column19: Nissan   EV Infrastructure Strategy and Business Development. ""We look   forward to ongoing teamwork and the continued build-out of public   quick-charge stations.""What it means: Small steps toward an electrified automotive   futureSlowly but surely
column20: America is acquiring some electric-car   recharging infrastructure beyondTesla Motors'(NASDAQ: TSLA) Supercharger network.These 50-kW chargers aren't quite in the same league as   Tesla's Superchargers
column21: which can deliver up to 120 kilowatts and   add 170 miles of range to a Tesla in about 30 minutes. But   at least as of right now
column22: Superchargers only work with Teslas.   And as noted above
column23: these new DC Fast chargers are a significant   step ahead of the most common public chargers available in the   U.S. now. That's important: Wide availability of reasonably fast   chargers will be key to convincing mainstream auto customers to   make the leap to fully electric vehicles.The stations only work at full power with electric vehicles   that have DC fast-charging capability built in. But most new   electric vehicles can be ordered with that capability. It's   standard on 2017 models ofFord's(NYSE: F) Focus Electric and available as an option onGeneral Motors'(NYSE: GM) Chevrolet Bolt.BMW and Nissan are funding these charging stations to help   support sales of their own electric vehicles first and foremost
column24: of course. But the network will help rival automakers sell their   electric vehicles as well -- and that in turn should help   convince all automakers to make larger commitments to electric   vehicles.Long story short: BMW and Nissan are taking some small but   important steps to help lead Americans -- and other automakers --   toward electric vehicles.10 stocks we like better than BMW AGWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column25: it can pay to listen. After all
column26: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column27: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column28: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and BMW wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column29: 2017John Rosevearowns shares of Ford and General Motors. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Ford and Tesla Motors. The Motley Fool     recommends BMW and General Motors. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Better Self-Driving Car Stock: Intel Corporation vs. NVIDIA Corporation;1/25/2017;"Right now
column2: one of the hottest trends in the semiconductor   industry is the emerging market for autonomous vehicles. It is   generally accepted that to do proper autonomous vehicles
column3: a lot   of computing power is going to be needed inside of the cars to   give them the required ""intelligence.""Image source: NVIDIA.makeArticleAd();Two companies that have made public their intentions to   aggressively pursue the market for the ""brains"" inside of   self-driving cars are microprocessor giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) and graphics specialistNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) .Both companies have announced major partnerships and deals   with automotive makers and suppliers. Intel
column4: for instance
column5: announced last year that it would be collaborating withMobileye(NYSE: MBLY) and Delphi Automotive to build platforms for use by   automotive manufacturers.Intel hasalso saidthat
column7: it booked self-driving car deals collectively   worth more than $1 billion in lifetime revenue.Last year
column8: NVIDIA and Audi announced that they would
column9: together
column10: try to bring self-driving cars to market by 2020.   NVIDIA's components are also found inside ofTesla Motors'(NASDAQ: TSLA) new vehicles
column11: as well.So
column12: both NVIDIA and Intel both look well-positioned to   capitalize on a potential self-driving car boom. Which stock is   the better way to play it?These are adjacent businesses for bothIt's important to understand that self-driving car platforms   aren't either of these companies' core revenue drivers today --   they're adjacent businesses. Intel's core business is   microprocessors and related components for personal computers and   data centers
column13: and NVIDIA's core businesses are graphics   processors designed for gaming
column14: workstations
column15: and data   centers.An Intel chip designed specifically for automotive use. Image   source: Intel.For Intel
column16: autonomous vehicles are just one (potentially   significant) part of the company's Internet of Things business   (though the company did recently announce that it'd be forming an   autonomous driving group within its Internet of Things group).   NVIDIA specifically calls out automotive as a key long-term   growth segment.The reason that both companies look well-positioned to play in   the self-driving car market is because the technology that   they've developed for other markets (high-performance computing   technologies) look to be applicable to self-driving cars.   However
column17: there is additional technical and sales/marketing work   required to succeed in self-driving cars
column18: and both companies   appear to be making the required incremental investments to   capitalize on these opportunities.Automotive could be a bigger deal for NVIDIA than for   IntelHere's the thing: Both NVIDIA and Intel have an opportunity to   make some real money from the self-driving market. Furthermore
column19: the market for significant computing capabilities inside of   self-driving cars could be quite substantial
column20: especially if many   (if not most) cars over the long term are endowed with such   computing capabilities.However
column21: I think that the self-driving car market could be   much more interesting for NVIDIA than for Intel by Intel's sheer   size relative to NVIDIA.If Intel manages to grow its Internet of Things business from   about $3 billion in annual revenue to $5 billion in annual   revenue
column22: then that'd certainly benice
column23: but not agame changerfor Intel
column24: which is expected to have generated more than $58   billion in revenue during 2016.However
column25: if NVIDIA -- which has generated about $6.1 billion   in revenue over the last 12 months -- generates an incremental $2   billion in automotive-related revenue from self-driving cars over   time
column26: then that's not only going to significantly boost the   company's top line
column27: but its bottom line as well.Answering the titular questionAlthough I wouldn't recommend buying either Intel or NVIDIAsolelybased on the potential for self-driving cars (these are complex   businesses that generate most of their revenue from outside of   the automotive market to begin with)
column28: NVIDIA's business does   appear to be more likely to benefit from growth in self-driving   cars than Intel's because it's a smaller one to begin with.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Is Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Ending the Age of Intel (INTC)?;1/25/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFor decades
column3: Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) was at the heart of the technology industry. As the company whose CPUs dominated the PC era
column4: it was second to none. But Intel missed out on the mobile revolution and with PCs losing relevance every year
column5: its leadership position has weakened. Nudging itself into Intel's place?NvidiaCorporation(NASDAQ:NVDA).makeArticleAd();Click to EnlargeSource: NVIDIANvidia started as a PC graphics card manufacturer
column6: but now
column7: NVDA stock is riding a wave of virtual reality gaming
column8: artificial intelligence
column9: deep data analysis
column10: cloud computing and self-driving cars.As its GPU-accelerated products take over processor-intensive computing
column11: is Nvidia set to dethrone Intel?GPUs Make the Leap From Graphics to Raw Processing PowerIn the old days of computing
column12: graphics processing units (GPUs) played second fiddle to central processing units (CPUs).Intel's processors were literally at the heart of almost every computer sold. The CPU was responsible for running the computer
column13: including its operating system. When a GPU was installed
column14: the CPU was still primary
column15: but it farmed off graphics-intensive tasks to the GPU. Most PCs used integrated graphics that were built into their Intel CPU. Graphics cards from companies like Nvidia - with a standalone GPU - were primarily used in specialized gaming PCs.It helps to think of the CPU as a generalist
column16: while the GPU does one thing over and over. This difference began really turning to the advantage of NVDA about a decade ago.10 Companies That Are Bringing Jobs Back to AmericaDesktop PC CPUs from Intel might have four cores
column17: letting the CPU manage a handful of different tasks simultaneously. GPUs were equipped with hundreds of cores
column18: and software developers realized they could take advantage of this raw parallel processing power for much more than just graphics. The GPU could be used to greatly accelerate software performance when repetitive tasks are being performed - encoding video
column19: for example
column20: or data analysis.GPU acceleration can make some tasks 100 times fasterthan a CPU alone.Because the GPU is designed for one primary purpose - everything including computer graphics boils down to crunching numbers - NVDA is able to produce them at far lower cost than a CPU at an equivalent performance level
column21: while producing less heat and using less power.Why GPUs Are in Higher Demand Than CPUsWhy the demand for GPUs?Think of how the demand for processor-intensive computing power has increased over the past decade. One early example was Bitcoin. The virtual currency could be purchased
column22: but it could also be ""mined"" by using a PC to run a complex algorithm in search of Bitcoins. Miners soon discovered that a GPU - with its parallel number-crunching capability - was far more effective than a CPU at mining Bitcoins.Anywhere from 50 to 100 times faster. Soon miners were running rigs consisting of multiple GPUs connected together.Meantime
column23: GPUs have rapidly become more powerful
column24: with more cores and faster clock rates
column25: even as CPU development has become relatively incremental.Intel's new seventh-generation Kaby Lake Core i7 CPU for desktop computers still has four cores. In comparison
column26: Nvidia's latestTitan X graphics cardhas 3
column27: 584 processing cores on tap. The Intel CPU costs less than a third of the Titan X's $1200 MSRP
column28: but when used in number-crunching applications
column29: the Nvidia card's price is a steal.The technology that has the big potential for future growth involvesextremenumber crunching. Think virtual reality
column30: the hottest trend in gaming. Cloud services - which are often a single
column31: processor-intensive task like image recognition offloaded to the web. Artificial intelligence
column32: machine learning
column33: data mining and deep data - these all require incredible processing power. Computers running INTC CPUs are too expensive and too general purpose to be running these tasks. Instead
column34: you're more likely to find server farms powered by GPUs.NVDA has also integrated its powerful GPUs into the forefront of one of the technology holy grails: self-driving cars.Nvidia Drive PX2is the company's AI car computing platform. With two GPUs providing the horsepower
column35: NVDA says it is capable of 34 trillion deep learning operations per second. Additional units can be run in parallel for fully autonomous driving. Nvidia has alreadypartnered with multiple high-profile automakersto equip their self-driving cars with its technology
column36: includingBMW
column37: VolvoandTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA)Growing Importance of the GPU Reflected in NVDA StockYou can track the relative trajectories in INTC and NVDA by comparing their stock prices. Over the past five years
column38: Intel has grown in value by a little more than 40%. That's not bad
column39: but doesn't look quite so good when you compare it to the height of PC popularity. Since 2000
column40: when PC sales were notching14.5% annual sales growth
column41: Intel stock has actually dropped by 10%.3 Internet of Things (IoT) Stocks to Buy Now (NVDA
column42: ISIL
column43: STM)In comparison
column44: Nvidia stock is up by a whopping 650% in the past five years
column45: and nearly 2
column46: 600% since 2000.Intel Isn't Going Anywhere
column47: But the Age of NVIDIA Has ArrivedComputer sales continue their slow slide
column48: down another 5.7% in 2016. Much of Intel's revenue is tied to the PC market. Nvidia is not immune to the effect of declining PC sales
column49: either.But while INTC is trying to tie its future to technology like the Internet of Things (which is struggling with security issues and competing standards)
column50: NVDA has leveraged the massive parallel processing power of its GPUs to be a leader in multiple cutting-edge areas like AI
column51: deep data
column52: virtual reality and autonomous vehicles.Increasingly
column53: it's looking like we're entering the age of Nvidia. NVDA stock reflects that reality.As of this writing
column54: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Stocks to Buy to Survive a ""Trumpsy-Turvy"" 20173 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in 201710 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsThe postIs Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Ending the Age of Intel (INTC)?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: How to Think About the Race to Self-Driving Cars;1/24/2017;"Alphabet's Waymo is one of several companies inside and   outside of the traditional auto industry working to bring a   self-driving solution to market. Image source: Fiat Chrysler   Automobiles.Who will win the ""race"" to a self-driving car?makeArticleAd();That's a question that lots of investors seem to be asking.   It's not hard to understand why: Self-driving cars could   transform the way many of us get around
column2: and transformative new   technologies tend to offer big profit opportunities for those who   are able to see them coming.Recently
column3: a Foolish colleague asked me to come up with some   sort of metric that might help us judge the likely ""winners"" in   the race to self-driving cars
column4: at least among the automakers. But   after some thought
column5: I decided that it's not so simple -- and that   the idea of ""winners"" might not be the right way to think about   things when it comes to self-driving technology
column6: at least in the   near term.Why it's hard to tell who is in the best position to profit   bigLots of companies in
column7: around
column8: and outside of the traditional   auto industry are working on autonomous vehicle (AV) or   ""self-driving"" technology. Some
column9: likeTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) are somewhat open about where they are in the   development process and when they hope to have something on the   market.But others aren't. Among established automakers and their   suppliers
column10: details of upcoming new products and technologies have   traditionally been held very tightly
column11: kept secret until a few   months before launch.Take the example ofGeneral Motors(NYSE: GM)
column12: which is probably among the leaders in developing AV   technology. We know that GMacquired self-driving start-up Cruise   Automationlast year and that the new electric Chevrolet Bolt is its   ""platform"" (GM's word) fortesting AV technology.A prototype self-driving Chevrolet Bolt undergoing testing   near GM's technical center in Warren
column13: Michigan. Image source:   General Motors.We also know that GM has been working on a   not-quite-autonomous system called ""Super Cruise"" that is   comparable to Tesla's Autopilot
column14: and that Super Cruise has been   expected to debut as an option on a Cadillac sometime this year   (althoughthat's not certain).But we don't know when GM will bring so-called Level 4 AV   technology
column15: a system that can provide full autonomy under some   (but not all) circumstances
column16: to market -- or how widely GM will   roll it out
column17: or evenhowit will roll out. Will it be an option on luxury Cadillacs
column18: a   self-driving Bolt built specifically for ride-hailing duty
column19: or   something else entirely? (Level 5 systems that can drive anywhere   a human driver could are thought to be much further off.)The same goes for most of the other automakers: We don't know   exactly where their technology is
column20: how much they're spending
column21: or   when (or how) they intend to bring it to market. Will they use an   off-the-shelf system provided by traditional industry suppliers
column22: or will they develop a customized
column23: more deeply integrated   solution in-house (as GM appears to be doing)?And we certainly can't tell right now how the different   systems under development are likely to stack up -- or how the   market will receive them.We can make some broad guesses as to when Level 4 technology   will come to market
column24: and as to who islikelyto be among the first to bring it to market. But as you'll see
column25: that's not necessarily helpful to us as investors: It's likely   that Level 4 technology will be a commodity not long after the   first Level 4 vehicle comes to market.Why self-driving technology will quickly become a   commodityHere's the thing that many investors seem to miss: It looks   very likely the entire incumbent auto industry will have access   to Level 4 technology before long. Giant auto supplierDelphi(NYSE: DLPH)
column26: assisted-driving specialistMobileye(NYSE: MBLY)
column27: and chip giantIntelare working together on a Level 4 system that they promise   will be available to any automaker that wants it by the end of   2019.It will probably be another year or more after that date   before the first new cars with those systems go into production.   But at some point
column28: likely by 2021 or so
column29: Level 4 technology will   be a commodity: Several other companies are known to have rival   systems under development.That doesn't mean that all new cars will offer self-driving   capabilities by 2021. The systems will probably be still   expensive enough that they'll only make sense for luxury cars and   commercial vehicles (which might include vehicles built for   ride-hailing services).Winter weather poses special challenges for self-driving   systems. Image source: Ford Motor Company.They'll also be geographically limited
column30: and they may   be limited by road conditions (think snow and ice) as well.   But the maps will expand quickly
column31: capabilities will improve as   more cars rack up miles (and data)
column32: and the prices of the   systems' sensors and other components will drop as more are made.   Assuming that it follows the pattern set by many other new   automotive technologies over the years
column33: Level 4 systems will   gradually become more widely available as costs drop.Long story short: Level 4 technology will probably be offered   on most new vehicles in the U.S. within a decade -- and   established auto-industry suppliers will be in a position to   supply it.Why it doesn't make sense to think in terms of ""winners""   yet""So what if
column34: I asked my Foolish colleague
column35: ""Tesla brings   a Level 4 system to market in 2019 -- but then by 2021 or so
column36: any   automaker can buy its roughly comparable technology off the shelf   from existing industry suppliers? Does Tesla 'win'?""I think in such a scenario
column37: Tesla would certainly win bragging   rights. That's not nothing: Bragging rights on new technology add   value to Tesla's brand in a way that they might not for a big   automaker.But Tesla is only likely to be able to make 500
column38: 000 or so cars   a year in 2019 and 2020
column39: and that's if all goes well with itsupcoming Model 3. That's not anywhere near enough to dominate the global auto   market -- it's not really even enough to dominate the luxury-car   market in the U.S.
column40: Europe
column41: and China. (And if the Model 3 is   anywhere near as good as Tesla fans expect
column42: Tesla will be selling   all it can make anyway -- with or without a Level 4 system   available.)And of course the Delphi-Mobileye-Intel system will probably   have other competition by 2021
column43: so we can't quite declare that   group to be the likely ""winner"" either
column44: at least not yet.So where does this leave us as investors?Good question. It's one that I've been struggling to answer   for a while.Right now
column45: the closest thing to a ""pure play"" investment in   autonomous driving (among public companies
column46: at least) is probably   Mobileye. Mobileye is a profitable business with an enviable   client list (nearly all of the world's automakers do business   with Mobileye)
column47: But it's currently trading at over 100 times   earnings
column48: and it's not clear that it will have the earnings   growth it will need to reward investors who buy at this   valuation.Meanwhile
column49: an investment in a company like Delphi or GM -- orAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) and its Waymo self-driving unit --   is far from a ""pure play."" Sure
column50: AV technology could turn out to   be a profitable business for any
column51: but it's not likely to be   transformative (at least
column52: not in a good way) for any of them. But   that said
column53: it's possible (likely
column54: really) that some companies   will come up with ways to differentiate their offerings that   allow them to win more market share or profit.Here at the Fool
column55: we're encouraged to give our readers an   ""actionable takeaway
column56: an investment idea to research or a   thought that could help you become a better investor. When it   comes to self-driving technology
column57: my takeaway for you is this:   There are no obvious winners now
column58: but there might be once we see   how the technology is coming to market.10 stocks we like better than AlphabetWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column59: it can pay to listen. After all
column60: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column62: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Alphabet wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: 5 U.S.-Focused Stocks to Buy for the Trump Era;1/24/2017;"On Friday
column2: Donald J. Trump was sworn in as the 45th president of the U.S.
column3: an event which evoked strong reactions from both the country and the world. Promising to put ""America First
column4: the president pledged to put an end to what he termed as the ""American carnage"" of rusted factories across the countries. Among his first actions on assuming office was a formal withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific trade Partnership.This is a clear indication that the President does
column5: in fact
column6: intend on following through on many of his campaign promises even at the cost of causing great alarm to the world at large. At this point
column7: it does make good sense to invest in domestic focused U.S. stocks which may be ideally suited to combat any volatility investors may encounter in the days ahead.Exiting the Trans-Pacific PartnershipAlmost immediately
column8: the President has set about fulfilling his agenda. On Monday
column9: Trump enacted the formal withdrawal of the U.S. from the Trans-Pacific Partnership. This was one of his key campaign promises and could create friction between the U.S. and its Asian allies. Trump has said that he wants to promote U.S. manufacturing and will now seek to conclude one to one trade deals which could be ended within a short period if necessary.This is in keeping with a feeling among several U.S. citizens that trade deals of this nature have had a detrimental effect on the U.S. job market. Trump also met with U.S. industry heavyweights at the White House on Monday
column10: promising to implement measures which will benefit domestic production and business.At the same time
column11: he warned that companies moving production abroad would have to face heavy penalties. Trump talked about enforcing a stiff border tax on products which come in from other countries.Encouraging Domestic IndustryTrump also told the gathering of CEOs
column12: which included the chief executives of FordFand TeslaTSLAthat he intends to reduce U.S. corporate taxes to within 15%-20%. This is a major cut considering that the current tax level is at 35%. Additionally
column13: such a move would require the assent of the U.S. Congress
column14: which of course is currently Republican dominated.Meanwhile
column15: business leaders emphasized that the need to reduce regulations was even more important in their view. Speaking to the gathering
column16: Trump said that he believed that regulations could be reduced by 75% or more.Previously
column17: Trump has said he is in favor of beefing up public spending by hundreds of billions of dollars on infrastructure. In fact
column18: he has proposed $1 trillion infrastructure spending financed by new tax credits to goad private equity investors. Increased outlays will be aimed at improving roads
column19: bridges and telecommunications. (Read:Welcome Trump Era with These ETFs)Our ChoicesPresident Trump has promised to bring jobs back to America
column20: in particular those related to manufacturing. However
column21: this may not be an easy process and certainly not a quick one. What is certain is that he has put the focus squarely back on economic activity within the country. In such an event it would a good idea to invest in sectors which are intrinsically linked to the domestic sector.In this case

column23: healthcare

column1: CVX Stock: How to Trade Chevron Corporation Q4 Earnings;1/24/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEnergy giant andDow Jones Industrial AverageconstituentChevron Corporation(NYSE:CVX) reports earnings Friday morning. In the days leading up to the event
column3: traders and investors alike are both asking themselves whether Chevron will trump fourth-quarter earnings expectations
column4: or whether the corporate confessional will cause a spill in CVX stock.Source:swong95765 via Flickr (Modified)Let's take a look at recent announcements for Chevron
column5: analyze the CVX stock chart and determine what (if anything) the options market is suggesting will come Friday.makeArticleAd();Then
column6: we'll set up a trade to help you capture profits from the announcement.Chevron Earnings Picture and Analyst   SentimentAhead of Chevron's Friday morning Q4 earnings release
column7: analysts are forecasting profits of 66 cents per share. Actual estimates encompass a very wide range from 35 cents to $1.15.The mean Street expectation implies a whopping 154% earnings growth year-over-year
column8: as Chevron reported a mere 26 cents in profit in 2016. That result came up short of views by more than 50%. We're not holding our breath
column9: but if Wall Street is on the money this time
column10: the 66-cent profit would represent a sequential decline of 8.3% from Q3
column11: which surprised by 31.5% to the upside.Revenues are estimated to grow by 26% to $36.7 billion compared to 2015's sales of $29.2 billion. Here too
column12: range views are volatile
column13: with a low forecast of $27.2 billion compared to a Street high of $62 billion. Sequentially
column14: CVX's revenues are forecast to jump by 22%.10 Stocks to Buy to Survive a ""Trumpsy-Turvy""     2017The Wall Street community is split on Chevron stock. Eighteen rate the stock a buy
column15: while 10 maintain hold ratings. Price targets on CVX range from a low of $95 to $145 with a median estimate of $125.50 over the year.CVX Stock Short-Term Trading RecordIf it isn't obvious yet
column16: Chevron has established a mixed record compared to actual Street profit views. Over the past couple years
column17: CVX has beaten forecasts 58% of the time
column18: while missing 42%.Investor reaction has proven a bit more consistent
column19: with gains in four of the past six announcements immediately following earnings.Working backwards

column2: Inc.: Expect Major Improvements Every 12 to 18 Months;1/23/2017;"Tesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) CEO Elon Musk took toTwitterthis weekend with a range of updates and commentary about the   electric-car maker's products. But perhaps the most telling of   all was a glimpse into how the company thinks about releasing   major updates for its vehicles. Here's a window into Tesla's   approach to product innovation.Image source: The Motley Fool.makeArticleAd();Frequent updatesWhen asked on Twitter whether the company would allow owners   to pay for a retrofit of their first-generation Autopilot   hardware to Tesla's October-launched improved new sensors for   Autopilot
column3: Musk said this won't be happening.""Unfortunately
column4: that would require stripping down the entire   car and replacing 300+ parts
column5: Musk explained. ""Wish there was an   easy way.""Going further
column6: Musk said anyone buying a Tesla shouldn't   expect their vehicle to keep up with future innovation in the   company's cars.""Tesla will never stop innovating
column7: Musk explained. ""People   are buying the wrong car if they expect this. There will be major   revs every 12 to 18 months.""Customer requests for retrofits are a part of an old narrative   from Tesla owners. The first major updates for the company's   vehicles came in October 2014
column8: when the electric-car maker   announced dual-motor all-wheel drive and the first Autopilot   hardware for its vehicles. This update introduced important   driver-assist safety features such as automatic emergency braking   and collision avoidance
column9: as well as convenience driver-assist   features like automatic steering and parking
column10: adaptive cruise   control

column12: and automatic parking. Furthermore

column15: after further software validation and regulatory   approval
column16: according to the company. In addition
column17: in January Tesla   began offering a new version of Model S with 20 miles of   additional range than its previous highest-range model
column18: helping   the sedan achieve a maximum driving range of 335 miles on a   single charge.For someone looking to buy the highest-range Model S

column20: of course

column28: however the 100D offers 20 more miles of range than the     P100D despite the lower price point. The same story can be told     for the Model X. A Model X 100D costs $37
column29: 000 less than     the P100D version and offers 6 more miles of range.Image source: The Motley Fool.Innovation is Tesla's priorityIn short
column30: Tesla doesn't expect its current vehicles' hardware   to keep up with new vehicles for very long. Even if that means   updating its vehicles within the same model year
column31: Tesla intends   to deliver major revisions as fast as possible. While Tesla will   continue to deliver big software updates for vehicles it has   already delivered
column32: the company won't be expending energy on   updating old hardware.Musk summed up this philosophy in a tweet this weekend: ""If we   applied resources to doing super complex retrofits
column33: our pace of   innovation would drop dramatically.""This fast pace of innovation is particularly important for   Tesla. While the company's annualized 100

column1: Here's Why Tesla Needs To Be Cautious In China;1/20/2017;"Recently
column2: Tesla Motors (TSLA)announcedthat its new car owners in China will no longer enjoy free supercharging for the life of the vehicle. This is in line with its global policy and does not impact existing owners who ordered their cars before January 15th. However
column3: consumers in China are critical of this policy and have started doubting Tesla's other promises. The company faces tough competition in the region with local companies building cheaper electric vehicles. AChinese start up NextEValready claims to have built the world's fastest electric vehicle
column4: which is likely to be cheaper than Tesla's Model 3.  The Chinese branded electric-vehicles market is supported by huge government subsidies as China looks to build global leadership in clean energy. The Chinese government has a target of5 millionelectric vehicles to ply on the country's roads by 2020 and is subsidizing local players to achieve large scale production. However
column5: these local vehicles do not offer the luxury and long range of Tesla and are likely to gain market share on their lower costs. With China on track to become the largest electric vehicles market in the world
column6: several players are looking to enter this market with a wide range of offerings creating a stiff competitive environment for Tesla. Audi announced recently that it would introduce five new electric vehicles in the country over the next five years. General Motors' Chinese joint venture is investing $ 3.8 billion in electrification and developing 10 'new energy' models by 2020. And the Indian company Mahindra is looking for a joint venture in China to manufacture and sell electric vehicles in the region.See our full analysis for Tesla MotorsChinese customers are not ""automatic"" fans of Tesla and might look for other luxury and value-based electric alternatives. Tesla's change in this life-of-car charging policy is likely to impact value-seeking customers more
column7: given that they are price sensitive to begin with. Tesla's Model X
column8: which is its ""mass scale"" electric vehicle
column9: is more likely to be impacted by the change in its ""free charging for a life time"" policy and wider availability of other cheaper brands. Tesla's charging rate is a ""guide"" rate which can be increased in future. Any increase in this rate can irk Chinese customers since they are averse to price increases.makeArticleAd();So far
column10: Tesla has had a good innings in China. Its Model 3 reservations in China were higher than any other country in the world
column11: other than the U.S.  and the company is considering construction of an assembly factory in the region. While this is a strong indicator of the company's growth potential in the region
column12: it needs to tread carefully in China. Players across the globe are looking to capture the Chinese EV (i.e.
column13: electric vehicle) market and competition especially for the low priced Model 3 is likely to get tougher. According to our estimates
column14: Tesla's Model 3 (Gen III) is the most important segment of its business accounting for nearly 50% of its valuation. We expect Gen III to capture a 20% market share in the global EV market by the end of our forecast period.While the electric vehicles market is still at a nascent stage
column15: China is the most important region for players in this segment. With government subsidies and high demand for EVs
column16: several players are looking to establish themselves in the region. Tesla is likely to be a key player in this market with its luxury offerings
column17: long range and wide network of supercharging stations. However the company needs to be cautious of the Chinese sentiment as it looks to grow further in the region.Understand How a Company's Products Impact its Stock   Price at TrefisView Interactive Institutional Research (Powered by Trefis):Global Large Cap|U.S. Mid & Small Cap|European Large & Mid CapMore Trefis   Research"

column1: Donald Trump Inauguration: Stocks To Buy
column2: Sell For The Next Four Years;1/20/2017;"Donald Trump (Shutterstock photo)Donald Trump has been sworn in as the 45th president of the United States. The President-elect
column3: who pledged to Make America great again
column4: promised plenty of things he would do regarding his first day in office. From repealing and replacing Obamacare to renegotiating NAFTA and beginning the construction of the wall on the Mexican border.We wont know for certain which of Trumps policies will take priority or how they will be enforced. But what we do know is that for Trump to make good on his promises to bring back jobs
column5: grow GDP and strengthen industry
column6: he needs businesses to lead
column7: innovate and hire workers. For that to happen
column8: businesses leaders need to know their government is on their side. To that end
column9: here are some names to own for the next four years (at least) as Trumps policies take shape.makeArticleAd();Lower Corporate TaxesTrumps promise to lower corporate taxes can have a boosting effect on the tech sector
column10: which has an estimated $1.4 trillion stashed in overseas tax havens. These include some America's largest corporations such as Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT)
column11: which could face a huge tax hit if they bring that cash home. Not only has Trump promised to lower the business tax rate from 35% to 15%
column12: he pledged to eliminate the corporate alternative minimum tax.Beyond lowering the tax rate
column13: it would hardly shock anyone if Trump  given his pro-business stance  were to enact a tax holiday at some point during his presidency. Companies like Cisco (CSCO)
column14: Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL) would thrive. They would no longer need to borrow cheap cash to fund their operations. Likewise
column15: a better capitalized Tesla (TSLA) can accelerate the building of its Gigafactory
column16: helping it achieve not only higher profit margins
column17: but also higher vehicle production. In the process
column18: Tesla would ignite the state of Nevada as an innovative hub
column19: while mass-producing producing emission-free vehicles at affordable prices.Repeal and ReplaceThe Affordable Care Act
column20: a.k.a Obamacare was designed to  among other things  insure the un-insurable. Notably
column21: to provide insurance coverage to people with pre-existing conditions who were blocked under the then-existing rules. Depending on what side of the aisle youre on
column22: Obamacare either did its job or was a complete disaster
column23: according to Trump. Still
column24: whether Obamacare is entirely dismantled or parts of it is kept
column25: you dont have to look too far beyond UnitedHealth (UNH) to find a stock can will thrive.UnitedHealth has worked aggressively to exit the Affordable Care exchanges
column26: which reduces its  exposure to any changes Trump might make. Whats more
column27: added from being the nation's largest health insurer
column28: UnitedHealth owns Optum
column29: which provides pharmacy benefit management services. Last week
column30: not only did the company beat top- and bottom-line estimates
column31: UnitedHealth raised its fiscal 2017 financial outlook
column32: suggesting it is ready for whatever Trump decides to do.Not every company will be as lucky. Conversely
column33: companies such HCA Holdings (HCA) and Universal Health Services (UHS) that prospered under Obamacare may suffer. As will government health care providers such as Centene Corporation (CNC) and Molina Healthcare
column34: Inc. (MOH).Scale Back Dodd-FrankCutting down strict regulations imposed on financial institutions has been another policy Trump has proposed. After all
column35: how can he achieve economic growth and strengthen small business if banks aren't lending money  something banks collectively struggled to do under Dodd-Frank. But as evidenced by the strong earnings results released so far from the likes of Bank of America (BAC)
column36: JPMorgan Chase (JPM)
column37: Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS)
column38: financials are once again the sector to bank on.Written to strengthen consumer protection and create tougher rules on excessive risk-taking
column39: the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act has been cited by bank executives as a prohibiter of growth. ""There's many aspects of it that we've got to kill
column40: said Steven Mnuchin
column41: Trump's pick for Treasury secretary. Mnuchin former partner at Goldman Sachs
column42: called Dodd-Frank ""the number one priority on the regulatory side.To that end
column43: I would be surprised if Trump doesnt take to repeal and replace Dodd-Frank in his first 100 days in office. Combined with the prospect of higher interest rates
column44: lower taxes its tough to ignore the potential upside a bank like Morgan Stanley (MS) can provide. Its not just the big banks that will prosper
column45: however. Keep an eye on super regionals like Comerica (CMA)
column46: US Bancorp (USB) and PNC Financial (PNC)
column47: which Trump has made great again."

column1: Why Boring AT&T Inc. (T) Stock Can Work For (Or Against) You;1/20/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading Tips""Boring is good"" forAT&T Inc.(NYSE:T)
column3: according to InvestorPlace writer and IPO Playbook Editor Tom Taulli
column4: and for whatever it's worth
column5: I mostly agree. But really
column6: what choice do I have? AT&T as a corporate entity has existed for over 50 years above the average American lifespan. This isn't Elon Musk andTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA). And I highly doubt that there are T stock fan boys trolling the internet to defend the honor of AT&T.Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrMaybe that's a bit of a low blow. T stock isn't irrelevant by any means. In fact
column7: AT&T scored the biggest ""T"" of our media ecosystem - as in Taylor Swift.makeArticleAd();I don't need to haul in loads of statistics for you to understand the marketing power behind the company's ""Taylor Swift Now"" experience. Just by name recognition
column8: AT&T can piggyback off the social media and pop culture phenomenon.But will this and other deals translate to profitability for T stock investors? The initial signs don't look too hot. Presently
column9: AT&T stock is just a few cents higher than when ""Taylor Swift Now"" launched. At one point
column10: T was up 4% generated by the enthusiasm.Why Investors Love T stockAt the same time
column11: T stock just gave investors a 30% return last year. Obviously
column12: they're doing something right. It would be intellectually dishonest not to acknowledge and credit the successes of AT&T.First
column13: the venerable company is making some savvy moves. The most conspicuous of these is the acquisition ofTime Warner Inc(NYSE:TWX). Although this deal has its own set of inherent risks - we are talking about media and entertainment
column14: after all - AT&T is loaded with money. More importantly from an administrative perspective
column15: itsfree cash flowis indeed free and flowing. If anybody can absorb the risk
column16: it's T stock.10 Companies That Should Fear Donald Trump's     ""America First"" PlansThen there's the exciting details written in the fine print. The company has revamped its acquisition of DirecTV with standard-bearing streaming services. Also
column17: the introductory rate for new DirecTV customers is $35 a month
column18: which then moves up to a still agreeable $60 regular rate. Best of all
column19: the platform is well-integrated with others
column20: includingApple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) TV andAmazon.com
column21: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Fire TV.If initial reports are anything to go by
column22: T has a big winner on its hands. There's good reason to believe that the late winter rally of AT&T stock was primarily attributed to DirecTV's popularity.Of course
column23: anyone that has had their eye on T stock knows that the AT&T dividend is a huge draw. With a 4.7% yield
column24: that is very difficult to ignore. This is all the more true considering that high rates of passive income typically carries significant capital risk. I don't know about you
column25: but I'm pretty certain that this company isn't going anywhere any time soon. Furthermore
column26: the payout on the AT&T dividend has steadily increased over the last 32 years.Is the Relationship With AT&T Getting Old?So why on earth would anyone cast doubt on T stock? The problem for me is that AT&T is in the maintenance business. As Taulli notes
column27: the company has ""79.4 million business wireless subscribers
column28: 53.9 million consumer wireless subscribers and 25.3 million video subscribers. More importantly
column29: AT&T has the benefit of a powerful moat - that is
column30: a nationwide fiber optic network. Replicating this would be incredibly expensive."" Although impressive
column31: there's not much more that T can do in that department besides annexing Canada.This is a point of heated contention
column32: but it's definitely worth mentioning - traditional media is dying.Naturally
column33: I'm leery of organizations and investments like AT&T stock
column34: where salvation comes from a steadily archaic industry. And here's another scary thought: According toInc
column35: a majority of millennialsdon't even watchtelevision.Don't Sweat Under Armour Inc (UA) Stock --     Here's WhyThis leads to a disconcerting theory. Maybe it's not that T stock is irrelevant; rather
column36: it's their core business that is losing influence. If AT&T's investments are focused on chasing yesterday's trends
column37: that might be a hindrance when tomorrow comes around.At the end of the day
column38: none of this matters depending on your personal perspective. If you're looking for growth and have the time frame to take on heavier risks
column39: avoid T stock. It just doesn't have the speculative potential that's necessary to reliably produce great gains. In addition
column40: the AT&T dividend isn't that big of a deal unless you're putting serious capital to work.Which then brings T stock to where it most belongs - in a conservative retirement portfolio. For that purpose
column41: there aren't that many superior candidates. It's boring as heck
column42: with a little bit of spice to not have you go comatose.As of this writing
column43: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Stocks to Buy for Donald Trump's Second     Wind7 Stocks to Sell Before They ImplodeThe postWhy Boring AT&T Inc. (T) Stock Can Work For (Or Against) Youappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Should You Take the Wheel in General Motors Company (GM) or Ford Motor Company (F)?;1/20/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI remember stopping at a roadside gas station in Arkansas as a child and seeing a bumper sticker that read ""I'd rather walk down the highway holding a Ford steering wheel than drive a Chevy."" Of course
column3: immediately next to this sticker was an almost identical one that read ""I'd rather walk down the highway holding a Chevy steering wheel than drive a Ford."" While my eight-year-old mind found both stickers to be hilarious and somehow profound
column4: I wasn't sure - as the owners of a Pontiac - where my family stood in this pecking order.makeArticleAd();Source:William Oliver via Flickr (Modified)I try to be a little less tribal when it comes to investing. I'm comfortable owning bothGeneral Motors Company(NYSE:GM) andFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) stock if the prices are compelling enough. (And in fact
column5: I do own both GM stock and F stock in my Dividend Growth portfolio.) But today
column6: we're going to do a good
column7: old-fashioned Ford vs GM stock smack down.GM Vs. F: ValuationI'll start first with valuation. The entire auto sector looks cheap right now
column8: and General Motors and Ford are certainly not exceptions.At current prices
column9: GM stock trades for a ridiculous 4.3 times trailing earnings and 6.1 times forward earnings estimates. F stock isn't exactly expensive
column10: mind you
column11: trading at trailing and forward earnings multiples of 5.9 and 7.6
column12: respectively. But GM is the cheaper stock based on earnings.7 Stocks to Sell Before They ImplodeLooking at the price/sales ratio
column13: which eliminates some of the accounting issues that can make direct comparisons difficult
column14: it's essentially a wash. General Motors and Ford trade for 0.35 and 0.32 times their respective annual sales.So
column15: in a world in which few stocks can credibly be called ""cheap
column16: GM stock and F stock are clearly exceptions. At these prices
column17: investors are essentially pricing in years of earnings stagnation or outright shrinkage. And hey
column18: automakers obviously have less growth potential today than they did a generation ago
column19: particularly with ride sharing rising in popularity and the concept of a car as a service rather than an asset is starting to take shape. And the strong sales of recent years will probably take a breather. But at 4 to 6 times earnings
column20: it's hard to argue the bad news wasn't priced in a long time ago.Winner:General MotorsGM Vs. F: DividendNext
column21: let's consider the dividends. At current prices
column22: General Motors and Ford sport dividend yields of 4.1% and 4.8%
column23: respectively
column24: making both high yielders by the standards of today's market. So F stock looks ever so slightly more appealing based on the raw yield.Of course
column25: there is more to a dividend than just its current yield. There is also the issue of growth. Since reinstating its dividend in 2014
column26: General Motors has already raised it 27%. Over that same period
column27: Ford has raised its regular dividend by a smaller 20% but also paid two special dividends that collectively equal a full two quarters' worth of regular dividends at the current rate. So when it comes to dividends
column28: Ford is the clear winner here.Winner:FordGM Vs. F: Future ProofingI'm going to skip the usual banter about whether the Chevy Silverado or the Ford F-150 sells more trucks next quarter. No
column29: instead we're going to focus on which one of these old-economy companies is doing a better job of preparing for the future.I'll start with General Motors. GM is looking to compete head on with the likes of electric car leaderTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) with the Chevy Bolt. Now
column30: Tesla clearly wins that contest based on both style and performance
column31: but the Bolt is no slouch. For drivers wanting to move beyond the internal combustion engine
column32: the Bolt is a viable option.But even bigger in my mind are GM's embrace of both ride sharing and autonomous self-driving cars via its partnerships with bothLyftandUber. Last year
column33: GM inked deals with both ride sharing companies to profit from the transformation of car transportation from a personal asset to a pay-as-you-go service.Rather that bury their heads in the sand
column34: GM's leaders are embracing this trend. And GM's partnership with Lyft will ideally create the infrastructure to make self-driving cars a practical reality for the masses.Short Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Stock While It's OverhypedFord is making its own efforts
column35: of course
column36: with a goal of creating its own fleet of self-driving cars by 2021. Ford also has an electric version of the Focus. But all in all
column37: GM seems to be doing a slightly better job of embracing the future. We're still early in the game
column38: and a lot can happen. But for now
column39: I'm giving the nod to General Motors.Winner:General MotorsThis gives GM the slight edge overall. Of course
column40: no one ever said you have to choose just one. I'm currently long both and expect both to be solid performers. Though I could only make one my choice forInvestorPlace's Best Stocks for 2017
column41: and that distinction goes to GM stock.Charles Sizemore is the principal ofSizemore Capital
column42: a wealth management firm in Dallas
column43: Texas.As of this writing
column44: he was long F and GM stock.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Buy to Double Your Money in 2017The 7 Best High-Yield Investments for RetirementThe postShould You Take the Wheel in General Motors Company (GM) or Ford Motor Company (F)?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column11: Inc.(NASDAQ:TSLA-Free Report) announced plans to invest $350 million in the Gigafactory in Nevada for the production of drivetrains
column12: mainly electric motors and gearboxes for the Model 3 mass-market vehicle. This investment will also lead to job creation for about 500 workers.Tesla manufactures Model S sedan and Model X SUV in its Fremont plant. Model 3 drivetrain will be produced in Nevada. However
column13: the distance between Fremont and Gigafactory is almost 250 miles which may lead to logistic issues for the company.makeArticleAd();Tesla is building the Gigafactory to deal with the shortage of lithium-ion batteries. The automaker will receive tax incentives of $1.3 billion over a period of 20 years from the Nevada government for the construction of the factory and hiring of 6
column14: 500 workers in the state. This investment and hiring strategy will help the automaker achieve its job creation goal.Further
column15: the company's latest decision will support President-elect Donald Trump's plans to boost production and employment in the U.S.Tesla's third-generation electric car
column16: Model 3
column17: which costs half as much as Model S
column18: is expected to be delivered from late 2017. The vehicle offers a range of 215 miles per charge and acceleration of 0-60 mph in less than 6 seconds. However
column19: Tesla is facing high pressure for Model 3 delivery due to intensifying competition. Other automakers are modifying their existing electric vehicle portfolio as new companies enter the market.Price PerformanceTesla has been underperforming the Zacks categorizedAuto Manufacturers-Domesticindustry for over a year. In the past one year
column20: Tesla gained 20% while the industry witnessed a 25.9% rise. The company's new Master Plan
column21: rapid international expansion and continued investment in infrastructure development are major positives. The Gigafactory construction should also prove beneficial.Zacks Rank & Key PicksTesla currently carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).Better-ranked companies in the auto space include Oshkosh Corporation (NYSE:OSK-Free Report)
