column1: Will Solar Manufacturing Be a Costly Mistake for Tesla?;1/20/2017;"When it bought SolarCity late in 2016
column2: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) may have taken on a manufacturing challenge that   makes automobiles look easy. The solar industry has left a string   of bankrupt manufacturers over the past decade
column3: and a price drop   of over 30% in 2016 alone could be a sign that more revenue   pressure is ahead.Amid this backdrop
column4: Tesla is trying to make new technology   work at scale
column5: is bringing in a new partner
column6: and is launching the   solar roof. That's a lot to take on all at once
column7: and it could be   more than even Tesla can handle.makeArticleAd();Image source: Tesla.Tesla's manufacturing plans are complicated
column8: at     bestSolarCity was in the process of building out manufacturing   capacity using technology it acquired from Silevo when it was   acquired by Tesla. The acquisition meant bringingPanasonic
column9: Tesla's battery partner
column10: and its HIT technology into   SolarCity's plant.Panasonic's technology has similarities to Silevo
column11: but is   different enough that they're not a natural fit. There's also the   small complication that Silevo uses a 156 mm cell and Panasonic   uses a 126 mm cell. In other words
column12: bringing SolarCity
column13: Silevo
column14: and Panasonic technology under one roof is far from a trivial   task.It's unclear how much equipment was installed before the Tesla   acquisition
column15: but there's certainly some Silevo technology in   SolarCity's Buffalo facility. In its research
column16: PV Techalso cited job postings that included language about Silevo   technology as evidence that Panasonic won't be the sole   technology in the plant.We also know that Tesla will be making solar roof cells and   shingles in the Buffalo plant. In other words
column17: Tesla will need to   manufacture three separate products in the facility.Solar manufacturing is hardMaking one solar product cost competitive is hard enough. But   Tesla is now trying to make three products simultaneously
column18: and is   facing a solar industry that currently is under pricing pressure.   The price of solar panels fell over 30% in 2016
column19: and prices are   now around $0.40 per watt for commodity solar panels
column20: which
column21: not   coincidentally
column22: is what SolarCity is still installing as it ramps   up solar manufacturing.Neither Tesla or SolarCity has given any information about   what efficiency or costs look like coming out of in-house   manufacturing to this point. But given delays in launching solar   panels and the fact that Panasonic had to be brought in as a   partner
column23: we can discern that it isn't going well.The financial impact could be big if manufacturing fails. New   York was nice enough tobuild the $750 million plant and buy equipment   for it
column24: but that came with a commitment to spend $5 billion in the   state over the next decade
column25: including hiring 1
column26: 460 high-tech   workers. And SolarCity estimated it would still spend around $150   million in capital costs at the plant
column27: plus cost overruns. If   SolarCity
column28: and now Tesla
column29: fails to meet obligations for   investment and job creation in New York it could be obligated to   pay $41.2 million per year as a ""program payment"". If panels   aren't competitive
column30: it's safe to say the impact on Tesla could   measured in the hundreds of millions in losses.Why Tesla doesn't need solar manufacturing in the first     placeAt the same time that Tesla is trying to complete   manufacturing plants to make three products
column31: competitors are   improving technology and lowering costs. On top of the already   low and declining costs for commodity panels
column32: many   manufacturers are building out mono-PERC high-efficiency   manufacturing capacity. Mono-PERC technology that's being built   out is comparable in efficiency to what Panasonic was producing
column33: so Buffalo may not have much
column34: or any
column35: efficiency advantage over   competitors.In other words
column36: Tesla could be buying solar panels in the open   market that would be similar to what the Buffalo plant would   make. No headaches
column37: no risk
column38: no promises to invest in   manufacturing capacity that may not be cost competitive at   scale.It looks like getting into solar manufacturing was an   unnecessary risk for SolarCity
column39: and now it's a problem for Tesla.   Investors should hope it's not a distraction that becomes a   financial drain
column40: something the company doesn't need right   now.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column41: it can pay to listen. After all
column42: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column43: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column44: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla Motors wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column45: 2017Travis Hoiumhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Tesla Motors. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Short Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Stock While Its Overhyped;1/20/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsShares ofTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) rose over 2% yesterday on the heels of an upgrade by Morgan   Stanley analyst Adam Jonas. TSLA stock also broke out past   some major resistance at the $235 level as well.While Tesla bulls are rejoicing for now
column3: however
column4: the party   should be short-lived
column5: if history is any guide. To me
column6: it's time   to take a (guarded) short stance in Tesla stock.makeArticleAd();While one can debate the valuation of Tesla stock and the   aggressive sales projections of the all-important Model 3
column7: the   fact remains that buying TSLA stock at current levels requires ahugeleap of faith. Some may even consider it blind faith
column8: especially   as the market cap approaches $40 billion and price-to-sales still   exceeds 6.From a technical perspective
column9: Tesla shares are becoming   extremely overbought. Previous instances when shares were at   comparable overbought readings were indicative of significant   intermediate-term tops in TSLA.Click to EnlargeTesla did break out past some significant resistance at the   critical $235 level. While this may serve the bullish thesis well   for the short-term
column10: it also provides the potential for a quick   and sharp reversal if that level fails to hold. Given that TSLA   shares are up over 30% since bottoming at $180 in early December
column11: a significant pullback would not be a surprise.Click to EnlargeMuch of the recent rally may be attributed to short covering
column12: as short interest continued to climb while the rally began in   earnest. But the shorts have been severely punished
column13: so that   tailwind is diminished.7 Stocks to Sell Before They ImplodeAlso interesting to note that Morgan Stanley is a lead   underwriter on both the secondary stock issuance and convertible   bond issuance for Tesla.Morgan Stanley upgraded Tesla stockprior to the last two times Tesla issued more stock and   convertible bonds. Kinda makes me wonder.Given the magnitude of the recent rally and the grossly   overbought levels of TSLA stock
column14: I think a counter-trend put   calendar play makes sense. While the $235 support may hold in the   short-term
column15: I think it eventually will give way to a sharp   reversal once the faith is broken.How to Trade TSLA Stock HereBuy Feb $235 puts and sell 27 Jan $235 puts for a $5 net     debit.The trade is 14 deltas short at inception with a maximum risk   of $500 per spread. Ideally
column16: TSLA stock pulls back towards the   $235 level over the coming week.The short strike expires before earnings due on Feb. 8.As of this writing

column1: Everything Is Coming Up Roses for UnitedHealth Group Inc (UNH) Stock;1/20/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News

column3: a Minnesota-headquartered health insurer recently released its fiscal year 2016 numbers. And they were impressive.Source:bradleypjohnson via FlickrGiven the fact that the industry has been racking up huge losses trying to sort out how to make money from Obamacare

column7: 000 people in individual plans (mostly Obamacare plans) in Q4

column9: 000 individuals. Its corporate plans saw an increase for the year of 205
column10: 000.And under a Republican controlled Congress

column14: growth is built in on a number of levels. And the biggest of those is the massive numbers of baby boomers who are going to be retiring over the next decade.Researchers have even dubbed the upcoming transition the '2030 problem' because that is when most of the 75 million baby boomers will be between the ages of 66 and 84. That breaks down to about 3 million boomers entering retirement age every year for the next two decades.This is an entire new industry that has not existed before and means those insurers that can best adapt and maximize revenue from this megatrend
column15: the better they will do.And UNH should do just fine.It is a major player in Medicaid and Medicare

column18: businesses
column19: governments as well the healthcare providers themselves in everything from billing to prescriptions to quality of care.Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Stock Gets a     Meaningless UpgradeAnd now

column21: ambulatory care) services. Last week UNH announced its purchase ofSurgical Care Affiliates Inc(NASDAQ:SCAI) for $2.3 billion. SCAI has more than 200 outpatient surgical centers in 35 states and does nearly 1 million surgeries a year.This will be another area of strong growth for the next two decades or more. And UNH is becoming a major player in the game.Louis Navellieris a renowned growth investor. He is the editor of five investing   newsletters:Blue Chip Growth

column1: NHTSA Drops Tesla Autopilot Investigation
column2: Highlights Technology Strengths;1/19/2017;"In June
column3: electric-car makerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) reported that the National Highway Traffic Safety   Administration had opened a preliminary evaluation into   Autopilot's performance in an unfortunate fatal accident that   occurred while the technology was activated. About seven months   later
column4: NHTSA says it is closing the investigation after   concluding that it did not identify any defects.But NHTSA went further than ending the investigation. NHTSA's   report on the analysis also highlighted some strengths of the   technology.makeArticleAd();Image source: Tesla Motors.Closing the investigationAfter NHTSA's Office of Defects Investigation (ODI) analyzed   Autopilot's systems
column5: NHTSA concluded both that it didn't find any   defects in the technology and that it didn't find ""any incidents   in which the systems did not perform as designed.""""At Tesla
column6: the safety of our customers comes first
column7: and we   appreciate the thoroughness of NHTSA's report and its   conclusion
column8: a Tesla spokesperson said in a statement on   Thursday.NHTSA's conclusion about Tesla's automatic emergency braking   (AEB) system is of particular interest given the nature of the   fatal crash
column9: which consisted of the Autopilot-engaged Tesla   driving on a divided highway and subsequently colliding with a   tractor trailer driving across the highway perpendicular to the   Model S. However
column10: NHTSA said AEB systems aren't designed to   operate in situations like this.ODI's analysis of Tesla's AEB system finds that 1) the     system is designed to avoid or mitigate read-end collisions; 2)     the system's capabilities are in-line with industry state of     the art for AEB performance through MY 2016; and 3) braking for     crossing path collisions
column11: such as that present in the Florida     fatal crash
column12: are outside the expected performance capabilities     of the system.Further
column13: NHTSA emphasized that Tesla's system explicitly   ""requires the continual and full attention of the driver to   monitor the traffic environment and be prepared to take action to   avoid crashes."" Suggesting the driver was inattentive
column14: NHTSA's   investigation found the driver had ""at least seven seconds"" to   notice the tractor trailer.Interesting takeaways from the reportIn addition to exonerating Tesla
column15: the report pointed to some   other notable tidbits about the technology and its   development.1. Tesla was proactive about considering inattentive   drivers in Autopilot's development.NHTSA found that ""it appears that over the course of researching   and developing Autopilot
column16: Tesla considered the possibility that   drivers could misuse the system in a variety of ways
column17: and that   ""the potential for driver misuse was evaluated as part of Tesla's   design process and solutions were tested
column18: validated
column19: and   incorporated into the wide release of the product.""2. The crash rate for Tesla Autopilot-equipped vehicles   dropped about 40% compared to vehicles without the   technology
column20: according to NHTSA's analysis of mileage and airbag deployment   for Tesla vehicles.Tesla Model S and 2016 Model X vehicles before and after   Autosteer installation. Chart source: NHTSA.Pointing to this particular data point from the report
column21: Tesla   CEO Elon Musk tweeted Thursday
column22: saying the company is targeting a   90% reduction in crashes for vehicles with the updated Autopilot   hardware Tesla started including in every vehicle in October.3. Tesla could have been more transparent about system     limitations
column23: but its warnings are more explicit now.Tesla's information about system limitations of Autopilot is   ""perhaps not as specific as it could be
column24: the report said. But   information
column25: particularly as it relates to user interface   warnings
column26: alerts
column27: and driver monitoring systems intended to   ensure the driver remains attentive
column28: improved significantly in   Tesla's 8.0 software update
column29: which NHTSA highlights:Tesla's design included a hands-on the steering wheel system     for monitoring driver engagement. That system has been updated     to further reinforce the need for driver engagement through a     ""strike out"" strategy. Drivers that do not respond to visual     cues in the driver monitoring system alerts may ""strike out""     and lose Autopilot function for the remainder of the drive     cycle.Tesla demonstrates the capabilities of its new Autopilot   hardware. Image source: Tesla Motors.NHTSA's conclusion about the fatal crash is good news for   Tesla investors. Not only does it emphasize how the company's   Autopilot technology works as it's intended
column30: but it also points   to improving safety because of the technology. And with Tesla's   new hardware being far more capable than the first-generation   Autopilot hardware examined in this report
column31: the safety of Tesla's   vehicles should only improve.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip
column32: it can pay to listen. After all
column33: the newsletter they       have run for over a decade

column35: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Tesla Motors wasn't one       of them! column1: Should You Buy Twilio Inc (TWLO) Stock? 3 Pros
column2: 3 Cons;1/19/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTwilio Inc(NYSE:TWLO) stock got clocked to end 2016. Shares tumbled from as high as $70 to just $28 today
column4: a crushing 60% decline. Is TWLO stock finally cheap enough today
column5: or is there room for even more downside?Source:Web Summit Via FlickrOn the plus side
column6: numerous analysts are upgrading the firm as the price drops. And a new partnership could reinvigorate the growth story.makeArticleAd();But don't overlook the risks here either. Just because a stock has fallen a long way already doesn't mean it can't keep dropping. Before you hit the ""buy"" or ""sell"" button on TWLO stock
column7: however
column8: take a minute to consider both sides of the coin.TWLO Stock ConsTwilio Doesn't Have a Moat:Twilio has generated a lot of interest in its services due to affordable pricing. The company is operating with a negative 15% net profit margin. And this figure has hardly budged over the past year
column9: even as revenue has soared. You would expect to see scale effects by this point. One alternative hypothesis is that Twilio has underpriced its services. It doesn't appear to have a genuine technological moat. Much of what the company does would probably not require excessive effort for its customers to do internally. A company such asFacebook Inc(NYSE:FB) always has the option of building their own message marketing platform. But why bother if Twilio is willing to provide the service at less than cost? However
column10: that sentiment could change quickly the moment Twilio tries to raise prices.Valuation Still an Issue:One of the issues with low-float IPOs such as Twilio is that the stocks can run far beyond seemingly logical valuations. TWLO stock soared out of the gate
column11: but this was likely mostly due to the limited number of publicly trading shares. Insiders still controlled the vast majority of the company. They've been slowly selling more of the stock into the market
column12: depressing the price. However
column13: given that initial pop to $70
column14: many investors have a mental anchor there. They see a drop from $70 to $28 and think it must be cheap now. However
column15: compare Twilio with other firms in its space. Its 9x EV/sales figure is still astoundingly high
column16: and is in fact the highest in its entire peer group. The company's revenue growth rate is slowing down enough to make it difficult to justify paying up for Twilio's expensive revenues.10 Companies That Should Be in the Dow     JonesPositive News
column17: But Stock Isn't Moving:The poor performance TWLO stock has delivered lately demonstrates the valuation issues. The company has gotten a stream of upgrades along with the announcement of a potentially game-changing partnership withAmazon.com
column18: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN). More on this below. Despite all the good news
column19: TWLO stock hasn't gone anywhere. After each bit of positive news or analyst upgrade
column20: the stock pops for a day or two and then gives back all the gains. This is indicative of an overpriced stock. Owners are happy to use any pop to sell
column21: while short sellers show no nervousness.TWLO Stock ProsNewsflow Turning Positive:In recent weeks
column22: TWLO stock has seen many positive news announcements. In late December
column23: Drexel Hamilton started the company with a ""buy"" opinion. Pacific Crest Securities upgraded the firm to start 2017. And just this week
column24: two more firms weighed in
column25: with Canaccord Genuity upgrading it to a ""buy
column26: and Oppenheimer naming TWLO stock a 2017 top pick. If that weren't enough
column27: in late December
column28: Twilioformed an expanded partnershipwith Amazon. Amazon Web Services had already partnered with Twilio to deliver text messages for AWS customers. Now that capability will be expanded to include voice messaging
column29: greatly expanding Twilio's reach within the booming AWS ecosystem.Short Squeeze Potential:Normally
column30: you see short sellers pile into a stock as it soars. However
column31: that's not always the case; sometimes short sellers pile onto a plunging stock. That's exactly what they've done with TWLO stock. As TWLO stock peaked in late September
column32: short interest was just 64% of the float. That's a huge number
column33: yes
column34: but it was about to get bigger. In November
column35: short interest topped 100% of the float (a very rare occurrence). By the end of November
column36: short interest hit 116% of the float
column37: suggesting that for every 5 tradable shares of TWLO stock
column38: 6 had been sold short. This is rather sketchy
column39: as generally exchange regulations prohibit this sort of behavior. Even with the continued weakness in Twilio stock
column40: short interest has hardly budged - the most recent data has it at 8.8 million shares
column41: or 102% of the float. Needless to say
column42: any concentrated effort by these short sellers to dispose of their positions could set off a large rally in the stock.Earnings Soon:TWLO stock needs something to reset the narrative. Over the past month
column43: Twilio has seen a variety of positive developments
column44: centered around the upgraded partnership with Amazon and numerous stock upgrades. However
column45: traders are still focused on insider selling and the company's high valuation level. At this point
column46: earnings in a couple of weeks could be the catalyst that finally revives the bull case. Twilio is trading not far off IPO levels now
column47: it'd take some gumption for the shorts to press the stock through that level. On the other hand
column48: given the massive short interest
column49: even a modest beat could send the stock flying. Remember that Twilio initially traded down on earnings last quarter
column50: but buyers appeared shortly thereafter.Bottom Line on TWLO StockTraders have punished TWLO stock over the past quarter. There are certainly reasons to expect the stock could turn around. Short interest is astoundingly high and persistent.Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Stock Gets a     Meaningless UpgradeThe stock has seen more positive news lately
column51: and earnings could be the mechanism that finally triggers a sentiment shift. However
column52: the company still appears richly priced. And it's not entirely clear that Twilio will ever be able to ramp to any significant level of profitability. For now
column53: this is a better trade than an investment.At the time of this writing
column54: Ian Bezek had no positions in   any of the aforementioned stocks. You can reach him on Twitter at   @irbezek.More From InvestorPlace7 Healthcare Stocks That Will Cripple Your     PortfolioThe 7 Best High-Yield Investments for     RetirementThe postShould You Buy Twilio Inc (TWLO) Stock? 3 Pros
column55: 3 Consappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Panasonic Wants to Produce More Than Just Batteries for Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA);1/19/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsPanasonic Corporation (ADR)(OTCMKTS:PCRFY) wants to extend its relationship withTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) beyond batteries.Source: TeslaPanasonic Corporation (ADR) wants to be a part of Tesla Motors Inc's self-driving car plans. The company is specifically interested in developing sensors that could be used with the system. This may include its ""organic photoconductive film CMOS image sensors"" that are currently in development.makeArticleAd();""We are deeply interested in Tesla's self-driving system
column3: Kazuhiro Tsuga
column4: CEO of Panasonic Corporation (ADR)
column5: toldReuters. ""We are hoping to expand our collaboration by jointly developing devices for that
column6: such as sensors.""Panasonic Corporation (ADR) already has strong ties with Tesla Motors Inc. It is the sole provider of batteries for the electric car company's Model S and Model X vehicles. It will also be the exclusive provider of batteries for the upcoming Model 3. Plus
column7: it is investing $260 million in a TSLA factory for photovoltaic cells and modules used in solar energy setups.Tesla Motors Inc has been moving forward with its self-driving efforts. It showed of the second generation of its Autopilot hardware a few months ago. This setup includes one radar
column8: eight cameras
column9: ultrasonic sensors and a supercomputer. The hardware will likely change over time
column10: but TSLA is dedicated to the technology
column11: reportsElectrek.Panasonic Corporation (ADR) may also be interested in showing off its new heads-up display technology to Tesla Motors Inc. The new tech was just recently revealed earlier this month at the Consumer Electronics Show. It could be used to provide drivers with additional information without cluttering the dashboard.TSLA stock was up 1% and PCRFY stock was down slightly as of Thursday afternoon.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks That Won't Be Around a Year From     Now10 Best Stocks for Retirement Investors7 Fast-Growing Consumer Stocks to BuyThe postPanasonic Wants to Produce More Than Just Batteries for Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Tesla Motors Upgraded: 3 Things You Need to Know;1/19/2017;"It's been nearly two months sinceTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) finalized its acquisition of SolarCity
column2: unifying   two of alternative energy's leading lights under Elon Musk's   leadership --and Wall Street hates them both.According to data from ratings aggregatorStreetInsider.com
column3: the past six or so months have seenTesla stockbombarded with negative sentiment -- a brand-new sell rating   (from Cowen)
column4: two downgrades (Argus and Goldman Sachs)
column5: and two   underwhelming initiations of coverage at ""hold"" (from Deutsche   Bank and Berenberg). But finally
column6: at long last
column7: someone had   something nice to say about Tesla today.makeArticleAd();Morgan Stanley just upgraded the stock. Here are three things   you need to know about that.Tesla's Model 3 electric sedan could hit big -- and mean big   things for Tesla stock. Image source:Tesla.1. Why Morgan Stanley loves TeslaIn a long
column8: drawn-out sketch of Tesla's several moving parts
column9: Morgan Stanley hit upon three key reasons it thinks investors   should own the stock. These include:The impending launch of theModel 3 mass market electric sedan
column10: which Morgan Stanley now sees arriving sooner than it had     feared
column11: and delivering ""a significant positive impact     on earnings and our price target.""Decreased competition from Silicon Valley rivals
column12: with     ""tech firms"" such asGoogleandAppleno longer seeming as interested as they once were in producing     whole branded electric cars on their own. Morgan thinks they're     now more inclined to just build bits and pieces of software     that Detroit can then insert into the cars that it builds (and     presumably
column13: Morgan Stanley sees Detroit as easier than Silicon     Valley for Tesla to beat).And generally speaking
column14: Morgan believes that America is     ""moving Tesla's way"" in its willingness to adopt electric cars     over gasoline-powered horseless carriages. According to the     analyst
column15: Tesla ""stands at the epicenter of US high tech     manufacturing job creation
column16: and will benefit     disproportionately as this industry evolves.Put it all together
column17: and Morgan Stanley is convinced Tesla   stock will outperform the market
column18: and assigns the stock a $305   price target -- 25% more than what the stock costs today.2. Summing up those partsThat's the big picture. Now here are a few specifics.In working up its valuation on Tesla stock
column19: Morgan Stanley   specifically excludes
column20: and assigns ""zero value"" to Tesla's   ""Energy"" battery business. Instead
column21: Morgan gets the its basic   target price from valuing (a) how many cars Tesla is likely to   produce
column22: and subtracting from that value (b) the number of cars   Teslafailed to produce as promisedlast year
column23: and (c) the cost of ""higher capex"" as Tesla builds its   business.Working these numbers
column24: Morgan arrives at a base value for   Tesla of $229 per share
column25: which Morgan Stanley admits is ""slightly   below the current share price.""3. Tesla's X-factorSo how does Morgan move from $229 to $305 on its target price?   This is the third part of the equation
column26: and it may surprise you.   The company assigns fully $76 in share price to the value of   Tesla's proposedTesla Mobilitycar-sharing service -- which doesn't actually exist yet.Its non-existence notwithstanding
column27: Morgan boldly proclaims   that ""over 100% of the upside to our $305 price target can be   attributed to the value we ascribe to Tesla Mobility."" And   adding $76 to $229
column28: the company finds the entire company to be   worth 25% more than it costs today.That's a big leap of faith that Morgan Stanley is making
column29: granted. But it's worth noting that the analyst has actually   ratcheted back its expectations. As the Fool's own Alex Dumortier   has noted previously
column31: Morgan Stanley said Tesla Mobilitycould be worth $244 a shareto Tesla. And ifthatprediction turns out to be true
column32: then the stock could literally   double from today's $244 share price.Bonus thing: How much is a Model 3 worth?Granted
column33: much of the above remains speculation -- the zero   value of Tesla's nascent battery business
column34: and the incredible   value of the car-sharing business that has yet to begin   operations. Meanwhile
column35: Tesla has yet to prove it can earn a   profit fromanyof its businesses over the course of a full financial year. For   the time being
column36: the stock is still being valued largely on the   volume of cars it produces
column37: regardless of the profits that they   do or do not produce.And this brings us to the final valuable tidbit of information   contained in Morgan Stanley's report. According to the analyst
column38: $81 of its $305 price target comes from Morgan Stanley's belief   that Tesla will deliver 75
column39: 000 ""additional"" Model 3s in 2018
column40: and   ""nearly 100
column41: 000 units"" in 2020. If you crunch those numbers
column42: therefore
column43: it appears that Morgan Stanley is valuing each 1
column44: 000   cars sold in 2018 at about $0.50 in added share value for Tesla   stock (75 x $0.50 = $37.50 per share)
column45: and valuing each 1
column46: 000   cars sold two years later at about $0.435 per 1
column47: 000 units (100 x   $0.435 = $43.50 per share).Knowing this may give you an idea of what to expect in future   upgrades (and downgrades) from Morgan Stanley
column48: as Tesla delivers   (and fails to deliver) on its car delivery promises. Simply put
column49: for every 1
column50: 000 units that Elon Musk promises to investors
column51: add   $0.435 to the stock price -- and for every 1
column52: 000 cars that Tesla   actuallydelivers
column53: you can mark up the value of Tesla stock by $0.50.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column54: it can pay to listen. After all
column55: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column2: Inc.TSLAannounced plans to invest $350 million in the Gigafactory in Nevada for the production of drivetrains

The investment represents an important step for Tesla ahead of   its planned high-volume Model 3 production later this year.Tesla Gigafactory construction progress as of Jan. 3. Image   source: Tesla Motors.makeArticleAd();Model 3 drive-unit productionAfter introducing Tesla's chief technology officer JB Straubel   at Nevada's State of the State Address this week

column6: and add 550 new skilled jobs to Nevada's   economy.Tesla job postings have already indicated the company was   working on drive-unit production at the Gigafactory
column7: but this   announcement officially confirms the electric-car maker's   commitment to drive-unit manufacturing -- specifically for its   upcoming Model 3.Drive-unit production expands the already mind-boggling scope   of Tesla's Gigafactory

column1: Tesla Motors
column2: Inc. Inches Closer to Its Important Autopilot Update;1/17/2017;"Over the weekend
column3: electric-car makerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) beamed a key update for its ""enhanced"" autopilot   to vehicles with its October-introduced sensor suite
column4: or what   Tesla calls its hardware two vehicles (HW2).But there's a catch. Besides the first 1
column5: 000 vehicles already   running the new software
column6: this update for Tesla's driver-assist   technology is only operating in ""non-actuating mode to assess   reliability
column7: Tesla CEO Elon Musk explained onTwitter. The full rollout of the new features
column8: if everything ""looks   good
column9: will happen by the end of the week
column10: Musk said.makeArticleAd();Inside Tesla's model X. Image source: The Motley Fool.The next steps for AutopilotTesla's upcoming Autopilot for HW2 vehicles will be aimed   mostly at catching up Tesla's HW2 vehicles to its HW1 vehicles.   The update should include ""most"" of the functionality from HW1   vehicles
column11: Musk explained on Twitter in December. This is in line   with the company's initial plan for the new technology. When   Tesla first announced its new autopilot sensors
column12: it said HW2   vehicles would initially lack HW1 features as it validates the   sensors with more robust driving data.Over time
column13: of course
column14: Tesla expects the improved sensor suite   to deliver an upgraded autopilot experience
column15: which Tesla calls   enhanced autopilot. And the company says the sensors will   eventually be enough to enable autonomous driving. But Tesla will   need to extensively validate and refine self-driving features
column16: as   well as obtain regulatory approval.Enhanced autopilot. Image source: Tesla Motors.This autopilot update is just one of many new features Tesla   plans to deliver wireless to its vehicles in the near future.   After following through with its promised updates for its   original autopilot announcement in October 2014
column17: the company has   recently been more transparent about the next steps for the   driver-assist technology. For instance
column18: Musk tweeted this weekend   that there are still ""many improvements"" to be released for its   HW1 vehicles ""over the course of the year."" And Tesla has   promised a range of new features to eventually make it to   enhanced autopilot
column19: including:Automatic lane changes without requiring driver inputTransitions from one freeway to anotherExiting the freewaySelf-parking when near a parking spotHowever
column20: as Tesla's autopilot features more closely resemble   autonomous driving
column21: the company is careful to emphasize that   these new features are ""subject to regulatory approval.""Tesla has also been transparent about its plan to make HW2   vehicles fully autonomous. The company says its vehicles will be   able to take drivers from their home to their destination without   any input and then park autonomously after dropping drivers off.   While regulatory hurdles will probably push these updates out   several years
column22: Tesla has said it will demonstrate a self-driven   cross-country trip this year.Tesla demonstrates its new hardware's capabilities on a drive   in Calfornia. Image source: Tesla Motors.A continuous stream of new autopilot features

column1: Profit From Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Stock No Matter Which Way It Moves;1/17/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOne of my favorite topics in the stock market these days isTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA). For anyone who likes an underdog story filled with drama and suspense
column3: TSLA stock is as good as it gets.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Lau via Flickr (Modified)Tesla - the company - has been an incredible success up to this point. TSLA stock has also been one of the best stocks in the market in the past five years. Unfortunately
column4: the company now has extremely high expectations
column5: and Tesla stock has an even higher valuation. I've been very critical of the bull case for TSLA. I wholeheartedly believe it's one of the most dangerous popular stocks in the market today.Yet I am the first to admit that if the Tesla story has a happy ending
column6: it could easily double within the next couple of years. If not
column7: I believe the bottom will fall out of the stock and the company may end up dead in the water.The TSLA Stock Bear CaseIn the past four quarters
column8: Tesla shipped76
column9: 000 automobiles
column10: generated over $6 billion in revenue and registered $874 million in net income losses. Last year
column11: General Motors Company(NYSE:GM) shipped 9.8 million automobiles globally.In the past four quarters
column12: GM generated $162.1 billion in revenue and reported net profits of $14 billion. Yet somehow
column13: TSLA stock is valued at a market cap of $39.2 billion compared to GM's valuation of $56.9 billion.7 Stocks to Buy to Double Your Money in 2017Why? The Tesla bull case involves the Model 3 and subsequent affordable Tesla models taking over the global mass auto market. If that's the case
column14: TSLA stock will eventually justify its absurd valuation.I'm skeptical. Elon Musk has made too many promises that will require perfect execution to keep. Anyone who has operated in the business world knows things rarely go exactly according to plan. Tesla plans to ramp production from 50
column17: 000 in 2018. Musk also promises that Model 3s will begin shipping by the end of 2017 andwill startat $35
column18: 000.Just ask any TSLA stock bull
column19: and those are the reasons they like the stock. To me
column20: that means that at the bare minimum
column21: all of those assumptions need to actually happen to justify Tesla's current valuation.TSLA Stock Is Too Dangerous to ShortUnfortunately for traders betting against TSLA stock
column22: they have plenty of company. According toshortsqueeze.com
column23: it has a short percent of float of nearly 30% with 8.7 days to cover. That means any dip in share price will likely be met with short covering. Any potential good news could also be followed by a huge short squeeze.Despite my belief that TSLA stock is extremely overvalued
column24: these risks have kept me away from ever taking a short position in the stock. The way I see it
column25: Tesla has so much potential for volatility in the next couple of years
column26: both longs and shorts are playing a dangerous game.When a friend asked me the other day where I think TSLA's share price will be by 2019
column27: I told him probably $50. Then I added that if it's not below $100
column28: it will probably be above $500. Tesla is either going to deliver on its story with a happy ending or it won't.A LEAPS Straddle Bet On TSLA StockAfter the conversation with my friend
column29: I got to thinking about the hypothetical $50 or $500 binary outcome for TSLA stock and what could be the best way to create a neutral trade based on that idea. The uncertainty makes long-term options very expensive. But if you agree with my premise that Tesla will be making a major move one way or the other within the next couple of years
column30: it is possible to set up a straddle trade using 2019 TSLA LEAPS.At a strike price of $220
column31: the Jan 2019 TSLA LEAPS calls last traded at about $57. The $220 puts last traded at around $50. If you invest equally in both options
column32: you will require roughly a $100 move in one direction or the other to break even on your trade. That means that if TSLA ends up above $320 or below $120 by January 2019
column33: you've made a profit. If TSLA ends up at $50
column34: you've earned a return of roughly 70%. If TSLA makes it to $500
column35: you've earned a return of roughly 180%.Take Advantage of a Misunderstood Fitbit Inc (FIT) StockThose returns are lopsided simply because the options market appears to be fairly bearish on TSLA stock in the long-term.If you're on the fence about which direction Tesla stock is headed in the next two years but agree with the idea that it will be making a huge move in one direction or the other
column36: consider a 2019 LEAPS straddle trade like the one described above. Then you can simply sit back and enjoy the end of the TSLA story
column37: one way or another.As of this writing
column38: Wayne Duggan did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Healthcare Stocks That Will Cripple Your Portfolio10 Dividend Growth Stocks That Simply Print MoneyThe postProfit From Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Stock No Matter Which Way It Movesappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why 2017 Is the Year to Invest in Artificial Intelligence Stocks;1/16/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.The other day I sat in a coffee shop across from a student who   was studying a complex math problem. The equation took up the   entire page
column2: and he sat there staring at it for quite awhile.   After I thought about how glad I am to not be in school anymore
column3: I started thinking about how jumping into a new investing market   can be intimidating. Like the math equation
column4: it can be hard to   make sense of all the information on the page.But it doesn't have to be this way
column5: especially if you closely   follow what smart companies are doing in new segments and pair   that with some good ol' fashioned research.makeArticleAd();Artificial intelligence (AI) is one such opportunity where   companies are making big bets on it and where the research backs   up its potential. And if AI pans out the way many are   thinking
column6: then 2017 may be a very good year to get on board with   this technological shift.AI is at an inflection pointIn 2016
column7: the AI market was worth just $644 million
column8: according   to Tractica. This year
column9: that amount will nearly double and then   grow exponentially from there. Take a look:Data source:TracticaandStatista.Clearly
column10: we're still at the beginning of AI's revenue   possibilities
column11: and its opportunity will accelerate over the   coming the years until it reaches $37.8 billion less than 10   years from now.Growth in the AI market will be spurred on by many large tech   companies that implement AI into their current businesses. For   example
column12: Facebook(NASDAQ: FB) uses its own internally developed AI programs to   read the posts we put on Facebook and understand the context   they're written in. The company's DeepText program reads   thousands of posts in just seconds and does so across 20   different languages. Facebook also uses deep learning to tag   our friends in photos
column13: and is even using AI to identify people   (and their voices!) in videos.But AI is expanding its reach outside of the technology sector   as well. There's plenty of talk about self-driving cars these   days (I've done my fair share) and that's because the number of vehicles worldwide with some   level of autonomy will hit 76 million by 2035 -- and be worth $77   billion by that year.That growth is being fueled
column14: at least in part
column15: by AI.NVIDIA Corporation(NASDAQ: NVDA) is using its graphics processors (GPUs) to create   some of the most sophisticated image processing supercomputers
column16: like the company'sDrive PX 2. The computer is being used by 80 automakers and auto suppliers   already
column17: andTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)  recently said that it would use some of   NVIDIA's technology in its next version of its semi-autonomous   Autopilot driving feature.Tesla is itself becoming a leader in AI technologies
column18: and back   in October
column19: the company posted a video of its self-driving AI   driving a person around in one of its vehicles --    completely hands-free -- as it navigated stop signs
column20: bicyclists
column21: and foggy roads.Image source: Tesla.OK
column22: so technology companies are obviously betting on AI's   future
column23: and NVIDIA is proving that the automotive sector will   bank on AI as well
column24: but it's important to note that governments   are betting on AI's growth as well.China announced last year that its government will invest in   new AI technologies over the next three years
column25: as it tries to   create its own $15 billion AI market. And even the U.S.   government has taken notice of China's recent focus on artificial   intelligence. In areportreleased back in October
column26: the White House said that Chinese   scientists are publishing far more AI research than American   scientists and that their work is being cited more often. The   U.S. then urged more AI research and development spending in   order to catch up and improve economic growth.The South Korean government recently turned its attention to   AI as well. AfterGoogle's DeepMind AI beat a South Korean grandmaster Go player in   an exhibition match in Seoul
column27: the country pledged $863 million to   develop more AI technology and called on private companies to   invest even more.There's no turning back nowWith so many companies (and leading world powers) focusing   their attention on AI
column28: there's no stopping the momentum now.   Investors waiting around to see how AI plays out could be left in   the dust
column29: as this technological shift begins to speed up even   faster this year. Of course
column30: there's no guarantee that 2017 will   be the best year to invest in AI. But if all of the AI focus from   2016 spills into this year
column31: then it certainly looks like a good   bet.10 stocks we like better than NvidiaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 5 Stocks Millennials Should Buy in 2017;1/15/2017;"Millennials have one of the most important things in investing   on their side: time.By starting to invest long before retirement
column2: millennials can   take a very long-term view of their investments. And at The   Motley Fool
column3: a long-term view is what we're all about. With that   in mind
column4: here are five stocks that are attractive for any   millennial's portfolio.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.SquareOne of the broad trends I think we can expect to continue for   decades to come is a growing number of mobile transactions.Square Inc(NYSE: SQ) is a leader in mobile transactions for businesses
column5: and   with Square Cash has become a leader in peer-to-peer transactions   as well.Square is losing money today
column6: but the company is growing like   crazy and margins are starting to improve
column7: as you can see   below.SQ Revenue (TTM)data byYChartsThe great thing about Square is that it's building a business   that will be the foundation on which thousands of other small   businesses will be built. With payment processing
column8: point of sale   solutions
column9: payroll
column10: and other offerings Square is making it   easier to build a business and operate it on mobile platforms
column11: something millennials probably interact with on a regular   basis.Whole FoodsMillennials didn't start the organic food trend
column12: but they're   taking it to a new level. It isn't necessarily that they want   food to be healthier than other generations have
column13: but how food is   made and what's in it is more important to millennials than ever   before. That's been a big driver ofWhole Foods'(NASDAQ: WFM) success over the past decade
column14: something that I   think will continue as millennials get older and more start   buying their own groceries.It's true that Whole Foods' stock price has dipped over the   past year as growth has slowed and profits sank. But the fall in   the stock price means shares trade at a much more reasonable 20x   earnings than the ratio's peak in the 60s a few years ago.WFMdata byYChartsWhat Whole Foods is riding is a long-term trend toward food   that's more transparent and more humanely produced than previous   generations have demanded. It's no longer the only player in the   market
column15: but it's still the biggest fish
column16: and is uniquely   positioned to become a go-to grocery store for millions of   millennials for decades to come.General MotorsTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) may be the easy auto pick for millennial   investors
column17: butGeneral Motors(NYSE: GM) is the better investment long-term. Not only has GM   generated more than twice as much net income over the past year   ($13.9 billion) as Tesla generated in revenue ($5.9 billion) --   in some ways
column18: it's ahead of the EV upstart on technology.GM bought a9% stake in ride sharing company Lyft in 2016and recently bought Cruise Automation to advance its self-driving   car technology as well. So GM is already ahead of Tesla in the   ride sharing business
column19: and is arguably on equal footing in self   driving technology.Where GM has really jumped ahead of competitors is with the   Chevy Bolt. The all-electric EV with a 238 mile range and price   tag under $30
column20: 000 (after the federal tax credit) beat Tesla's   Model 3 to the road and will likely have about a year head start   in deliveries.It may be exciting to talk about Tesla as a future power in   the auto industry
column21: but GM is far more established and is   executing on a strategic shift that will make the company   relevant for decades to come. For long-term investors
column22: that's   where I would put my money today.SunPowerIf there's one trend that will change the world more than any   other during the lifetime of millennials
column23: I think it's solar   energy. Fossil fuels have long powered everything from our homes   to our cars
column24: but it's energy from the sun that's actually our   most abundant energy resource
column25: providing the earth with enough   energy every hour to provide all of the world's energy   consumption needs for an entire year.SunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR) is the most efficient solar panel manufacturer in   the world
column26: and has exposure to nearly every segment of the solar   market around the world. Everything from small
column27: handheld solar   cells to the largest power plants in the world are powered by   SunPower solar cells
column28: and that gives the company a unique   position from which to grow into the multi-trillion dollar energy   market.What's encouraging for millennials buying now is that the   growth is just beginning. Subsidies no longer drive the adoption   of solar energy
column29: with SunPower winning bids in Chile
column30: Mexico
column31: and   Nevada that provide cost efficient energy more cheaply than   fossil fuels. And with falling costs we will see volumes grow   long-term. This is a volatile market
column32: but if you have a decade or   two to wait
column33: SunPower is well positioned to take advantage of the   booming solar market.NikeConsciousness about health and fitness is almost a standard   among millennials today. Whether it's biking to work or taking   yoga classes
column34: athletic gear is going to be a staple for the   entire generation. AndNike(NYSE: NKE) is a company that's proven to have staying power in   the athletics business.Nike has proven its ability to stay relevant as styles have   changed
column35: but it's their sales model that I think demonstrates why   they're built to last. Sure
column36: you can buy Nike products from most   retailers
column37: but the company is a master at dealing directly with   customers through digital marketing and direct online sales. This   cuts out all middlemen and will lead to more information on what   customers want and higher profits long-term. And as you build   your portfolio
column38: that's a great trend to be following in   retail.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: 9 Facts You Didn't Know About Driverless Cars;1/15/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.Technology and automotive companies are currently in a sprint   to bring the best (and the safest) self-driving technologies to   market. The companies have been spurred on by high traffic   fatalities
column2: increasing support by governments
column3: and
column4: of course
column5: new revenue potential.makeArticleAd();The pace at which driverless car technology advances is   astounding
column6: which means that most of us have probably missed a   few key developments if we haven't been keeping up lately. Check   out these nine facts to help bring your driverless car knowledge   back up to speed:Google's Waymo just cut the cost of LIDAR by     90%.Alphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google recently spun out its     self-driving business into its own company
column7: called Waymo
column8: and     this month it announced that it hasreduced the costof the LIDAR technology
column9: which is used to help self-driving     cars see what's around them. According toArsTechnica
column10: Waymo may have reduced the price from $75
column11: 000 down to $7
column12: 500.2018 is the year to watch.Electric-car makerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA)  released a video a couple of months ago     showing a person riding around in a Tesla -- in Autopilot mode     -- with the car completely in command. Tesla started adding     fully autonomous hardware to its cars a few months ago and says     it'll actively roll out software updates to bring full autonomy     to its vehicles after they go through more testing. But     CEO Elon Musk has said he wants Tesla to have a fully     autonomous vehicle on the road by 2018.Mars rover technology might find its way into     driverless cars.At the Consumer Electronics Show this month
column13: Nissan Motor Co.(NASDAQOTH: NSANY)announced that it wants to implement NASA technology used for     the Mars rovers to help control fleets of self-driving cars.     Nissan's Seamless Autonomous Mobility (SAM) system allows a     self-driving car to call on a person for help if the car     doesn't know what to do (for example
column14: if it needs to interpret     hand signals from a traffic officer). The vehicle would call     SAM in such a situation
column15: and a person would map out a quick     route around the problem area. Other self-driving cars would     then learn from these situations to improve their own driving     knowledge. NASA used a similar system
column16: called Visual     Environment for Remote Virtual Exploration (VERVE)
column17: for the     Mars rover and other vehicles
column18: which involved humans mapping     out routes around obstacles when the rover couldn't figure out     what to do on its own.Driverless cars will make you a better       driver.Chipmaker and driverless car tech leaderNVIDIACorporation(NASDAQ: NVDA)  recently announced its new artificial       intelligence (AI) Co-Pilot system that uses external cameras       and radar to tell you what's around (such as a bicyclist)
column19: and internal cameras that keep track of where you're looking.       The AI Co-Pilot will drive the car by itself most of the       time
column20: but will use its data to also help humans learn how to       drive better when they're controlling the wheel.Self-driving vehicles will be big business.Boston Consulting Group estimates that the driverless car     market will be worth $77 billion by 2035. Not all of that will     come from sales of the vehicles themselves
column21: though. Many     companies
column22: like Waymo
column23: plan on making money from self-driving     ride-hailing services.Not everyone is a fan of the technology.An advocacy group for professional drivers
column24: called the     Upstate Transportation Association
column25: is trying to get New York     toban self-driving carsfor 50 years. The organization wants to protect the jobs of     professional drivers
column26: though a 50-year ban seems a bit extreme     (won't the AI robots have taken over by then?). So far
column27: New     York's state government appears open to self-driving     technologies on its roads. But the state does have a     requirement for drivers to keep one hand on the wheel that     self-driving opponents are hoping can be used to ban the tech.Driverless cars might make traffic worse
column28: initially.A new study by the U.K. Department for Transport found that     traffic would actuallyget worseon Britain's roads when driverless cars take to the streets
column29: because the vehicles will be too cautious at first. When a     quarter of all cars are automated
column30: the government agency     expects road delays to tick up by 0.9%
column31: and the percentage     won't go down until about 50% to 75% of all cars are fully     autonomous.There will be slow
column32: but steady
column33: growth.One-quarter of all cars will be autonomous by 2040
column34: according     the Brookings Institution. AndIHSbelieves we'll reach driverless car ubiquity sometime     after 2050.China could lead the autonomous-vehicle     market.China is trying to revamp its trucking industry by     allowing companies to test out self-driving technologies at afaster pacethan many other countries. The lack of regulation in the     country means that China is in a position to roll out     self-driving tech faster
column35: though it raises the question of     whether accelerated development of the technology comes at the     expense of safety.Final thoughtsWhile there are certainly concerns around self-driving cars
column36: there's virtually no stopping this technology now. Automakers
column37: tech companies
column38: and governments are all eager to bring autonomous   driving to the masses
column39: and we're likely to see the pace of   innovation pick up over the coming years.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Detroit Auto Show: Why Audi's Q8 Concept SUV Is Significant;1/15/2017;"The Audi Q8 Concept at the North American International Auto   Show in Detroit. Image source: Audi AG.German luxury-car makerAudi AG(NASDAQOTH: AUDVF) unveiled a big new SUV in Detroit this past   Monday. The Audi Q8 Concept is technically just a show car
column2: but   Audi officials said that it's a close preview of an upcoming new   full-size luxury crossover SUV from the German brand.makeArticleAd();But in addition to being a preview of Audi's new flagship   crossover SUV
column3: it's also a preview of something else: The   approach that Audi and its corporate parent will take to get   past the diesel-emissions cheating scandal.What it is: A preview of a new flagship SUV for AudiFirst and foremost
column4: although the Q8 at the North American   International Auto Show in Detroit is officially a ""concept
column5: or   show vehicle
column6: Audi officials were clear: Something very much like   it
column7: probably with the Q8 name
column8: will arrive at dealers in   2018.If so
column9: the upcoming new Q8 will be a high-tech luxury   powerhouse with a profile that hints at the classic Audi Quattro   models of the 1980s. Audi describes its shape as ""an elegant   alternative to the robust presence"" of a typical big SUV.It is that. The Q8 Concept is big
column10: with high sides. But   up close it seems well scaled
column11: not enormous -- despite its very   big wheels (23 inches) and tires. Inside
column12: it's spacious
column13: with an   attractive design and Audi's usual top-notch materials and fit   and finish. The Concept's interior features an elaborate series   of touchscreen displays and a heads-up display for the driver;   it's unclear exactly how much of that will make it into the   production model. But much of it might.The Audi Q8 Concept's interior. Image source: Audi AG.The plug-in hybrid drivetrain seems more likely to make it to   production. It combines Audi's 3.0-liter turbo V6 with a   100-kilowatt electric motor for a combined equivalent of 443   horsepower and a beefy 516 pounds-feet of torque
column14: which should   make the Q8 a lively driver. The Concept's 17.9 kilowatt-hour   lithium-ion battery pack is good for an electric-only range of   just over 37 miles
column15: Audi said.""The Q8 concept is an Audi in peak form. It demonstrates the   strengths of our brand in both technology and design while   providing a glimpse at a future full-size
column16: production SUV
column17: said   Dietmar Voggenreiter
column18: Audi's chief of sales and marketing. ""With   its next-generation display and control solutions
column19: we are   enabling customers to experience connectivity in a whole new   way.""Why it's important: The Q8 Concept signals Audi's move past   the diesel messAudi
column20: of course
column21: is a subsidiary of German auto giantVolkswagen AG(NASDAQOTH: VLKAY)
column22: which is currently contending with a massive   (and massively costly) scandal after it admitted to programmingmillions of diesel-powered vehiclesto cheat on government emissions tests.Audi hasn't been tainted by the scandal to anything like the   same extent at VW's namesake brand. But like VW
column23: it needs to show   that it willmove past the diesel messinto a (cleaner) future -- and like VW
column24: it plans to do that by   putting a very strong emphasis on electrified drivetrains.Another view of the Audi Q8 Concept on Audi's show stand in   Detroit. Image source: Audi AG.Audi plans tolaunch an all-electric SUV next year. That's expected to provide some serious competition toTesla Motors'(NASDAQ: TSLA) Model X. But it's likely to be a niche product
column25: at least for the near future. Sophisticated plug-in hybrid   drivetrains like the one in the Q8 Concept will be the   mass-market alternative until pure-electric vehicles move more   fully into the automotive mainstream.It's likely that the production Q8 will feature a series of   gasoline engines as well as a plug-in hybrid version. But the   plug-in hybrid as Audi has presented it here is important: Rather   than positioning it primarily as an eco-friendly drivetrain
column26: Audi   talked up its performance.That probably reflects a lesson learned from Tesla: Customers   will line up for electric vehicles (and by extension
column27: plug-in   hybrids) if they're exciting and offer somethingmorethan gasoline-only alternatives. The Q8 Concept signals that Audi   is thinking along those lines for its upcoming flagship SUV.   That's a good sign.10 stocks we like better than Volkswagen AGWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why Hawaii Is Becoming the Proving Ground for the Future of Energy Storage;1/14/2017;"The islands of Hawaii are known for their gorgeous landscapes   and world famous beaches
column2: but they're probably not the first   place you think of when you think of renewable energy. But they   should be.Hawaii is the first state in the U.S. where rooftop solar has   become an almost standard item on homes and businesses
column3: something   I personally witnesses recently driving around the islands of   O'ahu and Kaua'i. Solar panels are also in places unthinkable in   other locations. They face north
column4: they're covered by trees
column5: and   some look like they're barely attached to the roof itself. But   Hawaiians find solar to be so economical that almost all solar   makes sense
column6: and they are increasingly finding energy storage an   economical solution as well. Understanding just how energy   storage is working here can help us understand why companies are   proving their technologies of the future on the Hawaiian   Islands.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Island energy doesn't look like continental U.S.     energyOn average
column7: U.S. residential consumers pay 12.45 cents per kWh   for electricity. Prices vary by state in the continental U.S.
column8: from 9.33 cents per kWh in Louisiana to 19.95 cents per kWh in   Connecticut
column9: but the prices in the lower 48 states pale in   comparison to those in Hawaii.According to the EIA
column10: in October 2016 residential electricity   prices in Hawaii were 27.54 cents per kWh
column11: and on the island of   Kaua'i rates are 32.78 per kWh starting this year. That makes   solar extremely viable given the fact that power purchase   agreements for residential projects can be found for less than   $0.13 per kWh. Utility contracts are going for less than $0.05   per kWh. And the difference means energy storage can make   financial sense as well.Big investments being made on Kaua'iSolarCity andTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) were the first big investors in Kaua'i
column12: building a   13 MW solar plant and 52 MWh battery system. They combined with   24 MW of existing solar power to provide as much as 13 MW of   power to the grid during evening's peak hours of 5 p.m. to 10   p.m. The reported price per kWh of electricity from the   Tesla/SolarCity system was 14.5 cents per kWh.This week
column13: AES Corp announced a deal to build a 28 MW solar   farm with a 100 MWh battery system attached. This time
column14: electricity will be sold to KIUC for 11 cents per kWh. When   completed
column15: Kaua'i will get over 50% of its electricity from   renewable sources.In less than a year and a half between the Tesla/SolarCity   deal and the AES deal
column16: the cost of solar+storage fell 30%. And it   shouldn't go unnoticed that the price of electricity is now below   the retail rate most consumers pay in the continental U.S. Hawaii   is proving that a 100% renewable energy future is not only   possible
column17: it's closer than you might think.Islands are the new proving groundsSunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR)  won a bid to build a similar system in the   French West Indies and Corsica. The company will build 20.7 MW of   solar power plants on the islands and five projects totaling 18.4   MW of solar power that will include energy storage.Islands around the world rely on burning diesel for   electricity
column18: so they're taking notice to the falling cost of   solar+storage.Solar+storage is the next big energy trendSolar energy contracts in the U.S. are now below $0.05 per   kWh
column19: and by the end of 2017 we should see contracts below $0.04   per kWh. So solar energy is competitive with new fossil fuel   plants on a per unit of energy basis. But the intermittency of   renewables is still a challenge
column20: something batteries can help   address.What Kaua'i is showing is that combining solar with energy   storage can create an economical energy combination that can   supply electricity beyond the hours the sun is out. The cost of   $0.11 per kWh is economical for a Hawaiian island
column21: and with   consistent cost reductions over the next decade it could be   economical for some states in the U.S. as well. And as   solar+storage becomes a very real option for utilities
column22: businesses
column23: and homeowners it will change the way we think about   energy forever.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: This Week in Solar;1/13/2017;"Normally
column2: this is the weekly recap where I cover the breaking   news from solar companies around the world
column3: from new project   signings to bankruptcies. But this week
column4: the industry's focus has   been on a much bigger picture: policy and advocacy. From   California to Washington D.C.
column5: investors will want to buckle in   for a wild ride in the solar energy space over the next few   years.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();California may make solar mandatoryAt the start of 2017
column6: San Francisco made solar energy   mandatory for all new buildings that are 10 stories or fewer. And   the election of Scott Wiener
column7: the author of that bill
column8: to the   state senate hasbrought the idea to the Capitol. Wiener has brought a summary proposal for legislation that   would take the mandate statewide
column9: which could end up in full   legislative form within a couple of months.Mandating solar on new buildings would be a huge boost for the   solar industry
column10: but it would have an ancillary benefit of being   much cheaper than solar through traditional sales channels. Sales   and marketing costs have proven to be very high for solar because   sales staff often have to visit each home individually.Tesla Motors'(NASDAQ: TSLA) SolarCity
column11: in particular
column12: has had to lower its   installation guidance multiple times over the past year
column13: and   costs have spiked because sales are becoming more difficult.But knowing that new buildings have to have solar would help   lower sales costs
column14: and having the cost of solar rolled into a   mortgage would lower financing costs
column15: as well. The result should   be a combination of lower costs for solar buyers and/or higher   margins for installers. What companies will want to do next is   partner with builders to efficiently sell their systems
column16: which is   where it's notable thatSunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR) already has partnerships with seven of the 10   largest homebuilders in the country. That could be an advantage   if the California mandate passes.The solar industry's biggest voice may be President     ObamaSolar energy has grown by leaps and bounds over the last eight   years
column17: increasing from 1.3 GW installed in 2008 to an expected   14.1 GW in 2016. And investors have to keep in mind that   subsidies and policies at the federal
column18: state
column19: and local levels   have helped drive that growth.Along with falling costs
column20: the federal investment tax credit
column21: state renewable mandates
column22: and policies likePURPAhave helped drive the industry forward. The concern within   the industry is that the new presidential administration and   Congress will tear down some of that support. One of the biggest   supporters of solar energy
column23: President Obama
column24: happens to be in the   White House for a few more days
column25: and he recently made a   compelling case for more investment in the future in aSciencearticle titled
column26: ""The irreversible momentum of clean energy
column27: saying in part:This should not be a partisan issue. It is good business and     good economics to lead a technological revolution and define     market trends. And it is smart planning to set long-term     emission-reduction targets and give American companies
column28: entrepreneurs
column29: and investors certainty so they can invest [in]     and manufacture the emission-reducing technologies that we can     use domestically and export to the rest of the world.Policy matters in the solar industry
column30: and to maintain   favorable policies that will drive future growth
column31: the industry   needs to have a positive message to sell to all Americans.   President Obama may emerge as the loudest voice for the industry
column32: and the message he outlined above is as good as anyone can ask   for
column33: no matter which way you lean politically.The biggest rooftop solar system in the worldTesla's Gigafactory will break a lot of records
column34: but one   important one will be the fact that it's expected to install the   biggest rooftop solar system in the world
column35: at 70 MW. That's about   seven times the second-largest array anywhere else in the   world.If the plant is going to get 100% of its energy from renewable   energy
column36: the roof is a good place to start. This also likely will   be a proving ground for SolarCity's solar panels that will be   produced in Buffalo
column37: New York.Tesla is certainly putting its money where its mouth is when   it comes to renewable energy. And powering what will eventually   be the biggest factory in the world with renewable energy is a   big endorsement of Tesla's overall vision of the future. Solar   energy is literally going to help keep the lights on.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Dont Sweat Analysts Unenthused Response to Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Battery Factory;1/13/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEarlier this week
column3: Tesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) finally put its ballyhooed gigafactory into motion
column4: beginning the production oflithium-ion batteries in Sparks
column5: Nevadain front of a crowd of a few hundred interested parties. TSLA stock soared on the heels of the event
column6: of course
column7: jumping nearly 5% the day it officially flipped the switch to ""on
column8: and then continued to rally. Indeed
column9: Tesla stock has rallied 27% since early November
column10: mostly in anticipation of the milestone event.Source: ShutterstockAnd yet
column11: while the market and most retail investors were clearly impressed
column12: more than a handful of analysts weren't. Their concerns?makeArticleAd();A lack of fiscal details about how the battery plant will impact the company's books
column13: for one. Another worry was about the sheer cost of the facility itself. Still another was whether the Model 3 may not be profitable when it finally goes into production.With all due respect to those professionals
column14: you want to start worrying about these things now?Now?!?Yes. No. Maybe.Just for the record
column15: yes
column16: I'm the same guy who's been more critical than constructive on Tesla Motors over the years (likehere
column17: hereandhere).7 ""New Industrial"" Stocks to Bore You to the     BankBut
column18: my pessimism was never to suggest that Tesla's take on electric vehicles wasn't game-changing. The companyhasmainstreamed EVs. Its carsareengineering marvels. My concerns were simply rooted in the notion that most investors had unrealistic expectations; the masses couldn't distinguish between Tesla Motors being a trade or an investment.In retrospect
column19: it's not clear if the analyst community was able to distinguish between the two either.Take the comments from Goldman Sachs analyst David Tamberrino as an example.He said
column20: following Tuesday's event at the facility:""Overall we found the tour helpful in illustrating the layout and process for manufacturing lithium ion battery cells and packs for its automotive and energy products. However
column21: there was a lack of quantitative updates for 2017 and the ramp expectations.""Fair enough. Just bear in mind
column22: however
column23: that Goldmanupgraded Tesla stock to a ""buy"" in May of last year- when the battery factory was well underway - with analyst Patrick Archambault commenting ""We do not believe Tesla shares are fully capturing the company's disruptive potential.""So  is Tesla any less disruptive now that it's making its own batteries en masse? The stock isn't any higher now than it was then
column24: but Goldman's current rating on TSLA is ""neutral.""Granted
column25: Goldman was just days away from underwriting another secondary offering of TSLA stock in May but the company didn't know anylessabout the math of the gigafactory than it knows now. The only real difference between then and now is the stock's price.Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas was also worried about Tesla's lack of fiscal details now that the factory is in production
column26: just as much as he's worried that another round of fundraising is in the cards. Again
column27: however
column28: that's nothing new for Tesla Motors
column29: and it wasn't a problem for Jonas back in 2014 when he doubled Morgan Stanley's price target on TSLA stock
column30: to $320 per share.He notedat the time:""If it can be a leader in commercializing battery packs
column31: investors may never look at Tesla the same way again  Tesla says it will team up with partners to build the world's largest Li-ion battery pack facility in the US. We reflect the potential for lower battery costs through higher sales volume nearly doubling Tesla's share of the global car market to 90bps by 2028
column32: driving our target increase.""Teslaisclearly going to have that ""world's largest Li-ion battery pack facility"" Jonas was stoked about three years ago. And
column33: there's at least alittlemore clarity now than there was then. Yet
column34: Morgan Stanley's current rating on Tesla stock is a modest ""equal weight"" despite clear progress being made since the 2014 call that said such progress would be compelling.The stock never even threatened to reach $320.And that's when it hits you  some (though not all) analysts are just taking their best guess on TSLA
column35: beingled bythe rhetoric rather thanleadingthe rhetoric.To be fair
column36: that's what analyst do.And it's not easy.Opinions should be updated as new information surfaces.On the other hand
column37: the ebb and flow between quantitative and qualitative analysis from some analysts has made it tough for investors to digest those professional insights. The things that didn't matter before - like profits or perpetual fund-raising - can't be too big of a deal for the stock now.Here's Where Apple Inc. (AAPL) Dominated     Holiday SalesIn other words
column38: don't sweat the naysayers' opinions too much.Bottom Line for TSLA StockNone of this is to suggest TSLA is inevitably going to skyrocket higher
column39: nor is it to imply Tesla stock is doomed; the actual outcome is apt to be somewhere in between the two extreme opinions. It's simply to point out that of all the reasons you may want to worry about owning Tesla shares
column40: the lackluster response from analysts regarding the gigafactory is the least of them. Those guys are largely expected to say something in response to milestone events
column41: and many of the pessimistic comments were off-the-cuff sound bites not meant to be taken as a complete analysis.As of this writing
column42: James Brumley did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Dividend Growth Stocks That Simply Print     Money7 Cheap Stocks to Buy That Could Double in     2017The postDon't Sweat Analysts' Unenthused Response to Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Battery Factoryappeared first onInvestorPlace."

kWh.Georgia- 16 cents per minute for tier 2 and 8 cents per minute for tier   1.Idaho-12 cents per kWh.Illinois- 15 cents per kWh.Indiana- 16 cents per minute for tier 2 and 8 cents per minute for
