column16: however
column17: with would-be iPhone buyers now reportedly holding out for an iPhone 8. It leads one to wonder if the consumer response to the iPhone 8 will be as lackluster as the response to the iPhone 7 has been
column18: with the bulk of them holding out for what will be the iPhone 8s or the iPhone 9.And that's when it hits AAPL investors right in the gut at some point
column19: the company has to sell iPhones right here
column20: right now
column21: and grow those sales as Apple managed to all the way through the iPhone 6.Perhaps the crux of the problem isn't would-be buyers waiting for the next version. Perhaps most everyone who is going to own any smartphone has a phone they can live with for a while. Perhaps competitors have finally figured out how to make a smartphone that's just as impressive as the iPhone used to be compared to alternatives. As mobile industry consultantChetan Sharma observed:""Apple has the strongest ecosystem
column22: with its hardware
column23: software and app and content stores. iPhone users looking for an upgrade stick with Apple. But in a year when Samsung dropped the ball in a huge way
column24: Apple didn't have a phone with a compelling enough feature set to lure Samsung owners away.""And make no mistake - the iPhone 7 hasn't been flying off the shelves the way it was expected to. Two weeks ago
column25: the Nikkei Asian Review reported the companycut its planned Q1-2017 production of the iPhone 7 by 10%compared to iPhone production from a year earlier [production of the iPhone 6s].Let's also not forget that in September
column26: for the first time in years
column27: Apple unexpectedly opted to not share figures from the first weekend's sales of the iPhone 7. The company said they no longer mattered. Others believed the company simply didn't want to report weaker results.The iPhone 8 Can't Stop the InevitableBut can the iPhone 8 turn things around for the company
column28: and relight a fire underneath AAPL stock?Maybe. The usual supporters are certainly hard at work again
column29: pointing out theall-glass body
column30: edge-to-edge screen
column31: and the OLED display. They all seem and sound like improvements to its predecessor. With the exception to the rumored wireless charging though
column32: the rumored specs may well be solutions to problems that don't actually exist.That has not prevented many people - including analysts - from predicting big things from the iPhone 8.Nomura Securities
column33: as an example
column34: believes the iPhone 8 will break all previous iPhone sales records. Just remember
column35: though
column36: it was Nomura that also said demand for the iPhone 7 waseven stronger than it had expected
column37: and that the supply chain was on the verge of ramping up production of the device. Nomuraraised its price target on AAPL stockfrom $120 to $135 in response.In the meantime
column38: not only have Apple shares not rallied to $135 (or even $120) on the heels of what was supposed to be a big catalyst
column39: we've seen multiple reports suggesting demand for the device wasquickly quelled.Why Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Will Gain 20% in     2017Point being
column40: take any optimism surrounding the iPhone 8 with a grain of salt. We've heard it before with the iPhone 7
column41: and it was wrong.Bottom Line for AAPL StockStill
column42: there's no denying the iPhone has earned a spot in the smartphone hall of fame. Though it wasn't the first to develop such a product - that honor belongs toBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY) - Apple was the first to make the smartphone a mainstream consumer device
column43: and for years was the name all others aspired to be like.Nothing lasts forever though. While Apple and the iPhone will both be around for the long haul

column1: Another Reason Tesla and Trump May Be a Better Fit Than First Thought;1/7/2017;"After Donald Trump was elected to be the next president of the   United States in November
column2: shares of electric-car makerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA)  fell about 5% during the next seven days.   Some investors may have been concerned about how a   Republican-controlled White House and Congress could impact   electric-vehicle and solar incentives -- both of which play a   role in Tesla's business.But concerns about Tesla's prospects during a Trump presidency   have eased after the President-elect invited Tesla CEO Elon Musk   to his Tech Summit meeting
column3: and even appointed him to his   Strategic and Policy forum. Indeed
column4: Tesla stockproceeded to soar 17.5% in December.Now
column5: investors may have another reason not to worry about   Tesla's potential during a Trump administration: Elon Musk thinks   the Trump administration could surprise when it comes to   renewables.makeArticleAd();Tesla factory in Fremont
column6: CA. Image source: The Motley   Fool.Report: Trump may be ""positive on renewables""In a telling report fromElectrek
column7: managing editor Fred Lambert noted that investors attending   Tesla's Gigafactory event this week said Musk was actually upbeat   about Trump's plans for renewables:The President-elect has a strong emphasis on U.S.     manufacturing and so do we. We are building the biggest factory     in the world right here
column8: creating U.S. jobs... I think we may     see some surprising things from the next administration. We     don't think they will be negative on fossil fuels... but they     may also be positive on renewables.While it's impossible to know exactly how the Trump   administration may ""be positive on renewables
column9: Musk's words   about the President-elect should carry some weight after Musk'srecent face-to-face interactionswith Trump.Trump and Musk's shared vision for jobsIt's possible that Trump could be positive on green   technologies because of the potential jobs that could be created   from nascent renewables segments. It's no secret that one of   Trump's top priorities when he takes office is to create domestic   manufacturing jobs. And Musk's Tesla is arguably leading the   charge in the U.S. when it comes to job creation.Tesla alone has created over 13
column10: 000 jobs in the U.S.   (excluding contractors)
column11: most of which are manufacturing related.   And the Tesla-acquired SolarCity has created about 12
column12: 000 U.S.   jobs. Yet Tesla is just getting started.The company recently announced amajor expansionto its car factory in California -- the expansion will create   about 3
column13: 000 more jobs. Further
column14: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has said its   Gigafactory in Nevada will likely employ around 10
column15: 000 people at   peak production
column16: and indirectly create between 20
column18: 000   additional jobs in surrounding regions.Tesla's under-construction Gigafactory in Nevada. Measured by   footprint
column19: the factory will be the largest building in the world   when it's complete. Image source: Tesla Motors.Notably
column20: however the Trump administration may impact   electric-vehicle and solar incentives
column21: Musk is confident Tesla   will thrive. Indeed
column22: Musk even noted in a November shareholder   meeting about the company's acquisition of SolarCity that he   believedTesla's competitive position would increaseif electric-vehicle incentives were removed
column23: since under the   current zero-emission vehicle mandates
column24: competitors would be able   to monetize their zero-emission vehicle credits at face value   while Tesla would only get about $0.50 on the dollar for its   credits.Still
column25: Musk is far from being against renewables incentives.   During the same shareholder meeting
column26: he said that Tesla does   believe ""there should be incentives."" But Musk said he believes   the incentives should exist ""for the good of the industry and to   accelerate the advent of sustainable transport
column27: not because Tesla   needs them.""Whatever the fate is for renewables mandates and incentives   after Trump takes the Oval Office

column1: This Week in Solar;1/6/2017;"After a year of both progress and stock market turmoil
column2: the   solar industry is likely facing a year of transition in 2017.   Companies are cutting costs so they can stay afloat
column3: and   positioning themselves for growth with new products. This week
column4: a   few companies moved in different directions in relation to those   goals.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Solar ends 2016 in a great positionIf you're hoping to see more solar power produced around the   world
column5: you should be very encouraged by new data fromBloomberg New Energy Finance. The group recently reported that the cost of building a solar   power plant is down 62% since 2009
column6: and new contracts in Chile   and the UAE have been signed for less than 3 cents per kWh
column7: a   price that would beat any new coal plant.Solar is already highly cost effective in sunny countries
column8: but   what's even more encouraging is that costs will likely be lower   than coal in nearly every country within a decade. It's easy to   see how solar could be cost effective today in Chile
column9: Dubai
column10: or   states in the American Southwest
column11: but the fact that it's becoming   price competitive in the U.K.
column12: Canada
column13: and U.S. states like   Minnesota has to be encouraging for the industry.The Gigafactory finally gets off the groundA lot has been written aboutTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) Gigafactory over the last few years
column14: but this week   Tesla and Panasonic announced the facility is actually producing   battery cells. Eventually
column15: the low-cost
column16: high-performance 2170   cells jointly developed by the two companies will end up in   Tesla's Model 3. But for now
column17: those coming off the assembly line   will be put into the Powerwall 2 and Powerpack 2.2017 could be a big year for Tesla's energy storage business   as utilities put rates in place that make home energy storage   more viable
column18: and large-scale storage solutions start to be good   options for utilities themselves. And now
column19: some of those   batteries will be coming from Tesla's Gigafactory.Is another residential solar growth story going     bust?Last summer
column20: residential solar company Sungevity seemed to   have found a bailout from Easterly Acquisition Corp.
column21: which would   have performed a reverse merger to take the company public. As   part of the deal
column22: Sungevity would have gotten access to $200   million of capital
column23: which could have kept it afloat while   management tried to steer it toward profitability.After the first of the year
column24: the reverse merger is off
column25: and   Sungevity seems to be in serious trouble. This isn't going to   upend residential solar as we know it because Sungevity had just   a 1.6% market share
column26: according toGTM Research. But it's a sign of how difficult the business has been for   companies in the past year. Tesla's SolarCity had to lower its   guidance multiple times
column27: and most companies had to pivot to   offering loans instead of long-term lease deals. Sungevity's   potential collapse is a another reminder of how hard it is to   make money in the rooftop solar business.Canadian Solar monetizes assetsThe year 2017 is going to be a tough year for solar panel   manufacturers and developers as demand sags and panel prices   continue slump. One of the ways companies are preparing for that   is by monetizing assets they have on their balance sheets.Canadian Solar Inc.(NASDAQ: CSIQ) did that just before the end of the year
column28: selling   20 MW of Canadian projects for $115 million and two more power   plants in China for $32.2 million.The cash can now be used to pay down debt
column29: reducing risk for   the business
column30: or sit on the balance sheet to create a cushion. No   matter how you look at it
column31: an infusion of $147.2 million is good   for Canadian Solar long term.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: As Calpers Flails
column2: Dont Bank on Your Pension;1/5/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMillions of Americans are partially or wholly banking on some form of pension funds for retirement
column4: whether they they work for a large corporation
column5: a municipality or a given state. The problem is that many of these pensions - such as Calpers
column6: which is the pension and health benefits system for well more than a million of California's public employees - are underfunded.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockWhat's ""underfunded"" mean
column7: exactly? It means many of these pension funds do not have adequate assets to pay out the full 100% of benefits due to their workers for the entire period of time they are projected to have to do so.That means that all government workers need to be aware that they cannot
column8: and should not
column9: assume their pension funds will provide for them in retirement.Instead
column10: you need to have alternative plans in place
column11: and that means investing on your own right now. Start learning the basics
column12: and start setting money aside. (Andsign up for a stock advisory newsletter like The Liberty Portfolio
column13: which I'll be launching shortly.)Calpers - the California Public Employees' Retirement System - has been in the news quite a bit this past year. Andbecause it is only 76% funded

column1: Nothing Can Stop the Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Freight Train;1/5/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlthough many analysts are putting aqualified success anglefor this year's retail holiday season
column4: there's no hiding the ugly truth - retail stocks are languishing.Source: ShutterstockSure
column5: the Black Friday weekend got off to agreat start
column6: but that has much to do with stores opening on Thanksgiving Day.makeArticleAd();Brick-and-mortar retailers are still finding it difficult to attract shoppers. The one bright spot is e-commerce. Unfortunately for everyone else
column7: that is a domain becoming increasingly swallowed up byAmazon.com
column8: Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN).A cursory look at major retail stocks gives you all the info you need to know. Shares ofWal-Mart Stores
column9: Inc. (NYSE:WMT) andTarget Corporation(NYSE:TGT) have given up a significant portion of their post-election rallies.For the month of December
column10: WMT slipped 1% below parity
column11: while TGT fell by more than 7%. And it wasn't just discount retailers
column12: either. High-end names such asNordstrom
column13: Inc. (NYSE:JWN) andWilliams Sonoma
column14: Inc. (NYSE:WSM) have absorbed horrible losses in the markets.5 Stocks to Buy for a Big JanuaryEven AMZN stock was not immune from the pain. Since closing at an all-time high in early October
column15: Amazon stock has given up more than 11%. Worse yet
column16: shares didn't seem to gain much traction. While AMZN closed out the year up 11%
column17: that may be little comfort to those who are assessing the nearer-term momentum. AMZN stock has been sandwiched between its 50- and 200-day moving averages for some time
column18: suggesting pensiveness among the bulls.A Challenging Environment for AMZN StockI think anybody can appreciate the lack of confidence toward AMZN stock. Wall Street is about making profits
column19: not pontificating about prior achievements. If there's one thing that can disrupt Amazon stock
column20: it would be declining consumer sentiment. To that end
column21: reduced advertisementsby retailers is a worrisome sign.Click to EnlargeThis is where hard data can help distinguish between either a natural correction for AMZN stock
column22: or something more permanent. According to the U.S. Census Bureau
column23: e-commerce is anunstoppable force.In the six years from 2000 through the end of 2005
column24: online retail sales totaled $326.6 million. In last year alone
column25: that figure jumped to $341.5 million. By default
column26: this just feeds into the Amazon stock machine.But more so than the raw numbers
column27: the growth rate in online retailing continues to impress. Of course
column28: nothing will come close to the nascent years of e-commerce. In the 2000s
column29: online sales grew annually by 21%. But over the past six years
column30: the growth rate is still a robust 15%. Since all indications point to a superior performance in the fourth quarter of 2016
column31: that rate is only going higher.This is simply great news for AMZN stock. Admittedly
column32: though
column33: its success is coming at great cost to the overall industry. Whiletotal retailsales exclusive of food services is a massive entity
column34: the percentage of shoppers doing business online is skewing unfavorably for the brick-and-mortars.A prime example is the immediate fallout from the Great Recession. Retail overall saw negative growth in 2008 and 2009
column35: particularly seriously during the latter. In contrast
column36: e-commerce growth was hit hard
column37: but never dipped into the red thanks to companies like AMZN. In addition
column38: aggregate retail sales this decade average an anemic 4.5%.Amazon Demonstrates Why It's the BestI think we also need to acknowledge another basic reality - AMZN is a freak of nature. Despite difficult circumstances for its land-based competitors
column39: the e-commerce giant finds new ways to leap above the fray. Case in point is the more thanone billion productsthat were pushed out the door due to its Prime and Fulfillment services. That has to be a major letdown for Amazon stock competitors
column40: who are trying to find some way of remotely keeping pace.An even greater challenge is addressing the in-house sales that the Seattle-based company generates. Demand for the Echo speakers that are an accessory to Amazon's Alexa voice recognition software jumped nine fold from last year's holiday season. According to their senior management team
column41: the Echo was flying off the shelf despite a significant boost in production. If there's just one reason to buy AMZN stock
column42: that might be it.Finally
column43: the most impressive element of the organization is that they haven't lost their hunger for innovation.Amazon Go- the firm's foray into the ultra-competitive grocery sector - is nothing short of astonishing. Layered with consumer-centric technologies that represents a paradigm shift in shopping
column44: AMZN takes integration to a new level. Thus
column45: an investment in AMZN stock is an investment into the future.The Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Gigafactory Is a     Make-or-Break StrategyI can only come to one conclusion. Amazon stock is as sure of a long-term bet as anything else in the markets. Not only is it dominating its own industry
column46: AMZN is disrupting others. It is both retailer and producer - and it does both things amazingly well.Finally
column47: it has enough moxie and leverage to compete in utterly foreign sectors. Again
column48: there's nothing out there quite like AMZN stock.As of this writing

column1: GoPro Inc (GPRO) Announces Karma Drone Re-Launch in 2017;1/5/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCES 2017 is in full swing and many tech companies are there showing off their new gear. Some are using the event and its concentration of journalists to explain what went wrong last year and what their plans are to make things right.GoProInc(NASDAQ:GPRO) is in the latter camp.Click to EnlargeSource: GoProThe company chose the Consumer Electronics Show to announce it will re-launch the GoPro Karma drone in 2017.makeArticleAd();GoPro was one of the top tech news stories of 2016
column3: but not in a good way. Seeking to diversify beyond action cameras
column4: GPRO released the GoPro Karma
column5: its first entry in the drone market. However the the Karma dronewas a disaster from the start
column6: despite an innovative folding design.The release itself was months later than expected. And once the Karma drone was officially unveiled
column7: DJI- the Chinese company that leads the consumer drone market - announced a compact folding drone of its own.5 Stocks to Buy for a Big JanuaryThe DJI Mavic included a 4K camera while costing the same as the entry-level GoPro Karma (which did not include a camera)
column8: effectively undercutting its price by several hundred dollars. Adding insult to injury
column9: the DJI Mavic was availablebeforethe GoPro Karma could hit store shelves.Then things went from bad to worse for GPRO. The GoPro Karma drones it did sell starting in September began falling out of the sky. This forced the company to recall the Karma drone.GPRO Stock Takes a BeatingGoing into the holiday shopping season
column10: GPRO was facing a PR issue with its recalled Karma drone. It had no drones to sell
column11: leaving consumers looking for big-ticket
column12: high-tech gifts to buy the DJI Mavic instead.Following the Karma recall
column13: the company was forced tolay off 200 employees(15% of its staff) and the company's president left amid the restructuring. Earnings were missed - badly - and GoPro stock took a beating.The company desperately needs some good news to kick off 2017.GoPro Karma Will Re-Launch in 2017Rather than demonstrate new products at the Consumer Electronics Show
column14: GPRO is there ""demonstrating recent product breakthroughs."" The biggest breakthrough of all for the company is a resolution to the Karma drone crisis.GoPro chose CES 2017 to announce it willre-launch the Karma drone in 2017. According to GoPro
column15: the issue that brought its drones out of the sky has been identified as ""power loss due to a mechanical issue related to securing the drone's battery.""GoPro says it has fixed the design flaw and is currently finishing up testing. It says further details will be provided in February outlining the plans for the GoPro Karma worldwide re-launch.2016 was not a great year for GPRO. Demand for action cameras softened even as additional competitors entered the market and smartphones began to emerge as a threat:Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) released a water-resistant iPhone 7 that could shoot 4K video and 120 frames per second slow motion 1080p video. There were manufacturing challenges with its new Hero5 camera and the Karma drone recall capped things off. After the dust settled
column16: GoPro stock shed over 50% of its value in 2016.However
column17: GPRO was able to sell the Karma Grip (handheld camera stabilizer) component of the Karma drone separately in time for Christmas
column18: and the company reportedGoPro camera sales up 35% on Black Fridaycompared to the previous year.If it is able to successfully re-launch the GoPro Karma in 2017 it will have missed out on the 2016 holiday shopping season
column19: but will have most of the year to build up sales and recognition leading into next Christmas.The Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Gigafactory Is a     Make-or-Break StrategySince announcing the Karma drone re-launch
column20: GoPro stock is up over 2.5%
column21: reflecting the possibility that the company is finally putting a terrible 2016 behind it.As of this writing
column22: Brad Moon did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceCES 2017: The Hottest Headlines From Media Day     13 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in     2017The postGoPro Inc (GPRO) Announces Karma Drone Re-Launch in 2017appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Tesla Motors
column2: Inc. Stock Soared in December;1/5/2017;"What happenedShares of electric-car makerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) soared 17.5% in December
column3: according to data   provided byS&P Global Market Intelligence. The stock's rise helped it recover some of its pullback earlier   in the year.The Tesla Model S. Image source: The Motley Fool.makeArticleAd();So whatThere's no surefire reason for Tesla's 17.5% gain during the   month
column4: but one did stand out as the most likely catalyst for at   least a portion of the gain.Tesla stockhad pulled back in the weeks following the U.S. presidential   election
column5: perhaps because investors were concerned about how   Tesla could be impacted during Trump's time as president. Trump   has expressed disbelief about global warming and outlined actions   for eliminating some government spending related to climate   change. But sentiment about how Tesla might fare with Trump as   president turned rosier when the president-elect startedcozying up to Elon Musk. Trump invited the Tesla CEO to his tech summit meeting in New   York City
column6: and even appointed him to his Strategic and Policy   Forum.So
column7: Tesla stock may have simply rebounded in December from a   sell-off spurred by an overreaction to Trump's election. Of   course
column8: there were probably other factors driving the rebound
column9: such as theS&P 500's overall 2% gain during this period
column10: but Trump's warming up to   Musk was likely one of the main catalysts for Tesla stock during   the month.Now whatInvestors shouldn't read too much into month-to-month moves   like this
column11: but it is notable to see Trump keeping Musk close to   his side. Still
column12: investors may want to keep an eye on any   political action during Trump's presidency that could impact   Tesla.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column14: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column15: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column16: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla Motors wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: The Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Gigafactory Is a Make-or-Break Strategy;1/5/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe new year is shaping up to be a make-or-break year for electric vehicle innovatorTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA). That's because we finally get to see whether CEO Elon Musk's vision of a fully integrated clean-energy company - spanning production
column3: storage and end-use of renewable energy - can come to fruition. Needless to say
column4: TSLA stock holders will be watching with eyes as wide as dinner plates.Source:OnInnovation via FlickrLast year
column5: the major piece of the puzzle was the bailout buyout of fellow Musk company
column6: SolarCity. That deal will supposedly tuck in the generation part of the plan.makeArticleAd();But right now
column7: the story is all about storage. Tesla finally flipped the switch on its massive battery production facility - dubbed the Gigafactory.Without it
column8: there's no way Tesla Motors can deliver on its lofty long-term goals. Nor can the company support the lofty price on TSLA stock
column9: either.The Gigafactory not just a battery farm. It's a critical piece of the Tesla Motors story.Tesla's Big Plans for Its Big GigafactoryLithium batteries make the world go 'round. Storage of energy is a key component in basically everything
column10: from solar panels to your smartphone. And lithium battery production has long been dominated by Japan
column11: China
column12: and other southeast Asian nations;roughly 88%of the world's battery production comes from the region.Tesla's problem is an ambitious goal of delivering 500
column13: 000 vehicles in 2018  which will take a ton of lithium batteries. Current production isn't up to snuff
column14: by alot. There's a significant shortfall.Like most Elon Musk solutions
column15: Tesla's fix for its battery problem is a large one.5 Stocks to Buy for a Big JanuaryA few years ago
column16: TSLA partnered withPanasonic Corporation (ADR)(OTCMKTS:PCRFY) and started construction on a massive plant in the Nevada desert. The dubbed Gigafactory would design and build the needed batteries to arm itself - and potentially other vehicle makers
column17: electrics firms and others - with the needed batteries to store energy. Over the spring
column18: Musk and TSLA predicted that the facility would be able to crank outnearly 50 gigawatts worth of production by 2018- more than the world currently produces.On Wednesday
column19: Tesla Motors turned on the third of the Gigafactory that is completed and started production of batteries.The Gigafactory Is CriticalThe Gigafactory's launch is a significant moment for TSLA stock
column20: because it will help determine Tesla's ability to survive
column21: and how healthy that survival will look.Without the Gigafactory
column22: Tesla simply can't deliver on its EV production goals. The rest of the world does not make enough batteries
column23: period. Plus
column24: a lack of supply leads to another issue: affordability. The Model 3 is supposed to be an electric car for the masses that takes Tesla Motors from a hobby car for the rich to a staple for your average Joe.But current battery prices are too high to make the $35
column25: 000 vehicle profitable. And despite its cult stock following
column26: Tesla still is a publicly traded company
column27: and TSLA stock holders will increasingly demand profits.By building its batteries in-house
column28: Tesla should be able to drive down costs for the critical component and make the Model 3 a profitable endeavor. One would hope so
column29: considering that TSLA took out around$5 billion in debtto build the facility.Equally as important is TSLA's other plans for the facility. Musk & Co. are planning on building battery packs for energy storage from renewables and other sources. That includes its Powerwall and Powerpack batteries that store energy from its SolarCity and utility customers.This is a double-edged sword.Macy's Inc (M) Stock Plunges on Disastrous     Holiday Sales
column30: Job CutsEven amid a shortfall in batteries
column31: battery prices tanked last year. According toBloomberg's New Energy Finance unit
column32: prices for lithium batteries sank by 22% in 2016 and are estimated to fall by another 15% this year. That's great for Model 3 profits and sales to utility customers
column33: but not great for its actual battery production arm. If Tesla plans on selling its battery packs outside its doors - and it does based on its estimated production size and recent deals - then it needs to find the perfect price in the middle. Not too hot and not too cold.That needs to happen soon
column34: too. The first things rolling off the Gigafactory line are storage batteries
column35: not vehicle packs.This Is Everything to TSLA StockTesla's Gigafactory is a much-needed gamble. Without it
column36: Musk can't achieve his vision of having an integrated clean energy company. Tesla will never be able to sell enough cars cost-effectively
column37: get solar panels on everyone's roofs and provide energy storage for larger utility companies.Obviously
column38: if it can't do that
column39: TSLA stock is sunk. Tesla Motors already had enough mishaps on its own without SolarCity and the Gigafactory weighing it down under certain worse- and worst-case scenarios.Thus
column40: the Gigafactory is a make-or-break strategy in a make-or-break year for Tesla Motors. If Tesla's past is any indication
column41: things won't go perfectly smoothly - but they must go at least somewhat according to plan to keep TSLA from hurtling toward the earth.As of this writing
column42: Aaron Levitt did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Growth Stocks Set to Pop in 2017The 12 Best Fidelity 401k Funds to OwnThe 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The     Experts' PicksThe postThe Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Gigafactory Is a Make-or-Break Strategyappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Options Traders Expect Huge Moves in Tesla (TSLA) Stock;1/5/2017;"Investors in Tesla Motors
column2: Inc.TSLAneed to pay close attention to the stock based on moves in the options market lately. That is because the January 20th
column3: 2017 $50 Put had some of the highest implied volatility of all equity options today.What is Implied Volatility?Implied volatility shows how much movement the market is expecting in the future. Options with high levels of implied volatility suggest that investors in the underlying stocks are expecting a big move in one direction or the other. It could also mean there is an event coming up soon that may cause a big rally or a huge sell off. However
column4: implied volatility is only one piece of the puzzle when putting together anoptions tradingstrategy.What do the Analysts Think?Clearly
column5: options traders are pricing in a big move for Tesla shares
column6: but what is the fundamental picture for the company? Currently
column7: Tesla is a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) in the Automotive - Domestic industry that ranks in the Bottom 23% of our Zacks Industry Rank. Over the last 60 days
column8: no analysts have increased their earnings estimates for the current quarter
column9: while one analyst has revised the estimate downward. The net effect has taken our Zacks Consensus Estimate for the current quarter from a loss of 56 cents per share to a loss of 72 cents in that period.Given the way analysts feel about Tesla right now
column10: this huge implied volatility could mean there's a trade developing. Often times
column11: options traders look for options with high levels of implied volatility to sell premium. This is a strategy many seasoned traders use because it captures decay. At expiration
column12: the hope for these traders is that the underlying stock does not move as much as originally expected.Looking to Trade Options?Each week

column1: The Simple Reason I Won't Buy Tesla Motors Stock;1/4/2017;"Tesla CEO Elon Musk. Image source:OnInnovationvia Flickr. Copyright 2010 The Henry Ford. Republished underCC BY-ND 2.0.There is a simple reason I won't buy shares ofTesla Motors Inc.(NASDAQ: TSLA) : I don't trust founder-CEO Elon Musk.Let me explain. It's not that I think Musk is fundamentally   dishonest
column2: but rather that his grand unifying vision for his   company has blinded him to his responsibility to minority   shareholders and to the risks he is asking them to bear. The   Tesla Motorsacquisition-rescueof SolarCity Corp. is all the evidence I need to support that   proposition.makeArticleAd();In a deal with as much potential for conflict of interest as   this one
column3: I think Musk had a personal obligation to spell out the   enormous risks associated with the acquisition in a clear and   forthright manner
column4: instead of letting the lawyers address them in   legalese in the pages of a securities filing. He didn't.A tangled webIf you're reading this article
column5: I assume you're probably   familiar with the conflicts of interest I refer to above
column6: but let   me recap the most obvious ones for those readers who aren't:Musk is the co-founder
column7: chief executive
column8: chairman and     largest shareholder of electric car manufacturer Tesla Motors
column9: with a 20.8% stake.Musk was also the chairman and largest shareholder of solar     power system manufacturer SolarCity.Lyndon Rive
column10: SolarCity's then-CEO and board member
column11: is     Musk's cousin. Rive's co-founder
column12: his brother Peter Rive
column13: was     SolarCity's chief technology officer and a board member.Allow me to draw on one of the lessons that 50 years of   stewardship ofBerkshire Hathawaytaught CEO Warren Buffett. As he wrote in his golden anniversary   annual letter (emphasis mine):Several of my subsequent errors also involved the use of     Berkshire shares to purchase businesses whose earnings were     destined to simply limp along.Mistakes of that kind are deadly... Too often CEOs seem blind to an elementary reality: The     intrinsic value of the shares you give in an acquisition must     not be greater than the intrinsic value of the business you     receive.A losing exchangeTesla gave away 0.11 of its shares for every SolarCity share.   Here is what I think they received in return
column14: in terms of   intrinsic value: zero. That's what I think SolarCity is worth as   a going concern. It isn't profitable
column15: either under GAAP   (generally accepted accounting principles) or on a cash basis.   The most recent estimates have SolarCity recording an accounting   loss of close to a billion dollars in 2017
column16: following an   estimated $925 million loss in 2016.By the end of the third quarter of 2016
column17: SolarCity's cash had   declined to $259 million from $373 million 12 months prior --   despite having issued debt and equity totaling $849 million (net   basis) over that period. Yet Teslatouted as a financial benefitof the acquisition that it ""is expected to be additive to Tesla's   cash balance... We expect SolarCity to add more than half a   billion dollars in cash to Tesla's balance sheet over the next 3   years."" Here's to wishing!Apparently
column18: I'm not the only with genuine skepticism regarding   the equity value Tesla shareholders received in acquiring   SolarCity. In themerger proposalit filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Aug. 31
column19: Tesla revealed thatfifteeninstitutional investors had passed on acquiring SolarCity or even   simply making an equity investment in it
column20: and that the company   was facing a liquidity squeeze. On its most recent financials
column21: the company's Altman Z-score of -0.20 indicated a significant   risk of bankruptcy.""[A] match made in market heaven""With the acquisition by Tesla
column22: SolarCity has found a lifeline   such that financial distress is no longer imminent. However
column23: to   justify the acquisition on any basis other than as a rescue   operation
column24: you have to buy into Musk's vision of the rich   synergies between the two businesses. I don't. As New York   Universityfinance professor and valuation expert Aswath Damodaranwrotein September:I don't think that Tesla's Solar City acquisition passes     [either] the smell test (for conflict of interest) [or] the     common sense test (of creating value)
column25: but I am not a     shareholder in either Tesla or Solar City and I don't get a     vote. When Tesla shareholders vote
column26: given that owning the stock     is by itself an admission that they buy into the Musk vision
column27: I     would not be surprised if they go along with his     recommendations. Tesla shareholders and Elon Musk are a match     made in market heaven and I wish them the best of luck in their     life together.(Note: Tesla shareholders approved the acquisition on Nov. 17
column28: and the deal closed five days later.)Like Damodaran
column29: I'm not a Tesla shareholder. I respect Musk   for his entrepreneurial vision and for what he has achieved
column30: but   there is a fine line between visionary drive in emerging   industries and recklessness. As far as I'm concerned
column31: buying or   holding Tesla Motors shares at this point has more to do with   blind faith than investing.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column32: it can pay to listen. After all
column33: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column35: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla Motors wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of Nov. 7

column1: Why Tesla Motors' Guidance Misses Should Concern Investors;1/4/2017;"Tesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) said that it delivered about 22
column2: 200 vehicles in   the fourth quarter of 2016
column3: a number that left it short of its   own guidance for both the quarter and the full year.It's far from the first time that Tesla has missed its own   guidance
column4: of course. Investors appeared to take this latest   shortfall in stride. But the trend suggests that Tesla might miss   some key deadlines
column5: and that could have much more serious   consequences for the stock.""Short-term production challenges""Tesla's guidance had called for ""just over 25
column6: 000"" deliveries   in the fourth quarter and at least 80
column7: 000 for the full year. But   its fourth-quarter shortfall left its tally for the full year at   76
column8: 230 vehicles delivered to customers.makeArticleAd();Now in its fifth year of production
column9: Tesla's Model S may be   facing declining demand. Image source: Tesla Motors.In a statement late on Tuesday
column10: Tesla said that ""short-term   production challenges starting at the end of October and lasting   through early December"" left it scrambling to make up lost   production late in the quarter.Tesla blamed the ""challenges"" on its transaction to install   new hardware for its Autopilot driver-assist system. The company   said on October 19 that it would begin shipping all of its new   vehicles with thehardware necessary for fully autonomous   driving
column11: allowing it to gradually enable self-driving capabilities in   those cars with software updates over time.Tesla last reaffirmed its fourth-quarter guidance in a   shareholder letter on October 26. Apparently
column12: the ""production   challenges"" started in the days immediately following the   letter.Another in a long list of missed goalsTesla has a long history of missing its own targets
column13: whether   for sales totals
column14: profits
column15: or the timing of key product-related   events. CEO Elon Musk has acknowledged that the company sometimes   falls short
column16: saying that he sets ambitious goals for the company   as a way to motivate employees and suppliers.That may work
column17: but it makes it challenging for investors to   evaluate the company's stated business plans. Musk has said that   Tesla will begin production of its compact Model 3 sedan sometime   in 2017
column18: but many analysts feel that's unlikely.In a note on Tuesday before Tesla announced its delivery   totals
column19: Barclaysauto analyst Brian Johnson said that there's a high probability   that the company won't be able to deliver any Model 3s in   2017.Why Tesla's routine misses could eventually be trouble for   the stockViewed in the context of its past results
column20: Tesla's 2016   delivery total is impressive even if it fell short of Musk's   goal. But it's still far short of the hundreds of thousands -- or   millions -- of annual deliveries that Tesla will need to be a   viable automaker over the long term.Tesla has said that it has nearly 400
column21: 000 preorders for the   Model 3. But more and more big automakers are announcing plans to   bring long-range electric vehicles to market over the next few   years. (Just yesterday
column22: Ford Motor Company(NYSE: F) said that it will begin production of anelectric SUV with 300 miles of rangeby 2020.)If the Model 3 is delayed
column23: which seems likely given Tesla's   history
column24: that could mean that those orders won't be filled until   late 2018 or 2019. How many of those customers will give up and   choose an electric vehicle from a major automaker instead?Tesla had a significant technological advantage over the big   automakers when it first launched the Model S in 2012. But the   risk to Tesla as an investment has always been that the big   automakers might close the electric-vehicle technology gapbefore Tesla can get to sustainable scale
column25: leaving the upstart Silicon Valley automaker in an uphill   battle for market share against better-funded competition.That risk could become reality if the Model 3 is delayed   significantly. Tesla has built a great brand and the Model 3   will find buyers no matter what happens. But the longer it waits
column26: the harder it will be for Tesla to ramp up to the millions of   deliveries a year that it will need to support its current   sky-high valuation.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Tesla's Gigafactory Doubles in Size
column2: Brings Battery Cell Production to U.S.;1/4/2017;"When ItouredTesla Motors'(NASDAQ: TSLA) Gigafactory in July
column3: it was  already a   massive structure. With an 800
column4: 000-square-foot footprint and 1.9   million square feet of manufacturing space when including the   building's several levels
column5: the factory would take hours to walk   through. Even more
column6: the company had already tooled significant   portions of the factory and had begun streamlining production of   Tesla Energy packs (the cells used in the packs were still made   in Japan).Tesla's Gigafactory (with Model 3 sitting outside) when I   visited last July. Image source: author.makeArticleAd();But a tour of the Gigafactory today would reveal some massive   changes. First
column7: in less than six months
column8: the building's total   footprint has doubled to 1.9 million square feet and its   operational square feet is 2.6 times what it was
column9: at 4.9 million   square feet. Second -- and perhaps more important for Tesla's   business -- the company has already begun mass production of   lithium-ion battery cells at the factory.Building battery cells""Today at the Gigafactory
column10: Tesla and Panasonic began mass   production of lithium-ion battery cells
column11: Tesla announced in a   blog post on Wednesday.Tesla said it will be mass producing its new high-performance   cylindrical ""2170 cell
column12: which CEO Elon Musk has said is both the   highest energy density cell in the world and is also the   cheapest.Production of battery cells for qualification purposes started   at the Gigafactory last month
column13: the company said. But today's   production is meant for Tesla's energy storage products
column14: including its Powerwall 2 and its Powerpack 2 energy storage   products. And Model 3 is up next
column15: with cell production for the   vehicle's batteries scheduled to begin in Q2.Tesla's ability to quickly expand production from energy   storage packs to battery cells for energy storage products and   its Model 3 continues to highlight the company's aggressive and   unique construction approach of building the Gigafactory in   phases so that Tesla
column16: Panasonic
column17: and other Tesla partners can begin manufacturing immediately in   finished sections.""Our phased approach also allows us to learn and continuously   improve our construction and operational techniques as we   continue to drive down the cost of energy storage
column18: the company   explained.Tesla Gigafactory as of Jan. 3
column19: 2016. Image source: Tesla   Motors.The beginning of cell production at Tesla's Gigafactory is   good news for investors. With Tesla planning to launch its   lower-cost
column20: higher-volume Model 3 in the second half of 2017
column21: the   company will need Gigafactory-based cell production both for its   lower cell costs and its higher-volume cell production.Model 3 will likely be the most American-made     carOne interesting takeaway from this news is that by bringing   cell production to the U.S.
column22: Model 3 will likely become the   world's most American-made vehicle. After Tesla brings cell   production from Japan to the U.S. for its vehicles

Tesla's emphasis on U.S. job creation will likely   resonate with one of the president's biggest priorities: boosting   U.S.-based manufacturing. column1: CES 2017: The Hottest Headlines From Media Day 1;1/4/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThis year's edition of the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) doesn't officially start until Jan. 5
column3: but tech companies spent yesterday showing off their latest products to the press.Source: AcerAmong the stars of CES 2017 so far are laptops featuringIntel Corporation's(NASDAQ:INTC) new Kaby Lake processors
column4: smart home devices and the appearance of an actual functioningFaraday Futureelectric car.makeArticleAd();Today
column5: we look at the most exciting headlines from Big Tech's meetings with the press.CES 2017: New CPUs Advance Mobile and PC CapabilitiesFor a while there
column6: computing ambition was being held back by the wait for new processors. Intel's new ""Kaby Lake"" CPUs were unveiled at CES 2017
column7: and that's good news for the PC industry. These seventh-generation chips are expected to power everything from thelong-awaited new iMacfromApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) to a new crop of VR-capable PCs and ultra-portable laptops.New computers were unveiled at the Consumer Electronics Show that take advantage of the new Kaby Lake silicon
column8: including a new convertible 2-in-1 version ofDell'spopularXPS 13 laptop. And in typical CES fashion
column9: there was an over the top moment whenAcer Inc(OTCMKTS:ASIYF) took the wraps off thePredator 21-X: a $9
column10: 000-plus gaming ""laptop"" with a 21-inch curved display
column11: Kaby Lake CPU
column12: mechanical keyboard
column13: dual graphics cards fromNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) and eye-tracking cameras.Qualcomm
column14: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) also showed off its new Snapdragon 835 processor. You can expect to see the new flagship Snapdragon chip powering 2017's must-have Android smartphones.The Smart HomeMuch of CES 2017 has been focused on the smart home. That includes a flood of new mesh routers that aim to simplify home Wi-Fi and provide the wireless coverage need for smart homes to function effectively. They'll be taking on the like ofAlphabet Inc.'s(NASDAQ:GOOGL) recently announced Google WiFi system.3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in     2017Also featuring prominently were smart speakers. Google Home is gaining the ability to remote start supported cars fromHyundai Motor Co(OTCMKTS:HYMLF).Lenovo Group Limited(OTCMKTS:LNVGY) showed off anew smart speakerthat incorporatesAmazon.com
column15: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa smart assistant - an Amazon Echo alternative that looks better and costs less than the Amazon Echo. There's also a premium audio version that will go for $179.Alphabet Soup! QLED 4K HDR TVsTVs always make the spotlight at the Consumer Electronics Show
column16: and Day One of CES 2017 did not disappoint. The big trend is in big-screen
column17: QLED 4K HDR TVs.What exactly do all those acronyms mean?QLED combines two of TV's bleeding edge display technologies: quantum dots and OLED. Together
column18: you get a picture that's brighter
column19: with the deep blacks and flexible panels of OLED
column20: but at a much more affordable cost. 4K is the the same Ultra HD resolution that has become an expected feature of TVs. HDR is the high-dynamic-range picture that makes viewing pop. Throw those letters all together
column21: and you get a new class of QLED 4K HDR TVs that offer the best showcase technology of the past few years in a single and relatively affordable package.Leading that charge to convince you to finally buy a new TV were the usual suspects
column22: includingSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF). Although this year
column23: Samsung avoided controversy by refusing to give out prices for its newflagship QLED TVs.CES 2017: Faraday FutureThe Consumer Electronics Show has increasingly been focused on cars. Automobiles are rapidly getting more advanced - electric power
column24: autonomous capabilities and integration with smart tech like Apple Car Play or Amazon Alexa - so that makes sense.The big story on the auto front from CES 2017 was the Faraday Future FF 91
column25: a high-performance electric car that hopes to take onTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA). Although Faraday promised a Tesla-killer at last year's show
column26: it only managed a non-functioning prototype.The Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone WAS the Most     Popular Smartphone
column27: ButThis year
column28: the company kicked off CES 2017 with live demonstrations of its Faraday Future FF 91
column29: showing its self-driving capabilities while bragging about new high-density battery packs and world-record speeds.All of this is just skimming the surface of what was announced on day one. Stay tuned for a wrap of CES 2017
column30: where we'll spike out the big technology trends and top stories that develop over the course of the show.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceSurface Hub is 2016's Stealth Hit for Microsoft     Corporation (MSFT)The Dirty Secret to Trading Tesla Motors Inc     (TSLA) StockThe postCES 2017: The Hottest Headlines From Media Day 1appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The Dirty Secret to Trading Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Stock;1/4/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI'll get right into it - the dirty secret ofTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) is that
column3: despite all of the controversies and fanfare
column4: TSLA stock has mostly been range-bound for the past three years.Source: ShutterstockIf you see a price below $200 per share as a buy signal
column5: and a price near $250 as a sell signal
column6: or even a sign to go short
column7: you have been making money off Elon Musk right along. The turns in the stock's price are often sharp - it plunged from $240 to $150 about a year ago
column8: then hit $250 again within two months - but they generally stay within the range.makeArticleAd();At the opening price of about $213.44
column9: then
column10: Tesla is clearly in ""meh"" territory. An uptrend has been in place for a month now
column11: but if you jump in you're likely to see a reversal after a gain of about 10%.What's Up With TSLA Stock Now?The main problem for Teslaremains what it has always been
column12: scaling production to meet the stock price's expectations.The 10 Best Contrarian Stocks to Buy in the New     YearFor the third quarter in four for 2016
column13: Tesla missed its production estimates
column14: delivering just 22
column15: 200 cars. The original estimate for the year had been 80
column17: 000 cars. The final number was 76
column18: 230. That compares with50
column20: so 2016 production showed a more than 50% increase.Tesla continues to paint a rosy production picture
column21: and CEO Elon Musk thinks it will deliver 800
column22: 000 cars next year. This will include the Model 3
column24: 000 unit on which 400
column25: 000 pre-orders (with $1
column26: 000 checks) were taken on its announcement.The cars are certain to be cool. The question is whether there will be enough of them to show a profit and please Wall Street.What If Musk Is Right?The production shortfall sent the shares down about $4
column27: but they should go right back up today as the company offers investors a tour of its Sparks
column28: Nevada battery""gigafactory
column29: hosted by Musk himself. The Nevada factory supplies batteries for Tesla cars and stand-alone PowerWalls that can store electricity produced by SolarCity solar panels.It is this production ramp-up that has both bulls and bears worried. If Tesla continues to fall short this year
column30: the bears think the stock will collapseonce and for all. If it comes close to its goals then
column31: adding in the Supercharging centers (on which it's finally going tostart making money this year)
column32: the PowerWalls and the solar panels
column33: the thought is the bulls may run again.SolarCity
column34: which Teslaformally acquired in November
column35: was last year's reason to worry. The concern was that the solar panel maker would drag the whole company down with it. Since oil prices are now rising
column36: SolarCity should soon see positive margins
column37: especially as it's sold alongside other Tesla products
column38: so that worry is passing.But whenever a worry passes with Tesla
column39: a new worry replaces it. Maybe if Musk's production plans seem about to fail
column40: he'll buy SpaceX. Or
column41: if they seem about to succeed
column42: he'll geta white Persian cat.Tesla Is a Trade and a TeaseFor analysts and reporters
column43: Tesla is the gift that keeps on giving. In a black suit and blue tie world
column44: Elon Musk and Tesla are a tie-dyed shirt. The story is always fun and always subject to change without notice.But beneath the hype
column45: and the talk of imminent catastrophe or unlimited profit
column46: lies this truth. Musk is building a real company
column47: but he may never let the stock get out of its trading range
column48: because once Tesla accomplishes a goal he will find it loftier goal that will worry analysts about his sanity
column49: and that of his investors.Fitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Is a Zombie
column50: But the     Cure Is ComingThus
column51: if you're going to get involved in Tesla shares
column52: and I'm not recommending you do unless you like some manic-depression with your morning coffee
column53: just watch the trading range. Get in when they're bearish
column54: get out when they're bullish
column55: and on days like today when it's in-between
column56: just have a laugh.Dana   Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author   of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column57: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. column1: Tesla Motors
column2: Inc.'s Vehicle Deliveries Miss Guidance -- What Investors Should Know;1/3/2017;"Tesla Motors'(NASDAQ: TSLA) fourth-quarter deliveries were below the   company's guidance
column3: making it the third quarter during 2016 in   which the company missed its own target for vehicle deliveries.   The quarter's miss also put the company below its guidance for   the full year. Ahead of its planned Model 3 launch late this   year
column4: another missed target does little to help investors have   faith in the company's much more ambitious goals for the upcoming   higher-volume
column5: lower-cost car.Image source: The Motley Fool.makeArticleAd();Another missTesla delivered about 22
column6: 200 vehicles during the quarter
column7: the   company announced on Tuesday. The Model S accounted for 12
column8: 700   deliveries
column9: and the Model X accounted for 9
column10: 500. This brought   total deliveries in 2016 to 76
column11: 230. Tesla had guided for ""just   over 25
column12: 000 deliveries"" during the fourth quarter. And management   had initially expected to deliver 80
column14: 000 vehicles in   2016 but ended up reducing its full-year guidance to about   79
column15: 000.Tesla explained the miss in a press release:Because of short-term production challenges starting at the     end of October and lasting through early December from the     transition to new Autopilot hardware
column16: Q4 vehicle production was     weighted more heavily toward the end of the quarter than we had     originally planned. We were ultimately able to recover and hit     our production goal
column17: but the delay in production resulted in     challenges that impacted quarterly deliveries
column18: including
column19: among     other things
column20: cars missing shipping cutoffs for Europe and     Asia. Although we tried to recover these deliveries and     expedite others by the end of the quarter
column21: time ran out before     we could deliver all customer cars.These deliveries are lower than the 24
column22: 821 units Tesla shipped   in Q3
column23: but they were up 27% sequentially.The silver liningTo go along with Tesla's disappointing fourth-quarter   deliveries
column24: the company gave investors a couple positive   takeaways from the quarter.First
column25: production did pick up meaningfully during the quarter
column26: after the company addressed short-term production challenges.   Tesla was able to produce 24
column27: 822 vehicles in Q4
column28: bringing total   2016 production to about 84
column29: 000 vehicles -- up an impressive 64%   from 2015. With production ramping steeply toward the end of the   company's fourth quarter
column30: Tesla closed the year with a record   6
column31: 450 vehicles in transit to customers. These in-transit   deliveries will be delivered in the first quarter of 2017.Second
column32: Tesla said demand during the quarter ""was particularly   strong."" Combined net orders for its Model S and X were 52%   higher than in the year-ago quarter and 24% higher than in   Tesla's third quarter of 2016.Tesla factory in Fremont
column33: Calif. Image source: The Motley   Fool.Despite a quarter-end rebound in production and higher demand
column34: Tesla's extension of its poor track record with hitting targets   in 2016 shouldn't be overlooked. Consistently missing its own   targets
column35: including management's initial and revised full-year   delivery targets and three of its quarterly guidance targets
column36: makes Tesla's plan to go from its current annualized production   run rate of 100
column37: 000 units to a target of 500
column38: 000 units in 2018   difficult to take seriously.On the other hand
column39: investors could benefit from zooming out of   the quarter's results and look instead at how rapidly the company   was able to increase full-year production compared with 2016. A   64% year-over-year increase in production during 2016 helps   reinforce the company's ability to grow production at an uncanny   rate
column40: and it bodes well for future growth. But a 500
column41: 000   annualize unit-build rate still seems speculative -- even if the   company has 400

column1: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles' Electric Minivan: A Huge Missed Opportunity;1/3/2017;"FCA's Chrysler Portal concept is a futuristic take on a   vehicle for families

Image source: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV.Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV(NYSE: FCAU) has released some information on the Chrysler Portal   concept car that it plans to unveil on Tuesday at the Consumer   Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas.makeArticleAd();The Portal is a futuristic take on a highly connected electric   minivan. It's an intriguing idea. But it's also a huge missed   opportunity -- and a troubling sign for FCA investors.A potential Tesla competitor
column3: if it were realFCA said that the Portal ""explores the possibility of what a   family transportation vehicle could look like."" It has some   self-driving capabilities
column4: FCA said
column5: and the ability to connect   to personal devices and ""the cloud"" in ways that will help to   keep the kids entertained on long (or not so long) trips.FCA said that the Portal has a battery-electric drivetrain   with 250 miles of range. Its battery packs are built into the   floor
column6: in the style ofTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) . Fast-charging capability will be able to add 150   miles of range in about 20 minutes.Simply put
column7: the Portal represents an intriguing and advanced   potential competitor to Tesla's Model X

column1: Can Tesla Stock Drive 60 Percent Higher in 2017?;1/3/2017;"The continuous pattern of stop-and-go in shares of Tesla (TSLA) was frustrating to watch in 2016. But one prominent Wall Street analyst believe the company not only will turn things around in 2017
column2: Tesla will deliver some 60% returns.Shares of the electric vehicle company ended last year's campaign down about 11%
column3: trailing not only the Nasdaq 100 Index (QQQ)
column4: but also both the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 Index. And much of Tesla's 2016 struggles was caused by the company's inability to make good on some promises
column5: including its own vehicle production and delivery estimates. And to say nothing about the headache CEO Elon Musk caused by spending $2.6 billion to acquire SolarCity -- a deal Wall Street collectively hated.Can things change in 2017? Ben Kallo
column6: analysts at Baird
column7: who added Tesla as a 2017 best-pick candidate
column8: thinks so. While citing the company's upcoming Model 3 and what he thinks is an undervalued energy storage business
column9: Kallo last Friday slapped Tesla stock with Outperform rating and a $338 price target. Tesla shares closed Friday at $213.69
column10: suggesting a potential premium of almost 60%.makeArticleAd();""We think the ramp of Tesla Energy and Model 3 production could exceed expectations during 2017
column11: and believe the opportunity is not currently reflected in share price
column12: Kallo wrote last Friday. ""We believe Tesla battery sales are accelerating
column13: and we should see additional benefits from the battery production ramp coinciding with the launch of the Model 3.""Calling Kallo's price target ""overly optimistic"" would be a gross understatement. Tesla shares have a consensus target of $236
column14: which is 30% below Kallo's estimate and suggests only a 10% increase from current levels. Tesla
column15: nonetheless
column16: ended 2016 on a strong note. Despite the 11% decline last year
column17: the shares drove about 5% higher in the last three months of the year
column18: posting 14.37% gains just in the last thirty days.Indeed
column19: Elon Musk still has a lot to prove. He's promised that Model 3 deliveries will begin in 2017. For that to happen
column20: Tesla needs cash to fund its aggressive production and delivery targets. Musk must also fully integrate SolarCity
column21: which -- in its own right -- has struggled with profitability. To the extent Tesla's own cash-burn rate can fund both operations and meet its delivery forecasts remains to be seen.But as with Kallo
column22: it's tough to bet against Musk and against Tesla stock. Assuming the company does reach its delivery target and begins Model 3 production this year
column23: Tesla stock should regain its 2016 high of around $270
column24: posting some 25% returns in 2017. While it's not 60%

column1: 1 Big Solar Trend to Watch in 2017;1/1/2017;"Efficiency is now the name of the game in the solar industry   and leading manufacturers will spend the next few years moving   beyond commodity silicon solar panels to higher-efficiency   technology.SunPower Corporation(NASDAQ: SPWR) has long led the industry in efficiency and with   its X-Series product exceeding 23% efficiency that leadership   position won't end soon. But others are starting to catch up.Trina Solar(NYSE: TSL) recently announced a new record of 22.61% for its   mono-PERC cell technology
column2: something others will follow.Canadian Solar(NASDAQ: CSIQ) is another major manufacturer moving forward with   mono-PERC technology
column3: andTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) is launching high-efficiency panels this year with   Panasonic's HIT technology. The world of solar energy is about to   get a lot more efficient.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Chinese solar manufacturers put an emphasis on     efficiencySolar panel manufacturers
column4: particularly in China
column5: have been   plagued by little differentiation in their products. They use   similar equipment and processes to make solar panels
column6: which leads   to very similar panel efficiencies and fairly similar cost   structures. But in the last decade there has been little   incentive to focus on efficiency because costs were coming down   quickly and often offset the advantage higher efficiency   brought.But the cost/efficiency dynamic is changing. Solar panel and   overall system costs have come down so far that even a   100-basis-point improvement in panel efficiency can lower a   system's cost per watt by 5% or more. And if that efficiency is   combined with lower long-term degradation
column7: as it is with   SunPower's panels
column8: the impact on cost per kWh can be even higher.   So
column9: manufacturers finally have an incentive to increase   efficiency and lower costs.Trina Solar and Canadian Solar are investing in PERC   technology to move up the value curve. Higher-efficiency panels   will sell for a higher price per watt
column10: particularly to customers   installing small residential or commercial projects where   efficiency is more valuable
column11: and both companies want to capture   the financial benefit of the market. For example
column12: a 300-watt   solar panel that sells for $0.40 per watt will generate $120 in   revenue. A 360-watt panel that sells for $0.55 per watt is worth   $198.Now that higher-efficiency panels are in demand
column13: look for the   15% to 17% efficient panels that have dominated production to   begin to be replaced by panels that are 18% to 20% efficient.Tesla's efficiency playThe efficiency dynamic isn't lost on Tesla's SolarCity
column14: which   is building a plant in Buffalo
column15: New York
column16: to make high-efficiency   solar panels. Management has said they expect efficiency to be   over 20% when the product launches with 22% panel efficiency on   the horizon.Since Tesla is installing mostly small rooftop systems
column17: the   investment in efficiency makes sense. It leverages the company's   sales and installation costs and puts more watts of solar   production on each roof.SunPower's two-pronged efficiency planComing from a leadership position is SunPower
column18: which has long   been an efficiency leader. The company's E-Series product
column19: which   was 19% to 21% efficient
column20: is now facing competition from PERC   manufacturers that have a lower cost structure. That's why the   investment in X-Series
column21: which is over 23% efficient
column22: has been   important to the last year's financial results in the residential   market. If X-Series can continue to improve efficiency and keep   down cost
column23: the company could maintain a lead over mono-PERC   competitors.In the utility maker
column24: SunPower is taking a different approach.   P-Series is its low-cost solar panel that's only slightly more   efficient than conventional solar panels. Right now
column25: it's a   multicrystalline product but management has told me it will   eventually be a mono-crystalline product
column26: likely leading to   efficiencies approaching 20%. And since there are fewer   processing steps
column27: it should be lower cost than mono-PERC on a   per-watt basis.Jockeying for position in solar efficiencyEvery major manufacturer is trying to improve its efficiency   to differentiate itself and 2017 will likely be a transitional   year. A great deal of how the industry progresses in the year   ahead will depend on if Tesla can make its products as   planned
column28: and how SunPower's strategy is played out. Which company   makes the right strategic moves in improving efficiency will see   a lot of upside in coming years.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column5: Facebook
column6: and many more when they were just nascent start-ups.makeArticleAd();However
column7: after considering the business wisdom ofvisionary business leaders
column8: it recently occurred to me that examining some quotes from   leading VCs could also prove tremendously useful for tech   investors. So
column9: banking off of this same logic
column10: let's examine a   series of quotes from some of the world's leading venture   capitalists on subjects including the business of venture   capital
column11: business in general
column12: and technology.About the business of venture capitalMany readers may not be particularly familiar with the venture   capital world: how it works
column13: how it's financed
column14: and how VC firms   make money. As such
column15: this quote from Union Squares Ventures   partner Fred Wilson serves as a nice way to frame what   exactly venture capitalists do.Venture capital is about capturing the value between the     start-up phase and the public company phase. -- Fred WilsonIn general
column16: venture capital firms can invest in private   companies at any stage in their development. Though not always as   strictly codified
column17: these stages range from the initial seed round   of financing used to get a nascent company off the ground to the   later stages
column18: series C or later
column19: that often take place in theyears preceding an IPO. What's more
column20: the results can be astounding. According to the   National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER)
column21: the average annual   return of VC investments is an astounding 57%.Especially in moments when tech investing is particularly en   vogue
column22: the number of VC firms and the amount of money chasing   start-ups can create some unintended consequences
column23: as a number of   established venture capitalists have also noted.There are lots of ways to make money in venture capital
column24: and     there are even more ways to be mediocre. The industry has too     much money and too many smart people chasing too few great     entrepreneurs. -- Dan LevitanAll markets have boom and bust cycles
column25: and I think venture     capital market has even more exaggerated boom and bust cycles.     -- Fred WilsonBoth issues might sound eerily similar to the issues many   investors encounter when investing in the stock market. However
column26: much like our ethos here at The Motley Fool
column27: investors can   overcome
column28: or even benefit from the cyclical nature of the market   by maintaining a focus on the long term.The big advantage that we have as a venture capital firm     over a hedge fund or a mutual fund is we have a 13-year lockup     on our money. And so enterprise can go in and out of fashion     four different times
column29: and we can go and invest in one of these     companies
column30: and it's OK
column31: because we can stay the course. -- Marc     AndreessenBusiness in generalInvesting in high-growth private companies involves many of   the same skill sets public market investors need to cultivate in   order to succeed. The best venture capitalists think about   business models
column32: market economics
column33: and competitive dynamics at a   high level. Especially in the tech sector
column34: where newly minted   public companies often remain unprofitable
column35: it's important for   investors to remember that a path toward eventual profitability   is an essential piece of any investing thesis
column36: as Bill   Gurley succinctly states in the two following quote:If one asserts that buying customers below what they charge     them is a corporate strategy
column37: this is in essence an arbitrage     game
column38: and arbitrage games rarely last. -- Bill GurleyYou can create infinite revenue if you sell dollars for 85     cents. And if you give consumers more value than you charge     them for
column39: they will love you. And I remind entrepreneurs all     the time that Webvan had the highest NPS scores of any company     I've ever known. It wasn't that the consumer proposition didn't     work
column40: it was that the economics didn't work. They weren't     charging enough for the service level. -- Bill GurleyA litany of examples come to mind
column41: here. Companies likeZynga
column42: Gluu Mobile
column43: Skull Candy
column44: and evenTwitterhave generated tremendous losses for their investors as the   overly optimistic stories around which they came public   predictably failed to materialize. If the company's economics   don't make sense or don't seem achievable
column45: that should be a major   red flag
column46: but it's one investors have consistently overlooked --   to their detriment.Also similar to investing in public companies
column47: the leaders of   the best start-ups resemble the entrepreneurs running the world's   most successful public companies. Individuals likeTesla's Elon Musk orFacebook's Mark Zuckerberg have taken huge personal risks to bring their   visions into the world. Further affirming this idea
column48: leading   venture capitalists also seek this visionary quality in the   companies in which they invest.The very best entrepreneurs are relatively advantaged in     times of scarce capital. They can raise money in any     environment. Loose capital allows the less qualified to     participate in each market. -- Bill GurleyInnovation and technologyRounding out these quotes
column49: venture capitalists live and die by   identifying the companies that will define coming waves of   disruption. As such
column50: they spend a disproportionate amount of time   thinking about the current and future state of technology. One of   the key themes is that software will continue to automate and   upend sections of the economy as Marc Andreessen candidly   observes:Over the next 10 years
column51: I expect many more industries to be     disrupted by software
column52: with new world-beating Silicon Valley     companies doing the disruption in more cases than not. -- Marc     AndreessenHowever
column53: software isn't necessarily the only way we should   understand technology either
column54: as early Facebook investor Peter   Thiel notes:The single word for vertical
column55: 0 to 1 progress is technology.     The rapid progress of information technology in recent decades     has made Silicon Valley the capital of ""technology"" in general.     But there is no reason why technology should be limited to     computers. Properly understood
column56: any new and better way of doing     things is technology. -- Peter Thiel fromZero to OneFurthering this idea
column57: famed VC John Doerr sees a truly   game-changing investing opportunity in one largely undisrupted   area of the economy:Green-tech could be the largest economic opportunity of the     21st Century. -- John DoerrSpotting the next big thing is indeed hard work. However
column58: as   the world's most successful venture capitalists have demonstrated   time and again
column59: doing so is indeed possible. Similarly
column60: investors   in public market companies that follow this same line of   reasoning can also do extremely well over the long term.   Integrating these above ideas to your research process should   certainly help increase your odds of successful investing.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock   tip
