column1: The Big Strategic Shift Coming to the Solar Industry in 2017;12/31/2016;"The solar industry has been through a lot of strategic changes   over the past decade as cell manufacturers moved to making   panels
column2: panel manufacturers started building power plants
column3: and   power plant companies began moving into financing. In many ways
column4: vertical integration was the name of the game.But the past year of turmoil has shown that vertically   integrating into every part of the solar business might not make   sense. There's no fundamental advantage an installer likeTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) has in financing solar versus a bank
column5: and in many   ways it may have a disadvantage. And solar manufacturers may not   be the best at building massive power plants
column6: something utilities   and independent power producers have decades of experience doing.   So
column7: what's the trend to watch in 2017? Solar companies are   offering an integrated product design that customers can install   more efficiently than the piecemeal designs of the past.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Backing away from the finance gameOne of the broad trends over the past five years in the solar   industry is that solar companies began to finance more of their   own projects. Small-system installers like Tesla's Solar
column8: Sunrun(NASDAQ: RUN)
column9: andVivint Solar(NYSE: VSLR) could offer simple lease or power purchase agreement   (PPA) financing with $0 for customers and then aggregate the tax   benefits and payments in large financing projects. For bigger   projects like whatFirst Solar(NASDAQ: FSLR) andSunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR) were building
column10: self-financing eliminated a   discount buyers demanded for taking on project risk and allowed   them to take advantage of falling financing costs.If there was one broad finance trend in 2016
column11: it was that   solar companies financing their own projects began to backfire.   Small projects began to be financed through loans as more banks   and small lenders emerged
column12: lowering the cost of capital for   customers. And rising yields on yieldcos like8point3 EnergyPartners(NASDAQ: CAFD) made self-financing less attractive because the   price a yieldco would pay for a project began to decline. For   large developers
column13: holding projects on the balance sheet suddenly   became a bad thing and now they're looking to sell projects   before construction even begins
column14: leaving financing risk to a   company better suited to accept that risk.Designing entire systems will be the name of the gameIn response to these financing trends
column15: major solar companies   are beginning to design off-the-shelf solutions for solar   developers and utilities. The developer will then take care of   things like financing and securing power purchase agreements
column16: while the solar company concentrates on designing solar systems   to maximize energy production and lower cost. In some cases
column17: they're even adding services beyond solar
column18: like energy   storage.Image source: SunPower.This shift can be seen in First Solar and SunPower's product   line changes. First Solar is upgrading from Series 4 solar panels   to Series 6
column19: which is a full panel and racking system with the   option of adding energy storage and functions all the way to   transmission. SunPower's Oasis system is a complete solution from   site selection to building a power plant with trackers and the   P-Series solar panels. Both solutions are essentially   off-the-shelf offerings the companies will provide to a variety   of customers around the world. And it means in many places   they'll be backing away from bidding on projects themselves in   many locations.SunPower's residential and commercial solar solutions follow   along the same lines. Known as Equinox and Helix
column20: respectively
column21: they are a solution installers can buy pre-designed and just   install on a rooftop.Tesla has been moving to this model for years. It bought Zep   Solar to bring a racking product in-house
column22: bought Silevo to begin   manufacturing solar panels
column23: and now Tesla's acquisition of   SolarCity brings both products together with energy storage. Now
column24: Tesla will be making most of the valuable components of the solar   system. And it's moving toward more sales through loans
column25: backing   away from leases and PPAs.Solar solutions are the next big thingMoving toward more complete solutions makes sense for the   solar industry because it helps move more cost from the field to   the factory
column26: where components can be built efficiently and   designed to work seamlessly together. The days of piecemeal   design of solar systems are coming to an end.The companies that can combine solar solution design with   differentiated products like high-efficiency solar panels will be   well positioned for the future. Bottom line: SunPower
column27: First   Solar
column28: and Tesla have a leg up on the competition in building out   the solar product solutions of the future.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Tesla's New Autopilot Is "Days" From Release;12/30/2016;"When electric-car makerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) announced its Autopilot 2.0 sensors in October
column2: Tesla CEO Elon Musk said he hoped to begin rolling out major   software updates for the new technology before the year ended.   But with only one more day left in the year
column3: it's not looking   like Tesla will meet its target. However
column4: the software is ""almost   there
column5: Musk said in a tweet on Thursday.""Under going final validation. Might go out in the next few   days
column6: Musk tweeted back to someone asking about whether 8.1   would be released this weekend.makeArticleAd();Tesla demonstrates the capabilities of its new Autopilot   sensors. Image source: Tesla Motors.Catching upThe update
column7: which would be a part of the expected Tesla 8.1   software
column8: is particularly important because it is set to help   catch up the capabilities of Autopilot 2.0 vehicles to those of   Autopilot 1.0. Until Tesla updates the software for vehicles with   its second-generation sensor suite
column9: Tesla vehicles are lacking   key safety assist features
column10: such as automatic emergency braking
column11: collision warning
column12: blind-spot detection
column13: and side-collision   warning. In addition
column14: the Autopilot 2.0 vehicles are still   missing convenience features like auto-steer
column15: auto-park
column16: and   summoning.Earlier this month
column17: Musk said on Twitter that the next update   may include most of the functionality from Autopilot 1.0.   Eventually
column18: of course
column19: Tesla plans for Autopilot 2.0 to exceed   Autopilot 1.0's capabilities
column20: hence its new name: enhanced   autopilot.Why it mattersSince Autopilot 2.0 sensors are included standard in   every vehicle Tesla delivers
column21: the stakes are high for Tesla to   get the software right.Just how useful Tesla's autopilot sensors are was recently   brought to light when a dash cam captured a Tesla vehicle   alerting an owner and begin applying brakes to avoid an accident   after the sensors observed a car hitting its brakes two vehicles   ahead.Original video
column22: authorisation from the owner. Essential
column23: no   one could predict the accident but the radar did and acted by   emergency braking.pic.twitter.com/70MySRiHGR- Hans Noordsij (@HansNoordsij)December 27
column24: 2016This capability for Tesla vehicles to see ""through"" the car in   front of it was added in an important update in September. As   part of the update
column25: Tesla upgraded radar from simply serving as a   supplementary sensor to become a primary control sensor alongside   the camera's image recognition system. Tesla asserted in a blog   post about the update that this would help vehicles ""almost   always hit the brakes correctly.""Going further
column26: Tesla explained how the vehicle can   surprisingly see ""through"" vehicles:[A] Tesla will also be able to bounce the radar signal     under a vehicle in front -- using the radar pulse signature and     photon time of flight to distinguish the signal -- and still     brake even when trailing a car that is opaque to both vision     and radar. The car in front might hit the UFO in dense fog
column27: but     the Tesla will not.Without Tesla's 8.1 software update
column28: Tesla owners won't   benefit from safety features like this.Tesla's upcoming Autopilot update will be just the beginning   of many for Tesla vehicles with second-generation sensors. Longer   term
column29: Tesla says Autopilot 2.0 will even enable fully autonomous   driving. But there are a few caveats: Tesla still needs to   validate the self-driving software
column30: regulators will need to   approve the features' use
column31: and owners will have to pay up $8
column34: depending on whether they purchase the feature before   or after delivery (safety aspects of Autopilot
column35: like emergency   braking
column36: come standard on every Tesla).10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: This Week in Solar;12/30/2016;"As the year comes to a close
column2: it's fitting that the week in   solar was dominated by the kind of large
column3: macro trends that seem   to move and shake the solar industry every few months. But unlike   2015
column4: when we had Nevada upend net metering in the final hours of   the year
column5: most of the news from the solar industry is positive at   the end of 2016. There are still some challenges looking forward
column6: but policy seems to be favoring solar energy in the long   term.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();China resets renewable energy pricesOne of the biggest drivers of solar growth in 2016 was China's   feed-in tariff rates. A feed-in tariff drove an estimated 13 GW   of solar installations in the first half of the year before being   reset in the second half. Now feed-in tariff rates will fall   another 19% for 2017
column7: and China has lowered its 2020 installation   target from 150 GW to a minimum of 105 GW.Chinese leadership has also suggested that local governments   use auctions for renewable energy
column8: which has been a successful   arrangement in Latin America and Europe. At the very least
column9: this   gives some stability to the solar market in 2017
column10: and may help   increase demand for solar panels overall next year.Another state solar winOhio has had a freeze on its renewable energy mandates for the   last two years
column11: and lawmakers wanted to extend that hold -- but   Governor John Kasich vetoed a bill that would have made energy   mandates voluntary for another two years. Kasich was praised by   seven major employers in Ohio for keeping renewable energy   mandates. And it shouldn't go unnoticed thatFirst Solar(NASDAQ: FSLR) has a major manufacturing plant there and is   upgrading the facility over the next couple of years.In state after state
column12: solar energy has fought off regulatory   and legislative battles to grow its presence in the energy   industry. Ohio is another example of a big solar win
column13: and as a   leading Midwestern state it may become a solar leader
column14: showing   where the future of energy jobs is headed.Panasonic helping Tesla with solarPanasonic is coming to the rescue of SolarCity's Silevo solar   manufacturing plant
column15: agreeing to invest $256 million in the   facility.Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) made the investment contingent on its SolarCity   acquisition going through; now that the companies are combined
column16: Panasonic is being brought in to help with solar.Panasonic says production will begin in the summer of 2017   with 1 GW of production expected in 2019
column17: but it's worth pointing   out that Panasonic has had trouble making competitive solar   panels itself
column18: and Silevo's technology has proven disappointing
column19: especially given the fact that it had to bring in a partner to   bring production to fruition.It's also worth noting that this Panasonic partnership will   help make the cells for the solar roof. Not only is the Buffalo   facility key to keeping Tesla ahead of competitors in rooftop   solar
column20: it will be key to making the solar roof a reality. There's   a lot riding on this partnership today.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Tesla Motors
column2: Inc. Shines in Consumer Reports Survey;12/30/2016;"Earlier this month
column3: Consumer Reportsonce again named electric-car makerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) the most-loved car brand
column4: with the brand's 91%   overall owner-satisfaction rating trouncing every other car maker   on the planet. Indeed
column5: second-place Porsche was a wide seven   percentage points behind. And third-place Audi trailed Tesla by a   whopping 14 percentage points. Topping off Tesla's high brand   score
column6: CRalso said both of Tesla's vehicle models -- S and X -- had   exceptionally high customer satisfaction scores on their own.Here's a closer look.makeArticleAd();Tesla's Model S (left) and Model X (right). Image source: The   Motley Fool.Tesla's customer satisfactionSo
column7: how exactly areCR's ratings derived?CRexplains:Our brand rankings represent owner sentiment across each     brand's product line. (Model satisfaction is determined by the     percentage of owners who responded ""definitely yes"" to the     question of whether they would buy the same vehicle if they had     it to do all over again.) To determine brand love -- or disdain     -- we took a straight average of the satisfaction score for     each brand's models.In order to qualify
column8: the brand had to have at least two     models with data. For this analysis
column9: we focused on cars from     model years 2014-2017 to represent the current state of the     brands
column10: which included over 300
column11: 000 vehicles from the     survey.Of course
column12: investors should note that whileCR's 91% customer satisfaction rating for Tesla was higher than any   other automaker's rating
column13: the rating was down considerably from   its 98% and 99% ratings in recent years. This is likely   attributable to the Model S's wider adoption outside of the   hardcore early adopters who likely represented a large portion of   Tesla customers in the sedan's earlier years. Tesla's sales have   doubled over the last two years
column14: opening up its vehicles to a   wider
column15: more diverse customer base.Customers love the Model X
column16: tooConsidering that Tesla's new Model X -- whichCRrecently criticized for having ""compromised functionality"" and   ""dismal first-year reliability"" -- was included in the survey   this year for the first time during 2016
column17: it's arguably good news   to see Tesla still ranked so high on the list.The Model X. Image source: Tesla Motors.Tesla's Model X surprisingly performed quite well when it   comes to owner satisfaction. InCR's car-by-car owner satisfaction ratings
column18: the Model X came in   eighth place
column19: with a score of 88% -- not far behind the Model S's   94% rating. So
column20: while the Model X was holding back Tesla's   overall brand ranking
column21: the new SUV's score was still notably high   considering the reliability issues the complex vehicle has   experienced during its first year.Tesla said in its third-quarter shareholder letter
column22: released   in October
column23: that the Model X's reliability improved dramatically   as the year went on.""The amount of [reliability] issues that we have addressed   with Model X have fallen by 92% in the last 12 months
column24: Tesla   said
column25: ""a reflection of the improvements we have made in Model X   due to our ability and commitment to react quickly to   issues.""Image source: The Motley Fool.Improvements in reliability are not only important for   customers
column26: but also for Tesla's business. By improving the   reliability of both the Model S and Model X
column27: Tesla's warranty   accrual rates (the percentage of warranty reserves used for   warranty claims
column28: on both new and used vehicles) declined between   Q2 and Q3.Tesla's ability to satisfy customers is a key metric for   investors. It's crucial for a young automaker to stand out with   satisfying products. If Tesla's ability to delight customers   fades
column29: its well-capitalized competition could establish a   foothold with would-be Tesla customers and mitigate Tesla's   growth potential -- a threat that will only become more prominent   as automakers follow through with their plans to release more   long-range
column30: fully electric vehicles in the coming years. Further
column31: Tesla's vehicles will likely be scrutinized closely in 2017
column32: as   the company prepares to launch its lower-priced
column33: higher-volume   Model 3 in the second half of the year.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: GM Takes a Step Forward Toward Autonomous Vehicles;12/29/2016;"General Motors' (GM) CEO Mary Barra said that the company would start testing autonomous cars on the roads of Michigan very soon to evaluate how the driverless technology would perform against the greater Detroit area's harsh winters.This comes after Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder signed the bill permitting the testing of autonomous vehicles on Michigan roads.General Motors plans to test the self-driving Chevy Bolt electric vehicles on the public roadways of Michigan after Snyder agreed to allow the testing of certain parameters for testing and deploying driverless cars in the state. Michigan aims to move ahead of California and other states in a drive to become home to the autonomous car movement. Silicon Valley players includingTesla(TSLA)
column2: Alphabet(GOOG)(GOOGL) and Uber are at the forefront of implementing self-driving technology. The laws provide ride-sharing services to use autonomous cars without human intervention.makeArticleAd();Barra made another major announcement that the next generation self-driving cars would be produced in the Orion Township assembly plant
column3: where the company manufactures the all-electric Chevrolet Bolt. The testing vehicles will be equipped with LIDAR
column4: sensors
column5: cameras and other devices for safety. Barra said in a press conference
column6: ""We expect GM will become the first high-volume auto manufacturer to build fully autonomous vehicles in a mass production assembly plant.""The Detroit automaker has already been testing its driverless vehicle in its Technical Center campus in Warren
column7: Michigan. In total
column8: General Motors has around 40 testing vehicles in the two cities. The automaker now plans to extend its testing to the public roads in the metro area of Detroit. General Motors proposes to make the area its key location for advancing its autonomous technology for winters.The bill signed by Snyder lays out parameters for testing the technology by establishing regulations on how driverless vehicles could legally run on public roads. The enacted law permits testing of vehicles without human intervention and without steering wheels or pedals.However
column9: there are certain challenges that driverless cars would have to face. During winters
column10: snowfall can cause the roads to be unclear and such tough road conditions would make the movement of cars not driven by humans unpredictable.Push toward going autonomousGeneral Motors' moves in the last 18 months have clearly displayed its aggression in developing the autonomous technology. The carmaker's announcement regarding its partnership with startup firm Lyft and acquisition of Cruise Automation are among its latest initiatives in advancing its autonomous technology.The automaker has been fueling its effort to develop a strong robust autonomous technology. This can be validated through the company's latest partnership and acquisition moves. In addition
column11: General Motors has also been testing prototypes in Arizona and California. At the press conference
column12: Barra displayed the electric Chevrolet Bolt with rooftop sensors
column13: which is designed to assist autonomous driving.General Motors has been working hard to build a foolproof driverless technology. The company's management hasn't disclosed when General Motors will begin testing without a human driver but expects it to happen over the next two years. General Motors also plans to begin operating a fleet of self-driving taxis
column14: which would be allowed under the Michigan law.Disclosure:I do not hold any position in the stock mentioned in this article.Start afree seven-day trialof Premium Membership to GuruFocus.Warren Buffett Recent BuysFree seven-day trialWhat Should Be Your First Stock?Toshiba Announces Possible Write-Down of Several Billion DollarsPremium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: 3 Big Stock Charts for Thursday: Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA)
column2: Visa Inc (V) and Walt Disney Co (DIS);12/29/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsThe year-end trading volume continues to dry up and allow   stocks to get pushed around
column4: but there are a few technically   driven names that are seeing an opportunity to move higher based   on their evolving technical pictures. Today's three big stock   charts look atTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA)
column5: Visa Inc(NYSE:V) andWalt Disney Co(NYSE:DIS)
column6: as all three stocks are getting ready to make technically   driven moves when the New Year opens for trading.Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA)makeArticleAd();Shares of Tesla are seeing selling today
column7: despite some   positive news in the media over the last few days. The TSLA   selloff is more attached to the technically oversold signal   generated by the recent rally than anything else. That said
column8: the   response to this signal is paramount in setting the tone for   Tesla's first-quarter trading direction.While the recent rally has taken out a few technical   trendlines
column9: it has left TSLA open to a reversal as the 200-day   moving average is acting out as resistance. This trendline acted   as resistance for the shares in November
column10: ultimately sending them   tumbling back to the $180-support-level.The 7 Best Monthly Dividend Stocks for       2017In addition
column11: the chart resistance of $220 has continued to   build. Tesla traders are familiar with this price point providing   reversals as the stock spent an extended period consolidating   above $220 in the summer months. A break back below $220 and the   200-day will likely trigger technical selling that moves TSLA   shares 10% lower in the first month of the New Year. Upside   potential remains if Tesla gets enough buying here to   maintain levels above this critical trading zone.Visa Inc (V)Visa shares have been worked into a technical corner as they   continue to try to muster the strength to move back above the   $80-level. The growing problem is that this mark is becoming   congested with technical trendlines that are declining to provide   resistance for V. The pending Death Cross that will be formed in   the next two weeks based on current trends is also concerning for   Visa stock.Since rolling over in October
column12: V stock has been   underperforming the market by a wide margin. The bump in consumer   optimism seen after the elections didn't even help the credit   card processor to gain traction. Now
column13: Visa stock is facing   growing pressure and a likely dip into the lower $70s during the   first quarter of 2017.Staunch pressure from the $80-level on the chart is now even   stronger from the 50-day moving average
column14: which has descended to   this same price region. The declining 50-day on its own puts V   stock in an intermediate-term bearish category.By our model's estimates
column15: we will see a Death Cross on Visa   stock in the next two weeks when the 50-day moving average   crosses below the 200-day. This is more of a headline-grabber   than a reliable signal
column16: but it will drive home short-term   selling.For now
column17: traders are better off watching for the next   meaningful dip to buy shares of V
column18: or moving on to another   processor in the same sector.Walt Disney Co (DIS)Disney shares have been one of the better performers in the   Consumer Discretionary sector as they have shot 15% higher since   November. Now
column19: DIS stock is pulling back from overbought signals
column20: but the move appears to be nothing more than a rest ahead of the   next rally.Looking at the trendline analysis
column21: Disney has successfully   transitioned into intermediate-term bullish conditions as of Dec.   7
column22: and has improved the breadth of the move.Should You Buy Micron Technology
column23: Inc. (MU)       Stock? 3 Pros
column24: 3 ConsThe current pullback is a ""healthy"" correction as DIS shares   moved too far
column25: too fast. This means that the profit-takers are   sending shares lower right now
column26: and it's not a change in the   money flow into the Disney stock. Given that DIS shares boast a   1.5% dividend
column27: they aren't going to get tangled-up in the   interest rate risk trade as the Ten Year Treasury Yield continues   to push higher. Instead
column28: Disney provides average dividend yield   potential along with growth - a good combination for the current   market.Watch for DIS shares to test the $100 to $102-range on prices   if the selling pressure picks up
column29: but this is where we're more   likely to see technical traders start to pick up on the   opportunity for the shares to set forth on their next rally.As of this writing
column30: Johnson Research Group did not hold a     position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 High-Risk

column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOn the surface
column4: Amazon.com
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) looks like a short seller's dream stock. But for decades
column6: the bears have been wrong about AMZN stock.Source:Atomic Taco Via FlickrMy last write-up on Amazon was a complete an easy win that delivered a 22% yield in about a month. Today
column7: I'd like to set up another trade on AMZN.makeArticleAd();Buying equities at all-time highs carries undue risk. This is especially true for a momentum play like AMZN stock. Should the markets correct
column8: Amazon and other momentum stocks will lead lower faster than most other stocks. Therein lies the dilemma. How can I go long Amazon without taking undue risk?Luckily
column9: the options markets allow me to structure trades with limited and calculated risk. In this case
column10: I will buy a bullish play since I have house money from previous AMZN trades. I also will sell bullish risk at levels that I deem unlikely to be reached.Fundamentally
column11: Amazon is great. It's eating the lunch of all its competitors. The e-commerce giant has crippled brick-and-mortar retail. And it's also beating a lot of other tech companies in the cloud with its Amazon Web Services (AWS) division.7 Beaten-Down Tech Stocks to Buy With 50%     Upside in 2017Also
column12: theAmazon Echo and Tapsold out during the holidays. The ubiquity of these two could infuse an influx of new Prime members. This membership money flows to the bottom line
column13: so there could be an upside surprise.Click to EnlargeTechnically
column14: I see AMZN's stock price tightening. This usually resolves itself with a breakout from these levels. The direction of the breakout though unclear
column15: I am willing to bet it will be to the upside. So I will buy that upside potential and finance it by selling risk below current levels.I see similar bullish setups in other mega-caps likeApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL). I could diffuse the risk and buy calls in thePowerShares QQQ Trust
column16: Series 1 (ETF)(NASDAQ:QQQ). But instead I will continue betting on a clear winner in AMZN - as long as markets in general don't correct early in 2017.Let's take a look at the trade.How to Trade Amazon Stock HereThe bet:Buy the AMZN Mar $785/$790 debit call spread for $2.10 per contract. That would be my maximum risk. If Amazon rises above $790
column17: I stand to double my money.If you want to make this a true lotto ticket
column18: buy the call spread much higher than current levels. The Feb AMZN $820/$825 debit call spread only costs $1.30 per contract. It's higher
column19: so it's less likely to win  but the reward would be much greater.Red-Hot Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Ending 2016     on a CliffhangerI always like to limit my risk. In this case
column20: I want to sell bullish risk to finance the purchase of the call spread.The Bank:Sell AMZN Feb $675/$670 credit put spreads for 65 cents per contract. Ideally
column21: I need AMZN stock to stay above $675 per share through mid-February.I am not obliged to hold these AMZN trades through expiration. I can close them for partial gains or losses at any time.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing

column1: What To Expect From BlackBerry's Software Unit In 2017;12/28/2016;"2017 will be all about software for BlackBerry (BBRY)
column2: as the firm shuts down its hardware operations to focus on brand licensing
column3: while its service access business becomes increasingly irrelevant
column4: amid user attrition from its legacy smartphone platforms. Below we take a look at what to expect from BlackBerry's software-focused businesses going into next year.Trefis has an$8 price estimate for BlackBerry
column5: which is roughly 15% ahead of the current market price.See our complete analysis for BlackBerry     heremakeArticleAd();Enterprise Mobility Management And SecurityBlackBerry's software and services revenues stood at $486 million for the first nine months of FY'17 (fiscal years end in February)
column6: marking a 29% increase on a year-over-year basis. Enterprise mobility management remained the key driver of sales
column7: with ~9300 new enterprise subscriber additions over the first nine months of the fiscal year. The EMM market is expected to grow from$1.76 billion in 2016 to over $4.5 billion by 2020
column8: driven by mounting electronic security concerns and an increasing shift from PCs to mobile devices
column9: which are often employee-owned. BlackBerry could outgrow the market
column10: given that it recently took steps to unify its various enterprise mobility and security offerings under the ""BlackBerry Secure"" umbrella
column11: enabling it to provide end-to-end security solutions
column12: while helping customers lower total cost of ownership (related: What BlackBerry Aims To Achieve With Its Latest Security Offering). Moreover
column13: roughly ~80% of BlackBerry's software and services revenue
column14: excluding patent licensing and professional services
column15: are now recurring after the firm transitioned to a licensing model for its EMM software. This should result in revenue growth as recent subscriber adds are monetized.Emerging Businesses Can Gain Traction
column16: But Competition Likely To Be IntenseThe relative revenue stability in the enterprise software space is giving BlackBerry headroom to expand its other software-oriented businesses such as connected vehicles and Internet of Things. The company recently signed an agreement to work directly with Ford Motor Company to expand its use of BlackBerry QNX and security software. The deal
column17: which effectively makes BlackBerry a Tier-1 supplier to the auto behemoth
column18: could pave the way for  more deals with auto manufacturers going forward (related: Why BlackBerry's Software Deal With Ford Is Promising). BlackBerry is also betting big on the car of the future
column19: launching an Innovation Center for Connected and Autonomous Vehicles
column20: with plans to hire over 600 engineers for this effort in the near term. While the final product may be a few years away
column21: competition in the space is likely to be intense
column22: with deep-pocketed Silicon Valley players such as Apple (AAPL)
column23: Tesla (TSLA) and Google (NASDQ:GOOG
column24: GOOGL) investing heavily in their own respective platforms.BlackBerry's IoT business is also slowly coming to fruition. The company's Radar solution
column25: which caters to the fleet management market
column26: saw some business development activity this year
column27: winning contracts with trucking firms including Caravan Transport Group in Canada and Titanium Transportation in the U.S.
column28: while carrying out a few other pilot deployments. However
column29: the fleet management market is very fragmented
column30: with competition only likely to get more intense with wireless behemoth Verizon doubling down on the space with its $2.4 billion purchase of market leader Fleetmatics earlier this year. Larger players are likely to benefit from greater economies of scale and better network effects
column31: posing a threat to BlackBerry.Looking For Greater Transparency In 2017While the growth in BlackBerry's Software business is unlikely to make up for the loss of revenue from the smartphone and SAF businesses
column32: the greater mix of high gross margin software revenue should help BlackBerry improve its profitability. That said
column33: there are some concerns relating to a lack of transparency for the software unit. Although software is likely to account for roughly two-thirds of BlackBerry's 2017 revenues
column34: per our estimates
column35: BlackBerry has not been breaking down its various software-related revenue streams
column36: leaving some uncertainty from a forecasting standpoint. Moreover
column37: we will be looking for the company to provide other metrics such as subscriber figures
column38: average revenue per subscriber and churn rates
column39: which are typical of firms providing SaaS products with recurring revenues.Interactive Institutional Research (Powered by Trefis):Global Large Cap|U.S. Mid & Small Cap|European Large & Mid CapMore Trefis Research"

column1: How Tesla Can Succeed in Solar in 2017;12/28/2016;"WhenTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ: TSLA) bought SolarCity this fall
column2: it marked a big   strategic shift for the company. Tesla is no longer just a   supplier of batteries to rooftop solar installers like SolarCity;   it is now a full-fledged solar company.SolarCity employs tens of thousands of people selling and   installing solar systems
column3: and it is also building a manufacturing   plant and has a large financing arm that handles billions of   dollars in solar financing deals. This makes Tesla a complicated   player in solar energy
column4: but there are three ways it can really   differentiate itself from its peers in 2017.makeArticleAd();Image source: Tesla.Manufacturing has to live up to expectationsTesla CEO Elon Musk and SolarCity have spent two years talking   about making solar cells and panels
column5: and in 2017
column6: the rubber has   to hit the road. When SolarCity bought Silevo in 2014 and began   construction on a 1 gigawatt (GW) solar panel manufacturing plant   in New York
column7: the thought was that SolarCity could be a technology   leader as well as a sales and installation giant. It's been a   difficult process
column8: to say the least.Silevo has yet to produce solar panels at scale
column9: and when   Tesla bought SolarCity
column10: one of the impacts was that Panasonic   would be brought in to help with solar manufacturing. None of the   companies has said a lot about what the details of Panasonic's   involvement will be
column11: but the fact that a third party would have   to be brought in is concerning. And the time to make efficiency   advancements before competitors do is coming to a close.SolarCity thought it could make cells that were 22% efficient   with Silevo technology
column12: which would lead to 19% to 20% efficient   modules. That would be an advance
column13: but with mono-PERC technology   -- which will have high teens efficiency -- starting to be rolled   out by Chinese manufacturers
column14: there's not a huge advantage to   this product SolarCity/Silevo hasn't even proven it can make. And   industry leaderSunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR) is already producing cells that are 25.1%   efficient and modules over 23% efficiency
column15: so the   Tesla/SolarCity/Silevo group is falling behind and has to catch   up fast.Then there's the solar roof
column16: which is a great headline but   mostly a mystery right now. We don't know price
column17: efficiency
column18: or   anything about installation
column19: so it's tough to say whether that   product will impact Tesla in 2017.What's clear is that Tesla has to get solar manufacturing   right this year. If it can
column20: it will have a high-efficiency   product with traditional solar panels and potentially a   compelling new product with the solar roof.Ditch reliance on the leaseIn 2016
column21: the residential solar industry came to the quick   realization that third-party financing from the lease/power   purchase agreement (PPA) won't be the dominant paradigm forever.   More loan financing is coming available and customers want the   choice that comes with self-selecting everything from panels to   financing.This takes away a key differentiator for SolarCity
column22: which has   been able to leverage its size to lower financing costs for its   lease/PPA. Now
column23: the company needs to make the transition to   loans
column24: and fast. But there's opportunity here.Large installers are fairly slow in making big changes to   their business models and Tesla can be a leader in moving to the   loan. If it does
column25: it could mean more upfront cash generation from   solar
column26: which would fund solar manufacturing and even the Model 3   expansion. Loans could be a boon for Tesla in 2017 if it makes a   big transition and leaves its third-party financing model   behind.Image source: Tesla.Energy storage is Tesla's biggest differentiatorThe single biggest advantage Tesla has in solar is that it can   integrate design up and down the supply chain. Solar panels
column27: racking
column28: inverters
column29: and energy storage design are now all   in-house
column30: and that could allow the company to lower costs and   offer new products to customers.In 2017
column31: I would expect energy storage with the Powerwall 2 to   become a much larger part of the business. And with the ability   to integrate the inverter with storage
column32: there are multiple ways   to create value for customers with energy storage. Look for the   company to leverage this fact this year.The SolarCity acquisition may have been a great moveNow that SolarCity is part of Tesla
column33: the company has to make   the transition to a solar installer and manufacturer. In a highly   competitive industry
column34: that may be easier said than done. But with   a high-efficiency manufacturing plant under way
column35: scale that beats   all competitors
column36: and an integrated energy storage product
column37: Tesla   could be well positioned for the future. Now it just has to   execute to create value for shareholders and customers.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Tesla-Panasonic to Manufacture Solar Cells at Buffalo Plant;12/28/2016;"Tesla Motors
column2: Inc.TSLAhas signed an agreement with Panasonic CorpPCRFYto produce photovoltaic cells and modules in Buffalo
column3: NY
column4: from the summer of 2017. The companies signed a non-binding letter of intent for the same in October.Per the agreement
column5: Panasonic will bear the capital expenses needed for the plant in return for a long term purchase commitment by Tesla. The companies plan to increase the production volume of photovoltaic modules at the plant to 1 Gigawatt by 2019. Additionally
column6: the companies will collaborate to develop the next generation of photovoltaic technology at the Fremont
column7: CA plant of Tesla's subsidiary SolarCity.Tesla will use the cells and modules produced in the Buffalo plant to make solar panels for its non-solar roof products. The company will also use these cells in various kinds of solar glass tile roofs
column8: when their production starts.Price MovementTesla has been underperforming the Zacks categorizedAuto Manufacturers-Domesticindustry for most of the year. Year to date
column9: the share price of Tesla lost 11.1% while the industry witnessed a 2.9% gain.Tesla has been facing production-related issues for a long time
column10: as a result of which it has failed to meet delivery targets in the first two quarters of 2016. This
column11: along with the losses incurred by the company
column12: pulled down its share price. Tesla's stock was also affected by the announcement of the SolarCity acquisition due to concerns related to the losses of the latter

column14: now that the acquisition is completed

column1: Tesla Leans on Panasonic to Build Solar Panels in Buffalo Plant;12/27/2016;"Tesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ: TSLA) is making good on its promise to bring in   Panasonic to help with solar manufacturing
column2: now that Tesla's   acquisition of SolarCity is complete. The company announced   on Tuesday that Panasonic will invest $256 million in SolarCity's   Buffalo
column3: New York
column4: manufacturing facility
column5: with a goal of   starting production in the summer of 2017.The hope is that the partnership will bring higher-efficiency   solar panels to SolarCity and Tesla
column6: and a greater level of   integration. But the idea that Panasonic was needed in the first   place is a bit of a mystery.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Why Panasonic is neededIn June 2014
column7: SolarCity announced the acquisition of Silevo
column8: a   solar technology start-up that hoped to make high-efficiency   solar panels in a plant in Buffalo
column9: New York. To pay for the   plant
column10: SolarCity got the state to throw in a $750 million subsidy   in exchange for commitments to meet minimum investments and hire   workers in the state. It seemed like SolarCity was on its way to   becoming a solar manufacturing giant
column11: with a target of production   beginning in 2016.But in the summer of 2016
column12: as part of the acquisition of   SolarCity
column13: Tesla announced plans to bring in Panasonic to make   solar cells using technology similar to Silevo's. It seemed that   Silevo's technology wasn't working out as planned -- if it were
column14: Panasonic wouldn't be needed at the plant at all.It now appears that Panasonic will essentially take over cell   manufacturing using its own technology
column15: which adds a thin   amorphous silicon layer to the cell to increase   efficiency. What's interesting about moving to this   technology is that Panasonic suspended operations at a solar-cell   plant in Osaka
column16: Japan
column17: because of weak demand. If the technology   was a true differentiator on efficiency at competitive costs
column18: the   company could have looked outside Japan to markets like the U.S.
column19: where high efficiency is in high demand. But Panasonic's   technology wasn't differentiated enough to thrive on the open   market
column20: so it's interesting that Tesla chose Panasonic as   the partner for Buffalo.Tesla has a bigger plan for solar cellsTesla hopes the Buffalo plant will help advance   higher-efficiency solar panels that pack more power generation   into each rooftop solar install
column21: and will provide cells for   Tesla's solar roof. This will also further vertically integrate   the manufacturing business. Tesla now designs and makes solar   panels
column22: roof racking
column23: and an energy storage product with an   inverter. In theory
column24: having development of these products   under one roof should make for a more seamless design and install   for Tesla.For Tesla to differentiate itself from competitors in solar
column25: this integration will be key. And the Buffalo facility could be   where Tesla's solar vision comes together.Tesla has a lot to prove in solarSaying you're going to make a high-efficiency solar panel or a   solar roof is one thing
column26: but actually doing it is apparently   proving more difficult than Elon Musk and SolarCity had planned.   Panasonic wouldn't have been asked to invest $256 million in the   Buffalo solar facility if Silevo's technology were working as   expected. And we still don't have confirmation that solar panels   coming from the facility will be higher-efficiency than those   from competitors
column27: or cost-competitive.Making solar panels is easier said than done. Tesla bringing   in Panasonic shows that Silevo/SolarCity/Tesla are finding that   out the hard way.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: This Is Why Under Armour Inc (UA) Stock Could Have a Bang-Up Year;12/27/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt's been a decidedly tough year for athletic apparel makers
column3: and despite making several strategic moves to set itself up for the future
column4: Under Armour Inc(NYSE:UA
column5: NYSE:UAA) was no exception.Source:SandyDover via Flickr (Modified)UAA stock is down nearly 30% on the year
column6: and the firm's Class C shares have lost a whopping 40% in 2016.makeArticleAd();Looking at those figures
column7: you might think you were dealing with a company that has very little hope for the future
column8: but in fact Under Armour appears to have a relatively bright future
column9: making it a good buy at its current valuation.What Happened to UA StockA few key events led to UA stock's declines over the past year
column10: but the majority of them are unlikely to keep shares of Under Armour depressed for long.In early December
column11: Under Armour's ticker symbol changed and that contributed to the decline in the stock price as investors shied away from the company due to confusion over which shares were which and questions regarding management's decision to have three separate share classes.10 Best Stocks for Retirement InvestorsBack in April
column12: UA introduced a new C class of stock with the ticker symbol UA.C. These shares had all the same economic value as the A class shares
column13: but shareholders would have no voting rights. CEO Kevin Plank also created a third class of B stock that does carry voting rights
column14: but only he holds these shares. Essentially what the stock split did was allow UA to issue new stock without Plank giving up his majority stake in the company.If this wasn't confusing enough
column15: Under Armour thenrenamedit's class C shares to just ""UA"" rather than ""UA.C
column16: and the A shares (which used to be named ""UA"") became ""UAA"" at the beginning of December.While it was a contributing factor
column17: confusion wasn't the entire reason that UA stock tumbled this year. Under Armour also faced some pretty worrying headwinds that caused investors to second guess whether the company could remain relevant in the years to come.Perhaps the most worrying event was the bankruptcy and closure of Sports Authority
column18: which hit UA hard because the distributor was Under Armour's largest seller. Sports Authority's troubles hurt UA's bottom line and weighed on investor sentiment. Many pointed to the bankruptcy as a sign of things to come within the sector.Finally
column19: despite a third-quarter earnings-beat
column20: Under Armour's results were less than perfect. The firm's margins declined and third-quarter sales growth was at a six-year low. Fourth-quarter guidance suggested that the final quarter's sales growth would be even slower as well.Why You Should Buy UA StockWith three major events contributing to UA and UAA stock's decline in 2016
column21: there's a lot of reason to believe that things are looking bright for the new year. Even without considering all the things that UA has done to set itself up for a profitable future
column22: UA stock is poised to gain.UA's losses resulting from investor confusion over the stock split and new ticker symbols are unlikely to have a lasting impact. As the confusion begins to fade
column23: UA stock will stabilize.This is especially true for the C class shares
column24: which are a great buy as they are trading at a discount. The voting rights that make A shares more valuable are negligible for traders
column25: as Plank has majority control no matter what
column26: so C shares are a good buy for investors who see UA improving in the coming year.The Sports Authority closure was certainly a blow to UA's momentum
column27: but it doesn't signal an athletic-wear apocalypse as many traders feared. It's worrying
column28: but other similar retailers likeDicks Sporting Goods Inc(NYSE:DKS) are stillthriving
column29: so it isn't time to panic about the industry's stability just yet.UA's sales issues are also a concern
column30: but the company isn't in danger of falling apart
column31: so a few difficult quarters shouldn't be reason to write UA stock off completely. Sales have improved by at least 20% every quarter for nearly a decade
column32: and that is a pretty positive sign of stability.Better Days Ahead for UAOnce you've addressed the three biggest reasons UA stock is down in the dumps
column33: the case for a marked increase in the next year looks promising. Not only are some of the market's worries about Under Armour overdone
column34: but the firm has also made some strategic moves this year that have put it in a good position for 2017.One of the biggest moves the company made this year was stepping into the athleisure market. Athletic wear has made it's way into the closets of just about everyone whether or not they've ever set foot in the gym. Under Armour's product line has always been aimed at athletes with clothing that is designed for performance rather than style.However
column35: the firmrecently unveileda new line of apparel that focuses on casual athletic wear for the masses. This is a segment that is likely to continue growing in the coming year
column36: so it's promising to see UA throwing its hat in the athleisure ring. This push into casual-wear is likely to be supported by Under Armour's new partnership withKohl's Corporation(NYSE:KSS)
column37: another big factor to watch in the coming year.The Bottom LineUA stock is a buy for investors looking to add to their portfolio in the coming year. The stock's major decline in 2016 has been the result of the market's overreaction to some challenges that the company is facing.Should I Buy Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Stock? 3     Pros
column38: 3 ConsNot only can investors expect much of that downside to fade in the coming year
column39: but UA's latest foray into casual wear is likely to give the stock a further boost.As of this writing
column40: Laura Hoy did not hold a position in any   of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 12 Best Fidelity 401k Funds to Own10 ""Best of the Best"" Stocks to Buy for     2017The postThis Is Why Under Armour Inc (UA) Stock Could Have a Bang-Up Yearappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column13: to see
column14: let's consider three pros and cons on Tesla stock.TSLA Stock ProsInnovation:Tesla Motors has made major breakthroughs in battery technologies (allowing for drives of over 300 miles on a single charge)
column15: electric powertrains and software systems. Yet the company has also been innovative with its business model
column16: such as having online purchases of vehicles as well company-owned showrooms and service centers. The result is that Tesla has direct connections with its customers and better control on quality service.Interestingly enough
column17: a Tesla car is kind of like an app. That is
column18: there are periodic updates to the systems with""over-the-air""transmissions. This has definitely been key with the Autopilot technology
column19: which allows for semi-autonomous driver assistance. So is it any wonder thatForbescurrently ranks Tesla asthe world's most innovative company? Not really.Megatrend:The auto industry is in the midst of major technology changes. Companies likeAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column20: NASDAQ:GOOG)
column21: Qualcomm
column22: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) andIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) have made big investments and acquisitions in the category. Of course

column24: the market could hit$15 billionwithin the next few years.All this is certainly good news for holders of TSLA stock. The company has been investing in new-fangled auto technologies since 2003. What's more
column25: the Autopilot hardware has logged over 1.3 billion miles so far. In other words
column26: Tesla has a major advantage in terms of data and analytics. But the growth is likely to ramp for some time. For the second half of 2016
column27: TSLA expects to ship50
column28: 000 cars
column29: which is roughly the same amount for all of last year.The Elon Factor:At 45
column30: Musk is already a legend of the tech industry. Besides Tesla
column31: he has launched other breakout companies
column32: such as Zip2
column33: Paypal Holdings Inc(NASDAQ:PYPL)
column34: SolarCity and SpaceX. Along the way
column35: Musk has made billions for shareholders. Unlike many in Silicon Valley
column36: though
column37: he is not only technically super smart but has incredible marketing chops. Oh
column38: and he is not afraid of ""going big."" Let's face it
column39: how many people have the goal of eventually living on Mars? Such qualities have inspired Musk's workforce
column40: which has led to amazing achievements.TSLA Stock ConsSolarCity Deal:OnTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR)
column41: Musk sent out thefollowingregarding the acquisition: ""Tesla + SolarCity future: solar roofs + batteries + electric cars."" Definitely ambitious
column42: right? Of course. But there has still been quite a bit of skepticism on the Street.One of the issues is that SolarCity has been a big-time money loser. For the past year
column43: the company has reported nearly$2 billion in negative operating cash flows. Keep in mind that there are heavy capital costs and marketing expenditures. The competitive environment is also intense and there are concerns that the regulatory environment could get tougher. Let's face it
column44: the Donald Trump Administration may not be too interested in maintaining tax credits for solar energy projects.In light of all this
column45: analysts at Morgan Stanley provided the followinggrim assessment: ""Given (SolarCity's) financial condition and recent reduction in guidance
column46: we have assumed zero value for (SolarCity) equity to (Tesla) shareholders.""Valuation:Even with the recent drop
column47: TSLA stock is still far from cheap. The multiple is at about six times sales. No doubt
column48: this is at quite a premium to traditional auto manufacturers. Consider thatGeneral Motors Company(NYSE:GM) andFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) sport multiples at about 0.3 or so.It's true that the premium valuation for TSLA is due to the strong growth ramp. And there is lots of value for the intellectual property. But then again
column49: profitability has remained elusive. If anything
column50: TSLA will likely continue to voraciously raise capital to meet production targets
column51: build the massive Gigafactory and fund SolarCity. In other words
column52: there will likely be ongoing dilution for shareholders.Perhaps this is why short sellers have been targeting TSLA stock. Right now
column53: the short interest is at a hefty 40% of the float
column54: which certainly indicates that many investors are expecting a fall in the value of the shares.Production Issues:Demand has not really been a problem for Tesla. Instead
column55: the real challenge has been to produce enough vehicles. After all
column56: the company has a limited number of facilities - and technical complexities are mind-boggling. It seems inevitable that there will be snags. Yet the biggest problem may be to achieve profitability on a unit basis. According to a recent 152-slide presentation from hedge fund managerMark Spiegel
column57: the Tesla Model 3 could cost $48
column58: 000 to produce. However
column59: the company has plans to sell it at $35
column60: 000!All in all
column61: this seems like a pretty good deal for customers - but not for holders of TSLA stock. Granted
column62: TSLA may ultimately decide to hike the price. But this could mean a drop in sales. No doubt
column63: this essentially highlights the extreme difficulties of succeeding in the mass market.Bottom Line on TSLA StockMusk has always had many doubters - and he has had a knack for proving them wrong. And so far
column64: he has done a tremendous job with TSLA. It's actually downright amazing that he was somehow able to stave off bankruptcy during the financial crisis.How to Protect Yourself in Bank of America Corp     (BAC) StockBut going forward
column65: TSLA will deal with its biggest challenges - such as selling into the mass market and also managing a solar energy company. Just doing one would be incredibly tough. In other words
column66: there is really not much margin for error.OK then
column67: should you buy Tesla stock? No

column1: Will Tesla's (TSLA) Share Price Rebound In 2017?;12/27/2016;"Tesla Motors

column25: to be named Tesla Semi

column32: the addition of SolarCity's debts and cash outflows will increase the strain on Tesla's financials.Moreover
column33: Tesla is investing heavily in increasing its production capacity
column34: the development of Model X and Model 3
column35: the Gigafactory construction and expansion of sales
column36: services and Supercharger infrastructure. As a result
column37: itsexpenses are expected to remain highin 2017

column1: 2 Big Winners in Consumer Reports' Owner Satisfaction Survey;12/27/2016;"It's easy for investors to become completely consumed by a   company's financials
column2: and that's obviously an important aspect of   investing. But wise investors also pay a lot of attention to the   products their companies make
column3: because a product mistake or   failure could send a promising company's stock crashing to the   ground.That's why reading through Consumer Reports' Annual Owner   Satisfaction Survey can be really important for auto investors:   It tells us how CR subscribers feel about the cars they bought.   I'd much rather own a financially healthy stock that produces   vehicles consumers would buy again
column4: than not.Lincoln's rebound isn't limited to sales as its consumer   satisfaction jumped this year. Image source: Ford Motor   Company.makeArticleAd();How does it work?CR's rankings emphasize owner sentiment across a brand's   entire portfolio of vehicles and model satisfaction is determined   by the percentage of subscribers that would ""definitely"" buy the   vehicle again. Also
column5: in order to qualify
column6: a brand must have at   least two models with data and the survey focused on 2014-2017   model years. Without further ado
column7: here are the results and some   takeaways.Information source: Consumer Reports'Ownership Satisfaction Survey. Chart by author.Tesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) is obviously a huge winner here as the only brand   scoring in the 90 percentile range
column8: and well ahead of the next   closest brand
column9: Porsche
column10: and that's even more impressive   considering the latter was the only brand scoring in the 80   percentile range. But Tesla's victory here is even more important   considering the battering it's taken over the past year in   regards to production issues.The Model X's wing doors caused consumer frustration
column11: and   occasional issues of doors not aligning properly aren't typical   complaints for a car that can cost well into the $100
column12: 000 range.   The fact that so many Tesla consumers would purchase again   despite the production complaints is a huge win
column13: and that's   amplified by the fact that it's more affordable Model 3 will be   launching at the end of 2017.Ford Motor Company's(NYSE: F) luxury Lincoln brand made an impressive jump for the   second-largest Detroit automaker. Lincoln jumped from its 21st   ranking in the prior CR survey
column14: up to 12th this year. That moved   Lincoln ahead of some notable luxury brands such as Cadillac
column15: Mercedes-Benz
column16: and BMW. Remember
column17: Lincoln was the only brand that   Ford didn't sell off amid its business crisis in 2006
column18: and the   following financial crisis. It's poured much capital into   reviving the luxury brand and it's now on pace for its third   consecutive year of sales gains
column19: something it hasn't accomplished   in at least 16 years.This is a great sign for Ford investors as luxury sales are   high margin business
column20: and increasing luxury sales at a time when   new-vehicle sales are peaking would be very beneficial for the   automaker. If more consumers are happy with the product
column21: and   would purchase again as this survey indicates
column22: this suggests   Lincoln's newest products are improved and that should enable the   brand's rebound to continue.Ultimately
column23: these types of surveys are more important to   investors than many realize. The automotive business is insanely   competitive
column24: and it's very costly to ""conquer"" consumers
column25: which   is luring them from a competing brand to your own. If you have a   high percentage of consumers remaining loyal to your brand
column26: it's   simply good business. These surveys can also give a glimpse of a   company that might not be producing vehicles up to standards
column27: and   that could lead to sales troubles in the near-term. TakeFiat Chrysler Automobilesfor example
column28: which had four of its five brands place 17th or   lower. Wise investors should use these surveys to their   advantage

column1: Will Elon Musk Really Build a Tunnel Boring Company?;12/25/2016;"So here's the latest revelation pulled out of ""Elon Musk's box   of crazy ideas."" The founder ofTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) and SpaceX has now decided to start a company that   will dig tunnels for cars to drive through.Tunnel boring machines are massive pieces of equipment --   train-sized mobile factories designed to dig into the Earth.   Coincidentally
column2: they're almost perfectly shaped to fit aboard a   rocket to Mars. Image source: Getty Images.We first learned of Musk's latest harebrained scheme (Get it?   Rabbits dig tunnels. too!) when the Tesla CEO was apparently   driving through California over the weekend
column3: got upset with the   holiday-time traffic
column4: and began blasting out a series of   tweets:makeArticleAd();""Traffic is driving me nuts
column5: observed the billionaire.So maybe he should ""build a tunnel boring machine and just   start digging.""He would call the company ""The Boring Company"" -- and he is   ""actually going to do this.""A hare among foxesMedia response to the Tesla tycoon's tweets has been mixed
column6: withUSA Todayobserving that these may be the mere ""musings of a guy stuck in a   traffic jam with time to tweet
column7: andRecode.net theorizingthat Elon was ""just venting
column8: or perhaps ""making a corny   joke.""Others
column9: including some of my own colleagues here at The Motley   Fool
column10: believe that Musk is serious about setting up a ""boring   company"" -- but that he's deluded if he thinks he can make it   work. After all
column11: while the idea of boring tunnels in the earth   appears to have just occurred to Musk
column12: there are plenty of other   companies that have been at this business much longer.Just a quick survey of the tunnel boring machine (TBM)   industry reveals major players in the form of:Norway's TerratecGermany's Bosch RexrothGermany's Herrenknecht
column13: which makes the TBMs building out     the London UndergroundJapan's Hitachi Zosen Sakai
column14: which makes the Bertha     TBM currently tunneling under SeattleChina Rail Engineering CorporationFrance's NFM Technologies and America's The Robbins     Company
column15: both now owned  by China's Northern Heavy     Industries GroupIf Elon Musk truly desires to enter the tunnel boring   business
column16: he's going to face some stiff competition --   competition stiff enough that it's already drivenCaterpillar(NYSE: CAT) out of the business. (Caterpillar stopped building   TBMs in 2013
column17: and is winding down its support of existing   equipment at the end of this year.) So if Musk truly is serious   about setting up a tunnel boring company
column18: he's picked himself a   tough row to hoe.Crazy as a March hare -- or crazy like a fox?And yet
column19: I actually think Muskisserious -- and what's more
column20: I think I knowwhyhe's serious about tunnel boring. It comes down to this:   Everything -- everything -- that Musk does these days is done   with an eye to his dream ofone day colonizing Mars.Consider: Musk has famously advocated the idea of launching   satellites into orbit
column21: and thenreusing the rockets. Previously
column22: advocates of reusable rockets always argued that   the best way to land rockets for reuse was to fly them back to   Earth and land them like an airplane
column23: on a runway. That's how   Rockwell International (now largely owned byBoeing) designed its space shuttle. That's how Boeing rivalAirbusis designingits ADELINE spaceplaneto land today.Musk
column24: however
column25: rightly points out that on Mars
column26: thereare no runways.If you want to land a rocket on Mars
column27: such that it can later take   off again
column28: you have to land ""on your feet."" Hence
column29: every rocket   that Musk makes at SpaceX is designed to land vertically
column30: on its   own rockets.You can make a similar point for Musk's other business   ventures
column31: includingSolarCity solar panels
column32: Teslaelectric cars
column33: and evensatellite internet. Mars lacks oil deposits
column34: which means that power must be   generated electrically (solar panels). Mars cars won't be able to   run on gasoline
column35: so battery power is a better option there as   well (Tesla). And Mars will lack a communications system to   connect potentially far-flung colonies -- so it might be a good   idea to develop expertise in running a satcom network here on   Earth
column36: preparatory to creating a similar system to encircle   Mars.Making sense of Elon Musk's Boring CompanySo how do tunnel boring machines play into this Mars-centric   thesis? Simple. In the early days of any Mars colony
column37: protecting   colonists from solar radiation will be a concern
column38: as will   construction of housing. Having tunnel boring machines on site
column39: however
column40: would solve both problems at once
column41: by enabling colonists   to bore radiation-proof tunnels underground in which to live.Mind you
column42: I'm not saying that this is Musk'sonlyobjective in setting up a company to build TBMs. Rather
column43: it's hisultimateobjective.As I see it
column44: Musk needs to figure out how to build TBMs --   which he can then ship to Mars by rocket
column45: for use in setting up a   Mars colony. To do that
column46: he'll want to first tinker with the   idea
column47: learn how to build TBMs himself
column48: and then perfect the   technology. By setting up a ""Boring Company"" on Earth
column49: he gets to   do all three -- and have his customers (and perhaps even   investors) pay for it.When you look at things this way
column50: Musk's idea isn't nearly as   crazy as it sounds.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column51: it can pay to listen. After all
column52: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: This Week in Solar;12/23/2016;"The end of the year is usually quiet for most businesses
column2: but   for the solar industry it can be a time of big changes.   Legislation and regulatory changes are often pushed through just   before the end of the year
column3: which has had a huge impact on the   solar industry in years past.2016 is no different
column4: and there are some significant policy   changes taking place right now. But this time solar energy may be   coming out on top. Here's a look at those policy changes and some   other notable items from the week in solar energy.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.A record year for U.S. solarDespite solar stocks' performance on the market
column5: the industry   had a record year in 2016. The U.S. Energy Information   Administration (EIA) says that 9.5 GW of utility-scale solar will   be installed in the U.S. this year
column6: enough to power 1.5 million   homes. That tops 8.0 GW of new natural gas plants and 6.8 GW of   new wind power.If you add in distributed solar generation
column7: which the EIA   doesn't account for
column8: the figure jumps to 11.2 GW or 14 GW of DC   power generation
column9: according to GTM Research. The future is bright for solar energy
column10: and as the biggest   source of new power generation in the country
column11: it's finally a   power player in electricity generation.States can't figure out what to do with solarThe rooftop solar industry is very dependent on state and   regulator policies driving the economics of solar systems. Under   net metering
column12: customers only pay for their net energy usage
column13: meaning they're effectively ""paid"" the retail rate for energy   they export to the grid. Not surprisingly
column14: utilities have tried   to undercut that economic model in a variety of ways over the   last few years.This week
column15: Arizona undercut net metering by lowering the rate   customers are paid for electricity sent to the grid
column16: and cutting   down the amount of time rates are guaranteed. This reduces the   known payback of a solar system and could make it difficult to   justify rooftop solar.In Nevada
column17: the state that eliminated net metering a year ago   in a very punitive way to the solar industry
column18: the Public   Utilities Commission unanimously approved utility Sierra Pacific   Power's bid to restore net metering in the northern part of the   state. This is a big reversal in Nevada
column19: and may show that   regulators went too far in their ruling last year.Utilities in the southwestern U.S. are finding themselves in a   difficult position as the cost of rooftop solar falls and energy   storage becomes more viable. They're trying to undercut the   economics of solar
column20: but by doing so they're making solar plus   storage a viable option for self-consumption. It's no coincidence   that this is the yearTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) andSunrun(NASDAQ: RUN) introduced new or improved energy-storage products.   Utilities are having a hard time finding a balance between   fighting rooftop solar and fighting so hard they push customers   toward solar plus storage. And that conflict is playing out in   plain sight in Arizona and Nevada right now.News and notesHere are a few notable items from around the solar   industry.Trina Solar(NYSE: TSL) said this week that it hit a new efficiency record of   22.61% for a monocrystalline silicon PERC cell. Mono-PERC
column21: as   it's more commonly known
column22: is an up-and-coming technology that   will likely gain market share in the next few years
column23: so being in   a leadership position is good for the company.SunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR) said it completed a 20 MW power plant for the   Sulphur Springs Valley Electric Cooperative this week. The   project completion itself isn't surprising
column24: but buried in the   release is that 0.5 MW of the installation was the company's   Oasis 3.0 platform that was launched in September. Putting the   system in the ground will both give SunPower the chance to test   installing it
column25: and allow data to be collected from the project.   Since it is probably the company's most important product over   the next five years
column26: this is an important test site for the   company.Private company 8minutenergy Renewables also completed a 155   MW project that it says beats fossil-fuel prices and is the   lowest-cost solar power to date. The $58 per MWh it is charging   the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power for electricity   over a 30-year power purchase agreement is impressive
column27: and it's   just one example of low-cost solar in the U.S. New contracts are   going for less than $50 per MWh
column28: and 2017 could see prices below   $40 per MWh
column29: which would make solar energy lower-cost than fossil   fuels in most of the country.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

This increase comes only a couple of months after CEO Elon Musk stated that the company would not need to raise any additional capital or debt in the fourth quarter of 2016 (read more:Tesla Unlikely to Raise Capital in 2016 for Proposed Merger).However
